The test aims to measure the soundness of British banks against severe economic and financial shocks, including a global slowdown, sharp drop in inflation, and reduced appetite for risk. The test will assess banks' capital ratios, with a 4.5% common equity Tier 1 capital ratio and a 3% Tier 1 leverage ratio. The test will cover a range of scenarios, including a Chinese economic downturn and a sharp contraction in the British economy.

site_title: Keppel Corp fails to hit compulsory acquisition threshold for Keppel Land buyout
summary: Keppel Corp failed to meet the compulsory acquisition threshold for its buyout of Keppel Land, falling short by 0.4 percentage points. As a result, the offer price remains at S$4.38 per share, and remaining shareholders have the option to exit their shares at the same price. Keppel Land's shares will be suspended from trading, and the company will attempt to delist from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: India central bank relaxes foreign investment norms for exchange-traded FX derivatives
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) relaxed foreign investment norms for exchange-traded FX derivatives, allowing trading limits of up to US$15 million for USD/INR and US$5 million for Euro/INR, GBP/INR, and JPY/INR pairs. This move increases the trading limits for foreign portfolio investors and importers, enabling them to hedge up to 100% of their eligible limit. The RBI aims to promote market participation and stability.

site_title: EU airlines urged to avoid Yemen airspace
summary: European regulators, the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), have urged EU airlines to avoid Yemen's airspace due to ongoing air strikes. The US Federal Aviation Administration has also banned all overflights of Yemen by US airlines. The Saudi-led coalition's strikes aim to counter Iranian-backed rebels in Yemen. EASA has also advised European-operated jets to maintain a 24,000-foot altitude when crossing Sudan or South Sudan, where fighting continues.

site_title: Lend Lease's top bid in Paya Lebar honed by its Jurong experience
summary: Lend Lease's top bid for the Paya Lebar Central site in Singapore reached S$1.67 billion, or S$942.56 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), surpassing the next highest bid by 8.8%. The Australian group's experience at Jurong East, where it developed the Jem retail and office project, may have boosted its confidence in the site. The bid reflects a "very optimistic" view of the market, with experts noting the site's attractive location and limited strata office and retail units.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: S'pore rig owners have room to sink some more: KGI Fraser
summary: Singapore-listed rig and offshore support vessel owners' shares may sink further due to shaky long-term contracts, according to KGI Fraser. Their stocks are already trading at a 20% discount to book value, and could fall 10-30% more to reach valuations comparable to global peers. Analyst Joel Ng warns that these companies' seemingly secure contracts are turning uncertain, posing a risk to their already vulnerable shares.

site_title: Global equity issuance hits first-quarter record as stake sales jump
summary: Global equity issuance reached a record high in the first quarter, reaching US$231.5 billion, driven by a sharp increase in secondary share sales. Money raised from initial public offerings (IPOs) fell 20% to US$37.2 billion. Fewer companies came to market due to investors' reluctance to participate in high valuations. This marks a shift from 2014, when private equity funds had excess inventory to sell.

site_title: Hollande: All victims of Germanwings crash to be identified by end of week
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced that all 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps will be identified by the end of the week, thanks to DNA samples provided by the French interior minister.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande said on Tuesday that all 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps would be identified by the end of the week.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Creative Technology warns that its 2nd half revenue may be lower than target, with an operating loss similar to the 1st half. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, was previously a DBS veteran, and Helen Wong is set to retire as OCBC CEO. In other news, a Trafigura employee was detained in an Indonesia graft case, and MAS and PBOC are planning to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade.

site_title: BP terminates Gulf of Mexico rig contracts as low oil prices bite
summary: BP terminates contracts for two deepwater oil drilling rigs in the Gulf of Mexico due to low oil prices. The contracts were for rigs operated by Ensco and Seadrill Partners. BP confirmed the termination, citing its adjustment of capital expenditures in response to the new, lower oil price environment. The company cut its 2015 capex budget to $20 billion from $22.9 billion in 2014, aiming to underpin its long-term future in the US offshore industry.

images.alt_text: BP terminated contracts for two deepwater oil drilling rigs in the Gulf of Mexico as the British oil company slashes its exploration budget due to fallen oil prices.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target, with similar operating losses to H1. Meanwhile, Singapore's OCBC announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and named Tan Teck Long as her successor. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Singapore's MAS and PBOC also plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Additionally, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2.

site_title: US: Wall St off after rally, but quarter to show gain
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Tuesday, reversing the previous day's rally, but the S&P 500 remained on track for its ninth straight quarterly rise. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 81.88 points, the S&P 500 lost 9.36 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 19.58 points. Despite the decline, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: China to relax overseas investment rules for insurance funds - regulator
summary: China will relax its overseas investment rules for domestic insurance funds, allowing them to invest beyond Hong Kong. Insurance funds will also be able to buy bonds with a credit rating of BBB- and above. This move is aimed at encouraging foreign investment and diversifying China's insurance market. The changes will take effect, but no specific timeline was announced.

site_title: US home prices rise in January: S&P/Case-Shiller
summary: US single-family home prices rose 4.6% in January from a year earlier, exceeding economists' forecast of a 4.5% gain. The South and West led the increase, with Denver and Miami reporting the highest year-over-year gains of 8.4% and 8.3%, respectively. Low interest rates and strong consumer confidence continue to support further home price increases, according to S&P/Case-Shiller Chairman David Blitzer.

site_title: Swiss regulator says HSBC scandal "unsavoury" reminder of past
summary: Switzerland's bank regulator, FINMA, described HSBC's scandal as "unsavoury" and a reminder of the past, but praised the bank's efforts to clean itself up. The scandal involves allegations of enabling clients to conceal millions of dollars in assets, leading to investigations by US and French authorities. FINMA has imposed a three-year ban on HSBC acquiring clients in positions that could be abused to launder money, and the bank has reduced its client base by 70%. HSBC has acknowledged past failings and is working to improve compliance and control.

images.alt_text: Switzerland's bank regulator said on Tuesday that while the scandal surrounding HSBC's private Swiss bank was "unsavoury" the Geneva-based lender had been working hard to clean itself up.

site_title: Opec oil output hits highest since October on Iraq, Saudi
summary: OPEC oil supply has reached its highest level since October 2014, with 30.63 million barrels per day in March, driven by increased production from Iraq and Saudi Arabia. Iraq's exports rebounded after bad weather and Saudi Arabia pumped at close to record rates. Despite this, analysts believe the excess supply will continue to impact the market, with some signs of higher oil demand. OPEC's next meeting in June is expected to maintain its current policy, refusing to cut production targets.

site_title: Lend Lease top bidder for Paya Lebar Central site
summary: Lend Lease has emerged as the top bidder for a 99-year leasehold mixed-use site in Paya Lebar Central, offering S$1.67 billion (S$942.56 per square foot per plot ratio). The site, with a maximum GFA of 1.77 million square feet, must allocate nearly 55% for office use. Other bidders include Keppel Land, Cheung Kong Holdings/Hutchison Whampoa, and Ho Bee Land. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has limited the number of strata lots for each use category.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore bank lending is not mentioned in the article. Key events include Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. Asean agrees that Myanmar's election is not a priority, while South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Indonesia central bank revises rules on Jakarta interbank rate
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, revised rules on the Jakarta Interbank Offered Rate (JIBOR) to increase its use as a benchmark for pricing in derivatives markets. The new regulation, effective Wednesday, requires banks to set JIBOR rates based on their indicative offered and bid rates for unsecured loan transactions every morning. The central bank also cut the number of contributing banks to 21 from 30 and removed setting of a JIBOR rate for dollars. The goal is to make JIBOR a real benchmark, increasing its use and reducing the volatility of the rupiah.

site_title: Lufthansa cancels 60th anniversary event
summary: Lufthansa cancels its 60th anniversary event to honor victims of the Germanwings plane crash in France. The crash, which killed 150 people, occurred on March 24. Instead of hosting an anniversary event on April 15, Lufthansa will broadcast the official state memorial service at Cologne Cathedral on April 17. Investigators suspect the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, deliberately crashed the plane into the French Alps.

site_title: Japan company makes tear-free onions
summary: A Japanese company, House Foods Group, has developed tear-free onions by irradiating ions into the bulb, reducing the production of an enzyme that causes tear-inducing fumes when sliced. The process, which won the Ig Nobel Prize in 2013, has not yet been commercialized, with the company's spokesman stating no decision has been made on mass production. The goal is to make cooking with onions less irritating, potentially benefiting chefs and home cooks.

site_title: EU to ban owners from scrapping ships on South Asian beaches
summary: The European Union has introduced strict new rules requiring EU-registered ships to be recycled only at sustainable facilities, excluding South Asian beaches where the practice of shipbreaking has been criticized for its human and environmental costs. The rules aim to split the market into a safe and substandard market, benefiting recyclers in Europe, China, and North America. However, loopholes exist, and ship owners may still opt to change a ship's flag or sell it to a third party to avoid the new regime, potentially facing harsh criticism.

site_title: Flight bans hitting revenues, customers of Thailand-based airlines
summary: Thailand-based airlines face significant financial losses due to flight bans in Japan, China, and South Korea. Nearly 120,000 passengers are affected, with 77,000 impacted by the Japanese ban, leading to potential revenue losses of up to 400 million baht for NokScoot and 500 million baht for Thai AirAsiaX. The government vows to take action to lift the restrictions, with the European Aviation Safety Agency to inspect Thai operations to restore international confidence.

site_title: Global green energy investment climbs after two-year decline
summary: Global green energy investment surged to US$270.2 billion in 2014, a 16.6% increase from 2013, driven by a solar boom in China and Japan and record offshore wind investment in Europe. This marks a reversal of two years of declining investment, reaching 3% below an all-time high of US$279 in 2011. The surge was attributed to lower prices for renewable technologies.

site_title: No deal yet with Greece, talks ongoing, EU says
summary: Greece's talks with international creditors are ongoing, but no deal has been reached. The European Commission says constructive talks are happening, and a Eurogroup working group will discuss the matter at its next meeting. A call on Wednesday will allow them to "take stock of the debate." Meanwhile, other news includes Malaysia seizing RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Gold eyes 3rd quarterly loss as expected US rate hike drags
summary: Gold fell for a third consecutive quarter, pressured by a strong dollar and expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Spot gold dropped 0.5% to $1,179.61 an ounce, following a 3% decline since its three-week high above $1,200 an ounce. The dollar is on track for its best quarter since 2008, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies and eroding its appeal. A potential US rate hike could further reduce demand for gold.

site_title: Thai junta to replace martial law but retain key powers
summary: Thailand's junta chief, Prayut Chan-O-Cha, announced plans to lift martial law, replacing it with special security measures after receiving King Bhumibol Adulyadej's permission. The move retains key powers for the military, sparking criticism that it will "deepen dictatorship." The martial law was imposed in May following the ousting of Yingluck Shinawatra's government and the imposition of martial law was a response to violent street protests. The new order is expected to maintain military control, despite concerns over the erosion of democratic institutions.

site_title: PetroChina to cut 2015 crude output by 1.5 per cent to 1.6 per cent - source
summary: China's state-owned PetroChina plans to cut 2015 crude output by 1.5-1.6% from last year due to low oil prices. The move is aimed at prop up prices, following a 1.4% increase in 2014. PetroChina's main domestic rival, Sinopec, has also forecast a 3.5% reduction in domestic crude output. Analysts say this is a common practice among producers to balance supply and demand.

site_title: Bad memories: Private equity funds go slow in India
summary: Private equity investors are slowing down in India due to soaring valuations, with 76 investments made this year, a decline from the previous two years. This slowdown contrasts with the optimism in India's financial markets, where foreign institutional buying has pushed share prices to a record. Sellers are demanding higher premiums for private equity deals, making it challenging for investors to exit expensive investments made before the 2008 global crisis. The slowdown may impact the Indian economy, which is still recovering from the crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close 0.18% higher
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.18% to 24,900.89, driven by China's central bank easing mortgage rules to boost the mainland property market. However, Shanghai's Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.02% after a recent surge, sending it to a seven-year high. The gains in Hong Kong were partly offset by losses in mainland China.

site_title: Eurozone deflation eases, unemployment drops: Eurostat
summary: The eurozone experienced a slowdown in deflation, with prices dropping 0.1% in March, less than the 0.3% decline in February. Unemployment rates also decreased to 11.3% in February, down from 11.4% in January and 11.8% in the previous year. These improvements ease concerns about a potential economic spiral, with low energy costs still affecting consumer prices.

images.alt_text: Deflation in the eurozone persisted in March but the rate of decline slowed, official data showed Tuesday, further easing concerns that the economy faces a dangerous spiral of falling consumer prices.

site_title: Jetstar Asia makes changes to cockpit protocol
summary: Jetstar Asia has implemented a new cockpit protocol following the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash, requiring two authorized operating crew members to be present at all times during flights. An operating crew member will enter the cockpit before a pilot leaves for any reason, ensuring the safety and security of passengers and crew. This change aims to enhance safety measures and prevent similar incidents.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Budget carrier Jetstar Asia will have two authorised operating crew in the cockpit at all times in-flight, following consultation with local regulators, it said.

site_title: German unemployment at new post-unification low: data
summary: Germany's unemployment rate fell to 6.4% in March, the lowest level since reunification in 1990, with 2.798 million people registered as unemployed. This decline is attributed to the country's strong economic recovery, which has been fueled by consumer spending, exports, and construction investment. The labor market is expected to continue pointing upwards, with favorable developments in 2015.

images.alt_text: German unemployment fell in March to the lowest level since the country reunited in 1990 as growth in Europe's biggest economy continues to pick up, official data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.95 points to close at 1,830.78, driven by a 2.15 billion lots traded worth RM2.46 billion. The market saw 417 gains and 410 losses.

site_title: Turkey grinds to halt after massive power outage
summary: A massive power outage hit Turkey, affecting almost all provinces, with the government investigating an outside attack on the system. The outage, the worst in 15 years, began in Istanbul at 10:36 am and caused chaos, trapping people in elevators and disrupting transportation. Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said every possibility, including a cyber-attack, was being investigated. The energy ministry established a crisis desk and the grid operator attributed the outage to a severing of power lines between Europe, which could take hours to restore.

images.alt_text: A massive power cut caused chaos Tuesday across Turkey, shutting down the metro networks in Istanbul and the capital Ankara, with the government saying an outside attack on the system was not ruled out.

site_title: US small-business borrowing slips in February, up on year: PayNet
summary: US small businesses borrowed fewer loans in February, with the Thomson Reuters/PayNet Small Business Lending Index falling to 119.2. However, borrowing is up 7% from February 2014, indicating a steadily improving sector. The index measures borrowing by firms with US$1 million or less in outstanding debt.

site_title: South-east Asian borrowers wince as deflation looms
summary: Southeast Asian economies are facing growing debt burdens due to deflation, with loans to businesses and households at their slowest pace in five years. In Singapore and Thailand, bank loans grew at 3.26% and below the rates seen after the 2008 global crisis, respectively. Despite this, outstanding loans remain high, equal to at least twice the size of their gross domestic product. Central bankers are in a quandary, reluctant to lower interest rates due to high debt, but without lower rates, their economies risk deflation and rising debt.

site_title: Taiwan to raise daily price limit for stocks to 10% from 7%
summary: Taiwan will increase the daily price limit for individual stocks to 10% from 7% as of June 1, according to the Financial Supervisory Commission. The decision was made earlier than expected due to system testing completion. This change aims to increase market liquidity and investor confidence.

site_title: Singapore: STI ends weaker on the day, up 2.4% for the quarter
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended 7.25 points weaker at 3,447.01 on the final trading day of the first quarter, despite a 2.4% gain for the quarter. Trading was relatively quiet, with 1.4 billion units worth S$1.4 billion in turnover. The day's most active stock was Sino Construction, which rose 34.3% after announcing a placement of new shares. The market's uneventful session may be attributed to investors still in mourning for former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Beijing rebuffs Taiwan's infrastructure bank application
summary: China has rebuffed Taiwan's application to join the Beijing-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), citing its "One China" policy. Taiwan plans to submit a letter of intent to the AIIB preparatory committee, despite China's opposition. The move comes as more than 40 countries, including Britain and Germany, have expressed interest in joining the $50 billion bank. China has welcomed all countries to join, but has consistently curtailed Taiwan's involvement in international agreements due to its disputed status as part of China.

site_title: China to introduce bank deposit insurance from May: sources
summary: China is set to introduce a bank deposit insurance system starting from May, according to sources. The system will be managed by the central bank and will require banks to pay into a fund to finance the protection of depositors. This move is seen as a crucial step towards full liberalisation of the country's interest rates market and greater competition between banks, a vital step in financial reform.

site_title: Search teams use new road to reach Germanwings crash site
summary: Search teams in the French Alps have resumed their investigation into the Germanwings plane crash, using a newly built road to access the remote crash site. The road, built in 48 hours, allows teams to work faster and retrieve more debris and body parts, with over 4,000 items already removed. The search is expected to finish by April 8, after which a civilian clean-up group will tidy up the site. Authorities believe co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane, and are investigating his background for a possible motive, with the second "black box" recorder still unaccounted for.

site_title: Insurers set aside US$300m in provisions for Germanwings crash: Lufthansa
summary: Germanwings' parent company Lufthansa says insurers are setting aside US$300 million in provisions for the crash that killed 150 people in the French Alps. The sum covers financial compensation for families and the cost of the Airbus A320 jet itself, with Allianz leading the consortium of insurers. The current list price of the jet is US$93.9 million. Germanwings had already announced it would compensate each family with 50,000 euros, which would not be deducted from any final compensation deal.

site_title: Thai junta chief says he has asked king to lift martial law
summary: Thai junta chief Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha announced that he has asked King Bhumibol Adulyadej to lift martial law, which was imposed in 2014. A new executive order will replace martial law, and the king's approval is required to lift it. This move comes after nearly a year of martial law, which has been a contentious issue in Thailand.

site_title: Broker's Take: DBS downgrades Super Group to "hold", prefers Oldtown Bhd
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Super Group to "hold" from "buy" with a revised 12-month target price of S$1.46, citing lower coffee prices and improved global supply. The analysts raised gross margin assumptions for FY2015 and FY2016, resulting in 11% and 9% increases to estimated earnings. As a result, they recommend switching to Oldtown Bhd as their preferred coffee play.

site_title: Six new members appointed to IPOS board
summary: The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) has appointed six new members to its board, effective April 1, 2015, including Tsui Kai Chong, Lim Kuo-Yi, and Tan Min-Liang. The appointments include the re-appointment of Stanley Lai as chairman. Four current board members, Jacqueline Poh, Freddy Boey, Guy Proulx, and Kevin Theseira, will step down on March 31, 2015. The new members will join the existing board members, including six re-appointed members, to continue overseeing intellectual property matters in Singapore.

site_title: Citi to sell Japan credit card unit to Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank
summary: Citigroup has agreed to sell its Japanese credit card unit, Citi Cards Japan, to Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank for an undisclosed price, reportedly around 40 billion yen. The deal is part of Citigroup's plan to slim down globally and bolster profitability. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the year, following Citigroup's previous announcement of selling its Japanese retail banking operations to Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp.

images.alt_text: Citigroup Inc has agreed to sell its credit card unit in Japan to Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank, the companies said on Tuesday, as the US bank slims down globally to bolster its profitability.

site_title: URA awards tender for Sturdee Road residential site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has awarded the tender for the Sturdee Road residential site to SL Capital (1) Pte Ltd with a bid of S$181.19 million. The site, covering 6,111.5 square metres, will be sold on a 99-year lease term. The maximum gross floor area is 21,391 square metres, with a tendered price of S$8,470.34 per square metre. The tender closed on March 24 after being launched on February 10.

site_title: Tigerair to launch Singapore-Ipoh flights from May 29
summary: Tigerair announced it will launch four-times weekly flights from Singapore to Ipoh on May 29, becoming the first and only Singapore carrier to operate jet flights in Ipoh. The Airbus 320 aircraft will carry about 1,440 passengers per week. Tickets will go on sale from April 20. This addition will help meet demand for leisure and business travel between Singapore and Malaysia, marking Tigerair's fourth Malaysian destination.

site_title: Thai household debt rises to record 85.9% of GDP at end-2014: central bank
summary: Thailand's household debt reached a record 85.9% of GDP at the end of 2014, totaling 10.43 trillion baht. The economy grew only 0.7% in 2014, with consumption crimped by high debt levels. However, a senior Bank of Thailand official noted that the pace of debt increases has slowed, and interest rates may be easing, leading to reduced debt burdens.

site_title: Oil extends losses as deadline for Iran nuclear deal looms
summary: Oil futures extended losses on Tuesday as Iran and six world powers neared a deadline to reach a preliminary deal on easing sanctions and allowing more Iranian crude onto world markets. Brent oil fell 72 cents to $55.57 a barrel, while US crude dropped 84 cents to $47.84 a barrel. Iran is believed to have stored at least 30 million barrels of oil, and analysts predict it could increase exports if sanctions are lifted.

site_title: UK growth revised higher at end of 2014, boosted by exports
summary: Britain's economy expanded at a faster pace than initially estimated at the end of 2014, driven by strong exports. The Office for National Statistics reported a quarterly 0.6% growth in GDP from October to December, up from a previous reading of 0.5%. This revised estimate puts the overall economy's growth at 2.8% for 2014, the largest expansion since 2006. The stronger-than-expected growth suggests a more robust economic recovery.

site_title: Head of The Edge media group arrested by Malaysian police
summary: Malaysian police arrested Ho Kay Tat, head of The Edge media group, and Jahabar Sadiq, chief editor of The Malaysian Insider, on sedition charges. The arrests follow a series of detentions of opposition figures, academics, and activists amid a crackdown on freedom of expression and civil liberties. The detentions are part of a mounting tally of arrests sparked by the February jailing of opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. The Edge has also faced government anger for reporting on a government-owned investment company's murky dealings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 1.05% on last day of Japanese financial year
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.05% on the last day of the Japanese financial year, erasing early gains. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,206.99, down 204.41 points, after a 10% gain over the quarter. Profit-taking was the main driver of the decline.

site_title: Taiwan to apply to join China-backed AIIB investment bank
summary: Taiwan plans to submit an application to join the Beijing-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), despite historical animosity and lack of formal diplomatic relations with China. This move makes Taiwan the latest country to express interest in joining the bank. The application's acceptance is uncertain, with Beijing's response yet to be determined.

site_title: Consumers able to compare life insurance products online from April 7 (Amended)
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore will launch a web portal, compareFIRST, on April 7, allowing consumers to compare over 200 life insurance products online. The portal will feature four classes of products: term life insurance, whole life insurance, endowment policies, and direct purchase insurance (DPI). Consumers will be able to compare up to four products at a time, with information on premiums, features, and insurer credit ratings. Twelve life insurance companies will also start selling DPI without commissions and financial advice on the same day. The move aims to empower consumers to make informed decisions.

site_title: Rhodes scholarships open up to Chinese students
summary: The Rhodes Scholarships, founded in 1903, are expanding to include Chinese students, starting with the first selection this year and entry in 2016. The scholarships, initially restricted to students from formerly British-ruled territories, will be funded by donations from Hong Kong businessman Li Ka-Shing's foundation. The move aims to reflect China's growing international role, but raises questions over academic freedom in the country, given Beijing's control over the education system and restrictions on university textbooks promoting "Western values".

site_title: Tampines Industrial Drive site up for sale by public tender
summary: JTC Corporation is offering a 0.57-hectare site at Tampines Industrial Drive for sale by public tender under the 1st half 2015 industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme. The site, zoned for Business-2 development, has a 20-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4. The tender closes on May 26, 2015.

site_title: Parts of Singapore's taxi fare structure to be standardised from H2 '15
summary: Singapore's taxi fare structure will be standardized from the second half of 2015, except for the flag-down fare, to simplify the fare system. The Public Transport Council (PTC) and Land Transport Authority (LTA) will standardize unit fares, surcharges, booking fees, and additional passenger fees. Taxi companies have expressed concerns that standardizing flag-down fares would lead to higher fares, while drivers prefer a level increase. The changes aim to prevent complex fare structures in the future.

site_title: Seoul: Shares up, on track for best quarter since Q3
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.2% to 2,033.36 on Tuesday, on track for their best quarterly gain since Q3 2013. The 6.2% quarterly increase puts the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) on pace for its best month since July 2014. The rally was driven by a rise on Wall Street and steps by China to shore up its economy, boosting risk appetite and demand for securities companies.

site_title: China's Q4 2014 current account surplus was US$67b
summary: China reported a Q4 2014 current account surplus of US$67 billion, with a US$30.5 billion deficit on its capital and financial account. This brings China's total 2014 current account surplus to US$219.7 billion. Preliminary data had shown a US$61.1 billion surplus in Q4.

site_title: IBM to invest US$3b in 'Internet of Things' unit
summary: IBM is investing $3 billion over four years in its 'Internet of Things' unit, aiming to sell its expertise in gathering and making sense of real-time data. The unit will offer cloud-based services to help companies utilize data from various sources, such as building sensors and smartphones. IBM's first major partnership will be with The Weather Co, which will move its weather data services onto IBM's cloud for enhanced analytics capabilities. This move aims to leverage the growing trend of IoT data and provide companies with tools to make sense of the increasing amounts of data.

site_title: Four new members appointed to URA board
summary: Four new members have been appointed to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) board, effective April 1, 2015. The new members are Khew Sin Khoon, Chew Men Leong, Brenda Yeoh Saw Ai, and Cheong Wei Yang. The chairman, Peter Ho Hak Ean, will be reappointed, along with eight others. The appointments, which include a three-year term until March 31, 2018, will replace three outgoing members.

site_title: Malaysian arrests of website editors draws flak
summary: Malaysian authorities arrested three editors of The Malaysian Insider over a disputed report on the rejection of opposition party's proposal to amend federal law on sharia punishments. The editors, suspected of sedition, spent the night in jail, sparking criticism from Malaysian press groups, who describe the move as a "worrying trend" of declining press-freedom standards. The incident has raised concerns about the government's treatment of independent media outlets.

site_title: Tsipras seeks 'honest compromise' as Greece wrangles with creditors
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is seeking an "honest compromise" with eurozone creditors to unlock 7.2-billion euros in bailout funds. The IMF and EU are reviewing a proposed list of reforms that would raise an extra three billion euros for Greece's coffers without wage and pension cuts. The Greek government claims the reforms will help stabilize the country's finances, but creditors are demanding stricter austerity measures. A compromise is needed to unlock the bailout funds, which are crucial for Greece's economic recovery.

site_title: AVA to appoint six new board members
summary: The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) will appoint six new board members, effective April 1, 2015, including Dr. Tang Kong Choong, Chua Mui Hoong, and Professor David Chan. Lim Neo Chian will be appointed as the board's deputy chairman. Five current members will step down, while Chairman Koh Soo Keong will be re-appointed. The new appointments and re-appointments aim to enhance the authority's governance and oversight.

site_title: Europe: Shares up, head for best quarter in years
summary: European shares rose, heading for their best quarterly performance in years, driven by the European Central Bank's bond buying program and improving economic outlook. Kingfisher's plan to sell 60 B&Q stores boosted the home improvement retailer's shares, while the FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.2% to 1,599.48 points. Germany's DAX index rose 23% this year, its best quarter since 2003, but fell 0.2% on Tuesday due to a decline in retail sales.

images.alt_text: European shares edged higher in early trading on Tuesday and headed for their best quarterly performance in several years, with Kingfisher leading the market higher following its plans to sell about 60 B&Q stores in Britain.

site_title: Beijing to limit motorists on heavily polluted days
summary: Beijing has introduced measures to limit motorists on heavily polluted days, with the city announcing "red alert" forecasts of heavy pollution when the air quality index tops 200. Motorists will be limited to driving on alternate days, and heavy vehicles will be banned during orange or red alerts. The move comes as China's capital struggles with choking smog, with lung cancer rates rising among residents. The US embassy has reported unhealthy air quality, and environmental awareness is increasing in China, with a national debate sparked by a documentary about pollution.

site_title: Struggling China developer Kaisa says won't report 2014 results on Tuesday
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, will not report its 2014 results as scheduled due to an assessment of its cash flow. The company has been struggling since local authorities blocked sales of some projects last year and is negotiating with bondholders on restructuring its $2.5 billion debt. Kaisa's debt woes highlight the risks faced by Chinese developers in the slumping property sector, which has been hit by the slowing economy and cooling measures. Trading in its shares has been suspended.

site_title: MDIS acquires Service Quality Centre
summary: MDIS Corporation, a subsidiary of the Management Development Institute of Singapore, has acquired Service Quality Centre (SQC) for an undisclosed sum. Established in 1990, SQC provides training solutions on service excellence, quality, and productivity. The acquisition diversifies MDIS's offerings and allows it to house SQC and its corporate training arm, MDC, under one roof. MDIS plans to invest S$1.2 million in renovating its Dhoby Ghaut campus to accommodate the new unit.

images.alt_text: MDIS Corporation, a subsidiary of the Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS), has acquired Service Quality Centre (SQC) for an undisclosed sum.

site_title: Japan denies plan to join China-led development bank
summary: Japan denies plans to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), contradicting a report that its ambassador to China said Tokyo would likely participate within a few months. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that the ambassador's comments were false and Japan's position on the AIIB remains unchanged. Japan is hesitant due to concerns about governance and potential damage to other creditors, and will work with the US and other countries to ask China for clarification on the bank's governance.

images.alt_text: Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said Tuesday the ambassador had not made any such comment and Japan's position on the AIIB had not changed.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai shares rose in opening trade on Tuesday, driven by hopes for further Chinese stimulus measures. The Hang Seng Index increased 1.04% to 25,113.20, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.96% to 3,822.99. This comes after China's central bank eased mortgage rules to support the property market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.29 points to 1,830.12. Gainers outnumbered losers 215 to 76, with a trading volume of 100.56 million lots worth RM74.1 million.

site_title: Philips to sell major stake in LED, car lighting arm for US$2.8b: statement
summary: Dutch electronics giant Philips has agreed to sell a majority stake in its LED and car lighting arm to a consortium led by China-based GO Scale Capital for US$2.8 billion. The deal, which is worth 80.1% of the business, is expected to generate approximately US$2.8 billion in cash proceeds for Philips. The sale is part of Philips' efforts to focus on core businesses and simplify its portfolio.

site_title: BlackRock clarifies it has accepted Keppel Corp's offer
summary: BlackRock has clarified that its sale of 37.3 million Keppel Land shares at S$4.38 on March 26 represents its acceptance of Keppel Corp's offer. This sale marks the end of BlackRock's ownership in Keppel Land, as it no longer holds any shares. The move comes after BlackRock disclosed a 5% stake in Keppel Corp, making it an associate of the company.

images.alt_text: Blackrock on Tuesday clarified in a filing to the Singapore Exchange that its sale of 37,333,850 Keppel Land shares on March 26 (which it disclosed a day later on March 27) "represents BlackRock's acceptance of the offer".

site_title: Workplace Safety and Health Council names two new members
summary: The Workplace Safety and Health Council has appointed two new members, Tan Puay Hin and Zee Yoong Kang, to serve on the council for a two-year term starting April 1. Tan will take over as chairman of the Logistics and Transport Committee, while Zee will serve as deputy chairman of the Workplace Health Committee. The council, which comprises 19 members, also re-appointed five current members, including WSH Council chairman Lee Tzu Yang, who also chairs The Esplanade Co.

site_title: China: Stocks bolt to fresh 7-year highs as Beijing eases property curbs
summary: China's stocks rose to fresh seven-year highs on March 31, led by property and banking stocks, after Beijing eased mortgage lending policies to bolster the struggling real estate market. The CSI300 index rose 0.9% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.3%. The People's Bank of China lowered the minimum downpayment requirement for second homes to 40% from 60%, and individuals selling ordinary houses were exempt from business taxes if owned for over two years. Analysts expect limited stimulus from the policies, but see them as accelerating money flow into stocks.

site_title: Tokyo bourse operator to strengthen screening measures: sources
summary: Tokyo Exchange Group Inc plans to strengthen screening measures for companies seeking to go public, including requiring firms to disclose earnings projections at the time of an initial public offering (IPO). This move comes after mobile game developer Gumi Inc issued a loss warning and cut its workforce shortly after raising hundreds of millions of dollars in a stock market listing, raising concerns about accounting and internal control issues. The new measures aim to prevent similar incidents and ensure greater transparency and accountability in the IPO process.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.93% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.93% higher on Tuesday, driven by a weaker yen and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 181.03 points to 19,592.43, amid speculation of more monetary stimulus in China.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on broad-based gains
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% on Tuesday, rebounding from a steep sell-off, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street and hopes for further economic stimulus in China. China announced steps to ease housing taxes and lending rules to prop up its sliding housing market. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 82 points to 5,928.1, its highest close since March 18. China is Australia's No. 1 trading partner, and the announcement is expected to boost economic ties.

site_title: Singapore's liquor control law to come into force on April 1
summary: Singapore's Liquor Control (Supply and Consumption) Act will come into force on April 1, regulating the supply and consumption of liquor in public places. The law aims to minimize public disorder and disamenities, restricting liquor consumption from 10.30pm to 7am daily and imposing additional restrictions in designated zones. Offenders will face penalties, including increased fines. The Act also limits the supply of liquor, with retail sales not allowed from 10.30pm to 7am daily, except in licensed premises.

site_title: Dutch seek BUK missile witnesses in MH17 crash probe
summary: Dutch authorities are seeking witnesses who may have seen the transport or firing of a BUK surface-to-air missile in eastern Ukraine around the time of the MH17 plane crash, which killed 298 people, mostly Dutch, in July 2014. Investigators are looking at all scenarios, including the possibility that the plane was shot down, and have released a video showing images of a lowbed truck transporting a BUK missile system and recorded phone calls between separatists referring to the system. The request for witnesses comes as the Netherlands leads the investigation into the cause of the incident.

images.alt_text: Dutch and international experts probing the MH17 plane crash in eastern Ukraine appealed Monday for witnesses who saw the transport or firing of a BUK surface-to-air missile around the time of the disaster.

site_title: Jay Z leads stars in rebranded Tidal streaming service
summary: Jay Z's Tidal streaming service launched on Monday, backed by artists such as Beyonce, Cold Play's Chris Martin, and Rihanna. The service, which aims to compensate artists fairly, offers high-fidelity music for $19.99/month, with deals for rights with major record labels. The launch comes as digital music downloads continue to shrink, with musicians complaining of low pay for streaming rights. Tidal's launch follows Taylor Swift's decision to remove her music from Spotify, and the service is available in 35 countries.

site_title: Australia new home sales rise 1.1% in February
summary: Australia's new home sales rose 1.1% in February, driven by a 11.1% increase in multi-unit sales. Detached home sales slipped 1.3%. The Housing Industry Association (HIA) predicts further upward momentum for multi-unit construction in 2015, with detached house building at above-average volumes.

site_title: HDB households to receive S$45m worth of GST Voucher - U-Save in April
summary: Singaporean households with HDB flats will receive a total of S$45 million worth of GST Voucher - Utilities-Save (U-Save) rebates in April. Eligible households will each receive a rebate of up to S$65, depending on their flat type. The rebate is part of the permanent GST Voucher scheme, designed to help lower- and middle-income households with living expenses. The U-Save component is distributed quarterly.

images.alt_text: MORE than 800,000 Singaporean HDB households will receive S$45 million worth of GST Voucher - Utilities-Save (U-Save) rebate in April, the Ministry of Finance said on Tuesday.

site_title: Jamie Oliver regrets heating up Gordon Ramsay food feud
summary: Celebrity chefs Jamie Oliver and Gordon Ramsay have a long-standing feud, with Oliver recently saying Ramsay was jealous of his success. However, Oliver has since regretted his comments, stating they were "no big deal" and he wishes he hadn't said anything. Oliver expressed concern that his remarks could upset Ramsay's children, but left the door open for reconciliation, saying they might be friends again someday. Despite their past barbs, both chefs have maintained that their rivalry is "friendly banter."

site_title: Japan still 'very cautious' about joining AIIB
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso stated the country remains "very cautious" about joining the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), missing the March 31 deadline for application. Aso cited concerns over governance, debt sustainability, and environmental and social safeguards. This decision comes as Sweden and Egypt have expressed plans to join the AIIB, enhancing China's regional and global influence.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Tuesday that Japan remains "very cautious" about joining the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), indicating that Tokyo will miss the March 31 deadline for application.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound as tech shares turn higher
summary: European stocks rebounded on Monday, driven by tech shares rallying after merger talks in the industry. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 1.2% to near a 7-1/2 year high, while Germany's DAX rose 1.8% to a record high. Tech shares such as Infineon, STMicroelectronics, and ASML surged 4.2%, 3.6%, and 2.9% respectively. Corporate deals and economic stimulus measures from the European Central Bank contributed to the gains. Greece's ATG index underperformed, while shares in Lafarge and World Duty Free fell 1.9% and 8.4% respectively.

site_title: Iran, powers rush for nuclear deal as clock ticks toward deadline
summary: Iran and six world powers accelerated nuclear negotiations ahead of a Thursday deadline for a preliminary deal, amid concerns that disagreements over enrichment research and sanctions could scuttle the agreement. The US, Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and China have been working to ease international sanctions on Iran in exchange for limiting its nuclear capabilities. A 12-year standoff between Iran and the West over nuclear ambitions is at risk of being resolved, but time is running out for a breakthrough. The fate of the deal remains uncertain as both sides warn of the consequences of failure.

site_title: NUS names 3 new members to board of trustees
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has appointed three new members to its board of trustees, effective April 1. They are Goh Choon Phong, CEO of Singapore Airlines; Chaly Mah Chee Kheong, CEO of Deloitte Asia Pacific; and Ng Wai King, joint managing partner of WongPartnership. The new additions bring diverse perspectives and knowledge to the 24-member board, chaired by Wong Ngit Liong, with the aim of enhancing NUS's global reputation and standing.

site_title: Kuroda bond-buying stimulus nearing limit as market shrinks
summary: Japan's central bank, the BOJ, is nearing its limit on quantitative easing stimulus as the bond market shrinks. The BOJ holds 255.8 trillion yen of Japanese government bonds, but sellers are running short of debt to offer to the central bank. This may lead to undersubscriptions as early as March 2016 if policy makers expand existing stimulus. The BOJ's buying pace is equivalent to 90% of notes offered to investors, and its holdings could exceed 50% of outstanding JGBs by fiscal 2017.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CCFH, Sino Construction, IPC, KepCorp, A-Reit
summary: Singaporean stocks to watch include CCFH, which plans to diversify into fund management and solar plants, and Sino Construction, whose share price rose 20.7% after raising S$6.5 million through a share placement. IPC Corporation is in talks to sell its seven hotels in Japan for S$150 million. Keppel Corp's shareholding in Keppel Land reached 93.9% and A-Reit acquired The Kendall at 50 Science Park Road for S$112 million.

site_title: Singapore's STI opens 0.35% higher, tracing gains in US, Europe
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.35% higher on March 31, 2015, following rebounds in US and European markets. Top gainers included Jardine C&C, DBS, and Keppel Corp. Trading volume reached 110.2 million shares worth S$274.3 million.

site_title: Bank lending dips in February, dragged by weaker business loans: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore declined 0.6% in February to S$604 billion, mainly due to a contraction in business loans for the third straight month. Business loans fell 1% to S$366 billion, while consumer lending remained flat at S$237 billion. Year-on-year, bank lending grew 3.3%, weaker than the 4.3% gain in January.

images.alt_text: Bank lending in February fell from a month ago, dragged by a contraction in business loans for the third straight month.

site_title: Macquarie cutting Asia banking jobs as deals fizzle
summary: Macquarie Group plans to cut about half of its investment-banking jobs in Asia, approximately 80-90 positions, due to a slump in deals and revenue. The move follows a strategy shift by CEO Nicholas Moore to focus on more stable businesses. This is part of a trend among global competitors, including Goldman Sachs and Standard Chartered, which have also reduced jobs in Asia. Macquarie's Asian retreat is expected to occur across Hong Kong, Singapore, Korea, India, and Japan, excluding Australia.

site_title: US, Japan have "significant gaps" on auto market access: US official
summary: US Acting Deputy Trade Representative Wendy Cutler stated that significant gaps remain between the US and Japan regarding auto market access for US automobiles in Japan, despite Japan having zero tariffs. The issue of non-tariff barriers and limited access to the Japanese market is a major sticking point. Cutler also mentioned that the US and Japan are working on bilateral trade talks, including access for US agricultural products, which is a critical sticking point. The Trans-Pacific Partnership negotiations are expected to wrap up by mid-year.

site_title: Asia: Stocks head for best quarter since 2012; oil extends slump
summary: Asian stocks are poised for their best quarterly advance since 2012, driven by optimism over global economic stimulus. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose 0.5% and is set for a 6.8% gain over the past three months. The US dollar maintained gains, while crude oil extended losses, with oil prices falling 0.9% and gold holding two days of declines. Central banks in Europe and Asia are bolstering stimulus to address slowing growth, with China announcing measures to stem a property slump.

site_title: Thailand admits 'urgent' need to improve aviation safety
summary: Thai authorities have admitted an "urgent" need to improve aviation safety following concerns raised by the UN's International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO). The ICAO reported "significant safety concerns" after an audit in 2014, prompting Japan to block new international flights from Thailand. Thai authorities plan to use special powers under junta rule to expedite safety improvements, including new training for staff and increased airline inspections. Several airlines, including Thai Airways and Nok Air, may also face potential bans on new flights from Seoul and Beijing.

site_title: AIG's Hancock expects more asset sales
summary: American International Group (AIG) CEO Peter Hancock plans to sell more businesses that don't align with the insurer's core operations, focusing on maximizing intrinsic value rather than market share. Hancock aims to avoid excessive risk and shift the company's strategy from blindly pursuing sales volume. This move follows Hancock's predecessor, Robert Benmosche, who sold assets and cut jobs to repay a $182.3 billion government bailout. AIG Chairman Steve Miller is set to step down this year, and Hancock was paid $12.06 million for 2014.

site_title: White House sends Congress US$478b 6-year transportation bill
summary: The White House has sent a $478 billion, six-year transportation bill to Congress, which is expected to face significant competition from other bills. The bill aims to bolster the Highway Trust Fund by taxing offshore corporate funds, increasing funding by nearly $25 billion per year. It also boosts transit funding by 79% and highway funding by 29%. The bill's fate is uncertain, with a May 31 deadline looming and the possibility of a short-term extension or a gas tax increase.

site_title: Facebook moves into 'not fancy' new headquarters
summary: Facebook has moved into its new Frank Gehry-designed headquarters in Menlo Park, California, with a rooftop park and the largest open floor plan in the world. The building is intentionally "not fancy" according to Mark Zuckerberg, who wants the space to feel like a work in progress. The goal is to create the "perfect engineering space" for Facebook's teams, with plenty of small spaces for collaboration and movement. The building is designed to foster innovation and connection, reflecting Facebook's mission to connect the world.

site_title: UK consumer confidence hits 12-year high in March: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence reached a 12-year high in March, with a +4 index, surpassing forecasts. The upward trend is seen as a boost to Prime Minister David Cameron's re-election hopes. Despite strong economic growth, Labour Party leader Ed Miliband argues that most households remain poorer due to high inflation and weak pay growth. A separate survey shows Britons are more optimistic about their financial situation improving in 12 months. This contrasts with the UK economy shrinking for the second month, a fresh blow to Labour leader Keir Starmer.

site_title: South Korea's February factory output rebounds more than expected
summary: South Korea's industrial output in February rebounded 2.6% from the previous month, surpassing expectations and easing economic concerns. The automotive and semiconductor sectors drove the recovery, with service sector output also rising 1.6% on a seasonally adjusted basis. However, on a year-over-year basis, industrial output declined 4.7%, missing forecasts of a 1.5% decline. This rebound helps alleviate some of the economic concerns, but the overall trend remains a concern.

site_title: Petrobras starts gas production in field off Louisiana
summary: Petrobras has started gas production from two wells in the Hadrian South field off the coast of Louisiana. The field, 370km off Louisiana, has 23.3% ownership by Petrobras, 46.7% by Exxon Mobil, and 30% by Eni SpA. The wells, at a depth of 2,332 meters, are connected to a platform processing 8.5 million cubic meters of natural gas per day.

site_title: China suspends bank tech restrictions
summary: China has agreed to delay implementing new bank technology restrictions, which were part of a set of regulations requiring foreign companies to hand over encryption keys and facilitate Beijing's ability to bypass security measures. The decision was made after US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew met with senior Chinese officials, including Premier Li Keqiang. The regulations were seen as unfair pressure on foreign firms, with US industry groups welcoming the delay and calling for a transparent consultation process. The move is seen as a positive development for US companies operating in China.

site_title: SpaceX to buy US$90m in SolarCity Solar bonds
summary: Elon Musk's SpaceX has agreed to buy $90 million in SolarCity Corp bonds, which are tied to payments from rooftop solar power systems. The bonds, offering a 2% interest rate, represent almost all of the $93 million in one-year bonds SolarCity is offering. Musk is SolarCity's chairman and largest shareholder. This move may be seen as a strategic investment in SolarCity, given Musk's involvement with the solar developer.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk's Space Exploration Technology Corp agreed to buy US$90 million in SolarCity Corp bonds tied to payments from rooftop solar power systems.

site_title: Cameron meets the Queen, starts knife-edge election campaign
summary: Britain's Prime Minister David Cameron met Queen Elizabeth to inform her of parliament's dissolution, marking the start of a closely contested election. The election, scheduled for May 7, is expected to result in no party winning an outright majority, potentially leading to a minority government or a formal coalition. Cameron and Labour leader Ed Miliband will engage in a seven-way TV debate, with key issues including the economy, immigration, and EU membership. Polls indicate a tight race, with the outcome uncertain, and the fate of Scotland's relationship with the UK hangs in the balance.

images.alt_text: "You can choose an economy that grows . . . or you can choose the economic chaos of Ed Miliband," said Mr Cameron.

site_title: Abbott opens US$24m nutrition R&D plant
summary: Abbott, a global healthcare firm, has opened its first nutrition pilot plant in Singapore, a $24 million investment that will serve as the company's second R&D hub outside the US. The plant, which can carry out R&D and manufacturing, will enable Abbott to respond to changing healthcare needs in Asia and incorporate local flavors. The company plans to ramp up staff strength for its nutrition R&D segment in Asia, aiming to have 40% of its global R&D team based in the region by 2018.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Partners in posturing
summary: The US federal budget faces a looming crisis as ageing society, military downsizing, and increased spending on healthcare threaten the 20% GDP ceiling. Current policies will lead to a $1.7 trillion deficit on elderly spending, prompting calls for tax increases and spending cuts. However, Republican and Democratic budgets proposed in Congress are not serious efforts, with the Republican plan cutting $5.5 trillion in spending and the Democratic plan running nearly $6 trillion in deficits. A genuine budget debate requires honest discussion on priorities, such as how much to spend on the elderly and the size of the military, but this has not happened.

site_title: Newbie Trevor Noah to succeed Jon Stewart on The Daily Show
summary: Trevor Noah, a 31-year-old South African comedian, has been chosen as the new host of The Daily Show, succeeding Jon Stewart later this year. Noah made his debut on the show in December and was given the promotion after only three appearances. The decision promises to add youthful vitality and an international perspective to the show, marking a first for a non-white performer at the head of a flagship Comedy Central franchise. Stewart expressed his endorsement, stating he's "thrilled" for the show and Noah.

images.alt_text: Newcomer to US television, Noah represents a non-white performer at the head of the flagship Comedy Central franchise, and one who comes with Stewart's endorsement. "He's a tremendous comic," says Stewart.

site_title: Beijing further eases mortgage policies
summary: China's central bank lowered down-payment requirements for some second homes to 40% from 60% to boost the property market, which has been impacted by an economic slowdown. The move aims to arrest a slide in home prices and spur growth. Despite recent interest-rate cuts and mortgage policy relaxations, new home sales have slumped 17% in the first two months of 2015. The government seeks to expand its economy, which has been its slowest pace in 15 years, and has seen industrial output, investment, and retail sales miss analysts' estimates.

site_title: Lisbon, Luxembourg rank Europe's worst for pollution fight: study
summary: Lisbon and Luxembourg ranked last in a European test of cities' efforts to combat air pollution, according to an environmental group. The study, which graded 23 cities, found that Zurich and Copenhagen had made significant strides in reducing pollution and promoting clean transportation. Cities like Dublin, Madrid, and Rome received F grades, but were deemed to be doing slightly better than Lisbon and Luxembourg. The study, backed by the European Environmental Bureau, highlighted the need for cities to take stronger action to reduce pollution and improve air quality.

site_title: Oil prices slip as market eyes possible Iran deal
summary: Oil prices declined on Monday as traders anticipated a possible deal between Iran and global powers, easing international sanctions on the country's oil exports. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 19 cents to $48.68 a barrel, while European benchmark Brent oil dropped 12 cents to $56.29 a barrel. The potential easing of sanctions is seen as a positive factor for oil prices, which have been influenced by US President Trump's trade policies.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dipped on Monday as traders eyed talks between Iran and global powers that could ease international sanctions on one of the world's leading oil producers.

site_title: Hollywood's new concern: digital security
summary: Hollywood studios are turning to digital security measures to protect sensitive data after a hacking incident at Sony Pictures revealed embarrassing emails and personal details. Executives like Lulu Zezza are now using technology companies like WatchDox and Box to manage data on employees' personal smartphones and cloud storage services. These measures include encryption, passwords, and monitoring systems to track who is accessing sensitive files. The industry is also adopting "air-gapping" techniques to prevent hackers from accessing movie editing software. Demand for digital security solutions has surged, with venture capitalists taking notice and expecting the market to reach $1 billion by 2017.

site_title: Aviva S'pore reports 49% jump in 2014 sales, thanks to DBS tie-up
summary: Aviva Singapore reported a 49% year-on-year rise in sales to S$301 million in 2014, driven by its partnership with DBS, which grew 30% in value of new business. The insurer's financial advisory channel saw a 42% increase, while its agency channel rose 27%. Aviva's capital adequacy ratio improved to 310% from 300% in 2013. The company aims to build on its distribution assets through DBS and independent financial advisers, with a 15-year exclusive deal with DBS estimated to be worth US$1.5 billion.

site_title: China firm makes cheaper fresh bid for Aussie miner PanAust
summary: China's Guangdong Rising Assets Management has launched a new US$850 million bid to buy Australian copper and gold miner PanAust Ltd, valuing it at A$1.1 billion. The offer is a quarter less than a previous bid made 10 months ago, reflecting the decline in mineral commodity prices. Analysts see this as a sign of Asian enterprises taking a more active role in the Australian resources sector, with a long-term investment approach. PanAust shares have jumped 40% to match the latest offer price, a four-month high for the stock.

site_title: Prada's 2014 down for first time since HK listing
summary: Prada reported its first annual net profit drop since listing in Hong Kong in 2011, with a 28% decline to €450.7 million in 2014, due to weaker sales in China and Hong Kong. Asia-Pacific sales fell 3.1%, while overall annual sales dropped 1%. The company attributes the decline to local issues, currency volatility, and government crackdowns on corruption. Prada shares have gained 14.6% this year, but the company is working to contain costs and increase efficiency.

images.alt_text: Prada has seen weaker sales in China and Hong Kong amid a government crackdown on corruption, including bribery which often takes the form of lavish gifts to officials.

site_title: BSI is first Swiss bank to settle under US tax program
summary: Swiss private bank BSI SA has become the first Swiss bank to settle under the US Department of Justice's voluntary disclosure program, paying a $211 million penalty for suspected tax-related offenses. BSI assisted thousands of US clients in opening undeclared accounts in Switzerland between 1976 and 2013. As part of the deal, BSI agreed to cooperate in related proceedings and implement better controls. The bank's cooperation avoids prosecution, marking a significant milestone in the US government's efforts to crack down on offshore tax evasion.

site_title: Asian stocks set for best quarter in 3 years
summary: Asian stocks rose, poised for their best quarterly gain in three years, as China's central bank announced measures to support economic growth. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.6% to 147.35, on track for a 6.9% quarterly advance. China's Shanghai Composite Index surged 17% this year, while Japan's Topix index added 11%. The yen fell 0.8% against the dollar, and US home sales rose 3.1% in February, fueling optimism for economic growth.

site_title: Consumer spending tepid; savings at 2-year high
summary: US consumer spending rose barely in February, with households boosting savings to a 2-year high, amid economic slowdowns due to bad weather, a strong dollar, and softer demand in Europe and Asia. Despite a weak first quarter, economists expect a temporary slowdown and good consumption outlook for the rest of the year.

site_title: Tokyo mulls over income tax hike on the wealthy
summary: Tokyo is considering raising income taxes on the wealthy and increasing inheritance tax if the government fails to reach its goal of returning to a primary budget surplus by 2020. The government plans to increase the nationwide sales tax to 10% in 2017 to pay for rising welfare and healthcare costs. If the goal is not met, further measures such as cutting spending or increasing taxes on the wealthy could be considered. The government will conduct a mid-term assessment in 2018 to determine the best course of action.

site_title: Google unveils unified email for Android users
summary: Google has updated its mobile Gmail app for Android users, allowing them to manage multiple email accounts from a single program. The new 'All Inboxes' option aggregates email from rival services such as Yahoo and Microsoft Outlook. This feature enables users to read and respond to all messages without having to switch between accounts. The update provides a unified email experience for Android users, streamlining their email management.

site_title: Stanchart committed to Islamic banking despite exit of head of unit
summary: Standard Chartered remains committed to Islamic banking despite the departure of Afaq Khan, head of its Islamic arm, who left after 12 years to take a career break. Khan's departure follows the naming of new CEO Bill Winters, who aims to reverse a two-year slump. The bank expects growth in core markets, including Bahrain, Malaysia, and the UAE, and has arranged US$20 billion in Islamic financing for customers in 2013. Standard Chartered is scaling down parts of its global business under a cost-cutting drive, but remains committed to Islamic banking.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew, truly the father of Changi airport
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew played a pivotal role in the development of Changi Airport, envisioning it as a strategic international air hub. In 1975, he decided to build the airport in Changi, replacing the original Paya Lebar airport. Lee's vision was driven by the need for flexibility in expansion, reduced impact on the population, and the ability to liberate land for future development. Despite initial skepticism, Lee invested in top civil servants, including "The Three Wise Men," to drive the project forward. Under his leadership, Changi Airport became the world's most-awarded airport, with over 480 "World's Best Airport" awards.

site_title: UK finance jobs down for 2nd quarter in a row
summary: UK financial services employment fell for the second consecutive quarter, with 39% of firms expecting a decline in headcount, according to a CBI survey. Banks cut costs amid restrictions on capital and tougher regulation, with Royal Bank of Scotland Group considering eliminating up to 14,000 investment-bank jobs. Transactions in banking and building societies remained unchanged.

site_title: Samsung Hub office floor sold at S$3,250 psf
summary: The eighth floor of the 999-year leasehold Samsung Hub in Singapore has been sold to a Hong Kong-based property investment company for S$42.6 million, or S$3,250 per square foot. The sale reflects a 3.2% net yield based on the monthly rental of S$10 per square foot. The seller, Sun Venture, plans to retain the remaining three floors in the building and is seeking long-term funding from Taiwanese investors. The sale is seen as attractive, given its lower price compared to recent transactions in the building.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Technology sharing the latest weapon in industry
summary: Facebook and other tech companies are sharing proprietary information to accelerate technology development, prioritizing speed over secrecy. This shift is driven by the abundance of cheap prototyping, global connectivity, and the rise of the hobbyist drone industry. Companies like Tesla and PCH International are already benefiting from sharing designs and ideas, with Tesla's patent release sparking an electric car industry. While not all information will be shared, the trend suggests a more collaborative approach to innovation, with companies balancing protection and sharing to drive growth and competition.

site_title: Creating a tech culture
summary: BH Global, a marine products firm, has successfully transformed its culture to become a technology-focused company. Founded in 1963, BH Global has introduced e-commerce and innovative technologies such as guided data analytics to drive productivity and profitability. The company's chief information officer, Ken Soh, notes that technology is seen as a critical enabler to identify new sales opportunities and increase customer satisfaction. By implementing Qlik data discovery solutions, BH Global has reduced reporting time and operating costs, and achieved a 70% reduction in backlog. The company plans to continue scaling its technology platform and expanding its e-commerce offering.

site_title: Details on govt spending available on Budget website
summary: The Singapore government has clarified that information on its spending, including a breakdown by categories, is available online through the Budget website. The government prioritizes cost control and effective resource allocation, with measures such as office space norms, Gateway approval processes, and centralizing human resources and finance functions. Large projects undergo thorough review to ensure value-for-money design, and the government continues to explore ways to improve service integration and cost optimization.

site_title: Thai factory output, visitor arrivals up but road ahead is slow
summary: Thailand's factory output has increased by 3.55% in February, ending a 22-month streak of decline, and tourist arrivals rose 29.6% year-over-year. However, a monetary policy committee member warned that traditional growth drivers are not working, and the economy's recovery is uncertain. The central bank reported a 1.5% rise in imports and a 6.14% decline in exports, with annual exports still weak. The government aims for a 3-4% increase in industrial output this year, but economists caution that sustained growth momentum depends on effective fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Bunching of AGMs in late April is unfair to investors
summary: SGX is warning of an unfair AGM season in late April, where small shareholders will be forced to attend multiple meetings due to a bunched schedule. This denies investors the opportunity to assess their company's performance and meet with management and directors. The upcoming change in leadership at SGX is expected to have little impact on the situation, and the columnist calls for listed companies and their boards to make changes to improve the AGM experience for small shareholders.

site_title: Whose side is the US on in the Mid-East?
summary: The US's stance in the Middle East is increasingly ambiguous as it shifts away from its traditional allies, including Israel, Saudi Arabia, and Egypt. This emergence of a Shia axis led by Iran is causing concern among these countries. Historically, the US has used diplomatic and military power to secure its interests in the region, primarily through alliances with moderate Arab governments and Israel. However, under the Trump administration, US foreign policy is undergoing a significant shift, leaving many wondering about its future role in the Middle East.

site_title: New board members at CRA and bodies under MTI and MOF
summary: Singapore government agencies have announced changes to their boards, including the Casino Regulatory Authority (CRA) and statutory boards under the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI), Ministry of Finance (MOF), and others. New board members have been appointed, including former Shell executive Lee Tzu Yang as CRA chairman, and Rita Soh Siow Lan and Eugene Leong Chee Gin to the Sentosa Development Corporation (SDC) board. Reappointments have also been made to various boards, with some taking effect on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang
Mr Lee Tzu Yang moves from deputy chairman to board chairman at the Casino Regulatory Authority.

site_title: Cyber attack on US coding site came from China: WSJ
summary: US coding site GitHub was targeted by a cyber attack originating from China, according to The Wall Street Journal. The attack, a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack, was aimed at two GitHub pages linked to banned Chinese websites. The attack began on Thursday and was deflected by GitHub, with the company attributing the attack to Chinese search engine Baidu Inc. Baidu has denied any involvement in the attack, stating it was not a security issue on their side.

site_title: Savings bonds may put fixed deposits at risk
summary: Singapore is set to launch its Singapore Savings Bonds (SSB) in the second half of 2015, offering flexible redemption terms and step-up coupons to incentivize long-term investment. The non-tradable bonds, priced at $500, are designed for individual investors, potentially offering a better alternative to fixed deposits. Industry observers praise the SSB's flexibility and low risk profile, but note that banks may still offer competitive rates, and the bonds' relatively low yields may not be sufficient for inflation-beating returns.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Monday announced details of the new bond programme, which was first mentioned by Senior Minister of State for Finance and Transport Josephine Teo on March 26.

site_title: Winning the fight for talent
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant challenges in attracting and retaining talent, with nearly half of employees looking to leave the organization. Aon Hewitt's Best Employers-Singapore awards highlighted the gap between SMEs and larger companies in terms of employee engagement, employer brand, leadership, and performance culture. To overcome this, SMEs must develop unique value propositions, foster trust among employees, and provide opportunities for growth and development. By addressing these people issues, SMEs can become workplaces of choice and improve their competitiveness in the job market.

site_title: Prices of completed condos down 0.3% in February: NUS
summary: Prices of completed condos in Singapore fell 0.3% in February, according to the National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate Studies. This marks a 5% drop from a year ago and a 9.4% fall from the peak in July 2013. The main decline was in the Central Region, including the financial district and Sentosa Cove. Experts predict a 5-8% drop in prices for the year, with the post-Chinese New Year period being a critical window for buying interest.

images.alt_text: Consultants note that monthly reporting of non-landed residential prices is becoming more volatile amid sharply reduced market transactions.

site_title: Markets fear Greek default as talks continue
summary: Greece's debt crisis escalates as markets fear a potential default, with repayments of approximately 500 billion euros at risk. Athens proposes linking future payments to GDP growth, but the move may not be enough to alleviate concerns. The European Union and other creditors have been engaged in talks with Greece, but a resolution has yet to be reached, putting the country's economic future in jeopardy.

images.alt_text: Greek public debt was 315.5 billion euros at the end of the third quarter last year, rising to about half a trillion euros when bank and company debt is taken into account.

site_title: To Mexico, with love
