summary: Singapore delegates participated in a week-long cultural and business exchange in Mexico City, titled Spotlight Singapore Mexico City. The event, held to commemorate 40 years of bilateral ties between the two countries, was marred by the death of Singapore's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew. Despite this, the exchange proceeded with a poignant concert featuring a rearranged version of Singapore's national anthem, "Majulah Singapura," which brought tears to the eyes of many delegates. The exchange fostered new business and cultural ties, with several agreements and collaborations announced, including a partnership between a Singaporean social enterprise and a Mexican educational institution.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: SGX seeks public views on position accounts for CDP clearing members
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking public views on introducing position accounts for Central Depository (CDP) clearing members. The move aims to improve the post-trade environment and allow individual clearing members to manage their own post-trade activities using their own back-office systems. The public consultation is open until April 13, and foreign clearing members will be able to connect to CDP directly from late-2015, while local members will customize features and services for their customers. The client accounting system will be discontinued and replaced by the position account.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Hatcher's new US$100m venture
summary: Hatcher, a Singapore-based investment firm, has launched a new US$100 million venture fund to invest in fintech and tech startups globally, focusing on growth-stage investments. The fund will deploy seven times more capital than Hatcher's current investments, allowing it to support entrepreneurs at a global level. Hatcher's CEO, John Sharp, believes that growth-stage startups require more capital to support worldwide marketing efforts and build customer support teams. The fund will replicate the financing structures typical of the Bay Area, providing entrepreneurs with enough capital to achieve their business vision.

site_title: HK retail rents drop on falling Chinese tourist numbers
summary: Hong Kong retail rents have dropped due to a 80% decline in Chinese tourist numbers, largely attributed to a Chinese government crackdown on lavish spending. The decline in sales has forced retailers to negotiate lower leases or move out, with some luxury retailers cutting prices in Asia. The slowdown has led to a 30% revenue fall for one consumer goods chain and a 25% decline in sales for a small shop in Causeway Bay, prompting retailers to adapt by shifting their focus to other markets.

site_title: Penny stocks in play again
summary: The Straits Times Index rose for the fifth consecutive day, closing at 3,454.26, driven by a firm closing for Hong Kong and a positive opening for Europe. However, the rise did not materialize into a "window-dressing push" as expected, with the average value per unit traded at S$0.60, indicating a preference for lower-priced or penny stocks. The top 20 most actively traded stocks included 18 priced below 50 cents, with Biosensors falling S$0.005 to S$0.76 despite recent product announcements.

site_title: Fortescue chief says China wants 'fair game' on iron supply
summary: China, the world's largest iron ore consumer, wants a diversified supply of the steelmaking ingredient to ensure a stable supply, according to Fortescue Metals Group founder Andrew Forrest. At least 165 million tonnes of iron ore output from smaller suppliers will exit the market in 2015, leading to a global surplus of 129 million tonnes by 2017. China's demand growth is curbing prices, and the largest producers, including Rio Tinto and Vale, have raised volumes, dismissing a potential output cap to stimulate prices.

site_title: BI says it doesn't have the luxury to go against market
summary: Bank Indonesia (BI) keeps its key interest rate at 7.50% due to the global financial market's influence, prioritizing stability over growth. Senior deputy governor Mirza Adityaswara stated the central bank can't defy the market, supporting a "pro-growth" stance through stabilization. This decision comes after the rupiah weakened to a 17-year low and amid expectations of a potential rate cut this year.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment improves: credit bureau
summary: Singapore businesses are slightly more optimistic about the next three months, with the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's quarterly Business Optimism Index rising to a positive 9 percentage points. Despite the upturn, sentiment remains lower than previous readings from 2013-2014. Expectations for sales volumes, net profit, and selling prices are positive, while inventory levels and employment expectations remain mixed. The services sector is the most optimistic, with the financial sector showing the largest improvement.

site_title: Singapore delivers Phase 1 of plan for Indian state capital city
summary: Singapore has delivered the first phase of a master plan to build a new capital city in Andhra Pradesh, India. The 7,325 sq km plan, developed by Surbana International Consultants and Jurong Consultants, outlines the long-term economic positioning of existing towns and cities, connectivity strategies, and urban development plans. The plan is the first of a three-stage master plan, with the next two phases due to be completed by June. Andhra Pradesh will then announce the appointment of Singapore master developers for the Seed Development Plan.

site_title: China's Premier Li helps to push railway profits to new record
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang has helped push railway profits to a new record, with four major rail companies expected to achieve all-time high profits in 2014. China's expertise in building rail networks and equipment manufacturing is being used to win overseas contracts, particularly in emerging markets and the US. The government has established the Silk Road Fund to finance infrastructure construction and promote trade, while companies like China CNR Corp and CSR Corp have announced a merger plan to boost exports. However, risks abound, including corruption allegations and inadequate knowledge of foreign markets, which may impact profitability.

site_title: Warburg Pincus plans to raise US$12b global fund: sources
summary: Warburg Pincus, a private equity firm, plans to raise a new $12 billion global fund, following its $11.2 billion fund raised two years ago. This move aims to capitalize on the relatively short time other firms take to invest investors' money in similar funds.

site_title: Sotheby's new CEO seeks to grow brand
summary: Tad Smith, the new CEO of Sotheby's, aims to grow the 271-year-old auction house by expanding its brand and reaching collectors who buy online. Smith, a former top executive at Madison Square Garden Co, brings experience in building brands and installing new technologies to the role. Sotheby's faces pressure from investors to increase profitability, which fell 9% in 2014 despite record auction sales of $6.1 billion. Smith's goal is to boost profit by expanding auctions to eBay's 155 million buyers worldwide.

site_title: Indonesia steps up campaign to attract more tourists
summary: Indonesia is stepping up its efforts to attract more tourists, easing entry requirements to boost its tourism industry. However, the country's patchy infrastructure still poses a challenge, making it difficult to support a surge in visitors. The islands of Belitung, located off the coast of Sumatra and Borneo, offer pristine beaches and uninhabited areas accessible by jet ski or boat. Despite these efforts, Indonesia's tourism industry remains a work in progress.

site_title: In brief
summary: KEPPEL Corp's shareholding in Keppel Land rose 0.5% to 93.9% as of March 30, still short of the 95.5% threshold for a higher offer price. IPC Corp is in talks to sell its 7 Japan hotels for S$150 million. Tianjin Zhongxin Pharmaceutical Group reported a 2% net profit increase and 18% revenue jump for the 2014 financial year. Meanwhile, OCBC's CEO Helen Wong is retiring and Tan Teck Long will take over as the new CEO.

site_title: Oil speculators focused on glut miss surge as bombs hit Yemen
summary: Crude oil prices surged after Saudi Arabia and its allies bombed rebels in Yemen, threatening supply disruptions in the region. Hedge funds cut their net-long position in WTI crude by 3.8% before prices jumped over 8% in the following days. The bombing, combined with a weaker dollar and strong US refinery production, led to a price increase. However, experts say it's difficult to hold gains in the short term, and the market fundamentals have not changed.

site_title: SGX should consider dual-class shares, says NUS professor
summary: A NUS professor suggests that the Singapore Exchange (SGX) consider allowing dual-class shares to attract more initial public offerings (IPOs from family firms. Dual-class shares have greater voting power for the founding family, but the professor argues they don't perform differently from non-dual-class shares. He recommends additional safeguards for investors, such as board observation rights, to address concerns about fairness. This could lead to a more vibrant stock exchange, attracting more venture capitalists and boosting the market.

site_title: Amprop, HPL, Temasek team up to redevelop two London projects
summary: Malaysia's Amcorp Properties Bhd, Singapore's Hotel Properties Ltd, and UK developer Native Land have teamed up with Temasek Holdings to redevelop two London properties, Ludgate House and Sampson House, with a gross development value estimated at over £1 billion. The joint venture, Bankside Quarter (Jersey) Ltd, will hold a 30% stake in the project, with Amcorp, HPL, and Temasek each taking 30% and Native Land holding 10%. Planning permission was granted in 2014 for a mixed-use development with residential units, office buildings, and retail facilities.

site_title: Bonsai sinks roots across borders
summary: A group of 18 foreigners visited the Shunkaen Bonsai Museum in Tokyo, where they learned bonsai techniques and pruning from curator Kunio Kobayashi. The event is part of a growing trend of bonsai enthusiasts abroad, with about 10,000 visitors annually, mostly foreigners. Kobayashi has taught over 100 students, both from Japan and abroad, and the museum is planning a Bonsai Cafe until April 5. The eighth World Bonsai Convention is set to take place in Saitama in 2017, showcasing Japan's world-class culture of beauty.

site_title: China's debt turned a corner (and no one noticed)
summary: China's debt-to-GDP ratio has stabilized at 251% as of mid-2014, a significant milestone in the country's debt turnaround. This stabilization is attributed to China's credit growth now aligning with GDP growth, and a shift in attitudes towards debt among loan officers. While China's leverage risks remain, the lack of a credit boom and escalating debt challenges mean the country's growth prospects are less concerning than previously thought. Positive sentiments from property developers and SMEs, as well as policy easing, also suggest China's "new normal" of slower growth may not deepen further in 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Ads in newspapers, magazines may be more effective: WPP chief
summary: WPP CEO Martin Sorrell suggests that advertisers reconsider spending on newspapers and magazines, citing data that shows consumer engagement with traditional publications remains high. He notes that readers spend 40 minutes with a newspaper, increasing the likelihood of retention. In contrast, GroupM forecasts a 2-point share gain for digital advertising, with print media losing share. Despite the shift to digital, Sorrell believes traditional media are more retentive and engaging for advertising and content.

images.alt_text: Mr Sorrell acknowledges that the shift to digital and social media will continue as there has been a "fundamental change" in media consumption by people born from 1983 onwards.

site_title: Australia's Treasurer invites tax-system overhaul discussion
summary: Australian Treasurer Joe Hockey has invited discussion on a tax system overhaul to reduce the government's reliance on income tax as the population ages. The 196-page report outlines opportunities and challenges in areas such as company tax, pension reform, and the levy of the sale of goods. The government aims to release a study paper in the second half of 2015 and proposes firm proposals for the 2016 national election. The current tax system is seen as ill-suited for the 2050s, with Australia having the sixth-lowest tax take as a proportion of its economy in the OECD.

site_title: A-Reit completes acquisition of The Kendall for S$112m
summary: A-Reit has completed the acquisition of The Kendall in Singapore for S$112 million, with an expected net property income yield of 6.8% in the first year. The acquisition is A-Reit's 27th from the Ascendas Group since its IPO in 2002. The property has a 64-year remaining land lease tenure and a current occupancy rate of 93.2%. The acquisition is expected to contribute to A-Reit's total portfolio of 105 properties in Singapore and two business park properties in China.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: HDB bans subletting of its industrial space from June (Amended)
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has banned subletting of its industrial space starting June 1, aligning with the JTC Corporation's policy change. The move aims to promote responsible use of scarce industrial land and encourage tenants to rent only the space they need. Approximately 380 tenants, or 3% of HDB's industrial tenants, currently sublet space, and the policy change is expected to have a minimal impact due to its small affected group and generous grace period.

site_title: Euro down on Greece uncertainty
summary: The euro fell 0.6% to US$1.0830 on Monday due to uncertainty over Greece's ability to secure funding before April 20, despite upbeat talks between Athens and creditors. The dollar rose 0.5% to 119.78 yen, driven by Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's comments on the likelihood of gradual interest rate hikes later this year. A robust US jobs report this week could see investors position for tighter monetary policy, further supporting the dollar's strength.

site_title: Drop in Japan Feb production points to slowing local demand
summary: Japan's industrial output fell 3.4% in February, the largest decline in eight months, due to a slowdown in domestic demand. The drop was worse than expected, sparking concerns that domestic demand could be faltering. Economists predict a gradual recovery, but the outlook is uncertain, complicating the Bank of Japan's task to revive the economy. A decline in auto output could indicate weak domestic demand, and another disappointing number makes a rapid recovery less likely.

site_title: The United States should not oppose, but support and even join, the AIIB
summary: The US is at risk of being isolated following several of its allies signing up to the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a China-led institution. Despite the Obama administration's pleas, Britain, France, Germany, and Italy joined as "founding" members, fearing the AIIB's potential to rival the World Bank and IMF. The US sees this as a challenge to its dominance in global finance, with Washington viewing Beijing's actions as an attempt to rewrite the rules of the international order.

images.alt_text: THE United States risks being isolated following the decision of several of its allies to sign up to the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB).

site_title: Sino Construction shoots up 21% on news of placement
summary: Sino Construction's share price surged 21% to S$0.035 after the company announced a S$6.5 million placement of 262 million new shares at a discount. The funds will be used to shore up the company's financial position and advance micro power plant construction. The new shares represent 6.4% of the existing share capital. The company's interim executive director, Drew Madacsi, stated that the restructuring efforts are necessary for the company's re-emergence.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Soon-to-be: Home free no more as legal countdown begins
summary: A legal countdown has begun in the US, where thousands of homeowners who missed mortgage payments for over five years may be able to keep their homes without paying another dime. The reason is that state statutes of limitations have expired, preventing lenders from seizing the homes. This issue is being tested in Florida, where the state's high court is weighing in on whether lenders can refile a foreclosure after a case is dismissed due to the statute of limitations. If the court rules in favor of homeowners, it could lead to a wave of settlements, potentially affecting millions of Americans.

site_title: Singapore medtech startup raises US$1m
summary: Singapore medtech startup Healint has raised over $1 million in its second round of seed funding, led by Wavemaker Pacific and including participation from GREE Ventures and the National Research Foundation. The funding supports Healint's development of its migraine tracking app, Migraine Buddy.

site_title: China may approve online sale of prescription drugs
summary: China is expected to approve the online sale of prescription drugs this year, potentially shifting the country's $149 billion market towards web retailers and away from hospitals, which currently control 75% of the market. Analysts predict increased competition, lower prices, and better services for patients, while also decreasing corruption. Companies like Alibaba Group and Shanghai Pharmaceuticals Holding plan to capitalize on the move, with Alibaba already offering over-the-counter products online and building a mobile application for prescription uploads. Industry experts acknowledge that ironing out details and building trust will take years.

site_title: Coutts purchase priced far below US$1b: UBP exec
summary: Union Bancaire Privée (UBP) has acquired Coutts International for a price significantly lower than the estimated US$1 billion, according to a top executive. The deal adds over 10 billion Swiss francs (S$14.25 billion) in assets under management (AUM) in Asia, which is roughly a third of Royal Bank of Scotland's (RBS) international wealth management business. The purchase is the fourth acquisition in four years for UBP, which aims to integrate Coutts International with minimal headcount cuts in Asia due to its small presence.

site_title: No end in sight for exodus out of commodity funds
summary: Investors are fleeing commodity funds at the fastest pace on record, with a net outflow of $1.23 billion in the first three months of the year. Ample supplies and weak demand, particularly from China and emerging markets, are driving the exodus. The Bloomberg Commodity Index is down 5% since December, with crude oil reaching a six-year low. Experts predict a 20% drop in commodities and a fifth straight annual drop in the commodity index, with most commodities in a "structural bear market."

site_title: Australia enforces 'rule of two' on flight deck after crash
summary: Australia enforces 'rule of two' on flight deck after crash. In response to the Germanwings disaster, Australian Deputy Prime Minister Warren Truss has implemented a new rule requiring two crew members on the flight deck of all commercial flights with 50 or more seats. This change follows a recommendation by the European Aviation Safety Agency to ensure at least two people are present in the cockpit at all times. The new policy aims to prevent similar incidents and make global aviation safer.

site_title: CCFH to diversify into helicopter leasing and solar plant project
summary: CCFH, a CATALIST-listed firm, plans to diversify into fund management, helicopter leasing, and solar plant projects in the Caribbean. The move comes after acquiring Chinese private equity fund manager Mercury Capital for up to S$2.8 million. CCFH will provide financing to lease heavy-lift helicopters and invest in a US$300 million fund for solar power projects. The firm aims to phase out its bedlinen business and is focused on providing financial services across its new ventures.

site_title: Settlements in Germanwings case likely to vary with nationality, say lawyers
summary: A Germanwings plane crashed in the French Alps, killing everyone on board, after the co-pilot intentionally brought it down. The airline's insurers may pay hundreds of millions of dollars to the victims' families, but payouts will vary by nationality due to differences in court awards. The Montreal Convention sets a maximum payout of US$170,000 per victim, but families of American victims may receive larger payments. Germanwings has set aside €50,000 for each family to cover initial expenses, and the airline is expected to honour its responsibilities.

site_title: Oman Air to grow fleet to 70 aircraft by 2020
summary: Oman Air plans to double its fleet to 70 aircraft by 2020, expanding its destinations from 48 to 75. The carrier will have 25 wide-body and 45 narrow-body planes. Oman Air aims to grow its fleet strength to 50 aircraft by 2020, enabling it to raise frequencies and offer more convenient connections. The airline has ordered 20 Boeing 737 aircraft, including 10 737 MAXs, and will take delivery of two Boeing 787s and six more 737s this year, increasing capacity by 35%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Evergrande core profit up on more completed projects
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd reported a 16.5% increase in 2014 core profit to 12 billion yuan, beating estimates. The company attributed the growth to record sales and completed projects. Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan predicted a "new normal" for the Chinese real estate market, with total sales expected to surpass 2014 levels. The company aims to shrink its debt ratio to 70% by mid-to-long term, amid concerns about its significant indebtedness. Shares rose 6.2% following the announcement.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintains an "overweight" stance on Singapore property, citing positive carry despite sharp mortgage rate jumps, and recommends deep value and diversified developers like Wing Tai and CapitaLand. OCBC Investment Research downgrades Biosensors International Group to "sell" due to weak earnings and a rapidly rising share price. Singapore rigbuilders are negatively impacted by the Brazilian graft scandal, with Keppel Corp seen as a more stable option.

site_title: Cameron announces start of UK election campaign
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron announced the start of the UK's May 7 election campaign after meeting Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace. Cameron stated that voters face a "stark choice" between him and Labour's Ed Miliband, highlighting his government's economic achievements and warning of economic chaos under Miliband. The general election marks the end of the parliamentary term, following a law passed by Cameron's government.

site_title: India's carriers need to find ways to foot bill for spectrum
summary: India's mobile carriers agreed to spend $18 billion buying airwaves from the government in a 19-day auction. Seven carriers must pay a third of the bid amount by next week, with the rest in installments over two years. To offset costs, carriers may increase tariffs, potentially leading to higher monthly bills for subscribers, with estimates suggesting a 13% increase for Bharti Airtel. The move may force end users to pay more, as carriers face a drastic change in their cost structure.

site_title: Big Oil again covets Iran's reserves after decades of conflict
summary: Big Oil companies such as BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Total SA are eager to return to Iran, which holds 10% of the world's oil reserves and 19% of gas reserves, after decades of conflict. However, reaching a deal on commercial terms could be challenging due to Iran's crippled energy industry, which needs significant investment and foreign expertise. Iran's new oil minister has proposed a revised contract, known as the "Iran Petroleum Contract", which offers better terms but may not be enough to compete with other countries opening to international investors.

site_title: GIC, Temasek to each acquire up to 450m Swiss francs of shares in Dufry
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corp (GIC) and Temasek Holdings have each committed to buying up to 450 million Swiss francs (S$641.1 million) worth of shares in Swiss travel retailer Dufry. The deal values Italy's World Duty Free (WDF) at about 3.6 billion euros, with Dufry to acquire the 50.1% stake in Q3 2015 and launch an offer for the remaining 49.9% stake. The acquisition is expected to strengthen Dufry's global travel retail industry presence and generate cost reductions and gross profit improvements.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Ex-Fed chief Bernanke back as blogger
summary: Former US Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke launched his own blog, hosted by the Brookings Institution, a year after leaving the Fed. He addressed criticisms of his interest rate policies, stating that keeping rates low was necessary to support economic growth after the 2008 recession. Bernanke defended the policies of his successor, Janet Yellen, and argued that his opinions are his own and do not reflect the views of his former colleagues. The blog post sparked a debate on the impact of ultra-low interest rates on retirees and savers.

site_title: Oil prices drop on possible Iran nuclear deal, strong US dollar
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday as officials from Iran and six world powers discussed a possible deal over Tehran's nuclear program, which could lead to an end of sanctions and increased Iranian oil exports. Brent crude fell 40 US cents to US$56.01 a barrel, while US crude fell 80 US cents to US$48.07. Analysts expect a framework deal to result in an immediate bearish reaction in the markets, with oil prices potentially losing around US$5. A build-up in US stocks is forecast to lead to an oversupplied global market in the second quarter, with demand unlikely to support oil prices.

site_title: Apple Watch to spark wearable tech growth: IDC
summary: The global wearable technology market is expected to experience significant growth, driven by the release of the Apple Watch. According to IDC, wearable devices are projected to ship 45.7 million units globally in 2015, a 133% increase from 2014. By 2019, this number is expected to reach 126.1 million units, with an average annual growth rate of 45%. Smart wearables, including smartwatches, smart clothing, and connected eyewear, are expected to dominate the market, with wrist-worn wearables accounting for over 80% of shipments.

site_title: Crash pilot showed suicidal tendencies in past: prosecutors
summary: A Germanwings plane crashed in 2015, killing all 150 people on board, and prosecutors have revealed the co-pilot had shown suicidal tendencies several years prior to obtaining his pilot's license. Despite receiving treatment, the pilot showed no signs of suicidal tendencies or aggression until the crash.

site_title: Greek reforms list proposes bad bank, lowers asset sales target
summary: Greece's government has proposed setting up a bad bank to address rising bad loans and aims to raise approximately 1.5 billion euros from asset sales this year, a 30% reduction from the current target. The proposal also includes reducing early retirements to alleviate pension system burden and avoiding tax hikes in the tourism sector. The bad bank will be funded with 10.9 billion euros from bank bailout funds. The measures were included in a package of reforms submitted to euro zone lenders in hopes of unlocking aid.

site_title: RBS investment bank boss goes after disagreement on strategy implementation: source
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland executive Rory Cullinan has left as head of its investment bank due to a disagreement over the implementation of strategy, a source confirmed. Cullinan was appointed executive chairman of the Corporate and Institutional Bank just a month ago. The bank announced his departure, citing the end of April as the effective date. This move comes amidst a shift in leadership at RBS, with new appointments and departures affecting various divisions.

site_title: Malaysia's Amcorp and Singapore's Temasek sign £308m London property deal
summary: Malaysia's Amcorp Properties Bhd and Singapore's Temasek Holdings (Private) Ltd have signed a £308 million (S$626 million) deal to purchase two London properties for redevelopment. The mixed-use project, located on London's Bankside, is expected to have a gross development value exceeding £1 billion. The redevelopment will be undertaken by the parties, with no further details on the project's timeline or completion date announced.

site_title: US biodiesel output slowed to 72m gallons in January: EIA
summary: US biodiesel output declined to 72 million gallons in January 2015, down from 73 million gallons in the same period last year and 123 million gallons in December 2014, according to the US Energy Information Association. The decrease was largely due to lower feedstock usage, with 545 million pounds of soybean oil used to produce the renewable fuel.

site_title: German firms embrace start-ups to catch up with digital world
summary: German companies are partnering with start-ups to stay competitive in the digital age, as the country's traditional blue-chip firms struggle to keep pace with nimble tech giants like Google, Apple, and Amazon. Many big German companies, including Metro, Bayer, and Deutsche Telekom, are investing in start-ups to gain digital expertise and adapt to changing market trends. The trend aims to address a shortage of venture capital and help German companies avoid falling behind in the digital revolution.

site_title: India regulator proposes to ease rules for start-up IPOs
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India proposes reducing the lock-in period for start-up IPOs to six months for all shareholders. This move aims to make it easier for start-ups to list at home, with the lock-in period previously ranging from one to three years depending on the category of investor. The regulator is seeking responses to the proposals by April 20.

site_title: Tunisia tourism will rebound despite museum attack: UN
summary: The UN World Tourism Organization (UNWTO) is confident in Tunisia's ability to rebound from the Bardo National Museum attack, which killed 21 tourists and raised concerns about the country's tourism industry. The museum reopened on Monday, with reinforced security measures in place. Tourism Minister Selma Elloumi Rekik stressed the government's commitment to reviving the industry, which accounts for 7% of the country's GDP and employs 400,000 people directly. The industry has seen a 60% drop in bookings since the attack, but UNWTO Secretary General Taleb Rifai believes Tunisia will overcome the setback and move forward.

site_title: Germany's Merkel says Greek reforms must "add up"
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel emphasized that Greece's reforms must "add up" to satisfy European partners. Merkel stated that while there can be variation in specific measures, the overall framework must be effective in restoring Greece's financial stability. She expressed that Greece is in talks with the institutions, awaiting their evaluation, and Germany will wait for the results.

site_title: German economy leading the charge amid QE
summary: The German economy is leading the charge in the Eurozone, despite global challenges, with unemployment falling and confidence rising. Manufacturing and services are strengthening, and output growth is forecast to be sustained this year. Germany's strong fundamentals and relatively weak currency union with weaker partners, such as Greece, have contributed to its growth. The European Central Bank's stimulus program has also benefited German exporters, with the economy expected to grow 1.6% this year, outpacing other Eurozone countries.

images.alt_text: Chairman of the board of Skoda Auto, Winfried Vahland, presenting the new Skoda Superb model during a preview of Volkwagen Group earlier this month in Geneva. Volkswagen shares have surged about 31 per cent this year.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to sell natural gas business scrutinized by Fed
summary: Morgan Stanley has agreed to sell its compressed natural gas business, Wentworth, to Pentagon Energy LLC, a newly formed company, as the business faced regulatory scrutiny. Two Morgan Stanley managers, Alberto Chiesara and Ryan Comerford, will join Pentagon Energy as principals. Simon Greenshields, former co-head of Morgan Stanley's commodities business, is not joining the new company. The sale is seen as a response to regulatory concerns and the departure of key personnel from Morgan Stanley.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on M&A flurry
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by four M&A deals in the biotech sector, lifting market sentiment after the worst weekly decline for the S&P 500 in two months. The Dow Jones rose 105.5 points, the S&P 500 gained 9.5 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 31.30 points, with the Dow reaching 17,818.16, the S&P 500 at 2,070.52, and the Nasdaq at 4,922.52.

site_title: BNP Paribas on track for growth in Asia-Pacific
summary: BNP Paribas is on track to grow its revenue in the Asia-Pacific region to $4.5 billion by 2016, driven by its wealth management business and covered-bonds market. Despite a one-year suspension of US dollar clearing services for oil-and-gas transactions, the bank increased revenue by 7% in the region last year and added 500 clients. The bank has set up dedicated desks in China and Japan, and expects expansion in most client segments, with a focus on trade finance and covered bonds. Deposits and assets under management also grew significantly, with AUM in Asia-Pacific reaching $60 billion.

images.alt_text: "As far as we're concerned, vis-à-vis China . . . our structure is not so much ups and downs. We didn't feel a need to suddenly press the brakes," said Mr Veyres

site_title: German inflation creeps higher in March: data
summary: German inflation rose 0.3% year-on-year in March, driven by rebounding energy prices, according to preliminary data. The Harmonized Index of Consumer Prices (HICP) also increased by 0.1% year-on-year, despite being below the European Central Bank's target of 2.0%. Analysts attribute the modest pick-up in inflation to rising energy prices and the weaker euro. While the inflation rate is still below target, economists predict it will continue to rise throughout the year, potentially reaching 2.0% by the end of 2015.

site_title: Bank Indonesia says it doesn't have the luxury to go against market
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is unlikely to cut interest rates despite global market pressures, citing the need to maintain stability to support economic growth. Senior Deputy Governor Mirza Adityaswara stated that the bank cannot go against the global market, and instead will keep its policy tight. The rupiah has weakened to a 17-year low, but Bank Indonesia is expected to maintain its stance to curb imports and narrow the current account deficit. The bank expects economic growth to rebound to 5.4-5.8% this year.

site_title: 23 - the magic number that can make or break a China IPO
summary: China's equity market has a mysterious "magic number" of 23, where companies can only raise funds by pricing their IPOs at or below 23 times their earnings per share. This ceiling has been quietly enforced by Chinese regulators, who control the timing and pricing of deals, handing investors guaranteed profits and companies smaller cash infusions. Despite the success of the Shanghai benchmark index, only two of 147 IPOs in the past year have broken through the 23 valuation threshold, with the rest valued at 22-23 times reported earnings.

site_title: Malaysian airliner crash investigators appeal for missile witnesses
summary: Dutch prosecutors are seeking witnesses in eastern Ukraine who may have seen a Russian-made BUK rocket being fired at Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which killed 298 people on July 17, 2015. The Netherlands leads an international investigation, with Western governments and Kiev blaming pro-Russian rebels, while Moscow claims the plane was hit by a Ukrainian fighter jet's missile. The cause of the crash remains unclear.

site_title: Pending sales of US homes rose more than forecast in February
summary: US pending home sales rose 3.1% in February to 106.9, the highest since June 2013, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 0.3% increase. Strong labor market, low mortgage rates, and rising rents drove the gains, with two of four regions experiencing increases. Pending sales fell in the Northeast and South, but the Midwest saw an 11.6% jump and the West a 6.6% gain. This marks a solid start to the spring selling season, with the index indicating historically healthy home-buying traffic.

site_title: New bonds, old comforts
summary: Singapore's OCBC bank has named Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong, who is retiring. Meanwhile, MAS and PBOC have announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push, potentially putting fixed deposits and savings bonds at risk.

site_title: Japan labour ministry delays wages data release due to sampling glitches
summary: Japan's labour ministry has postponed the release of February wages data due to sampling glitches. The data, which provides clues on the economy's growth, was originally scheduled for Tuesday. The ministry is uncertain when the data will be released, stating it will publish it once it completes its investigation. This delay comes as analysts closely watch wages data to determine if a virtuous economic cycle is underway to end nearly two decades of slow growth and deflation.

site_title: China says 66 golf courses shut in renewed crackdown
summary: Chinese authorities have closed 66 golf courses in a renewed crackdown on courses built in contravention of rules protecting arable land and water resources. The central government ordered the demolition of courses built by five developers last year, marking the first enforcement of a 2004 ban. The ban aims to address China's shrinking land and water resources, with the country having only 7% of its water despite being home to a fifth of the world's population.

site_title: Iron ore plunges to another record low on glut concerns
summary: Spot iron ore plummeted 2.2% to a record low of $52.90 a tonne, with Chinese futures hitting a contract low, due to tepid demand and growing supplies. Global miners are expected to ramp up production, while demand remains weak. China's port inventories rose to 97.06 million tonnes, and the country aims to cut 80 million tonnes of excess steel capacity in the next three years to tackle a massive supply glut.

site_title: Singapore to launch savings bond programme in second half of 2015
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore plans to launch a savings bond programme in the second half of 2015, offering principal-guaranteed, non-tradable bonds with returns matching Singapore Government Securities. The bonds will be issued monthly, with a maximum tenure of 10 years and a minimum purchase amount of S$500. They will be sold to individuals only, with a cap on individual purchases yet to be set. The programme aims to provide a simple, low-cost option for long-term savings and safe returns.

site_title: Thailand admits 'urgent' need to improve aviation safety
summary: Thailand has admitted an "urgent" need to improve airline safety procedures amid significant safety concerns raised by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). Following a UN audit, several Thai carriers face bans on new international flights, with Japan blocking new flights from Thailand. The Thai Department of Civil Aviation plans to increase airline inspections and provide new training for staff as part of its overhaul. Transport Minister Prajin Juntong emphasized the need for immediate improvement, stating that the ICAO has warned Thailand about aviation management since 2005.

site_title: Searchers build roadway to remote France air crash site
summary: French investigators aim to expedite the identification of 150 victims of a Germanwings plane crash by creating a road access to the remote Alpine crash site. A military police track is being built, expected to be completed by Tuesday or Wednesday, allowing for easier access to the site. The track will aid in the recovery of bodies and parts, with 78 different DNA prints already discovered. The second "black box" flight recorder remains missing, but investigators believe it will provide further evidence of pilot Andreas Lubitz's deliberate actions.

site_title: China central bank says to ease lending policies for second home buyers
summary: China's central bank eased lending policies for second home buyers, adjusting the minimum downpayment and improving lending policies to promote a healthy real estate market. The move aims to counter deflationary pressure and support economic growth. The Ministry of Finance also announced a reduction in taxation for home sales. Real estate stock indexes surged in Shanghai following the news, which sparked rumors of a broader easing of regulations. The changes are seen as a step to stabilize the market and boost sales.

site_title: US consumer spending rises modestly; savings at 2-year high
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in February, the smallest increase in three months, as households boosted savings to a 2-year high. This follows a 0.2% drop in January. Economists had expected a 0.2% increase. A cold snap lifted spending on utilities, but purchases of big-ticket items like automobiles were cut back. Savings jumped to $768.6 billion, the highest level since December 2012, and the saving rate rose to 5.8%, also the highest since 2012. Despite a slowdown in economic growth, economists expect consumer spending to boost in the coming year.

images.alt_text: US consumer spending barely rose in February as households boosted savings to their highest level in more than two years, the latest sign that economic growth slowed sharply in the first quarter.

site_title: LME drops proposal to stop issuing Malaysia warrants
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) has withdrawn its proposal to stop issuing warrants for metal in Malaysia from July, following the government's resolution of issues over its new tax reforms. The exchange had warned of halting warrant issuance for stocks in Malaysian warehouses due to uncertainty over the tax reforms. The decision comes after the government addressed the concerns, allowing the LME to continue issuing warrants for Malaysian warehouses.

site_title: Former JP Morgan banker to head Barclays' UK ECM team: source
summary: Barclays has hired Barry Meyers, a former JP Morgan executive director, to head its UK equity capital markets team, starting in July. Meyers will report to Tom Johnson, co-head of ECM for Europe, Middle East, and Africa. This move comes after Chris Madderson was named EMEA head of equities syndicate last year and follows the recent hiring of Philip Shelley from Goldman Sachs. The appointments are part of Barclays' efforts to strengthen its ECM capabilities, with the bank having roles in several high-profile IPOs and recent trades.

site_title: Singapore: Penny stocks in play
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 4.16 points to 3,454.26, its fifth consecutive gain, as investors took advantage of a firm closing in Hong Kong and a positive opening in Europe. The average value per unit traded was S$0.60, indicating a preference for lower-priced stocks, contrary to expectations of a shift towards higher-priced issues. This is the first time since the start of 2014 that the average value has been above S$0.50.

site_title: Keppel Corp's stake in Keppel Land rises to 93.9%
summary: Keppel Corp's stake in Keppel Land rose to 93.9% by March 30, just short of the 95.5% threshold for the higher offer price of S$4.60 per share to take effect. Shares of Keppel Land fell 1.3% to S$4.46, contradicting expectations of a higher possibility that the offer price would remain at the base offer of S$4.38 per share. The final closing deadline for the offer is March 31.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corp's shareholding in Keppel Land inched up to 93.9 per cent by 5pm on Monday.

site_title: Abbott launches nutrition pilot plant in Singapore
summary: Abbott, a global healthcare company, has launched its first nutrition pilot plant in Singapore, marking its second R&D hub outside the US. The facility will enable the company to respond to changing healthcare needs in Asia, incorporate local flavors and textures, and accelerate product innovation. The move is seen as a strategic step to tap into the region's growing market, with Abbott's presence in Singapore also expected to enhance its research and development capabilities.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Europe: Rallying techs help European stocks bounce back
summary: European stocks rose 1.2% on Monday, rebounding from last week's losses, with tech shares leading the gains. The FTSEurofirst 300 index reached 1,597.12 points. Shares in Infineon, STMicroelectronics, ARM, and ASML jumped 2.3-3.2% after merger talks in the sector sparked a late-session rally on Wall Street. The rally was also fueled by a renewed fall in the euro and weekend comments from Chinese central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan on further monetary easing.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index gaining 0.43 per cent to 6,579.08 points.

site_title: GIC, Temasek to acquire up to CHF450m shares each in travel retailer Dufry
summary: Government of Singapore Investment Corp (GIC) and Temasek Holdings have each committed to buying up to CHF450m shares in Swiss travel retailer Dufry to fund its acquisition of World Duty Free (WDF). The deal values WDF at 3.6 billion euros and is expected to strengthen Dufry's global market share. The funds will be raised through a rights issue and debt financing, with existing shareholders having the option to participate. The acquisition is expected to enhance Dufry's position in the global travel retailer industry.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SGX consults public on introduction of position accounts for CDP clearing members
summary: SGX is consulting the public on introducing position accounts for CDP clearing members, allowing them to manage post-trade activities independently. The proposed system will be available to foreign clearing members starting late-2015, with local members to customize features for customers. The client accounting system will be discontinued, and the position account will replace it for clearing and settlement with CDP. The public consultation, open until April 13, seeks views on the structure of the position account and proposed rule amendments.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Confidence in euro zone economy near a four-year high
summary: The European Commission's economic sentiment indicator rose to 103.9 in March, its highest level since July 2011, indicating confidence in the euro zone economy is near a four-year high. Business morale improved, with Italy showing the largest jump, followed by Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands. The euro zone's economy is expected to grow 1.3% this year and 1.9% in 2016, driven by the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program and low oil prices, which are weakening the euro and stabilizing energy costs.

images.alt_text: Confidence in the euro zone's economy rose for a fourth straight month in March to its highest since July 2011, a European Commission survey showed on Monday, suggesting the weak euro and lower oil prices are spurring the recovery.

site_title: Hunt resumes for Alps plane crash DNA, black box
summary: French investigators have resumed searching for the cause of the Germanwings plane crash in the Alps, focusing on DNA and the second black box. The search, hindered by bad weather, is being done on foot due to helicopter flights being impossible. Forensic teams have isolated 80 distinct DNA strands, while authorities believe co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane, killing all 150 on board. The investigation aims to build a more accessible road to the site and uncover the circumstances behind the tragedy, with media reports suggesting Lubitz may have been driven by depression and hidden an illness from his airline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.46 points to close at 1,821.83, driven by gains in some 400 stocks. The index saw 1.92 billion lots valued at RM1.71 billion traded. This marks a higher close compared to the previous day.

site_title: Thailand's Feb tourist arrivals up 29.6% year-on-year: ministry
summary: Thailand's tourist arrivals rose 29.6% year-on-year in February, with 2.69 million foreign visitors, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth. This recovery is attributed to the end of months of political unrest after an army coup last May. The Finance Ministry's Fiscal Policy Office expects robust tourist arrivals for the rest of the year.

site_title: Italy business and consumer morale both rise sharply in March
summary: Italy's business and consumer morale both rose sharply in March, with the manufacturing confidence index increasing to 103.7, its highest level since June 2011. The composite business morale index rose for the fourth month, while consumer confidence reached 110.9, the highest level since May 2002. This surge in confidence is seen as a positive sign for the country's stagnant economy, which has shrunk for the last three years. Prime Minister Matteo Renzi is likely to be encouraged by the data, as it supports his efforts to revive the economy.

site_title: Japan govt weighing income tax hike on wealthy to meet fiscal goal: sources
summary: Japan's government is considering increasing income taxes for the wealthy and inheritance taxes if it fails to reach its goal of returning to a primary budget surplus by 2020. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government plans to raise the nationwide sales tax to 10% in 2017 to cover rising welfare and healthcare costs. If the goal is not met, further measures such as raising other taxes may be necessary. The government will conduct a mid-term assessment of its finances in 2018 to determine the need for additional measures.

site_title: China's Alibaba signs digital distribution deal with music rights group BMG
summary: China's Alibaba signs a digital distribution deal with music rights group BMG, bringing over 2.5 million copyrights to the e-commerce firm. This deal aims to boost earnings for BMG artists in China and promote legitimate music sales in the country. Alibaba's Digital Entertainment arm will promote BMG writers and artists through streaming apps and monitor copyright infringement. The partnership is part of Alibaba's bid to become a digital media empire, competing with Tencent Holdings and Baidu Inc. for dominance in China's online entertainment market.

images.alt_text: Germany's BMG music rights company said on Monday it had signed a music digital distribution deal with China's Alibaba Group Holding Ltd , as the world's largest e-commerce firm firms up its bid to become a digital media empire.

site_title: US coding site undergoes denial-of-service cyber attack
summary: US coding site GitHub reported a days-long denial-of-service cyber attack, deflecting most traffic with mitigation efforts. The attack, attributed to China's Baidu search engine, targeted GitHub pages linked to banned Chinese sites. The attack used sophisticated techniques, including web browser exploitation, to flood the site with traffic. GitHub confirmed intermittent issues, while Baidu stated it was neither a security issue nor a hacking attack, and was working to resolve the issue. The incident highlights the growing threat of distributed denial-of-service attacks on online platforms.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump on falling metals, oil prices
summary: Australian shares fell 1.25% on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching its lowest close since March 18, as resources stocks declined following lower oil and metals prices. Caltex Australia's stock slumped after Chevron Corp sold its half stake at a discounted price, marking Australia's largest block trade ever.

site_title: Swiss leading indicator edges off of three-year lows in March
summary: Switzerland's leading economic indicator, the KOF economic barometer, rose to 90.8 points in March, up from a revised 90.3 points in February, signaling weak growth ahead. The indicator, which forecasts the economy's performance in about six months, exceeded analyst expectations but remained below the long-term average. A recovery in consumption, manufacturing, and exports contributed to the increase, while construction and financial sector sentiment deteriorated further. The Swiss economy is expected to develop weakly in the near future due to the effects of the central bank's decision to end its franc-euro cap.

site_title: Asian shares mostly up after Wall St gains
summary: Asian markets rose Monday, following Wall Street's gains, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul advancing, while Shanghai and Sydney declined. The US economy grew at a 2.2% annual rate in the last quarter of 2014, beating expectations. Chinese economic stimulus hopes and interest rate cuts also boosted markets. Investors await key events, including Greece's bailout reform proposals and US jobs data, which will influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans.

site_title: Singapore delivers phase 1 of master plan to Andhra Pradesh government
summary: Singapore has delivered phase one of a master plan for Andhra Pradesh's new capital city, covering 7,325 square kilometers. The plan, developed by Surbana International Consultants and Jurong Consultants, aims to enhance connectivity and protect agricultural zones while promoting transit-oriented urban development. The plan was delivered during Indian Chief Minister Chandrababu Naidu's visit to Singapore in March 2015. It is the first of a three-stage master plan for the Indian city.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: No subletting of HDB industrial properties from June 1, 2015
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore announced that as of June 1, 2015, no new subletting of HDB industrial properties will be allowed. Existing tenants with approved subletting agreements can renew up to December 31, 2017, to adjust their business operations. The revised policy aims to promote responsible use of scarce industrial land and align with other government agencies.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.99% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 0.99% higher on Monday, following a four-day losing streak on Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 241.26 points to 24,727.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.67% to 3,715.93. This positive trend also affected the Shenzhen Composite Index, which added 0.29% to 1,941.20. site_title: China's Zhou says PBOC has room to act on growth slowdown
summary: China's central bank chief, Zhou Xiaochuan, stated that the nation's growth rate has slowed "a bit" too much and that policy makers have room to respond with interest rates and monetary measures. site_title: Xi says bigger China role in global economy benefits neighbours

site_title: US millennials reject their parents' treasures

site_title: The crucial task of succession planning
summary: Business leaders must prioritize succession planning to ensure a company's longevity and sustainability. Effective succession planning is crucial for a company's continued success, and it is essential for board members to take this task seriously to ensure the organization's future.

site_title: Lessons from behavioural finance
summary: Investors are often held back by cognitive and emotional biases, causing them to miss out on investment opportunities. Cognitive biases, such as confirmation bias and anchoring bias, lead investors to hold onto assets for too long or make irrational decisions. Emotional biases, including loss aversion, endowment effect, and regret-aversion, also prevent investors from taking calculated risks. To overcome these biases, investors can implement a systematic process to screen investment decisions and ask themselves critical questions. Awareness of these biases is key to becoming a more informed and rational investor.

site_title: Deflation danger rings wake-up call to east Europe central banks

site_title: Dow Chemical to sell most chlorine assets in US$5b deal
