site_title: VMware's solution looks to solve cloud headache
summary: VMware has announced a unified platform to solve cloud integration issues, enabling businesses to create a consistent environment and focus on reaping the benefits of IT applications. The "one cloud, any application, any device" solution unites on-premise and public clouds with open management, allowing for rapid and automatic deployment and secure consumption of any application. This unified platform, built on VMware's software-defined data centre technologies, aims to provide a flexible, agile, and fast IT service delivery model, reducing the risks of data loss and downtime, and positioning IT as an enabler rather than a barrier to business growth.

site_title: Greenback heading for 9th month of gains
summary: The US dollar is on track for its 9th consecutive month of gains, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index advancing 1.6% in March to 1,190.89. Fed Chair Janet Yellen expects interest rates to rise this year, supporting the dollar's climb. The greenback has risen 5.3% this year, the longest monthly streak since 2004, while the euro has fallen 2.7% to US$1.0889. Global peers are loosening policy, with the yen bucking the trend, amid an escalation in conflict in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last Friday that she expects rates to rise this year, supporting the greenback, which is headed for its ninth straight monthly advance.

site_title: Government grant to kick-start mega London housing project
summary: A US$300 million government grant has been awarded to the Canary Wharf Group to kick-start a mega London housing project. The project, which has been in development for over 10 years, will transform a 455,000 square metre area of London's Canary Wharf with 607 affordable homes, office blocks, shops, parks, and public squares. The grant will enable work to start on the project, which is expected to deliver thousands of homes and job opportunities, and is part of the UK government's long-term economic plan to boost housebuilding.

images.alt_text: Canary Wharf Group will receive a US$300 million loan from the government to pay for the infrastructure needed to unlock the site.

site_title: PM Lee: "The light that has guided us all these years has been extinguished."
summary: Singapore's founding father Lee Kuan Yew, a key figure in the country's development, has passed away. In a eulogy, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described the loss as "a dark week for Singapore" and said "the light that has guided us all these years has been extinguished." He paid tribute to his father's life and legacy, who "lived and breathed Singapore all his life." The funeral service was held at the University Cultural Centre of the National University of Singapore.

site_title: Weak capital ties Italian banks to bad debts
summary: Italian banks are struggling to sell billions of euros of bad debts, hindering their ability to support new lending and help the country recover from a three-year recession. The bad debts, which tripled as a share of total lending since 2007, are being sold at a significant discount. Banks are unwilling to weaken their capital position further, making it challenging for them to support new lending and contribute to the country's economic recovery. The issue is rooted in the banks' weak capital ties to the bad debts.

site_title: Silicon Valley set to face more gender bias suits despite Pao loss
summary: Silicon Valley is expected to face more lawsuits alleging gender bias, sexual harassment, and retaliation despite the recent loss of Ellen Pao's suit against Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Several lawsuits are already in the pipeline, indicating that companies in the tech industry are not yet off the hook. This trend suggests that the issue of gender bias in Silicon Valley is ongoing and may require continued efforts to address and prevent such incidents.

site_title: To each, his own way of bidding goodbye
summary: World leaders and the Lee family bid farewell to Singapore's founding father Lee Kuan Yew on a rainy Sunday, honoring his vision, wise counsel, and passion for the country. The somber send-off came after a life dedicated to the nation's growth and development. The event marked the end of an era, leaving a legacy that continues to shape Singapore's future.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew "lived and breathed Singapore" all his life: PM Lee
summary: Singapore has lost its founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, who "lived and breathed" the country. At the state funeral, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong recalled his father's life story, highlighting his efforts to build Singapore into a successful nation through discipline, education, and economic growth. The late leader's principles and ideals will continue to guide the government, inspiring Singaporeans and others for generations to come. Tributes were paid by President Tony Tan, Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong, and other speakers, hailing Mr Lee's achievements in pulling together a strong team and ensuring a corruption-free government.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Business leaders say LKY's legacy will live on
summary: Business leaders in Singapore have called for ways to preserve the legacy of former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, who passed away on March 23, 2015. Suggestions include renaming the airport, establishing a centre for learning, and creating Lee Kuan Yew bursaries for every university course. Some also proposed conserving his home at 38 Oxley Road as a national monument. The leaders emphasized the importance of holding on to Lee's values, such as intolerance of corruption and a thirst for learning, and living up to his spirit in the country's ethos and actions.

site_title: Cocoa players' mergers pose risk to farmers
summary: Major cocoa and chocolate players' mergers may reduce farmers' bargaining power, threatening the sector's future. The World Cocoa Producer Association warns that these mergers could lower incomes to levels that could harm farmers. Mergers, such as Cadbury and Mondelez's fusion and Barry Callebaut's acquisition, have already reduced farmers' choices and bargaining power. The industry must ensure that farmers benefit from these expansions, or risk farmers cutting down cocoa trees and planting other commodities.

site_title: The security officers cared for Mr Lee like he was their own father
summary: Singapore's first prime minister Lee Kuan Yew's personal security detail provided 24/7 care, treating him like their own father, according to his daughter Lee Wei Ling. She praised the security officers in her eulogy, thanking them for being an integral part of her father's life. Lee Kuan Yew passed away, and his daughter shared stories of his loving relationship with his security officers, who also cared for him like family.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: New streaming apps could boost citizen journalism
summary: New streaming apps like Meerkat and Periscope are changing the way people get news by delivering live video through Twitter to anyone online. The apps' widespread use, combined with improved networks and smartphones, could boost citizen journalism by providing an intimate connection between viewers and the breaking news event. Experts say live video can shed new light on key events, such as police shootings or human rights abuses, and could eventually bring more abuses to light, making it harder for governments to shut down information flows.

site_title: Mr Lee Kuan Yew begins final journey across Singapore
summary: Singapore's founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew began his final journey across the country on March 29, 2015, after lying in state at Parliament House since March 25. His coffin was carried by eight pallbearers onto a ceremonial gun carriage, driven by a Land Rover, as he was taken to his final resting place.

site_title: Another jerky road to nowhere for US market
summary: US stocks have experienced a stagnant recovery, with major indices failing to register two consecutive gains in 29 days, the longest streak since 1931. Despite wild swings, the S&P 500 remains almost flat for the year, up 0.1%. Economic data, oil prices, and the Federal Reserve's rate hike schedule are contributing to the uncertainty, with traders reassessing everything through the lens of the Fed's rate hike schedule. A strong US dollar is hurting commodities prices, and analysts warn of a 5% decline in S&P 500 first-quarter earnings due to currency and oil price impacts.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: Over 250 beneficiaries from five charities will participate in Project Cheer, a mentorship program where teens will run activities with children from various charities. The project aims to promote volunteerism and create a chain of giving. Additionally, the Gentle Warrior's Trust was launched, providing grants and financial aid to applicants who wish to develop their skills and uplift their communities. The SPD Charity Show 2015 raised over S$4.8 million for people with disabilities, while Singapore aims to ink a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by end-2025.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China to cut 80m T of steel capacity over 2015-17: official
summary: China plans to cut 80 million tonnes of excess steel capacity from 2015-2017 to tackle a massive supply glut, aiming to reduce the number of steel enterprises to around 300 from over 500. The goal is to strengthen market position and improve competitiveness. China also aims to achieve zero energy growth and a 2017 cut in emissions. The steel sector faces its worst crisis due to slowing economic growth, pollution concerns, and changes in consumption patterns.

site_title: Braving the rain, thousands throng the streets to bid farewell to Mr Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Thousands of people braved the rain to bid farewell to Singapore's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, as his funeral procession made its way from Parliament House to the National University of Singapore campus. The cortege, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, featured a 15.4km route, including a 21-gun salute, a "Missing Man" formation by Black Knight jets, and a ceremonial sailpast by navy vessels. The funeral service, attended by eulogies and a minute of silence, will last over three hours.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: The skies cried for Mr Lee on his final journey
summary: More than 100,000 Singaporeans gathered to bid farewell to the country's first prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, as his cortege traveled from Parliament House to the National University of Singapore campus. The grand procession, which included a 21-gun salute and a ceremonial sailpast, was held on a rainy Sunday. Eulogies were delivered by leaders and former leaders from 23 countries, including Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and former US President Bill Clinton. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described his father's principles and ideals as guiding Singapore for generations to come.

images.alt_text: The cortege leaving Parliament House in the Central Business District to begin the 75-minute journey to the National University of Singapore campus in Kent Ridge where the funeral service was held.

The funeral procession making its way along Jalan Bukit Merah. Throughout the 15.4km route, Singaporeans called out Mr Lee's name when they saw his casket, which was covered by the national flag and protected by a glass case.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: He was 'a good man, a good husband, and a good father and grandfather'
summary: Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's first prime minister, died on February 4, 2015. His son, Lee Hsien Yang, eulogized him at his state funeral, describing him as a "good man, a good husband, and a good father and grandfather." Nearly 455,000 people paid their respects to Lee Kuan Yew during his four-day state funeral, with 1.2 million more visiting community tribute sites. The Lee family thanked Singaporeans for their affection and respect, acknowledging that their loss is also the nation's loss. Lee Kuan Yew's legacy was marked by his relentless drive to improve Singapore and his dedication to public service, earning him the nickname "LKY."

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Tributes from Chiam, Mahathir
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and opposition leader Chiam See Tong paid tribute to Singapore's first Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, who passed away on March 23, 2015. Mahathir expressed sadness over Lee's passing, despite their differences in opinion, and recalled instances of their mutual respect and cooperation. Chiam, who had clashed with Lee in Parliament, praised Singapore's good fortune in having him as its first PM, calling him a great leader and debater. The outpouring of tributes, with over 100,000 people filing into Parliament House, marked the end of an era in Southeast Asian politics.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Fed focuses on shadow banking as it gauges financial risk
summary: The Federal Reserve is focusing on the shadow banking system as it assesses financial risk, particularly after the latest round of bank tests. The US$25 trillion shadow banking sector, comprising money-market mutual funds, hedge funds, and brokerages, is seen as a significant source of credit and a potential risk to the financial system. The Fed's financial stability committee is considering measures such as stricter margin requirements to limit borrowed money, and policymakers are working to clarify regulatory authority over the shadow banking sector. This effort aims to mitigate potential negative impacts and ensure the stability of the financial system.

site_title: Japan now attractive to foreign investors, says Jetro
summary: Japan has become more attractive to foreign investors, with the yen's depreciation lowering business costs and boosting inward foreign investment. Office rents in Tokyo are now below those in major Asian cities, and expatriate rents are significantly lower. The country has also loosened regulations, with one-stop investment centers set to be established. Foreign firms have taken advantage of the weaker yen, making acquisitions and increasing investment in Japan. The total foreign direct investment in Japan has nearly tripled to 1.02 trillion yen, driven by foreign investments in the financial sector and improved English language skills among Japanese.

site_title: Dow Chemical to sell most chlorine assets in US$5b deal
summary: Dow Chemical Co. is selling its majority chlorine assets to Olin Corp in a $5 billion deal, making Olin the world's largest producer of chlor-alkali. The move is part of Dow's efforts to shed low-margin assets and focus on more profitable businesses. This sale follows Dow's previous announcement to sell its chlorine operations in 2013 and averts a proxy fight with activist investor Dan Loeb. Dow's CEO, Andrew Liveris, has stated that there could be more deals in the next 12 months as the company simplifies its joint ventures.

site_title: Dollar's 9th month of gains signals faith in Fed remains intact
summary: The US dollar has gained for its 9th consecutive month, with a 2.7% increase to $1.0889 against the euro in March, marking the longest monthly streak in history. The Federal Reserve, led by Chair Janet Yellen, expects interest rates to rise this year, supporting the dollar's strength. Despite a temporary decline after the Fed's rate hike forecast, traders expect the dollar to continue its upward trend, with some speculators betting on further gains.

images.alt_text: After the Federal Reserve tempered market expectations for a mid-year interest-rate increase last week, sending the dollar to its biggest weekly decline since 2011, traders refocused on the bigger picture: the US central bank is still moving toward monetary tightening as global peers loosen policy.

site_title: Brazil says will join China-backed Asia investment bank
summary: Brazil has accepted China's invitation to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) as a founding member, marking a significant step in China's global influence. The move comes after the US had warned against the new institution, but European allies Britain, France, Germany, and Italy have announced their participation. Brazil's decision is seen as a challenge to the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, and follows a shift in the Obama administration's stance on the matter.

site_title: 'I made a lot of textbook mistakes'
summary: A final-year student at Singapore Management University, Ronald Sim, shares his experiences with investing, despite making several textbook mistakes in his early days. Sim, 25, dabbled in technical analysis and lost money on stocks like Singtel and Olam International. He attributes his interest in investing to his parents' thriftiness and his own desire to learn from books. Sim now focuses on small-cap and mid-cap stocks, with a preference for consumer and real estate sectors. His experiences serve as a reminder that investing is a learning process, and it's essential to be patient and informed.

images.alt_text: "I am looking a lot more at small-capitalisation stocks these days, some mid-cap, less-covered names. Companies I prefer are those which I have an understanding of, like consumer, real estate, financials, manufacturing, telcos." - Ronald Sim (above)

site_title: Update: 1 in 10 Singapore citizens queue to pay respects to Lee Kuan Yew
summary: More than 330,000 Singapore citizens, or 10% of the population, have visited the parliament to pay respects to late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew ahead of his cremation this weekend. The surge of mourners forced the government to temporarily suspend access to the parliament for crowd safety. Due to the large number of people, mourners could only spend a few seconds in front of Mr. Lee's casket, with many bowing quickly before being ushered out.

images.alt_text: More than 330,000 people, equivalent to 10 per cent of Singapore's citizen population, have visited the city-state's parliament to pay their respects to late prime minister Lee Kuan Yew ahead of his cremation this weekend, officials said Saturday.

site_title: Carnival orders 9 cruise ships from Germany, Italy
summary: Carnival Cruise Line has ordered nine new cruise ships from German and Italian shipbuilders, with deliveries set to take place between 2019 and 2022. The new ships will cater to established cruise markets in North America and Europe, as well as newer venues like China. The company reported a profit of $49 million for the quarter ending February 28, up from a loss of $20 million a year ago, due to lower fuel costs. Carnival projects earnings of $2.30-$2.50 per share for 2015, up from $1.93 last year.

images.alt_text: CRUISE giant Carnival, which reported better earnings on lower fuel costs, has ordered nine new cruise ships from shipbuilders in Germany and Italy.

site_title: China central bank governor calls for vigilance on deflation
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan warned of the need to be vigilant for deflation, citing declining inflation and slowing global economic growth. China's inflation rate quickened to 1.4% in February, while producer prices declined 4.8% in the same month. The country's economic growth target for this year has been set at around 7%, the slowest in 24 years. Policymakers are watching for signs of deflation and are prepared to take more aggressive easing measures if needed. China has already cut interest rates twice since November.

site_title: Bold flavours in an east-west menu
summary: A new restaurant, Adrift, is showcasing mod-Indian cuisine with a unique east-west menu. The restaurant aims to balance flavors without overwhelming the palate, addressing the "buffet effect" often seen in shared-plates concepts. This approach allows for a diverse and exciting dining experience.

site_title: Oil dives 4.7% on easing Yemen worries
summary: Oil prices plummeted 4.7% on Friday, reversing gains from a two-day surge, as tensions over the Saudi-led airstrikes in Yemen eased. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell $2.43 to $48.87 a barrel, while global benchmark Brent North Sea crude dropped $2.78 to $56.41 a barrel. The decline follows a sharp rise on Wednesday and Thursday as Yemen's unrest escalated, with the Saudi-led coalition continuing airstrikes in support of President Abedrabbo Mansour Hadi.

site_title: Abbott: Australia set to join China-led investment bank
summary: Australia is set to join China's development bank, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), as one of its founding members. The move follows a pledge of cooperation from the Asian Development Bank and support from over 30 nations, including the UK and Switzerland. Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott stated the country is joining due to the bank's potential to provide tens of billions of dollars in loans to the region. Key matters to be resolved include governance principles and preventing any one country from controlling the bank. The US remains opposed to the AIIB.

site_title: Singapore reopens queue for Lee Kuan Yew mourners
summary: Singapore reopens a massive queue for mourners to pay their last respects to founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew after a temporary suspension due to safety concerns. The queue, which had been closed since Friday, was reopened after seven hours, with over 290,000 people having paid their respects to Mr Lee since Wednesday. Mr Lee, who led Singapore to independence in 1965, is to be given full state honors before being cremated on Sunday.

site_title: Chevron exits Caltex Australia stake for US$3.7b
summary: US energy giant Chevron sold its 50% stake in Australian refiner Caltex Australia Ltd for US$3.7 billion, Asia's largest block deal this year. The stake was sold at A$35 per share, a 9.7% discount to the closing price, following strong demand from offshore institutional investors. The sale is part of Chevron's exit from Australia's refining industry, following Royal Dutch Shell and BP's previous sales. The deal comes as the industry grapples with low oil prices, ageing equipment, and high costs.

site_title: Update: UK and Switzerland follow Brazil to China-backed Asia investment bank
summary: China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has welcomed its 30th founding member, with the UK and Switzerland joining alongside Brazil, which accepted China's invitation the previous day. The US had warned against the new institution, but European allies Britain, France, Germany, and Italy have joined, leading the US administration to reassess its stance. China's President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for "pragmatic cooperation" in financial fields, while Brazil expressed interest in participating in the initiative, seen as a challenge to the World Bank and Asian Development Bank.

site_title: In swansong, US FDA chief defends drug approval process
summary: US FDA Commissioner Margaret Hamburg defended the agency's drug approval standards in her final speech, citing a 50-year history of evidence-based medicine as a result of high standards. Critics, including lawmakers, have pushed for faster approvals of experimental drugs, but Hamburg disagreed, stating that innovation doesn't matter if the product doesn't work. The FDA has proposed allowing pharmaceutical companies to distribute medical literature, but Hamburg opposed an approach that undermines the incentive for studies to be done, citing patient harm from relying on incomplete information.

site_title: US oil rig decline smallest since December: Baker Hughes
summary: US oil rigs declined by 12 this week to 813, the smallest decline since December, according to Baker Hughes. This marks the 16th consecutive week of a decline, with the number of rigs falling to the lowest level since 2011. Despite the reduction, US oil production reached a 9.4 million barrels per day high last week, driven by increased efficiency and focus on productive acreage. Analysts expect the US oil rig count to continue decreasing in the second quarter before rebounding in the fourth quarter, allowing shale production to grow by 500,000 bpd this year.

site_title: Takata sued for US$1.9b in Canada over faulty airbags
summary: Canadian drivers have launched three class action lawsuits against Takata, a Japanese auto supplier, seeking US$1.9 billion in damages over faulty airbags linked to at least five fatalities worldwide. The lawsuits, filed by two Canadian law firms and a fourth considering it, aim to compensate for personal injuries, car repairs, and lost vehicle value. Approximately 400,000 vehicles, produced by major automakers, are being recalled due to the risk of explosive airbags. The plaintiffs claim Takata's airbags are "like grenades going off," posing a significant danger to drivers and passengers.

site_title: Germanwings crash circumstance means recoveries 'uncapped'
summary: The families of 150 Germanwings passengers and crew who died in a plane crash in the French Alps can seek unlimited recoveries from the airline, as the co-pilot's alleged deliberate actions render the carrier liable without defenses. Investigators found a torn doctor's note indicating Andreas Lubitz, the 27-year-old co-pilot, was unfit for work on the day of the crash, and he allegedly locked the pilot out of the cockpit. Authorities believe Lubitz hid his medical condition from his employer. The airline's liability is considered uncapped, as the actions were deemed irrational and without defense.

site_title: JPMorgan retains top spot in investment banking but revenues slip
summary: JPMorgan retained its top spot in investment banking in 2014, with US$22 billion in revenue, despite a 6% decline. The bank's trading in fixed income, currencies, and commodities saw the largest drop, 12.8%. Morgan Stanley overtook JPMorgan in equity business, while US banks dominated the top spots, with Goldman Sachs second and Citigroup and Bank of America Merrill Lynch sharing third.

site_title: Greek reforms will put economy on track: Athens
summary: Greece is set to present reform proposals to its creditors, expected to bring in 3.0 billion euros in revenue without austerity measures. The proposals aim to put the country's economy on track, with a 1.4% growth forecast this year. A deal is needed by next week to unblock stalled EU-IMF loans and prevent debt payments from being delayed. Greece's government has repeatedly warned its creditors that it will not continue to service its debt without help from the EU. The proposals are part of the government's efforts to crack down on tax evasion and corruption.

images.alt_text: Greece said Friday the reform proposals it will soon present to its creditors will put the country's economy on track without the pain of austerity.

site_title: Argentina suspends Citibank Argentina from capital market operations
summary: Argentina's securities regulator suspended Citibank Argentina from capital market operations due to its deal with litigating hedge funds in US courts, violating local laws. The move aims to protect holders of restructured debt from potential risks. The leftist government is concerned Citigroup's departure may hinder interest payments on debt restructured after its 2002 default. The regulator described the situation as "grave danger and uncertainty" for restructured debt holders.

site_title: AllianceBernstein to launch fund of funds with daily liquidity
summary: AllianceBernstein plans to launch a hedge fund of funds with daily liquidity in Singapore later this year, driven by Asia's growing demand for dollar asset diversification. This strategy, led by Ajai Kaul, will provide investors with daily liquidity, a feature not yet available outside the US. The move aims to tap into Asia's growing wealth and investment market, where retail investors are expected to drive significant growth in exchange-traded funds (ETFs).

site_title: Opel sesame
summary: Opel has qualified for entry into Singapore's Category A with its latest Meriva model, featuring a new 1.364cc turbocharged engine producing 120 hp. The compact MPV has undergone a facelift with redesigned headlamps, a new front grille, and improved interior materials. The Meriva boasts a spacious interior, good headroom, and rear legroom, along with a smooth and refined drive. With a price tag of $109,800, the Meriva is expected to compete with Japanese mass market models in the local market.

site_title: Coutts International to be sold to UBP
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) Group has agreed to sell its international wealth management business, Coutts International, to Swiss bank Union Bancaire Privee (UBP) for between $600 million and $800 million. The sale, which has been in the works since August 2014, will lift UBP's market share at home and increase its presence in Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. The sale is expected to close by early 2016, with most of the business transferring to UBP by the end of the year.

site_title: Cycle Asia Singapore event cancelled
summary: CYCLE Asia Singapore event has been cancelled due to inability to secure a new title sponsor, organisers Spectrum Worldwide (SWW) announced. The event was originally scheduled for April 10-12 but will now take place in 2016. Participants can opt for full refund, credit for next year's event, or transfer to Cycle Asia Kuala Lumpur. Those who have incurred unrecoverable travel expenses can contact SWW for a case-by-case discussion. All participants will still receive their cycling gear.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: 3G to streamline operations after Kraft, Heinz merger
summary: 3G Capital Partners, the owner of Kraft Foods Group and HJ Heinz Co, plans to streamline operations after the merger, aiming to save US$1.5 billion annually by 2017. The company will implement a zero-based budgeting strategy, scrutinizing every expense, and likely exceed its savings target. This approach, similar to its previous strategy with Heinz, involves reducing headcount, eliminating perks, and slashing mundane expenses. Analysts expect significant cost savings and a leaner business model.

site_title: Whack, bam, kapow!
summary: The WWE has announced a one-night-only show in Singapore on July 2, 2015, marking the company's return to the city-state after a 8-year absence. Tickets for the event, featuring stars like John Cena and Brock Lesnar, have sold out quickly, with the most expensive ringside seats selling out. The writer, a WWE fan, is excited to attend the event, citing the energy and excitement of live wrestling matches, and hopes to catch a glimpse of the wrestlers and get autographs.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Fed weighs rate hike 'this year': Yellen
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said the Fed is considering raising interest rates this year, despite the US economy's slow recovery. The Fed is taking a "gradualist approach" and may raise rates in mid-year if the economy is strong enough. Yellen noted that a rate hike would slow the economy's pace but would not halt its progress. The Fed's growth forecast was lowered to 2.3-2.7% for this year due to sluggish consumer spending and housing.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve is considering raising near-zero interest rates this year even though this may slow the US recovery, Fed Chair Janet Yellen said Friday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.58% and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.55%. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index added 0.21%. The mixed performance followed a rally in Asia, where mining and healthcare stocks boosted shares. US stocks also reached fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Friday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index ending the day down 0.58 per cent at 6,855.02 points.

site_title: New apps to help business get in step with mobile customers
summary: Apple and IBM have partnered to develop mobile apps for businesses, with the goal of creating 100 apps by the end of 2015. The apps aim to equip customer service employees with iPads to serve shoppers in-store and pre-order products online. Companies like Boots UK, Citi, and American Eagle Outfitters are already using the apps, which provide employees with access to customer profiles and allow them to interact with customers on their own terms. The partnership offers a range of features, including design expertise, remote technical support, and integration with back-office systems.

site_title: Cosco lands contract for 7 container vessels
summary: Cosco Corporation (Singapore) has secured a contract with Maersk Line to build seven 3,600 twenty-foot equivalent (TEU) container vessels, scheduled for delivery between April 2017 and November 2017. The contract price remains confidential. This follows a 32% drop in Cosco's 2014 net profit to S$20.9 million, despite a 21% rise in revenue. The company's order book stood at US$8.4 billion as of December 2014.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US investors rushing into European property
summary: US investors are purchasing European commercial property at a record pace due to the dollar's eight-month rally and struggling economies on the continent, making properties cheap. Last year's US spending on European commercial real estate was near its 2007 peak, and a strong first quarter may break this record. The surge in US investment is driven by the dollar's appreciation and low interest rates, making European properties more affordable. This trend is expected to continue as US investors seek yield in a low-yielding market.

site_title: China's Xi preaches peace in key note address
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the importance of peace and stability in his keynote address, stating that turmoil at home or abroad is not in China's interests. He pledged that Beijing will adhere to its path of peaceful development, avoiding the turmoil and war that China has experienced in the past 100 years. Xi also proposed dialogue among Asian civilizations and suggested signing more friendship treaties with neighboring countries. He concluded that any country using force to achieve development goals will ultimately fail and China will continue to develop peacefully.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping said on Saturday that turmoil at home or abroad were not in the country's interests as its bitter past has shown, pledging that Beijing will never stray from its proclaimed path of peaceful development.

site_title: Fitch cuts Greece's rating amid default worries
summary: Ratings firm Fitch cut Greece's credit rating by two notches to "CCC" due to concerns that the country is close to defaulting on its sovereign debt. Fitch expects the Greek government to survive the current cash squeeze without running arrears, but warned of heightened risks. The downgrade comes as the new anti-austerity government seeks a deal with EU and IMF creditors by next month to unblock EU-IMF funds. Fitch slashed its growth forecast for Greece to 0.5% for this year, citing damage to investor confidence and worsening liquidity conditions.

images.alt_text: Ratings firm Fitch cut Greece's credit rating Friday amid worries that the eurozone country is running perilously close to defaulting on its sovereign debt.

site_title: Singapore festival opens in Paris, marking 50 years of diplomatic ties
summary: The three-month-long Singapore Festival in Paris was launched with a theatre piece and art exhibition at the Palais de Tokyo art centre, marking 50 years of diplomatic ties between Singapore and France. The festival celebrates the connection between the two countries, dating back to Sir Stamford Raffles' arrival in Singapore with two French naturalists in the early 19th century. A minute's silence was observed for Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's founding father, before the event.

site_title: Economy expands at 2.2% pace in 4th quarter
summary: The US economy expanded at a 2.2% annualized pace in the fourth quarter, driven by a 4.4% gain in household consumption, the largest since 2006. This growth rate matches the Commerce Department's previous estimate and follows a 2.4% expansion for the year, the most since 2010. Despite harsh winter weather and a stronger dollar, economists predict the economy will continue to support demand in the coming months, with one economist stating the consumer will "continue to see aggregate income growth."

site_title: Remembering our founding father
summary: A large crowd in Singapore paid respects to a founding father, with many waiting up to eight hours in the sun and shedding tears in gratitude. The outpouring of emotions was the largest in the nation's history. The event marked a significant milestone in the country's history, from self-government to merger to becoming an independent nation. The crowd's emotional response was a testament to the founding father's impact on the nation.

site_title: Google to pay new CFO more than US$70m
summary: Google has agreed to pay new CFO Ruth Porat more than $70 million, making her one of the highest-paid CFOs in the industry. Porat will receive a $5 million signing bonus, a $25 million stock grant, and a $40 million biennial stock grant, in addition to an annual base salary of $650,000. Her hiring aims to bring fiscal discipline to the company, which is under pressure to trim costs while investing in new businesses.

site_title: Germanwings co-pilot suffered serious depression
summary: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz, who crashed a plane into a French mountainside killing 150 people, suffered from serious depression and was still receiving medical treatment. Lubitz, 28, locked his captain out of the cockpit and deliberately sent the plane into the Alps, in what appears to be an act of suicide and mass murder. The incident has raised questions over how he was cleared to fly despite his mental health issues. Airlines are reviewing their cockpit policies, with many announcing plans to require two crew members in the cockpit at all times.

site_title: Intel in talks with Altera on tie-up
summary: US tech giant Intel is in talks with Altera on a potential tie-up, aiming to broaden Altera's product line amid growing demand for Internet-connected devices. The deal, if successful, would be Intel's largest acquisition, valued at $10.4 billion. Altera's expertise in designing processors for various devices would help Intel diversify its product line, particularly in the face of slumping demand for personal computers. The acquisition would also enable Intel to expand its offerings beyond traditional PC chips.

site_title: Housing a new purpose
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Residential properties in Singapore are being reimagined as more than just homes. Seven luxury properties by AN Developments are being showcased in an art exhibition, with artworks by Banksy, Andy Warhol, and Blek Le Rat. The "Jalan Bahasa" project combines fantastic architecture with art, offering a unique experience for potential homeowners. Another property, Casa Gessi, is an Italian luxury bathroom and kitchen fittings store in a Victorian semi-detached house, while Workhouse is a co-working space in a shophouse in Little India. Meanwhile, Within is a floral studio in a conservation terrace home, offering workshops and a peaceful retreat.

site_title: German court dismisses hedge funds' suit against Porsche
summary: A German court has dismissed a lawsuit filed by hedge funds seeking 1.2 billion euros in damages against Porsche SE over its 2008 attempt to acquire Volkswagen. The hedge funds claimed Porsche SE had concealed a plan to acquire Volkswagen, but the court ruled against them. This is the fifth time the complaint has been dismissed, with Porsche SE labeling it an "important victory". The hedge funds can still file an appeal with Germany's Federal Court of Justice.

site_title: US: Stocks snap 4-day slide
summary: US stocks rose Friday, snapping a four-day losing streak, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 31.53 points (0.18%) to 17,709.76. The S&P 500 rose 4.62 (0.22%) to 2,060.77, and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 27.86 (0.57%) to 4,891.22. US economic growth in the fourth quarter was reported at 2.2%, below analyst projections. The market's rally was seen as a pause after four down days, with traders shrugging off worries about the Yemen crisis and excessive equity valuations.

site_title: BlackRock disposes entire 2.4% stake in KepLand
summary: BlackRock has sold its entire 2.4% stake in Keppel Land, disposing of 37.3 million shares at S$4.38 each and 19,000 shares at S$4.54 each. This sale comes after concerns that BlackRock was "hoarding" the shares for unknown reasons. Keppel Corp's stake in Keppel Land now stands at 93.4%, just shy of the 95.5% threshold for a compulsory acquisition. The sale does not affect BlackRock's ownership, and the stock price fell to S$4.52 on Friday.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of the release of GDP data. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positivity despite ongoing tariff uncertainty. The split views on the Federal Reserve's future actions also contributed to the rally. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and PSC received a mandatory offer from Popiah king Sam Goi at S$0.40 per share.

site_title: Charming enclave
summary: Keong Saik Road in Singapore has become a hub for hip food and beverage establishments, drawing in visitors with its unique blend of old and new Singapore. The street has gained a reputation for cool, attracting businesses like Restaurant Ember, Potato Head Folk, and Cure. New businesses, including The Working Capitol, a hybrid space with co-working areas and eateries, have sprouted up, boosting gentrification. Founders of Neon Pigeon and Lollapalooza praise the area's charm, citing its diversity and energy. However, some, like co-founder of Lollapalooza Pang Hian Tee, express concern that the area's rapid gentrification may lead to the loss of existing charm.

site_title: Facebook's Internet drone plan gets boost
summary: Facebook successfully tested a solar-powered drone prototype, dubbed "Aquila," in Britain, marking a milestone in the company's internet.org project to bring online access to 10% of the world's population living in remote areas. The drone, capable of flying at altitudes of 18,300 meters and remaining aloft for months, is designed to beam down internet service to remote communities. Facebook aims to connect one billion to three billion people to the internet in the coming years, with plans for efficient data centers and AI-powered technology.

site_title: India makes Sunday national day of mourning for Mr Lee
summary: India has declared Sunday a national day of mourning for Singapore's first prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, in a mark of respect. The Indian government will fly the national flag at half-mast and there will be no official entertainment on the day. The send-off for Lee's funeral, attended by world leaders, will include a 21-gun salute and a salute by the Black Knights.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Banks, Singtel help STI gain 1.1% for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% to 3,450.10 over the week, driven by external factors such as Wall Street gyrations, Middle East conflicts, and European quantitative easing. Banks, Singtel, and offshore marine-sector plays benefited from quarter-ending window-dressing. Noble Group's shares recovered after three negative reports from Iceberg Research, with DBS Vickers noting the law of diminishing returns had set in. The European Central Bank's monetary developments and bank lending surveys also influenced the market, with ABN Amro predicting money flowing into the euro zone.

site_title: By gum, the West is wrong about Singapore
summary: Singaporeans are defending their country's reputation after Western media praised its efficiency and productivity, but criticized its lack of "charm" and "personality." The author, who became a Singaporean citizen, argues that Singapore's strict policies and high standards are a result of its unique history and culture, rather than a lack of creativity or freedom. They suggest that Westerners are judging Singapore through a biased lens, comparing it unfavorably to other countries. Singaporeans are embracing their country's no-nonsense attitude and demanding more self-determination, paving the way for potential changes in governance.

site_title: Bears piling back into VIX note
summary: Speculators are piling into the iPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures ETN, a six-year-old security that lets them bet on market volatility. The trade, known as VXX, has seen its shares outstanding reach an all-time high and is poised for an eighth straight week of inflows, with the S&P 500 flat for the year. Bears are betting that concerns such as declining corporate profits and conflict in the Middle East could lead to market volatility, which has been mostly absent.

images.alt_text: BANKING ON VOLATILITY: Traders working in the VIX options pit on the floor of the CBOE .
BANKING ON VOLATILITY: Sustained gains in US stocks have proven elusive on the NYSE (above), with the S&P 500 having dropped 2.5% this week.

site_title: Sino Construction halts trading
summary: Sino Construction halted trading on March 27, 2015, pending an announcement. The company had previously announced the cancellation of its acquisition of Guildford Coal and a profit warning, leading to a downward spiral in its stock price. Sino Construction recorded a net loss of S$7 million in its latest quarter and saw revenue decline to S$1.12 million. The company's stock price had fallen to S$0.029, a significant drop from its peak in February. This development followed the resignation of several directors and the cancellation of its takeover bid.

site_title: Bourse link investors favour made-in-China stocks
summary: Mainland Chinese investors are favoring domestic shares over international ones, with a majority of their investments going into Chinese brokerages, banks, and state-backed companies. Since the Shanghai-Hong Kong exchange link's debut in November, Chinese investors have purchased a net 30.2 billion yuan of Hong Kong stocks, mostly at discounts. Despite the link's intention to introduce new investors to the Hong Kong market, Chinese investors are instead focusing on inward investment due to a strong domestic rally and lack of research on Hong Kong equities.

site_title: Low Keng Huat Q4 profit soars
summary: Low Keng Huat, a Singapore-based builder and developer, reported a sharp spike in its fourth-quarter net profit, rising to S$61.4 million, driven by completed projects such as Parkland Residences and Paya Lebar Square. The company's full-year net profit tripled to S$144.9 million. Despite losses in other business segments, the revenue from completed projects offset these losses. Low Keng Huat expects a soft market in the coming period due to cooling measures and land releases. The company declared a full-year payout of five Singapore cents per share.

site_title: German allies fed up as Tsipras fails to convince
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's visit to Berlin has fueled skepticism among German allies that he can resolve the financial impasse. Despite a good atmosphere in talks with Chancellor Angela Merkel, German policymakers remain unconvinced that Tsipras's government can deliver the necessary reforms. The deadline for Greece to submit its reform list is looming, with a possible Greek exit from the eurozone being considered by some, including Social Democratic lawmakers. Tsipras's government is under pressure to deliver, with the European Union and creditors waiting for progress.

site_title: Britain to release Prince Charles' 'black spider memos'
summary: The Supreme Court of Britain has ruled that secret letters from Prince Charles to government ministries, known as the "black spider memos," should be published. The letters, written in 2004 and 2005, reveal Prince Charles' outspoken views on various topics, including the environment and social issues. The decision is seen as a victory for media freedom and may lead to a necessary debate about the limits of royal interference, potentially affecting the monarchy's popularity.

site_title: BOJ's inflation target remains elusive with flat February data
summary: Japan's inflation target of 2% appears elusive after February's flat data, with the core annual rate of price increase falling to zero. The Bank of Japan's options for remedying the situation are diminishing, and financial markets expect further monetary easing to stimulate spending and price rises. However, this could exacerbate the yen's depreciation, hurting consumers and smaller firms. Despite weak consumer demand and capital investment trends, there are signs of hope, including improving wages and job availability, which could put upward pressure on inflation and personal consumption.

site_title: Chinese tourists can't get enough of Japan
summary: Chinese tourists continue to visit Japan despite the country's chilly diplomatic ties. In 2014, 2.4 million Chinese tourists visited Japan, an 83% increase from the previous year. The Japanese government has responded to the surge in applications by increasing Chinese consular staff. This apparent contradiction suggests that Chinese tourists are not swayed by the diplomatic tensions between Beijing and Tokyo, prioritizing their travel plans over national sentiments.

site_title: China plans IPO authority changes: report
summary: China's securities regulator plans to devolve authority over approving initial public offerings (IPOs) to the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges by May, aiming for a US-style "registration" system. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) will retain ultimate authority, but the exchanges will vet new listings. This shift is part of a bid to let market players determine IPO timing and pricing, and may be part of an anti-corruption campaign.

site_title: Posco backs out of US$12b India project
summary: South Korea's steelmaker Posco is backing out of a planned $12 billion steel complex in India due to local disputes and lease issues. The project, which was proposed over a decade ago, has been stalled since 2005. Posco is seeking a refund of $6 million paid for a 10% stake in a railway firm and has asked for the return of $6 million paid for a seven-acre land lease. The company's Indian unit overseeing the project has seen six employees resign, and Posco is waiting for further progress.

images.alt_text: LOSING STEAM: The Odisha project, the nation's biggest foreign investment, has failed to take off since 2005 because of resistance by local farmers and the failure to secure iron ore mining leases.

site_title: Architect of fashion
summary: COS, a fashion brand known for its understated approach, has collaborated with architect Andre Fu to present its Fall 2015 collection in a modernist space overlooking Hong Kong's Victoria Harbour. The gallery-like showcase, designed by Fu, features a melange of glass cubes, planes, and mirrors, and is meant to evoke a sense of urban regeneration. The collection itself is more theatrical than COS's usual minimalist style, with oversized proportions and sculptural shapes. The brand's focus on basics and details remains, with the introduction of a versatile, unisex white shirt. The collaboration marks a departure from COS's usual approach, but the brand's commitment to quality and design remains unchanged.

site_title: US consumer sentiment falls in March but above forecasts
summary: US consumer sentiment fell month-over-month in March to 93, beating forecasts of 92, but was below February's 95.4. This marks the first decline in consumer sentiment in five months.

site_title: Bad debts drive China banks to cut dividend payouts
summary: China's four largest banks have cut their dividend payouts due to rising bad debts from struggling exporters, coal companies, and manufacturers. Three of the banks, including Industrial & Commercial Bank of China Ltd (ICBC) and China Citic Bank Corp, have reduced their payment ratios for 2014, with ICBC's dropping to 33% from 35%. The cuts are part of a broader trend of Chinese banks adjusting to a slowing economy and increasing non-performing loans.

site_title: Yarra delights
summary: The Melbourne Food and Wine Festival showcased the city's diverse culinary scene, featuring over 1,500 diners at the world's longest lunch and various pop-up events. Restaurants like Mister Jennings, Burch and Purchese Sweet Studio, and Gewurzhaus Herb and Spice Merchants offered innovative and bold cuisine. The Lake House restaurant, set in the picturesque town of Daylesford, served cutting-edge modern Australian cuisine, with dishes like tempura quail in nori and berry-foraging-inspired desserts. The festival highlighted Melbourne's thriving food and wine culture, with a focus on local produce and expert chefs.

site_title: Petrobras to shut refinery on Okinawa island: Nikkei
summary: Brazil's state-owned oil company Petrobras is set to shut its 100,000-barrels-per-day refinery on Okinawa island, Japan, and build an import terminal to sell fuel products to other refiners. The move comes due to Japan's shrinking oil demand and a limited pool of potential buyers for the small refinery. Petrobras had previously considered upgrading the refinery and selling it to another oil marketer, but no sale materialized. The shutdown is part of the company's efforts to focus on domestic offshore oil discoveries amid a corruption scandal.

site_title: It's time for businesses to build a 'we economy'
summary: Businesses should form partnerships to create a "we economy" by leveraging digital technologies, as solo efforts are unlikely to fully utilize the potential of digital advancements. Accenture's 2015 Technology Vision notes that pioneering companies are tapping into each other's digital businesses, customers, and devices to expand joint business potential. This collaborative approach enables companies to offer connected suites of services people want, mirroring the way people use their smartphones to multitask, such as watching TV while playing video games. By forming partnerships, businesses can tap into new opportunities for growth in the digital era.

site_title: Apple chief to give away his wealth: report
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook plans to donate his estimated US$785 million fortune to charity, citing a desire to make a difference. Cook, who is not listed on the "Giving Pledge" website, aims to develop a more systematic approach to philanthropy. His decision follows the trend of the world's richest people, including billionaire financier Warren Buffett, who encourages the wealthy to give away at least half their worth in their lifetimes. Cook's philanthropic efforts are seen as a significant step towards creating positive change, particularly in areas such as the environment and civil rights.

images.alt_text: MR COOK: He told the magazine he is trying to develop a more 'systematic approach' to philanthropy that goes beyond writing cheques.

site_title: New UK, Australian properties beckon Singapore investors
summary: Singaporean investors are increasingly drawn to UK and Australian properties, despite potential changes in the two countries' real estate markets. Developers are showcasing projects in London, including The Atlas Building and West Grove, with prices starting from £512,000 for a London studio. In Melbourne, Royal Como is set to launch with prices ranging from £465,000 for a one-bedroom apartment to £6.9 million for a four-bedroom penthouse. Investors may be attracted to these properties due to the UK's 18-28% capital gains tax and Australia's lower foreign buyer fees compared to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Personal reflections on a nation builder like no other
summary: A former derivatives banker recounts his personal experience with Singapore's transformation under Lee Kuan Yew, a nation builder who prioritized trust and serving its people. The author, who later became a Singaporean citizen, was impressed by the country's efficiency, trustworthiness, and community spirit. He credits Lee's emphasis on trust as a key factor in Singapore's success, citing examples such as streamlined immigration processes, a reliable public transportation system, and a caring society. The author expresses gratitude to Lee, praising his legacy of building a nation that balances strong leadership with a sense of community and harmony.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng sells Melbourne site for A$64.8m
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp sold a Melbourne site for A$64.8 million (S$69.3 million) after buying it for A$32 million in 2013. The 2,927 sq m site, which includes a planning permit and marketing materials for a 72-storey high-rise development, was sold with no expected impact on Chip Eng Seng's net assets or earnings. The company's shares rose half a cent to 96.5 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: Mr Lee's final journey
summary: Singaporean statesman Lee Kuan Yew passed away, but the article does not mention the date or details of his passing.

site_title: House of antiques
summary: Kelvin Pow, a Singaporean businessman, has transformed a 1928 shophouse in Geylang into a treasure trove of Peranakan and Chinese antiques. The two-storey terrace house, which Pow bought to house his collection, now showcases intricate carvings, ornate furniture, and cultural artifacts. Pow's love for preserving cultural heritage and symbolism in Chinese and Peranakan furniture is evident in his eclectic yet historically accurate home design. Despite Geylang's gentrification, Pow finds solace in the fact that his property has increased in value, and he can continue to appreciate the unique character of his neighborhood.

site_title: Noble up after MPA dismisses some claims by Iceberg
summary: Noble Group's shares rose 1.5 cents or 1.6% to S$0.945 after the Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) refuted claims made by Iceberg Research that the commodities trader had breached regulations. The MPA stated that its investigation found no malpractices and that Noble's bunkering unit was not renewed due to non-compliance with license commitments, not a breach of regulations. The statement lifted the stock, which had taken a drubbing since Iceberg's claims in February.

site_title: Macquarie unit to pay US$15m to settle US SEC charges
summary: A unit of Macquarie Group Ltd will pay US$15 million to settle US Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it underwrote a stock offering for China-based Puda Coal Inc despite having a report showing false information. The settlement also requires the unit to cover the costs of setting up a fair fund to compensate Puda investors. Two former Macquarie Capital employees have agreed to pay settlements and face industry bans. The defendants did not admit or deny wrongdoing.

site_title: Germany needs more immigration from non-EU countries: study
summary: Germany needs to increase immigration from non-EU countries to sustain its economy, with a study predicting a 33% drop in working-age population by 2050. The country requires 276,000 to 491,000 net immigrants annually to maintain prosperity and economic activity. The Bertelsmann foundation suggests focusing on attracting talent from beyond Europe's borders due to a shrinking pool of qualified workers. This comes as concerns about immigration have led to increased support for right-wing parties.

site_title: Mixed report card for S'pore designs
summary: Singapore's design scene has seen a marginal improvement over the last 20 years, according to Red Dot Award founder Peter Zec. Despite a few high points, including the opening of the National Design Centre in 2014, Zec notes that the scene has largely plateaued. He credits efforts to boost the industry, but expresses disappointment that Singapore's design scene has not reached its full potential. Zec's comments are based on his observations from frequent visits to the country, where he has also established the Red Dot Museum.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns that its H2 revenue may be below target and operating loss will be similar to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. OCBC Bank has announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and named Tan Teck Long as her successor. The company will also be led by former DBS veteran. In other news, MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Grab has been downgraded to 'hold' by CGSI due to expected slow earnings growth in the second half.

site_title: Customers change banks on the quiet, spurred by digital trend
summary: Banks are facing a quiet exodus of customers, with over 30% of customers in developed countries switching to competitors for financial products like credit cards and loans. Digital startups and specialist firms are driving this trend with simpler, more convenient solutions, eroding banks' classic advantages. As a result, bank revenues and profit margins are vulnerable, with at least 30% of retail bank revenues at risk of migrating or disappearing by 2020.

site_title: KepCorp disputes higher conglomerate discount by analysts
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore-based conglomerate, disputes analysts' higher conglomerate discount of 10-20% after it took its listed property arm private. The company cites strong performance and earnings visibility, despite some analysts questioning the synergies between its diverse portfolio. KepCorp's CEO Loh Chin Hua also expressed confidence in delivering rigs to Brazilian company Sete Brasil, despite financing problems, and stated that the company's shares have been trading at "single-digit multiples" with consistently strong performance and dividend distributions.

site_title: Google teams with J&J on robotic surgery
summary: US healthcare giant Johnson & Johnson has partnered with Google to develop an innovative robotic-assisted surgical platform. The collaboration aims to integrate advanced technologies to improve healthcare delivery in operating rooms. The platform will utilize robotic tools and capabilities to enhance surgeons' control, access, and accuracy in procedures such as heart, eye, and prostate surgery. The goal is to advance surgical care and put the best science, technology, and surgical know-how in the hands of medical teams worldwide.

site_title: Greece eyes boosting state revenues by 3b euros in 2015: govt official
summary: Greece's government has proposed measures to boost state revenues by 3 billion euros in 2015 as part of a list of reforms to unlock aid from European creditors. The list, set to be discussed on Saturday, estimates a primary budget surplus of 1.5% and growth of 1.4%, without including recessionary measures or wage or pension cuts. The goal is to meet the 3% target set in the existing EU/IMF bailout, but the official emphasized that the revenue increase will not come from these measures.

site_title: Torn-up sick notes show crash pilot should have been grounded
summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed into the French Alps on Tuesday, killing all 150 people on board. Authorities found torn-up sick notes indicating pilot Andreas Lubitz had been suffering from depression and was grounded due to illness, but he had hidden this from his employer. Lubitz, 27, deliberately steered the plane into a mountain, leading to speculation about his mental health and potential airline liability. German prosecutors are investigating the crash, and several airlines have changed their cockpit rules to require a second crew member during flights.

images.alt_text: German authorities found torn-up sick notes showing that the pilot who crashed a plane into the French Alps was suffering from an illness that should have grounded him on the day of the tragedy, which he apparently hid from the airline.

site_title: Rolex offshoot Tudor wakes up to challenge mid-priced rivals
summary: Tudor, a mid-priced watch brand from Rolex, is reviving its presence in the US and UK after a two-year hiatus. The brand, which was founded in 1926, plans to enter Japan and is introducing its first in-house mechanisms, a move aimed at reducing dependence on external components. Tudor's pricing, around $2,000 to $5,000, is seen as a threat to mid-range watchmakers like Longines and TAG Heuer, as it offers a more affordable alternative to Rolex. This move is part of a broader challenge for Swiss watchmakers, including a slump in Chinese demand and the impact of the Swiss franc's surge.

images.alt_text: ATTRACTIVE: Priced at about US$2,000 to US$5,000, Tudor targets buyers who may not purchase a Rolex, which starts at US$4,800.

site_title: Americans faced fewer credit rejections: NY Fed survey
summary: US credit rejections decreased to 25% from 30% over the last 12 months, according to a New York Federal Reserve survey. Rejection rates for the least creditworthy group increased, while overall credit application rates remained steady at 40%. Respondents plan to seek higher credit for mortgage refinancing and card limits in the coming year.

site_title: German hospital says examined Germanwings pilot this month
summary: A German hospital in Duesseldorf confirmed that Andreas Lubitz, the suspected co-pilot of the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps in 2015, underwent a diagnosis at the hospital in February and March 2015. The hospital stated that reports of Lubitz being treated for depression were incorrect, citing patient privacy rules. The hospital declined to provide further details.

site_title: Two missing, 25 hurt after NY building collapse
summary: A gas-related explosion brought down three buildings and damaged a fourth in New York's East Village, injuring 25 people and leaving two missing. The blast, which triggered a fire, damaged a commercial and residential building, two adjoining properties, and a sushi restaurant. Preliminary indications suggest the incident was gas-related, raising concerns about safety in older Manhattan buildings. The Red Cross set up an emergency site, and a hotel offered free nights to those displaced. New York Mayor Bill de Blasio attributed the initial impact to plumbing and gas work at the site.

site_title: Lufthansa to toughen up cockpit rules
summary: Lufthansa will introduce new rules requiring two crew members in the cockpit at all times following a fatal crash of a Germanwings plane in the French Alps. The airline initially did not see a reason to change its procedures, but many others have since followed suit. The Lufthansa Group, which includes several airlines, will implement the new rule "as soon as possible" in agreement with authorities. This move comes after the crash, which killed all 150 people on board.

site_title: The doors, by Mini
summary: Mini has introduced its first five-door hatchback, the Mini 5-Door, offering more space while maintaining its fun personality. The new model is based on an extended version of the Mini 3-Door's platform, resulting in a 155mm longer and 20mm taller design. The additional space provides 37mm more legroom for rear passengers, making it suitable for taller occupants. However, the third seatbelt in the back row may be compromised by the positioning of a cupholder. The Mini 5-Door is available in the Cooper S variant, weighing 1,315 kg and measuring 4,005mm in length.

site_title: Prototype US penny sold for 117.5 million pennies
summary: A rare 1792 prototype US penny, known as the Birch Penny, sold for $1.175 million, including buyer's premium, at an auction in Baltimore, Maryland. One of only seven known to exist, it was engraved the year the US Mint was created and features Lady Liberty. The buyer, not identified, purchased the coin, which depicts "Liberty parent of science and industry," at an auction organized by Stack's Bowers Galleries.

site_title: Euro bond investors grow fed up of QE effect
summary: Euro bond investors are growing frustrated with the expensive effects of the ECB's quantitative easing (QE) program, which has driven up yields and spreads. Spain recently priced a 3.5 billion euro bond at a lower-than-expected price, while Germany's KfW opted to fund in US dollars instead of euros. The market's shift is attributed to investors benefiting from the QE rally but now seeking better yields, with many buyers seemingly "done" with the program's impact. The ECB's asset purchase program is set to run until September 2016, and investors are calling for a balance in expectations for future transactions.

site_title: By gum, the West is wrong about Singapore
summary: Singapore's reputation is being unfairly scrutinized after the death of former leader Lee Kuan Yew, with Western media focusing on perceived shortcomings rather than the country's economic success and low crime rate. The article argues that Singaporeans are being unfairly judged and that the country's efficiency and productivity are being overlooked. The author, who is a Singaporean, defends the country's approach to governance and economic development, saying that it has allowed Singaporeans to enjoy a high standard of living and personal freedoms.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat; indexes set for down week
summary: US stocks opened flat on Friday, with indexes set for a sharp weekly decline, ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.13 points, the S&P 500 gained 0.31 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 2.98 points. The week's declines in the Dow (2.4%), S&P (2.4%), and Nasdaq (3.1%) suggest investors are cautious about economic outlook and monetary policy.

site_title: Annica unit's customer seeks to terminate RM87m contract
summary: Annica Holdings' subsidiary Industrial Power Technology is terminating a contract for a biomass power plant in Malaysia worth RM87 million (S$32.35 million) due to alleged breach and default by Industrial Power. The customer, FTJ Bio Power Sdn Bhd, claims Industrial Power failed to meet certain contract terms. Industrial Power will object to the claim and initiate arbitration proceedings if a resolution cannot be reached amicably.

site_title: Oil drops after Yemen-inspired gains
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday after spiking the previous day due to Saudi Arabian jets striking rebel targets in Yemen, sparking supply fears in the Middle East. Brent crude fell 63 cents to $58.56 a barrel and US benchmark West Texas Intermediate slid 81 cents to $50.62 a barrel, reversing strong gains from the previous two days. Despite initial concerns about disruptions to oil supplies, analysts say the market has pulled lower due to oversupply and no actual disruption to oil shipments.

site_title: Goldman climbs to top commodity bank ranking over JP Morgan
summary: Goldman Sachs surpassed JP Morgan as the top commodities bank last year, according to financial industry analytics firm Coalition. Goldman had the largest commodity revenues, while JP Morgan took second place. This marks a shift, as Goldman has maintained its focus on commodities, while rivals such as JP Morgan have pulled back.

site_title: Visa to miss deadline for new Russia payment system, Mastercard on time: payment system head
summary: Visa is still in the process of transferring credit card transaction processing to a local Russian payment system, with a deadline of one to two months, while Mastercard has met the April 1 deadline as ordered by Russian authorities. Foreign card companies face a security deposit if they fail to comply, with Visa refusing to comment on the issue. The move follows Visa and Mastercard stopping services for sanctioned Russian banks over Moscow's role in the Ukraine crisis.

site_title: Japan cuts deposit insurance paid by banks after drop in failures
summary: Japan's Deposit Insurance Corp of Japan (DICJ) has cut the deposit insurance premium for the first time, effective April 1, to 0.042% of deposits. This move is aimed at saving the banking industry approximately 200 billion yen annually. The cut comes after a decrease in bank failures and public-funded bailouts in recent years, with no bank failure since 2010. This rate cut is the first since the system's inception in 1971, following a significant surplus in DICJ's reserve, which stood at 1.7 trillion yen at the end of March last year.

site_title: Power restored at Schiphol airport after major regional outage
summary: Power has been restored at Amsterdam's Schiphol airport after a major regional outage hit the Dutch capital and surroundings on Friday morning. Incoming flights were diverted to other regional airports, and there would be delays to all outbound flights from Europe's fourth-largest airport. The outage affected the Dutch capital and surrounding areas, causing disruptions to air travel.

site_title: Microsoft says data requests down, reforms needed
summary: Microsoft reported a 11% decrease in global law enforcement requests for user data in 2014, from 72,279 to 65,496. The majority of requests came from the US, France, Britain, Germany, and Turkey. Microsoft's deputy counsel emphasized the need for reforms, citing the importance of "rule of law" and security in online communications. The company also released data on US national security requests, showing a range of zero to 999 orders from a secret court. Microsoft calls for commitments to prevent governments from hacking technology companies to access data outside the legal process.

site_title: Now fireworks maker joins China's tech gold rush
summary: A Chinese fireworks maker, Panda Fireworks Group Co Ltd, plans to diversify into the internet sector amid weakening demand for fireworks due to government efforts to reduce air pollution. The company will invest 50 million yuan in establishing a venture capital arm to invest in high-tech companies. This move illustrates China's tech gold rush, with internet firms like Alibaba and Xiaomi boasting high valuations and rapid growth, and comes after Premier Li Keqiang's announcement of policies to support innovation and entrepreneurialism in China.

site_title: Keppel Corp's shareholding in Keppel Land inches up to 93.4%
summary: Keppel Corp's shareholding in Keppel Land has increased to 93.4% as of 5pm on Friday, narrowly missing the 95.5% threshold for a compulsory acquisition of the company at S$4.60 per share. Keppel Land fell one cent to S$4.52 on the stock market, with 9.7 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Central banks slow reductions of US Treasuries holdings: Fed data
summary: US foreign central banks reduced their US Treasuries holdings to $2.899 trillion on March 25, the lowest level in over a year, with a $360 million decrease in the latest week. This is the smallest decline in four weeks. The modest decline coincides with a further pullback in the dollar after the Fed signaled no rush to raise short-term interest rates. Foreign central banks' holdings in corporate bonds fell for the first time in six weeks, while those in agency debt and mortgage-backed securities rose.

site_title: Low Keng Huat Q4 profit spikes on recent projects
summary: Low Keng Huat, a Singaporean builder and developer, reported a sharp spike in Q4 profit to S$61.4 million, up from S$6.7 million a year ago, driven by completed projects Parkland Residences and Paya Lebar Square. Net profit for the full fiscal year tripled to S$144.9 million. The company declared a first and final dividend of 3 cents per share and a special dividend of 2 cents per share, raising its full-year payout to 5 cents per share.

site_title: Tesla's Musk says to 'localise' China output: Xinhua
summary: Tesla Motors founder Elon Musk plans to "localise production" of electric cars in China over the next three years, according to a report by Xinhua news agency. Musk stated that localising production in China, as well as Europe, is "sensible and logical." This move is seen as a strong commitment to China, where Tesla aims to establish both local production and engineering capabilities.

site_title: Hu An tumbles into 164m yuan net loss in Q4
summary: Hu An Cable Holdings reported a net loss of 164 million yuan (S$36.14 million) in Q4 2014, driven by a slowdown in China and government tightening. The company's full-year net loss was 161.6 million yuan, with sales for all products falling 23.3% to 2.2 billion yuan. Hu An attributed the decline to China's economic reforms, which shifted the country's growth model from investment to consumption, and tightening financing facilities for the traditional cables and wires industry. The company plans to reassess client creditworthiness and seek sales in industries with better prospects.

site_title: ECB shelves euro clearing house policy: source
summary: The European Central Bank has shelved its policy requiring euro-denominated securities clearing houses to be located within the eurozone, after a top European court ruled against it. The policy was challenged by Britain, citing concerns it would harm London's finance centre. The ECB source confirmed the policy's abandonment, following the court's earlier decision that the central bank lacked the power to impose it.

site_title: Co-pilot hid sick leave note for crash day: German prosecutors
summary: German prosecutors say the co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings jet deliberately hid his sick leave notice on the day of the crash, which killed 150 people. The co-pilot, who suffered from severe depression, kept his illness a secret from his employer and colleagues. Medical documents found in his homes suggest he had an existing illness and was receiving treatment. This backs up the suspicion that the co-pilot intentionally crashed the plane.

images.alt_text: The co-pilot thought to have deliberately crashed his Germanwings jet into the French Alps, killing all 150 aboard, kept secret the fact that he was written off sick on the day, German prosecutors said on Friday.

site_title: Dutch government delays ABN Amro listing over executive pay row
summary: The Dutch government has delayed the privatisation of ABN Amro bank due to a dispute over executive pay, specifically a 100,000-euro salary increase for most executive board members. Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem put the listing on hold until lawmakers can address concerns about the move, which was widely condemned as excessive. The bank was nationalized in 2008 and has since reported a book value of 14.9 billion euros, with taxpayers footing the bill for its costs.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore Wrap Friday. Key stories include Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin is optimistic about clearing his daughter's suspension in an ethics case, while ASEAN agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy shrinks for the second month, and South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: EU agency may advise airlines adopt 2-person cockpit norm: source
summary: The European Union's air safety regulator may advise airlines to have two crew members in the cockpit at all times following a suspected suicide crash of a Germanwings airliner. This recommendation, rather than a binding law, is being evaluated to achieve quicker results.
