The move comes after a German co-pilot was found to have deliberately crashed the plane by locking himself alone in the cockpit.

site_title: Taiwan leader backs joining China-led infrastructure bank
summary: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou expressed support for joining the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a Beijing-backed institution. He stated that Taiwan should actively participate in regional economic integration and linked potential membership to bids to join other free-trade blocs. However, Beijing's stance on Taiwan's potential membership remains uncertain, as the island is considered part of China's territory awaiting reunification. The move comes after several countries, including Britain and South Korea, have expressed interest in joining the AIIB.

site_title: Daughter bests father in feud at Japan shareholder's meeting
summary: A rare family feud erupted at a Japanese shareholders meeting for Otsuka Kagu Ltd, with the company's CEO, Kumiko Otsuka, defeating her father's attempt to oust her. Kumiko, 47, vowed to push ahead with her plan to take the furniture retailer more mass-market, while her father, company founder and chairman Katsuhisa Otsuka, criticized her record. The feud highlights the risk of failed succession planning at Japanese companies with high family ownership, and is Japan's first major proxy battle since the country adopted corporate governance guidelines.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng sells vacant Melbourne site for A$64.8m
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp sold a vacant Melbourne site for A$64.8m (S$69.2m) plus tax, including a planning permit for a 72-storey, 1,035-apartment high-rise development. The sale has no expected impact on the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share for 2015. Chip Eng Seng shares rose 0.5% following the announcement, closing at 96.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: US GDP unrevised at 2.2% in Q4; corporate profits fall
summary: US economic growth cooled in Q4 with a 2.2% annual rate, unrevised from last month's forecast, as businesses reduced inventory and equipment investment but consumer spending limited the slowdown. Corporate profits fell 1.6% due to a strong dollar, while exports grew but imports increased, resulting in a trade deficit. This moderate pace of expansion may delay the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike until later this year, as policymakers reassess growth estimates.

images.alt_text: US economic growth cooled in the fourth quarter as previously estimated, with businesses throttling back on inventory and equipment investment but robust consumer spending limiting the slowdown in the pace of activity.

site_title: No sure way to prevent pilot 'suicides': psychologists
summary: A Germanwings pilot deliberately crashed an Airbus A320 into the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board. Investigators are still probing the cause, but psychologists warn there's no foolproof way to prevent similar incidents. Despite ICAO's recommendation that someone with depression shouldn't fly, psychological tests are "rarely of value" and not reliable. Airlines may not be doing enough to detect mental health issues, with pilots reluctant to self-report concerns due to fear of losing their jobs. Experts say a second crew member in the cockpit may be the most effective suicide prevention technique.

site_title: Thai junta approves US$58b, 8-year investment plan
summary: Thailand's military government has approved an 8-year, $79.73 billion investment plan to develop the country's transport system and ease logistics. The plan aims to boost the economy by strengthening investment, employment, transportation, and tourism. The plan will cut logistics costs to 2% in 2027 from 14.4% currently. The plan will be funded through the annual budget, borrowings, state enterprises' revenues, and public-private partnerships. The move aims to revive Thailand's struggling economy, which grew only 0.7% last year and is expected to reach 4% this year.

site_title: Mercedes to launch a pickup truck outside the United States
summary: Mercedes-Benz plans to launch a mid-sized pickup truck outside the United States in the next five years, aiming to narrow the sales gap with rival BMW. The move comes as pickup trucks have gained popularity globally due to eased gasoline prices. The new truck will offer features traditionally found in passenger cars, catering to customers demanding more versatility. This expansion is part of Mercedes' strategy to expand its premium brand into a lower-priced bracket.

images.alt_text: German carmaker Mercedes-Benz plans to launch a mid-sized pickup truck, expanding its premium brand into a lower-priced bracket in a bid to narrow the sales gap with arch rival BMW.

site_title: BlackBerry reports fiscal fourth-quarter profit
summary: BlackBerry Ltd. reported a fiscal fourth-quarter profit of US$28 million, or 5 cents a share, a significant turnaround from a year-earlier loss of US$148 million. Excluding one-time items, the quarterly profit was US$20 million, or 4 cents a share. Quarterly revenue declined to US$660 million from US$793 million. This marks a positive step for the company's turnaround efforts.

site_title: China Minsheng Investment to invest US$5b in Indonesia industrial park
summary: China Minsheng Investment Group plans to invest US$5 billion in an industrial park in Indonesia as part of China's "one belt, one road" project. The investment is part of a US$40 billion worth of agreements signed with the Indonesia-China Business Council in Beijing. This move aims to support China's initiative to reestablish trade links along the old Silk Road route.

site_title: French consumers more confident, PM upbeat on growth
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls expressed optimism about the country's economic growth, stating that France will achieve solid growth faster than expected, potentially leading to a decrease in unemployment this year. Consumer confidence in France rose to its highest level since 2010, with households expressing lower concerns about unemployment. However, the economy still faces challenges, including stagnant housing starts and a decline in real estate investments. The government's popularity remains low ahead of local elections.

site_title: Bundesbank opposes more emergency funding for Greece: report
summary: Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann opposes providing Greece with more emergency loans, citing the new government's loss of trust and the country's ability to meet financial obligations. Weidmann rejects Greece's claims of being financially overburdened, instead pointing to lower interest rates and extended repayment deadlines as factors making the debt more manageable. The ECB has restricted Greek banks' ability to purchase short-term debt, forcing them to rely on the more expensive Emergency Liquidity Assistance facility. Weidmann expresses a lack of confidence in the Greek government's ability to find a solution, warning that time is running out.

site_title: China's Finance Minister: yet to decide whether to expand local debt swap
summary: China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei said the country has yet to decide whether to expand a one trillion yuan debt swap for local governments. The initial swap allows local governments to swap maturing high-interest debt for new official bonds to cut interest costs. The quota could eventually reach 3 trillion yuan, but any expansion depends on circumstances. The swap is not a bailout, according to Lou.

site_title: German police find no 'smoking gun' in crash pilot's home
summary: German police investigating the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525 have found no conclusive evidence linking the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, to a deliberate act. Lubitz's home in Duesseldorf was searched, but police found no "smoking gun" to explain the motive behind the crash, which killed 150 people. Lubitz's personal documents are being examined, but officials say no motive has been found yet. A parallel inquiry has been opened in Germany to help clarify the situation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,813.37, down 5.05 points. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 1.64 billion lots traded, with 354 gainers and 391 losers.

site_title: French investigators hunt black box from doomed jet
summary: French investigators are searching for the second black box from the crashed Germanwings jet, which killed 150 people, in the French Alps. Co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately initiated the descent and crashed the plane, according to prosecutors. Lubitz's profile and career will be investigated by German and Lufthansa authorities. The majority of family members have left the remote site, and officials are collecting biological elements and debris to aid in identification and shed light on the incident. French Prime Minister Manuel Valls described the act as "criminal, crazy, suicidal."

site_title: Deutsche Bank co-CEO says he was moved by gathering at Lee Kuan Yew's wake
summary: Deutsche Bank co-CEO Anshu Jain described Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew as a "visionary global leader" who had a lifelong commitment to developing Singapore's economy and citizens' welfare. Jain attended Lee's wake in Singapore and was moved by the emotional expression of condolences from the gathered crowd. He praised Lee's lasting impact, saying he left an "indelible impression" on him.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Oil prices fall more than US$1 as supply threat eases
summary: Oil prices fell more than $1 a barrel on Friday as concerns over a disruption to supplies due to Saudi Arabia-led air strikes in Yemen eased. Goldman Sachs said the strikes would have little effect on oil supplies due to Yemen's small crude export capacity and tankers' ability to avoid the country's waters. Oil prices rose 5% on Thursday, sparking fears of a regional conflict, but analysts believe the impact of the strikes is unlikely to be significant.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell more than US$1 on Friday, after sharp gains in the prior session, as worries of a disruption to supplies due to Saudi Arabia-led air strikes in Yemen eased.

site_title: BlackRock disposed entire 2.4% stake in Keppel Land on March 26
summary: BlackRock sold its entire 2.4% stake in Keppel Land on March 26, disposing of 37.3 million shares at S$4.38 each and 19,000 shares at S$4.54 each. The sale came after Keppel Corp's 93.2% stake, which excludes BlackRock's stake, fell short of the compulsory acquisition threshold of 95.5% for a higher offer price. Keppel Land's stock price fell to S$4.52 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Fund manager BlackRock has disclosed that it had on Thursday sold 37.3 million Keppel Land shares at S$4.38 each, and another 19,000 shares at S$4.54 each.

site_title: PetroChina mulls Canadian asset swap to ride out oil plunge
summary: PetroChina is in talks with international oil companies to swap assets in North America, particularly in Canada's oil sands, to help the company ride out the slump in crude prices. The asset swap is seen as more efficient than outright sales, which would cause losses for international companies. PetroChina has already acquired several Canadian assets, including the Dover oil-sands project, and is looking to strengthen cooperation with international oil companies to restructure its assets.

site_title: Singapore: Banks, Singtel help STI gain 1.1% over the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.1% over the week, driven by banks and Singtel. Despite concerns about the impact of Lee Kuan Yew's passing on the market, the index rebounded, with banks and Singtel benefiting from quarter-ending window dressing. External factors, including gyrations on Wall Street, Middle East problems, and QE, also contributed to the rally. The index closed at 3,450.1 on Friday, with 1.6 billion units traded worth S$1.1 billion.

site_title: China to let mutual funds invest in Hong Kong via connect scheme: regulator
summary: China's securities regulator announced it will allow mainland mutual funds to invest in Hong Kong stocks via the Shanghai-Hong Kong connect scheme, promoting product and business innovation. This move aims to deepen the financial integration between the two cities. The decision was made by the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) spokesman Deng Ge, who stated that the scheme will facilitate investment and business growth.

site_title: CNOOC posts 6.5% rise in 2014 profit, vows cost cuts amid low oil prices
summary: CNOOC Ltd, China's top offshore oil producer, reported a 6.5% rise in 2014 net profit to 60.2 billion yuan (S$13 billion), beating forecasts. The company attributed the growth to cost cuts and higher output, which helped offset the decline in global oil prices. For the current year, CNOOC prioritized cost cuts and production growth to prepare for long-term weakness in oil prices.

site_title: Swatch CEO optimistic on 2015 sales, shares jump
summary: Swatch Group's CEO, Nick Hayek, expressed optimism about 2015 sales, citing strong demand in brands like Tissot and Omega, with turnover growing at a double-digit pace in key markets. The company is expected to hit the upper end of its 5-10% sales growth target range. Shares rose 3.2% after the announcement. Despite challenges in Russia, where unit sales have risen but prices have not kept pace with the weakened rouble.

images.alt_text: Swatch Group will hit the upper end of its sales-growth target range of 5-10 per cent in 2015 as demand in its stable of brands such as Tissot and Omega advanced more quickly than expected, group Chief Executive Nick Hayek said on Friday.

site_title: Indian airline IndiGo heads towards US$400m IPO as air travel booms
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, is planning to raise US$300 million to US$400 million through an initial public offering (IPO), as air travel continues to boom in the country. The airline, owned by InterGlobe Enterprises, has remained profitable in the past two years and has picked lead managers Citigroup, Kotak Investment Bank, and Morgan Stanley. The draft prospectus is expected to be filed by the end of May, with the market debut pending market conditions. This move comes as the airline seeks to capitalize on the growing demand for air travel in India.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.19% to 6,908.13 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index climbed 0.63% to 11,918.79 points, while the CAC 40 in Paris advanced 0.27% to 5,020.09.

site_title: Honda to invest US$154m to expand India motorcycle, car output
summary: Honda Motor Co Ltd plans to invest $210 million in India to expand motorcycle and car production, targeting growing demand in the Asian market. The company will increase motorcycle production capacity by 30% to 2.4 million units and car production by 50% to 180,000 units in India. The investments will create approximately 2,500 new jobs. This move aims to boost Honda's overall annual production capacity in India to 6.4 million motorcycles and 300,000 cars.

site_title: China Jan-Feb industrial profits down 4.2% y-o-y
summary: China's industrial profits declined 4.2% year-over-year to 745.2 billion yuan in January-February, a decrease from the 8% annual fall in December. This is attributed to the Lunar New Year holiday, which started on February 19 this year. The combined profit figure is used to smooth out seasonal distortions.

site_title: UK house price growth slows again in March: Nationwide
summary: British house prices rose by 0.1% in March, the smallest annual increase since September 2013, according to Nationwide. The annual rate of increase dropped to 5.1% from 5.7% in February, marking the seventh consecutive month of slowing price growth. This further indicates the UK's housing market is cooling, with annual growth rates now at their lowest level since 2013.

site_title: Germanwings co-pilot's personal life takes centerstage in probe
summary: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz, 28, crashed a plane into the French Alps, killing 149 people, amid a "personal life crisis." Lubitz had relationship difficulties and was undergoing psychological treatment for depression. He allegedly locked the captain out of the cockpit and deliberately initiated a high-speed descent. Investigators believe Lubitz's actions were intentional and not due to a technical fault. Lubitz's medical records were confidential, but sources suggest he was deemed fit to fly despite being labeled "unfit" during training. The investigation is ongoing, with police searching Lubitz's apartment and house for clues.

site_title: Margin costs soar as Singapore rates double
summary: Singapore's benchmark interest rates have surged, doubling to 1.295% for a six-month loan, making it more expensive for wealthy investors to buy bonds on margin. This has reduced the appeal of bonds and squeezed returns for investors relying on leverage. Private banks, which typically charge around 1% over the benchmark rate, are now charging nearly 2% for margin loans, leading to reduced demand for riskier bonds and lower liquidity for smaller companies.

site_title: Swiss private bank UBP says to buy RBS's Coutts International
summary: Swiss private bank Union Bancaire Privee (UBP) agreed to buy Royal Bank of Scotland's international private banking arm Coutts International. The acquisition is seen as a significant milestone in UBP's growth strategy, with Britain's Financial Times reporting a potential price range of US$600 million to US$800 million. UBP Chief Executive expressed commitment to developing its wealth management business. Details of the deal, including the exact price, have not been disclosed.

site_title: China: Stocks rise; property shares jump on policy support
summary: Chinese stocks rose on Friday, driven by a surge in property shares due to government support measures. China's CSI300 real estate index jumped 3.9% after Beijing urged local governments to support residents with housing conditions and reduce land supply. The CSI300 index also rose 0.6% to 3,971.70, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.3% to 3,691.10. The move offset concerns from poor economic data and offset expectations of fresh money inflows from foreign investment rules.

site_title: Quick take: Japan's central bank will boost stimulus by end of Q2 '15: HSBC
summary: Japan's central bank is expected to boost stimulus by the end of Q2 2015 due to a slowdown in core consumer inflation to zero year-on-year in February. The Bank of Japan has stated it will act decisively to get inflation back on track if underlying price trends deteriorate. This decision comes despite Governor Kuroda's previous statement that inflation is 'likely to be around zero per cent for the time being'.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Iron ore slump set to shrink China's mining capacity
summary: China's mining sector is facing a significant slump due to the decline in iron ore prices, with three-quarters of its mining capacity operating at a loss. This has led to mine closures and consolidation, which would increase China's appetite for imported iron ore and help ease a global glut. Industry officials see the decline in prices as a positive development, as it has given bigger domestic mines an opportunity to operate profitably and forced smaller miners to cut production.

site_title: Fed focuses on shadow banking as it gauges financial-system risk
summary: The Federal Reserve is focusing on the shadow banking system as it assesses financial-system risk. The shadow banking system, which includes money-market mutual funds, hedge funds, and brokerages, has grown to $25 trillion, prompting concerns about contagion. The Fed's financial stability committee is mapping the system and considering stricter margin requirements for broker-dealers to limit borrowed money. The committee aims to identify and limit sources of risk to the financial system, following successful stress tests for the nation's largest banks.

site_title: Singapore ranks third in gender parity among Asia-Pac's developed markets
summary: Singapore ranks third in gender parity among Asia-Pac's developed markets, with a score of 70.5 index points, behind New Zealand (77.3) and Australia (76.0). The country has seen significant advancements in women's leadership since 2007, with an 8.7-point gain. Women's business ownership has also increased from 29.9% to 42.1% over the same period.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Malaysia's Mahathir says he is sad over the passing of Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad expressed sadness over the passing of Singapore's founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, despite not being close friends. Mahathir recalled their frequent debates during Malaysia's early years and acknowledged Kuan Yew's role as a strong leader against communism. He shared personal anecdotes, including a friendly call and a visit to Kuan Yew when he was ill, highlighting their professional relationship. Mahathir concluded that Kuan Yew's passing marks the end of an era of strong leadership in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Gold dips after 7-day rally but set for second weekly gain
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,201.70 an ounce after a seven-day rally, but are expected to post its second straight weekly gain due to low US interest rates. Tensions in the Middle East, particularly in Yemen, provided some support to the metal. However, traders are cautious due to profit-taking and a stronger dollar, with prices consolidating around $1,200. Despite this, gold is on track for a 1.5% weekly gain, its longest winning stretch since August 2012.

images.alt_text: Gold eased on Friday as traders booked profits after a seven-day rally and as the dollar rebounded on strong US data, but the metal looked set to post its second straight weekly gain on expectations US interest rates will stay low for longer.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.95% on profit taking
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 0.95% on Friday due to profit taking, erasing earlier gains. The Nikkei 225 index fell 185.49 points to close at 19,285.63, while the Topix index dropped 1.02% to 1,552.78. The decline came after a day of see-saw trading, with the benchmark Nikkei sitting in positive territory at the morning break. The losses were attributed to profit taking, with investors taking profits from earlier gains.

site_title: William Hague to represent UK at state funeral service for Lee Kuan Yew
summary: British High Commissioner to Singapore William Hague will represent the UK at the state funeral service for Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew on Sunday.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: South Korea sees gains for its infrastructure firms from joining AIIB
summary: South Korea is set to benefit from its infrastructure companies as it joins the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), with shares in iron and steel product makers rising sharply. The country's finance ministry expects its companies to win orders for projects in areas such as communications, energy, and transportation. South Korea's decision to join the AIIB, despite US reservations, marks a significant step for the bank, which aims to provide project loans to developing nations and counter China's growing financial influence in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Airlines introduce two-person cockpit rule after Alps crash
summary: Airlines worldwide have introduced a two-person cockpit rule after a Germanwings flight crashed in the Alps, killing 150 people, with French prosecutors suspecting the co-pilot intentionally crashed the plane. The US already requires two crew members in the cabin, but many countries do not. Airlines including Norwegian Air, easyJet, Air Canada, Air New Zealand, and Air Berlin have implemented the rule, while Germanwings parent Lufthansa plans to discuss the matter with authorities. The incident raises questions about cockpit protections and whether pilots can be a danger, prompting debate about the future of cockpit safety measures.

site_title: JPMorgan retains number one spot in investment banking but revenues slip
summary: JPMorgan retained its top spot in investment banking in 2014 with US$22 billion in revenue, a 6% decline from 2013. The bank's fixed income trading division saw the largest drop, 12.8%, while its equity business rose 15.7% to US$5.9 billion. Morgan Stanley took the lead in equity business, surpassing JPMorgan. US banks dominated the top spots, with Goldman Sachs coming second and Citigroup and Bank of America Merrill Lynch sharing third place with Deutsche Bank.

images.alt_text: The US bank JPMorgan retained its crown as the top performing investment bank in 2014, although its revenues fell 6 per cent, new data showed on Friday.

site_title: COSCO secures contract for 7 container vessels
summary: COSCO Zhoushan Shipyard has secured a contract with Maersk Line to build seven 3,600 TEU container vessels, scheduled for delivery between April 2017 and November 2017. Maersk Line has an option to order two additional vessels within eight months. The contract price remains confidential. This deal is not expected to significantly impact COSCO Corporation's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the 2015 fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

COSCO (Zhoushan) Shipyard, a subsidiary of COSCO Corporation (Singapore)'s 51 per cent owned subsidiary COSCO Shipyard Group, has secured a contract with Maersk Line to build seven 3,600 TEU (twenty-foot equivalent) container vessels.

site_title: Chiam See Tong pays respects to Lee Kuan Yew at Parliament House
summary: Veteran opposition politician Chiam See Tong paid his last respects to late Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew at Parliament House on March 27, 2015. He was accompanied by his wife and daughter. This marks a significant moment for Singapore as it bids farewell to its founding father.

images.alt_text: Veteran opposition politician Chiam See Tong was at Parliament House on Friday afternoon to pay his last respects to Mr Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end flat, Shanghai up again
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 10.88 points to 24,486.20, as gains in Shanghai were offset by losses on Wall Street and concerns over the Yemen crisis. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.24% to 3,691.10, marking its 12th consecutive gain.

site_title: Petrobras to shut refinery, exit Japan: Nikkei
summary: Brazil's state oil company Petrobras plans to exit Japan by shutting down its 100,000-barrels-per-day Nishihara refinery in Okinawa as early as this year. The refinery, which processes expensive crude, has been under consideration for sale since 2011 but has not found a buyer due to limited interest. Petrobras will instead build an import terminal to sell refined products to another refiner, citing shrinking oil demand in Japan due to an ageing population.

images.alt_text: Brazil's state oil company Petrobras is exiting Japan due to shrinking oil demand, shutting down its refinery in Okinawa as early as this year and building an import terminal it will sell to another refiner, the Nikkei reported on Friday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.37 points to 1814.05. Volume was 164 million lots worth RM72 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 134 to 81.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew featured on Time Magazine cover
summary: The April 6 edition of Time Magazine features Lee Kuan Yew, describing him as "The Founding Father of Singapore". The magazine portrays him as having brought prosperity to the city-state, but at the cost of freedom. Lee Kuan Yew passed away in 2015.

site_title: Indonesia's bonds set for best week in a month on foreign buying
summary: Indonesia's government bonds are expected to have their best week in a month as foreign investors bought the nation's debt, driven by signs of a stabilizing currency. Overseas investors added $530 million to their holdings of local notes, paring this month's outflows to $8.2 trillion. The rupiah's swings declined to its lowest since March 6, and the yield on November 2020 notes fell 11 basis points, the biggest drop since February 27. This comes as the rupiah advanced 0.3% and one-month implied volatility dropped 19 basis points.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.18% in opening exchanges on Friday, following Shanghai's 0.11% gain. Shanghai Composite Index has climbed over 12% in two weeks due to hopes for fresh stimulus from China. The benchmark Hang Seng Index added 44.36 points to 24,541.44.

site_title: Gold rallies for second week as Yemen conflict increases demand
summary: Gold prices rose for the second consecutive week as tensions in Yemen increased demand for the metal as a safe-haven asset. The metal traded at $1,203.41 an ounce, its highest level since March 2, amid concerns of geopolitical tensions and potential disruptions to oil supplies. The rally comes after Saudi Arabia and its allies launched air strikes in Yemen, and follows a week of gains driven by weak US interest rates and a drop in the dollar. Gold is set to gain 1.8% this week, its first quarterly gain since June.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble up one cent in early trade
summary: Noble Group shares rose one Singapore cent to S$0.94 in early trading, with over 9.3 million shares changing hands. The Maritime Port Authority of Singapore dismissed allegations of malpractice at Noble's defunct bunkering business in 2013. This comes after Iceberg Research made similar claims. The move follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Singapore's STI opens 0.25% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.25% higher on Friday at 3,440.18, despite tepid US market losses. Top gainers included UOB, DBS, and City Developments Limited. Trading volume was 122.9 million shares worth S$93.6 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 90 to 54. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of upcoming GDP data.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Japan core inflation falls back to zero year-on-year in February
summary: Japan's core inflation fell back to zero year-on-year in February, marking the first time in nearly two years, due to lower oil prices and lacklustre consumer spending. Core consumer inflation rose 2.0% year-on-year, but adjusted for a sales tax hike, the nationwide core consumer-price index was flat. This reading is short of the Bank of Japan's goal of 2.0% inflation, highlighting ongoing challenges in achieving price growth.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher; down 0.9% for the week
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Friday, led by gains in financials and consumer staples, but ended the week down 0.9% after the benchmark fell 1.6% on Thursday. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,919.9, its biggest gain in 3.5 months. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also rose 0.36%. Despite Friday's gains, investors bought shares for the new quarter, with settlement only kicking in by April 1.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.50% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.50% lower on Friday due to drops on Wall Street and a firm yen amid risk aversion over the Yemen crisis. The Nikkei 225 index fell 96.40 points to 19,374.72. Oil prices rose after a Saudi-led coalition bombed Huthi rebels in support of Yemen's president. The yen held up despite Japanese data showing consumer inflation returned to zero in February.

site_title: Sino Construction requests trading halt
summary: Sino Construction requested a trading halt on March 27, 2015, amid significant share price decline, a loss of S$7 million for the latest quarter, and the resignation of key executives. The company also reported a lapse in its Guildford Coal transaction and recorded losses for the quarter. This follows a S$2.18 million net gain in the previous year.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Made-in-China a must for Chinese bourse link investors
summary: Chinese investors are favoring domestic shares over Hong Kong-listed stocks, with purchases concentrated in Chinese brokerages, banks, and state-backed companies. Since the Shanghai-Hong Kong exchange link's debut in November, mainland investors have purchased a net 30.2 billion yuan ($4.9 billion) of Hong Kong stocks, mostly in dual-listed Chinese businesses. The bourse link has failed to spark interest in foreign-listed companies, with foreigners taking up 41% of their 300 billion yuan investment cap. Mainland investors are prioritizing domestic growth over international opportunities, citing a world-beating rally at home and concerns about Hong Kong's valuation and growth prospects.

site_title: EU regulators extend Cargill, ADM chocolate deal review to July 23
summary: EU regulators have extended their review of Cargill's planned $440 million takeover of Archer Daniels Midland's chocolate business to July 23. The investigation, launched in February, concerns the deal's potential impact on industrial chocolate prices in Germany and Britain. Cargill, ADM, and Barry Callebaut AG are the main suppliers to customers in these countries. Companies typically offer concessions to ease competition concerns, but Cargill and ADM have not made any concessions so far. The EU competition watchdog will review the deal again on July 23 to determine whether it would harm competition.

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce on banks, energy
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Friday, led by gains in financial, energy, and consumer staples sectors, as investors bought ahead of the new quarter. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 47.8 points to 5,926.9, despite geopolitical tensions and a sluggish US market. Banks, including Commonwealth Bank and ANZ, and retailers such as Woolworths and Wesfarmers, were among the top gainers. The index is still expected to end the week in the red, but analysts anticipate strong bank earnings and a potential RBA rate cut to boost the market.

site_title: Shoppers' personal info not part of RadioShack sale: ombudsman
summary: RadioShack Corp's sale does not include shoppers' personal info, according to its consumer privacy ombudsman. Concerns were raised by several states, including Oregon and Pennsylvania, that the data could be sold. Oregon Attorney General Ellen Rosenblum and Pennsylvania Attorney General Kathleen Kane urged stripping out personally identifiable information from assets. RadioShack's buyer, Standard General, would keep about 1,740 stores open, while a rival bid by Salus Capital Corp offers US$271 million in cash. The issue is part of RadioShack's bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Apple's Tim Cook will give away all his money: Fortune
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook plans to donate his estimated $785 million fortune to charity after paying for his 10-year-old nephew's college education, according to Fortune magazine. Cook's donation is part of his efforts to make a difference, despite not being listed on the "Giving Pledge" website of billionaire financier Warren Buffett. Cook has started donating quietly and is developing a systematic approach to philanthropy, following in the footsteps of other wealthy individuals who are giving away a significant portion of their wealth.

site_title: Dollar's rise fuels transatlantic dash for European real estate
summary: US investors are buying European commercial property at a record pace, driven by the dollar's eight-month rally and struggling European economies. Last year, US spending on European commercial real estate reached nearly $45 billion, just shy of the 2007 peak. The dollar's 26% gain against the euro in the last 12 months has made unhedged European real estate look cheap, prompting US investors to make a big push for Europe. European commercial properties are expected to average 10% annual returns for two years, making them attractive to foreign buyers.

site_title: ECB will reach QE target even in shorter first month: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi expressed confidence that the ECB's quantitative-easing program will hit its 60 billion euro target in the first month of operation, despite starting only on March 9. As of March 20, the ECB had settled public-sector purchases of 26.3 billion euros. Draghi also warned that the euro-area economy's recovery remains cyclical and needs structural reforms, while recent data suggest that ECB stimulus is reaching the real economy.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi said he's confident that his bond-buying program will hit its targets in the first month of operation.

site_title: Japan Feb jobless rate down, jobs availability at over 20-yr high
summary: Japan's jobless rate fell to 3.5% in February, the lowest in over 20 years, as the jobs-to-applicants ratio reached its highest level since 1992. The number of new job offers decreased 3.5% from the previous month but rose 1.7% from last year. The unemployment rate edged down from 3.6% in January, matching economists' forecasts.

site_title: Japan still cautious on AIIB, to keep in close contact with US
summary: Japan remains cautious about joining the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) due to its unclear governance structure. Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso is in close contact with the US to discuss the issue, while South Korea has decided to seek founding membership. China has not responded to Japan's inquiries about the AIIB. Japan's decision is seen as a reflection of its concerns about the bank's influence and potential implications for regional stability.

images.alt_text: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Friday that the country remains cautious about joining the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) as its governance structure is unclear.

site_title: Most Asian stocks rally while yen holds climb; crude pares surge
summary: Asian stocks rose, paring weekly losses, as US equity-index futures advanced. The yen held gains after inflation slowed more than forecast. Crude oil fell, trimming its best weekly climb since 2011. The MSCI Asia Pacific excluding Japan Index rose 0.1%, while Japan's Topix index headed for its first weekly decline since mid-January. US oil slipped 1%, and Standard & Poor's 500 Index futures climbed 0.2%. Analysts predict the first contraction in US profits since 2009, citing mixed data and a proxy fight in Yemen between Iran and Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Oil prices ease as market downplays supply threat from Yemen
summary: Oil prices fell over 1% on Friday as traders downplayed the threat of a disruption to global crude supplies from Saudi Arabia-led air strikes in Yemen. Goldman Sachs estimated the strikes would have little effect on oil supplies due to Yemen's small crude export status and tankers' ability to avoid its waters. Internationally traded Brent crude futures dropped to $58.44 a barrel, while US crude fell to $50.55 a barrel. The decrease was attributed to bearish market sentiment amid the ongoing Trump tariff outlook.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell over a percentage point on Friday as traders estimated that the threat of a disruption to world crude supplies from Saudi Arabia-led air strikes in Yemen was low.

site_title: Oil producers try to go deep, cheap for subsea wells
summary: Oil producers are exploring ways to cut costs and make subsea crude reserves economically feasible at US$70 oil, following a price crash that ended 10 years of spiraling spending. Companies like FMC Technologies and Schlumberger are forming joint ventures to reduce equipment costs, while service companies are pushing to get involved in projects earlier to prevent costly re-design work. The average cost for subsea equipment on deep-water wells has increased 325% since 2004, but with prices now less than half that, the industry is reconsidering its approach to reaching ever-deeper wells.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as Yemen crisis stokes volatility
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday due to volatility sparked by the Yemen crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 40.11 points to 17,678.43, while the S&P 500 dropped 4.78 to 2,056.27. The Nasdaq Composite Index declined 13.16 to 4,863.36. The decline was attributed to the escalating crisis in Yemen, which raised concerns about global instability and potential economic impact.

site_title: Mr Lee's final gift: One united people
summary: Singaporeans pay their last respects to founding father Lee Kuan Yew, who passed away on March 23, 2015. Thousands gathered outside Parliament House, with many expressing regret and gratitude for his leadership and vision. The article highlights the emotional response to Lee's passing, with many acknowledging the sacrifices he made for the country's development. The article also touches on the criticism of Lee's authoritarian rule, but notes that his legacy is being reevaluated as more information about his motivations comes to light.

site_title: Chinese regulator to devolve some IPO approval powers: Chinese media
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission plans to devolve some IPO approval powers to the Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges around May, in a step towards a US-style "registration" system. The CSRC will dissolve its Issuance Examination Committee, allowing the exchanges to create "hearing committees" to vet new listings. This move is aimed at increasing efficiency and reducing bureaucratic hurdles in the IPO process.

site_title: Australia investors headed for cash deluge
summary: Australia is set to receive a record A$50 billion in cash over the next few weeks from dividend and bond payments, injecting spending power into the economy. A $27 billion bond maturation and $4.3 billion in coupon payments are expected, with corporates paying out A$21 billion in dividends. Analysts hope the influx will stimulate economic growth, which slowed to 2.5% last year due to a mining boom decline and reduced business investment. The Reserve Bank of Australia may ease interest rates again to boost activity.

site_title: Talk of biotech bubble rattles Wall Street
summary: The biotech sector is under scrutiny as analysts debate whether its high-flying stocks are a bubble. Despite the sector's long-term promise, concerns about the commercialization of potential blockbusters and the risk of sharp falls on poor clinical or sales results have raised doubts. Analysts point to the sector's rapid growth, with companies like Celgene and Gilead Sciences surging in value, as evidence of a bubble. However, others argue that valuations are fine and that the surge reflects a fundamental shift in the sales and earnings power of the sector.

site_title: Singapore ranks 25th for government openness
summary: Singapore ranks 25th out of 102 countries for government openness in the inaugural Open Government Index 2015, released by the World Justice Project. The index measures government openness based on the general public's experiences and perceptions. This ranking is based on factors such as access to information, transparency, and citizen participation. The report provides a snapshot of government openness globally, highlighting areas of improvement for Singapore and other countries. The findings are expected to inform policy decisions and promote greater transparency and accountability in governance.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Singapore's success puts global spotlight on its corporate leaders
summary: Singapore's 50th year of independence has put its corporate leaders in the global spotlight, with the city-state's success driving the growth of local companies and making them attractive to global firms. The country's reputation for professional ethics and absence of corruption, combined with the fluency of its executives in English and Mandarin, has made them sought-after candidates for leadership roles. In the last 10 years, the number of Western executives on the boards of Singapore's largest government-linked corporations has fallen by nearly 25%, with local executives increasingly being appointed to top jobs.

site_title: Mystery surrounds Germanwings co-pilot who crashed plane
summary: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed a plane killing 150 people, sparking a mystery over his motivations. Lubitz, 28, had no known terrorist links and passed medical and psychological tests. He had suffered from burnout and depression in the past but seemed fine before the crash. Authorities are searching his apartment and childhood home for clues, but the reason behind the crash remains unknown.

images.alt_text: Investigators are frantically trying to piece together what led the Germanwings co-pilot to deliberately steer himself and 149 passengers and crew to their deaths in Tuesday's plane crash in the French Alps.

site_title: Facebook moves ahead toward Internet drone air fleet
summary: Facebook successfully tested a wide-winged, solar-powered drone, dubbed "Aquila," which can deliver wireless internet service to remote areas. The drone has a wingspan greater than a Boeing 737 and can remain aloft for months, flying at altitudes of 60,000 feet. Mark Zuckerberg aims to connect billions of people worldwide, particularly those in remote communities, to the internet. Facebook plans to use drones, massive data centers, and artificial intelligence to tackle the challenge, with a vision for efficient internet access and virtual reality technology.

site_title: India's Mahindra in talks to buy luxury car designer Pininfarina, say sources
summary: India's Mahindra & Mahindra is in talks to buy a majority stake in luxury car designer Pininfarina, which has designed cars for Ferrari and other major brands. The talks are at an advanced stage, but a deal has not been finalized. Pininfarina's shares jumped 21% on hopes of a takeover, amid a struggling company with significant debt and a history of loss-making. If successful, the acquisition would be the latest Asian bid for an iconic Italian brand, following China's purchase of Pirelli.

site_title: Yahoo boosts share buyback plan by US$2b
summary: Yahoo has increased its share buyback plan by $2 billion, bringing the total to $7 billion. The program, which began in 2013, will expire at the end of March 2018. With $726 million remaining, Yahoo plans to spend the rest by the end of 2017. The move is part of the company's effort to re-invent itself as a pioneering US internet search firm.

site_title: German aviation association 'seeks two-person cockpit rule'
summary: Germany's aviation association BDL plans to introduce a two-person cockpit rule after a Germanwings flight crashed due to a co-pilot's deliberate actions. The new policy requires two crew members to be in the cockpit at all times, with the second person potentially being a flight attendant. This change comes after the co-pilot of the doomed Germanwings flight appeared to intentionally crash the plane, killing all 150 passengers and crew. The rule will be discussed at an industry meeting on Friday to increase security on planes.

site_title: Google to pay Porat annual base salary of $650,000
summary: Google has announced it will pay new CFO Ruth Porat an annual base salary of $650,000 and a one-time $5 million sign-on bonus. Porat, who joins Google on May 26, will also receive a $25 million restricted stock unit grant and a $40 million biennial grant in 2016. This move aims to rein in costs as Google invests in new businesses. The company has also shifted from annual cash bonuses for senior vice presidents to a system with annual base salary and biennial equity grants.

site_title: Toyota re-engineers its appeal to stay atop car industry
summary: Toyota Motor is revamping its brand image to regain appeal in the competitive car industry. The company is re-examining its designs, technologies, and manufacturing processes to make its cars more stylish and diverse. This makeover aims to differentiate Toyota from its competitors and regain its position as a leader in the global market.

site_title: Market for US landmark buildings risky: China Life
summary: China Life Insurance Co, the country's largest insurer, warns that the US market for landmark buildings has become risky due to increased competition from its peers, pushing up prices. The insurer, which has $362 billion in assets abroad, is cautious about investing in the US market, citing a 15% jump in office prices in central London and Manhattan. In contrast, Europe is seen as a more attractive option, with China Life watching it "closely" due to its economic stability.

site_title: Singapore's factory output for February disappoints
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted 3.6% year-on-year in February, exceeding economists' expectations. Most industry clusters shrank, driven by plant closures during the Chinese New Year holidays and weak external demand. The general manufacturing cluster rose 1.3%, while the electronics cluster fell 4.5%. The biomedical cluster declined 2.5%, and the precision engineering cluster slipped 5.8%. Economists expect Q1 2015 GDP growth to be below the government's forecast range of 2-4%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: CIMB to advise KL on sale of 1MDB firm
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd has been appointed by Malaysia's Finance Ministry to advise on the potential sale of Edra Global Energy Bhd, a power firm owned by 1MDB, to strategic investors. CIMB's role includes identifying potential buyers and running a competitive process to derive an optimal outcome for the ministry of finance. The sale is seen as a way to recover losses from the indebted state fund.

site_title: Oil prices surge after Saudi air strikes in Yemen
summary: Saudi Arabia and its Gulf Arab allies launched a military operation in Yemen, raising concerns about the security of Middle East oil shipments. Oil prices surged over 4% to $59 a barrel, with Brent futures up $2.47 at $58.93. The conflict, which has driven the Yemeni president from the capital, could stoke concerns if it widens. The waters between Yemen and Djibouti, known as Bab el-Mandeb, are a "chokepoint" to global oil supplies, with 3.8 million barrels passing through annually.

images.alt_text: While the strikes have not yet disrupted major oil facilities of key Gulf producers, such as Saudi Arabia, there are concerns that the conflict might widen.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its "buy" recommendation for CDL Hospitality Trusts, citing a weaker-than-expected outlook for the Singapore hospitality market, particularly with Indonesian tourists expected to fall 7% year-over-year. Maybank Kim Eng Research also downgraded its sector outlook, recommending "buy" for Wing Tai and Ho Bee, and "hold" for CDL Hospitality Trusts. The research firm believes a broad-based lifting of measures for citizens and permanent residents may come later to support the high-end market.

site_title: In search of a lost time
summary: Simryn Gill, a renowned Asian artist, opens her first major regional exhibition at the Centre of Contemporary Art (CCA) in Singapore, showcasing over 1,000 photographs accumulated over two decades. The exhibition, titled "Simryn Gill: Hugging The Shore," features works capturing time and place, including a massive installation of cut sea apple leaves. Born in 1959 in Singapore, Gill has spent her life balancing art and family, eventually becoming one of Asia's most respected artists, with exhibitions at top institutions such as the Museum of Modern Art and the Guggenheim.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Rising German wages, consumption fuel recovery
summary: German salaries rose 1.7% in 2014, the strongest increase in six years, according to official data. This growth is expected to continue the consumer-driven recovery in Europe's largest economy. Analysts attribute the rise to rising wages and consumption. The increase in real salaries, adjusted for inflation, is seen as a positive sign for Germany's economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore banks seen profiting as rising rates bolster margins
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, are poised to benefit from rising interest rates, with the 3-month Singapore interbank offered rate (SIBOR) more than doubling to 1% this year. This could reverse a squeeze on their net interest margins, boosting profits. Analysts predict DBS's net income will rise 5.6% to $4.27 billion, while UOB and OCBC are forecast to see 0.8% and 1.2% increases, respectively, as deposit rates climb and the banks' core lending businesses generate higher interest income.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp could reverse a squeeze on their net interest margins, the difference between the interest they charge for loans and pay out to depositors.

site_title: A calibre that's sadly lacking in regional leaders now
summary: Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, a highly respected leader, has passed away. Lee transformed Singapore into a clean and prosperous city-state, earning him international admiration. Despite his sometimes confrontational relationship with the media, particularly the Far Eastern Economic Review, he was widely respected globally, including in Britain and Japan. His passing leaves a void in regional leadership, with few comparable figures remaining, including China's President Xi Jinping and Japan needing someone of his caliber.

site_title: How to fight currency manipulation with trade pacts
summary: The US is considering including anti-currency manipulation provisions in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade agreement. However, the US Treasury and Trade Representative have refused to include such provisions, citing concerns that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) cannot enforce its guidelines and that no precise currency rules can be negotiated. Experts argue that the IMF guidelines can be used as a basis for a TPP currency chapter, and that a dispute-resolution mechanism can quickly dismiss frivolous claims. The inclusion of anti-currency manipulation provisions could address a significant problem caused by countries manipulating their currencies to boost exports and limit imports.

site_title: A leader unfazed by politically sensitive questions
summary: Lee Kuan Yew, the former Prime Minister of Singapore, demonstrated his openness to discussing politically sensitive questions during a series of meetings with authors of the book "The Singapore Water Story." Despite initial concerns from Singaporean friends, Lee answered all questions directly and candidly, sharing his thoughts on water management and policy decisions. He even dedicated the book to the authors, showing his warmth and kindness. Lee's willingness to discuss complex issues without fear of offending his audience contributed to Singapore's exceptional water management system, which is considered one of the best in the world.

site_title: 1MDB doubters not swayed by Malaysian premier Najib's guarantee
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has guaranteed the payment of 1Malaysia Development's debts if needed, but investors remain skeptical. The company's US dollar bonds are trading at a premium of 476 basis points over Treasuries, indicating doubts about the government's commitment. Despite the guarantee, investors continue to question its validity, with some viewing it as "as good as a guarantee" but not a true guarantee. The company's debt woes weigh on the nation's credit rating, and investors remain cautious.

site_title: Making his mark in LKY's S'pore
summary: FAN Shao Hua, a Chinese-born artist, created his first portrait of Singapore's late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in 1994, two years after moving to Singapore. The artist, who benefited from the government's artist policy, has since produced several portraits of Mr Lee, incorporating symbolic elements. Fan's admiration for Mr Lee stems from the country's orderliness and multicultural mix, reflecting the PM's passing on of Confucian values. The artist's work showcases the significant impact Mr Lee had on Singapore's development.

site_title: Firms need to consider cyber exposure as high-risk priority
summary: Singapore's first cybersecurity agency will begin operations on April 1, overseeing national cybersecurity functions and developing infrastructure to combat cyber threats. However, many public companies in the region do not consider cyber exposure as a high-risk priority, despite increasing vulnerability to cybercrime. A recent study by AIG found that only 15% of listed companies in Asia consider cybercrime a priority, with 42% prioritizing loss of reputation and 33% protecting against financial loss. Companies are advised to take cyber insurance to safeguard themselves against significant financial losses and reputational damage.

site_title: Singapore companies sell US$5.4b bonds year-to-date
summary: Singapore-based companies have sold a total of US$5.43 billion worth of bonds so far this year, a 1.6% increase from the first quarter of 2014. The financial sector led the way, raising US$4.3 billion, followed by the high technology sector with US$634.6 million. HSBC Holdings currently leads the underwriting with 24.1% market share, followed by OCBC Bank and Bank of America Merrill Lynch. The Singapore-dollar bond market saw a decline in issuances, with foreign issuers tapping the market raising S$1.3 billion.

site_title: Mind the info gap on AEC
summary: Research conducted by M-Brain in Singapore found that companies prefer a wait-and-see approach towards the Asean Economic Community (AEC) due to inadequate information. Eight out of 10 respondents expect a medium to very high impact, but six out of 10 believe they are unprepared due to lack of internal infrastructure. Singapore is seen as the clear winner, with its efficient policies, sound regulations, and transparent framework. However, the lack of information on the AEC's impact and policies is hindering businesses' ability to make informed decisions, leading to a cautious approach.

images.alt_text: Industry specialists and thought leaders interviewed by M-Brain have identified Singapore's vast pool of talent as one of the key advantages for the nation.

site_title: London's 'Silicon Roundabout' big hit with investors
summary: London's "Silicon Roundabout" has become a top hub for financial technology, with investment in fintech firms in Britain and Ireland reaching $623 million in 2014, more than double the previous year. This represents 42% of fintech investment in Europe. Despite the US being the main fintech investment destination, London has established itself as Europe's fintech hub, with top banks and trading firms investing in fintech startups and programs. London's tech cluster is now the third-largest in the world, with many startups and banks collaborating to drive growth.

site_title: O2 deal bets Brits want just mobile service
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing is planning a $15 billion takeover of UK's O2, creating the country's largest wireless carrier. The move is a bet that Britons want just mobile phone service, as opposed to TV and broadband offerings. This strategy contrasts with competitors who are expanding their services. Li's plan combines his Three unit with Telefonica SA's O2, focusing solely on mobile.

site_title: Grooving to their own beat
summary: Local musicians are adding diversity to the jazz scene with a new generation of jazz-influenced artists. Melissa Tham, a sultry jazz diva, and Charlie Lim, a neo-soul singer-songwriter, are among those making waves. Tham won the Sing Jazz Emerging Jazz Vocalist of the Year award and is set to release her debut album in May. Lim has been touring internationally and has been commissioned to write theme songs for the SG50 project and 2015 SEA Games. Meanwhile, The Steve Mcqueens, a jazz quintet, are set to perform at the O2 Arena in London with British acid jazz band Incognito in May, after forming the band after securing a regular gig.

site_title: AIIB shows bigger public-sector role needed in providing infrastructure
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is being touted as a solution to Asia's infrastructure needs, with China's President Xi Jinping envisioning a "Silk Road" linking Asia with Europe. The AIIB is seen as a way to increase public investment in basic infrastructure, facilitating trade, investment, and economic activity. However, critics argue that private financial institutions should play a larger role in infrastructure financing. Ultimately, the AIIB's success hinges on increased public-sector involvement in infrastructure provision, which is seen as crucial for economic well-being.

site_title: Indonesian Islamic banks see loans tripling
summary: Indonesian Islamic banks are expected to see loan growth triple to 25.8% in 2015 due to a shift of over 30 trillion rupiah from the state-controlled Hajj fund to syariah-compliant lenders. The government's move will reduce costs of capital and support demand for loans, driven by a predicted cut in Bank Indonesia's policy rate. This growth is expected to outpace the 8.3% increase in 2014 and the forecasted 16.5% increase by both Islamic and non-Islamic banks.

site_title: Indonesia seeks major role in Chinese-led AIIB
summary: Indonesia aims to play a major role in the Chinese-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), with the country's finance minister reserving a vice-president position. Indonesia is expected to be a main beneficiary of the $50 billion bank, seeking funding for infrastructure projects. However, Beijing has already agreed to host the AIIB headquarters, and the US has expressed concerns about the bank's governance and environmental standards. At least 35 countries have joined the AIIB by the deadline, with Indonesia and China vying for influence in the bank.

site_title: India will cut emissions for more money, tech
summary: India is considering a sharper cut in emissions if rich nations provide funding and technology. Environment Minister Prakash Javadekar said India may present two sets of commitments: one it can fund itself and a more ambitious one if developed economies pledge money. The decision comes ahead of a December global climate meeting, where India is expected to make or break a global deal. India has promised to cut its carbon intensity by 25% and is calculating its potential commitments based on funding and technology from developed nations.

site_title: Stellar service is key to success
summary: Realstar, a premium real estate company, has achieved over $5 billion in sales since specializing in landed property. Managing director William Wong attributes the company's success to its team of 60 staff with in-depth market knowledge and personalized service. Despite a slow property market, Wong sees landed property as a good investment opportunity, with prices down by 2-3% and potential for further drops. Realstar is launching a new sales gallery and showroom in mid-April, offering a venue for clients to meet sales staff and view recommended properties.

site_title: Beijing seen to relax rules on trading by foreign investors
summary: China is relaxing rules on trading by foreign investors on its Shanghai-based interbank market, making it easier to obtain quotas and reducing paperwork. This move aims to advance foreign institutional funds' access to the market but does not increase the size of foreign investments allowed. Foreign investors will now be able to invest in more products, including CDs, bond repurchase agreements, and swaps. The reform does not address tax plans for foreign fund profits, and its impact on domestic rates and liquidity remains uncertain.

site_title: Nutritionists wary of Buffett's portfolio
summary: Warren Buffett is expanding his investment portfolio to include junk food brands such as Velveeta, Jell-O, and Oscar Mayer wieners, despite nutritionists' concerns about the health implications. Buffett's existing portfolio already includes fast food chains, soft drinks, and processed foods. While Buffett has a high-sugar, high-salt diet and dismisses the idea of eating healthier, some experts worry that his investments send a negative message about nutrition. However, financial analysts see the acquisitions as a smart business move, generating significant cash flow for Berkshire Hathaway.

site_title: Swiber shares up on news of US$405m contracts
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-based construction firm, has secured US$405.6 million worth of new contracts, including a major US$333 million contract from India's Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC). The company's shares rose 14.7% after the announcement, bringing its order book to over US$1.8 billion. Despite a slump in crude oil prices, Swiber remains competitive and is tendering for at least US$1.1 billion of new contracts in India. The firm intends to fully pay its S$95 million debt due in June and is considering restructuring its 2016 and 2017 debt.

site_title: Property auction sales almost double in Q1 to $34.3m
summary: Singapore's property auction market saw a significant increase in sales in Q1 2015, with 10 properties sold for S$34.3 million, more than double the S$13.7 million from the same period last year. The majority of sales were from mortgagees, with 56 properties put up for auction, and only one from an owner. Shophouses and high-end properties are in high demand, selling at 20-30% below their 2007-2008 peak prices. The market is expected to continue growing, with total sales value projected to reach S$50-55 million for H1 2015.

site_title: Boeing nears US$7.7b sale of 30 Dreamliners to China's Hainan Airlines
summary: Boeing is set to sell 30 787-9 Dreamliner aircraft to China's Hainan Airlines for $7.7 billion, valued at $257.1 million each. The deal would bolster Boeing's sales, following a slow 2015 order tally. China's carriers are expected to benefit from a travel boom, as the 787-9 is a marquee jet for the company. The sale would be a significant boost to Boeing's order book, following a period of low sales.

site_title: EU unveils ambitious overhaul of digital economy
summary: The European Union unveiled an ambitious plan to overhaul its digital economy, aiming to make online media and services available across the continent's 28 economies. The proposal, set to be officially unveiled on May 6, includes measures to allow Europeans to access foreign media services while abroad and encourage cross-border online shopping. However, the plan faces significant challenges, including copyright and trademark laws, which vary across the EU, and opposition from digital powerhouses and industry groups. The implementation of the plan is expected to be arduous, with EU officials acknowledging the need for a "modern" approach to copyright.

site_title: New govt bond, easier ETF access ahead for retail players
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced plans to launch the Singapore Savings Bond (SSB), a new type of government bond that offers retail investors a fresh option. The SSB will not penalize early redemption and pays bonus interest when held to maturity. Additionally, MAS will ease financial and administrative costs for corporate issuers to tap the retail market, making plain vanilla corporate bonds more readily available to retail investors. The government also plans to amend the definition of Excluded Investment Products (EIPs) to allow more retail investors to access exchange-traded funds (ETFs).

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Macau junket operator plans US$4b Vietnam casino with 2 partners
summary: A Vietnamese investment group, VinaCapital, and Hong Kong's Chow Tai Fook Enterprises, have teamed up with Macau's Suncity to develop a US$4 billion casino resort in Quang Nam, Vietnam. The project, despite a ban on Vietnamese citizen gambling, aims to capitalize on tourist revenue. The Vietnamese government is considering changing legislation to allow local residents to gamble, which could increase annual gaming revenues to US$3 billion. The partnership will initially rely on foreign passport holders, but the potential for growth is significant, with analysts predicting annual gaming revenues of US$3 billion if laws are loosened.

site_title: Property investment deals cross S$3b so far in Q1
summary: Investment sales in Singapore's property market have reached S$3 billion in Q1, surpassing the previous quarter but falling short of the S$4 billion mark from last year. The office sector has been a standout performer, while residential sector deals have halved year-on-year. Private sector deals account for 74% of total investment sales, with the remaining 26% coming from government and institutional investors. Despite a surplus of capital, a pricing standoff continues to hinder deal-making.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Facebook bets on Messenger app, opens it to developers
summary: Facebook has launched the Messenger Platform, allowing developers to create new features and monetize mobile applications targeting the social network's 1.39 billion users. The platform enables sharing of photos, audio clips, videos, and other digital content, and aims to make Messenger a full-featured and rich media platform. The move is part of Facebook's efforts to compete with rivals like Snapchat and to integrate e-commerce and peer-to-peer payments into the app. The platform is being tested with select partners, with revenue tactics to be determined in the future.

site_title: Britain says Huawei poses no threat to its national security
summary: Britain's board monitoring Huawei's operations has concluded that the Chinese telecoms equipment giant poses no threat to the country's national security. Established in 2010, the board set up an independent cybersecurity evaluation centre in Oxford to assess whether Huawei's equipment could compromise national security. The evaluation centre has found no evidence of a threat, allowing Huawei to continue providing equipment to Britain's mobile and fixed-line networks. This decision comes after concerns over Huawei's ties to the Chinese government and potential security risks.

images.alt_text: Founded by a former People's Liberation Army officer, Huawei has been involved in the UK's telecoms networks for a decade.

site_title: Crude at 2-week high on low US output gains, Yemen crisis
summary: Crude oil prices surged to a two-week high due to shrinking US crude production gains and mounting geopolitical tensions in Yemen. Despite the increase, analysts remain bearish on crude prices, citing fundamental factors such as oversupply. US crude inventories reached a record high, but the market reacted positively to geopolitical tensions, with Brent futures gaining 4.4% to $58.97. Analysts predict further price drops as the market becomes numb to headlines and fundamental factors remain bleak.

images.alt_text: Bulls trumped bears on Thursday, propelling crude futures to a two-week high as the market reacted to shrinking US crude production gains, mounting geopolitical tensions in Yemen and a weakening dollar.

site_title: State subsidies prop up China shipping lines amid industry slump
summary: China's shipping industry is receiving a boost from state subsidies amid a global slump. Three major domestic cargo freighters, China Cosco, China Shipping Development, and China Shipping Container Lines, are expected to report profits in 2014, thanks to hundreds of millions of dollars in cash grants for scrapping old vessels. This is the first time these companies have reported profits in years, with earnings showing some of the best in years. The subsidies are a response to China's economic slowdown, which has squeezed the global shipping industry.

images.alt_text: Without at least 1.38b yuan in subsidies, China Cosco would have incurred a 2014 loss of 500m yuan, says an analyst.

site_title: S'pore 'should adapt to China's services shift'
summary: Singapore needs to adapt to China's shift from a production-based to a services-based economy, according to Credit Suisse's chief economist Dong Tao. China's economy is expected to slow further, but its consumption and services sectors are growing, creating jobs and absorbing losses from the manufacturing sector. Singapore must efficiently tap into China's consumption and services-based economy to benefit, with the US recovery also providing possible cheer.

site_title: DSM opens regional Nutrition Innovation Centre here for R&D
summary: DSM has opened a S$5 million Nutrition Innovation Centre in Singapore, part of its new premises at Mapletree Business City. The centre focuses on R&D in nutrition science, catering to diet-conscious Singaporeans. The centre is part of DSM's S$8.8 million expansion plans.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Citic, KKR control 60.2% of United Envirotech as offer goes unconditional
summary: Citic and KKR have gained control of 60.2% of water-treatment specialist United Envirotech, making their takeover bid unconditional. The buyers offered S$1.65 per share, with UEL shares closing at S$1.64. The company plans to invest 300 million yuan in a wastewater treatment plant in China and has also announced a joint venture with China National Offshore Oil Corp to build an integrated wastewater facility. UEL's shares rose on the news, following an active day of deals.

site_title: High profile for Singapore sculpture at Paris art show
summary: Singaporean artist Chen Sai Hua Kuan's sculpture "Listening 2" is on display at the Art Paris fair in Paris, marking the first time Singapore has been featured as the guest of honor. The 4.5m x 3m x 5m steel structure invites visitors to shout into its opening to hear how sound travels, inspired by a primitive gadget for sound travel. The fair, which opened on Wednesday, features over 50 artists from South-east Asia, including Singapore, and is expected to draw over 60,000 visitors through the weekend.

site_title: Global IPO proceeds shrink in Q1: EY
summary: Global IPO proceeds fell 19% to $38.2 billion in Q1 2015, with the US seeing a 53% decline to $5.6 billion. Asia-Pacific proceeds dropped 18% to $15.8 billion, primarily due to Greater China's 21% decline. Despite a slow start, EY expects IPO activity to pick up as the year progresses, with a healthy and growing pipeline. Europe, the Middle East, India, and Africa contributed positively, with a 20% increase in main-market listings to $16.5 billion.

site_title: Alps crash: Co-pilot may have brought down plane
summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board, after the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, deliberately brought the plane down. Lubitz, 28, left the cockpit and refused to re-enter, operating a control that sent the plane into its fatal descent. The Marseille prosecutor said Lubitz was not a terrorist and there were no grounds to consider the crash as a terrorist incident. The cause of the crash remains under investigation, with investigators studying voice recordings from the "black box" and searching for the second pilot.

site_title: STI lift may be due to early window dressing
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 12.57 points to 3,431.59 on March 26, 2015, possibly due to early quarter-ending window dressing and expectations of a Wall Street rebound. Banks, including Keppel Corp, CapitaLand, and Singtel, contributed to the gains, while shares of SIIC Environment slipped after the company announced a water treatment acquisition. Despite regional weakness and a red European market opening, turnover increased to S$1.2 billion, with notable contributions from Keppel Corp and offshore marine sector shares.

site_title: Lloyd's 2014 pre-tax profit unchanged at £3.2b
summary: Lloyd's of London reported a pre-tax profit of £3.2 billion in 2014, unchanged from 2013, due to flat growth in the insurance and reinsurance market. The combined ratio, a measure of underwriting profitability, was 88.1%, weaker than the previous year. Despite this, Lloyd's said its results were "strong" and attributed the performance to a conservative asset mix and low interest rate environment. The company plans to expand globally, opening branches in Dubai, China, Mexico, and India, and is looking to enter markets such as Turkey, Malaysia, and Colombia.

site_title: MPA refutes Iceberg claims
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) of Singapore has denied claims made by research outfit Iceberg Research that a member reported Noble Group's commercial practices in Singapore to the MPA in 2013. Iceberg claimed Noble was associated with "less than reputable" companies, but the MPA found no malpractices. The MPA did not renew Noble Resources International's bunker supplier licence due to non-compliance with commitments, not due to any regulatory breaches. The MPA also stated that no information about the bankruptcy of OW Bunker, a Danish bunker supplier, was provided to the authorities before the company's bankruptcy.

site_title: Owners of strata title properties expect rise in maintenance fees despite GST exemption
summary: Malaysian strata title property owners can expect an increase in maintenance fees despite a 6% goods and services tax (GST) exemption, as the fees are not zero-rated. Property consultants and tax experts predict a fee hike of over 10% to cover shortfalls, particularly in developments with substantial defaulters. The exemption, while a compromise, only partially eases the burden on joint management bodies (JMBs) and management corporations, which must now recover the additional expenses. This may lead to higher home prices and reduced collections.

site_title: From making money to making music
summary: Ex-banker Druv Kent, who spent 15 years in the corporate world, has pursued his lifelong passion for music, releasing his debut album "About Time" after penning 17 songs in six months. The album, produced by Tim Bradshaw and others, has been released in Singapore, India, and the UK, and Kent has built a steady following in Singapore by playing at venues such as Timbre and Sing Jazz Club. Despite the late start, Kent's family supports his move, and he aims to overcome the bias that people expect English songs to come only from Western performers.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Singapore-based Druv Kent live in concert.
Kent with Simon Edwards (left) and Calum MacColl, who produced six of the 10 tracks in his debut album, About Time. The album has been released in Singapore, India and the UK.

site_title: More than just a simple tale of a girl and her dog
summary: Hungarian director Kornel Mundruczo's film "White God" tells a tale of a young girl's struggle to find her loyal dog Hagen, but beneath the surface is a darker allegory about society's ills and marginalized minorities. The film critiques nationalism, right-wing elements, and the treatment of mixed-breed dogs, using Hagen as a symbol of the oppressed. After Hagen's mother is taken away, he faces harsh realities, including being dumped by his owner and encountering unsavory characters. The film takes a surreal turn, conveying a sense of optimism and the possibility of beauty emerging from darkness.

site_title: Zopim to power FB's Businesses on Messenger
