summary: Crude oil prices dropped 50-70 cents to US$47.47 and US$55.30 respectively, as US commercial crude oil inventories reached a record 466.7 million barrels, the highest level in at least 80 years. Analysts predict oil prices will remain sideways before slowly climbing to the US$60-US$70 range by year-end, with potential changes in Opec production and the lifting of an oil embargo on Iran.

site_title: Talks on Plan B for IMF reforms emerge
summary: The US Congress's failure to ratify the 2010 International Monetary Fund (IMF) reforms has led to discussions of "Plan B", which could slash US voting power nearly in half. This comes as patience wears thin with lawmakers. The proposed reforms, originally supported by the White House, were blocked by the US Congress. Talks on "Plan B" have emerged as a result, sparking concerns over the future of IMF reforms.

site_title: It may cost US$99,000 to attend a top business school in US this year
summary: Top-ranked US business schools are raising tuition fees by 2-10% for the 2015-16 academic year, with the most expensive school, MIT's Sloan School of Management, charging US$65,750. The University of Maryland's Smith School of Business has the largest tuition hike, with an 9.9% increase, while Cornell University's Johnson Graduate School of Management reported the smallest bump. Despite rising tuition, applications to business schools remain strong, with 62% of full-time, two-year MBA programmes receiving more applications in the 2013-14 admissions cycle.

site_title: Germanwings air crash puts spotlight back on flight safety
summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board. The incident, the latest in a series of high-profile accidents, has raised concerns over flight safety. An investigation is underway, with one of the black boxes recovered but believed to be damaged. The accident rate in Europe has been declining, with 0.15 jet aircraft lost per million flights in 2014, down from 0.24 in 2009-2013. The incident is a major setback, but the aviation industry has seen a significant improvement in safety records, with low-cost carriers boasting low accident rates similar to larger airlines.

site_title: Record coffee harvest expected in Indonesia after favourable rains
summary: Indonesia is expected to harvest a record coffee crop this season, with production potentially increasing 18% to 650,000 tonnes, according to trader estimates. This would surpass the previous record of 630,000 tonnes in 2009-2010. Favorable rains have boosted yields, and the global harvest is expected to expand 7% to 152.8 million bags in 2015-2016. The increase in supply may put pressure on prices, particularly for robusta beans.

site_title: EU imposes anti-dumping duties on stainless steel from China, Taiwan
summary: The European Union has imposed anti-dumping duties on imports of cold-rolled stainless steel sheet from China and Taiwan, effective Thursday. Tariffs of up to 25.2% for Chinese imports and up to 12% for Taiwanese imports will be applied, following a complaint by the European steel producers association Eurofer. The duties aim to counter unfair pricing practices by Chinese and Taiwanese producers, who have flooded the EU market with steel since 2010. The move is expected to impact the global market and boost European stainless steel makers.

site_title: Weak Feb business spending data points to Q1 slowdown
summary: US business investment spending plans fell 1.4% in February, likely due to a strong dollar and weak global demand, prompting economists to lower first-quarter growth estimates. The slowdown could delay the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike until later in the year. A strong dollar has cut into overseas profits of multinational companies, while lower crude prices have forced oil firms to cut back on investment projects. Economists now expect a 1.2-2% annual GDP growth pace, down from previous forecasts of 1.5-2.5%.

site_title: Crowds brave heat and long wait to pay their final respects
summary: Thousands of Singaporeans gathered to pay their final respects to late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, braving the heat and long wait to catch a glimpse of the gun carriage bearing his casket. The crowds showed remarkable determination and kindness, with businesses handing out free water, seats, and flowers to those waiting in line. The lying-in-state, which began on Wednesday, is expected to continue round the clock until Saturday, with dignitaries and ordinary citizens alike paying tribute to the country's first prime minister.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Morgan Stanley cuts commodities price forecasts
summary: Morgan Stanley cut its price forecasts for base metals and bulk commodities, citing China's "dormant" industry failing to bolster demand. The bank reduced forecasts for copper, nickel, iron ore, and coal, citing a collapse in oil prices and a strengthening US dollar. Industrial metals are expected to perform better than bulk commodities, driven by growth in developed countries. China's economic slowdown and oversupply of commodities have dragged down prices, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index reaching a 12-year low.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley cut its price forecasts for almost all base metals and bulk commodities as China's "dormant" industry fails to bolster demand in the world's biggest consumer of copper and iron ore.

site_title: As value emerges, investment in Asian real estate to swell: Colliers
summary: Colliers expects real estate investment in Asia to rise 102% in 2015, driven by yield improvements in some Asian markets. China remains the top destination, with institutional investors and high-net-worth individuals refocusing on the region. Yields in Asia are expected to increase due to economic slowdowns and a US interest rate increase. Outbound real estate investment from Asia is forecasted to rise 61% in 2015, with prime gateway cities such as New York and London remaining popular destinations.

site_title: ECB's purchase of ABS pays off as prices rise
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) asset-backed securities (ABS) purchase program is showing signs of success, with prices rising to the highest levels in over seven years. The program, which has bought €4 billion of ABS since November, is encouraging banks to offload bonds and free up their balance sheets, allowing them to lend more. This has led to a surge in bond sales, with average prices reaching 98.2 cents on the euro, near the highest since October 2007. While the plan has yet to revive the new-issue market, it is helping to stimulate the economy and increase lending.

images.alt_text: Mr Draghi's purchase programme is breathing life into the asset-backed securities market.

site_title: Prominent eye surgeon's former home up for sale
summary: The former home of late eye surgeon and philanthropist Arthur Lim has been put up for sale in Singapore's prime landed residential area. The two-storey detached house, located on Chancery Hill Road, has a land area of approximately 12,772 sq ft and is selling for an indicative price of S$19 million. The property is zoned for redevelopment into a luxurious bungalow, two bungalows, or strata landed housing, and has received approval from the Urban Redevelopment Authority for subdivision into two bungalows. The expression of interest closes on April 21.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang
With a land area of 12,772 sq ft, the late Prof Lim's Chancery Hill Road property is selling for an indicative price of S$19 million, or about S$1,488 per sq ft.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Three Singapore-listed companies received positive broker recommendations. NOL was upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$1.30, citing a more favorable supply-demand outlook for the container industry. SingHaiyi Group was also upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$0.19, driven by rising US property prices and a stronger US dollar. Ezion Holdings was upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$1.83, despite a resilient liftboat business, due to steady earnings deliveries and a mispriced valuation.

site_title: 'Buy' upgrade and takeover rumours buoy NOL
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL), Singapore's largest container line, saw its stock surge 6.9% after Goldman Sachs upgraded it to a 'buy' with a 12-month target price of S$1.30, citing a possible merger and acquisition. The company's balance sheet has strengthened following the sale of its logistics business for US$1.2 billion, and analysts speculate a potential takeover by Orient Overseas International or other European shippers. However, NOL's spokesman declined to comment on market speculation, fueling ongoing takeover rumors.

images.alt_text: NOL has posted four straight years of underlying losses but may start making profits again in 2015 due to its exposure to trans-Pacific trade from Asia to the United States, Goldman said.

site_title: Rio in adrenalin-driven Olympic race
summary: Rio de Janeiro is racing against time to be ready for the 2016 Olympics, but pollution in the bay hosting sailing events and concerns over the choice of golf course site are major hurdles. Despite assurances from organisers, green campaigners and athletes express dissatisfaction with the city's efforts to clean up Guanabara Bay, with only 49% of raw sewage to be treated. The Olympic golf course is also set to be built in an ecological reserve, sparking outrage among environmentalists. Organisers remain optimistic, with city mayor Eduardo Paes insisting the Games will be a success despite the challenges.

site_title: Vietnam legacy has lessons for anti-Americanism today
summary: The 50th anniversary of the launch of Operation 'Rolling Thunder' bombing campaign in Vietnam marks a pivotal moment in the escalation of the Vietnam War. The conflict led to a significant growth of anti-Americanism across the world, undermining US prestige and soft power. This legacy remains relevant today, as the US continues to recover from the international unpopularity of the Iraq War and perceptions of excessive US power. A recent Pew Global Attitudes Project survey found that favourability towards the US has declined in many countries, with Muslim-majority nations showing particularly strong anti-American sentiment.

site_title: HSBC chairman says new rules on banker accountability reasonable
summary: HSBC chairman Douglas Flint stated that new rules on banker accountability, set to be implemented in 2016, are "entirely reasonable" given the UK's financial crisis pain. The new "senior managers' regime" makes top bankers directly accountable for rule breaches on their patch, reversing the "burden of proof". Bankers may face jail time if their reckless behavior leads to a bank's collapse. Flint believes the rules will restore public trust in the financial sector and ensure a fair and robust regulatory regime. The new regime aims to draw a line under misconduct in financial services.

images.alt_text: Mr Flint said he wanted to see a regulatory regime that was seen as the fairest and most robust.

site_title: Mattel's Hello Barbie draws ire of toy critic
summary: Mattel's Hello Barbie, a doll with speech-recognition software and a web connection, has drawn criticism from toy critic Susan Linn, who claims it could violate children's privacy. Linn, known for her campaigns against Baby Einstein videos and Pussycat Dolls, argues that the doll's features make it "creepy." The product was unveiled at the Toy Fair in New York last month, with the intention of helping Mattel's turnaround. Linn's concerns have sparked debate about the potential risks of connected toys for children's well-being and online safety.

site_title: High rents push millennials towards home buying
summary: Millennials in the US are increasingly turning to homeownership due to rising rents. In 2014, 32% of the US housing market consisted of Americans in their 20s and early 30s, up from 28% two years earlier. Many, like Eric Arther, who pays $1,410 in rent, are seeking to build equity by buying a home. This trend is driven by high rents, with many opting to invest in a down payment over continued rent payments.

site_title: Big Indon banks count on infrastructure deals
summary: Indonesia's state-run banks are relying on government-led infrastructure projects to boost loan growth, which slowed to 11.5% in January, the smallest year-on-year gain in almost five years. The banks have reduced credit lines to the commodities sector and local businesses have delayed expansion plans due to the slowing economy. Analysts predict loan growth will increase in the second half of 2015 if infrastructure projects are completed, but warn that a delay or cancellation could lead to loan growth below 14% this year. President Jokowi's infrastructure plans aim to improve the country's dilapidated infrastructure.

site_title: China approves free-trade zones in Guangdong, Fujian and Tianjin
summary: China has approved free-trade zones in Guangdong, Fujian, and Tianjin, aiming to deepen economic reform and expand opening up. The zones, which were announced in December, focus on integrating with Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Beijing, respectively. The Shanghai FTZ, established in 2013, has shown "positive progress" but has yet to fulfill its promised financial reforms. The move comes amid concerns from companies, including the American Chamber of Commerce in Shanghai, that the zones offer no tangible benefits.

site_title: South Asian beaches target of new EU ship recycling rules
summary: The European Union has implemented strict new rules on ship recycling, requiring EU-registered ships to be recycled at sustainable facilities. This move aims to reduce the practice of dismantling old ships on beaches in South Asia, where hundreds of unskilled workers risk their lives and the environment is severely affected. The new rules are expected to benefit European, Turkish, and Chinese recyclers but may not stop the practice in South Asia, where incentives are high due to lax regulations.

site_title: Shangri-La Asia FY14 bottom line hit by lower fair-value gains
summary: Shangri-La Asia reported a 54% drop in net profit to US$180.89 million for FY14 due to lower fair-value gains from investment properties. Revenue rose 2% to US$2.11 billion, while net profit before non-operating items increased 36% to US$89.8 million. The group's Singapore hotels saw mixed results, with Shangri-La Hotel experiencing a 3% rise in revenue per available room and Shangri-La's Rasa Sentosa Resort & Spa seeing a 10% surge. The board recommended a final dividend of 6 HK cents per share for 2014.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Rising minister takes on Israel's surging home prices
summary: Finance Minister designate Moshe Kahlon has promised to tackle Israel's surging home prices, a key issue in the recent election. However, experts warn that the task will be challenging due to a tangled bureaucracy, construction programs, and a land shortage. Kahlon plans to cut real estate tax benefits and disband the Israel Land Authority, but may face opposition from contractors and the authority's employees. Experts suggest that interest rate hikes could help reduce demand, but Kahlon's success in reducing mobile phone prices is seen as uncertain, given the complexity of the housing market.

site_title: Singapore bond market still sizzling as rates rise
summary: Singapore's bond market continues to thrive despite interest rates reaching multi-year highs, with over $2.4 billion raised from 16 issues in March, surpassing the same period last year. The 3-month Sibor rate stands at over 1%, 2.2 times higher than the beginning of the year. Investors are attracted to the market, driven by liquidity and the Fed's revised guidance on interest rate hikes. However, bond activity in March is unlikely to make up for the slow start to the year, with volumes still behind that of the same period in 2014.

site_title: Consumer confidence hits 8-month high in March: survey
summary: Consumer confidence in Singapore reached an 8-month high of 124.5 in March, driven by improved personal financial outlook and expectations for better times ahead. The ANZ-Roy Morgan index rose 3.8 points, with 31.1% of respondents saying they were better off financially, compared to 26.8% in February. However, consumers were less ready for major spending, with 16.6% saying it was a good time to buy. The improved confidence was attributed to the national Budget and is expected to be short-lived, with economists predicting a dip following the death of former prime minister Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: IMF inclusion of yuan 'very live' issue, says UK official
summary: The UK has weighed in on the IMF's consideration of including the yuan in its Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, calling it a "very live" issue. China has asked the IMF to include the yuan, citing its growing role in global trade and its efforts to float the currency freely on global markets. The IMF's head, Christine Lagarde, has stated that the yuan will eventually be incorporated into the SDR basket, but the decision will depend on member countries' views.

site_title: RBA warns easy global monetary policy raises risks of office price fall
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) warns that easy global monetary policy is driving demand for Australian office buildings, despite rising vacancies and falling rents, which raises the risk of a future price slump. The central bank notes that investors are seeking yield in a low-interest-rate environment, resulting in lower yields across major office markets, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne. The RBA's concerns about the commercial property market reflect the disconnect between prices and fundamentals, with a growing risk of market dislocation.

site_title: Rig operator Seadrill eyes assets amid downturn
summary: Seadrill, a rig operator owned 24% by billionaire John Fredriksen, is preparing to acquire rivals or assets during the downturn in offshore drilling due to a slump in oil prices and oversupply of new rigs. CEO Per Wullf stated that the company is ready to weather the storm and emerge stronger, even if it takes a couple of years. Seadrill has suspended dividends and is negotiating with shipyards to delay delivery of units, while also seeking contract adjustments with clients. The company aims to "swipe the table" and make acquisitions once valuations have fallen further.

site_title: Companies pay tribute to LKY
summary: Companies in Singapore are paying tribute to the country's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, who died on Monday at 91. Many firms have given employees time off to attend a national week of mourning and some have made donations to charitable causes. Companies such as Unilever, Shell, and CapitaLand have turned off building signages and arranged for transportation to Parliament House. Tributes include a private memorial service at Keppel Corporation and a webcast event at Sembcorp Industries.

site_title: A shared Singapore moment
summary: Singapore mourned the passing of founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, with tributes pouring in from around the world. The "straddle" generation, born during his rule, reflected on their experiences with him, from struggling with bilingual education to serving National Service. As a journalist, the author covered Lee's final major news event, the Sars crisis, showcasing his leadership. The nation will come together to bid him a final farewell, with history judging how Singapore and Singaporeans move forward from this loss, having achieved an economic miracle under his leadership.

images.alt_text: Wong Wei Kong

site_title: Bank of China chief credit officer leaves job
summary: Bank of China chief credit officer Chim Wai Kin left his job after his contract expired and wasn't renewed, amid pay cuts imposed on senior executives at Chinese lenders. The departure comes amid pay cuts being implemented at Chinese lenders. The exact reasons for his departure are not disclosed, but the move is seen as part of broader efforts to reduce executive compensation.

images.alt_text: Chim Wai Kin, the chief credit officer who was Bank of China Ltd's highest-paid executive, left his job amid pay cuts being imposed on senior executives at Chinese lenders, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: More needed for yuan to go global
summary: China needs to further open its domestic market to allow the renminbi to flow freely globally, enabling its emergence as an investment currency. The renminbi has already seen strong organic growth in the offshore market, but more needs to be done to stimulate investor interest. China's domestic equity and bond markets are growing, but are not yet efficient enough to support the renminbi's global adoption. The government must accelerate reform to improve capital markets, increase access to borrowing, and develop the onshore market's liquidity and depth. This will ultimately determine the renminbi's role in the global capital market and its potential as a reserve currency.

site_title: Weak rupiah driving Japanese carmakers to expand in Indonesia
summary: Japanese carmakers are expanding in Indonesia due to the country's weak rupiah, which has driven down imported car sales. Indonesian car imports fell below 10,000 units in February for the 11th consecutive month, less than 10% of overall new car sales. Toyota, Nissan, and Mitsubishi are investing in local production and selling cheaper models, aiming to tap Indonesia's growing market. Mitsubishi plans a $600 million investment to build an Indonesian factory, which could eventually export to nearby countries, taking advantage of the weak rupiah.

site_title: SIIC Env shares rally on news of 1.55b yuan acquisition
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings' shares surged 9.3% to close at 16.4 cents after announcing a 1.55 billion yuan (S$348.3 million) acquisition of China-based water-treatment business Global Envirotech Investment. The deal includes 479.18 million yuan for debt repayment and 1.56 billion new shares, valued at 13.2 cents apiece. The acquisition is expected to increase SIIC's earnings per share and is seen as a strategic addition to the company's existing business.

site_title: Why Singapore's extraordinary leader will be missed
summary: Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, known for transforming the country into an economic powerhouse, has passed away at 91. Under his leadership, Singapore developed a thriving middle class, a comprehensive healthcare system, and a pension system that avoided the pay-as-you-go trap. Lee's pragmatic approach to governance and his emphasis on human ingenuity and sound finance earned him international recognition. His influence extended beyond Singapore, with China's economic reforms under Deng Xiaoping credited to his insights and advice. Lee's legacy as a statesman and leader is being celebrated globally.

site_title: Aussie engineer Civmec eyeing acquisitions
summary: Australian heavy engineering firm Civmec is eyeing acquisitions to expand its business, shifting focus from mining and oil to public infrastructure projects. CEO Pat Tallon expects significant revenue from eastern Australia and Southeast Asia, estimating up to A$125 billion in infrastructure investment over the next seven years. Civmec shares have recovered marginally after a 29% drop last week, but may consider buying back shares to support the stock due to potential merger and acquisition deals. The company remains active in tendering for contracts and is expanding its focus on public infrastructure projects.

images.alt_text: Australian heavy engineering firm Civmec, which has seen its share price plunge over the past couple of weeks, said that it is on the lookout for potential acquisitions to expand its business.

site_title: Adidas CEO seeks more time for new strategy after two flops
summary: Adidas CEO Herbert Hainer is seeking an additional two years to implement a new strategy after two previous plans failed to deliver results. The company will present a five-year financial plan aimed at regaining market share from Nike and protecting its soccer franchise. Hainer will present the plan alongside internal candidates Eric Liedtke and Roland Auschel, and external candidates, as the supervisory board begins the search for his successor. Investors are calling for faster change at the top, citing the company's struggles to compete with Nike.

images.alt_text: Mr Hainer will present on Thursday a five-year financial plan aimed at wresting back market share from Nike and protecting its soccer franchise from upstarts such as Under Armour. Adidas is predicting a profit margin of 6.5-7 per cent this year, compared to 14 per cent at Nike.

site_title: A Picasso up for auction has dizzying value
summary: A Picasso painting, "Les Femmes d'Alger (Version 'O')" valued at approximately $140 million is set to be auctioned off by Christie's on May 11. The painting, created in 1955, is part of a new sale featuring 25 modern and contemporary artworks spanning 100 years. This sale marks a shift in Christie's postwar and contemporary sales, with collectors increasingly seeking earlier art for its historical importance and rarity. The sale is part of Christie's broader strategy to cater to a broader client base and includes works by artists such as Mark Rothko and Monet.

site_title: Hutchison Whampoa to buy UK mobile network O2 for £10.25b
summary: Hutchison Whampoa, a Hong Kong-based conglomerate, agreed to acquire O2, a UK mobile network, for £10.25 billion. The deal, led by billionaire Li Ka-shing, aims to increase the company's stable income streams. The acquisition includes £9.25 billion in cash upfront, with the remainder to be paid upon meeting financial targets. Regulatory approval is expected to take a year, with completion anticipated by June 2016. This move intensifies Hutchison Whampoa's push into stable income-generating businesses.

site_title: China's clout rises to match its ambitions with establishment of three institutions
summary: China is establishing three institutions to match its growing economic influence, including the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) with authorized capital of $100 billion. The institutions, also including a $50 billion development bank and a $40 billion Silk Road fund, aim to revive the ancient trade route between Asia and Europe. China's yuan may also become an official reserve currency, recognized by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The move reflects China's rising role in global affairs and its desire to challenge the US-led international economic architecture.

site_title: Helicopters search for bodies from crash in French Alps
summary: French helicopters are searching for the wreckage and bodies of the Airbus A320 that crashed in the French Alps on its way to Germany from Spain, killing all 150 on board. Approximately 600 personnel are involved in the recovery efforts, with 50 military police working to find a ground route to the site. The terrain is described as mountainous and steep, with debris found to be smoking. No bodies have been evacuated from the site, and teams are seeking to recover the second black box.

site_title: What I learnt from Lee Kuan Yew
summary: The article reflects on the late Lee Kuan Yew's legacy, drawing from the author's personal experiences as a policymaker. Key takeaways include: the importance of culture in shaping policy, strategic thinking in planning for the next lap of development, and the critical balance between security and economic development. Lee Kuan Yew's leadership and vision led to Singapore's transformation from a Third World to First World nation, and his lessons will be a case study for generations to come.

site_title: The leader who delivered - and made history
summary: Singapore's founding leader Lee Kuan Yew led his country to independence and fulfilled its promise, making him one of the most extraordinary personalities in Asia and the world. Unlike other Afro-Asian leaders, Lee successfully transitioned from revolutionary to ruler, whereas others failed. He credited India as a key model, but unlike Nehru, Lee delivered on his promise. Lee's ability to see into the future and his pragmatic approach allowed him to navigate complex situations, including the merger with Malaysia and the separation in 1965. His leadership led to Singapore's transformation into a clean and comfortable public housing society, a full employment society, and a major hub of global manufacturing and service industries. Lee's secret to success was Singapore's "ideology-free" approach, which prioritized pragmatism and effectiveness over ideology.

site_title: Thoughts turn to window-dressing
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 5.76 points to 3,419.02, despite its year-to-date performance of just 1.6%. The gain was driven by firms like UOB, Singtel, and Keppel Corp, as well as SIIC Environment, which jumped 9.3% after announcing a buyout. Goldman Sachs upgraded Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) to a "buy" with a 12-month target price of S$1.30, citing its potential for profitability and balance sheet restoration. The commodities sector, however, saw Noble Group's shares remain unchanged amid concerns over fair values.

site_title: Hollande pledges to shed full light on Alps plane crash
summary: French President Francois Hollande pledged to shed full light on the Alps plane crash that killed 150 passengers, mostly German or Spanish. A second black box envelope was found, but the box itself remains elusive. Hollande assured German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy that authorities will uncover the cause of the tragedy. France stands by its international partners in mourning the victims.

site_title: Wall Street stars join Silicon Valley gold rush
summary: Wall Street's top talent is flocking to Silicon Valley, with Morgan Stanley's CFO Ruth Porat joining Google in a move that highlights the growing appeal of the tech industry. This trend is driven by Silicon Valley's blockbuster growth and the financial industry's struggles with regulations and public confidence. As a result, many young graduates are opting for careers in tech over finance, with software companies like Uber and Twitter hiring a higher percentage of MIT graduates in 2014 compared to finance firms. The movement between industries has built on itself, with Wall Street talent bringing financial expertise to startups, and startups luring away lower-ranking programmers.

site_title: JPMorgan pares US Q1 GDP view to 1.5%
summary: JPMorgan economist Michael Feroli downgraded his US Q1 GDP view to 1.5% due to a weak report on domestic durable goods orders, which showed a 1.4% drop in February. This is a decrease from his previous estimate of 2.0%. Despite this, Feroli still expects annual GDP growth to remain on track at 2.4%. The downgrade is a reflection of the slowing US economy.

site_title: Euro advances, bolstered by German data
summary: The euro climbed towards US$1.10 against the dollar, boosted by a strong German business morale survey and other encouraging economic data in the eurozone. The eurozone composite flash PMI jumped to a near four-year high, while regional business surveys were also robust. However, gains are likely to be limited due to the ECB's asset purchase program, and currency strategist Peter Kinsella said the data doesn't change much for the euro.

site_title: Global reach of French plane crash tragedy
summary: A German airliner crashed in the Alps, killing 150 people from 18 countries, including Germany, France, and Sweden. Hundreds of TV crews are covering the tragedy, with reporters struggling to access the inaccessible crash site. Local residents are offering support to families of the victims, but relatives are unable to visit the area due to its inaccessibility. The cause of the crash remains a mystery, fueling widespread dread and fascination with aviation disasters. French authorities are providing limited updates, frustrating foreign officials seeking information.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of TV crews are crowding small French towns in the Alps nearest the crash site of a German airliner in a testament to the global reach of the tragedy.

site_title: Germanwings crash cannot be explained by plane's age: experts
summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320, 24 years old at the time of the crash, cannot be explained by its age due to strict maintenance checks. Modern civilian aircraft can fly for 40 years without major problems as long as they are well-maintained. Companies like IranAir and charter companies in Asia continue to use older aircraft, and the US Air Force One is also a quarter-century old. Despite this, planes are subject to rigorous maintenance checks, including a major overhaul every 5 years, allowing them to remain in use for a long time.

site_title: French A320 crash likely doubled Lufthansa's historic death toll
summary: A French Alps Airbus A320 crash on Tuesday is likely to have doubled Lufthansa's historic death toll, with 150 passengers and crew thought to have died. This would surpass the 146 fatalities in five other crashes since Lufthansa was refounded in 1955. The incident is Lufthansa's worst crash before this week, surpassing a 1974 Boeing 747-100 crash that killed 59 passengers and crew. Lufthansa's safety record has been a strong selling point for the airline.

site_title: French Alps crash heavy blow to Lufthansa's image
summary: A plane crash involving Germanwings, a low-cost carrier owned by Lufthansa, has dealt a significant blow to the airline's image, just as it was trying to expand its low-cost business and compete with rivals. The crash of Germanwings flight 4U 9525 in the French Alps, which killed 150 people, raises concerns about the airline's safety record and could impact its low-cost concept. Analysts say the crash could lead to a substantial damage to Lufthansa's reputation and potentially jeopardize its low-cost strategy, which is already being tested by a bitter labour dispute with pilots.

site_title: Labourious 'black box' inquiry aims to unlock German crash cause
summary: French investigators are conducting a complex inquiry into the Germanwings airline disaster in the French Alps that killed 150 people. The cockpit voice recorder, one of the "black boxes," was found and will be analyzed to determine the cause of the crash. The investigation will also involve analyzing debris, radar tracks, and operational records, and may take over a year to complete. A parallel criminal inquiry has been opened, and Airbus and engine maker CFM will provide technical advice. The investigation aims to establish a cause and make safety recommendations, but will not attribute blame.

images.alt_text: A warren of laboratories on the outskirts of Paris is where French investigators could face months of laborious and complex detective work to try to establish what caused a German airline disaster in the French Alps that killed 150 people.

site_title: Leaders see horror of French Alp crash as probe gathers pace
summary: French, Spanish, and German leaders visited a makeshift rescue base near the site of the Germanwings air crash, where 150 people died in the worst crash in France in four decades. Investigators are analyzing the badly damaged black box and technical flight data to determine the cause of the mysterious eight-minute descent. Authorities have ruled out terrorism and weather as factors, with officials describing the disaster as "inexplicable." A counselling unit has been established for grieving relatives, and hundreds of firefighters and police are searching the rugged crash site.

images.alt_text: French, Spanish and German leaders on Wednesday visited a makeshift rescue base near the site of the Germanwings air crash, as investigators stepped up their probe into the mysterious disaster that killed 150.

site_title: Greece fails in bid for early cash release, reforms awaited
summary: Greece failed to secure a quick cash payment from the eurozone rescue fund, raising pressure on Athens to deliver a convincing reform program. The European Financial Stability Facility denied Greece's appeal for 1.2 billion euros, citing a lack of legal entitlement. The decision is a setback for Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, who is struggling to secure fresh funds while presenting a comprehensive reform plan and arguing for debt relief. A full list of planned reforms is due by next Monday, but its contents remain uncertain.

images.alt_text: Greece failed in a bid on Wednesday to secure a quick cash payment from the eurozone rescue fund to help stave off potential bankruptcy next month, raising pressure on Athens to deliver a convincing reform programme within days.

site_title: US crude stocks rise as Cushing storage maintains record: EIA
summary: US crude inventories rose by 8.2 million barrels last week, maintaining the 80-year high for the 11th consecutive week. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub rose by 1.91 million barrels. Gasoline stocks fell by 2 million barrels, while distillate inventories dropped 34,000 barrels. Refinery crude runs rose by 94,000 barrels per day and utilization rates increased by 0.9 percentage points. US crude imports fell by 129,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Swedish soccer team narrowly escaped flying on Germanwings flight
summary: A Swedish soccer team, Dalkurd, narrowly escaped boarding a Germanwings flight that crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board. The team had initially considered flying on Germanwings flight 4U 9525 but rejected it due to a long wait for a connection in Duesseldorf. Instead, they flew in three separate groups, citing "little luck" in avoiding a tragic fate. The team's sporting director expressed shock and sadness, noting that they had been at the same check-in desk as the doomed passengers.

site_title: Spain investigates malicious Tweets about air crash
summary: Spain's government is investigating malicious tweets about the air crash in the French Alps, where 150 people died. The tweets targeted Catalans, with one user joking that if all the victims were German and Catalan, what is the tragedy. The Spanish government has ordered an investigation into possible criminal responsibility for the messages, which may constitute hate speech punishable under the penal code. This is not the first time social networks have been used for hate speech, following a crackdown in May 2014.

site_title: EU, US 'likely' to miss year-end target for free trade deal: Latvia
summary: The European Union and the United States are likely to miss the year-end target to conclude the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) free trade deal. EU President Latvia's Foreign Minister Edgars Rinkevics said negotiations may not be concluded due to the need for "two willing parties." Despite EU leaders' commitment to conclude the deal by the end of the year, talks will continue under the Obama administration or before January 2017, with harmonization of regulations and slashing of trade tariffs on the table, but also facing opposition from social activists.

site_title: Cheap eurozone takeaway fuels Chinese acquisitions
summary: The euro's decline has made eurozone business cheaper for Chinese firms, sparking a surge in acquisitions. A recent deal for Italian tyremaker Pirelli valued at 7 billion euros is the latest in a multibillion euro acquisition binge. Chinese companies are taking advantage of the weaker euro to invest in Europe, driven by lower profit margins and a slowing domestic economy. The euro has fallen to nearly 13 billion yuan, making eurozone assets more affordable for Chinese investors. This trend is expected to continue, with Chinese firms looking to acquire technology and brands to exploit domestically.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher buoyed by Kraft-Heinz merger
summary: US stocks opened higher on March 25, 2015, due to the proposed merger of Kraft Foods and HJ Heinz, creating North America's third-largest food conglomerate. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 17.46 points, the S&P 500 added 4.44 points, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 5.76 points. Kraft surged 32.6% to $80.99 after the deal's special dividend of $16.50 per share, a 27% premium to Kraft's closing price.

site_title: KepCorp crosses 90% mark for KepLand delisting
summary: KepCorp has crossed the 90% ownership threshold required to delist its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land. As of March 25, 2015, KepCorp owned 90.9% of Keppel Land shares, still needing 95.5% for compulsory acquisition. Analysts are divided on whether KepCorp will extend its offer again, following its initial offer. The delisting is a significant milestone for KepCorp, which will lead to Keppel Land's removal from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: US core inflation has room to fall: Goldman
summary: US core inflation is expected to decline from a stronger dollar and lower crude prices, according to Goldman Sachs economist Kris Dawsey. The core personal consumption expenditure, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge, is likely to reach 1.2% in the second and third quarters of 2015 before increasing in the fourth quarter, bottoming at 1.5% in the middle of the year.

site_title: Fed's Evans sees 'no compelling reason' to hurry with rate hikes
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Charles Evans expressed concerns about raising interest rates, citing weak inflation and an unemployment rate of 5.5%. He urged a delay in rate hikes until the first half of next year, citing the costs of premature tightening. Evans believes inflation is headed back to a healthy 2% and would need to see core inflation rise above 1.3%, wage growth increase, and inflation expectations rise before raising rates. Most market participants expect a slow rate hike, with Evans stating that he thinks the Fed should be cautious in raising interest rates.

site_title: India's Modi to visit France, Germany and Canada
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will visit France, Germany, and Canada in April, focusing on attracting investment to India. During his three-day visit to France, Modi will meet with President Francois Hollande to discuss a deal for 126 Rafale fighter jets. In Germany, Modi will attend the Hannover Messe and meet with Chancellor Angela Merkel. In Canada, he will address members of the diaspora, continuing his tradition of engaging with overseas Indians. The visits aim to boost India's economic fortunes and attract more foreign investment.

site_title: BoE's Forbes says rates will need to rise despite current low inflation
summary: Bank of England policymaker Kristin Forbes predicts that Britain's low rate of inflation is temporary and will not persist, leading to the need for interest rate hikes as the economy recovers. She also believes there's a "very good chance" that inflation will fall again next month, potentially prompting the Bank of England to cut interest rates below its record low.

site_title: ECB's Praet optimistic on growth, urges restraint on Greece
summary: European Central Bank chief economist Peter Praet expressed optimism about near-term eurozone growth, citing the timing of the ECB's one trillion euro bond-buying campaign. However, Praet warned that lower productivity remains a structural issue and urged policymakers to show "verbal discipline" to avoid stoking tensions over the Greek crisis. The ECB's actions may create better economic conditions, but governments may ease off on needed reforms, exacerbating structural issues. Eurozone finance ministers meet on Monday to address the crisis, which Praet described as a "cyclical recovery" with big structural problems.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO: "safety in aviation not a given"
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr stated that safety in aviation is not a given, following a plane operated by its Germanwings unit crashed into the French Alps, killing all 150 onboard. Spohr visited the crash site and emphasized the importance of prioritizing safety, promising it will remain a top target for the company's 120,000 employees worldwide.

site_title: French air disaster black box 'damaged': source
summary: A cockpit voice recorder (CVR) recovered from the Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps has been damaged and taken to Paris for analysis. The CVR, which is orange in color, is badly mangled and its metal casing is twisted and ripped. A second black box, recording flight data, has yet to be found. The investigation into the crash that killed 150 people is ongoing.

site_title: Asia-Pacific to continue to drive yuan demand: HSBC
summary: HSBC's survey indicates the Asian-Pacific region, particularly Greater China, will continue to drive demand for the Chinese yuan. This contrasts with companies in Europe, such as France and Germany, which are showing signs of divergence in yuan demand.

images.alt_text: HSBC forecasts that trade settlement in the yuan will top 50 per cent of China's total trade by 2020

site_title: US business spending gauge tumbles in February
summary: US business spending plans for February fell for the sixth consecutive month, with non-defense capital goods orders excluding aircraft dropping 1.4% due to a strong dollar and weak global demand. This decline may lead economists to lower their first-quarter growth estimates. The core capital goods orders, a closely watched proxy for business spending, last rose in August, indicating a prolonged slowdown in business investment.

site_title: Hollande, Merkel arrive in Alps for crash victims homage
summary: French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel arrived in the Alpine region to pay homage to the 150 victims of the Airbus plane crash. The leaders, joined by Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, thanked search teams and met with families of victims. The crash, which killed 72 Germans and 49 Spaniards, is the first major air passenger disaster on French soil since 2000. Investigations are ongoing into the still-unexplained cause of the crash.

site_title: UK's FCA proposes fine on Asia Resource Minerals
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority has proposed a "substantial" fine on Asia Resource Minerals Plc for breaching listing and disclosure rules. The investigation, launched in 2013, found serious breaches from June 2011 to July 2013. Asia Resource Minerals has set aside $7 million as a provision in its 2014 half-year accounts. The company is cooperating with the investigation and considering its response. The FCA's proposal highlights breaches of listing and disclosure principles related to procedures, systems, and controls.

site_title: Heinz, Kraft to merge as Buffett, 3G reinvest US$10b
summary: US food giants Heinz and Kraft will merge to form the Kraft Heinz Company, becoming North America's third-largest food and beverage company. Warren Buffett's 3G Capital will reinvest $10 billion in the new group, with Heinz's shareholders holding a 51% stake. The merged company expects $28 billion in revenues, with eight brands earning over $1 billion each, and five in the $500 million to $1 billion range.

site_title: Search for bodies, clues in 'inexplicable' French Alps crash
summary: A German airliner, Germanwings Airbus A320, crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board. The crash, which occurred on a routine flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf, remains "inexplicable" with no distress signal sent before the plane entered a fatal eight-minute descent. Investigators are searching the crash site, analyzing black boxes, and questioning relatives of the victims. French President Francois Hollande and his counterparts from Germany and Spain are scheduled to visit the site to pay respects. The investigation is ongoing, with no initial conclusions on possible causes, and officials rule out a terrorist attack.

site_title: Keppel Corp crosses 90% mark to delist Keppel Land
summary: Keppel Corp has reached the 90% threshold to delist its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land. As of March 25, 2015, Keppel Corp owned 90.9% of Keppel Land shares. Trading in Keppel Land shares will be suspended after the offer closes on Thursday. Keppel Corp still needs to acquire 95.5% of shares to complete the buyout.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corp has crossed the 90 per cent threshold in acceptances required to delist its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land.

site_title: Germany mourns country's largest loss of life in 15 years
summary: Germany mourns its largest loss of life in 15 years after 67 citizens died in the Germanwings crash in the French Alps. Chancellor Angela Merkel prepared to travel to the accident scene, and flags flew at half-mast on federal buildings for three days. The country's largest-circulation newspaper, Bild Zeitung, described the nation's grief as "under shock." Germanwings returned to normal operations, using planes and crews from other airlines to operate some flights, while passengers left candles and flowers at a memorial at Dusseldorf airport.

site_title: Thailand to borrow US$1.7b locally to boost economy
summary: Thailand plans to borrow 57 billion baht (S$2.39 billion) domestically to fund road and water projects, shifting from foreign loans to reduce financial costs. The move aims to boost the country's economy, which grew only 0.7% last year, its weakest pace since 2011. The government expects 4% growth in 2015, despite the central bank cutting its projection to 3.8% due to weak government spending, exports, and consumption. The domestic borrowing plan is part of a larger plan to borrow 80 billion baht this fiscal year.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO says crash "inexplicable"
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr described the crash of a Germanwings A320 in France as "inexplicable," citing a plane free of technical issues and an experienced pilot. The Airbus, carrying 150 passengers and crew, crashed into an Alpine mountainside on Tuesday, killing everyone onboard. Lufthansa will offer special flights to Marseilles for the victims' families. The cause of the crash remains unknown and Spohr refused to speculate.

site_title: BoE payment outage showed crisis management failures, report concludes
summary: A report by the Bank of England concludes that a major payment outage in October 2014 showed the central bank's crisis management failures. The outage suspended nearly £300 billion in payments for several hours, affecting financial market trades and house purchases. The report highlights the need for the BoE to improve its ability to handle crises affecting Britain's banks, citing the Real Time Gross Settlement system as a key area for improvement.

images.alt_text: A major outage last year in the Bank of England's interbank payments system showed the central bank was not fully equipped to handle crises affecting Britain's banks, a report published by the BoE showed on Wednesday.

site_title: UK inflation expectations rise for first time since August: Citi/YouGov
summary: The British public's expectations for inflation rose for the first time since August, with year-ahead inflation expectations increasing to 1.4% in March from 1.0% in February. Expectations for inflation over the next five to 10 years also rose to 2.8%, up from 2.6% in January and February. Despite a record-low zero percent consumer price inflation, economists believe inflation expectations are not deflationary, citing a potential slight increase in inflation in coming months.

site_title: Update: Lying in state to be open 24 hours daily until 8pm on March 28; public transport hours extended
summary: Visiting hours for paying respects to late Singaporean leader Lee Kuan Yew have been extended to run 24 hours daily from March 25 until March 28 at 8pm. Public transport services, including trains and buses, will also operate extended hours, including night services, to accommodate the large number of people. The State Funeral Organising Committee and Land Transport Authority are working together to monitor passenger demand and maintenance during this period.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore Wrap Wednesday highlights key international news. Malaysia's agency is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case. ASEAN has deemed Myanmar's election a low priority. The UK economy shrank for the second month, while South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%.

site_title: Gold near 2-1/2 week high on US rate expectations
summary: Gold prices held near 2-1/2 week highs on Wednesday, supported by upbeat eurozone economic data and receding expectations of a US interest rate rise. Spot gold was at $1,192.40 an ounce, with US gold futures for April delivery up 80 cents an ounce. Commerzbank analyst Daniel Briesemann attributed the rally to Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's cautious tone on the US economy, which reduced expectations of a rate hike.

site_title: Black boxes: crucial to air crash probes
summary: French investigators are searching for the missing black box from the Germanwings Airbus crash, which killed 150 people. The cockpit voice recorder was recovered but found damaged, while the digital flight data recorder is still missing. The black box, which can survive extreme conditions, is expected to be found with a beacon signal. The recovery of the black box from previous crashes, such as Air France AF447, has provided crucial information for investigations. The search for the missing black box is ongoing, with investigators hoping to determine the causes of the plane's mysterious crash.

images.alt_text: When investigators comb through the devastation of an aircraft crash site, the first thing they'll look for - if there are no survivors - is the black box.

site_title: French Alps crash site saw another air disaster 50 years ago
summary: A French Air France plane crashed in the French Alps on September 1, 1953, killing 42 people, including celebrated violinist Jacques Thibaud. The incident occurred 50 years before a recent Air France Airbus A320 crash that killed 150. The 1953 plane clipped a mountain and crashed into a rocky crevice during a nighttime flight from Paris to Saigon, with the pilot having requested altitude adjustments just minutes before the accident. A postman's alert raised the alarm, and the wreckage was discovered near Barcelonette ski resort.

images.alt_text: Tuesday's air disaster was not the first crash seen at the tiny ski resort of Barcelonette in the French Alps: half a century ago, an Air France plane to Vietnam crashed in the same spot.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.06 points to close at 1,819.10, with 2.04 billion lots valued at RM2.12 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 449-391.

site_title: Sinopec Oilfield sees lower overseas contracts; eyes acquisition
summary: Sinopec Oilfield Service Corp expects to sign overseas contracts worth $2.4 billion this year, a 21% decline from last year due to lower demand amid a sharp decline in crude prices. Despite this, the company will continue its overseas expansion strategy, focusing on integrated oilfield services in countries such as Mexico, Kuwait, and Nigeria. Chairman Jiao Fangzheng stated that the company will implement its strategy, prioritizing geophysics, drilling, engineering, and construction services.

site_title: Chinese tax hikes slash fuel oil imports 30% so far this year
summary: China's fuel oil imports have declined 30% in the first two months of 2015, reaching 2.86 million tonnes, half their peak in 2013. The decline is attributed to fuel tax hikes, which have reduced energy use and squeezed refiners' profits. The tax increases, implemented three times from November to January, have accelerated the downward trend in imports. Analysts expect a further decline in fuel imports this year as more refiners gain access to crude oil and switch to tax-free bitumen.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.53% higher
summary: Hong Kong's stock market rose 0.53% on Wednesday, driven by Hutchison Whampoa's US$15.2 billion acquisition of British telecom giant O2. The Hang Seng Index increased 128.63 points to 24,528.23. In contrast, Shanghai's benchmark composite index fell 0.83% due to a 10-day winning streak.

site_title: Business group ranks US near last in welcoming skilled immigrants
summary: The US ranks near the bottom among major economies in terms of policies to allow hiring highly skilled immigrant workers, according to a study by the Business Roundtable. The US ranked 9th out of 10 countries, behind Germany, Australia, Hong Kong, France, and Canada. The report highlights the issue of US restrictions on immigrants for jobs in science, technology, and specialized fields, which business leaders say are unable to fill highly skilled positions. The study suggests that more liberal immigration policies could help address this issue.

site_title: First Germanwings Barcelona-Duesseldorf flight since crash takes off
summary: A Germanwings flight on the Barcelona-Duesseldorf route, which crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday, took off from Barcelona's El Prat airport on Wednesday. The flight, an Airbus 319 passenger jet, departed with a few minutes' delay and no survivors were reported. Germanwings had canceled at least one flight due to pilot shock, and the company held a minute's silence for the victims. The first flight on the same route since the crash marked a return to normalcy at the airport, where family members of the passengers were still gathered.

site_title: Brent oil rises as eurozone morale boost offsets oversupply concern
summary: Brent oil prices rose 32 cents to $55.43 a barrel as eurozone business morale improved, offsetting concerns of oversupply. Germany's business morale rose for the fifth month in a row, while France's rose to its highest in nearly three years. US crude oil inventories rose 4.8 million barrels, reaching record highs, and China's oil imports are expected to stay flat or rise slightly due to storage limits. The market is unlikely to balance until the second half of the year, with rising inventory levels and potential pressure on oil prices.

site_title: India's capital orders Uber off its roads
summary: India's capital, New Delhi, has ordered US-based Uber and its Indian rival Ola Cabs off the city's roads due to unlicensed operations despite pending licence applications. The ban was issued after an Uber driver was charged with raping a passenger, sparking concerns about inadequate background checks. Authorities have asked both companies to file an affidavit confirming their compliance with the order before their licence applications will be processed. Uber resumed operations despite the ban, prompting further action from authorities.

site_title: Bank of China Q4 profit rises 5% while bad loans jump
summary: Bank of China Ltd reported a 5% increase in Q4 profit to 38.5 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates. However, losses on bad assets doubled and unpaid loans jumped, as China's economy slows. The bank's non-performing loan ratio rose sharply to 1.18%, with impairment losses increasing by over 100% to 48.4 billion yuan. The results show the bank's vulnerability to a slowing domestic economy, which is projected to grow at around 7% this year.

site_title: China to relax rules for foreign investors for trading on interbank market: sources
summary: China plans to relax rules for foreign investors trading on its interbank market, including easier access to quotas and permission to invest in more products. The Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) scheme and its renminbi-denominated version (RQFII) will use a registration system, eliminating the need for regulatory approval. Foreign investors will be allowed to trade CDs, bond repurchase agreements, swaps, and interest rate swaps. No firm date has been set for the reforms, but they may be implemented as early as May.

site_title: Australia: Shares stall as index flirts with 6,000 level
summary: Australia's stock market ended flat on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,973.3, just below the 6,000 level. Gains in bank stocks, led by ANZ and Westpac, were offset by weakness in the resource sector, particularly BHP Billiton. The index has stalled near the 6,000 level for several sessions.

site_title: Businesses pay tribute to Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Singapore's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, has passed away. Companies across the country, including law firm Lee & Lee, The Travel Corporation, OCBC, CapitaLand, and Singapore Airlines, are paying tribute to him. The Singapore Exchange and UBS bank have also closed their offices to observe the national week of mourning. Donations are being made to charitable causes, with OCBC contributing S$100,000 to the NTUC-U Care Fund. The country is mourning the loss of a leader who built Singapore into a thriving nation over 60 years ago.

site_title: Singapore's bond market continues to sizzle (Amended)
summary: Singapore's bond market continues to thrive despite rising interest rates, with over S$2.4 billion raised in March from 16 issues, surpassing S$1.6 billion and 13 deals in the same period last year. The three-month Sibor rate has surged to 1%, the highest level since December 2008. Local banks, including OCBC, DBS, and UOB, dominate the market, with OCBC holding the top spot with a 35% market share. Year-to-date bond volumes are 72% of the same period in 2014.

site_title: China, Taiwan hit with European Union tariffs on stainless steel
summary: The European Union imposed tariffs up to 25.2% on stainless steel imports from China and Taiwan, effective Thursday, to curb competition for EU producers. The tariffs punish exporters for allegedly selling below cost, causing material injury to EU producers. The measures are in place for six months and may be prolonged for five years. The EU's 5.5 billion-euro market is affected by the dumped imports, used in various products such as elevators, tanks, and kitchen equipment.

site_title: Beijing behind Internet security violation: group
summary: China's cyberspace administration is accused by an anti-censorship group of being "complicit" in attacks on major Internet companies, including Google, through "man-in-the-middle" operations. The accusations come as Beijing dismisses the claims and calls for proof. GreatFire.org points to statements from Google, Microsoft, and Mozilla as evidence, and urges firms to strengthen their defenses. The ruling Communist Party maintains tight controls over the Internet, blocking politically sensitive websites and requiring social media companies to censor content.

site_title: Most analysts now see Singapore central bank holding off on further easing in April
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, is expected to maintain its stance of allowing the local dollar's appreciation in April, contrary to earlier expectations of easing policy to ward off deflationary pressures. Core inflation rose 1.3% in February, up from January's 1.0%, after a five-year low. Analysts expect no policy easing, with some predicting the central bank may widen the policy band to accommodate currency market fluctuations. This move aims to stabilize the Singapore dollar as global foreign exchange markets grow more volatile.

images.alt_text: Singapore's central bank is expected to maintain its stance of allowing the local dollar's appreciation in April, a Reuters poll showed on Wednesday, a marked change from expectations just a few weeks ago that it would ease policy again to ward off deflationary pressures.

site_title: Lying in state extended to 24 hours daily until 8pm on March 28
summary: Visiting hours for paying respects to the late Lee Kuan Yew have been extended to 24 hours daily until March 28, 2015, at 8pm. Due to the "overwhelming response", the line to enter Parliament House began at the riverside Promenade next to Parliament House. Thousands of people waited in line as of 3pm on March 25, with the waiting time stretching to eight hours. The public is advised to check for latest updates on the official website.

images.alt_text: Visiting hours for paying respects to the late Lee Kuan Yew have been extended to run around the clock, due to the public's "overwhelming response", the State Funeral Organising Committee said on Wednesday.

site_title: Delhi govt asks federal ministry to block Uber, Ola mobile apps: official
summary: The New Delhi state government has asked the federal Information Technology ministry to block the mobile apps of taxi-hailing companies Uber and Ola in the capital city. This move comes after a female passenger reported being raped by an Uber driver in December, leading to a nationwide ban on unregistered web-based taxi companies. Delhi transport officials gave Uber and Ola an ultimatum to cease operations if they want their radio taxi licence applications to be processed. The request is pending a response from the federal ministry.

site_title: Update: New Zealand ministers pay special tributes to Lee Kuan Yew in Parliament
summary: New Zealand's Deputy Prime Minister Bill English paid special tributes to Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew during the country's parliamentary session on Tuesday, March 24, 2015. English expressed his condolences to Lee's family and the people of Singapore, describing him as a "long-time friend of New Zealand" and a supporter of New Zealand's role in South-east Asia. This was part of a special tribute to Lee, who passed away on Monday.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Europe: Shares dip early; Hermes falls after results
summary: European shares fell 0.3% to 1,600.35 points, hovering below 7-1/2-year highs, amid uncertainty over Germany's business climate. Hermes shares dropped 1.9% after the luxury goods maker posted a 7% rise in full-year operating income but cited lower margins due to foreign exchange rates. Despite this, French business morale reached its highest in nearly three years in March.

images.alt_text: European shares dipped in early trading on Wednesday, hovering below 7-1/2-year highs, as investors awaited a survey on German business climate for insight on the outlook for Europe's biggest economy.

site_title: German business confidence rises in March: Ifo
summary: German business confidence rose to its highest level in eight months in March, according to the Ifo economic institute. The business climate index reached 107.9 points, surpassing analyst expectations. This marks the first time the index has exceeded 107 since July 2014. The optimism about the European economy's outlook continues to drive growth in Germany, the continent's largest economy.

site_title: Germanwings cancels flight as pilots refuse to fly
summary: A flight operated by Germanwings, a low-cost subsidiary of Lufthansa, was cancelled on March 25, 2015, after its pilots refused to fly due to mourning the victims of a deadly crash in the French Alps that occurred on the same day, killing 150 people.

site_title: Oil prices dip as US stock-build drags, China strategic reserves fill
summary: Oil prices dropped as US crude storage volumes continued to rise, with US WTI crude falling 43 cents to $47.08 a barrel and Brent oil futures dropping 29 cents to $54.82 a barrel. China's strategic petroleum reserves are nearing capacity, with a Sinopec executive stating that they are reaching current limits, which may cap China's import needs until new facilities are completed. This news pressured oil prices, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks inch higher in muted trading; Wall Street rebound expected
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.76 points to 3,419.02 on Wednesday, driven by gains in UOB, Singtel, and Keppel Corp, with SIIC Environment leading the unit volume list. The year-to-date performance stands at 1.6%, a weak start considering zero interest rates and a recovering US economy. Turnover was below the daily average, with 1.24 billion units traded at S$950.6 million. Traders are optimistic about Wall Street's rebound, despite muted trading in Singapore.

site_title: China: Weak banks break stocks' 10-day winning streak
summary: China's stocks ended a 10-day winning streak as the country's major banks reported weaker earnings. Agricultural Bank of China's fourth-quarter net profit fell below expectations, while bad loans hit a three-year high. The banking index declined 2.8% after the report, contributing to a broader market downturn. Profit-taking and concerns about rising volatility ahead also played a role in the decline.

site_title: Germanwings says 72 Germans died in plane crash
summary: Germanwings confirmed 72 Germans died in the plane crash in the French Alps on Tuesday, with the number of victims from other nationalities still being updated. A total of 150 people were on board, including 35 Spaniards, two each from Australia, Argentina, Iran, Venezuela, and the US, and citizens from Britain, the Netherlands, Colombia, Mexico, Japan, Denmark, and Israel. The list of nationalities is being constantly updated.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.17% in see-saw trade
summary: Tokyo stocks closed up 0.17% on Wednesday, recovering from early losses, as late bargain-hunting offset a weak lead from Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 19,746.20, while the Topix index increased 0.28%. Despite the Nikkei reaching its highest levels in 15 years, experts say it may take a specific event to push the index above 20,000. The Dow fell 0.58% on Wall Street, following positive economic data that sparked speculation of a faster interest rate hike.

site_title: North Korea's well-to-do feast on French baguettes
summary: North Korean's affluent class is enjoying French baguettes, courtesy of a 2011 food factory that trained pastry chefs in France. The Kumkop General Foodstuff Factory for Sportspersons has been producing wholewheat baguettes, which have been a hit among the privileged classes. This contrasts with the struggles of the general population outside the capital, highlighting the disparity in access to food in North Korea. The factory's efforts to become a world-class food producer suggest a growing focus on improving the country's culinary offerings.

site_title: Rescuers struggle to recover bodies in French Alps crash
summary: Rescuers in the French Alps continue their search for victims of the Germanwings flight crash, which killed all 150 people on board. The plane, carrying 144 passengers including 16 German teenagers, crashed after the pilots lost control, with no response to air traffic controllers' attempts to hail them. European leaders are visiting the site to pay their respects. The search effort is ongoing, with no survivors found so far.

site_title: A320 crash probe not focusing on terrorism: French minister
summary: France's interior minister Bernard Cazeneuve stated that investigators are examining all possible causes of the Germanwings crash, but are not focusing on terrorism. The minister noted that the plane's debris spread over a significant area, suggesting it did not explode, and that the theory of a terrorist attack is "not the theory we're focusing on." However, Cazeneuve emphasized that all theories must be examined until the investigation results are available.

site_title: Top US CEOs reaped billions from stock gains in recent years
summary: US CEOs at S&P 500 companies collectively gained at least $6 billion more in compensation from 2009-2013 due to soaring stock awards. The estimated total is $22 billion, with an average of $73 million per CEO. This is significantly higher than the initial reported $16 billion, which was based on stock grant values at the time of awards. The discrepancy is attributed to the significant increase in stock values during this period.

site_title: Indonesia's big banks hang hopes on infrastructure projects
summary: Indonesia's big banks are relying on government-led infrastructure projects to boost loan growth, which slowed to 11.5% in January, the smallest year-on-year gain in almost five years. The government's infrastructure plans aim to improve the country's dilapidated infrastructure, and analysts expect loan growth to reach 14% this year. Banks have reduced their exposure to commodity firms and local businesses have delayed expansion plans due to the slowing economy and currency fluctuations. Non-performing loans remain relatively low at 2.23%.

site_title: ECB actions working, but structural reforms needed: Liikanen
summary: European Central Bank policy actions have positively impacted the eurozone economy, with determined member state action allowing the ECB's bond-buying program and low interest rates to exert maximum benefit. ECB Governing Council member Erkki Liikanen stated that structural reforms are still necessary to support the recovery. Liikanen emphasized the need for member states to adopt reforms to complement the ECB's monetary policy decisions.

site_title: Oil prices dip as inventory build drags
summary: Oil prices dipped slightly on Wednesday due to a buildup of US storage volumes, despite healthy demand from Europe. Brent oil futures fell to $55.09 a barrel, while US WTI crude dropped to $47.40 a barrel. A poll of analysts forecast a record US commercial stock level, with the American Petroleum Institute reporting a 4.8 million-barrel build last week. The expectation of further stock builds in the US weighed on oil markets, despite strengthening European manufacturing data.

site_title: Backers of a Thai rate hold worried about imbalances, high household debt
summary: The Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee members expressed concerns over imbalances and high household debt levels, citing potential risks to financial stability. A 25 basis point rate cut was made in March, but the 4-3 vote showed policymakers struggling to balance growth and debt. The committee warned that further easing could exacerbate financial imbalances, despite acknowledging the economy's sluggish growth and low inflation. The central bank's growth forecast was lowered to 3.8% for this year, below previous expectations.

site_title: Fortescue calls for iron ore output cap, angers competition body
summary: Australia's Fortescue Metals Group founder Andrew Forrest proposed capping iron ore production to boost prices, but competition authorities swiftly rebuked the move, citing concerns over cartel behavior. Forrest suggested limiting production to 180 million tonnes, a move that could potentially trigger a price recovery from the current US$55.60 per tonne. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) warned that any attempt to restrict output could lead to severe penalties.

images.alt_text: Fortescue founder and chairman Andrew Forrest told a gathering in Shanghai late Tuesday he was happy to challenge rivals to "cap our production right here and start acting like grown-ups", the Australian Financial Review reported.

site_title: Hong Kong leader warns against protests
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Leung Chun-ying, warned protesters that the public would not be sympathetic to further pro-democracy protests as the city prepares for the next phase of political reforms. The leader, who has faced low support ratings, stated that Beijing has confidence in Hong Kong's handling of the protests and that pro-democracy lawmakers who supported the Occupy movement could face consequences in the 2016 election. The city's legislature is set to consider a Beijing-approved proposal for the 2017 election, which pro-democracy lawmakers have vowed to veto.

site_title: China approves three more free-trade zones
summary: China has approved three more free-trade zones, including Guangdong, Fujian, and Tianjin, in a bid to deepen reform and expand economic integration. The zones aim to improve economic ties with Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Beijing. Despite China's first FTZ in Shanghai proving disappointing, the new zones are seen as part of a push to boost economic growth. The establishment of FTZs was approved by the Communist Party's politburo, with President Xi Jinping hosting the meeting. The zones are expected to offer new approaches to economic reform, but progress has been slow, with many companies expressing skepticism about the benefits.

site_title: Currency volatility reduces investment, global trade: BofAML
summary: Currency volatility is reducing global trade and foreign investment, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch's Claudio Piron. The recent "currency wars" between central banks are causing uncertainty, making investment decisions harder and increasing risk to countries that export to China, such as Korea, Australia, and New Zealand. Piron warned that if China depreciates the yuan, these countries will be hit the hardest. The currency fluctuations are exacerbating the issue, making it challenging for investors to make decisions, and increasing the risk of economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: The current bout of currency volatility can reduce trade flows and foreign direct investment, said Claudio Piron, Bank of America Merrill Lynch co-head of Asia FX and rates strategy.

site_title: Minister sees Vietnam's Q1 2015 GDP growth at 5.5-5.6%: media
summary: Vietnam's economy grew 5.5-5.6% in Q1 2015, faster than 5.06% in the same period last year, according to a deputy minister. The full-year growth target is 6.2%, potentially reaching 6.4% in favorable conditions. Vietnam's trade deficit in Q1 is estimated at $1.8 billion, or 5% of total exports. The government aims to achieve 6.2% annual GDP growth in 2015, with the World Bank and Asian Development Bank predicting 5.6% and 6.1% growth, respectively.

site_title: ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence index hits 8-month high
summary: The ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence index reached an 8-month high of 124.5 in March, driven by improved expectations of personal financial situations. 31.1% of respondents reported being better off, up from 26.8% in February, while 32.7% expected to be better off in the year ahead. However, consumers remained cautious about major spending, with only 16.6% considering it a good time to buy a major household item.

site_title: Facebook said in talks with publishers on hosting content
summary: Facebook is in talks with several publishers, including the New York Times, BuzzFeed, and National Geographic, to host their content directly on the social network. This shift would allow publishers to post articles and videos directly to Facebook, bypassing their own websites. The move aims to improve the quality of news content on Facebook's feed, while publishers seek to increase their online presence. Facebook's goal is to provide a better experience for users, while publishers want to maintain control over their content.

site_title: China tells banks to lend more to farm sector
summary: China's central bank urged banks to increase lending to the farm sector, citing a need to support the vulnerable sector and the overall economy. Outstanding loans to agriculture totaled 23.6 trillion yuan (US$3.8 trillion) at the end of 2014, accounting for 28.1% of total bank loans. The central bank aims to enhance affordable financing for agriculture, following a 13% annual increase in farm loans last year.
