summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel was "deeply shaken" by the crash of a Germanwings passenger plane in France, according to her spokesman. The chancellor was scheduled to give a statement on the accident.

images.alt_text: Chancellor Angela Merkel was"deeply shaken" by news that a passenger plane operated by Germanwings had crashed in France, her spokesman said on Tuesday.

site_title: Lufthansa fears "dark day" on French crash: Lufthansa on Twitter
summary: Lufthansa's Germanwings budget airline suffered a fatal crash in southern France, with all 148 on board feared dead. Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr described the situation as a "dark day" for the airline if the fears are confirmed, expressing hope for survivors. The airline released a statement on Twitter, offering sympathy to the families and friends of the passengers and crew, while awaiting confirmation of the cause of the crash.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr said it would be a "dark day" for the German flagship airline if fears of a deadly crash were confirmed, according to Lufthansa's Twitter feed.

site_title: German private sector grows at strongest rate in eight months
summary: Germany's private sector experienced its strongest growth rate in eight months, according to a survey, with the Markit PMI index rising to 55.3 in March, its highest level since July 2014. This marks the 23rd consecutive month of growth, surpassing the 50-point threshold that divides growth from contraction. The result suggests that Germany's largest economy is gaining pace, further indicating a positive outlook for the European economy.

site_title: French accident agency sends team to plane crash site
summary: A team from France's BEA accident investigation agency has been sent to the site of a Germanwings plane crash in southern France. The agency confirmed the accident and will investigate the cause. No further details have been released at this time.

site_title: Singapore's February industrial output seen falling 3.4% year on year
summary: Singapore's industrial output is expected to fall 3.4% year-on-year in February, primarily due to weak exports and the Lunar New Year holiday. This decline is in line with the median estimate of 10 economists polled. On a month-on-month basis, manufacturing output likely fell 0.7%. The decline is attributed to the holiday period and weak export performance, which impacted January's 0.9% year-on-year growth.

site_title: US Treasury's Lew says passing fast track trade legislation "vital"
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew emphasized the importance of passing bipartisan legislation to streamline the passage of free trade deals through Congress, stating it will protect American workers and promote businesses. The legislation aims to strengthen the US hand in forging trade deals that increase middle-class security in a changing global economy. Lew also clarified that the administration will only enter into trade agreements that are free, fair, and beneficial to workers and businesses.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew said on Tuesday passing bipartisan legislation to streamline the passage of free trade deals through Congress is vital.

site_title: No signs of French crash survivors: Spanish king
summary: Spanish King Felipe VI said there are no signs of survivors from the crash of an Airbus passenger jet in the French Alps. The king announced he would be suspending his state visit to France in the wake of the crash. The search area is described as extremely difficult, complicating the rescue efforts.

images.alt_text: Spain's King Felipe VI, in France on a state visit, said there were no signs of survivors from the crash of an Airbus passenger jet in the foothills of the French Alps on Tuesday.

site_title: US consumer prices rebound, underlying inflation firming
summary: US consumer prices rebounded 0.2% in February after a 0.7% decline in January, ending three straight months of declines. Gasoline prices rose for the first time since June, contributing to the increase. Underlying inflation pressures, as measured by the core CPI, also showed signs of firming. The Federal Reserve, which has kept interest rates near zero since 2008, may consider raising rates when labor market conditions improve and inflation reaches its 2% target. This could keep a June interest rate increase on the table.

site_title: Gold rally continues on lower dollar and US rate speculation
summary: Gold prices rose to a 2-1/2 week high, reaching US$1,194.80 an ounce, as the dollar weakened and speculation of a US interest rate increase in September gained traction. Investors favored gold due to a weaker dollar and the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on the US economy. The metal is expected to post its longest winning streak since January last year, with some analysts targeting US$1,200 as a strong resistance level.

images.alt_text: Gold rose to a 2-1/2 week high on Tuesday, heading for its fifth session of gains on a weaker dollar and growing expectations that a US interest rate increase could be pushed to September.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip, Shanghai rises on China data
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.39% on Tuesday, while Shanghai rose for the 10th consecutive session, driven by Chinese manufacturing data hitting an 11-month low. The Hang Seng Index fell 94.91 points to 24,399.60, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.10% to 3,691.41. The data fueled hopes for further government stimulus, supporting the Shanghai rally.

site_title: Malaysia plans to resolve LME tax issue before April: Deputy finance minister
summary: Malaysia plans to resolve the issue with the London Metal Exchange (LME) over a new goods and services tax on metals traded or stored in bonded zones before an April 1 deadline. The LME may stop issuing warrants for stored metal if clarification is not received. Deputy Finance Minister Chua Tee Yong said the government will work closely with LME to resolve the issues, and a solution is expected within the week. The government is considering two options to neutralize the impact of the 6% GST on metals inventories.

site_title: Malaysia's MAHB sells stake in Delhi airport
summary: Malaysia Airport Holdings Bhd (MAHB) is selling its 10% stake in Delhi International Airport for US$79 million to GMR Airports Ltd. The sale is due to India's 49% foreign ownership cap, which limits MAHB's control over the airport's management. The stake sale allows GMR to focus on investments with a significant degree of control.

site_title: UK annual CPI inflation hits zero in February for first time on record
summary: UK annual CPI inflation dropped to 0.0% in February, the first time on record, due to lower prices for food and computer goods. This marks a significant fall from 0.3% in January and is a welcome news for Britons ahead of the national election on May 7. However, the further inflation falls below the Bank of England's 2% target raises speculation about potential rate cuts, which most economists expect to be a rate rise in around a year's time.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 18.19 points to close at 1,814.04. The index saw 1.95 billion lots valued at RM1.84 billion traded, with 400 gainers and 415 losers.

site_title: 16 bids for private condo site at Sturdee Road
summary: A 99-year private housing site at Sturdee Road in Singapore drew 16 bids, with the top bid by SL Capital (1) Pte Ltd reaching S$181.19 million (S$786.92 psf ppr). The site, located near Farrer Park MRT Station, can be developed into a 30-storey project with 265 homes. Wee Hur Development was in third position with a bid of S$703.06 psf ppr, while the lowest bid was from NSS Sturdee at S$79.50 million (S$345.28 psf ppr). The tender closed on Tuesday, marking the latest development in the Singapore property market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore: A quiet but slightly firm session ahead of expected US rebound
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed at 3,413.26, up 3.13 points, with 239 rises and 173 falls, amid an uncertain US market and indifferent Hong Kong. The session was described as "agonisingly boring" with thin tradeable newsflows. The largest drag on the index came from UOB's S$0.21 drop. Despite this, the positive closing suggested a likely US market rebound.

site_title: Singapore's central bank in touch with Malaysia on 1MDB probe
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is in touch with Malaysia's regulators over the investigation into state fund 1MDB. MAS said it would assist within its laws, but could not provide more details due to ongoing investigations. The investigation centers around 1MDB's debt of nearly RM42 billion and alleged financial mismanagement, with Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak facing criticism over his role. An audit of 1MDB's accounts is underway, and the company plans to sell assets and go public to cut debt.

site_title: Nordevo Investments to sell stake in Beijing mall
summary: Nordevo Investments, a 50% stakeholder of Metro Holdings, has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to sell its entire stake in China East Investment (CEI) for approximately US$179.5 million. CEI owns the retail mall property, EC Mall, in Beijing, which is 99.5% occupied. The sale is considered a matured investment with stable rental income, allowing Metro to divest its stake. The transaction is part of Metro's strategy to divest matured assets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Germanwings plane crashes in France, up to 150 feared dead
summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 plane crashed in southern France on Tuesday, en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf, with up to 150 feared dead. The 24-year-old plane, operated by Lufthansa's budget airline, crashed near Barcelonnette, 100km north of Nice. The cause of the crash is unknown, according to French Prime Minister Manuel Valls. Lufthansa's Germanwings unit was unable to verify reports of the crash.

site_title: Chinese firms' profits resilient despite sliding investment, weak retail: survey
summary: China's private companies reported resilient profits despite a cooling economy, with growth in capital expenditure at its weakest on record. Investment declined in every sector except real estate, but companies managed to boost profit margins and reduce debt by taking advantage of falling input costs and wage growth. Despite Beijing's 7% economic growth target, many economists predict the target may be too ambitious, and a survey found companies are weathering the slowdown better than expected, questioning the usefulness of additional policy easing measures.

site_title: Angelina Jolie has ovaries removed over cancer fears
summary: Angelina Jolie has undergone a preventive surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes due to her family history of cancer and a high risk of developing ovarian cancer. The actress, who had a double mastectomy two years ago, made the decision after a blood test raised concerns about early cancer. Although further tests showed no cancer, Jolie chose to proceed with the surgery, citing her family history and genetic predisposition to the disease.

site_title: Singapore currency intervention seen in interbank rate above 1%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is believed to be intervening in the local currency market to strengthen the Singapore dollar, which rose above 1% for the first time since 2008. The move comes after the MAS unexpectedly eased policy in January, pushing the Singapore dollar to its lowest level against a trade-weighted basket of peers. Goldman Sachs predicts the MAS will further undermine the currency by lowering its target at the April meeting, potentially widening the policy band.

site_title: Islamic State recruits 400 children since January: Syria monitor
summary: Islamic State has recruited at least 400 children under 18 in Syria since January, with military training and indoctrination, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The group uses children to brainwash and recruit, often luring them with money. Children are trained to fire live ammunition, fight, and drive, and are also used as informants and guards. This recruitment may be a response to difficulties in recruiting adults, with only 120 joining the group since the start of the year.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip after poor Chinese factory data
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, following a 0.7% drop the previous day, due to poor Chinese factory data showing an 11-month low. This signals weakness in the world's second-largest economy. In contrast, France's private sector expanded for the second consecutive month in March, indicating the eurozone's second-largest economy is edging back to growth.

site_title: EU-Greek deal possible this week: EU parliament chief
summary: Greece and the European Union may reach a deal by the end of this week, allowing the release of urgently needed aid funds, according to European Parliament President Martin Schulz. Greece is seeking the last tranche of a 240-billion-euro bailout, but Brussels is refusing until Athens approves its new economic reforms package. Schulz expressed optimism that a new understanding will be reached, unblocking the most urgent funds.

images.alt_text: Greece and the European Union could reach a deal as early as this week to allow the release of badly needed aid funds for Athens, European Parliament President Martin Schulz said on Tuesday.

site_title: French private sector expands for 2nd straight month: PMI
summary: France's private sector expanded for the second consecutive month in March, with a composite purchasing managers' index of 51.7, according to Markit. The services sector saw a 52.8 reading, while the manufacturing sector contracted at a slower pace. This growth suggests a tentative expansion of France's private sector economy, offering hope for a sustainable eurozone recovery.

site_title: India's top court strikes down ban on 'offensive' online comment
summary: India's top court struck down a 2009 law that made posting "offensive" online comments a crime punishable by jail, deeming it unconstitutional and a restriction on freedom of speech. The law, section 66A of the Information Technology Act, was challenged after two young women were arrested in 2012 for a Facebook post criticizing the shutdown of Mumbai after a politician's death. The court ruled that the amendment could not be saved by government assurances, upholding the public's right to know and free speech.

site_title: Land Securities sells Times Square, London property to Blackstone
summary: Britain's Land Securities Group Plc sold its 95% stake in a 380,000 square foot office building in London's Times Square to Blackstone Group LP for 268.4 million pounds (S$552.54 million). The building is fully let until 2023 to six tenants, including Bank of New York Mellon and Dechert. The deal is expected to close by the end of July.

site_title: Morgan Stanley cuts commodities prices on China outlook
summary: Morgan Stanley reduced its 2015 price forecasts for base metals and bulk commodities due to China's slowing economy, which is failing to bolster demand for copper and iron ore. The bank cut its estimates for nickel (23% down to $14,815/ton), copper (16% down to $5,945/ton), iron ore (28% down to $57/ton), and coking coal (16% down to $58/ton). Analysts predict industrial metals will perform better than bulk commodities, driven by growth in developed countries.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley cut its price forecasts for almost all base metals and bulk commodities as China's "dormant" industry fails to bolster demand in the world's biggest consumer of copper and iron ore.

site_title: Eurozone business growth accelerates as ECB QE kicks in: PMI
summary: Business activity in the eurozone accelerated in March, with the Eurozone Composite Flash Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI) rising to a near four-year high of 54.1, beating expectations. The increase is attributed to the European Central Bank's quantitative easing programme, which has been flooding markets with cash. Despite the growth, firms continue to cut prices, and inflation is not expected to rise sharply. The PMI indicates first-quarter growth of 0.3%, matching the previous three months, and suggests a further upturn in the coming months.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda: Tapering asset buying an option in ending QE
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that tapering asset purchases is an option in ending the bank's quantitative easing program, but emphasized it's too early to discuss timing and methods. Kuroda also acknowledged concerns over liquidity in Japan's government bond market, citing low volatility as a factor. However, he noted the BOJ closely monitors market liquidity.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble leads the actives
summary: Noble Group's shares slipped 1.5 Singapore cents, or 1.7%, to 89.5 Singapore cents on Tuesday, following allegations by Iceberg Research. The commodity trading firm rejected the allegations and announced it will start legal proceedings.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UK's FCA to examine asset management fees, pensions
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) plans to launch a market study on asset management fees, examining charges paid by investors. The regulator will also look into pension firms' sales practices and flexibility in the mortgages market. Additionally, the FCA will study the use of "big data" in the insurance market and assess the importance of companies' systems and controls in preventing financial crime, following last year's review of annuities sales. The study is part of the FCA's business plan for the coming year, which focuses on key areas such as pension policy and financial crime prevention.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares ease 0.21% on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 0.21% on Tuesday, driven by a stronger yen and profit-taking after a 15-year high. The Nikkei 225 index fell 40.91 points to 19,713.45, while the Topix index dropped 0.29% to 1,587.59. The decline was attributed to profit-taking after the previous session's close.

site_title: US economy can handle high dollar: Federal Reserve's Williams
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams stated that the US economy can handle a high dollar, despite it being a drag on growth this year. He expects the economy to expand by 2.5% in 2015, citing the strong US economy and positive global growth due to easy central bank policies. Williams also anticipates the Fed to start raising interest rates this year, driven by nearing full employment and potential inflation.

site_title: Thai auto sales may bounce back in H2 if government spends
summary: Thai auto sales may rebound in the second half of 2015 if the government accelerates spending to boost the economy, according to the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI). Domestic auto sales fell 10.8% in February, but are expected to rise 25.35% to 950,000 vehicles in 2015, with production increasing 14.36% to 2.15 million cars. The FTI attributes the decline to a slow economy and sluggish investment, citing the need for government spending to revive economic growth.

site_title: Japanese PM's advisers split over WWII 'aggression'
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's advisers are divided over how to describe Tokyo's wartime military action in a highly sensitive statement about World War II. The panel, comprising academics, journalists, and business leaders, disagreed on the use of the word "aggression," with some arguing it was wrong to retrospectively apply values and definitions. Abe is expected to make the statement on the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II, with China and South Korea closely watching for signs of Japan's acceptance of its wrongdoing.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down; Pegatron leads techs lower
summary: Taiwan's stocks dropped 0.46% on Tuesday, with Pegatron Corp leading the decline despite record quarterly earnings. The main TAIEX index fell 45.20 points to 9,712.89, driven down by Pegatron's 4.13% drop. The electronics subindex also fell 0.51% due to Pegatron's decline, while semiconductors dropped 0.63% and banks and insurance holdings declined 0.43%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar, standing at T$31.379 to the US dollar.

site_title: China province says graft probes leaves 300 jobs empty
summary: A graft probe in China's Shanxi province has left nearly 300 government jobs vacant, including senior positions. Vice Premier Ma Kai described the issue as "like a cancer." This is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to tackle deep-seated corruption. The most senior official to fall in the probe was Ling Jihua, a former aide to former president Hu Jintao.

site_title: China developer Sunac says Kaisa can't survive if takeover deal fails
summary: China developer Sunac urged Kaisa Group Holdings' creditors to accept a $2.5 billion debt restructuring plan or risk the company running out of cash by April. Sunac Chairman Hongbin Sun warned that Kaisa's financial woes are "very severe" and would walk away from the deal if creditors don't cooperate. Kaisa's bonds traded at 60/61, with some traders calling Sunac's "scare tactics." A successful deal would help Sunac expand in the rapidly growing Pearl River Delta market, but a failed takeover could have worse consequences for creditors, including a 2.4% recovery rate in a liquidation scenario.

site_title: Japan finance minister says would be desirable for AIIB to work with ADB
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso expressed his desire for the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) to collaborate with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to meet growing infrastructure demands in Asia. However, he cited a lack of transparency in the AIIB's management as a major concern, preventing Japan from deciding to join the bank by the March 31 deadline. Aso reiterated Japan's concerns over the AIIB's debt sustainability and environmental/social impact assessments, which could affect existing loans by the ADB, World Bank, and other lenders.

site_title: Philippine central bank says sees room for monetary, fiscal tweaks as needed
summary: The Philippine central bank governor, Amando Tetangco, stated that there is room for adjustments in monetary and fiscal policies if necessary, given low inflation. The overnight borrowing rate remains at 4% for the third consecutive meeting. The country's growth target of 7-8% is within reach, and inflation is expected to be within its 2-4% target. The central bank's decision comes ahead of a policy meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore labour movement pays tribute to Lee Kuan Yew
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore has paid tribute to the late Lee Kuan Yew, describing him as a "dear brother" to the labour movement who prioritized workers' welfare. Lee Kuan Yew's ties with the union and workers dated back to the 1950s, and he championed tripartism, introducing policies that improved the economy and gave workers a better life. His selfless leadership and steadfast support to unions and workers will be remembered forever, according to the NTUC.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: City Dev's 5-yr bond aggressively priced at 3% due to strong credit standing: OCBC
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) issued S$125 million 5-year senior unsecured fixed rate notes at 3% due to its strong credit standing. The bond, launched with a price guidance of 3%, was aggressively priced with a 20 basis point yield spread compared to its 10-year notes. The deal attracted over S$150 million orders, surpassing the original target of S$50 million to S$100 million. This reflects investors' confidence in CDL's credit and one of the most aggressive pricings by a property issuer in the past few years.

site_title: China March flash HSBC PMI contracts to 11-month low, new orders drop
summary: China's factory sector activity contracted to an 11-month low in March, with a flash HSBC PMI reading of 49.2, below the 50-point growth threshold. New orders dropped to an 11-month low, while manufacturing companies continued to benefit from falling input costs. Economists expect China's growth to cool further to 7% in 2015, with the central bank expected to implement more stimulus measures to support the economy. The decline in factory activity signals persistent weakness in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Central banks agree new rules for FX market conduct
summary: Central banks have agreed on new rules for the foreign exchange (FX) market, aiming to curb abuses and market manipulation. The 8-page document bans traditional slang and gives dealers more guidelines on what they can and cannot say about the market. The code also instructs asset managers to prioritize clients' best deals and categorizes confidential information. The move follows two years of regulatory investigations and billions of dollars in fines for banks. The new rules are expected to improve transparency and reduce opportunities for traders to make money on trading.

site_title: Australia: Shares end 0.2% up on commodity rally
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,969.1, driven by gains in resources and energy-related stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index remained close to the 6,000-mark, having failed to break through twice this month. In contrast, New Zealand's NZX 50 index fell 0.08%. The rally follows firmer commodity prices, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records in the US despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: Shares retreat after China data
summary: Asian shares retreated on Tuesday after China's manufacturing gauge plunged to an 11-month low, while the euro was boosted by hopes of a breakthrough in Greece's bailout talks. The Shanghai Composite Index sank 0.60%, while Hong Kong lost 0.33%. US interest rate expectations were also lower, putting downward pressure on the dollar. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq edged lower, while oil prices fell. The euro gained ground against the dollar, and gold prices remained stable.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's vision turned Singapore into major aviation hub: Qantas
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's vision for liberalizing the aviation industry led to Singapore becoming a major aviation hub, benefiting airline Qantas. Qantas hailed Lee as an inspirational figure and respected statesman, acknowledging his legacy. Lee's vision welcomed investment and strengthened ties between Singapore and Australia, leaving a lasting impact on the country.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Singapore's STI opens 0.2% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.2% higher at 3,415.5, with 51 million shares traded worth S$104 million. Despite moderate US stock falls and concerns over Greece's debt talks, the local market rose.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: S&P 500 firms post record shareholder payouts in 2014
summary: S&P 500 companies reported record shareholder payouts in 2014, totaling $903.7 billion, up from $787.4 billion in 2013. The majority of payouts, 61%, were in share buybacks, with the remaining 39% in dividends, which reached an all-time high of $350.4 billion.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices in Asia fell on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate easing 44 cents to $47.01 and Brent falling 30 cents to $55.62. This decline followed disappointing manufacturing data from China, which saw its manufacturing sector's purchasing managers index dip to an 11-month low of 49.2 in March. Analysts expect US economic figures, including weekly crude stockpiles and fourth-quarter GDP growth, to be closely watched for market direction. Saudi Arabia's recent oil production increase also added to price pressures.

site_title: Greece to present reforms package by Monday: government spokesman
summary: Greece is set to present its proposed reforms package to its euro zone partners by next Monday in an effort to secure fresh aid from creditors. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras met with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, but it's unclear if they've narrowed differences on economic reforms. The reforms are necessary for Greece to win urgently needed cash and avoid default on its debt.

site_title: Japan March flash manufacturing PMI falls to 50.4, domestic orders weak
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity expanded at a slower pace in March, with the Markit/JMMA flash PMI falling to 50.4, its lowest since June last year. Domestic orders contracted for the first time in 10 months, while new export orders remained above the expansion threshold. The weak yen improved price competitiveness for Japanese exporters. This slowdown in manufacturing activity raises concerns about Japan's recovering economy losing momentum, following revised fourth-quarter data showing slower-than-expected growth.

images.alt_text: Japanese manufacturing activity expanded in March at a much slower pace than the previous month as domestic orders contracted in a worrying sign that the recovering economy may be losing some momentum.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 2.90 points to 1,798.75. The index saw 49 million lots traded worth RM18 million, with 93 gainers and 46 losers.

site_title: US auto labor cost study shows impact of two-tier wage system
summary: A new study by the Center for Automotive Research found that US auto labor costs for General Motors and Ford Motor are significantly higher than those of Fiat Chrysler Automobiles. GM's US workers earn an average of $58 per hour, while Ford's average $57 per hour. The study also revealed that 43% of Fiat Chrysler's US auto workers earn the lower entry-level wage, compared to 21% at GM and 21% at Ford. The two-tier pay scale, implemented in 2007, contributes to the labor cost disparity among the Detroit Three automakers.

site_title: Shanghai may raise cap for housing fund loans: newspaper
summary: Shanghai is considering raising the ceiling for housing loans under its provident fund by up to 75%, from 400,000 yuan (S$88,000) to 700,000 yuan and 1.2 million yuan. The move aims to help low- and mid-income residents improve their housing conditions amid a glut of housing supply in China, which has led to a decline in property sales and real estate investment growth. The move is part of a broader effort by the Chinese government to stabilize the real estate market and support the country's economy.

site_title: ECB's Draghi says resurgent bank lending supporting recovery
summary: ECB President Mario Draghi said resurgent bank lending in the euro zone is supporting economic recovery, driven by cheaper credit and lower interest rates. The ECB's monetary stimulus policies are accelerating the transmission of lower interest rates, making new investment projects more attractive. This should sustain demand for credit and investment, increasing potential output in the long term. Euro zone money supply figures are expected to show a slight rise in lending to households and firms in February, marking the first increase since July 2012.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened flat on Tuesday, following the previous day's gains and losses on Wall Street, ahead of US manufacturing data. The Hang Seng Index dropped 9.83 points to 24,484.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.16%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.46%. The flat opening follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Japan lawmakers to submit casino legalisation bill by end: March
summary: Japan's pro-casino lawmakers plan to resubmit a bill to legalize integrated resorts by the end of March, despite opposition from some ruling coalition members. The bill aims to generate US$40 billion in annual revenue, with gaming companies such as Las Vegas Sands Corp and MGM Resorts International hoping for Japan's casino market to be unlocked. The submission of the bill by March 31 allows local governments to continue researching the topic in the coming year, with the goal of passing the law this year.

site_title: US: Stocks slip as transports' decline offsets consumer gains
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, with the S&P 500 slipping 0.2% to 2,104.42, as transportation companies led the decline. Kansas City Southern dropped 8% after cutting its revenue growth outlook, and the Dow Jones transportation average fell 2%. Consumer-staples producers, however, rose 0.3% led by gains in shares of Mondelez International and Reynolds American. The Nasdaq composite index approached a record but closed down 0.3% from its 15-year high.

site_title: Genting Singapore's RWS secures S$2.27b credit facilities
summary: Genting Singapore's Resorts World at Sentosa (RWS) has secured S$2.27 billion in credit facilities to refinance existing debt. The new facilities, provided by DBS Bank and OCBC, will extend the tenure of RWS's existing facilities to 2020 and offer better repayment terms, enhancing its balance sheet strength and financial flexibility.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Italian-made version of iconic Jeep goes on sale in US
summary: The US is set to see the Italian-made Jeep Renegade go on sale, marking a shift in production from the US to Italy. The small 4x4 SUV, priced at around $20,000, was shipped to dealers last week and will hit showrooms nationwide in volume next month. Designed and engineered in the US, the Renegade will be built in a refurbished Italian assembly plant, with components from Italy and the US. This move is part of Fiat Chrysler Automobile's plans to expand globally, and is expected to augment US sales without cutting into existing Jeep models.

images.alt_text: US off-roaders seeking to rev up the four-wheel drive of a Jeep might soon find out that their American icon is made in Italy.

site_title: Top Indonesia stock picker predicts rally on infrastructure boom
summary: Indonesian stocks are expected to rise 11% by year-end as infrastructure spending boosts economic growth, according to PT Schroder Investment Management Indonesia. The nation's biggest mutual-fund manager, Kiekie Boenawan, favors construction, banking, and property stocks. Indonesian President Joko Widodo plans to spend $22 billion on infrastructure development in 2015, aiming to revive the country's economy. The Jakarta Composite Index is forecast to reach 6,011 by December.

site_title: Japan plans tax breaks for firms to move headquarters from Tokyo
summary: Japan's Cabinet approved plans to offer tax breaks to companies moving their headquarters out of Tokyo to revitalize regional economies. The tax breaks, set to be introduced to parliament, will give companies a 7% deduction on new headquarters construction costs outside the Tokyo area. The goal is to create 300,000 new jobs in regional areas by 2020, addressing concerns about Tokyo's high concentration of companies and talent. The policy is seen as a step in the right direction, but its effectiveness remains unclear, with some experts noting the need to address job opportunities in regional areas.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Cabinet approved plans to give tax breaks to companies that move their headquarters out of Tokyo as Japan seeks to revitalize its regional economies.

site_title: Australia: Shares post modest gains, Kathmandu slides
summary: Australia's share market rose modestly on Tuesday, driven by gains in energy and mining stocks following firmer commodity prices. The US dollar's fall overnight boosted commodity prices, allowing investors to re-enter the sector. However, market strategist Stan Shamu noted that the sector's fundamentals remain unchanged, despite the short-term gains. The Australian market's gains were seen as a response to the sector's weakness, with major banks experiencing weakness.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Monday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.22% at 7,037.67 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index fell 1.19% to 11,895.84 points. Paris's CAC 40 index dipped 0.65% to 5,054.52 points. The mixed performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, but US-EU trade talks remained a focus.

site_title: Fed's Fischer says rate rise probably warranted by end-2015
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer stated that raising interest rates "likely will be warranted before the end of the year" due to the economy's growth, despite the recent plunge in oil prices. He also emphasized that subsequent rate increases won't be uniform or predictable. Fischer noted that the Fed wants to be "reasonably confident" that inflation is rising toward its 2% goal before moving to raise rates.

site_title: Slack is said to be in funding talks at US$2 billion-plus value
summary: Slack Technologies, a collaboration software company, is in talks with investors to raise financing at a valuation of over $2 billion. This funding round, if successful, would more than double the company's valuation from its previous $1.12 billion valuation in October. Slack has seen significant growth, with over 500,000 active daily users and plans to double its head count this year. The company's success is a validation for founder Stewart Butterfield, who co-founded Tiny Speck and previously raised $17 million for an online game before pivoting to Slack.

site_title: Australia competition watchdog may deny Qantas, China Eastern agreement
summary: Australia's competition watchdog has proposed to deny Qantas Airways' plan to co-ordinate operations with China Eastern Airlines due to concerns it could limit capacity and increase airfares on the Sydney-Shanghai route. Qantas and China Eastern account for over 80% of capacity on the route, significantly reducing competition between the two airlines. The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) fears the agreement could result in "significant public detriment".

site_title: Russian Finance Minister warns of risks of burning through reserves
summary: Russian Finance Minister Anton Siluanov warned that the country's budget deficit could reach 3.7% of GDP if not reduced, forcing Russia to spend its entire emergency reserve fund and print money. If the deficit isn't cut, Siluanov said Russia would face inflation and undermine confidence in the economy. The Reserve Fund is expected to be depleted to 2.6 trillion roubles, prompting concerns about the country's fiscal sustainability. Siluanov urged lawmakers to reduce the deficit to avoid a potential economic crisis.

images.alt_text: Russian Finance Minister Anton Siluanov warned on Monday that if the budget deficit was not reduced, Russia would quickly spend its entire emergency Reserve Fund and be forced to start printing money.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.18% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.18% lower on Tuesday, following a strengthening yen against the dollar, which negatively impacted Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index fell 35.37 points to 19,718.99. This decline came after the dollar fell on Monday, sparking speculation that the Federal Reserve may not raise interest rates soon.

site_title: Treasuries gain as Fischer says rate rise won't be predictable
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer stated that interest rates will rise but not in a predictable pattern, as economic developments will guide the pace and extent of increases. This led to a decrease in 10-year Treasury yields to 1.91%, with some analysts questioning the sustainability of US economic strength. Fischer also mentioned that forward guidance on rates may diminish, and the economy may encounter shocks such as oil price plunges or geopolitical crises.

site_title: Emerging trends in urban water management
summary: Urban water management is expected to undergo significant changes by 2030, driven by factors such as population growth, economic development, and increasing consumer expectations. Utilities worldwide are losing trust and confidence from consumers, with households taking matters into their own hands by installing private treatment systems. In Singapore, despite having a well-managed utility, households still boil water before consumption due to concerns about water quality. The "cheap water" hypothesis suggests that stagnant water prices and lack of perceived quality improvements contribute to this trend, which could lead to utilities losing importance and households spending more on alternative water sources.

site_title: Seattle approves US$34m to expand historic Pike Place Market
summary: Seattle lawmakers approved a US$34 million investment to expand and renovate the historic Pike Place Market, a 30,000-square-foot public plaza will be created, featuring a walkway connecting the market to the waterfront. The expansion, the largest in 50 years, aims to increase accessibility and visitor capacity, despite restrictions under historic preservation rules. The project will transform a nearby parking lot into the new public space, enhancing the market's appeal and supporting local businesses and tourism.

images.alt_text: Seattle lawmakers voted on Monday to invest US$34 million in taxpayer funds to expand the city's historic Pike Place Market, which draws millions of visitors each year to its fresh produce, flower and fish stalls.

site_title: Oil prices rise as dollar dips
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as the dollar retreated against the euro, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate gaining 27 cents to $46.84 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude climbing 12 cents to $55.44 a barrel. The increase was driven by a weaker dollar, which made US-priced oil cheaper for holders of rival currencies. Saudi Arabia's oil minister warned that the cartel refuses to take responsibility alone for boosting falling crude prices, exacerbating a global supply glut.

site_title: Rouble set for 2015 high as US$9b tax deadline spurs demand
summary: The Russian rouble rose 1.1% to 58.5810 per dollar as tax-payment deadlines boosted demand, driven by an estimated 530 billion rubles in corporate taxes. Oil prices stabilized around $55 a barrel, supporting the currency. Russian bonds gained for a fourth day, despite JPMorgan Chase excluding them from its indexes due to a junk credit score. The Micex Index retreated 1.6% as the rouble strengthened, while RTS stocks declined for the first time in five days.

images.alt_text: The rouble headed for the strongest level this year as tax-payment deadlines boosted demand, while Russian bonds gained for a fourth day.

site_title: Nasdaq to provide trading technology for bitcoin marketplace: WSJ
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group has agreed to provide a startup, Noble Markets, with its X-stream trading system to power a marketplace for trading bitcoins and related digital-currency assets. The deal includes marketing support. This follows the launch of a regulated exchange in the US by Coinbase, a bitcoin payments processor backed by the New York Stock Exchange. The partnership aims to bring more stability and regulation to the emerging digital currency market, which has faced scrutiny after high-profile scandals.

site_title: Court order to return planes may dampen SpiceJet stock surge
summary: SpiceJet's stock surge faces a threat from a court order seeking to return six of its Boeing 737 planes to lessors who are owed money. The airline plans to appeal the decision, which could disrupt flights. SpiceJet has received offers to lease more than 20 aircraft and aims to add eight to nine 737s starting April. The airline's financial struggles underscore challenges in the Indian airline industry from rising competition and high jet fuel taxes.

site_title: New partnerships extend Microsoft's reach into Android
summary: Microsoft has partnered with Samsung and 10 other Android manufacturers to pre-install its services, including Word and Skype, on devices. The deal aims to bring Microsoft's productivity services to a broader range of devices, including tablets. The partnership is part of Microsoft's mobile-first, cloud-first strategy, which seeks to deliver services to consumers and businesses using Apple and Android hardware. The move is seen as a push to catch up with rival Google, and 10 other hardware makers, including Dell and HP, will also install Microsoft services on their Android devices.

images.alt_text: Microsoft on Monday unveiled partnerships with Samsung and other manufacturers to install its services including Word and Skype on devices powered by the rival Google Android system.

site_title: Adapting time management tips for social media growth
summary: A self-assessment exercise for social media leaders is crucial due to the need for adapting time management tips to individual brand cultures. The article emphasizes the importance of re-evaluating weekly social media plans for efficiency, considering tools and team utilization. For social media enthusiasts, making a plan, allocating time and resources, and utilizing other teams for content creation and sharing can be effective. A single approver can ensure brand tonality consistency, and recent tools like Outbox Pro, Buffer, and Hootsuite offer this functionality.

site_title: Palm losing ground in India to soya bean, sunflower and canola oils
summary: India, the world's largest importer of cooking oils, is expected to buy more soya bean and sunflower oil this year due to a global glut and weakening palm oil prices. Soya bean and sunflower oil purchases are projected to jump 15% to 4.2 million tonnes, accounting for 33% of shipments, while palm oil will represent 67% for the first time in eight years. The shift is attributed to palm oil's lower price, with soya bean oil being 50% cheaper than palm oil on average.

site_title: China's crisis-hit steel mills look overseas
summary: China's struggling steel mills are looking to expand abroad to escape weak demand and environmental costs at home. The government has included support for foreign acquisitions in a revised restructuring plan, with targets set on South-east Asia, Eastern Europe, Africa, and Indonesia. Some companies, such as Hebei Steel Group and Shougang, are already investing in foreign projects, while others are exploring opportunities. Analysts believe that overseas expansion could help reduce excess capacity and increase growth for Chinese steelmakers.

site_title: US opposition to China-backed AIIB is pointless
summary: The US opposition to the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is seen as pointless, despite initial concerns over governance and environmental standards. The UK's decision to apply for a founding membership has strained US-China relations. The AIIB aims to address the $1 trillion annual infrastructure financing gap in Asia, a need that is largely unmet. US officials are wary of China's growing influence, but World Bank President Jim Yong Kim welcomes the AIIB and is willing to work with it. The US has long opposed the AIIB, but its opposition now appears to be futile.

site_title: Name change, new ambitions for Biogen
summary: Biogen, a Massachusetts-based biotech company, is changing its name to Biogen IDEC Inc and has new ambitions in developing drugs for Alzheimer's, ALS, and other nerve degenerative diseases. CEO George Scangos aims to develop an Alzheimer's drug by 2025 and transform the treatment of multiple sclerosis. The company's shares rose 9.7% following successful clinical trial results for its Alzheimer's drug aducanumab, which showed significant slowing of cognitive impairment in patients with mild symptoms. Biogen is also expanding into the biosimilars market, manufacturing cheaper versions of older biotech drugs.

site_title: Roll over Ebola: measles is the deadly new threat
summary: Liberia, still recovering from the Ebola epidemic, is now facing a new health threat: the measles virus. Refugees in Monrovia's Peace Island ghetto, who survived the devastating outbreak a year ago, are once again at risk. The resurgence of measles is a concern for the country, which is emerging from the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

site_title: Tsipras, Merkel urge end to ugly eurozone 'stereotypes'
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged an end to "stereotypes" and name-calling threatening the eurozone, stressing their common ground on the debt crisis. Tsipras said Greece is not to blame for its debt and Merkel agreed that Europe must overcome stereotypes to ensure the currency's future. Despite initial talks, entrenched differences surfaced, with Tsipras criticizing austerity measures and Merkel advocating for fiscal discipline. The two leaders agreed to build cooperation based on trust, with Merkel pledging to reduce unemployment in Greece.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday urged an end to the vicious "stereotypes" and name-calling that have threatened to rip the eurozone apart.

site_title: Women take centre stage at the box office
summary: Women are driving ticket sales to a degree rarely seen before, with the release of The Divergent Series: Insurgent, Fifty Shades of Gray, and Cinderella, delivering the three biggest live-action openings of 2015. The audience for Insurgent was 60% female, Fifty Shades of Gray 67%, and Cinderella 66% female, indicating a significant shift in the box office demographics, with young men being relatively absent.

site_title: Fed review says leak in one case was unintentional, careless
summary: The Federal Reserve has concluded that two recent leaks of confidential information about 2012 policy deliberations were unintentional and "careless." The leaks occurred when a Wall Street Journal reporter spoke with numerous Fed officials, while a Medley Global Advisors report was based on a limited number of contacts. The Fed's review did not disclose any details of the policy proposals or actions discussed during the meetings. The incidents prompted recommendations for improved dealings with the press. The September 2012 FOMC meeting, which was a precursor to significant monetary policy actions, was not directly affected by the leaks.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages have provided updates on several companies. Noble Group was downgraded to "hold" by Maybank Kim Eng Research due to short-term headwinds, but the analysts believe value is starting to emerge. Centurion Corp was maintained as a "buy" with a target price of S$0.75, despite concerns over high gearing. Genting Hong Kong's stock was held with a target price of US$0.38, citing a disappointing 2014 results and industry trends tempering its outlook. Keppel Land is expected to be privatized, with analysts recommending shareholders accept the offer.

site_title: Property sector to focus on inventory clearing: China Resources Land
summary: China Resources Land, a state-backed property developer, plans to focus on clearing inventory in the property sector due to a supply glut. The sector, accounting for 15% of China's GDP, is seen as the greatest risk to the government's 7% economic growth target. The company set aggressive sales targets despite a slump in the property market, which began to decline last year after the central government implemented measures to cool the sector. A weak property market poses a significant threat to the government's economic growth target.

site_title: Canadian National Railway derailment numbers soared before recent crashes: analysis
summary: Canadian National Railway (CN) experienced a sharp deterioration in its safety record in 2014, with 57 derailments on its main lines, up 73% from 2013, and 27 caused by track problems. This trend reverses years of improvements and raises concerns about the impact of oil unit trains on track conditions. CN Railway attributes the increase to bad weather and increased freight volume, but data analysis suggests track problems were the main cause. The Transportation Safety Board (TSB) has suggested oil trains may have contributed to the Ontario accidents, fueling calls for tougher regulation and potential changes to train operations.

site_title: Sales of existing homes rise 1.2% in February
summary: Existing home sales rose 1.2% in February to a 4.88 million annual rate, falling short of the five million mark for the second consecutive month. The median home price increased 7.5% to $202,600, driven by a lack of inventory and rising prices outpacing income growth. Tight lending standards and affordability issues continue to hinder purchases, despite near-historical low mortgage rates. Experts expect further labor market gains and loosening of credit rules to help offset these challenges.

site_title: Fed's rate decision will be affected by numbers, history
summary: The US Federal Reserve may consider raising interest rates this year, but the decision is uncertain due to changing economic conditions. Fed Chair Janet Yellen dropped the phrase "patient" from the Fed's statement, sparking speculation about a potential rate hike in June. However, Yellen emphasized that the Fed is not declaring its plan, citing concerns about the unemployment rate and stagnant wages. The Fed may be influenced by the lessons of the 1937 Great Depression, when a contraction in the money supply led to a new recession. Instead, policymakers are likely to consider the current economic trends and the Fed's two mandates: price stability and full employment.

site_title: Modern Singapore mourns founding father
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, a founding father of the country, has passed away at 3:18 am on March 23, 2015, at the age of 91, after battling severe pneumonia for six weeks. Tributes poured in from world leaders, business leaders, and citizens, praising his leadership and vision that made Singapore a thriving nation. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong declared a seven-day national mourning period, with a state funeral service to be held on Sunday, and the body will lie in state at Parliament House.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: BI's about-face on rupiah is challenged by lack of reserves
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia (BI), is under pressure to stabilize the rupiah amid its smallest foreign-exchange reserves relative to economic output in South-east Asia. The rupiah has slid to a 16-year low, prompting the bank to intervene in the market and raise interest rates to 7.75%. However, critics argue that the bank's ability to support the currency is constrained by its limited reserves, and a prolonged period of intervention could damage its credibility. The government and BI have pledged to strengthen the rupiah, but experts warn that rebuilding credibility will take time.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific picks up 4th investment in Australia
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has acquired a 4.4-hectare land parcel in North Fremantle, near Perth, Australia, for A$59 million (S$63 million). The 45,456 sq m site is currently zoned industrial but will be rezoned for residential and commercial uses. Roxy-Pacific and its joint-venture partner Hostplus will provide 40% and 60% of the equity, respectively. This is Roxy-Pacific's fourth investment in Australia, demonstrating the company's confidence in the market. The acquisition is expected to have a minimal impact on the group's earnings and net tangible assets.
