summary: There is no article content provided for summarization.

site_title: Record US$30b in green bonds seen this year: S&P
summary: Standard & Poor's predicts that US$30 billion in green bonds will be issued this year, a record high, mainly by development banks and corporates. Proceeds from these bonds are used on projects to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote renewable energy. Further growth in the market will depend on developments in China and the establishment of common standards.

site_title: GIC makes two property investments
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has made two property investments, including a joint venture with Brigade Group to develop an IT special economic zone in Bangalore, India, spanning over 3 million square feet. GIC has also partnered with Exeter Property Group to invest in logistics properties in key European distribution hubs, focusing on value-add opportunities in core locations. This is GIC's second project with Brigade Group, following a memorandum of understanding to jointly invest in southern Indian cities last year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

SINGAPORE sovereign wealth fund GIC announced two property investments on Monday - one to develop an IT special economic zone (SEZ) in Whitefield, Bangalore, and the other to invest in logistics properties in Europe.

site_title: Draghi sees no sign of bond shortage for ECB debt buying
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi says there are no signs of a shortage of bonds available for the ECB to purchase under its quantitative easing plan, which aims to revive inflation. The ECB plans to buy 60 billion euros of public sector debt per month until September 2016, and Draghi believes the program will be a decisive driver of the euro area's accelerating recovery. Despite concerns over Greece's potential default and the rise of nationalist sentiment, Draghi remains optimistic about the euro area's economic outlook, citing improving consumer and business confidence and data showing growth gaining momentum.

site_title: Crisis warnings are flashing, but investors aren't listening
summary: Global financial experts are sounding the alarm, warning of another potential financial crisis due to the "throw-money-at-the-problem" approach of central banks, particularly the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England, through quantitative monetary easing (QE). Critics argue that this policy has led to asset price bubbles, excessive borrowing, and a shortage of high-quality assets, threatening a market liquidity crunch and potentially devastating global economic consequences. IMF officials and financial experts are increasingly concerned, with some warning of a "bigger the boom, the bigger the bust" scenario.

site_title: Singapore providing assistance to Malaysia in 1MDB probe
summary: Singapore's financial regulator, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has pledged to assist Malaysia in its high-profile probe into 1MDB, a state-backed development company. The assistance will be provided "within the full ambit" of Singapore's laws. The MAS has been in touch with Malaysian authorities and is committed to supporting the probe, which has been ongoing since 2014. The move comes after a local branch of Swiss wealth manager BSI Singapore was found to be holding $1.103 billion in 1MDB cash.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Pirelli's biggest shareholder to sell its stake to ChemChina
summary: Pirelli's largest shareholder, Cam Finanziaria SpA, has agreed to sell its 26.2% stake to ChemChina for 15 euros per share, valuing the Italian tyremaker at approximately 7.1 billion euros. ChemChina will then make a public tender offer for the remaining shares at the same price, marking the largest deal in Italy by a Chinese company. The partnership is expected to expand Pirelli's truck-tyre business and allow ChemChina to enter the international market with Pirelli's high-end car tyres.

site_title: Oil prices unlikely to return to US$100 a barrel, says Saudi official
summary: Saudi Arabia's governor to Opec says oil prices are unlikely to return to US$100 a barrel due to increased shale production. The kingdom is pumping 10 million barrels a day, close to its record in 2013, to maintain its share of the global crude market. Opec has committed to maintaining output amid a global surplus, and Saudi Arabia is able to meet demand from any customer. The drop in prices has not undermined Opec's role in the market, and the organization is focused on achieving balance rather than controlling prices.

site_title: Thai property tax law to be reviewed in April
summary: Thailand's Finance Ministry plans to review a draft law introducing the country's first property tax in April, with the goal of raising around 200 billion baht (S$8.44 billion) annually. The law, part of a broader tax reform plan, aims to boost revenue and promote fairness. A draft was initially set to be submitted to the Cabinet in March, but was delayed due to criticism, with the new review date set for April. The proposal is expected to be finalized in two years, pending Cabinet approval.

site_title: STI weakens ahead of likely fall on Wall St
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) closed with a 2.31-point loss at 3,410.13, despite a strong start due to gains in the three major banks. Noble Group's shares rebounded after the company rebutted Iceberg Research's claims and announced a legal action against the firm. The market was largely unaffected by the death of Singapore's first prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew. Analysts expect a soft US market due to weak European opening, with Maybank Kim Eng maintaining a "hold" on Noble shares and Nomura upgrading Ezion to "accumulate".

site_title: Asian Development Bank to boost Islamic financing
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is boosting Islamic financing efforts, providing technical assistance and credit guarantees to its 67 member countries to promote financial inclusion and stability. The bank is focusing on sukuk, Islamic bonds, for infrastructure financing and public debt financing, mirroring the G20's move to include sukuk in its agenda. A $2 million technical assistance program is being prepared to support five central and west Asian countries in developing their regulatory framework and strengthening Islamic finance supervision, starting in September.

site_title: China dotcom boom fades even as Nasdaq soars
summary: China's Internet boom is losing steam as half of the 14 Chinese dotcoms that debuted in the US last year are now trading below their IPO prices. Despite the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching record highs, Chinese shares have dropped 3.1% this year, with poor earnings from companies like Weibo Corp and Momo Inc contributing to the decline. The slowdown in the Chinese economy and intensifying competition are also affecting investor confidence, with some analysts predicting a shift towards the domestic market as mainland investors reallocate funds.

site_title: Latest inflation report divides views on further Sing $ easing
summary: Singapore's latest inflation report has left the market uncertain about the central bank's next move. Core inflation rose to 1.3% in February, driven by stronger food and services inflation, while headline inflation remained negative at -0.3%. Private-sector economists are divided on whether the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will ease policy further next month, with some expecting a re-centering of the S$NEER policy band downward and others believing no change is necessary.

site_title: Iceberg: 'Not the first time we acted as whistleblower against Noble'
summary: Iceberg Research has released its third report on Noble Group, stating it has acted as a whistleblower against the commodities trader before, citing a 2013 report to the Maritime Port Authority in Singapore regarding Noble's commercial practices. This comes after Noble's bankruptcy in 2014 of Danish bunker supplier OW Bunker.

site_title: Jakarta to compete with Beijing to host AIIB headquarters
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, announced that Jakarta will compete with Beijing to host the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank's (AIIB) headquarters. The AIIB, led by China, aims to start operations by the end of the year and will focus on infrastructure. At least 35 countries have expressed interest in joining the bank. International Monetary Fund (IMF) head Christine Lagarde welcomed Beijing's creation of the new infrastructure bank, expressing her desire to cooperate with the institution.

site_title: MMI on fast-track expansion path
summary: Modern Montessori International Group (MMI) has marked its first preschool opening in Myanmar and expects its first school in Vietnam to be operational by September. The preschool provider aims to set up between 5-10 new schools in Indonesia, once a sufficient supply of Montessori-trained teachers is established. MMI chairman T Chandroo has set up the first teacher-training college in preparation for its expansion in Indonesia. The group's expansion plans are part of its groundwork laid out in the last few years.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Markets calm on spirit of Lee Kuan Yew's legacy
summary: Singapore's markets remained calm following the death of founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, reflecting confidence in the country's investment prospects due to its rule of law, strong infrastructure, and open economy. Investors, business executives, and analysts attribute this confidence to the legacy of Mr Lee and the governance system he established. Despite global economic concerns, Singapore's strong economy and governance continue to attract investors, with confidence in the country's future remaining high. The news has brought an end to an era, but has not disrupted the country's stability.

site_title: BOJ researchers undermine Kuroda's view on bond buying
summary: The Bank of Japan's own researchers have undermined Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's view that the market is functioning well, citing declining liquidity in Japanese government bonds. A report by the BOJ found that long-term yields have dropped, regulations have changed, and the central bank has bought debt, leading to increased volatility and a gauge of expected bond-price swings set for its biggest quarterly gain since 2013. The report suggests that liquidity issues are a concern, contradicting Kuroda's statement that quantitative easing is working well.

site_title: Chinese property giants look for a share in winter sports
summary: Chinese real estate companies, such as China Vanke and Dalian Wanda Group, are investing in winter sports resorts to tap into China's booming winter sports market, following Beijing's joint bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics. The companies plan to upgrade and expand ski resorts, including the Songhua Lake Ski Resort, which was recently opened by Vanke. The industry is expected to be lucrative in the long run, with a huge potential market in China, despite being lagging behind European countries and Japan.

site_title: Top phonemaker in India plans fund-raiser to beat Samsung
summary: Micromax, India's top smartphone vendor, plans to raise capital to develop locally focused software and differentiate itself from foreign rivals like Samsung. The company aims to hit $2 billion in sales this fiscal year and secure 30% of the Indian smartphone market by the end of the next fiscal year. Micromax plans to hire hundreds of developers to supplement its existing game line-up and app store, and may seek outside investment to fund its mobile Internet services space.

images.alt_text: Micromax's Mr Taneja said that the company plans to secure 30 per cent of the Indian smartphone market by the end of its next fiscal year.

site_title: People's Association offers condolences on the demise of its founding chairman
summary: The People's Association (PA) has sent condolences to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong on behalf of its members and grassroots organisations following the passing of his father, Lee Kuan Yew. The PA's Deputy Chairman, Lim Swee Say, expressed his deepest condolences and praised Mr Lee Kuan Yew for laying the foundation for a socially connected Singapore through his establishment of community centres and grassroots movement. The PA acknowledged Mr Lee's vision of a united and harmonious multi-racial nation, which continues to inspire the grassroots movement.

site_title: Rex's joint entity raises financing facility; Loyz in S$14m placement
summary: Rex International Holding's joint entity, Lime Petroleum Norway AS, has secured a financing facility increase from S$52 million to S$700 million to fund offshore exploration drilling in Norway. The entity, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Lime Petroleum plc, aims to exploit 50 million barrels of oil potential. Meanwhile, Loyz Energy has raised S$14 million through a share placement to improve its financial position and bolster corporate requirements. The placements are expected to increase trading liquidity and shareholder base.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Norway's wealth fund looking to stock up on Asia properties
summary: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global, worth $870 billion, is expanding its real estate investments to Asia, focusing on Singapore and Tokyo. The fund has narrowed its search to these cities due to growth potential and supply constraints. It aims to build a portfolio in 10-15 cities globally, with a target of 5% real estate assets. The fund has already invested in major cities like New York, Paris, and London, and is seeking office properties in Singapore and Tokyo, driven by market recovery and limited supply.

site_title: Govt expanding voucher scheme for SMEs
summary: The Singapore government is expanding its Innovation and Capability Voucher (ICV) scheme to provide SMEs with 30 integrated solutions by June. The scheme allows SMEs to raise productivity with a total of 30 solutions, up from 12, and includes consultancy services. Five new solutions will be rolled out by the end of the week, with pre-qualifying solution providers being approved to prevent consultants from abusing the scheme. The ICV, valued at S$5,000, has already helped an SME like Romanez, which reduced its year-end stock-taking duration from two days to half a day.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Boeing foresees hike in S-E Asia demand for jet fighters, tankers
summary: Boeing predicts a significant increase in demand for defense equipment in South-east Asia over the next decade, driven by the region's growing economic growth. According to James Armington, Boeing's vice-president for the East Asia-Pacific region, the demand for defense equipment will grow rapidly. This growth will enable South-east Asian countries to boost their defense purchases, making the region an increasingly important market for Boeing.

site_title: It's been an honour, Mr Lee
summary: Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's former Prime Minister, passed away, leaving behind a legacy of a country transformed from a Third World nation to a first-world economy. Born with a passion for politics, he defined Singapore's future and shaped its policies. His vision and determination led to significant reforms, including bilingualism, industrialization, and globalisation. However, he also had controversial beliefs, such as the "Stop At Two" population policy and views on women's education. Despite his tough exterior, he was a devoted husband and family man, and his love for his country was evident in his daily routines and habits.

site_title: Equation Summit unit provides QuickCheck on fake goods
summary: DiSa Digital Safety Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Equation Summit, has partnered with China Tobacco Anhui Industrial Corporation to implement its QuickCheck anti-counterfeiting solution. QuickCheck uses unique QR codes to identify genuine products and flag counterfeit goods. The solution will be deployed for 5 million cigarette packs and will run for one year. This is part of DiSa's efforts to tackle counterfeit trade, which is estimated to exceed US$1.7 trillion by 2015, and affects various sectors such as tobacco, tea, liquor, and food.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: A life rich in achievement that leaves behind a precious legacy
summary: Singapore's first prime minister and founding father Lee Kuan Yew has passed away, receiving tributes and condolences from around the world. Global leaders, politicians, academics, and ordinary citizens have expressed their respect and admiration for his legacy, with many acknowledging his transformative role in transforming Singapore into a post-modern first-world city-state. Lee's vision, policies, and methods are credited with achieving a hundred-fold increase in per capita income, cementing his place in history as a truly transformational leader.

site_title: Bond traders taking chances on riskier assets to elude negative yields
summary: Investors in the European bond market are taking risks to generate returns in a negative-yield environment. Many are buying lower-rated debt and emerging market assets, such as Nigeria and Brazil, to boost returns. Top wealth funds, including Norway's sovereign wealth fund and Allianz SE, are shifting from traditional bonds to riskier assets, exposing clients to deeper losses. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing has pushed yields on many government bonds below zero, prompting investors to seek higher returns elsewhere.

site_title: Euro slips ahead of Greek debt talks
summary: The euro slipped to US$1.0813 and 129.69 yen ahead of Greek debt talks in Berlin, where Greek leaders met with German Chancellor Angela Merkel to discuss economic reforms. Spanish economy minister Luis de Guindos reiterated that Greece won't receive bailout cash until it implements all reforms. Germany's insistence on cuts and reforms has raised concerns about Greece's access to fresh bailout loans.

site_title: New hope for stroke boosts demand for devices to nab blood clots
summary: A breakthrough in stroke treatment has boosted demand for devices to remove blood clots from the brain, as research shows that swift intervention can significantly improve recovery rates. Studies have found that 89% of patients who underwent surgery and received drug treatment had near-complete restoration of blood flow, compared to 34% who received drug treatment alone. This has led to a surge in referrals for the procedure, with medical centers ordering more equipment and medical centers in Europe and the US experiencing a significant increase in orders. The procedure, known as thrombectomy, can slash the cost of stroke and improve patient outcomes.

site_title: Central banks warn inflation may be driven by events abroad
summary: Central banks worldwide are acknowledging that global events are increasingly influencing local inflation rates. Policymakers have been emphasizing the need for flexibility in monetary policy, as events abroad can complicate their ability to set the right rates. This shift in perspective is evident in recent speeches from Ottawa to London. The global economic landscape, including China's slowing GDP growth and the UK's shrinking economy, is putting pressure on policymakers to adapt their strategies.

site_title: China mulls easing curbs on foreign securities JVs
summary: China is considering changes to its securities industry that would allow foreign banks to own majority stakes in local joint ventures, potentially as soon as this year. Regulators plan to broaden offerings and give foreign-owned joint ventures permission to expand into areas beyond stock and bond underwriting. The move aims to increase competition and broaden the offerings of foreign banks in China.

site_title: Buffett tells foreign investors good profits to be made in US
summary: Warren Buffett, CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, encourages foreign investors to invest in the US, citing the country's advantages of rule of law, equality of opportunity, and encouragement for innovators. He believes the US economy and investment climate will continue to thrive, stating that Berkshire Hathaway will do well in the years ahead.

site_title: Evergrande scraps 90b yuan solar push as timing 'immature'
summary: Evergrande Group, China's most indebted publicly traded homebuilder, scrapped its 90 billion yuan solar power plan due to "immature timing." No funds have been spent on the solar business, and analysts advise against investing in solar power due to unpredictable returns. The decision comes as Chinese developers face strain from slowing real estate markets and rising debt levels, with Evergrande obtaining 100 billion yuan in credit lines from Chinese banks in recent months.

site_title: Big hotels drawn to 'lifestyle' boutique sector
summary: Big hotel chains like Marriott, Hilton, and InterContinental Hotels Group are shifting focus to the "lifestyle" boutique hotel sector, driven by demand from millennials. These hotels aim to offer unique, authentic experiences with a local feel, often featuring community spaces and locally sourced food. The mega-chains are investing in tailored brands to meet the growing demand for individualized experiences, with some seeing impressive returns. Boutique hotel chains like Citizen M and Indigo are already gaining popularity, with Indigo's revenue per available room outpacing its Holiday Inn Express arm in Europe.

site_title: Fed rate hike 'widely expected' this year, Fischer says
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise US interest rates this year, according to Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer, citing significant economic progress and a near-full employment labor market. The rate hike is expected to occur before the end of the year, when the expected return outweighs the costs, and will be adjusted based on future economic conditions. The Fed aims to return inflation to its 2% objective over the medium term.

site_title: Noble files HK suit after third Iceberg report
summary: Noble Group has filed a Hong Kong court suit against ex-credit analyst Arnaud Vagner and Seychelles-registered Enlighten Ace Ltd, claiming conspiracy and spreading false information that drove down its share price. The suit comes after the third report by Iceberg Research alleging Noble understated its debt position. Noble believes Vagner is a key player behind the allegations, while credit rating agency Standard & Poor's defends its methodology, stating commodity traders' inventories are typically highly liquid.

site_title: Of AIIB's rickety foundations
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has been criticized for its shaky foundations, with concerns over debt, waste, and corruption in its member countries. China, the bank's main backer, aims to use it to stimulate development and growth in poorer countries, but its track record on infrastructure projects is questionable. The US and Western countries have joined the bank, but its influence is limited by the lack of confidence from commercial lenders in Asian governments' ability to manage projects responsibly. The bank's design and operations must be re-examined to ensure it operates with fairness, openness, and financial discipline.

site_title: China developers returning to onshore bonds
summary: Chinese property developers are shifting from borrowing in the offshore market to onshore bonds due to lower funding costs and improved liquidity resulting from monetary easing measures. This move is expected to coincide with interest rate cuts in China and a potential hike in US interest rates later this year. Despite a cooling housing market and scandals, developers such as Country Garden plan to raise more onshore yuan loans, with Country Garden aiming to increase its proportion of yuan loans to 60% this year.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat after strong gains last week
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, following strong gains in major indexes the previous week, amid investor assessment of dollar and crude price gyrations. The Dow Jones rose 0.09%, the S&P 500 gained 0.02%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.12%.

site_title: A lasting legacy
summary: Lee Kuan Yew, the former Prime Minister of Singapore, passed away on March 23, 2015. Meanwhile, on July 11, 2025, Malaysia is set to seize approximately RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The ASEAN region has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy has shrunk for the second consecutive month, affecting Prime Minister Starmer's stance.

site_title: SNB open to IMF suggestion of foreign currency QE
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is considering foreign currency quantitative easing, a form of asset purchase programme, as suggested by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). This move comes amid slowing economic growth and declining consumer prices due to the franc's appreciation against the euro. The SNB's Alternate Governing Board member, Thomas Moser, mentioned that the IMF's policy proposals are among the options being explored. The decision aims to stabilize the economy and mitigate the impact of the currency cap removal.

site_title: ECB says public sector programme purchases now 26.3b euros
summary: The European Central Bank announced it has spent 26.3 billion euros on a public sector programme to boost the eurozone economy, aiming to lift inflation from below zero to its target of 2%. The plan, known as quantitative easing, will purchase 60 billion euros of securities per month until September 2016 or beyond if needed. This move is part of the ECB's efforts to stimulate economic growth and achieve its inflation target.

site_title: US existing home sales rise marginally in February
summary: US existing home sales rose 1.2% to a 4.88 million-unit annual rate in February, less than expected, due to a persistent shortage of properties on the market and harsh winter weather. Sales were constrained in the Northeast, but rose in the South and West. Economists had forecast a 4.90 million-unit pace. Tight supply and winter weather impacted sales, suggesting a challenging spring selling season.

site_title: 'Remembering a true giant of history'
summary: Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew passed away, prompting tributes from world leaders, business leaders, and Singaporeans. Tributes highlighted his remarkable foresight, relentless pursuit of Singapore's development, and his vision for a prosperous nation. Leaders praised his contributions to Singapore's transformation into a major economic hub, his commitment to good governance, and his legacy as a great strategist of Asian affairs. His passing marks the end of an era in Singapore's history, and his contributions will be remembered for generations to come.

site_title: Japan upgrades economic view for first time in 8 mths
summary: Japan's government has upgraded its economic view for the first time in eight months, citing a moderate recovery trend driven by improving corporate activity and factory output. The country's overall economy is expected to continue its recovery, with production, corporate profits, and sentiment also showing signs of improvement. This upgrade comes after a recession caused by a sales tax hike last April.

site_title: IBM to share technology with China in strategy shift: CEO
summary: IBM's CEO, Virginia Rometty, announced a strategy shift to share technology with Chinese firms, shifting from viewing China as a sales destination to a partner in building the country's IT industry. This move comes amid growing pressure from China to reduce foreign-made technology and amid US companies forming alliances with domestic operators. IBM plans to help Chinese companies build semiconductor chips, servers, and software, and has already partnered with Chinese vendors, including Suzhou PowerCore Technology Co and Youyou, a Beijing-based software firm.

site_title: Bundesbank predicts strong German growth in H1
summary: The German central bank, Bundesbank, predicts strong economic growth in the first half of 2015, driven by robust exports and consumer spending. The economy is expected to continue growing strongly, with foreign demand, private consumption, and residential construction as key drivers. The growth rate is seen as a continuation of the 0.7% expansion in the fourth quarter of 2014, lifting the full-year growth to 1.6%. The Bundesbank also emphasizes the need for individual states and investors to take responsibility for their debts to ensure the eurozone currency bloc can withstand a possible insolvency of a member state.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 7.8 points to close at 1,795.85 on Monday, with 436 losers and 374 gainers. The index was impacted by a decline in shares, with 2.13 billion lots valued at RM1.77 billion traded.

site_title: MPA, M1 to provide 4G network up to 15km from coast
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) and M1 have partnered to provide 4G wireless broadband network coverage to vessels up to 15km from the coast, boosting productivity and crew welfare for ships in the port waters. This is part of the "Smarter Port" initiative, aiming to keep Singapore's port internationally competitive through innovative technology. The move is expected to enhance network coverage in port waters, with subsequent initiatives including automation, data analytics, and traffic management. MPA has set aside S$2 million to co-fund projects for business-to-business apps for the maritime industry.

site_title: Major Asian markets mostly up after US, Europe gains
summary: Asian markets rose Monday, following US and European gains, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Hong Kong leading the way. The US Federal Reserve's dovish comments on interest rates lifted global shares, while the dollar struggled. European markets also surged, driven by Greece's promise to submit fresh bailout reform plans. Oil prices fell, and gold prices rose. The dollar is down from its Tokyo high, while the euro is up against the yen.

site_title: ECB has its eyes wide open
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is aware of the risks associated with its quantitative easing program, which may hinder economic reforms in the euro area. The ECB aims to buy €60 billion in bonds monthly, with a focus on German government securities. ECB President Mario Draghi has stated that central banks will buy bonds yielding above the bank's deposit rate of -0.2%. The ECB's efforts may be undermined if euro member countries fail to adjust their economic policies, with the responsibility lying with national governments rather than the ECB.

site_title: Lower oil prices to have long-lasting impact: Russian central bank
summary: Russian Central Bank First Deputy Governor Ksenia Yudayeva stated that lower oil prices will have a long-lasting impact on Russia's economy. The country is forecast to slip into recession for the first time since 2009 due to declining crude prices and sanctions. The rouble has dropped 40% against the dollar compared to mid-2014, further exacerbating the economic downturn.

site_title: UK factory orders stagnate in March, hit by sliding exports: CBI
summary: UK factory orders stagnated in March, with new business from abroad declining sharply, according to a CBI survey. The total order book balance fell to zero, its lowest in five months, and new export orders plummeted to -26, the lowest level since January 2013. Economists attributed the decline to a still subdued eurozone and a stronger pound. Despite this, respondents were optimistic about the next three months, expecting steady growth.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees inflation risk as Fed sends TIPS yields down
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts US consumer prices will revive due to the Federal Reserve's reluctance to tighten policy, citing low TIPS yields and a break-even rate out of line with long-run inflation measures. The Fed has pared forecasts for interest-rate increases, and analysts expect inflation to rise by 1.76% over the decade, with some economists predicting a rebound in inflation by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley is advising clients to bet on a revival in US consumer prices, predicting the Federal Reserve will refrain from tightening policy until 2016.

site_title: China plans regional power markets under sector revamp plan
summary: China plans to launch regional power markets through a sector revamp, aiming to boost efficiency and attract private investment. Qualified generating companies and bulk end-users will settle tariffs themselves through spot electricity trading platforms. The markets will be launched in stages and by region, starting with Shenzhen, and will target commercial and industrial power consumers. The government will grant licenses to qualified power suppliers, allowing them to trade electricity with big commercial users while maintaining price-setting control over residential users and public utilities. The revamp is expected to take place by 2018.

site_title: India govt to borrow US$57.83b in H1 of 2015/16
summary: India's government plans to borrow 3.60 trillion rupees (S$79.49 billion) in the first half of the fiscal year 2015/16, accounting for 66.7% of its full-year target of 6 trillion rupees. This borrowing will help fund a 3.9% fiscal deficit of the gross domestic product for the year.

site_title: Greece wants 100m euros in damages from German defence firms
summary: Greece's government is seeking approximately 100 million euros in damages from German defence firms, including Airbus, Rheinmetall, STN, and Atlas Elektronik, over alleged bribery in arms deals. The alleged bribes total around 103 million euros, with 41 million euros for helicopter sales and 62 million euros for submarine contracts. Greece's investigation includes other cases and could result in 500-800 million euros in compensation. The move follows Greece's overhaul of arms procurement and deteriorating relations with Germany, which is trying to renegotiate its bailout terms.

site_title: Collaborative robots getting increasingly accessible
summary: Universal Robots unveiled the UR3 robotic arm, a smaller version of its predecessors, with a 3kg payload capacity. The arm is capable of 360-degree rotation and infinite rotation on the end joint, allowing for a range of tasks such as pick-and-place, soldering, and painting. This move aims to make collaborative robots more accessible to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) at a lower price point and with simpler implementation.

images.alt_text: Ms Gotfredsen has plans to expand the team from three to six by the end of the year. She believes in the local talent pool that the company can tap to grow the team.
Mindy Tan

site_title: Oil slips close to US$55 as Saudi output rises to near record
summary: Saudi Arabia increased oil production to near a record 10 million barrels per day, contributing to global oversupply concerns. Oil prices declined, with Brent crude holding near $55 a barrel. US WTI crude fell to $46.02. Saudi Arabia has refused to cut output unless other Opec producers join, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Capital regulation adds risk as Asia debt safety net decays
summary: Global banks are pulling back from the Asian corporate debt market due to stricter regulatory capital requirements, reducing liquidity and leaving investors without a debt safety net. The credit default swap (CDS) market, which allows bondholders to buy insurance against borrower defaults, is also shrinking. This has led to increased volatility in bond prices, as seen in the case of Chinese property developer Kaisa Group, which is trying to restructure $10.6 billion of debt. The decline of the CDS market is seen as a risk for investors, with Chinese debt defaults now ranking as the second-biggest tail risk in global markets.

images.alt_text: Kaisa's bond maturing in June 2015 has swung wildly in price since December in an extreme range of 20 to 90 cents on the US dollar, in an often-illiquid secondary market.

site_title: Japan, Indonesia sign defence deal before Joko's China trip
summary: Japan and Indonesia signed a bilateral defence cooperation deal on Monday, as Indonesian President Joko Widodo visited Tokyo for the first time outside Southeast Asia. The deal aims to strengthen strategic partnership and cooperation on capacity building, defense equipment, and technology. This follows Japan's agreements with Vietnam and Singapore, and comes ahead of Mr. Widodo's trip to China. The move is seen as part of Japan's efforts to bolster security ties with Southeast Asian governments amid territorial disputes with China.

site_title: German businessmen challenge ECB's bond purchase programme
summary: Three German businessmen, Heinrich Weiss, Patrick Adenauer, and Juergen Heraeus, are challenging the European Central Bank's (ECB) bond purchase programme, known as Quantitative Easing (QE), arguing it oversteps the bank's mandate. The ECB's massive 1.14-trillion-euro programme aims to pump liquidity into the financial system and kick-start lending. German Constitutional Court's previous ruling on a similar OMT programme was partially in favor of the plaintiffs, and the ECJ is expected to publish its judgement later this year, but the German court may still rule against the programme.

images.alt_text: Three German businessmen are seeking to block the European Central Bank's controversial bond purchase programme, arguing it oversteps the bank's mandate, their legal expert told AFP on Monday.

site_title: Political will not enough, action needed from Greece: Commission
summary: The European Commission urged Greece to take real action on implementing reforms, stressing that strong political will is not enough. The Commission expects Greece to present a list of reforms in the next few days. Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas stated that at this stage, "strong political will by itself does not suffice, it must translate into action and progress." This comes as Greece seeks to unblock more loans to Athens.

site_title: Six community sites for public to pay respects to Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Six community sites in Singapore will be available from March 24 for public to pay respects to late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. The sites are located in Ang Mo Kio, Tanjong Pagar, East Coast, Chua Chu Kang, Jurong, and Tampines GRCs. A total of 18 community sites will be set up by March 25.

site_title: China's Alibaba invests in funds of Israeli venture capital firm
summary: Alibaba Group, a Chinese e-commerce company, has invested in the funds of Jerusalem Venture Partners (JVP), one of Israel's leading venture capital firms, in a deal worth tens of millions of dollars. This marks Alibaba's first investment in a venture capital fund. JVP has nearly $1 billion under management and has backed successful investments in cybersecurity companies, including CyberArk Software. The investment follows Alibaba's previous investment in Visualead, a barcode technology start-up. A delegation from Alibaba is currently in Israel to meet with JVP and attend a cybersecurity conference.

site_title: Japan govt upgrades economic view for first time in 8 months
summary: Japan's government upgraded its economic view for the first time in 8 months, citing a moderate recovery trend driven by improving corporate activity. Factory output is picking up, and company profits showed improvement. However, private consumption and capital spending remain unchanged, suggesting a virtuous economic cycle is far from assured. The upgrade comes ahead of a Bank of Japan meeting, which stuck to its massive stimulus program, signaling the country's potential emergence from recession without additional monetary easing.

site_title: GIC ties up with US property firm to invest in logistics properties in Europe
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has partnered with US property firm Exeter Property Group to invest in logistics properties in key European distribution hubs. The 300 million euro partnership aims to target value-add opportunities in core locations, focusing on easy access to transportation networks. Exeter will manage the partnership and implement value-add strategies to generate stable, long-term income returns. The partnership is expected to capitalize on growing demand for logistics space due to e-commerce and supply chain reorganization in the region.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares buoyed by China rally, global markets
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.5% on Monday, following a ninth consecutive winning session on mainland China shares. Gains in Wall Street and European markets also contributed to the increase. Banking and real estate stocks led the rise, with signs of Beijing easing policies to aid the struggling property sector. The Hang Seng index reached 24,494.51 points, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.2%.

site_title: GIC-Brigade JV buys site in Bangalore to develop it into IT special economic zone
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, in a joint venture with Indian property developer Brigade Group, has acquired a 100% stake in a 3 million square foot site in Bangalore to develop an IT special economic zone. The site, located in Brookefields, Whitefield, has received SEZ Board of Approvals and is expected to provide natural connectivity to two major IT hubs. This is the second project by Brigade Properties, which also includes a high-end residential project, and marks a joint investment of up to 15 billion rupees (S$330 million) in south Indian cities.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Peugeot says economic tailwinds may speed recovery plan
summary: Peugeot's chief financial officer, Jean-Baptiste de Chatillon, said the French carmaker may reach its 2% operating margin goal early, thanks to economic tailwinds, including a weaker euro and cheaper raw materials. This aligns with the company's pledge to restore auto-division profitability by 2018. Despite initial market skepticism, Peugeot shares rejoined the CAC-40 index after a two-and-a-half-year absence, with shares initially falling 4.7% before recovering.

site_title: Business community sends tributes in honour of Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew has died at the age of 91. The government has declared a period of National Mourning from March 23 to 29, and flags on government buildings will be flown at half-mast. Business leaders and industry leaders have paid tributes to Lee, praising his vision and leadership in creating a favorable business environment, shaping the electronics and technology industry, and transforming Singapore into a thriving metropolis. They remember him as a visionary leader who played a critical role in the country's economic development and a giant of a man who changed the course of history.

images.alt_text: Former prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, a co-founder of the People's Action Party, has died at the age of 91.

site_title: Japan PM Abe set for one-week US tour
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will embark on a week-long US tour from April 26 to May 3, marking the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II. The visit will focus on deepening trade and military ties, as well as showcasing Japan's post-war pacifism. Abe will become the first Japanese leader to address a joint session of the US Congress, and a "two-plus-two" meeting between foreign and defense ministers of the two nations will take place on the sidelines. The visit aims to mend frayed ties with South Korea and China.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks weaken ahead of expected Wall St fall
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 2.31 points to 3,410.13 on Monday, following a weak opening for the US market. The index had initially risen 18 points before reversing. Turnover was 950 million units worth S$957.6 million. The market showed little reaction to the passing of Singapore's first prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew. Gains in banks and Noble Group's shares helped keep the index positive. The decline was attributed to concerns over rising US interest rates and low liquidity.

site_title: Gold near 2-week high, retains gains on weaker dollar
summary: Gold prices remained near a two-week high at US$1,182.55 an ounce, boosted by a weaker US dollar and the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on interest rate hikes. The Fed's comments reduced expectations for a June interest rate hike, with most banks now expecting a delay until at least September. Analysts expect gold demand to increase due to the weaker dollar, but investor sentiment remains cautious, with the world's largest gold-backed ETF reporting its lowest holdings in months.

site_title: Britain tells United States: We'll always fight by your side
summary: British Defence Secretary Michael Fallon assured the US that Britain will always stand by its side in times of need, amid concerns over defence spending cuts. Fallon's statement was made ahead of the UK's national election on May 7, where both the Conservative and Labour parties are under pressure to commit to protecting defence spending. Fallon cited Britain's strong financial foundation, largest defence budget in the EU, and its involvement in Iraq as reasons to reassure the US of its commitment.

site_title: Thailand plans national data centre worth up to US$1.23b: Deputy PM
summary: Thailand plans to build a national data centre worth up to $1.23 billion as part of its digital economy initiative. The project, which aims to boost internet access nationwide and increase competitiveness, will be funded by the private sector. The data centre is expected to be completed by late 2016. This move is part of the government's efforts to enhance Thailand's digital economy.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) will examine the effectiveness of the recall remedy and potential residual customer concerns.

site_title: Ringgit rises most in a month on bet Fed to hold rates past June
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 0.7% to 3.7060 a dollar, its biggest gain in a month, on speculation the Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates until the second half, supporting the nation's stocks and bonds. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index was little changed, while Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart and Chicago Fed chief Charles Evans acknowledged a stronger dollar hinders economic growth, easing pressure on the ringgit. This move follows Fitch Ratings' warning of a 50% chance of a credit downgrade, and futures show a 62% likelihood of US interest rate hikes by mid-year.

site_title: Singapore's senior statesmen send condolences, tributes
summary: Senior statesmen in Singapore sent tributes to the late Lee Kuan Yew, the country's founding father, who died at 91. In a condolence letter, Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong remembered Lee's stoicism and dedication to Singapore. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam praised Lee's leadership, saying he built a multiracial nation and led a team, not a one-man show. Condolence boards were set up in front of the Istana and Parliament House, and a period of National Mourning was declared from March 23 to 29.

images.alt_text: Senior statesmen in Singapore sent tributes on Monday in honour of Lee Kuan Yew, who died early Monday morning at age 91.

site_title: As Nasdaq soars, China's Alibaba-led dot-com boom starts to fade
summary: China's Alibaba-led dot-com boom is losing momentum as the Nasdaq Composite Index nears a record high. Half of China's 14 dot-coms that debuted in the US last year are now trading below their initial sale prices, with Alibaba Group Holding down 28% from its record high. Poor earnings from Chinese tech companies, including Weibo and Momo, are eroding investor confidence. The Shanghai Composite Index has risen 13% this year, but the decline in Chinese shares is a concern, with investors scaling back valuations due to intensified competition and spending increases.

images.alt_text: Just as the Nasdaq Composite Index surges to the cusp of the record high set during the dot-com-era, the excitement about China's Internet boom is fading.

site_title: Bank capital regulation seen adding risk as Asia debt safety net decays
summary: Asia's corporate debt market is facing a liquidity crisis due to stricter regulatory capital requirements, which has reduced market liquidity and left fund managers with no debt safety net. The lack of comprehensive credit default swaps (CDS) contracts has made it difficult for investors to hedge against borrower defaults, particularly in China. This has led to increased volatility in bond prices and a decline in trading volumes in CDS contracts, with some investors relying on diversified credit baskets and praying for favorable events.

images.alt_text: A debt restructuring plan submitted to creditors last week said Kaisa's bond holders will likely suffer a severe 50 per cent capital loss, or haircut, although not the 100 percent some fear.

site_title: US President Obama offers condolences, calls Lee Kuan Yew a "true giant of history"
summary: US President Barack Obama has offered condolences to Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew's family, calling him a "true giant of history" and "father of modern Singapore". Obama praised Lee's vision and leadership, stating that his views on Asian dynamics and economic management were respected worldwide. Lee passed away on March 23, 2015, and Obama remembered him as a devoted public servant and remarkable leader who will be remembered for generations to come.

site_title: Loyz Energy to raise S$14m through share placement
summary: Loyz Energy has announced a share placement to raise S$14 million, with new shares priced at S$0.095 apiece. The funds will be used to improve the company's financial position and cover general corporate requirements. This move aims to bolster the company's financial stability and support its long-term growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.24% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.24% higher on Monday, following a pullback in the dollar last week. The Nikkei 225 index reached a fresh 15-year high on Friday. US stocks gained on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 0.94% and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.68%. The strong dollar could hurt US exports, but investors remain optimistic.

site_title: Honour Lee Kuan Yew by keeping Singapore exceptional and successful: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong addressed the nation after the death of founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, paying tribute to his "spirit" and urging the nation to "build on his foundations" and "keep Singapore exceptional and successful". He described Lee Kuan Yew as a man who "gave of himself in full measure" to Singapore, inspiring the country's independence and building a nation where there was none. The prime minister vowed to honor Lee Kuan Yew's legacy and continue his ideals.

site_title: US proposes cooperation between new China-led bank and Western institutions: WSJ
summary: The US is proposing cooperation between the new China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) and Western institutions, including the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, despite initial concerns. The US Treasury Undersecretary stated that co-financing projects would ensure the AIIB complements existing institutions, not competes with them. 27 countries have signed up to participate in the $50 billion AIIB, with the US, Britain, France, Germany, and Italy already on board. US allies Japan, Australia, and South Korea are still absent, but the International Monetary Fund and Asian Development Bank are in talks with the AIIB.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as investors take profits below 6,000 level
summary: Australian shares slipped below the 6,000 level on Monday, retreating from a strong opening session, as investors took profits from the previous week's rally. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 15.6 points, or 0.3%, to 5,959.9. Financial stocks led the decline, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac Banking Corp down 0.8% and 0.5%, respectively. Despite a strong start, the index failed to break above the 6,000 psychological barrier, which it last traded above in February 2008.

site_title: Singapore's Cabinet remembers Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Singapore's Cabinet ministers have sent condolences to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong on the death of his father, Lee Kuan Yew. They praised him for his "sound guidance, constant questioning, and fatherly care" for Singapore. The statement was released in memory of Lee Kuan Yew, the country's founding father and former prime minister.

site_title: Noble Group to start legal proceedings following third Iceberg Research report
summary: Noble Group will initiate legal proceedings against Hong Kong resident Arnaud Vagner and associates in the Hong Kong High Court for alleged conspiracy to injure the company. The move comes after Iceberg Research released three reports criticizing Noble Group, which the company describes as inaccurate, unreliable, and misleading. Noble Group claims the reports were calculated to inflict damage rather than facilitate research.

site_title: Singapore's STI up 4.21 points at opening, tracing gains in US, Europe
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.21 points to 3,416.65 at opening on Monday, following gains in US and European markets. Top gainers included UOB, DBS, and Singapore Exchange, with 86.7 million shares changing hands worth S$120.9 million. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains for the STI, ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: Singapore share prices opened higher on Monday with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 4.21 points to 3,416.65 as at 9.08 am, following gains in US and European markets on Friday.

site_title: OPV film spells riches for vTrium
summary: vTrium Energy, a Singapore-based firm, has partnered with German company Heliatek to test the performance of organic photovoltaic (OPV) film technology on building facades in Singapore. The pilot project, funded by JTC Corporation and Spring Singapore, aims to generate over 12 kilowatt peak (KWp) of power. The deal is a boost for vTrium's ambitions to grow its presence in the region and supports Singapore's path towards sustainable city development. The partnership also opens up market opportunities for Heliatek's OPV film in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US court authorises Citigroup to process Argentine bond payments
summary: A US judge has authorised Citigroup to process Argentine bond payments, potentially easing tensions between the bank and Argentina. The ruling allows Citigroup to meet its payment-processing obligations for dollar-denominated bond payments due on March 31 and June 30, and also permits the bank to exit the Argentine custody business. The decision comes after a court battle between Citigroup and a group of hedge funds seeking full payment on Argentina's defaulted sovereign bonds, with the court ruling that Argentina must settle with these funds before continuing to pay interest to other investors.

images.alt_text: Citigroup Inc said it has been authorised by a US judge to process two Argentine debt payments, the bank said, which could ease tensions between the bank and the default-hit nation.

site_title: Tributes pour in for Singapore's former prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, a co-founder of the People's Action Party, has died at 91. The government has declared a period of National Mourning from March 23-29, with State flags flown at half-mast. Tributes poured in from various organizations, including the Labour Movement and the Cabinet Office, praising his dedication to workers' welfare and Singapore's development. The government and ruling party leaders extended condolences to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and his family, vowing to build on his legacy.

site_title: Greek, German leaders to meet amid sour notes
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel will meet Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in Berlin amid strained relations over Greece's debt crisis and austerity measures. The two leaders will discuss potential bailout loans and reforms, amid popular opposition in Germany and bitter historical memories, including Greece's WWII occupation. Merkel maintains that Greece must accept cuts and reforms to receive more bailout loans, while Tsipras accuses Germany of being insensitive to Greece's humanitarian crisis. The meeting aims to improve relations between the two countries and find a solution to Greece's debt crisis.

site_title: Stricken China steel mills look to state to ease exit strategy
summary: China's struggling steel mills may shut down this year due to economic slowdown and environmental enforcement. The government is expected to offer more incentives for loss-making enterprises to close, addressing pollution and overcapacity issues. Excess capacity in the industry stands at around 300 million tonnes, with prices near 20-year lows. Analysts predict the central government will need to take decisive measures to close failing steel firms, potentially affecting China's demand for iron ore. The government has revised a restructuring plan to improve "exit mechanisms" for the sector.

site_title: President Tony Tan pays tribute to Lee Kuan Yew
summary: President Tony Tan Keng Yam paid tribute to Singapore's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, in a condolence letter to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Tan described Lee as the "architect of our modern Republic" and praised his dedication to Singapore's development. Lee's contributions, including establishing a meritocratic society, building public housing estates, and promoting bilingualism, have left a lasting legacy. Tan urged Singaporeans to treasure and build upon this legacy, making Singapore an even better home for future generations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble Group, Cambridge Industrial Trust, S-Reits
summary: Noble Group is suing Hong Kong resident Arnaud Vagner and Enlighten Ace Ltd over alleged conspiracy. RBC Investor Services Trust Singapore Limited will buy a 40% stake in Cambridge SPV1 LLP for S$11 million. Singapore Reits offer value, but concerns include a depreciating Singapore dollar and high leverage among private clients.

site_title: CIT buys remaining stake in Cambridge SPV1 LLP for S$11m
summary: CIT agrees to buy the remaining 40% stake in Cambridge SPV1 LLP for S$11 million from Oxley Projects Pte Ltd. The stake holds an industrial property at 3 Tuas South Avenue 4. This move is part of RBC Investor Services Trust Singapore Limited's capacity as trustee of CIT. The purchase will further solidify CIT's ownership in the property.

site_title: Sinopec profit dips to lowest since '08
summary: China Petroleum & Chemical Corp (Sinopec) reported its lowest annual profit since 2008, with a net income of 46.5 billion yuan, down from 66.1 billion yuan in 2013, due to a 48% drop in Brent crude prices. The decline in oil prices forced explorers to pare investment and lay off workers. Sinopec's sales reached 2.83 trillion yuan, with a mean of 23 analyst estimates compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: Airbus raises A380 seat count to 544 passengers from 525
summary: Airbus has increased the standard number of seats in its A380 superjumbo to 544, up from 525, by adopting a denser cabin configuration with 11 seats in each Economy row. The change aims to boost sales of the plane, which has not found an airline customer since 2013. The revised layout maintains 18-inch wide seats while better utilizing the double-decker's space. This move reflects industry trends towards denser cabin configurations, and Airbus believes it will make the A380 more appealing to customers.

site_title: Sri Lanka's Sirisena forms national govt with opposition
summary: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena formed a national government with the main opposition party, Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), to push through reforms and preserve stability. The move came after his predecessor Mahinda Rajapaksa's rise in popularity. Sirisena gave 26 SLFP members cabinet posts, boosting the government to 77 members. The move is seen as a bid to satisfy Rajapaksa's supporters while also addressing corruption and re-enacting independent commissions abolished by Rajapaksa.

images.alt_text: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena formed a national government incorporating the main opposition party on Sunday in a bid to push through reforms and preserve political stability, a government spokesman said.

site_title: The virtues of a conglomerate
summary: Warren Buffett argues that conglomerates, such as Berkshire Hathaway, bring value to shareholders. In contrast, conglomerates have a poor reputation among investors due to past accounting practices. Buffett explains that conglomerates can allocate capital efficiently, avoid historical industry biases, and profit from buying and selling businesses. Berkshire Hathaway's ability to retain business owners and their teams, and its lack of competition in acquisitions, also provides an advantage. Buffett rejects the idea of spin-offs or sales, as they would eliminate control value and capital allocation benefits.

site_title: China to keep prudent monetary policy
summary: China's central bank chief Zhou Xiaochuan stated that maintaining prudent monetary policy is crucial to support structural reforms, despite recent interest rate cuts. The country aims to make the yuan fully convertible, but excessive looseness could hinder this goal. Zhou emphasized the importance of foreign exchange reserves in managing short-term speculative outflows. China will continue to relax capital controls and reform the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investors scheme to facilitate overseas investments. The central bank maintains its focus on supporting economic growth while ensuring the stability of the financial system.

site_title: Tesla to push software updates to its cars
summary: Tesla will push software updates to its cars, similar to Apple's operating system upgrades, to add capabilities and improve the user interface. CEO Elon Musk announced the plan, which includes a "range assurance application" and enhanced trip planning. The company plans to release version 7.0 of its software, including computerized steering, in a few months. This approach allows Tesla to refresh its cars' software through over-the-air updates, potentially slowing depreciation and making it a unique feature among carmakers.

site_title: Biggest wealth fund ready to buy 'a lot' of Asian real estate
summary: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global is set to invest in Asian real estate, with a focus on Singapore and Tokyo, after scouting for opportunities in the region. The $870 billion fund aims to build a portfolio of properties in 10-15 cities globally, with a target of 5% of its assets in real estate. Tokyo's commercial real estate market is showing signs of recovery, while Singapore's property market is booming due to rising wealth and limited supply. The fund will partner with local investors for the expansion, with its first Asian investments expected in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: BofA alters bylaws on director nomination
summary: Bank of America has altered its bylaws to allow shareholders to nominate up to 20% of the board's directors, following talks with pension funds. This change, known as "proxy access," makes it easier for shareholders to participate in corporate governance. The move is seen as a step towards making boards more responsive to investor concerns. The change was made after discussions with New York City Comptroller Scott Stringer and the California State Teachers' Retirement System, and does not necessarily imply a commitment to holding a binding shareholder vote on certain issues.

site_title: Spain says no cash for Greece until reforms implemented: FT
summary: Spain's Economy Minister Luis de Guindos stated that Greece will not receive cash payments until it implements all agreed-upon reforms. The euro zone will not make any disbursement before the reforms are approved and implemented, according to de Guindos. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras will visit German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday to discuss the reforms. The reforms aim to increase competitiveness, productivity, and proper tax collection, and the Greek government should return to the policies of the previous centre-right government to put Greece back on the growth path.

images.alt_text: The euro zone will not make any cash payment to Greece until it has passed and implemented all the reforms Athens agreed on in February, Spain's Economy Minister Luis de Guindos told the Financial Times on Sunday.

site_title: Dubai builder Arabtec swings to Q4 loss
summary: Dubai's largest construction firm, Arabtec, reported a net loss of 67.4 million dirhams in Q4 2014, missing analyst estimates due to high costs. The company's full-year net profit was 241.6 million dirhams, down from 468.3 million dirhams in 2013. Revenues rose 46% to 8.3 billion dirhams, but non-recurring expenses jumped 75% to 749.9 million dirhams. Arabtec is proposing a 5% bonus share issue and has secured a contract for a US$40 billion housing project in Egypt.

site_title: National mourning declared for Lee Kuan Yew; PM Lee to address nation
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has declared a National Mourning period from March 23 to 29 in honor of founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, who died early on March 22. A private family wake will be held, followed by a lie-in-state at Parliament House, and a State Funeral Service will be held on March 29 at the University Cultural Centre. Condolence books and cards will be available for public tributes, and Prime Minister Lee will address the nation on Monday.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Prime Minister has declared a period of National Mourning from Monday, March 23, to Sunday, March 29. Founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew died early Monday morning.

site_title: China aims to build 3 to 5 giant steel mills by 2025
summary: China plans to build 3-5 giant steel mills by 2025 to boost crude steel output to over 60% of the country's total by 2025 and increase production utilisation rate to over 80% by 2017, aiming to address overcapacity and reduce losses in the steel sector. The move comes after years of efforts to improve industry efficiency, with local governments taking responsibility for enforcing environmental measures to cut overcapacity and ease air pollution.

site_title: Graco to pay US$10m for delay in recall of defective seats
summary: Graco Children's Products agreed to pay US$10 million to settle claims it delayed recalling defective child car seats. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) alleged the company's failure to promptly recall about four million seats with a defective buckle could hinder a child's emergency escape. Graco will pay a US$3 million fine and spend US$7 million developing safety programs.

site_title: Stressed oil firms turn to junk bonds, bankruptcy
summary: US oil companies are experiencing financial stress due to the 60% decline in crude prices since June. This has led to a rise in junk bond issuances and bankruptcies. Quicksilver Resources, a shale producer, filed for bankruptcy protection after missing a bond payment. The financial toll is forcing companies to seek expensive junk bonds to stay afloat, indicating a growing crisis in the petroleum sector.

site_title: Markets mirror performance of greenback
summary: Commodity markets mirrored the performance of the US dollar last week, with a weaker dollar contributing to a surge in oil prices. The US Federal Reserve's decision to drop its pledge to remain patient on raising interest rates led to a fall in the US dollar, making US dollar-priced oil cheaper for holders of rival currencies. Oil prices rose to their highest levels since March 2009, while gold, silver, and copper also saw significant gains, with gold reaching its highest level since December.

site_title: Former US president and leaders from Australia and New Zealand remember Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Former US President George W Bush and leaders from Australia and New Zealand have remembered Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's first elected prime minister, who died at 91. Mr Lee led Singapore from 1959 to 1990, fostering stability and prosperity, and encouraging foreign investment and interracial harmony. His legacy has been praised by world leaders, with Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott calling him a "giant of our region" and New Zealand Prime Minister John Key noting his determination to see Singapore succeed. Mr Lee's son, Lee Hsien Loong, has been prime minister since 2004.

images.alt_text: Lee Kuan Yew was the "father" of modern Singapore who helped bring his country and Southeast Asia into the modern era, according to former US President George W Bush.

site_title: US investors kept buying Singapore shares in Q4
summary: US investors continued to buy Singapore shares in Q4, despite selling US$2.08 billion of US stocks, likely due to a stronger US dollar and weaker Asian share prices. Meanwhile, Singapore-based investors sold US equities to take profits, with prices rising on Wall Street.

site_title: Deutsche Bank revamp plan to hit retail hardest, say sources
summary: Deutsche Bank is planning to restructure its retail operations, which will likely be spun off in a stock market listing, according to sources. The bank's supervisory board favours a proposal to bundle retail operations, including Postbank, and list it separately, as a shift away from its "universal" strategy to focus on investment and merchant banking. The move aims to trim the balance sheet and meet capital requirements, but no decisions have been finalized until the end of April.

site_title: IMF, ADB add to support for China-led lender
summary: China received critical support from the International Monetary Forum (IMF) and Asian Development Bank (ADB) for its goal of establishing the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a US$50 billion lender majority funded by China. At least 27 countries have signed up, and eight more are expected to join by the March 31 deadline. The IMF and ADB expressed willingness to cooperate with the AIIB, and China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei assured that the lender will follow international rules and not bully other members.

site_title: STI likely to open softer this week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) is expected to open softer this week due to market expectations of a dovish statement from the US Federal Reserve during its two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Despite this, the STI jumped on Friday, following a similar rise in Wall Street, and is on track for a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The market's reaction to the Fed's statement was in line with past trends, where rises and falls in the STI preceded those in Wall Street.

site_title: Cracks appearing between Japanese premier, BOJ chief over fiscal target
summary: A rift is emerging between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda over fiscal targets, potentially affecting the impact of "Abenomics" stimulus policies. Kuroda believes Japan cannot afford to delay tax hikes, while Abe focuses on boosting growth to increase tax revenues. This disagreement may blunt the timing of further monetary easing and an eventual end to the massive money-printing program. The disagreement highlights a growing divide between Abe's growth-oriented approach and Kuroda's focus on fiscal discipline.

site_title: Slow to change, Kodak now clings to a future beyond film
summary: Kodak, the film company, is still in business despite emerging from bankruptcy in 2013. CEO Jeff Clarke is focusing on the company's underlying technologies, including those developed during its history. Research and development head Terry Taber, a 34-year employee, is key to Kodak's future, overseeing innovation ideas. The company has reduced its campus size, with 80 buildings demolished and 59 sold, but still employs staff, including Taber, who works on developing new technology. Kodak's future looks promising, with Clarke mining its history for innovative ideas.

site_title: North Koreans take a lesson in business with a high-tech emphasis
summary: North Korean officials spent two weeks in Singapore learning about business concepts such as profit margins, online marketing, and Kickstarter campaigns as part of a training program run by Choson Exchange, a non-governmental organization. The program aims to encourage entrepreneurship and shape the business environment in North Korea. Over 800 North Koreans have been trained since the program's inception in 2009. Analysts debate the effectiveness of such programs, with some arguing they are too small to bring about meaningful change, while others see them as a positive step towards reform.

site_title: Selling its assets may be Bombardier's best option
summary: Bombardier Inc, a US$3.5 billion maker of planes and high-speed trains, is considering asset sales to lift its shares, which have slumped 40% in a year. Analysts predict selling its Learjet division for up to US$750 million or a minority stake in its rail business, valued at US$9 billion. The company aims to reduce debt, which is over twice its market value, and is exploring other initiatives, such as industry consolidation. Selling off non-critical assets could reassure investors and help Bombardier regain investment-grade status.

site_title: Singapore Reits offer value against HK, US peers
summary: Singapore Reits may offer value against HK and US peers due to a depreciating Singapore dollar and concerns over leveraged private clients. Despite the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, Reit income is expected to remain minimal as the impact on interest costs will be spread out over many years. However, the situation is precarious, and investors should be cautious, especially with the benchmark of S$3,000 psf for prime projects looming.

images.alt_text: As The US Federal Reserve prepares to hike interest rates for the first time since 2006, there are differing views on the impact on Singapore real estate investment trusts (Reits).

site_title: Shanmugam to attend Johor Sultan coronation (Amended)
summary: Singapore Minister for Foreign Affairs and Law K Shanmugam, accompanied by his wife, is visiting Johor to attend the coronation of Sultan Ibrahim Sultan Iskandar on Monday. The coronation is a historic event steeped in Johor's royal traditions.

site_title: Lockheed sets sights on new target: climate change
summary: Lockheed Martin, the world's largest defense contractor, has launched initiatives to address climate change, including harnessing energy from tides, purifying water, and ecological fish farming. The company aims to go green and capitalize on growing demand for sustainable solutions. However, its efforts have been met with skepticism from analysts, who question the feasibility of transitioning from defense to energy production. Lockheed's attempts at nuclear fusion and ocean wave energy have been criticized for their early spottiness and lack of scientific backing. Despite this, CEO Marillyn Hewson sees the forays into energy markets as a growth opportunity.

site_title: Euro has best week vs US dollar since Oct 2011
summary: The US dollar experienced its worst weekly performance against the euro in over two years, as investors anticipated a slower interest rate hike. The Federal Reserve downgraded its forecasts for growth, inflation, and interest rates, citing the strengthening US dollar since December. This move is seen as a sign that the Fed is sensitive to large dollar movements and may delay future rate hikes. The euro's strength against other currencies, including the Swiss franc and yen, also contributed to the dollar's decline.

site_title: China yuan level reflects fx supply, demand: central bank researcher
summary: China's yuan level is reflective of foreign exchange supply and demand and is in line with economic fundamentals, according to Lu Lei, head of the People's Bank of China's research bureau. The current level is "basically stable on a reasonable and balanced level," reflecting the real economy, global capital flows, and money supply. This comes after the yuan ended its best week since 2007 due to dollar sales by major state-owned banks. The central bank's policy goal remains to keep the yuan stable.

site_title: Irish milk output set to surge with end to EU caps
summary: Ireland is poised to surge in milk production as the European Union lifts milk production quotas on April 1, allowing the country to increase its dairy output by 50% over the next decade. With 90% of its milk exports going to overseas markets, Ireland's dairy industry is expected to add 10,000 jobs, including 4,000 on farms, by 2020. Ireland's low-cost milk production, thanks to its grassy countryside and outdoor cow grazing, makes it an ideal location for dairy expansion, with some farms already seeing significant increases in milk output.

site_title: Bull market back as global stocks rally 3%, Nasdaq nears record
summary: Global stocks surged 3.2% for the week, pushing the Nasdaq near a record, amid speculation the US Federal Reserve will keep interest rates at zero past mid-year. The MSCI All-Country World Index also rose 3.2%, while the Stoxx Europe 600 Index reached 0.4% from its 2000 high. The rally comes as European policymakers push stimulus, and traders brush off new Trump threats, focusing on US-EU trade talks and economic growth.

site_title: Your first board meeting
summary: Newly appointed directors face a daunting task at their first board meeting, requiring proper preparation and understanding of the company's operations and governance. Key steps include meeting with key management, reading board papers carefully, and actively participating in strategic decisions. Directors must also be mindful of their fiduciary duties, exercise emotional intelligence, and avoid rushing into decisions. A well-prepared director can add value to the board, while a poorly prepared one may struggle with the role, which can have serious consequences.

site_title: Cracks appearing between Abe and Kuroda over fiscal target
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda are at odds over Japan's fiscal target, with Kuroda pushing for deeper spending cuts and Abe focusing on boosting growth to raise tax revenues. The rift has raised concerns that the BOJ may delay its plans to end monetary easing, which has contributed to Japan's massive public debt of 230% of GDP. Kuroda fears that delaying fiscal reform will leave the BOJ with a bloated balance sheet, while Abe is seeking more wiggle-room on spending. The disagreement could blunt the impact of Abe's "Abenomics" stimulus policies.

site_title: US oil industry challenges first federal fracking rules
summary: The US Interior Department has issued new federal fracking regulations requiring drillers on federal land to reveal chemicals used, meet construction standards, and safely dispose of contaminated water. Industry groups, including the Western Energy Alliance, have denounced the rules as costly and unnecessary, and filed a lawsuit challenging them. The regulations are expected to exacerbate a flight from federal and tribal lands to private property, costing local jobs and federal revenue.
