Australia's potential involvement is seen as a significant development, with Beijing indicating it is "open" to Japan and South Korea joining the bank.

site_title: Singapore dollar prospects worst since '98 as Asia losses spread
summary: Singapore's currency is expected to continue its decline, marking its worst performance since 1998, as investor anxiety about the region's economic growth and deflation grows. The currency is being used as an Asian proxy, with traders betting on its further depreciation. The Singapore dollar has fallen 4.4% against the US dollar this year, and its forward points have rallied to levels not seen since the Asian financial crisis, signaling pessimism about the region's prospects. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to further weaken the currency in April to support growth.

site_title: Philippine financial capital in chaos as two mayors stand off
summary: Makati, the Philippines' financial capital, is in chaos as two politicians, Mayor Jejomar Erwin Binay and Deputy Mayor Romulo Pena, claim to be in charge, following the ombudsman's suspension of Binay due to graft allegations. The standoff has forced courts to close and delayed government business. Binay refuses to cede power, while Pena insists he is the "acting mayor". The dispute is ongoing, with hundreds of supporters surrounding Binay at city hall.

images.alt_text: The Philippines' financial capital Makati has been plunged into chaos with two politicians claiming to be mayor, forcing courts to close and delaying government business during a bitter stand-off triggered by graft claims.

site_title: Stock sales on SGX drop 76% in Q1 as IPOs dry up
summary: Stock sales on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) plummeted 76% in Q1 2015, with proceeds from stock sales falling to US$175.6 million, the lowest January-to-March performance since 2003. All proceeds came from follow-on issues, with no initial public offerings (IPOs) taking place. The consumer staples sector dominated the slow quarter, and Singapore-domiciled companies were largely inactive in selling equity. Total equity proceeds from Singapore-based companies fell 81% to US$146.6 million.

site_title: Morgan Stanley won more than 90 Asia prime broker mandates
summary: Morgan Stanley secured over 90 prime brokerage mandates in Asia last year, surpassing rivals due to slower expansion by other banks under tighter capital and liquidity rules. The bank is targeting smaller hedge funds, even those with low returns, to increase its client base. Morgan Stanley's focus on clients with higher returns and investment styles is driven by global Basel III rules and investors directing new inflows to larger hedge funds.

site_title: Brent falls towards US$54, heads for third weekly loss
summary: Brent crude oil prices fell to around $54 a barrel, on track for its third weekly loss, due to oversupply concerns and high US inventory levels. Opec's decision to maintain output levels, as stated by Kuwait's oil minister, has led to a lack of confidence in predicting a floor for oil prices. The US crude inventory numbers have been climbing for 10 straight weeks, reaching their highest levels in 80 years, further weighing on prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closing at 1,803.65, down 5.48 points. The index saw 2.12 billion lots traded, with 325 gains and 471 losses.

site_title: Vietnam proposes allowing foreigners to wholly own listed brokerages
summary: Vietnam's State Securities Commission proposes allowing foreigners to wholly own listed domestic securities firms, aiming to liberalize its capital markets and boost growth. Foreigners could buy shares of brokerages "without limit" as part of the reforms, which are part of a broader effort to modernize the country's equities markets. The proposal is open for public and corporate feedback, but it's unclear if it will be extended to sectors beyond securities.

site_title: OECD urges Greece to tackle bribery of foreign officials
summary: Greece needs to tackle bribes paid to foreign public officials to win overseas contracts, according to the OECD. The organization has urged the Greek government to prioritize fighting foreign bribery, particularly in the export, shipping, and small and medium-sized business sectors. Despite efforts to tackle domestic corruption, Greece has made little progress in detecting foreign bribery cases, with most allegations going undetected. The OECD report comes as Greece's new leftist prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, seeks to present economic reforms to unlock bailout funds and avoid bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: Greece has made some headway in tackling rampant graft at home but needs urgently to crack down on bribes paid to foreign public officials aimed at winning contracts overseas, the OECD said in a report on Friday.

site_title: China central bank survey: Business confidence falls in Q1 vs Q4
summary: China's business confidence fell in Q1 2015 compared to Q4 2014, according to a survey by the People's Bank of China. Fewer households rated consumer prices "unacceptably high" and property prices as "high or unacceptably high" in Q1. Additionally, more bankers believed the economy was cooling in Q1 than in Q4 2014. This decline in confidence may raise pressure on policymakers to address economic concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong property boom poised to end as Fed preps for rate hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by June, potentially reining in Hong Kong's property boom. Industry experts forecast a slump in home prices, with some predicting a 30% drop by end-2016. The local currency's peg to the US dollar will lead to a rise in mortgage repayments, exacerbating a record-high household debt-to-GDP ratio. Major developers, including CK Hutchison Holdings, may face challenges as home prices surge 130% since 2008. Experts advise investors to reduce their weighting to Hong Kong property stocks, citing a wait-and-see attitude among home buyers.

site_title: Singapore: Market follows the FOMC script
summary: The Singapore market followed the US Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) script, trading cautiously ahead of the meeting and rallying after the statement was deemed more dovish than expected. The FOMC dropped the word "patient" from its post-meeting statement, a move that was seen as less hawkish than expected. However, the rally was short-lived, and the market fell sharply on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) only 1.5% up for the week and 1.4% up for the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down 0.38%
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.38% lower on Friday, marking the end of a two-day rally, while Shanghai rose 0.98% to a near seven-year high on hopes of Chinese stimulus measures. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,375.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index reached a new high of 3,617.32. This marks the ninth consecutive session of gains for the market, which has risen over 9% since its last low in mid-May 2008.

site_title: India central bank to talk to lenders about passing rate cuts: deputy
summary: India's central bank plans to discuss with lenders the possibility of passing on interest rate cuts through lower lending rates. Despite the Reserve Bank of India's 50 basis point rate cut this year, most banks have yet to lower their lending rates. The RBI and government are also discussing the creation of an independent public debt management agency. India is better prepared to handle potential US Fed rate hikes.

site_title: China: Stock indexes post biggest weekly gains in 3 months; financials jump
summary: China's stock indexes posted their biggest weekly gains in three months, with the CSI300 index rising 7.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index up 7.25%. Financial shares led the rebound, with the CSI300 Financials subindex jumping nearly 3%. Analysts attribute the gains to resurgent trading volumes, margin financing, and expectations of further monetary easing. Total A-share trading volume in Shanghai was 51.5 billion shares, with Shenzhen volume reaching 29.7 billion shares.

site_title: Singapore assisting Indonesia in investigations of ship detentions
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) clarified that only two out of four detained ships were registered in the country, with the sole Singaporean detained returning to Singapore on March 16. The two detained ships, DM55 Singapore and ASL Glory, were registered in Singapore, while the other two, Sea Sparrow I and BG AST 183, were registered in Belize and Indonesia, respectively. MPA is assisting Indonesia in the investigations of the two incidents involving ships allegedly without proper papers.

site_title: India expected to frontload debt borrowing for first-half of year
summary: India's government is expected to sell up to two-thirds of its planned 6 trillion rupees (US$95.89 billion) in debt issuance in the first half of the year, a move to capitalize on a market rally. Benchmark 10-year bond yields have fallen 10 basis points after the Reserve Bank of India cut interest rates twice, leading traders to expect a frontloading of borrowing. The borrowing plan, set to be finalized on Monday, could result in a higher-than-normal 60-67% of the full-year target.

site_title: SGX to equip teachers with some financial savviness
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is partnering with the National Institute of Education (NIE) to provide financial literacy and investment skills to over 30,000 teachers through a S$1.5 million programme. The six-module programme includes online investment education and access to investor seminars, aiming to equip teachers with knowledge to make informed financial decisions. The programme is part of the Citi-NIE Financial Literacy Hub for Teachers and the SGX Academy's investor education initiatives.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Indonesia's Widodo to visit Japan, China seeking investment
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is set to visit Japan and China, seeking fresh investment to boost Indonesia's slowing growth. During his four-day state visit to Japan, he will meet Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and discuss trade, investment, and defense cooperation. In China, Widodo will meet President Xi Jinping and participate in the Boao Forum for Asia, aiming to strengthen economic ties and cooperation. The visits aim to attract investment and boost Indonesia's economic growth, which slipped to its slowest pace in five years in 2014.

site_title: Euro up after Greece agreement, Shanghai surges again
summary: The euro rose after Greece agreed to provide new reform plans, boosting investor confidence. The euro reached $1.0680 and 129.02 yen, while Shanghai stocks surged 0.98% to a seven-year high. The US dollar's rally fizzled out, and analysts expect the euro to continue its advance as the US Federal Reserve prepares for a rate hike. Global markets, including Tokyo, Sydney, and Hong Kong, also saw gains, while Seoul and Hong Kong declined slightly.

images.alt_text: The euro pushed higher on Friday after Greece's promise to provide new plans to reform its bailout, while Shanghai stocks continued their latest rally towards a seven-year high.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest weekly gain in 10 months
summary: South Korean shares posted their biggest weekly gain in 10 months, rising 2.6% on reduced worries about an early US interest rate increase. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,037.24 points, edging down 0.03% on Friday. The won also rose, ending onshore trade at 1,123.0 per dollar, 0.5% higher than the previous close.

site_title: OECD chief welcomes European participation in China-backed bank
summary: The head of the OECD welcomed major European countries' participation in China-backed infrastructure bank, citing professional and transparent operations. Britain, Germany, France, and Italy have expressed interest in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, contrary to US and Japanese opposition. OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria expressed confidence that the institution would adhere to global standards, and China views this as a tool to meet Asia's infrastructure financing needs. The bank's details remain to be worked out, but Gurria assures comparable standards to other development banks.

site_title: Greece says it will receive funds once reforms are submitted to Eurogroup
summary: Greece has agreed to submit a list of proposed reforms to the Eurogroup in exchange for much-needed funding. The reforms are expected to unlock the release of funds, which have been frozen since the country's international bailout program was extended in February. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras held crisis talks in Brussels with senior European figures, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, to discuss the reforms and secure the aid. Once the reforms are submitted, Greece expects to receive the funding, which is crucial to prevent bankruptcy.

site_title: Update: Suitors circle Noble after commodity trader's US$1.8b market plunge
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-listed commodities trader, has seen its market value slump by US$1.8 billion due to allegations of inflated asset values. Chinese and Japanese companies are exploring potential acquisitions, with China Minmetals Corp, Brightoil Petroleum, and Temasek Holdings mentioned as potential suitors. Founder Richard Elman has expressed a desire to maintain independence, but his stake in the company remains significant, and it's unclear if he would be pressured into a sale.

site_title: MND asks court to appoint independent accountants to protect AHPETC S&CC funds
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has applied to the court to appoint independent accountants to protect government grants disbursed to the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC). The move follows a report by the Auditor-General's Office that found several governance lapses in AHPETC. If granted, the independent accountants will be able to review past payments and recover losses, but will not take over AHPETC's operations. The court's decision will allow MND to disburse S&CC grants for FY14 and FY15 to AHPETC.

images.alt_text: THE Ministry of National Development (MND) has applied to the court to appoint independent accountants to safeguard government grants disbursed to the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC).

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.43%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.43% on Friday, reaching a 15-year high, driven by bargain-hunting. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,560.22, while the Topix index gained 0.30%. Nintendo's shares retreated after surging 30% in two days following its plan to enter the smartphone gaming market. The US stock market also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Eclipse sweeps across Atlantic, visible only from remote islands
summary: A solar eclipse swept across the Atlantic Ocean on March 20, 2015, visible only from remote islands such as the Faroe Islands and Svalbard. The moon's shadow blocked out the sun for a few thousand sky gazers, while millions more in Europe, Africa, and Asia saw a partial celestial show. The eclipse was accompanied by clear skies, making stars and planets visible, and a ring of fire around the sun. The event drew tourists to the affected areas, with hotels sold out in Svalbard, and some experiencing polar bears and frostbite.

images.alt_text: A solar eclipse swept across the Atlantic Ocean on Friday with the moon set to block out the sun for a few thousand sky gazers on remote islands with millions more in Europe, Africa and Asia getting a partial celestial show.

site_title: OECD head says Europe heading for faster recovery, expects 7% China growth in 2015
summary: OECD head Angel Gurria stated that Europe is heading for a faster economic recovery due to low oil prices, low interest rates, and a more competitive euro currency. China is expected to achieve 7% economic growth in 2015, with strong domestic demand preventing deflation. These predictions come as the OECD secretary-general spoke in Beijing.

images.alt_text: Europe is heading towards a faster economic recovery due to low oil prices, low interest rates and a "more competitive" euro currency, the head of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development said in Beijing on Friday.

site_title: Sharp says not considering LCD spin-off as banks seek overhaul
summary: Sharp Corp, a Japanese electronics firm, is not considering spinning off its LCD business as part of a potential bailout plan. The company, facing its third annual loss in four years, is negotiating a rescue plan with banks, including Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ and Mizuho Financial Group. Sharp will likely cut 12% of its workforce and incur costs of over $1.7 billion in a global restructuring. The plan comes after the company warned of its financial struggles and follows its previous bailouts in 2012.

site_title: UOL launches pricing for Botanique at Bartley
summary: UOL Group has released pricing for its 797-unit Botanique at Bartley condominium, with an average price of "a shade below S$1,300 per square foot". The development features one, two, and three-bedroom units, with over 70% priced below S$1 million to ensure affordability. Prices range from S$598,000 to S$1.68 million, with showflats open for public viewing until Saturday. Units are expected to be launched for sale in phases starting early April, with completion anticipated in 2019.

images.alt_text: UOL Group on Friday released the prices for its newest project, the 797-unit Botanique at Bartley, with the average price being "a shade below S$1,300 per square foot".

site_title: Thai central bank cuts 2015 growth, export forecasts
summary: Thailand's central bank reduced its 2015 economic growth forecast to 3.8% from 4.0%, citing slower government spending and weak confidence. The bank also trimmed its export growth projection to 0.8% from 1% and projects 3.9% growth for 2016. The military-led government has struggled to boost the economy, with the country experiencing its weakest growth since 2001 at 0.7% in 2014. The central bank's decision reflects the ongoing challenges faced by Southeast Asia's second-largest economy.

site_title: Japan says difficult to reach Japan-US trade deal without TPA
summary: Japan's Economy Minister Akira Amari stated that reaching a Japan-US trade deal without trade promotion authority (TPA) is difficult. The two countries are working on a bilateral deal for access to agriculture and auto markets, which is crucial for the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement. Amari urged President Obama to make a clear effort on TPA, as the US delay is pushing back the timetable on the TPP. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's visit to the US in late April to early May may be impacted by the uncertainty surrounding TPA.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks ease 0.21% at open; China up
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.21% at open on Friday, easing after a two-day gain, while losses on Wall Street added to selling pressure. The Hang Seng Index dipped to 24,417.53, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.13%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slip on profit-taking; Apple supplier TPK jumps
summary: Taiwan's stocks slipped 0.17% on Friday as cautious trading led to profit-taking, despite a seven-year high on Thursday. Suppliers of Apple Inc, such as TPK Holdings, jumped 4% and Largan Precision added 0.4%. The TAIEX index fell to 9,720.29.

site_title: Australia: Shares take breather after hot rally, set for weekly gain
summary: Australian shares were little changed on Friday, closing 0.04% higher at 5,953.4, ahead of a 2.4% weekly gain, the best in over a month. The rally followed comments from the Federal Reserve that prompted investors to price in a later US interest rate rise start and slower pace. Meanwhile, New Zealand's NZX50 index rose 0.1% to a near-lifetime high, driven by gains in Spark, the nation's dominant telecommunications provider.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.13 points to 1,802. The trading volume was about 233 million lots worth RM68 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 166 to 108.

site_title: Amazon wins approval to test delivery drones outdoors
summary: Amazon has received US federal regulators' approval to test a delivery drone outdoors, marking a significant step in the e-commerce giant's efforts to deliver packages through the air. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) issued an experimental airworthiness certificate to Amazon, allowing it to conduct test flights over private, rural land in Washington state. This approval follows exemptions granted to more than two dozen companies for drone flights, as Amazon pursues its vision of speeding packages to customers. The FAA also granted Amazon an exemption from general flight restrictions on drones.

site_title: Indonesia state pension to lift housing investment fivefold
summary: Indonesia's state pension fund, BPJS Ketenagakerjaan, plans to increase its affordable housing investment by fivefold to 10% of its assets under management, with a goal of building 100,000 homes this year. The move aims to address low-income workers' housing demand and boost growth to 7%. The fund's assets are expected to expand to 233 trillion rupiah by the end of 2015, benefiting construction and cement companies. The government's plan is part of its efforts to address inequality and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Lufthansa cancels 700 flights on Friday due to pilots' strike
summary: Lufthansa cancels 700 flights on Friday due to a pilots' strike, affecting 84,000 passengers. The strike is the third consecutive day, with 50% of its 1,400 scheduled flights grounded. Long-haul services will operate as scheduled, while short- and medium-haul flights will be canceled. The pilots' union is seeking to scrap early retirement arrangements and push back against Lufthansa's expansion of low-cost activities.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains as banks rally
summary: Australian shares rose for a fourth straight session, closing at their highest in over two weeks, with the S&P/ASX 200 index up 0.4% to 5,975.5. The rally was driven by a strong performance from three of the big four local banks, including Commonwealth Bank, which reached an all-time high of A$96.60. The index also rose 2.8% on the week, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index rose 0.2%.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew remains critically ill: PMO
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew remains critically ill, according to a statement from the Prime Minister's Office. His condition worsened due to an infection, with his health declining from Tuesday to Wednesday. Lee was admitted to the Singapore General Hospital on February 5 for severe pneumonia. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed gratitude for public support and good wishes.

site_title: Singapore appoints career diplomat as new ambassador to the Philippines
summary: Singapore has appointed Kok Li Peng as its new ambassador to the Philippines, effective March 30, 2015. She replaces V. P. Hirubalan, who has been appointed as the Deputy Secretary-General of Asean for the Asean Political-Security Community. Ms. Kok has extensive diplomatic experience, including serving as Director-General (ASEAN) from 2012 to 2015 and Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Thailand will keep VAT rate at 7% until Sept 2016: deputy prime minister
summary: Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula announced that the country will maintain its 7% value-added tax (VAT) rate until September 2016 to support the economy. This decision comes after the government initially planned to increase the VAT rate to 8% by the end of September if the economy improved. Meanwhile, Thai exports are expected to grow 2-4% this year, according to the deputy prime minister.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.02% to 19,479.71. The dollar remained steady against the yen after a dovish US Federal Reserve statement on Wednesday. The euro traded at $1.0667 and 128.83 yen. This followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which are set to release GDP data on Friday. Meanwhile, the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: S Korea to increase budget spending, investment to spur recovery
summary: South Korea plans to increase budget spending and investment in the first half of the year to stimulate its weak economic recovery. The move comes after the Bank of Korea lowered interest rates to a record-low 1.75% to boost growth. Finance Minister Choi Kyung-hwan emphasized the need for factors like low interest rates, oil prices, and the exchange rate to support the economy. The decision aims to encourage consumption and investment, which have yet to show signs of improvement.

site_title: Greece to submit new reform list 'in the next few days': talks statement
summary: Greece has agreed to submit a new list of reforms in the coming days to secure bailout funds. The agreement comes after talks between Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and European leaders. Greek authorities will have ownership of the reforms and will present a full list of specific reforms. This follows a key agreement last month to extend Athens's EU-IMF rescue package.

site_title: Japan says could join China-backed AIIB if conditions met
summary: Japan may consider joining the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) if it can guarantee a credible mechanism for providing loans, said Finance Minister Taro Aso. Japan has expressed concerns about governance and environmental safeguards, and has asked the AIIB to screen and approve individual loan cases to ensure debt sustainability. The US has urged countries to think twice before joining the AIIB, citing similar concerns. If conditions are met, Japan may discuss joining the AIIB, but has not yet received a response.

images.alt_text: Japan could consider joining a China-led development bank if it could guarantee a credible mechanism for providing loans, Finance Minister Taro Aso said, the first time Tokyo has signalled it could be part of the institution led by its arch-rival.

site_title: Garuda Indonesia posts net loss of US$373m for 2014
summary: Indonesia's flag carrier Garuda Indonesia reported a net loss of $373 million for 2014, down from a profit of $10.8 million the previous year. The significant decline in earnings is attributed to increased costs and decreased revenue. This loss marks a substantial setback for the airline, which has struggled with operational issues and financial constraints.

site_title: Japan to raise economic assessment for first time in 8 mths: Nikkei
summary: Japan's Cabinet Office is expected to raise its economic assessment for the first time in 8 months, citing improving factory output and corporate earnings. The report is expected to indicate a moderate economic recovery progressing steadily, but with slow improvement in private consumption. Industrial production and corporate earnings are likely to be upgraded, while private consumption is maintained.

site_title: Malaysia already seen losing single-A debt rank in default swaps
summary: Malaysia's credit-default swap market has already reflected Fitch Ratings' potential downgrade, with five-year contracts costing 136 basis points, nearly double the average of 75 for A- rated countries. Fitch considers Malaysia "sits more naturally in the BBB range" due to concerns over state investment company 1Malaysia Development Bhd. and public finances. The government's fiscal deficit target has been raised, and foreign-exchange reserves are at their lowest in over three years, raising concerns of a ratings downgrade, with a 50% chance of a downgrade in the second quarter.

site_title: US-based stock funds attract US$8.6b in latest week: Lipper
summary: US-based stock funds received $8.6 billion in new investments in the week ending March 18, marking their sixth consecutive week of inflows. Domestic-focused funds attracted $5.2 billion, while international funds drew $3.3 billion. Taxable bond funds reversed outflows with $2.3 billion in new cash, while money market funds posted $21 billion in outflows.

images.alt_text: Investors in US-based funds poured roughly US$8.6 billion into stock funds in the week ended March 18, marking their sixth straight week of inflows, data from Thomson Reuters' Lipper service showed on Thursday.

site_title: New industrial plants must meet tighter emissions standards from July 1: NEA
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) in Singapore announced that new industrial plants will have to meet tighter emissions standards starting July 1, 2015. The stricter standards aim to improve air quality and safeguard public health as Singapore strives to achieve its air quality goals for 2020 and beyond. This move is part of the NEA's continued effort to improve air quality in the country.

images.alt_text: NEW industrial plants in Singapore will have to meet tighter industrial emissions standards with effect from July 1, 2015, the National Environment Agency (NEA) said on Friday.
Angela Tan

site_title: Update: Greece in new reform pledge to Europe
summary: Greece agreed to present a new list of reforms to its creditors, aiming to get its bailout back on track after crunch talks with European leaders. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said the process is "back on track" and will complete the EU-IMF rescue programme as fast as possible to free up crucial funds. The deal comes after a key debt deadline, with Greece needing to pay 300 million euros to the IMF and redeem 1.6 billion euros in treasury bills.

site_title: EU agrees Russia sanctions to stay until Ukraine peace terms met
summary: EU leaders agreed to maintain economic sanctions on Russia until a Ukraine peace deal is fully implemented, effectively extending them to the end of 2015. The compromise, reached at an EU summit, maintains EU unity on sanctions and links the duration to the complete implementation of the Minsk agreements. EU leaders also expressed readiness to take further decisions if necessary, threatening additional sanctions. The sanctions, which expire in July, will now be formally decided upon at the next EU summit in June.

site_title: Asian markets mostly lower after Fed-fuelled rally
summary: Asian markets retreated on Friday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul dropping 0.17-0.21% each, while Shanghai gained 0.17%. The rally that occurred after the Federal Reserve's dovish interest rate outlook on Wednesday subsided as profit-takers moved in. The euro received support from news that Greece agreed to give creditors a new list of reforms within days to secure bailout funds. Despite the decline, analysts expect the euro to resume its advance as the Fed prepares for a rate hike.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 fall; Nasdaq up, back near 5,000
summary: The US stock market experienced mixed results on Thursday, with the Dow and S&P 500 falling, while the Nasdaq Composite Index edged up to 4,992.38, nearing the psychologically significant 5,000 level for the second time in 15 years. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 117.16 points (0.65%) to 17,959.03, and the S&P 500 shed 10.23 points (0.49%) to 2,089.27.

site_title: Europe: UK stocks hit record high; eurozone markets hover
summary: The British stock market reached a record high, with London's FTSE 100 index closing at 6,962.32 points, a 0.25% gain. Eurozone stocks, however, remained stable, with the CAC 40 index flat and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index losing 0.20%. The rally follows optimism over the UK government's budget, which has boosted investor confidence. The eurozone markets await news from an EU summit on the Greek debt crisis, which may impact investor sentiment.

site_title: Australian regulator to consider action on mortgages next month
summary: Australia's banking regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), will assess bank mortgage-lending practices next month to ensure emerging risks are contained. APRA is focused on the nation's booming housing market, driven by record-low interest rates and high household debt. The regulator may impose extra capital requirements on higher-risk lenders, but will keep the decision private. Chairman Wayne Byres stated that APRA is ready to take further action if needed to maintain sound lending standards and contain potential risks.

site_title: Cacola Furniture plans to cut par value of shares
summary: Cacola Furniture International plans to cut the par value of its shares to HK$0.01 from HK$0.10, following a fluctuation in share prices over the past six months. The move aims to allow the company to issue shares below the current par value, enabling it to adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China Mobile shares slump following largest profit drop since 1999
summary: China Mobile Ltd reported its largest annual profit drop since 1999, with net income declining 12% to 26.7 billion yuan (S$6 billion) in the fourth quarter. The company's shares in Hong Kong plummeted 3.3%, the largest decline since September, erasing US$9 billion from its market value. This is attributed to rising spending on a new high-speed network. The company's annual results showed a significant drop in profit, affecting its market value and investor sentiment.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower following Dow's dip
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, following a dip in US indices. The Straits Times Index fell 3.49 points to 3,382.67, with a total of 45 million shares worth S$88.5 million changing hands. Noble Group and Ezion Holdings were among the biggest movers, with Noble Group up 4.7% and Ezion Holdings up 2.7%. The dip in US indices followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: A fragmented history of art
summary: Artist Fyerool Darma's first solo exhibition, "Moyang," explores how people remember and recall fragments of history. The exhibition, which translates to "ancestors" in Malay, reflects on the fragmented nature of Singapore's history, particularly during the British colonial era. The show features works that capture the remnants of the past, highlighting the limited knowledge of ancient Singapore's history, such as that of Malay chronicler Munshi Abdullah. The exhibition aims to spark conversation about how we remember and recall the past.

site_title: Cathay sticks to fuel price shield despite HK$911m hedging loss
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd reported a loss of HK$911 million from fuel hedges in 2014, with an additional HK$12.5 billion in unrealised losses. Despite this, CEO Ivan Chu plans to stick with the current hedging position, citing a potential net benefit if oil prices drop. Chu stated that the current hedging position will be positive to the business, even without hedging, as lower fuel prices would help. This decision aims to protect the airline from rising fuel costs.

site_title: Genting HK's FY14 earnings fall, recommends final dividend of US$0.01/share
summary: Genting Hong Kong reported a net profit of US$384.48 million for FY14, down from US$552.39 million in the previous year. Earnings per share decreased to 4.79 US cents, while gaming revenue rose 10.5% to US$349 million. Passenger ticket revenue fell 15.6% to US$134.8 million. The company's "others" segment increased due to dividend income and aviation revenue. Genting HK maintained a net cash position of US$260.1 million and recommended a final dividend of US$0.01 per share.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Swiss, EU initial pact to swap tax data from 2018
summary: Switzerland and the European Union have agreed to automatically exchange tax data on citizens from 2018, ending years of fighting over tracking down cross-border tax cheats. The pact reflects new global standards for exchanging information on income from dividends, interest payments, and license fees. The plan is to start collecting data in 2017, then exchange it with EU member countries from 2018, with talks ongoing about swapping data with the US and other countries. This move aims to increase tax transparency and revenue collection for EU countries.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers have issued buy recommendations for ComfortDelGro and Venture Corporation. ComfortDelGro's stock is supported at S$19.20 and could break above S$20.30, suggesting further upside. Venture's stock is in five-year-high territory, driven by structural trends in the enterprise and industrial solutions sector. The company is expected to see low-double-digit earnings per share growth for FY2015E-2017E, with a target price of S$10.25. The public transportation sector is overweight, with ComfortDelGro being the sector top pick due to its strong balance sheet and growth strategy.

site_title: A bad idea, shoddily executed
summary: A 2015 film "Kidnapping Freddy Heineken" based on the 1983 abduction of the Heineken heir is panned for its uninteresting and uninspired portrayal of the true-crime events. Director Daniel Alfredson fails to recreate the tension of his previous work, "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" trilogy. The film's poor execution, lack of backstory, and unrealistic accents lead to a "messy failure" with an illogical conclusion, resulting in a mediocre rating of C- from critics.

site_title: Lippo continues e-commerce push with payment service
summary: Lippo Group, an Indonesian conglomerate, plans to launch payment, chat, and other online services early next year as part of its e-commerce push. The company has earmarked $500 million for a new online department store and will invest an additional $100 million in services in the first quarter of 2016. Lippo owns the infrastructure necessary for e-commerce, including fibre optic cables and data centers, and aims to focus on the flow of money, data, and merchandise. A significant investment in a payment service similar to PayPal is planned, along with data services that could include chat and news functions.

site_title: Suitably exotic but not that foreign this time around
summary: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, a sequel to the 2012 sleeper hit, follows a group of British retirees as they navigate life in India. The film, featuring an all-star ensemble including Judi Dench, Maggie Smith, and Richard Gere, maintains a similar tone to the original, with romance, mystery, and humor at its core. The Marigold Hotel's management, led by Sonny and Muriel, continues to provide a sense of well-being and purpose for its residents. The film's lighthearted tone and colorful setting make for an enjoyable watch, despite some predictable subplots.

site_title: Ranked 3rd among Bordeaux, but so glorious
summary: A 2001 Chateau Lafleur Pomerol, a third-place Bordeaux, is now ready to drink, but its full potential won't be reached until 4-5 years. The wine's minerality and concentration of ripe fruit are notable, but it still needs time to open up. In contrast, a 2002 Drouhin Beaune 1er cru Clos des Mouches is described as "glorious" and "delicate and fine," with a refined, lightly sweet flavor. A 2009 La Fleur de Bouard Pomerol is also praised for its freshness, complexity, and drinkability, making it a "very useful stand-by" at an affordable price.

site_title: HK's art scene rise looks unstoppable
summary: Hong Kong's art scene continues to rise in influence and commercial value, with the city's art market leading the world in 2014 with $5.6 billion in sales. Art Basel Hong Kong (ABHK) saw significant growth, with Asian art sales making up a larger share of the top sales, and smaller Asian galleries expanding their presence. The fair's new director, Adeline Ooi, aims to increase interest in Asian art content. The art scene is also expanding beyond ABHK, with new galleries and art spaces opening, and a new rival fair, Art Central, launched.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Siemens' energy woes hurt profitability, sales
summary: Siemens' shares fell 3.8% in Frankfurt trading after CEO Joe Kaeser warned of operational difficulties at the power business, hurting profit and sales in the second quarter. The company predicts a "moderate organic revenue decline" due to the oil price slump. Kaeser has spent billions on acquisitions to focus on the power business, but these efforts are now being impacted by declining energy revenues. The company is cutting 9,000 jobs to save costs by 2017.

site_title: Yahoo seen cutting up to 300 jobs as China office closes
summary: Yahoo is closing its China office, eliminating 200-300 jobs, as part of its efforts to trim expenses and improve collaboration. The move comes after the company sold its Chinese operations to Alibaba Group in 2005 and is seen as a response to declining revenue growth since 2008. The closure is not related to government concerns and is part of a series of retrenchments by US technology companies operating in China. This move follows previous cuts in other Yahoo offices, including Canada and India, and is part of the company's efforts to focus on efficiency and cost-cutting measures.

site_title: London says it'll regulate digital money
summary: The UK government announced plans to regulate digital currencies, including bitcoin, for the first time by applying anti-money laundering rules to exchanges. This move is seen as a step towards supporting innovation and preventing criminal use of digital currencies. The proposals, to be consulted on in the next Parliament, are expected to provide legitimacy without stifling innovation. The move comes as bitcoin's supporters argue that the technology behind it could be revolutionary, and major companies like IBM are considering adopting it for digital payments.

site_title: Catalist IPO activity and market value have been growing: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reported growing Catalist IPO activity and market value. Since its launch in 2008, 88 companies have joined Catalist, with 70% being homegrown Singaporean companies. 16 of these companies have successfully transferred to the Mainboard, demonstrating the effectiveness of the sponsor-supervised regulatory regime. Catalist companies are not subject to the S$0.20 minimum trading price requirement, and share consolidation is a cost-effective solution for Mainboard companies. SGX remains committed to supporting entrepreneurs and small and medium-sized enterprises, with plans to launch more activities in support of Catalist companies in the coming months.

site_title: Thailand's outdated tech sector casts cloud over economy
summary: Thailand's electronics industry is facing a significant decline, with production of goods such as televisions and radios down 38% year on year. The country's manufacturing index has fallen for 22 consecutive months, raising concerns about its economic slowdown. Thailand's electronics sector is struggling to adapt to modern technology and is being outcompeted by lower-cost neighbors such as Vietnam, which has seen its exports rise by 80% in the past five years. The decline is attributed to a structural competitiveness problem, and economists warn that it may impact Thailand's long-term growth rate.

site_title: BOA must allow shareholder vote on spin-off
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has ruled that Bank of America (BOA) must allow shareholders to vote on a proposal to consider spinning off its investment banking business, following a similar rejection of similar resolutions by the SEC last year. The proposal, filed by a Bank of America shareholder, aims to create a separate sub-committee to develop a plan for divesting non-core banking activities. BOA's board has stated it will respond to the proposal in its proxy statement, but has expressed skepticism about the need for a separate sub-committee.

site_title: Regional training centre for energy policymakers coming up in Singapore
summary: Singapore will host the Centre of Excellence for Renewable Energy, a first-of-its-kind regional training centre for energy policymakers, with funding support from the Asian Development Bank. The centre, run by the Sustainable Energy Association of Singapore, will train up to 150 policymakers annually and aims to build capabilities and drive partnerships in clean and renewable energy. The initiative is expected to create market opportunities and access to sustainable projects in the region, and will involve partnerships with industry players to educate and train policymakers.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Nominations open for Business China Awards 2015
summary: Nominations are open for the 2015 Business China Awards, with three categories: Excellence Award, Young Achiever Award, and Enterprise Award. The awards aim to recognize individuals and organizations that have made significant contributions to strengthening Singapore-China relations and promoting bilingualism and biculturalism. The deadline for nominations is April 20. Last year's winners included Liu Thai Ker, the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and local singer-songwriter JJ Lin.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: REACH's post-Budget poll gives snapshot of public reaction
summary: A post-Budget poll conducted by REACH, a Ministry of Communications and Information unit, gathered public reaction to key Budget announcements. The poll, which included dialogues, radio talk shows, and engagement exercises, aimed to understand the public's sentiment on the Budget initiatives. REACH defended its poll methodology, stating that questions were properly framed and included quantifiers to assess the extent of respondents' opinions. The detailed poll results are available on the REACH website.

site_title: New UK payments watchdog aims to break Big 5's dominance
summary: The UK's new Payments Systems Regulator (PSR) aims to break the dominance of the "Big Five" lenders by introducing changes to improve access to payment systems, starting with "meaningful" changes in 2015. The regulator will oversee the £75 trillion payments sector, making it easier and cheaper for new challenger banks to use the existing system. The PSR has the power to force divestments and impose fines for breaches, with a twin-track approach focusing on quick fixes and fundamental changes. The regulator's goal is to increase competition and boost innovation in the payments industry.

site_title: Overseas investors load up on Japanese government bonds
summary: Foreign investors are buying large amounts of Japanese government bonds, adding three times more than local insurers, with a record 45.4 trillion yen held as of December 31. This is driven by attractive swap rates and the weak yen, which provides a discount. Investors are also seeking higher yields, with a preference for longer maturities, and are expecting the Japanese yield spread to narrow further. The Bank of Japan's stimulus is expected to continue, with 23 out of 34 economists predicting expansion by the end of October.

images.alt_text: The yen tumbled to a seven-and-a- half-year low of 122.03 to the greenback last week and traded at 119.92 at 10.33 am in Tokyo on Thursday.

site_title: Gold price-setting: technology takes over from a century of tradition
summary: The London Bullion Market Association (LBMA) will begin using electronic auctions for gold price-setting on Friday, marking the end of a century-long tradition of phone-based agreements between four banks. This move aims to increase transparency in the $18 trillion global gold market. The change follows similar shifts in the silver, platinum, and palladium markets, which transitioned to electronic auctions last year. The shift is expected to enhance market efficiency and reduce price volatility.

site_title: Former Australian leader Malcolm Fraser dead at 84: office
summary: Former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, 84, died peacefully on March 20, 2015, after a brief illness. He served as the nation's leader from 1975 to 1983, following a constitutional crisis in which Sir John Kerr dismissed Gough Whitlam. Fraser's office announced his passing, asking for respect and privacy for his family at a difficult time.

images.alt_text: Former Australian prime minister Malcolm Fraser (center), who served as the nation's leader from 1975 until 1983, died on Friday after a short illness at the age of 84, his office said.

site_title: 100,000 lay-offs so far in the oil industry and counting
summary: The oil industry is experiencing a significant wave of layoffs, with over 100,000 jobs lost so far, as oil prices remain low. Companies such as Husky Energy, Suncor, and Royal Dutch Shell have cut thousands of jobs, including construction workers and employees, due to decreased capital expenditures. Industry recruiters warn that companies cutting too deep may pressure older workers to retire early, leading to a talent gap and exacerbating the crisis. The US is expected to feel the pain, with up to 75,000 jobs potentially lost in Houston, where the hydrocarbon capital is a major hub.

images.alt_text: In the US, the worst pain is, not shockingly, expected to be felt in Houston. The hydrocarbon capital of the world could lose 75,000 jobs.

site_title: Discovery Channel founder starts non-fiction video streaming service
summary: Discovery Channel founder John Hendricks launched CuriosityStream, a non-fiction video streaming service, on March 19, 2015. The ad-free service offers a range of science, technology, and history content, including documentaries and interviews with celebrities. CuriosityStream costs $3/month for standard resolution and $6/month for high-definition, with plans to expand worldwide over five years. Hendricks aims to dominate the non-fiction category in on-demand, online video, competing with Netflix, Hulu, and other streaming services.

images.alt_text: Mr Hendricks says that the service CuriosityStream fulfilled his long-held desire to deliver programming that people can watch whenever they want.

site_title: A*Star gets S$380m of R&D investment from industry
summary: Singapore's Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) has secured S$380 million in industry investment for over 1,700 projects in the first nine months of fiscal 2014. This growth is attributed to public-private partnerships, startups, and a steady pipeline of scientific talent. A*Star aims to remain innovative and competitive by focusing on productivity-driven growth and collaboration with local and multinational enterprises.

site_title: Motor insurers' underwriting profit hits record S$149.5m in 2014
summary: Singapore motor insurers achieved a record underwriting profit of S$149.5 million in 2014, a 153% increase from the previous year, with four consecutive years of profitability. The General Insurance Association of Singapore attributes the gain to adjustments in loss-reserving from a few insurers.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew remains critically ill
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew remains critically ill in the ICU of Singapore General Hospital, with his condition deteriorating further. He was hospitalized on February 5 for severe pneumonia. The Prime Minister's Office confirmed the update on Thursday.

site_title: Fed signals slow pace of tightening as it opens door to rate rise
summary: The US Federal Reserve signaled a slow pace of interest-rate tightening, opening the door to a potential rate increase for the first time in almost a decade. Chair Janet Yellen stated that policy makers will be data-dependent, not date-dependent, and reduced forecasts for economic growth and inflation. The median estimate for the federal funds rate at the end of 2015 fell to 0.625%, and the 2016 estimate dropped to 1.875%. The likelihood of a rate rise in September increased to 39% from 55% previously.

site_title: Eclipse to put unprecedented strain on Europe's power grid
summary: A total solar eclipse on Friday will put unprecedented strain on Europe's power grid, as the moon blocks about 80% of the sun's light across the continent. Thousands of solar panels in Germany will briefly shut down, forcing grid operators to switch to natural-gas and coal plants. The event will test the grid's ability to manage the loss of renewable energy, with potential power cuts and higher prices if the system fails to balance. European grid companies are preparing for the event, with close communication and power reserves to mitigate the impact.

images.alt_text: A boy in France testing special glasses for watching a partial eclipse. The moon will cross in front of the sun, blocking about 80 per cent of its light across Europe from 8am to 11am London time.

site_title: Ezion at lowest since Nov 2012 as O&M woes spook investors
summary: Ezion's shares plummeted 5.1% to S$0.94, their lowest level since November 2012, despite an analyst report saying the stock is oversold and a good buy. Investors may have been spooked by concerns over contract terminations and spending cuts in the offshore and marine (O&M) sector, but analysts believe Ezion's contract renewal rates will hold steady. The company's liftboats have locked-in contracts for three to seven years with major oil companies, and cancellations are unlikely.

site_title: Yields on Malaysia's Islamic bonds slide
summary: Malaysia's long-term Islamic bond yields have fallen, dropping 35 basis points for 15-year local currency sovereign sukuk and 22 basis points for 2017 notes. This is a boost for Prime Minister Najib Razak's development program amid a fiscal deficit. Yields have fallen twice as fast as those on shorter-dated debt, making it a favorable time for companies to sell long-term notes. The government has raised its 2015 fiscal deficit target to 3.2% of GDP, and borrowing costs for infrastructure projects may fall further as speculation of interest rate cuts in Malaysia and Europe offsets concerns about a US rate hike.

site_title: Global carmakers manoeuvre China's political seesaw
summary: China's central government has cracked down on foreign carmakers, accusing Volkswagen, Tata Motors, Daimler, and Nissan of selling defective vehicles and overcharging consumers. The crackdown is part of a broader effort to extract concessions from major carmakers, with China leveraging its market to score populist points. The government's anti-corruption campaign is also aimed at the allies of former president Jiang Zemin, who was close to the country's largest carmakers. The latest target is Xu Jianyi, chairman of FAW Group, as the country's car industry faces overcapacity and consolidation.

site_title: US airlines seek to limit flights of Gulf carriers
summary: US airlines, including Delta Air Lines, are seeking new limits on flights by Gulf carriers, citing unfair competition. Delta CEO Richard Anderson asked the Obama administration to restrict Emirates, Qatar Airways, and Etihad Airways from flights not stopping or starting in the UAE or Qatar. This could include bars on expanding US services. The move aims to address concerns over unfair market access and impact US carriers' financials.

site_title: Swiss, EU ink deal to swap tax data from 2018
summary: Switzerland and the European Union have signed a deal to automatically exchange tax data on citizens from 2018, aiming to combat tax evasion. The agreement, subject to a potential referendum in Switzerland, reflects new global standards on exchanging information about income. EU citizens can no longer stash wealth in Swiss accounts to hide it from tax authorities. The plan is to start collecting data in 2017 and exchange it with EU member countries from the next year.

site_title: The lighter side of Rufus Wainwright
summary: Rufus Wainwright performed a 100-minute solo show at the Esplanade Theatre, playing 22 "non-hits" from his latest compilation, Vibrate. The 41-year-old musician showcased his intricate baroque pop style on grand piano and acoustic guitar, including unreleased material and a new composition, Lucy Blue. Despite a disappointing turnout, Wainwright remains undeterred, acknowledging his cult status and focusing on his art rather than commercial success. His self-deprecating humor and creative genius were on full display, highlighting his musical heritage from his folk-singer parents.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Sharp to cut around 6,000 jobs: source
summary: Sharp Corp, Japan's loss-making electronics firm, plans to cut around 6,000 jobs, about 10% of its workforce, in a global restructuring costing over 200 billion yen (S$2.3 billion). The job cuts will include 3,000 in Japan and 3,000 overseas, amid weak sales of smartphone screens and an unexpected comeback by rival Japan Display Inc. Sharp expects to post its third annual net loss in four years, following a previous forecast of a 30 billion yen net loss.

site_title: Osborne baits voters with upbeat view of economy ahead of May 7
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne presented a budget that aims to boost consumer spending and boost the economy ahead of the May 7 general election. He forecasts a 2.5% real growth this year, driven by quantitative easing and a depreciation of the sterling. However, critics argue that the economy remains unbalanced and reliant on consumer spending, with a government debt-to-GDP ratio of 80%. Economists warn that the UK economy is on a "knife edge" and that foreign investors are cautious due to the projected budget deficit and balance of payments current account deficit.

site_title: Petronas: Bond proceeds for capex, possible M&A
summary: Petronas plans to use the US$5 billion raised in its Asia's largest bond offering for corporate expenses and possible acquisitions. The state-owned energy firm posted its first quarterly loss in at least five years due to the slump in global oil prices. Petronas declined to provide details about its potential merger and acquisition plans.

site_title: In brief
summary: KepCorp's stake in Keppel Land has risen to 87.2%, nearing the 90% threshold needed to delist the company. Meanwhile, two firms plan a 10-into-1 share consolidation to meet the Singapore Exchange's S$0.20 trading price requirement. This move aims to increase institutional investor interest and research coverage, making the consolidated shares more attractive to investors.

site_title: BT clinches international award for newspaper redesign
summary: The Business Times (BT) won the Award of Excellence from the Society of News Design for its newspaper redesign, which was part of a major relaunch of Singapore's sole financial daily. The redesign, completed last October, introduced wider columns, distinct fonts, and extensive use of data and information graphics. The SND praised the redesign for its clarity, ease of use, and innovative approach. The redesign was carried over to the website and mobile apps, featuring a responsive design that adapts to different screens.

site_title: Fed has little about which to be patient
summary: The Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee has dropped the word "patient" from its policy statement, indicating it may soon consider raising the federal funds rate. The committee now expects domestic GDP growth to be less than 3% a year indefinitely, down from previous projections. Most members forecast GDP growth at 2.3-2.7% this year and next, with overnight rates rising to 0.625% by year-end. The Fed's narrow projections and central tendency estimates make it vulnerable to changes in the economy, suggesting it has little to be patient about.

site_title: 1MDB may scrap energy IPO, opt for direct sale instead
summary: TROUBLED 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) may scrap its long-delayed initial public offering (IPO) of its energy assets, opting for a direct sale instead, to tackle its debt woes. The company's energy arm, Edra Global Energy, had planned to raise up to $3 billion through the IPO, but concerns over the controversy surrounding 1MDB may lead to a swifter disposal of its 16 power and desalination plants. A direct sale is deemed a faster solution to overcome the company's debt dilemma, which stands at $15.7 billion.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Singtel ends ties with Gushcloud and employee over marketing drive
summary: Singtel Group terminated its services with social media agency Gushcloud amid a controversy surrounding a marketing campaign that discredited rival telcos M1 and StarHub. The campaign allegedly instructed bloggers to bad-mouth the companies to promote a Singtel youth plan. CEO Chua Sock Koong apologized to M1 and StarHub, stating Singtel does not condone negative campaigns. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore is investigating the matter, while StarHub is exploring legal action against Singtel.

site_title: City buzz
summary: No relevant article summary found, provided article appears to be a list of past articles and does not contain a specific article to summarize.

site_title: Brave new selections that stretch the boundaries
summary: Two festivals, the Francophonie Festival and the Southeast Asian Film Festival (SEAFF), are premiering diverse and edgy works in Singapore. The Francophonie Festival, held at Alliance Française de Singapour, showcases French-language films, stand-up comedy, and concerts, featuring local and international artists. SEAFF, running from April 10 to May 3, includes 20 films and documentaries from Indonesia, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam, with a focus on independent movie-making. The festivals aim to build cultural bridges and promote cooperation through diverse projects.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Dovish Fed helps nudge STI 0.73% higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.73% to 3,386.16 on Thursday, driven by gains in Singtel, OCBC, and Hongkong Land, as well as a firm session in Hong Kong and Europe. Analysts attribute the rebound to short-covering, with some speculating that the market-friendly Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting on interest rates was the trigger. Despite the rally, many analysts believe it may not last beyond a day or two.

site_title: Philly Fed business index falls for 4th straight month
summary: The Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank's business activity index fell to 5.0 in March, its lowest level in over a year, marking the fourth straight month of decline. This indicates a slowdown in the US manufacturing sector, which is seen as a leading indicator of the national economy. The index, which measures growth in factory activity, had previously reached its highest level since 1993 in November. Economists had forecast an increase to 7.1.

site_title: Ssangyong suspends car exports to Russia on weak rouble
summary: South Korea's Ssangyong Motor has suspended car exports to Russia due to the weak rouble and prolonged economic slump. The company, owned by Mahindra and Mahindra, has no plans to resume shipments until the rouble stabilizes. Instead, it will boost sales to Europe and China. This decision follows other global carmakers, as the plunging rouble affects demand in major export markets. Ssangyong aims to diversify its sales channels to mitigate the impact of the economic downturn.

site_title: Cordea Savills' purchase of SEB Asset Management to create S$3b AUM in Asia-Pac
summary: Cordea Savills is acquiring SEB Asset Management AG for up to 21.5 million euros (S$31.6 million) to create a Singapore-based real estate investment platform with approximately S$3 billion (2 billion euros) assets under management. The combined entity will have a global AUM of 17 billion euros. The acquisition aims to capitalize on long-term investment opportunities in key Asian markets, particularly Japan's office sector, and will enable the company to deliver attractive products to investors.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China welcomes US role in infrastructure bank
summary: China's Deputy Finance Minister Shi Yaobin has welcomed the US role in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), stating the new bank will mainly support other international institutions and adopt their good practices. This comes after major European powers, including France, Germany, and Italy, announced their decision to join the AIIB. The US perceives the AIIB as a threat to the World Bank, but Shi emphasized that the AIIB will not replace existing institutions. China's move is seen as a diplomatic effort to expand its global influence and economic presence.

site_title: Singapore dollar in knee-jerk rally over Fed 'relief'
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) experienced a brief relief rally after the US Federal Reserve's dovish statement on interest rate hikes, with the currency reaching a high of S$1.37 before weakening to S$1.38. However, analysts expect the underlying strength of the US dollar to remain intact, leading to further weakness of the SGD and continued rise in local interest rates. The three-month Sibor increased to 0.939%, while the three-month SOR eased marginally to 1.055%. Most analysts expect the Fed to downsize its growth forecast and lower interest rates, which could lead to more volatility in the currency and interest rates.

site_title: Paying a musical tribute to lost classics
summary: Two Singapore orchestras will pay tribute to local composers. The Braddell Heights Symphony Orchestra will perform Leong Yoon Pin's lost Symphony No 2, while the Philharmonic Winds will showcase Zechariah Goh Toh Chai's work and feature Roald Dahl poems. The performances mark the debut of the newly formed Philharmonic Chamber Winds and aim to introduce Leong's music to a new generation of listeners.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: S&P upgrades BOC Aviation to A- rating
summary: S&P upgraded BOC Aviation's long-term credit rating to A- from BBB, citing a stable outlook due to the company's strategic importance to Bank of China and expected indirect government support. The stable outlook also reflects BOC Aviation's sound market share, competitive position, and manageable financial risk profile. The company's liquidity is viewed as adequate, with sufficient liquidity sources and asset sales contributing to flexibility.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Won leads Asian gains as Fed signals slower tightening
summary: Asian currencies rose after the Federal Reserve signaled slower US interest-rate increases. The won led gains, rising 1.1% to 1,117.24 a dollar, while Indonesia's rupiah rose 0.9%. China's yuan strengthened 0.53% to 6.1961 a dollar, completing its biggest three-day rally since 2007. The Bank of Korea vowed to monitor financial and currency-market volatility and take measures if needed.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us to give up flagship Times Square store
summary: Toys 'R' Us is set to leave its flagship store in New York's Times Square early next year due to a rent increase. The 110,000-sq-ft store, which has been a prominent tourist attraction, will be broken up into smaller spaces. The move reflects the rapid growth of rents in the Times Square area, driven by retailers seeking access to tourist traffic. The toy chain will not sign a new lease, and its future location is uncertain, although it may relocate to a nearby Marriott Marquis Hotel.

site_title: IMF official flags rewards and risks of closer Asean integration
summary: IMF official David Lipton warns that Asean's closer economic integration poses both opportunities and risks, particularly in volatile financial markets. The region's growth and productivity are expected to rise, but risks include rapid credit growth, geopolitical tensions, and uncertainty about interest rates in advanced economies. Lipton advises Asean to adopt a measured and gradual approach to integration, citing Europe's experience as a cautionary tale. Despite risks, Asean's recent performance has been impressive, with growth averaging 6.5% annually since the 2008 crisis.

site_title: Asian markets get lift from dovish Fed
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance, with the MSCI All-Country Asia ex-Japan index rising 0.4%. The Fed's report showed a cut in its views on interest rate increases, with median views shaved to 0.625% by end-2015. However, HSBC noted that this relief did not improve the fundamental outlook for emerging markets, citing poor trade cycles, erratic capital flows, and structural challenges. Government bond yields fell, and the US dollar lost ground against Asian currencies, with some analysts predicting potential rate cuts by regional central banks.

site_title: Cleantech gains momentum in building a more sustainable world
summary: Cleantech is gaining momentum worldwide, with Asia-Pacific countries leading the way. Renewable energy consumption is on the rise, driven by investments from economic giants India and China. Singapore is also investing heavily in cleantech, with a projected contribution of S$3.4 billion to its GDP by 2015. The country's revised Sustainable Singapore Blueprint 2015 outlines a vision for sustainable development, including creating sustainable housing estates and reducing energy consumption. Cleantech innovations are expected to improve consumer convenience, increase business efficiency, and reduce costs, with applications in areas such as energy storage, smart homes, and sustainable building design.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard on track to separate businesses in November
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) is set to split into two separate companies, HP Enterprise and HP Inc, in November. HP Enterprise will focus on software, services, and hardware for businesses, while HP Inc will sell personal computers and printers. The split will be led by CEO Meg Whitman and Dion Weisler, respectively. The move aims to make HP more responsive to corporate customers and will result in two firms with distinct characteristics. The separation is expected to cost around $2 billion over two years, with $1.3 billion in charges for fiscal 2015.

site_title: India's record forex war chest set for Fed rate hike test
summary: India has built record foreign exchange reserves of nearly $340 billion, largely due to the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike, which could impact emerging economies. Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan has been actively buying US dollars to insulate the economy from capital flight, and has accumulated enough reserves to face a US rate hike. The central bank's efforts have helped stem foreign selling and narrow the country's current account deficit, but Rajan considers foreign capital inflows as a double-edged sword, leaving the RBI at the whim of global investors.

site_title: Fancy a 'float' so your cares drift away?
summary: In Singapore, a floating pod business, Palm Avenue Float Club, offers sensory deprivation sessions in a saltwater tank to induce a meditative state. Founded by Derrick Ong in 2014, the business has seen a significant increase in clients, with over 45 sessions per week. Clients, mostly high-stress professionals, report improved mental clarity and a sense of calm after the sessions. Ong, who initially struggled with floating but later became a proponent, believes the experience can change a person's outlook on life and provide clarity.

images.alt_text: Derrick Ong (above), the 28-year-old owner of the Palm Avenue Float Club, says floating in a pod of heavily-salted water has given him focus, drive, a sense of calm and clarity of thought. Don't worry about drowning in the pod, he adds, as it takes effort even to sink.

Derrick Ong, the 28-year-old owner of the Palm Avenue Float Club, says floating in a pod of heavily-salted water (above) has given him focus, drive, a sense of calm and clarity of thought. Don't worry about drowning in the pod, he adds, as it takes effort even to sink.

site_title: Loan default by 1MDB unlikely to rock KL banking sector: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings has stated that 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB)'s estimated RM42 billion debt is manageable for Malaysia's banking sector, as it represents about 3% of loans and 5% of system equity. The country's central bank also believes its banking sector has a high degree of resilience and can withstand defaults. Meanwhile, 1MDB is moving forward with developing a retail-led project in Kuala Lumpur's Tun Razak Exchange (TRX), with a projected gross development value of RM8 billion.

site_title: Indian farmers upset by Modi's land overhaul
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's proposed land overhaul bill, which would make it easier for private companies to obtain property, has sparked widespread opposition from farmers. The bill, which has passed through the Lower House, faces a tough challenge in the Upper House, where opposition parties have vowed to block it. The move is seen as a major hurdle to investing in India, with an estimated backlog of $392 billion in stalled projects. Farmers are demanding that at least 50% of property holders agree to acquisitions, and that barren land is prioritized for projects.

site_title: Starbucks to debut delivery in Seattle, Manhattan this year
summary: Starbucks plans to launch delivery services in Seattle and Manhattan later this year, partnering with Postmates in Seattle and using its own "green apron" delivery service in Manhattan. The company will also expand mobile order and pay services across the US. Starbucks' shares have risen 25% over the past year and the company announced a two-for-one stock split, which is expected to modestly increase its earnings forecast. The move is part of the company's efforts to increase sales and connect with young, tech-savvy consumers, as US restaurant chains turn to technology to stay competitive.

site_title: Israel faces prospect of a messy coalition
summary: Israel's parliamentary elections ended in a deadlock between the ruling right-wing Likud party and the center-left Zionist Camp opposition, with both parties potentially having around 27-28 seats. However, a narrow Likud-led bloc may not survive for more than a few months due to domestic and international challenges, including economic and national security issues. A grand coalition between Likud and Zionist Camp, with Netanyahu and Herzog rotating as prime minister, is seen as a possible solution, as it would offer a more centrist and moderate government preferred by Washington.

site_title: Facebook wants to crash the online payments party
summary: Facebook has introduced a new feature allowing users to send money to friends via its mobile Messenger app. This move is a response to the growing demand for in-app payments, following the footsteps of messaging apps like WeChat and KakaoTalk. Facebook's decision to enter the online payments market is led by David Marcus, a former PayPal executive, who joined the company last June to lead its mobile messaging business. The feature is expected to compete with existing online payment platforms.

site_title: Businesses must step up to the plate to bring AEC into being
summary: US Ambassador Nina Hachigian expresses skepticism about the Asean Economic Community (AEC) forming by 2020, citing a survey that half of respondents believe it won't happen. Despite progress in reducing non-tariff barriers, labor laws and other issues remain unresolved. Asean leaders consider 2015 a "milestone" rather than an end-point, with a combined market of 600 million people and a $2.4 trillion GDP. The business community, including prominent Asean leaders, sees the potential of the common market and is advocating for economic integration. Experts, such as Kishore Mahbubani, emphasize the need for the business community to take ownership of Asean.

images.alt_text: ASEAN Leaders pose for the cameras during the opening ceremony of the 21st ASEAN Summit held in Peace Palace Building, Phnom Penh, Cambodia. ASEAN leaders have been saying for over a year now that 2015 is not an end-point but a "milestone" in economic integration - with high stakes.

site_title: Voyage ups valuation for Roxy-Pacific stock
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has raised its valuation for the stock to 74 Singapore cents after acquiring a 40% stake in properties in Brisbane for S$35.6 million. Research firm Voyage Research estimates the project will generate S$240 million in gross sales proceeds and S$64 million in gross profit. The acquisition is seen as a timely addition to replenish Roxy's pipeline, expected to elevate forecast profits in FY17 or FY18.

images.alt_text: ROXY-PACIFIC Holdings' latest acquisition of a 40 per cent stake in properties in Brisbane has prompted one research house to raise its valuation for the stock.

site_title: Euro's weakness feeds robust Germany's concerns
summary: Germany's export sector is concerned about the euro's slide towards parity with the dollar, which could undermine the country's post-war prosperity built on the strong Deutsche mark. Analysts attribute Germany's attachment to a strong euro to its historical pride and economic success. The euro's weakness could impact Germany's vital export sector, which disapproves of a weak European currency.

site_title: GM all but pulls out of Russia, even as Ford pumps up the volume
summary: General Motors (GM) has announced it will idle a plant in St Petersburg and halt sales of its Opel brand and most Chevrolet models in Russia, citing declining sales and growing tensions in the country. In contrast, Ford Motor Co. continues to invest in the market, despite a 10% decline in car sales last year. GM will focus on higher-end models, including luxury Cadillac and select Chevrolet models, while Ford plans to manage through the current challenges with cost-cutting measures. The decision marks GM's latest move to cut underperforming businesses overseas, following similar moves in Indonesia, Australia, and western Europe.

site_title: Pimco downgrades US growth to 2.5 to 3% on sluggish exports, capex
summary: Pimco downgraded US economic growth forecast to 2.5-3% for 2015, citing sluggish exports and slowing capital expenditures. The company also expects a "fairly slow pace" of Federal Reserve rate hikes. Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke warned that the Fed's challenge in tightening policy and exiting the zero-interest rate level is unprecedented. Pimco anticipates solid above-trend growth in the US, but sees weaker growth elsewhere and a stronger US dollar reinforcing expectations of a lower neutral rate for the Fed.

site_title: Vertex Venture invests in theAsianparent
summary: Vertex Venture invests S$4.5 million in theAsianparent, a Singapore-based online parenting platform, with the latest funding round also including angel investors. The investment will be used to expand offerings to new markets in India and Sri Lanka, targeting fathers in Asian households. Since its founding in 2009, theAsianparent has built a readership base of over six million mothers in South-east Asia, generating revenue from custom advertising and market research.

images.alt_text: Ms Mahtani says that each country in the region has its specific needs on the availability of a centralised source of information on parenting.

site_title: Fragment from MH17 crash site supports missile theory: Dutch TV
