Despite the Straits Times Index's 130% gain since the 2008 US sub-prime crisis, the Catalist Index has lost 42% over the past 17 months. Banks and stockbrokers are reluctant to provide financing and coverage, exacerbating the issue. To revive interest, experts suggest targeting up-and-coming companies and promoting the board as an ideal corporate nursery, while the Singapore Exchange can help with marketing and education.

site_title: BOJ maintains stimulus, tempers price outlook
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its stimulus program, signaling a steady economic recovery will meet its price target without immediate easing. The central bank downplayed the slowdown in inflation, attributing it to temporary oil price declines. Despite this, the BOJ acknowledged a less optimistic price outlook. The decision was made despite China's expected slowdown in GDP growth, which may raise pressure on policymakers.

site_title: February housing starts down at year's low
summary: US housing starts plummeted to a year-low 897,000 units in February, the lowest level since January 2014, due to harsh weather keeping building crews at home. Permits for future construction rose 3% last month, suggesting a temporary setback for housing. Bad weather, a strong US dollar, and weaker overseas growth have dampened economic activity, casting doubts on an anticipated June interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve. Economists now forecast a 1.2% annualized GDP growth rate for the first quarter, down from previous estimates.

site_title: Pinterest valued at US$11b after new fundraising round
summary: Pinterest has raised approximately $367 million in a new round of financing, valuing the company at $11 billion. This marks a significant increase in valuation, nearly tripling in just over a year and a half. Existing investors, including Andreessen Horowitz and Rakuten, participated in the round. The funds will be used for corporate moves, including an international push, as the company expands its user base, which has increased to over 40% of customers abroad. Pinterest plans to focus on advertising revenue, which has been a key growth area for the company.

site_title: Adobe unveils Web-based tools to create and manage documents online
summary: Adobe has introduced Acrobat Document Cloud, a web-based tool for creating, storing, and managing documents online. The service costs $15/month and offers digital signatures, mobile applications, and document tracking features. This move aligns with Adobe's shift to internet-based subscriptions and follows a 2011 transition to cloud computing, which led to a decline in sales. Despite this, analysts project a 18% increase in sales this year. The service joins Adobe's cloud-based marketing and creative-design tools, solidifying its push into the subscription-based market.

site_title: GM settles faulty ignition suit, now faces class-action case
summary: General Motors has settled a wrongful-death lawsuit related to a defective ignition switch, but still faces a class-action case. The company has avoided depositions in the case, but its lawyers are continuing to pursue internal documents and employee testimony. The settlement was reached after a decade-long internal investigation revealed GM's knowledge of faulty ignition switches in millions of vehicles, leading to the recall of 2.6 million cars. The company's lax safety procedures and internal dysfunction have been exposed, resulting in the dismissal of 15 employees and a reorganization of its engineering department.

site_title: Clinton vs Bush race no more a certainty
summary: A scandal surrounding former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's private email account has thrown a wrench into the expected 2016 presidential election matchup between Clinton and Jeb Bush. Clinton's use of a private email account for official business has reignited concerns about her conduct and raised questions about her leadership. The controversy has sparked a new wave of speculation about potential Democratic candidates, including former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley. Meanwhile, Jeb Bush faces challenges from within his own party, with some Republicans expressing "Bush fatigue" and opposition to his immigration stance.

site_title: Novo Group's Q3 loss narrows
summary: Novo Group, a China-based steel company, reported a narrower third-quarter loss of $83,000 compared to a year-ago loss of $2.49 million. Revenue fell 18.1% to $68.2 million, while loss per share decreased to 0.09 US cents. The company expects China's steel exports to benefit from urbanization and economic recovery, despite being affected by sliding iron ore prices. Net asset value per share fell to 18.1 US cents from 24 US cents last year.

site_title: TCS expands presence in Singapore
summary: TCS has expanded its presence in Singapore with the opening of a new 1,000-person banking and financial services centre. The centre will provide application development, digital, and general IT services to leading global banks in the Asia-Pacific region. TCS' BFS business has grown substantially in Singapore, with the new centre replacing a 500-seat centre opened in 2011. The company aims to expand its presence in the market and assist global clients, with 40% of its revenue coming from the BFS sector globally.

site_title: Online account opening for SMEs
summary: DBS Bank has introduced a virtual account opening service for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), allowing them to open business accounts without meeting with a relationship manager or visiting a branch. The service uses video applications to verify customer particulars and complete applications virtually. Since its launch in December 2013, over a third of DBS' new business accounts are now opened online, saving SME owners time and eliminating unnecessary form-filling and data entry. This innovation aims to simplify and streamline the banking experience for SMEs.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: US credibility at risk if IMF reforms not approved: Lew
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew warned that the country's credibility is at risk if Congress fails to approve International Monetary Fund quota and governance reforms. The reforms, which have been stalled for over two years, would give more weight to emerging-market powers like China and double the Fund's permanent financial resources. Lew stated that the delay is pushing other countries to create their own parallel financial institutions, threatening the US's leadership role in multilateral institutions.

site_title: Tat Hong Holdings disposes Sungei Kadut property for S$7m
summary: Tat Hong Holdings sold its 18 Sungei Kadut Avenue property to Top Zone Construction and Engineering for S$7 million in cash. The sale is part of the company's plan to consolidate operations and move less time-sensitive operations to Johor, Malaysia. The property had a net book value of S$2.8 million and the sale will result in a net gain of S$4.1 million after expenses.

site_title: Google app store gets more oversight
summary: Google is tightening oversight of its Play store by forming a team to screen new apps for malware and explicit material, and strengthening its age-based rating system. The change aims to bring the Play store closer to Apple's tightly controlled App Store, but Google won't adopt Apple's quality standards. A new expert team will screen apps, with approved apps available within hours, and developers must answer questionnaires for age-based ratings. The move aims to better label apps for different audiences and improve user safety.

site_title: France confirms to join China-led AIIB investment bank
summary: France has confirmed its participation in the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), joining Italy and Germany in the institution. The decision comes despite US pressure to stay out, with European officials agreeing to follow Britain's lead. France's participation is seen as a significant development for the bank, which aims to provide financing for infrastructure projects in Asia. The move is likely to strengthen China's influence in regional economic development.

site_title: KL's US$ sukuk sale reflects investor appetite for yields
summary: Malaysia plans to sell up to $2 billion of Islamic notes, its first dollar sukuk since 2011, amid investor appetite for yields at an eight-month high. The government aims to use the sale to price its sukuk, which will replace maturing debt, and has hired banks to arrange the global offering. The yield on Malaysia's 2021 US currency sukuk rose to 3.17%, the highest since July, as the government limits fallout from the breakup of a state investment company.

site_title: ANZ sells S$500m Basel 3 bonds
summary: ANZ sold S$500 million Basel 3 Tier 2 bonds, the first for an Australian bank, with DBS, HSBC, and UOB as joint bookrunners. The 12-year bonds were priced at 3.75% and received over S$700 million in orders, with 89% coming from Singapore investors. The Basel 3 compliant bonds can be written off or converted into capital in case of a non-viability trigger event. This issue is seen as a sign of the SGD bond market firming up, with strong non-private bank participation.

images.alt_text: AUSTRALIA and New Zealand Banking Group Limited has sold S$500 million Basel 3 Tier 2 bonds.

site_title: Grexit would have "serious consequences" for eurozone: Moody's
summary: Greece's potential exit from the eurozone, known as "Grexit," would have "serious consequences" for the eurozone, according to Moody's. The ratings agency warns that the exit would raise questions about the stability of other eurozone countries, particularly those on the periphery, such as Portugal and Italy. Despite a stable credit outlook for eurozone sovereigns, Moody's notes that the region is likely to experience moderate growth, with high debt-to-GDP ratios expected to continue rising, particularly in Greece, Italy, Spain, and France.

site_title: Payrolls increased in 39 states in January led by California
summary: US payrolls rose in 39 states in January, led by California's 67,300 increase, with 24 states seeing a drop in unemployment. Job growth is a positive sign despite sluggish economic indicators, with the unemployment rate falling to 5.5% and factory output slowing due to inclement weather. Economists expect demand for goods and services to pick up to justify expansion. The labor market is accelerating, with 295,000 jobs added in February, and Fed officials weigh labor data as they consider an interest rate increase.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's condition 'worsens' due to infection
summary: Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew's health has worsened due to an infection. The 91-year-old was admitted to the Singapore General Hospital six weeks ago for severe pneumonia. His condition had previously improved, but it has taken a turn for the worse. Lee Kuan Yew remains sedated and on mechanical ventilation. Thousands of messages and prayers have been sent to him on social media, wishing him a speedy recovery ahead of Singapore's 50th National Day celebrations on August 9.

images.alt_text: The health of Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew has taken a turn for the worse.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: Xpress Holdings Q2 net profit falls 51.6%
summary: Xpress Holdings, a printing company, reported a 51.6% drop in Q2 net profit to S$214,000, down from S$438,000 a year earlier. Revenue fell 14.1% to S$4.1 million. The company faces cash flow problems, with a negative working capital position and a net drop in cash and cash equivalents of S$57,000. Despite a proposed share and warrants issuance to raise up to S$23 million, the board believes the company can meet its short-term obligations.

site_title: In brief
summary: Keppel Corp now owns 86.2% of Keppel Land, surpassing the 90% threshold needed for delisting. Olam International issued A$125 million 5-year senior unsecured notes with a 4.875% annual coupon. Meanwhile, Helen Wong is set to retire as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named her successor.

site_title: New BoE regulator warns of risks from US rate hikes, dollar strength
summary: The Bank of England's Financial Policy Committee warns of potential risks to global financial markets from US interest rate hikes and a strong dollar. New member Alex Brazier cited these factors as key risks, stating that rate hikes would reduce global risk appetite and prompt a decrease in the search for yield. Brazier also expressed concerns over high debt levels in the eurozone and the potential for Greece to default, which could impact British banks. The FPC will continue to monitor these risks and consider additional measures to ensure financial stability.

site_title: Zara owner has edge in online battle with H&M
summary: Inditex, the parent company of Zara, appears to have an edge in the online fashion market compared to H&M. Inditex's centralized distribution network and IT synergies between brands and outlets give it a competitive advantage. Zara launched its e-commerce platform in 2010, while H&M went online 12 years later. Inditex makes online sales in 27 of its 80 markets, whereas H&M operates in 13 markets. Analysts predict Inditex's e-commerce sales will reach nearly 8% of its total sales by 2020, while H&M's online sales may already be around 5-10% of its total sales.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Fed meeting eyed
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, falling 0.52% to 17,883.66, ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting that could influence interest rate hike timing. The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite declined 93.76 points, 8.85 points, and 15.82 points, respectively. Investors await the Fed meeting for guidance on potential rate hikes, which could impact the market's rally.

site_title: EU banking supervisor calls for more harmonisation
summary: The head of Europe's single banking authority, Daniele Nouy, called for more harmonization of eurozone banking rules, stating that while progress has been made, there is still room for improvement. The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) has identified over 150 national options and discretions that hinder its effectiveness. Nouy emphasized the need for fully harmonized regulation to deliver consistent supervision and a level playing field. With the entry of Lithuania into the euro area, the ECB now directly supervises 123 banking groups covering 85% of total banking assets in the euro area.

site_title: US influence challenged in global financial institutions: Lew
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew warned that rising powers are challenging US leadership in global financial institutions, urging Congress to approve a reform deal that would give emerging markets a bigger say while preserving US veto power in the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: GMG Global proposes share consolidation
summary: GMG Global has proposed a share consolidation of every ten existing issued ordinary shares into a single consolidated share to comply with Singapore's minimum trading price requirement of S$0.20. The move aims to reduce volatility and increase the company's profile, potentially making its shares more attractive to investors. The proposal is subject to approval from SGX and GMG's shareholders.

site_title: Italy confirms intends to join China-led infrastructure bank
summary: Italy has confirmed its intention to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a China-led development bank, alongside France and Germany. The move aims to establish an institution with high global standards, contrasting with US concerns over governance standards. The AIIB was launched in Beijing last year to support infrastructure investment in Asia. Italy's decision is seen as a key step in spreading China's "soft power" and a potential rival to the Western-dominated World Bank.

site_title: Lagarde warns emerging economies to prepare for US rate rise
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief Christine Lagarde warned emerging economies to prepare for potential US interest rate rises, citing the risk of a repeat of the "taper tantrum" that hit markets in 2013. Lagarde urged India and other emerging economies to strengthen their economies through higher GDP growth, lower inflation, and stronger external current accounts. Central banks must also be prepared to act with aggressive and temporary liquidity support and targeted foreign exchange interventions. Lagarde praised India's economic reform efforts and urged clear communication of policy intentions to avoid market volatility.

site_title: Ford turns back to Microsoft to build connected-car services
summary: Ford is partnering with Microsoft to build connected-car services through its new Service Delivery Network, expanding on its Sync 3 infotainment system. The service will use Microsoft's Azure platform to gather data on vehicle usage, enabling remote diagnostics and scheduled maintenance. This data can also be used to provide insurers with information on vehicle usage and owners' driving habits. Ford aims to generate revenue through services like car sharing and pay-per-use rentals, creating new opportunities for developers to deliver services to vehicle users.

site_title: Mercedes, Japanese brands race ahead in 2015
summary: Mercedes-Benz tops the luxury car sales in Singapore for 2015, with 1,161 new-car registrations, followed by Toyota with 1,122 units. Honda, Mazda, and Nissan are in the top three mass-market Japanese brands, with Honda in third place. BMW, which slipped from third to seventh, and Volkswagen are the biggest surprises in the rankings. The COE quota expansion and reclassification of engine-output limits have contributed to Mercedes' rise. The total year-to-date market volume is 6,439 units, up 62.4% from last year.

site_title: Thai cabinet approves US$1.7b borrowing plan to boost economy
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a plan to borrow $1.7 billion to boost the economy, focusing on road and water projects. The loan is part of a larger borrowing plan of $2.4 billion and aims to revive growth after months of political unrest. The government targets 87% of its investment budget to be disbursed in 2015, with plans to spend $34 billion on road construction and $23 billion on water management projects. The move aims to support economic recovery, which is expected to grow less than 4% this year due to weak government spending and exports.

site_title: Major US allies to join China-backed bank: reports
summary: Major US allies France, Germany, and Italy have agreed to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a China-backed bank, despite US pressure to stay out. The decision is seen as a diplomatic setback for the US, which has questioned the bank's governance and environmental standards. EU parliament president Martin Schulz welcomed the four nations joining, emphasizing the need for the bank to conform to international standards. Other countries, including South Korea, Switzerland, and Luxembourg, are also considering membership.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.33 points to close at 1,787.87, with 2.49 billion lots valued at RM1.84 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 347-490.

site_title: US expects China to table investment treaty proposal soon
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew stated that China is expected to propose a bilateral investment treaty (BIT) within days or weeks, outlining industries that would remain protected from foreign investment.

site_title: Europe braces for 'unprecedented' power issues from solar eclipse
summary: Europe is preparing for a potential disruption in power supply due to a solar eclipse on March 20, which could knock out almost all solar-generated electricity. The European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity (Entso-e) has put in place unprecedented contingency plans, coordinating with operators across the continent to compensate for the sudden loss of power. The countries hardest hit are likely to be Germany, Italy, and Spain, where solar power capacity is significant. Operators are bolstering teams and daily reserves, and countries are sharing information to ensure a smooth operation of the power system.

site_title: US housing starts tumble in February, weather likely a factor
summary: US housing starts plummeted to a 1-year low in February, falling 17% to 897,000 units, the lowest level since January 2014, likely due to harsh weather conditions. The decline was seen in all four regions, with the Northeast experiencing the largest drop. Despite this temporary setback, a rapidly tightening labor market is expected to drive up wage growth and boost housing starts in the coming months. Permits for future home construction rose 3.0% in February, the highest level since October, indicating a potential rebound in the housing market.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's agency plans to seize approximately RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin is confident that a court will clear his daughter's suspension in an ethics case. The Asean group has deemed Myanmar's election a low priority. The UK economy contracted for the second month, while South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) will jointly investigate market misconduct from now on, the two agencies announced on Tuesday afternoon.

site_title: Tye Soon to sell Waterloo Centre units to ValueMax Properties for S$11m
summary: Tye Soon Limited has agreed to sell its 11 leasehold units at Waterloo Centre to ValueMax Properties for S$11 million, representing about 34% of the company's market capitalization. The sale is expected to result in a net gain of S$7.9 million, with proceeds used for general working capital and reducing bank borrowings. The company plans to relocate its automotive parts retail operation to an area outside the central business district.

site_title: Singapore: After an early bounce, stocks finish in the red
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 6.09 points to 3,369.95, closing in the red despite a brief 20-point gain at the start of the day. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision was a major factor, as traders sold into strength after Monday's US market rally. The decline was broad-based, affecting major companies such as Jardine group, Keppel Corp, banks, SIA, and Noble Group.

site_title: US Republican budget offers deep cuts to end deficits in 2024
summary: US House Republicans unveiled a budget plan aiming to eliminate deficits by 2024 through deep cuts to social safety net programs, domestic spending, and repealing "Obamacare" health reforms. The plan proposes $5.468 trillion in spending cuts and interest savings over 10 years. It boosts military spending and cuts domestic discretionary spending more deeply, but does not include tax increases. The plan's passage is unlikely, as it would require bipartisan support and is non-binding.

site_title: China said to mull options to extend finance chief Lou's term
summary: China is considering extending the term of Finance Minister Lou Jiwei, who is set to retire at 65, to keep him in office and maintain stability in fiscal policy amid an economic slowdown. Options include giving him a position with the legislature's advisory body or a state councilor role, allowing him to work with Governor Zhou Xiaochuan beyond retirement age. This move aims to address China's record local government debt and avoid a crisis.

site_title: German investor morale at brightest in just over a year in March
summary: German investor morale reached its highest level in over a year in March, with the ZEW survey of economic sentiment increasing to 54.8, surpassing a consensus forecast of 58.2. This marks a fifth consecutive month of improvement. However, the survey warned that the Greek and Ukraine crises are having a dampening effect on sentiment.

site_title: American Airlines CEO says Gulf carriers put US jobs at risk
summary: American Airlines CEO Doug Parker stated that Gulf carriers pose a threat to US jobs due to unfair government subsidies. He claimed that state-backed rivals in the Middle East benefit from over $40 billion in subsidies, making it difficult for US airlines to compete. This has led to US carriers presenting a report to the Obama administration, advocating for a level playing field. Parker warned that if the field isn't leveled, jobs will shift from the US to the Gulf, potentially increasing fares for consumers.

images.alt_text: American Airlines Group Inc Chief Executive Officer Doug Parker said Persian Gulf carriers threaten US jobs because the Middle East companies are benefiting from unfair government subsidies.

site_title: Rowsley debuts in bond market with a 3-year issue, offering 6.50%
summary: Rowsley Ltd, a company controlled by Singapore billionaire Peter Lim, debuted in the bond market with a 3-year issue offering a 6.50% coupon rate. The unsecured bonds are non-callable in the first year, with a change of control "put" and maintaining one interest payment in an interest reserve account. The issue size is expected at S$100 million, with DBS Bank and Standard Chartered Bank as joint lead managers and bookrunners. This is Rowsley's maiden issue, tapping the bond market to raise funds.

site_title: Japan's Nintendo to develop smartphone games with online firm
summary: Nintendo and online gaming firm DeNA are teaming up to develop smartphone games featuring Nintendo's iconic characters, such as Super Mario. The two companies will invest $252 million in each other and jointly develop gaming apps for smartphones. Nintendo will acquire a 10% stake in DeNA, while DeNA will acquire a 1.2% stake in Nintendo. The partnership aims to retain users who are increasingly playing games on smartphones rather than Nintendo's consoles.

site_title: China state-owned steelmaker plans closure as overcapacity bites
summary: China's Pangang Group Chengdu Steel & Vanadium Co, a state-owned steelmaker, plans to close most of its facilities due to persistent overcapacity and falling steel prices, forcing the company to halt production and lay off workers. The move is expected to be a sign of the damage caused by overcapacity in the sector, with more inefficient mills likely to shut down permanently. Chinese steelmakers face headwinds this year due to soaring environmental costs, slower demand growth, and overcapacity.

site_title: Anwar's daughter Nurul Izzah released after arrest for sedition
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's daughter, Nurul Izzah, was released on police bail after being arrested and remanded overnight under the Sedition Act for remarks criticizing her father's imprisonment. The arrest was made over a speech she made in parliament, where she criticized the judiciary and her father's sodomy conviction. The incident has been seen as a move to re-energize opposition supporters and may have unintendedly boosted the opposition movement. Human rights groups and analysts have expressed concerns over the government's use of the sedition law to restrict free speech.

site_title: Tata Consultancy Services expands Singapore centre
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) has expanded its Singapore centre, opening a new 1,000-person facility focused on banking and financial services. The centre, replacing a 500-seat centre, will provide application development, digital, and general IT services to leading global banks in the Asia-Pacific region. TCS' BFS business has grown substantially in Singapore, solidifying its position as a leader in the sector.

site_title: Europe: VW helps European shares climb to fresh 7-1/2 year highs
summary: European shares reached fresh 7-1/2 year highs on Tuesday, driven by gains in Volkswagen and Sainsbury's. Volkswagen's shares rose 2.2% after European new car registrations increased 7% in February, shifting demand towards mass market brands. Sainsbury's rose 2.3% despite a fifth consecutive quarter of declining underlying sales, beating market expectations. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.2% to 1,597.17, its highest level since 2007.

site_title: ANZ sells S$500m Basel 3 bonds at 3.75%
summary: ANZ has sold S$500 million Basel 3 Tier 2 bonds at a 3.75% yield, marking the first compliant SGD bond for an Australian bank. The 12-year non-call 7-year bonds were oversubscribed by S$700 million, with 89% of the deal going to Singapore investors. Institutional investors dominated the issue, with insurers taking 68% and fund managers 16%. The sale indicates the SGD bond market is firming up, with strong non-private bank participation.

site_title: MAS, CAD to together probe market misconduct from now on
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) will jointly investigate market misconduct, aiming to consolidate resources and expertise. This change will enable MAS officers to have the same criminal investigation powers as CAD officers. Both agencies will investigate potential misconduct together, with the decision on civil or criminal action made after investigations are concluded. This new approach is expected to make enforcement more efficient.

site_title: 'Significant support' for Budget 2015 initiatives: REACH poll
summary: Singaporeans overwhelmingly support Budget 2015 initiatives, with 77% agreeing the Silver Support Scheme will help low-income elderly and 72% supporting SkillsFuture to promote lifelong learning. The poll, conducted by REACH, showed "significant support" for other key initiatives, including GST Voucher-Seniors' Bonus and changes to personal income tax. Senior Minister Amy Khor stated that the poll findings align with other engagement platforms, indicating a comprehensive, fair, and inclusive Budget. The poll was conducted from February 25 to March 6 and surveyed 947 citizens aged 20 and above.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds benchmark rate at 7.50%
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its benchmark rate at 7.50% as expected, maintaining efforts to contain inflation and the current account deficit. This decision comes after a 25-basis-point rate cut in February, which revised the inflation outlook for 2015 to below 4%. The rupiah has been weakening since the last policy meeting, trading at 13,181 per dollar. Analysts had predicted a rate hold, but some expect a cut later in the year to address the currency's decline.

site_title: Sony confirms Q3 net profit, annual loss
summary: Sony has reported a net profit of 90 billion yen for the October-December quarter, more than tripling from the same period last year, driven by a weak yen and increased sales of smartphones and image sensors. Despite this, the company confirmed it will incur an annual loss of 170 billion yen, as sales in other operations, such as the PC business and Pictures segment, declined. Sony's sales grew 6.5% to 2.56 trillion yen, with operating profit more than doubling to 182.1 billion yen.

site_title: Chinese central bank expands banks' medium-term lending facility: sources
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has expanded its medium-term lending facility (MLF) to 450-500 billion yuan, with all outstanding 350 billion yuan from previous periods being rolled over. The move aims to provide liquidity to banks amid a slowdown in China's economy. This expansion follows a rate cut in February and a reduction in banks' reserve requirement ratios. The MLF tool is similar to the US Federal Reserve's discount window, allowing banks to withdraw funds in case of liquidity needs.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's condition worsens due to infection: PMO
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's condition has worsened due to an infection, according to a statement from the Prime Minister's Office. He is on antibiotics and being closely monitored by doctors.

site_title: Malaysia's Malakoff to offer 30% of IPO to cornerstones: sources
summary: Malaysia's Malakoff Corporation Bhd, the country's largest independent power producer, is planning to offer 30% of its US$740 million IPO to cornerstone investors, including domestic state funds. The IPO, targeting a May listing, aims to raise funds for the company's growth and cut MMC Corporation Bhd's borrowings. The deal could be Malaysia's largest IPO since 2012, with Maybank Investment Bank advising MMC on the listing.

site_title: ST Telemedia acquires land for flagship data centre in Singapore
summary: ST Telemedia acquires land for a 150,000 square foot flagship data centre in Singapore, built to Tier III industry standards and supported by experts with industry relationships. The facility will cater to growing demand for data centre space in Singapore, where utilisation is forecasted to remain strong at 90% by 2018. Singapore's position as a hub for internet connectivity and data centres in Asia-Pacific will enable ST Telemedia's long-term global plans.

images.alt_text: Singapore Technologies Telemedia (ST Telemedia), on Tuesday completed the acquisition of land to develop a state-of-the-art flagship data centre in Singapore. The announcement follows ST Telemedia's data centre investment in China's GDS Services last year.

site_title: Indonesia's loan growth slows to 11.5% y-o-y
summary: Indonesia's loan growth in January slowed to 11.5% year-over-year, down from 11.6% in December, according to the central bank. The central bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 7.50% and forecast 15-17% bank lending growth this year. Broad money supply rose 14.3% year-over-year, slightly above the previous month's 11.9%.

site_title: Thailand files charges against former commerce minister
summary: Thailand's attorney general has filed charges against former Commerce Minister Boonsong Teriyapirom and 20 others over alleged graft in rice export deals with Chinese firms in 2013. The case, which could result in life imprisonment, claims the government falsified deals and sold rice locally instead of exporting it. The charges come as Thailand's Supreme Court prepares to decide on a case against former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, who faces up to 10 years in jail over a rice subsidy programme.

site_title: Amoy Street shophouse row up for tender, with guide price of S$66.8m
summary: A public tender sale for 77-80 Amoy Street shophouses in Singapore's Chinatown Conservation Area has been launched with a guide price of S$66.8 million. The shophouses, refurbished recently, have a combined land area of approximately 8,182 sq ft and a 999-year land tenure. The tender is open to local and foreign buyers with no additional stamp duty, and closes on April 20, 2015. The sale is expected to offer stronger capital and rental upside due to the rejuvenation of Tanjong Pagar.

site_title: Kuroda won't rule out CPI dipping below zero, maintains stimulus
summary: Japan's central bank maintained record monetary stimulus, keeping an annual pace of 80 trillion yen, despite a pledge to meet its inflation goal. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the possibility of consumer prices dipping below zero cannot be ruled out, but he remains optimistic about the economy's moderate recovery. The BOJ will continue to monitor wage talks and inflation expectations, with a focus on the impact of lower oil prices.

summary: London's asking home prices fell 0.4% in March to £580,308, marking the first decline in three years, due to affordability constraints and pre-election jitters. This follows a 2.8% increase in February. The market is experiencing a slowdown, with near-record house prices and lending curbs affecting first-time buyers. Demand continues to outstrip supply, and buyers are putting down larger downpayments. The slowdown is reflected across England and Wales, with annual house-price growth slowing to 5.4%.

site_title: YuuZoo launches virtual mall in Turkey
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has launched a virtual shopping mall in Turkey through a joint venture with a local partner. Under a franchise model, YuuZoo holds a significant stake in the franchise company, aiming to reach 1 million users within 12 months and 4 million users within 36 months. Based on market assumptions, this could generate over $250 million in annual revenue. YuuZoo chairman & CEO Thomas Zilliacus sees Turkey as a key market for social e-commerce and gaming, with patent-pending solutions expected to drive targeted user growth and revenue.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE-LISTED social media company YuuZoo Corporation on Tuesday announced that it has launched a localised version of its virtual shopping mall in Turkey through a joint venture with a local partner.

site_title: Noble debt trades like junk with record maturities during rout
summary: Noble Group Ltd, Asia's largest commodities house, is facing a credit crisis amid a global resources rout. The company has record bond maturities and low investment-grade scores, yielding over 400 basis points above Treasuries. Noble posted its first quarterly loss since 2011 and faces about $1 billion of debt due this year. The company denied allegations of overstating accounting gains and rejected a lawsuit from its former CEO. Its credit protection costs have risen 146 basis points in the last month, making it the worst performing in Asia.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd, Asia's biggest commodities house, is being punished by traders as it faces record bond maturities and closer scrutiny of earnings amid a global resources rout.

site_title: Noble slips as Iceberg warns of third report
summary: Noble Group shares dropped 2.1% after Iceberg Research announced it would issue a third report, raising concerns over the commodity trader's governance, debt, and liquidity. This is the third report from Iceberg, which has caused Noble's shares to fall 23% since its campaign began.

site_title: Crystal ball for the near term
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow at a moderate pace of 2-4% in 2015, driven by lower oil prices and reduced inflation pressures. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is likely to slow the appreciation of the Singapore dollar, making exports more competitive. Companies should focus on innovation and value-added services to stay competitive, rather than just trying to do the same things more efficiently. Two upcoming opportunities, the AEC 2015 and European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, may provide new avenues for growth and expansion, but companies must adapt and redefine themselves to take advantage of these opportunities.

site_title: More room for growth
summary: Centurion Corporation, a Singapore-listed company, has achieved record profits due to its expansion in Singapore and abroad. The company has over 40,000 beds in Singapore, Malaysia, and Australia, with a portfolio expected to reach 74,000 beds by 2017. Centurion diversified into student accommodation last year, adding assets in the UK and Australia, and has seen a 48% rise in revenue. CEO Kong Chee Min attributes the growth to diversification into student dormitories, which share synergies with its core workers accommodation business, and plans to accelerate overseas expansion to drive future growth.

site_title: India needs own model of manufacturing
summary: India needs a unique manufacturing model that creates employment for Indians, differing from China's, to combat poverty. The "Make in India" programme aims to transform the country into a global manufacturing hub. Panellists emphasized the importance of the infrastructure sector and technology-led manufacturing, warning against automated, "jobless" manufacturing. Singapore can contribute to India by sharing expertise in urban management and the real estate investment trust market, offering opportunities in infrastructure and other industries.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: In brief
summary: Management changes occurred at Yoma Strategic Holdings in Myanmar, with Jeremy Noel Westmore and Elmar Heinrich Antonius Busch resigning to pursue personal interests. Thiri Thant Mon took over as head of financial management. At Jes International, CEO Jin Xin resigned to focus on restructuring efforts, replaced by Audrey Jin Yu, his daughter. China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings proposed a share consolidation.

site_title: India banks not paring rates despite central bank easing
summary: India's largest banks are not passing on the Reserve Bank of India's two rounds of monetary easing to borrowers, despite a 50 basis point cut in the benchmark rate to 7.5%. Profits are sliding, and bad loans are surging, with stressed assets expected to rise to 13% in the next 12 months. Banks are limited in their ability to cut deposit rates due to competition from other savings instruments and rising equity markets.

site_title: Crude oil joins rail industry staples as key revenue producers
summary: US railroads generated almost as much revenue from hauling crude oil and sand as they did from moving industry staples last year, according to a Reuters analysis of federal data. This trend is linked to the US shale oil boom, indicating a growing marriage between the energy and rail industries.

site_title: Shopping in first class
summary: DFS Venture Singapore, now rebranded as T Galleria Singapore, has revamped its downtown store along Scotts Road to offer a high-end retail experience. The store features luxury brands, exceptional services, and unique experiences tailored to customers' needs. T Galleria has ranked first in the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore for four consecutive years and received the Best People Practices award. The company is expanding its reach with initiatives such as an online shopping service and a new duplex store design at Changi Airport. DFS Group, majority-owned by Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, aims to adapt to changing customer spending patterns and maintain its commitment to quality.

images.alt_text: The DFS brand stands for an expertly curated assortment of the world's preferred luxury brands, exceptional retail environments, highly personalised services and unique experiences.
The DFS brand stands for an expertly curated assortment of the world's preferred luxury brands, exceptional retail environments, highly personalised services and unique experiences.

The DFS Group's operations in Singapore is just one of a sprawling network that consists of duty free stores located in 18 major global airports, 14 downtown Galleria stores, as well as affiliate and resort locations.
