site_title: Singapore: STI rebounds, but not broad market
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore rebounded 13.27 points to 3,376.04 on Monday, driven by short covering ahead of a potential Wall Street rebound. However, the buying did not extend to the broader market, with 155 gains versus 284 losses. This marks a 12-point gain for the year 2015. Turnover was weak, with a low average value per unit traded.

site_title: Developer sales rise 2.1% to 382 private homes in February
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 382 private homes in February, a 2.1% increase from January, but half the units sold in the same month last year. Including executive condominiums, developers sold 447 units, lower than January and February last year. The figures, released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, indicate a slowdown in the market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Yoma announces management changes
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings announced key management changes, including the resignation of group general manager Jeremy Noel Westmore and co-head of real estate Elmar Heinrich Antonius Busch, both to pursue personal interests. Thiri Thant Mon, head of financial management, took over as head of corporate development. The company's shares closed 3.3% lower at S$0.435.

site_title: Palm hits lowest in nearly 6 weeks on Malaysia's export tax decision
summary: Malaysia's decision to impose export taxes on palm oil for April has led to a slump in palm oil futures, with prices reaching their lowest in nearly six weeks. The benchmark June contract fell 1.7% to RM2,199 a tonne, amid concerns that the additional tax could curb demand for the tropical oil. Analysts expect a potential boost in Indonesian biodiesel consumption, which could support palm prices, but overall market sentiment remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm oil futures slid to their lowest in nearly six weeks on Monday, after a decision by the second-largest producer to impose export taxes next month fuelled worries that price-sensitive buyers would switch to rival edible oils.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge down ahead of BoJ, Fed meetings
summary: Tokyo stocks ended a three-day winning streak on Monday, falling 0.04% due to investor anticipation of Bank of Japan and US Federal Reserve meetings this week. The benchmark Nikkei 225 closed at 19,246.06, while the broader Topix index fell 0.14%. The decline follows the index's record high on Friday.

site_title: India wholesale prices drop 2.06% in February
summary: India's wholesale inflation fell 2.06% in February, the fourth straight drop, due to global oil prices at multi-year lows and a drop in food and fuel prices. This sharp decline exceeded expectations and may lead to another interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government revised the November WPI inflation to 0.17%, and economist predictions suggest a 25 basis point cut in April. The RBI has made two unscheduled cuts this year to ease inflation and boost business borrowing.

site_title: Airbus, SIAEC to offer maintenance training services in Singapore
summary: Airbus and SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) have entered into an agreement to provide maintenance and engineering training services for Airbus aircraft in Singapore. SIAEC will utilize Airbus standards and tools to offer training capabilities to its personnel and third-party personnel in the region. The SIAEC Training Academy will be equipped with Airbus' newest maintenance training devices and courseware for various aircraft families. This partnership aims to enhance commercial aviation maintenance and engineering proficiency in the region, further strengthening SIAEC's service offerings to airlines.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares follow mainland market higher on policy hopes
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.5% to 23,949.55, following mainland China's strong gains, driven by Premier Li Keqiang's comments on policy adjustments to boost the slowing economy. Financial stocks led the gains, but a strengthening US dollar is expected to negatively impact Hong Kong stocks. Analysts say investors are cautiously optimistic about the potential policy changes, but are also wary of the dollar's effect.

site_title: Greece to pay 580m euro IMF loan tranche on Monday: government source
summary: Greece is set to pay a 580 million euro IMF loan tranche on Monday, the third installment of a 1.5 billion euro loan repayment due this month. This payment follows previous installments of 310 million euros on March 6 and 340 million euros on March 13. The payment is made despite ongoing bailout program talks with the IMF and eurozone partners. Greece has to pay a final tranche of about 350 million euros on March 20.

site_title: China: Stocks rise to five-year high after Li pledge on economy
summary: Chinese stocks surged to a five-year high after Premier Li Keqiang pledged to take action if economic growth slows too much. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 2.3% to 3,449.31, with technology shares leading the gain, up 40% this year. Li's comments bolstered investor confidence, and funds locked up for new share sales returned to the banking system, pushing the seven-day repurchase rate down 10 basis points.

site_title: Daughter of Malaysia's Anwar arrested for sedition
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's daughter, Nurul Izzah, 34, has been arrested for sedition after reading out parts of her father's speech criticizing his recent jailing in parliament. This move is part of a government crackdown on critics, with dozens investigated or convicted of sedition over the past year. Nurul, a member of parliament, criticized the independence of Malaysia's judiciary and questioned the legitimacy of Anwar's conviction, which he denies. The arrest has been met with anger from opposition politicians and international human rights groups.

site_title: South-east Asia attracts more foreign direct investment than China for second year
summary: South-east Asia's major economies drew more foreign direct investment than China in 2014, with a combined total of $128 billion, surpassing China's $119.56 billion. The region's growth outpaced China's due to China's cooling manufacturing sector, prompting Chinese businesses to seek alternative locations for their factories. Economists attribute the shift to rising wages in China and the region's strong economic fundamentals, with the Philippines experiencing the fastest growth. However, concerns remain over Indonesia's business infrastructure and Malaysia's industrial production, which fell short of expectations.

site_title: Global recovery slow, brittle, fragile: IMF's Lagarde
summary: IMF head Christine Lagarde stated that the global economic recovery is "too slow, too brittle and too lopsided" due to divergences in monetary policy, posing a risk of financial market volatility. The IMF forecasts a 3.5% global economic growth this year and 3.7% in 2016, below expectations after the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Blumont mulls over options to meet minimum share price of S$0.20 for mainboard listing
summary: Blumont Group, a Singapore-based company, is considering options to meet the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) minimum share price requirement of S$0.20 per share. The company may undertake a share consolidation or transfer the listing to the Catalist board. Blumont has a one-year transition period to comply with the requirement, set to take effect on March 1, 2016. The company's takeover bid for Genesis Resources Limited is now unconditional and set to close on March 23, 2015.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: IFIAR flags 'persistent deficiencies' in key areas of company audits
summary: The International Forum of Independent Audit Regulators (IFIAR) has raised an alert on "persistent deficiencies" in key areas of public company audits in Singapore, including fair value measurements, internal control testing, and revenue recognition. The findings, based on a global survey of 948 audits, are a concern for audit quality in Singapore, despite the country maintaining a high quality of audits. ACRA plans to implement initiatives to improve audit quality, including sharing audit quality indicators among firms.

site_title: PM Cameron's plan for EU treaty change is "mission impossible": EU's Tusk
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron's plan to reform EU treaties as part of his country's renegotiation of ties with the bloc is deemed "mission impossible" by European Council President Donald Tusk. Tusk expressed concerns that treaty change is not feasible due to rational and logical reasons, setting the stage for a potential referendum on Britain's EU membership by the end of 2017.

site_title: IMF chief hails India as 'bright spot' in world economy
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief Christine Lagarde hailed India as the "bright spot" in the global economy, citing the country's above 7% growth rate and falling inflation. Despite urging Prime Minister Narendra Modi to further open up the economy, Lagarde praised Modi's efforts to boost manufacturing and ease business regulations. She identified areas for improvement, including labor laws and land acquisition, to encourage investment and achieve faster growth. The visit is part of a two-day trip to India, where Lagarde will discuss economic reforms with Modi and other officials.

images.alt_text: International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde hailed India as the bright spot of the global economy on Monday ahead of talks in New Delhi with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

site_title: India better prepared for external financial shocks : IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that India is better prepared to cope with external financial shocks compared to most emerging market economies. This comes ahead of a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve, which could lead to capital outflows from emerging markets. The IMF's Christine Lagarde noted that India has reduced its current account deficit and increased its international reserves, making it more resilient to external shocks.

images.alt_text: India is better positioned to cope with external financial shocks than most emerging market economies, International Monetary Fund head Christine Lagarde was quoted saying on Monday, just ahead of a of a crunch meeting of the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Aussie securitisation storms ahead
summary: Australia's securitisation market is experiencing a surge, with demand for higher-yielding assets driving investors into asset-backed securities. Four companies priced securitisations last week, adding A$3.825b to this year's total, with the market on track to match pre-crisis annual totals. Domestic demand from local deposit-taking banks and offshore investors, particularly from Asia and Europe, is driving the growth, with Australian residential mortgage-backed securities offering attractive yields of 80bp-90bp over bank bills.

site_title: Euro slips to fresh 12-year low on dollar
summary: The euro fell to a 12-year low against the dollar, reaching US$1.0451 in early Tokyo trading, due to the European Central Bank's stimulus program and anticipation of a potential US interest rate hike. The dollar also rose to 121.35 yen, while investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting this week and the Bank of Japan's meeting on Tuesday. Analysts predict the dollar will hit parity with the euro by next year, citing central bank divergence and a strengthening US economy.

site_title: Indonesia posts US$738m trade surplus in Feb, imports slump
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of US$738.3 million in February, driven by a significant decline in imports. Exports fell 16.02% to US$12.29 billion, while imports dropped 16.24% to US$11.55 billion. This marks the fifth consecutive month of decline in imports and the fifth month of weak exports. The trade surplus exceeded expectations of US$520 million.

images.alt_text: Indonesia posted a third straight monthly trade surplus of US$738.3 million in February, helped by a large fall in imports, the statistics bureau said on Monday.

site_title: China slowdown concern spurs record option hedges on ETF
summary: Investors are rushing to hedge against potential losses in Chinese stocks amid concerns of an economic slowdown. Demand for option protection on the largest US ETF tracking China's mainland market reached a record high, with $34 million pulled from the fund in two weeks. This surge in bearish contracts pushes the ratio of bearish to bullish contracts to a five-month high, reflecting growing skepticism about the Shanghai Composite Index's ability to sustain its 39% advance since October. The concerns come as China's economy expands at its slowest pace in 24 years.

site_title: Hot stocks: Tiger, SIA surge amid drop in oil prices
summary: Shares of Tiger Airways Holdings surged 6.5% and Singapore Airlines rose 1.6% amid a 2% drop in US crude oil prices, a six-year low. The decline in oil prices, coupled with the dollar hitting new highs, lifted airline stocks.

images.alt_text: Shares of airlines rose in early trading on Monday as oil prices fell sharply.

site_title: Gold climbs before Fed meeting as investors weigh rates, Greece
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,162.30 an ounce ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting, as investors weighed concerns about Greece's cash holdings and potential interest rate hikes. This marked a rebound from the metal's second weekly drop, with prices hitting a low of $1,147.72 on March 11. The Fed's decision will be key to its debate on raising interest rates, with the economy's growth being a crucial factor in their decision-making.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend rally as euro falls
summary: European stocks rose on Monday, extending their rally, as investors bet a weakened euro would boost the region's economy. The FTSEurofirst 300 index gained 0.4% to 1,585.23 points. Lafarge and Holcim fell 4.2% and 1.4%, respectively, due to a conflict over their planned merger. The euro's drop is seen as a positive for exporter earnings, contributing to the European stocks' rally.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 0.22% at open
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.22% to 23,771.40, following a sell-off on Wall Street. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.54%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.68%. The decline in Hong Kong was attributed to the sell-off on Wall Street, while the Chinese markets showed resilience.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover losses as investors see upside of high US dollar
summary: Australian shares recovered from early losses as investors considered the positive impact of a high US dollar on exporters. Despite weak US inflation data and expectations of a rate hike, the S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.3% down, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index reached an all-time high. The benchmark has risen 3.5% in the past month, narrowing losses.

site_title: China's Jan-Feb fiscal income growth slows to 3.2% y-o-y
summary: China's fiscal income growth slowed to 3.2% year-over-year in January and February, below the 8.6% gain in the same period of 2014. Meanwhile, fiscal expenditure growth accelerated to 10.5% during the same period, from an 8.2% rise in spending in 2014.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC places Vard's rating under review
summary: OCBC Investment Research has placed its rating on Vard Holdings under review after the shipbuilder terminated two contracts due to a customer's insolvency in Germany. Vard received a 10% instalment for one of the vessels, which it expects to sell at a lower price to cover construction costs. The rating review comes after Vard announced the termination of the contracts, with one PSV scheduled for delivery in 2016. The company's share price remained unchanged at S$0.52.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat ahead of Fed meeting; TSMC down
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Monday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, with the main TAIEX index down 0.1% at 9,566.27. TSMC, the world's top contract chip maker, fell 0.7% and contributed to the decline. Investors are cautious due to uncertainty surrounding the Fed's meeting, which may impact global markets and Taiwan's electronics sector.

site_title: China's ambitious IT sector lays claim to global role
summary: China's IT sector is gaining global recognition, showcasing its capabilities as a tech superpower. The country's booming smartphone market and high number of internet users are driving innovation, with over 600 Chinese firms participating in Germany's CeBIT fair. Chinese companies such as Alibaba, Lenovo, and Huawei are demonstrating their latest software and hardware advancements. Despite concerns over security and espionage, industry experts believe China's IT sector is ready to lead globally, with a focus on integrated circuits, cloud computing, and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales jump in February, led by surging SUVs
summary: Australian new vehicle sales surged 2.9% in February, with SUVs leading the way, accounting for a 10.5% increase to a record 33,516 units sold. This growth reverses a decline seen in January and surpasses February 2014 sales. Passenger vehicle sales dropped 0.9%, while truck sales decreased 0.3%. The increase is attributed to falling petrol prices, possibly contributing to the surge in SUV demand.

site_title: SIA and CAG extend Changi Transit Programme partnership
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Changi Airport Group (CAG) have extended the Changi Transit Programme partnership until March 31, 2016. The programme allows SIA and SilkAir passengers transiting through Changi to redeem Changi Dollar Vouchers worth S$20 or S$40 at over 510 retail outlets. Passengers connecting on select Air New Zealand flights can also redeem vouchers for one-time access to the Ambassador Transit Lounge for up to four hours.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.29 points to 1776.46. Losers outnumbered gainers 103 to 97, and volume was 130 million lots worth RM35 million.

images.alt_text: Malaysia share prices opened lower on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.29 points to 1776.46.

site_title: China investigates auto executive, Yunnan official for graft
summary: China is investigating Chairman of FAW Group Corp, Xu Jianyi, and Yunnan official Qiu He for "serious violation of party discipline and laws", the Communist Party said. The investigation is part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has brought down scores of senior officials since taking office in 2012. Xu, 61, and Qiu, 58, hold high-ranking positions and are accused of corruption, with Qiu being investigated for urban construction projects in Kunming. The investigation is the latest in Xi's crackdown on graft.

site_title: South Korea' February exports revised down 3.3% year on year
summary: South Korea's February exports fell 3.3% year-over-year, with imports dropping 19.7% from a year earlier, according to revised customs data. The data was initially reported as preliminary figures on March 1. The decline in exports is largely unchanged from the initial report. The South Korean trade chief is seeking a "landing zone" in US trade talks, indicating a continued focus on trade negotiations.

site_title: 7.1% hike in Singapore non-executive directors' fee in FY13/14: Hay Group
summary: Non-executive directors in Singapore-listed companies saw a 7.1% increase in median average director's fee in FY13/2014, rising to S$60,000 per annum. This growth was driven by medium-sized companies (market cap: S$500m-S$3b), with a 16% increase to S$75,000. Large-sized companies raised fees by 15% to S$142,000, while small-sized companies saw a 7% increase to S$53,000.

images.alt_text: Non-executive directors (NEDs) at Singapore-listed companies received an increase of 7.1 per cent in the median of the average director's fee - or S$60,000 per annum - in the financial year 2013/2014, compared to S$56,000 in the previous financial year, global management consultancy Hay Group said in a report on Monday.

site_title: Singapore's potential delay of tighter consumer debt rule is credit negative for banks: Moody's
summary: Moody's warns that Singapore's potential delay in implementing tighter consumer debt rules could be credit negative for banks, particularly DBS, OCBC, and UOB, due to their large consumer loan exposures. The rule, set to limit unsecured consumer debt to 12 months of income, would require borrowers to pay down excess borrowing over a grace period. A delay would allow highly leveraged borrowers to increase their borrowing, potentially worsening the quality of unsecured consumer loans and negatively affecting bank asset quality.

images.alt_text: Last Tuesday, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said it was reviewing and might delay the scheduled 1 June 2015 rollout of tighter macro-prudential measures to limit consumer debt.

site_title: Greek finance minister says liquidity problems "insignificant": German TV
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis stated that Greece's liquidity problems are "insignificant," while pledging to repay its debts. Varoufakis suggested a debt restructuring as the best way for Greece to repay its debts, and refused to discuss World War Two reparations to Greece from Germany. Tensions between Greece and Germany have escalated, with Greece submitting a formal protest to the German Foreign Ministry, accusing Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble of insulting his Greek counterpart.

site_title: Loss of UK shops up nearly threefold in 2014: report
summary: UK shops saw a nearly threefold increase in closures in 2014 compared to 2013, with 5,839 outlets shutting down versus 4,852 openings, resulting in a net reduction of 987 shops. Traditional shops like clothes and shoe stores closed 765 more, while service retailers declined by 457. Leisure stores, charity shops, and other categories saw gains, but the overall trend highlights the impact of online sales and changing consumer habits on the high street.

site_title: Oil hits 6-year low, dragging energy stocks down; dollar weakens
summary: Oil prices hit a 6-year low, falling to $44.39 a barrel, as the US dollar weakened and energy stocks declined. The US Federal Reserve may remove the word "patient" from its statement, giving it more flexibility on raising interest rates. The International Energy Agency warned of a potential surplus that could strain storage capacity. Energy shares, including those of South Korea's S-Oil Corp. and Japan's Inpex Corp., dropped 4.1% and 3.6%, respectively.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vard, Singapore Press Holdings
summary: Vard Holdings has terminated two shipbuilding contracts due to a customer affiliate filing for insolvency in Germany. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has invested S$2 million in a data analysis firm, DC Frontiers, which owns the Handshakes app.

site_title: Australia: Shares narrow losses as attention shifts to high US dollar benefits
summary: Australian shares narrowed losses as investors focused on the potential benefits of a high US dollar for exporters. Stocks initially fell 1% due to weak US inflation data and concerns about a rate hike, but recovered as investors weighed the positive impact on exporters. Continuing weakness in oil and iron ore prices also weighed on Australian resources firms. The market ultimately closed with losses of around 0.2%.

images.alt_text: Australian shares clawed back hefty early losses on Monday as investors looked past concerns about the impact of a higher US dollar and pondered the likely positive impact on exporters.

site_title: Iceland government's move to reject EU talks sparks protest
summary: Icelanders staged the largest demonstration since 2008 to protest the government's decision to reject EU talks, citing underhand manner. About 7,000 people protested in Reykjavik, with opposition parties claiming the government made the decision without sufficient consultation. Iceland had started talks on joining the EU in 2009, but popular support has waned since the current government came to power. The opposition argues that parliament, not the current government, can withdraw the EU membership mandate.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slightly higher in early trade
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.25% in early trade on Monday, reaching 19,301.97, as investors sought gains ahead of expectations for higher corporate earnings and wages. The Nikkei 225 index surpassed 19,000 points for the first time in 15 years, driven by the Bank of Japan's super-easy monetary policy. In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.82% in New York due to renewed anxiety over falling oil prices and the rising US dollar.

site_title: Vietnam targets record year of stake sales in state companies
summary: Vietnam plans to sell a record amount of shares in state-owned companies this year, with 280 companies on the list, aiming to accelerate a program that has repeatedly missed targets. The government aims to spur economic growth to a four-year high of 6.2% this year and reduce bad debt to below 3% by the end of the year. To quicken the process, the government will simplify privatization procedures and consider simultaneous IPOs and listings. The stake-sale process will also change this year, with companies selling shares to strategic partners rather than going through an IPO first.

site_title: Land Rover, China Mobile criticised by China state broadcaster
summary: China's state-run television, CCTV, criticized Jaguar Land Rover for allegedly failing to address gearbox problems in Range Rover Evoque SUVs, car dealerships for inflating repair costs, and China Mobile for enabling fraudsters to use fake caller ID numbers. The allegations also targeted car dealerships for brands including Nissan, Volkswagen, and Mercedes for overstating problems and overcharging for repairs. China Mobile and the companies have apologized and vowed to investigate and resolve the issues, while China has strengthened consumer protection laws to combat such issues.

images.alt_text: China's state-run television reported that Tata Motors Ltd's Jaguar Land Rover hasn't handled an alleged fault properly, car dealerships inflate repair costs and China Mobile Ltd enables fraudsters.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens lower after weaker US markets on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened lower on Monday, down 0.75 points to 3,362.02, following weaker US markets on Friday. Top gainers included UOB, while top losers included DBS and OCBC. The STI has underperformed since the start of the year due to profit-taking and concerns about an economic slowdown and higher credit costs.

site_title: Asking prices for London homes fall amid UK election jitters
summary: Asking prices for London homes declined 0.4% in March, marking the first decline in three years, due to affordability constraints and election jitters. The average London house price fell to £580,308, while values in England and Wales rose 1%. The slowdown was attributed to near-record house prices, lending curbs, and a "mansion tax" prospect. Demand continues to outstrip supply, with buyers putting down larger downpayments, and pressure builds in the buy-to-let sector.

site_title: UK teens 'believed to be travelling to Syria' held
summary: British police have detained three male teenagers, aged 17 and 19, believed to be traveling to Syria. The trio, from northwest London, were intercepted by Turkish authorities in Istanbul and deported back to Britain, where they are being held on suspicion of preparing acts of terror. Initial data suggests they were headed to join the Islamic State group. This comes as an international police hunt continues for three east London schoolgirls who traveled to Syria.

site_title: Anti-Rousseff protests draw 1.5 million people across Brazil
summary: Brazil witnessed massive anti-Rousseff protests on March 15, 2015, with approximately 1.5 million people taking to the streets across the country, calling for the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff. The demonstrations, which took place in 83 cities and towns, were the largest since 2013's World Cup protests. Rousseff faces growing crises, including a massive corruption scandal at Petrobras, economic woes, and rising inflation. The protests, which included chants of "Out Dilma, out PT," mirrored those in 2013, with some calling for military intervention to end the ruling Workers' Party's 12-year rule.

site_title: New Zealand services activity eases in February
summary: New Zealand's services sector activity eased in February, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) falling to 55.6 from 57.8 in January. Despite growth in all five sub-indices, employment and stocks and inventories slowed, while sales rose. The slowdown follows a companion manufacturing survey showing a pick-up in activity last month.

site_title: Purchase of RadLink by Parkway, Fortis blocked: Singapore competition panel
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) blocked the proposed acquisition of RadLink-Asia and its subsidiaries by Parkway Holdings, citing substantial lessening of competition and infringement of the Competition Act. The acquisition, which would have given Parkway control of the radiopharmaceutical market in Singapore, was deemed to have moderate to high entry barriers and weak bargaining power for customers. Both parties, Parkway and Fortis, have announced that the acquisition is off. The CCS stated that no new supplier would enter the market in the next two to three years to compete with the merged entity.

site_title: China becomes world's number three arms exporter: study
summary: China has surpassed Germany and France to become the world's third-largest arms exporter, according to a Stockholm-based think-tank. The volume of the global arms trade rose 16% from 2010 to 2014, with the US maintaining a 31% lead. China's sales increased 143% from the previous five years, mainly to Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Myanmar. The US had a diverse clientele, while Russia's top client was India. The data reflects arms deliveries, not financial value, and the trade remains about one-third below its post-war peak.

site_title: S.Korea's top firms to lift investment, recruit fewer workers in 2015
summary: South Korea's 30 largest conglomerates plan to increase investment by 16.5% in 2015, reaching 136.4 trillion won (S$167 billion), but will hire fewer new employees due to increased labor costs. The number of new recruits is expected to fall 6.3% to 121,801 employees, while the total number of employees will increase slightly to 1,180,651. This is attributed to the extension of retirement age and higher labor costs due to increased base wages.

images.alt_text: South Korea's 30 biggest conglomerates will increase investment 16.5 per cent in 2015 from a year ago, but will hire fewer new employees due to increased labour costs, business lobby group the Federation of Korean Industries (FKI) said on Monday.

site_title: China's luxury big spenders: young, trendy and not so rich
summary: China's luxury market is shifting towards "HENRYs" (high earners, not rich yet), who prioritize individualism and affordability over ostentatious spending. Younger consumers, aged 25-35, are driving demand for niche labels like Celine and 3.1 Phillip Lim, as well as affordable brands like Tory Burch and Longines. In contrast, pricier luxury brands have seen a decline in sales due to economic slowdown and government scrutiny of official excesses. Social media and online retail platforms are fueling this shift, offering consumers greater access to a wider range of products.

site_title: Hamilton dominates F1 opener as only 11 cars finish race
summary: Lewis Hamilton dominated the Australian Grand Prix, leading from start to finish and beating Nico Rosberg by 1.3 seconds. Only 11 cars completed the 58-lap race due to mechanical issues and injuries. Mercedes secured their eighth straight victory and 20th consecutive race with at least one driver on the podium. Hamilton, 30, has now won seven of the last eight races, while Rosberg vowed to beat him throughout the season. Sebastian Vettel finished third in his Ferrari debut, as Ferrari finished fourth in the constructors' championship.

site_title: Yahoo sees 'end to end' email encryption by year-end
summary: Yahoo plans to introduce "end to end" email encryption by the end of the year, allowing users to send encrypted messages with a single click. The new security feature, developed in collaboration with Google, aims to boost privacy protection for users concerned about government surveillance or hacking. The encryption software is being released for developers now and will be rolled out to users in the coming months, with a goal of making encryption accessible to non-technical users.

images.alt_text: Yahoo said on Sunday it plans to introduce "end to end encryption" for email this year to boost privacy protection for users concerned about snooping from governments or hackers.

site_title: Country Garden to launch Jakarta project this year
summary: Country Garden, a Hong Kong-listed developer, is accelerating its pace in Indonesia and exploring land sites in Jakarta and Surabaya. The company is gunning for its first residential project in Indonesia this year, targeting 1,000 units, and has set up a representative office in Thailand to scour for opportunities. Despite a delay in the Forest City project in Singapore, Country Garden's group deputy general manager Liu Zhenyu emphasized the company's fulfillment of strict requirements laid down by the government before launching the project.

site_title: China consumer show targets Volkswagen, Nissan
summary: China's annual consumer rights day TV show criticized several major carmakers, including Volkswagen, Nissan, and Daimler, for overselling repairs and spare parts to drivers. The show also targeted Jaguar Land Rover for gearbox problems. The criticism comes as China is the world's top auto market, and media scrutiny can significantly impact reputations and sales. This marks the latest in a series of high-profile criticisms of major brands, including Apple's 2013 apology for its after-sales service.

site_title: China slowdown concern spurs record option hedges on A-share ETF
summary: Investors are increasingly hedging against potential losses in Chinese stocks amid concerns of an economic slowdown. Demand for options to sell the largest US ETF tracking China's mainland market has reached a record high, with investors pulling $34 million from the fund in two weeks. Economists predict a decline of 11% in the Shanghai Composite Index by the end of 2015, citing slower economic growth, a weak property market, and overcapacity issues. Despite China's easing measures, investors remain skeptical about the market's sustainability.

site_title: Israel immigration seen fueling real estate boom amid shortage
summary: Israel is anticipating a surge in European immigration amid rising anti-Semitic attacks, which could exacerbate the country's real estate boom and housing shortage. The number of Western Europeans moving to Israel nearly doubled last year, driven largely by French Jews seeking security. With the government struggling to control housing prices, Prime Minister Netanyahu's call for European Jews to move to Israel may fuel further demand, further straining the supply of homes and driving up prices.

site_title: In China, trust firms shift, rather than reduce, shadow banking risk
summary: China's trust firms, with $2.2 trillion in assets, are redirecting cash into capital markets and OTC instruments, rather than reducing shadow banking risk. This shift, in response to a clampdown on lending to risky projects, means a significant chunk of shadow banking risk is migrating. The trusts are acting more like hedge funds or lightly regulated mutual funds, blunting regulators' efforts to curb the risk.

images.alt_text: China's trust firms, with total assets of US$2.2 trillion, are shifting more cash into frothy capital markets and over-the-counter (OTC) instruments instead of loans - blunting regulators' efforts to reduce shadow banking risk.

site_title: Disgraced former top Chinese officer dies of cancer: Xinhua
summary: Former Chinese top military officer Xu Caihou died of cancer on Sunday, sparing the government an embarrassing trial. Xu, a vice chairman of the Central Military Commission and the ruling Communist Party's Politburo, had confessed to taking massive bribes in exchange for promotions. His death means the government won't have to prosecute him, but a second former top military officer, Guo Boxiong, is still under investigation on suspicion of corruption. The government will still deal with Xu's "illegal gains" according to the law.

site_title: Li dismisses worries over HK policy tightening
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang has dismissed concerns that Beijing will tighten controls over Hong Kong, stating that the country's leaders will not "easily" change the policy towards the former British colony. Li reaffirmed the government's commitment to the "one country, two systems" policy, which gives Hong Kong a separate legal system and greater freedoms. Beijing had previously considered introducing a patriotic curriculum and limiting democratic reforms in Hong Kong, but Li's comments suggest these plans are on hold.

site_title: Merkel urges closer tech ties with rising IT giant China
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel emphasized the importance of high-tech cooperation with China, citing the country's growing IT sector and its potential for innovation. Merkel opened the CeBIT fair in Hanover, where over 600 Chinese companies showcased their tech marvels, marking a significant step in strengthening business ties between the two nations. China's Premier Li Keqiang praised Germany's digital strategies, expressing hope for further cooperation and a "path of win-win cooperation" in the world.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Sunday urged closer high-tech cooperation with China as she opened a major IT business fair where the Asian giant is the official partner country.

site_title: Celebrating Women's Day
summary: Over 1,000 Citi staff and their families celebrated International Women's Day on March 12, reaffirming the company's commitment to promoting gender equality.

site_title: Uber faces another suit in US over breach of drivers' personal data
summary: Uber faces a proposed class action lawsuit over a 2014 data breach affecting 50,000 drivers, alleging the company failed to prevent the breach and waited too long to disclose it. The lawsuit claims Uber violated a California law requiring companies to safeguard employee personal information. The suit seeks over $5 million in damages. This is the latest in a series of legal woes for Uber, including claims from drivers, passengers, and the government.

site_title: Oil slumps to six-year low as US production seen filling tanks
summary: Oil prices fell to a six-year low, trading 2.8% lower in New York, amid speculation of record US crude inventories straining storage capacity. The International Energy Agency predicted US oil production will rise in 2015, driven by rising supply. Despite demand strengthening, prices remain low, with Saudi Arabia citing a strengthening demand. Oil capped its fourth weekly loss, with prices nearly 50% lower last year due to a global glut.

images.alt_text: Oil fell for a fifth day, trading at the lowest intraday price in six years, amid speculation that record crude inventories in the US may begin to strain the country's storage capacity.

site_title: Low interest rates, cheaper oil helping eurozone recover: Societe Generale
summary: Societe Generale's deputy CEO Severin Cabannes says low interest rates and low oil prices are helping the eurozone recover, with GDP growth forecasted at 1.5% for 2015. The plunge in the euro is boosting exports, while a cheaper currency is increasing European export-competitiveness. The bank is also expanding its Asian business, allocating more capital and resources to help multinationals with trade finance and infrastructure development. Asia's contribution to Societe Generale's global finance business has doubled in five years, with the bank aiming for 8-10% annual growth in the sector.

site_title: Basel watchdog shifts emphasis to fine-tuning bank rules
summary: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has shifted its focus from implementing new banking rules to fine-tuning them, according to its secretary-general William Coen. The new framework, established since the global financial crisis, aims to strengthen capital reserves and reduce risk. However, Coen stated that the focus is now on finalizing rules on leverage ratios and capital floors, and ensuring that the regulations interact effectively. This marks a shift from the intense regulatory focus of the past few years, with Coen acknowledging "regulation fatigue" among banks and regulators.

site_title: Greek state not facing a cash shortage: PM Tsipras
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras denied the country is facing a cash shortage, stating there is "absolutely no problem with liquidity." The government is set to issue 1 billion euros in treasury bills to meet debt repayments, including 900 million euros to the IMF and 1.6 billion euros in treasury bills. Greece has not drawn loans from its EU-IMF rescue package, but is locked in talks on a revised reform plan. Analysts have described the move to direct pension funds into state debt purchases as "scraping the barrel," amid concerns of a potential disorderly exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Australia's RBA working on replacement for BBSW benchmark
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is working on a new interest rate benchmark to replace the scandal-tainted bank bill swap rate (BBSW), which has been compromised by charges of manipulation by banks. The new benchmark, likely based on overnight indexed swap (OIS) rates, aims to create a robust risk-free interest rate for the local market. The RBA and ASIC expect to see progress on this in the coming months, with the goal of moving products towards referencing a risk-free benchmark rather than a credit benchmark like BBSW.

site_title: UK backing for Islamic bonds just starting with Emirates deal
summary: Britain is backing Islamic bonds with a deal with Emirates airline, the UK's first non-Muslim nation to sell a sovereign Shariah-compliant bond. The UK Export Finance will guarantee the bond, valued at $1 billion, and plans to extend this to other industries. This move is part of the UK's commitment to developing its role in Islamic finance, which has grown to $1.8 trillion in assets over the past five years. The UK government aims to increase transparency and availability of Islamic finance products, with a feasibility study planned for a Shariah-compliant liquidity facility for lenders.

site_title: CT scan, other tests equally effective for heart patients
summary: Researchers at the American College of Cardiology found that standard stress tests and CT scans are equally effective in diagnosing heart problems and preventing death and heart attacks. A CT scan used for initial diagnosis reduces the need for subsequent tests. This discovery may lead to more efficient and cost-effective treatment plans for heart patients.

site_title: CeBIT showcases China's rise as a high-tech heavyweight
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is set to open the CeBIT fair in Hanover, where over 600 Chinese companies are showcasing their tech marvels, marking China's rise as a high-tech heavyweight. The event aims to cement economic ties between Germany and China, with China's IT market expected to grow rapidly and have significant influence on the global market. However, human rights concerns surrounding China's treatment of critics, including jailed Nobel Prize laureate Liu Xiaobo, are also expected to be highlighted during the fair.

site_title: Invest in Asian frontier markets, says IIF
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) recommends investing in Asian "frontier" markets, including Bangladesh, Mongolia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Vietnam, citing China's support and higher growth rates compared to emerging markets. These economies are increasingly influenced by China, which may lead to outperformance of Asian frontier markets over other regions.

site_title: US banks regain confidence, increase dividends
summary: US banks have regained confidence, increasing dividend payouts as a result of passing the Federal Reserve stress test. Seven major financial firms have increased shareholder payouts, with financial stocks now accounting for 15.1% of the S&P 500's dividends, surpassing technology companies. This marks a significant recovery from the 2008 financial crisis, with financial stocks contributing 30% of S&P 500 dividends in 2007. The increased confidence is attributed to the banks' improved capital position and investors' renewed faith in the industry.

site_title: China-led Asia investment bank gains traction with more support
summary: China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has gained international support with the UK and Australia expressing interest in joining, despite US and Japanese opposition. The AIIB, set to open by the end of the year, will compete with the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, posing a challenge to Western-dominated development institutions. China has pledged $50 billion in initial capital, with the Silk Road Fund also expected to play a significant role. The AIIB's impact on the multilateral development landscape is seen as significant, with potential implications for infrastructure financing and global economic development.

site_title: UK's 'Pension Freedom Day' could herald confusion for months
summary: The UK's "Pension Freedom Day" is set to take effect on April 6, allowing pension-holders to choose how to spend their pension pots without buying a fixed-rate annuity. Industry players expect some retirees to opt out of annuities, while others may use the funds to pay off debts or make discretionary purchases. This reform could lead to a significant shift in the sector, with some predicting widespread changes in retirement planning. The move is expected to bring flexibility to pension-holders, but also raises concerns about potential financial instability.

site_title: Dollar-buying momentum trumps weak US data
summary: The US dollar reached a 12-year high against the euro on Friday, despite weak US inflation and consumer sentiment data. The euro fell 1.60% to US$1.04625, while the dollar was little changed against the yen. Analysts attribute the dollar's rise to positioning ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting and a lack of yield advantage, despite low front-end yields. This move contradicts expectations of an anticipated June interest rate increase by the Fed, and a potential dollar pullback is expected next week.

site_title: Live stream app Meerkat a Twitter sensation
summary: Meerkat, a live streaming app that integrates with Twitter, has become a sensation since its release on the App Store. The app allows users to launch live video streams with a single touch of a button, and has been adopted by journalists, politicians, and social media celebrities. Twitter has taken notice, announcing a deal to buy the maker of a rival video streaming app, Periscope, for between $50 million and $100 million. However, Meerkat's access to some Twitter features has been cut, raising concerns about the app's future.

site_title: Commodities mostly drop on soaring dollar, China woes
summary: Commodity prices dropped last week due to a strong US dollar and weak data from China, a major consumer of raw materials. The dollar reached a 12-year peak against the euro, further exacerbating commodity weakness. Oil prices fell, with world oil prices dropping sharply, while gold, silver, and other metals also declined. Analysts attribute the decline to dollar strength and the ongoing global supply glut.

site_title: Bulgari's Octo watch hits the sweet spot
summary: Bulgari's CEO Jean-Christophe Babin declares the brand's Octo watch campaign a success, having left a lasting impression on consumers. The campaign, which ran for three years, aimed to establish the Octo as a watchmaking icon, rather than a sales-driven effort. As a result, sales of the Octo are "stunning" and the brand has successfully integrated the watch line into its overall business. Babin also highlights the potential for growth in the watch segment, aiming to enter the top 5 luxury watch brands in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Mr Babin says Bulgari has also succeeded in making the jewellery and watch business complementary

site_title: FOMC meeting to take centrestage this week
summary: The Singapore market is expected to remain volatile this week due to the FOMC meeting, which will influence interest rates and affect global markets. Despite the uncertainty, the STI has shown a tendency to follow Wall Street's movements, with last week's movements mirroring US stock performance. The Fed's decision on interest rates will be closely watched, and even if the news is favorable to stocks, a persistent flight to safety has led to high bond prices, including negative yields in some European countries.

site_title: Long-term use of AstraZeneca drug brings benefits, risks
summary: AstraZeneca's Brilinta has shown a 16% reduction in death, heart attack, or stroke risk in patients with a history of past cardiovascular events after long-term use. The study, involving 21,000 patients, also found a lower risk of fatal bleeding. While doctors must balance the benefits against the risk of bleeding, the findings are expected to boost Brilinta sales, potentially reaching $3.5 billion annually by 2023.

site_title: Strong advocate for IT in business
summary: DBS Bank's group executive and head of group technology & operations, David Gledhill, is a strong advocate for IT in business, bringing over 25 years of experience in the financial services industry. He oversees 5,000 staff and leads transformation initiatives to drive resilience, innovation, and customer experience. Gledhill, a British citizen, holds a degree in computing and electronics from the University of Durham, and has held senior positions with JPMorgan and DBS since 2008.

site_title: Share buybacks' uptrend tapers off
summary: SHARE buybacks by listed companies have slowed down since the start of the year, following a surge in December. Analysts believe share buybacks may not be the best use of a company's cash and may not effectively support share prices. Although a well-defined share buyback strategy may still be viewed positively by shareholders, the trend may be beneficial for investors.

site_title: Using IT to be nimble and innovative
summary: DBS Bank's managing director, David Gledhill, emphasizes the importance of harnessing data to add value to customers quickly and seamlessly, enabling companies to increase their reach while maintaining costs. The bank has over 2 million internet banking users and 1 million mobile banking users, with over 130 online services and 1 million daily transactions. Gledhill believes that a holistic view of IT can help companies extend their reach without breaking the bank, as DBS continues to expand its online banking services to meet unmet needs in the market.

site_title: Asian art powers on in Hong Kong
summary: Art Basel Hong Kong (ABHK) has kicked off with a strong showing of Asian art, with many blue-chip works selling for five-figure US dollar price tags. Asian artists, including Do Ho Suh, Nam June Paik, and Zhang Enli, were among the top sellers, signaling a shift in favor of Asian art. The fair, which features 233 top galleries from 37 countries, has also seen notable sales of works by Western artists, including Chris Ofili and Yayoi Kusama. Despite Hong Kong's recent political turmoil, the VIP preview went smoothly, with many artworks incorporating themes of revolution and democracy.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Fostering future growth
summary: Singapore is poised to excel in various growth areas beyond the five clusters outlined in the 2015 Budget speech. Data & Analytics is a promising sector, with Cisco aiming to become an international hub, enabling near-real-time insights and driving innovation. Traditional medicine and manufacturing are also potential areas of growth, with companies like Tiger Balm and Infor Asia-Pacific Japan & Middle East excelling in these sectors. The government should adopt an IP-centric approach, focusing on developing intellectual property to push Singapore to greater heights of excellence and economic success.

site_title: Soaring food imports leave countries vulnerable
summary: Global grain imports have increased more than five-fold over the past 50 years, with over a third of countries relying on imports for at least 25% of their grain supply. This dependence on international markets creates vulnerability, especially during price fluctuations or export bans. The trend is expected to continue due to population growth, expanding appetites for meat, and environmental pressures. To mitigate this, governments should protect farmland and water resources, promoting homegrown production over reliance on global markets.

site_title: Keppel Reit, Mirvac mark topping out of Perth tower
summary: Keppel Reit and Mirvac Group celebrated the topping out of the Old Treasury Building Office Tower in Perth, a 35-storey office tower with an estimated 331,000 square feet of net lettable area. The project is wholly pre-committed to the government of Western Australia for a 25-year lease with options for another 25 years. Keppel Reit acquired a 50% stake in the development in 2013, and the completion of this project will mark the company's fifth office tower in Australia, set to be finished in the middle of the year.

images.alt_text: The 35-storey Old Treasury Building Office Tower will be completed in the middle of this year.

site_title: Egypt sets out US$20b tourism growth plan
summary: Egypt aims to generate US$20 billion in tourism revenue by 2020 by attracting 20 million visitors, with new tourism minister Khaled Ramy unveiling a US$20 billion growth plan. The plan includes creating two new resorts and hiring a private company to run a three-year advertising campaign. The goal is to counteract the negative news that has discouraged tourists in recent years, with tourism numbers rising 15% this year.

site_title: Stamford Law to go global after full merger with top US law firm (Amended)
summary: Singapore's sixth-largest law firm, Stamford Law Corporation, will fully merge with US-based Morgan Lewis & Bockius LLP on April 1, creating a Singapore law practice, Morgan Lewis Stamford LLC. The combined practice will have 28 offices globally, including Singapore, and offer both foreign law and full Singapore law counsel. This merger aims to make Singapore a global legal hub, providing opportunities for Singapore lawyers to work on complex cross-border transactions and contribute to the growth of the country's international dispute resolution centre.

site_title: Stimulus will come if necessary: Premier Li
summary: China's new growth target of around 7% is considered challenging, with the economy facing considerable downward pressure. Prime Minister Li Keqiang stated that the government will not hesitate to implement stimulus measures if employment is threatened, indicating a willingness to loosen monetary policy. Li also emphasized the need for sustainable economic growth, painful reforms, and increased investment in small entrepreneurship. The government plans to ease business conditions for small companies and will continue to pursue environmental reforms, despite acknowledging current efforts to fight pollution are insufficient.

site_title: PwC to launch cyber security centre
summary: PwC Singapore is launching its Cyber Security Centre of Excellence to serve the business community locally and regionally. The centre will provide research, training, and skill development in cyber security, aiming to expand its cyber practice from 40 to 300 staff over the next three years. The centre's launch coincides with the start of the Singapore government's Cyber Security Agency on April 1. PwC Singapore plans to invest S$50 million in capability and technological development, emphasizing the need for a robust culture and mindset to manage digital risks and prevent cyber threats.

site_title: Gender diversity: make it happen
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

International Women's Day marked a growing awareness of gender equality, with a global need for more women in senior leadership positions. Only 11% of global boards have women, with Singapore lagging behind at 8.3%. Research shows companies with women on boards see 14% net income growth, compared to 10% without. To make diversity happen, corporate leadership must take action beyond a one-off effort, focusing on talent management and succession planning. Top-down leadership is crucial, and creating conditions for both men and women to thrive is key to achieving gender balance in organizations.

site_title: What you tweet might tell Yellen it is time to raise rates
summary: The Federal Reserve is exploring the use of non-traditional data sources to improve the accuracy and timeliness of its economic forecasts. The data, including Google search terms, social media posts, and labor market indicators, may provide a more complete picture of the economy. Fed economists are reviewing research papers and working with private companies to gather this data, but concerns about quality and reliability remain. The goal is to shorten the time lag between economic events and the Fed's understanding of them, but officials are cautious about relying on private data due to sponsorship issues and sampling concerns.

site_title: Japan keen on KL-S'pore high-speed train project
summary: Japan has conducted high-level talks with Malaysia over the proposed high-speed train project between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe requested a meeting with Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to discuss Japan's potential involvement in the project, which would be the first time a foreign country has been involved in the project. The talks aim to explore the possibility of Japan's rail companies participating in the project.

site_title: Oil industry must join US railroads to boost train safety: regulator
summary: US rail regulator Sarah Feinberg says the oil industry must take responsibility for train safety after a string of oil train derailments. The industry must control the volatility of its cargo, as fuel from North Dakota's Bakken energy fields is particularly light and volatile. A national safety plan for oil trains, set to be finalized in May, will require tougher tankers and advanced braking systems. The plan will not address the fuel's inherent dangers, and officials will identify publicly the energy companies that supplied the crude oil involved in accidents.

site_title: Rate-hike fears could continue to cloud the markets
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, potentially impacting the stock market. The Fed, under Chair Janet Yellen, has hinted at shifting from rate cuts to hikes, sparking concerns about a potential end to the bull market in equities. The US dollar is strengthening, making it more expensive for corporations to service bonds and driving up mortgage costs. Analysts predict the Nasdaq Composite will continue to outperform sectors like financials and technology, despite the uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Even after last week's rout, the Nasdaq Composite is less than 5 per cent from the heights of 2000. The Nasdaq has approached that summit in the face of considerable scepticism.

site_title: Aid heads for Vanuatu after devastating Pacific cyclone
summary: Aid efforts are underway in Vanuatu after Cyclone Pam devastated the Pacific island nation, causing widespread destruction and killing at least 8 people. The category 5 cyclone, which brought winds of over 300 kph, left many homes and buildings destroyed, with residents struggling to access basic necessities like shelter, food, and medical supplies. International aid, including shipments from Australia, New Zealand, and the UN, has begun to arrive, with relief officials warning of a potentially catastrophic situation, particularly on the densely populated island of Tanna.

images.alt_text: A boy stands near trees uprooted by Cyclone Pam near his home in Port Vila on Sunday.

site_title: Sinking under debt, Kansai airport privatisation presents big test for Abe
summary: Japan's Kansai International Airport privatization deal is at risk due to a disputed US$18 billion price tag. The government agency running the bid refuses to lower the price, despite investors balking at the cost, which is six times that of a comparable deal in Portugal. The deal, part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to cut debt, aims to create a market for infrastructure investment in Japan and abroad. The sale includes the rights to operate the airport and a smaller Osaka airport, with a debt transfer of nearly US$10 billion to a private investor.

site_title: Vard Holdings terminates 2 contracts linked to insolvent customers
summary: Shipbuilder Vard Holdings has terminated two shipbuilding contracts for a platform supply vessel due to insolvency of a customer, E.R. Offshore. The company expects to sell the vessels at a price covering construction costs minus a prepayment received. This termination is not expected to significantly impact the company's earnings per share for the 2015 financial year.

site_title: Thousands plan protest in Frankfurt against policies blamed on ECB
summary: Thousands plan to protest in Frankfurt on Wednesday against European Central Bank policies they blame for austerity measures, coinciding with the ECB's new headquarters inauguration. The gathering follows protests in Cyprus and dissatisfaction with the ECB's role in eurozone politics.

site_title: FDA toughens rules on reusable medical devices
summary: The US FDA has issued new requirements for testing procedures of reusable medical devices, including duodenoscopes, following two deaths in a California hospital linked to deadly bacteria. The changes apply to new devices, not those already on the market, and manufacturers must submit data on cleaning and disinfection procedures. The agency has faced pressure to take stronger action due to numerous hospital infections, with 500,000 procedures performed annually in the US. Officials say the stricter guidelines may not be in broad practice immediately, but could apply to devices hard to clean.

images.alt_text: Officials at the Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles reported that five patients had fallen ill and two had died from what they said were contaminated scopes.

site_title: Enjoying a balanced budget, Germany will boost spending: govt sources
summary: Germany's government plans to increase spending on infrastructure and foreign aid over the next five years, following its first balanced budget in nearly half a century. The budget will be boosted by 4.2 billion euros, with spending expected to rise by 3.3% in 2016 and 4.1% in 2019. The government will also increase foreign aid to 8.3 billion euros and provide more funding for security agencies. Tax revenues are expected to rise, making debt issuance unnecessary, and the government aims to maintain a balanced budget.

site_title: How European oil giants are profiting from slump
summary: European oil giants BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Total are benefiting from the current oil slump due to their significant trading operations. As the largest oil traders in the world, they can generate higher returns by storing cheap oil and selling it at higher prices later. Trading profits already rose in the fourth quarter of 2014, and analysts expect the companies to beat estimates despite lower oil prices. The companies' trading arms are expected to report healthy earnings in 2015, taking advantage of increased volatility and contango in the market.

images.alt_text: Europe's largest oil companies are gaining support from an unlikely source as they confront the industry's worst slump since the financial crisis: lower oil prices.

site_title: Buying remains high, but directors' selling plunges
summary: In the second week of March, buying activity on the Singapore Exchange increased, with 30 companies recording 67 purchases worth S$15.6 million. Selling activity plummeted, with only one firm disposing of shares worth S$0.06 million. Buyback activity also rose for the second straight week, with 19 companies posting 69 repurchases worth S$53.4 million. Several significant buyback and director purchases were recorded, including first-time buys by HTL International, Karin Technology, and Wing Tai Holdings, as well as purchases by directors in UG Healthcare Corporation, TEE International, and Hong Fok Corporation.

site_title: Samsung to focus on premium products
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to focus on premium products, using more metal casings, slim designs, and high-definition displays in its mobile devices to regain market share. The company aims to consolidate its leadership in the premium market and strengthen competitiveness. Samsung will also expand into new areas such as business-to-business, smart home, and health devices. The company has invested over $21 billion in capital expenditure this year to increase revenue from supplying chips and displays to rivals.

site_title: Li: HK shouldn't worry about China tightening grip
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reassured Hong Kong residents that China won't tighten its grip on the former British colony, despite concerns over a proposed plan granting Beijing control over the city's first election of its chief executive. Li stated that the government is committed to granting Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy, as agreed upon in the Basic Law. The plan, which includes vetting candidates for the chief executive election, has triggered pro-democracy demonstrations, with lawmakers pledging to veto the proposal.

site_title: Driverless cars have a dirty downside, says US study
summary: A US study by the University of Michigan found that driverless cars may actually increase fuel consumption, potentially reversing years of declining fuel use. The researchers concluded that autonomous vehicles would require more energy to operate than traditional cars with human drivers, despite initial expectations that they would reduce energy consumption. This discovery contradicts the long-held assumption that autonomous vehicles would lead to a more fuel-efficient transportation system.

site_title: Philippines planning debt swap, repo: Treasurer
summary: The Philippines plans a peso-denominated debt exchange to trim its outstanding securities, aiming to reduce the count to below 100 by the end of the year. The move, led by Treasurer Roberto Tan, seeks to boost trading volumes and improve the yield curve in the debt market, which has seen volatile trading volumes and low returns. The Treasury plans to offer new securities in exchange for illiquid and infrequently traded securities, with a target of at least 50 billion pesos each.

site_title: Tokyo to extend term of public pension fund head
summary: Tokyo's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) will extend the term of its head, Takahiro Mitani, 66, to another three years starting April 1. Mitani's term expiration was closely watched by global investors due to the fund's massive $1.57 trillion assets, making it the world's largest pension fund. The decision aims to stabilize the fund amidst government uncertainty on governance.

site_title: Aug 7 declared a holiday as part of Singapore's 50th birthday celebrations
summary: Singapore has declared August 7 a public holiday as part of its 50th birthday celebrations, marking an extended Jubilee Weekend from August 7-10. This move aims to encourage Singaporeans to participate in commemorating the nation's history. The declaration was made by Minister Heng Swee Keat, chairman of the SG50 Steering Committee, who hopes everyone will take part in activities and events organized around the island.

site_title: Osborne unveils pension reform
summary: British finance minister George Osborne announced pension reform, allowing pensioners to cash in their annuities for lump sums, in a bid to boost re-election prospects. Despite no major tax cuts, Osborne aims to reduce austerity measures, potentially dampening Labour's criticism of ideologically-driven cuts. The move is seen as a sweetener to pensioners, but Osborne reiterated there would be "no giveaways, no gimmicks" in his budget, emphasizing the need to balance the books. The budget statement is set for Wednesday, ahead of a national election.

site_title: EU, Germany raise 'Grexit' alarm over Greece bailout
summary: EU Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker warned of an alarming lack of progress in talks on Greece's bailout, as Germany raised the specter of a Greek exit from the euro. Greece's leader Alexis Tsipras renewed a demand for Germany to repay WWII debts, sparking tensions among eurozone members. Frustrations are mounting, with some officials warning of a "Grexit" that could have a domino effect on the eurozone. Juncker insisted that failure was not an option, but Germany and other partners have held a hard line against the Greek government, which must first detail its reform plans before any release of European cash.

site_title: Facebook acquires TheFind, said to ramp up product advertising
summary: Facebook is acquiring TheFind, a search engine for web shopping, to integrate its features into the company's advertising service. TheFind's technology will help make Facebook ads more product-oriented, and its website's features will eventually be integrated into Facebook's advertising platform. This move aims to increase Facebook's revenue from e-commerce-related ads and direct purchases. Facebook has also been testing a "buy button" for direct purchases, further emphasizing its focus on e-commerce.

site_title: The origins of Buffett's Berkshire
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway was founded in 1964 when Buffett Partnership Ltd (BPL) refused to tender its 225,000 shares at the offered price of $11.375 per share due to Seabury Stanton's chiselling. This decision led to Berkshire Hathaway's textile business continuing to operate at a loss, with its net worth shrinking by 37% over the next seven years. Buffett eventually took control of the company in 1965 after purchasing more shares aggressively. He later made two costly mistakes, purchasing National Indemnity Company in 1967 for $8.6 million without BPL's involvement, and buying Waumbec Mills in 1975. However, with the help of his business partner Charlie Munger, Buffett shifted his focus to acquiring "wonderful businesses at fair prices," leading to Berkshire Hathaway's success.

site_title: Art madness descends on Hong Kong
summary: Art Basel Hong Kong, the Asia's largest art fair, opened to VIP clients on March 13, 2015, with notable sales including Yoshitomo Nara's works, Sun Xun's paintings, and George Condo's art. The fair drew over 65,000 visitors and generated approximately $3 billion in art sales. The success of Art Basel Hong Kong has led to the establishment of a new art fair, Art Central, at the Central Harbourfront.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: UN disaster meeting opens in tsunami-hit Japan
summary: The United Nations held a 10-yearly disaster risk reduction meeting in tsunami-hit Japan, with hopes for real efforts to tackle natural disasters and climate change. The meeting comes as a tropical cyclone hit Vanuatu, prompting condolences from UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. He emphasized the need for disaster risk reduction as a front-line defense against climate change impacts. The conference aims to establish a disaster early warning system for vulnerable populations and could lead to a success in the COP 21 climate conference in Paris.

site_title: Apple Watch not on shopping list for 69 per cent of Americans: Reuters poll
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos poll found that 69% of Americans do not want to buy an Apple Watch, with only 13% of non-iPhone owners considering purchasing one. The smartwatch's limited awareness and perceived novelty may hinder its success, with many respondents viewing it as a "passing fad." Initial demand is expected to come from existing iPhone users, but wider adoption depends on the creation of killer apps. Analysts predict Apple will sell between 10 million and 32 million watches in 2015.

site_title: Heartwarming cookware
summary: German cookware company WMF is revamping its brand image to connect emotionally with customers. The company's minimalist look is being replaced with a more lifestyle-focused approach, featuring models using the cookware in new packaging and store layouts. The goal is to show warmth and approachability, reflecting changing consumer perceptions of cooking as an enjoyable experience. WMF is also expanding its product range to meet growing demand in Asia, particularly in China, and introducing new items such as a ThermoIndicator display on frying pans and a Mix and Go smoothie maker.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: BP win cutting gulf spill tab by US$4b fought by US
summary: The US is appealing a judge's decision to reduce the maximum pollution penalties for BP's 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill from $18 billion to $13.7 billion. US District Judge Carl Barbier had set the spill size at 3.2 million barrels, while the US estimates it at 4.2 million barrels. The US is fighting the reduced fine, while BP has already spent $28 billion on spill response and cleanup, with a total set aside of $43.5 billion to cover all costs.

site_title: Blending artistry with earnestness
summary: Rabbit Stash, a restaurant on the rooftop of the WANGZ Hotel in Singapore, serves well-crafted food with an emphasis on artistry. However, the dining experience is marred by an excessive need to intellectualize the menu, with detailed descriptions of the inspiration behind each dish. The restaurant's attempts to elevate comfort food with Asian twists, such as crayfish and truffle cream, are admirable, but the forced showmanship detracts from the overall experience. Despite this, the food is enjoyable, and the restaurant's earnestness and care in adapting Western recipes to suit the Asian palate are commendable. Rating: 7.

site_title: Credit Suisse shakes up global M&A, naming Lindsay chairman
summary: Credit Suisse is reorganizing its global mergers and acquisitions department. Scott Lindsay, the bank's global head of M&A, will become chairman of M&A, succeeding him. Lindsay will be succeeded by Greg Weinberger and Robin Rankin, who will share the role as co-heads of global dealmaking. Lindsay has 32 years of experience with Credit Suisse, establishing the bank's takeover defense and cross-border M&A practice.

site_title: US: Stocks end volatile week lower
summary: US stocks ended a volatile week lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 107.47 points (0.60%) to 17,749.31. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with losses of 17.86 (0.86%) and 55.61 (1.13%), respectively. The rising dollar and sinking oil prices were major contributors to the market's decline, as investors grappled with the implications of a strong greenback on US exports and emerging economies.

site_title: Oil products glut feared as refiners step on the gas
summary: Refiners are stepping up production, potentially leading to a glut of fuel products and lower oil prices. Despite a 23% rebound in Brent futures to $57.18 a barrel, global refining has surged to the highest level since 2010, outpacing consumer demand. Analysts warn that refiners may flood product markets again, reversing recent price gains. The International Energy Agency forecasts a record 2.83 billion barrels of crude and refined products by mid-year, with OECD members storing 2.7 billion barrels of crude and fuel in December.

site_title: Hedge funds slash bullish oil bets to November lows on supply worries
summary: Hedge funds reduced their bullish bets on US crude oil for a second consecutive week, to the lowest level since November, due to growing concerns about oil oversupply. Global crude prices, including US West Texas Intermediate, fell 9% this week amid a strong dollar, which increased the cost of dollar-denominated commodities. The decline follows initial fears that a 60% price drop since June was excessive.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton dominates withdrawal-hit opener
summary: Lewis Hamilton dominated the season-opening Australian Grand Prix, leading from start to finish and securing a 34-second victory over teammate Nico Rosberg. Mercedes claimed their eighth consecutive win, while Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel secured a podium finish on his debut. The race was marred by mechanical issues and withdrawals, with only 11 cars completing the 58-lap event. Hamilton's victory marked his seventh win in the last eight races, and he now has 34 wins from 149 Grands Prix.

images.alt_text: Race winner Mercedes Formula One driver Lewis Hamilton of Britain sprays champagne on the podium after the Australian F1 Grand Prix at the Albert Park circuit in Melbourne March 15, 2015.-Reuters

site_title: S'pore focused on long-term disaster risk mgt planning: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore prioritizes long-term disaster risk management due to its small size and high population density. Minister K Shanmugam emphasized the importance of planning for disaster risks, citing statistics that 87% of disasters over a 10-year period are related to climate change. The country integrates disaster risk reduction into national development plans and policies, such as building reclaimed land 2.25 meters above the highest recorded water levels. Singapore welcomes the adoption of the post-2015 Hyogo Framework for Action and is prepared to provide humanitarian assistance to Vanuatu following Cyclone Pam.

site_title: UK construction output in January down sharply
summary: UK construction output fell 2.6% in January, the largest monthly decline since 2013, due to a sharp drop in housebuilding. Total new housebuilding dropped 5% on the month, the steepest fall since February last year. Weak mortgage lending, high house prices, and skill shortages among builders are cited as contributing factors. The decline in construction output is a disappointment, fueling concerns that Britain is building too few new houses to meet demand.

site_title: China has 'ample' room for stimulus: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country has "ample" room for stimulus measures to boost its slowing economy, amid concerns about a potential slowdown in growth. The country's annual growth target was lowered to approximately 7% last month, the lowest since 2004.
