Khamenei called the letter "a sign that the other party is deceitful and stabs in the back," and warned that Iran would not be bound by any agreement. The US and Iran are set to meet in Switzerland for new nuclear talks, with a March 31 deadline looming for a political framework.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up after weak US data tame rate talk
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday following weak US data that tempered interest rate hike expectations. Stocks in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul gained, while Shanghai and Sydney eased. The US dollar maintained its strength against the yen and euro despite retreating from multi-year highs. The Dow surged 1.47%, the S&P 500 added 1.26%, and the Nasdaq rose 0.89%. The data may prompt the Federal Reserve to wait until fresh data is released before making a decision on interest rates.

site_title: Seoul: Shares up after rate cut; won edges up
summary: South Korean shares rose 1% on Friday, snapping a four-day losing streak, after the Bank of Korea cut interest rates by 25 basis points to a record low of 1.75% to support economic growth. Local institutional investors turned net buyers, buying stocks worth 3.9 billion won, while the won edged up 0.3% to 1,122.9 per dollar. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose to 1,990.05 points, led by shares of leisure and media companies.

site_title: Australia: Shares down, but NZ stocks sets record peak
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,811.4 points, due to declining commodity prices and disappointing economic data. In contrast, New Zealand stocks reached a record peak, with the NZX-50 index rising 0.3% to 5,906.73. Large miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto declined, while telecommunications sector gained after TPG Telecom's acquisition of iiNet.

site_title: China envoy urges Japan to stick to apology script
summary: China's ambassador to Japan, Cheng Yonghua, urged Japan to stick to its 1995 "Murayama Statement" apology for wartime actions, warning that an ambiguous or defiant stance would jeopardize peace. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has adopted a conservative agenda with a less apologetic tone, causing tensions with China and South Korea. If Japan fails to adhere to the apology, China may question its commitment to peace, potentially worsening relations.

images.alt_text: China will question Japan's commitment to peace if it adopts an ambiguous or defiant stance regarding its wartime actions, Beijing's ambassador to Tokyo told the English-language China Daily newspaper in an interview published on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose marginally in opening trade on Friday, edging up 11.01 points to 23,808.97, following a surge on Wall Street. Weak US retail sales alleviated concerns about a possible interest rate hike this summer. This move was seen as a positive sign for the markets, with investors brushing off new US President Trump's threats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 2.25 points to 1784.98. Volume was 65.25 million lots worth RM16.39 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 122 to 44.

site_title: Germany's Schaeuble says can't rule out "Grexident"
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that Greece is responsible for its own economic situation and that Europe remains prepared to help, but he couldn't rule out an accidental exit of Greece from the euro zone. Schaeuble emphasized that Greece needs to help itself and take responsibility for its economy. This comes as concerns about Greece's financial stability continue to rise.

site_title: China: Shares higher in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose in morning trade, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.30% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.25%. The Shanghai Composite Index closed at 3,359.49 and the Shenzhen Composite Index at 1,688.99. No specific reasons for the rise were mentioned.

site_title: Indonesia regulator to ease investment rules for pension, insurance funds: official
summary: Indonesia's financial regulator plans to ease investment rules for pension and insurance funds to boost the local bond market, aiming to increase liquidity and product offerings. The move will allow these funds to invest in riskier products, potentially attracting more investors. Additionally, the regulator plans to encourage municipal bond issuance for infrastructure development, with provinces like West Java and East Kalimantan set to issue bonds.

site_title: Britain seeks to join China-backed infrastructure bank
summary: Britain announced plans to join the Chinese-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), the first major Western country to do so. Finance minister George Osborne said joining the bank would create opportunities for investment and growth between the UK and Asia. The move drew a cautious response from the US, which expressed concerns about the bank's governance and environmental standards. China, India, and other countries signed the AIIB's founding agreement in October, with several major economies, including Japan and Australia, declining to participate.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's condition 'largely unchanged': PMO
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's condition remains largely unchanged since his March 6 update, with him still sedated and on mechanical ventilation in the hospital's intensive care unit. He has continued with antibiotics. It has been over a month since Lee was first admitted to SGH for severe pneumonia.

images.alt_text: Wong Wei Kong

site_title: India parliament passes key Modi reform
summary: India's parliament approved a key economic reform bill, allowing foreign companies to invest up to 49% in the country's insurance sector. The bill, which increases foreign direct investment limits, aims to revive flagging investor sentiment and bring in billions of dollars into the industry. The legislation, passed in the upper house after being stalled for over six years, is part of a series of reforms by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government. The move is expected to tap funds for India's infrastructure projects, with the insurance industry being a key source of funds for industrial projects.

site_title: Oil CEOs said to ask Obama administration to lift export ban
summary: US oil drilling executives, including CEOs from ConocoPhillips and Occidental Petroleum, met with White House officials and lawmakers to urge the Obama administration to lift the 40-year ban on US oil exports. The ban, imposed after the 1973 Arab oil embargo, restricts US oil sales to other countries, resulting in lower prices. Executives argue that lifting the ban would allow US producers to sell for higher prices, boosting the industry and the economy. Administration officials have called the restrictions antiquated and are being reviewed in a study, with some lawmakers, including Senator Lisa Murkowski, backing the lifting of the ban.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher after Wall Street surges
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday after Wall Street stocks surged, snapping a two-day losing streak. The Straits Times Index rose 0.01 point to 3,373.61 points, driven by a 1.47% gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and 1.26% gains in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index. The dollar retreated from a 12-year high, boosting investor sentiment. This marks a 5-day rally for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: British author Terry Pratchett dies aged 66
summary: British author Terry Pratchett, creator of the science fantasy Discworld novels, died aged 66 after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. He sold over 85 million books worldwide and campaigned to raise awareness and reduce stigma related to the disease. Pratchett wrote 70+ books, including the 41st Discworld novel completed before his death. His legacy will endure, with tributes from world leaders and fans praising his passion, resilience, and courage in fighting dementia.

site_title: China financial ECM deals set for strongest year since 2010
summary: Chinese financial institutions plan to raise at least $30 billion in new funds through equity offerings in 2015, making it the most active year since 2010. The year started with a strong start, with over $6 billion in equity deals in the first three months, driven by banks, insurers, and brokerages seeking to strengthen balance sheets and expand lending businesses. This surge in ECM deals is attributed to the need to meet new capital adequacy rules and capitalize on profitable margin financing opportunities.

site_title: US dailies join 'micropayments' news startup Blendle
summary: US daily newspapers The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and The Washington Post have partnered with Dutch-based startup Blendle, which offers micropayments for news articles. The platform allows readers to buy individual articles online, with prices set by the publisher. The deal marks a shift for the US media organizations, which are adapting to the digital news landscape. Blendle has previously partnered with major Dutch publishers and has over 220,000 users in the Netherlands.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as dollar dips; Dow +1.47%
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.47% to 17,895.22, after big US banks cleared Federal Reserve stress tests and the dollar retreated from a 12-year high. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with tech companies like Apple and Amazon making gains. However, investors remain cautious about the impact of a strong dollar on US exports.

site_title: Secret meetings in Pakistan expose obstacles to Afghan peace talks
summary: Senior Afghan Taliban representatives met with Pakistani officials in secret discussions, amid efforts to broker peace talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government. The talks, facilitated by Pakistan and China, aim to end the long-standing war in Afghanistan. However, obstacles remain, including the Taliban's demand for the immediate withdrawal of foreign troops, which the Afghan government is unlikely to accept. The process is moving forward, with Pakistani pressure on the Taliban to negotiate, but a breakthrough is uncertain, and the fate of the talks hangs on the verdict of the Taliban's reclusive supreme leader, Mullah Mohammad Omar.

site_title: Australia's TPG Telecom to buy local rival iiNet for US$1.08b
summary: Australia's telecommunications company TPG Telecom is acquiring local rival iiNet for A$1.4 billion, a 26.3% premium on Thursday's closing price. TPG will pay A$8.60 per iiNet share, with the combined business expected to serve over 1.7 million subscribers. The deal is seen as a significant reward for iiNet shareholders, with iiNet Chairman Michael Smith stating that the board views it as a "significant reward for shareholders." The acquisition aims to boost TPG's broadband business.

site_title: GM recalls about 64,000 Chevrolet Volt hybrids
summary: General Motors is recalling approximately 64,000 Chevrolet Volt hybrid electric cars from 2011-2013 model years due to a software issue that can cause carbon monoxide buildup when the vehicle is left idling. Two injuries have been reported, and the company is issuing a software update to limit idling time. The recall affects vehicles with a faulty idle mode that can lead to carbon monoxide buildup, and affected owners will be notified and instructed to update their software. The update is expected to prevent potential injuries and ensure vehicle safety.

site_title: Gradual rate hikes will benefit Singapore banks, says S&P
summary: Singapore banks are expected to benefit from gradual rate hikes, according to a report by Standard and Poor's (S&P). The credit cycle is at a turning point, with higher interest rates lifting net interest margins by mid-year. However, the risk of soured loans remains, particularly for customers with variable-rate loans. S&P notes that Singapore banks' non-performing loans (NPLs) and credit costs are near historical lows, and the government's macro-prudential measures should provide some protection.

site_title: Clinton had no official Blackberry: State Dept
summary: US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton did not have an official government-issued BlackBerry during her tenure, contrary to speculation. This revelation adds to the controversy surrounding her use of a private email account during her four years as secretary of state. Clinton has submitted 60,000-plus emails, with the State Department reviewing which ones can be released to the public. The lack of a BlackBerry has raised concerns about national security, fueling suspicions that Clinton and her husband Bill may be hiding information.

images.alt_text: Piling on more embarrassment for Hillary Clinton amid a row about her emails, US officials revealed Thursday that during her time as secretary of state she had eschewed a government-issued cell phone.

site_title: German employers get creative to skirt new minimum wage
summary: German employers are finding creative ways to avoid paying the minimum wage of 8.50 euros per hour, introduced in March 2015. Employers are charging workers for personal items, reducing overtime pay, and offering coupons to use on-site instead of paying the minimum wage. The German Labour Minister has admitted to implementation problems but has not yet suggested changing the law. Firms breaking the law face fines of up to 500,000 euros.

site_title: Lyft secures US$530m to take on Uber
summary: Lyft raises $530 million in funding, valuing it at $2.5 billion, as it seeks to expand in the US and abroad. The Japanese ecommerce giant Rakuten led the funding round, with Lyft aiming to deepen its presence in 65 markets and expand into new cities. The company plans to use the funds to improve technology that reduces traffic and builds community. This investment makes Lyft a significant rival to Uber, valued at $41 billion, and both companies face competition from local regulators and traditional taxi services.

site_title: Thinking beyond the checklist
summary: The dean of the Lee Kong Chian School of Business at Singapore Management University, Gerard George, aims to build entrepreneurial thinking in his students. He believes the country is missing an opportunity-framing mentality, which stifles innovation and stifles growth. To address this, the school is developing a new course, "Managing in a VUCA Context," and ramping up entrepreneurship initiatives, including internships and projects in the Biopolis/Fusionopolis cluster. George also plans to raise students' overseas exposure and encourage them to venture into the region, rather than just focusing on established hotspots.

site_title: MAS sees S'pore growing into a commodities trading centre
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) plans to support the city-state's development as a commodities trading centre by working with exchanges, investors, and producers. The MAS aims to expand clearing houses in Asia to boost liquidity and encourage product development. Clearing houses improve risk management in derivatives markets, particularly during Asian hours. This move is expected to enhance Singapore's position as a key trading hub in the region.

site_title: MAS has had two meetings with remisiers' reps
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) met twice with remisiers' representatives to discuss issues plaguing the local stock market, including rebuilding confidence, creating an environment for investing and trading, and maintaining listing quality. Remisiers proposed splitting trading days into two sessions with a shorter lunch break, a move that could reduce extreme volatility. The proposal comes after the Society of Remisiers appealed to the Ministry of Manpower to reinstate the lunch break, citing it as a "basic human right".

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has met twice with representatives of the 1,225 remisiers who in January wrote to Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam about issues plaguing the local stock market.

site_title: South Korea's tallest skyscraper rises in cloud of fear
summary: South Korea's tallest skyscraper, the Lotte World Tower, is under construction, sparking concerns about safety amidst a backdrop of public mistrust in corporate giants. The 92-story tower, envisioned 28 years ago by Shin Kyuk Ho, is set to be completed by 2016. However, its opening has been marred by a nearly 50% decline in visitor numbers at a nearby mall, forcing Lotte to cut rents. The project's massive scale and public scrutiny have heightened concerns, despite Shin's success and Lotte's safety record.

images.alt_text: At 92, the man who built South Korea's biggest retail empire is finally making his mark in the Seoul skyline as the country's tallest tower takes shape - just as public faith in corporate giants crumbles into safety fears and mistrust.

site_title: Oil falls back on record-high US supplies
summary: Oil prices dropped on Thursday as traders shifted focus to record-high US stockpiles, wiping out earlier gains. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 61 cents to $47.56 per barrel, while European benchmark Brent North Sea crude retreated 51 cents to $57.03 a barrel. Analysts attributed the decline to the relentless growth in US crude inventories and a weaker dollar, which failed to support oil prices despite a weaker European single currency.

images.alt_text: World oil prices hit reverse gear on Thursday, wiping out earlier gains, as traders switched their attention back to record-high US stockpiles, dealers said.

site_title: Going upriver in style
summary: Luxury river cruises are gaining popularity, with many operators launching new itineraries in exotic destinations such as the Mekong River, Irrawaddy River, and Ganges River. Research shows 25% growth in river cruising from 2009 to 2014, with destinations including Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar, and India. New ships and itineraries are being launched, offering unique cultural and culinary experiences, and luxurious accommodations. Operators such as Avalon Waterways, Abercrombie & Kent, and AmaWaterways are leading the way, with options ranging from 8-day cruises to 16-day itineraries.

site_title: Voyage of discovery
summary: Silversea Expeditions offers specialty cruises targeting adventure travellers with a focus on photography, diving, and wellness. The cruise line features immersive photo expeditions, birding and ornithology cruises, and expedition voyages to exotic locations. SeaDream Yacht Club offers wine-intensive journeys, including a 5-9 day Mediterranean voyage with wine tastings and expert-led masterclasses. Linblad Expeditions-National Geographic offers Arctic voyages with breathtaking wildlife experiences, including polar bears and narwhals, and opportunities to visit Inuit villages.

site_title: Greece looks to social security funds to plug debt bills
summary: Greece's government is considering raiding its social security funds to raise 6 billion euros to meet its debt repayments, amid a frozen bailout and a cashflow problem. The finance ministry will ask parliament to allow state bodies to transfer their reserves to the Bank of Greece, with the government guaranteeing them for any capital losses. Critics argue this is a desperate measure, as the European Central Bank's emergency loan assistance is insufficient to plug the hole in the government's finances.

site_title: Panel discussion on IoT at Fuji Xerox event next Tuesday
summary: Fuji Xerox is hosting a roundtable discussion on the Internet of Things (IoT) on March 17 as part of DocuWorld 2015, moderated by BT Tech editor Amit Choudhury. The panel includes experts from Trend Micro, Siemens, and Xerox Corporation. The discussion aims to explore how businesses are embracing IoT to increase productivity and overcome operational challenges. The event is open to the public and will be held at the Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel in Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.59% to 6,761.07 points. In contrast, the CAC 40 in Paris lost 0.21% to 4,987.33 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index slipped 0.06% to 11,799.39 points. The mixed performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty continued to influence investor sentiment.

site_title: US chicken exports at risk as bird flu strikes
summary: US chicken exports are at risk due to a confirmed case of highly pathogenic H5N2 avian flu in turkeys in Arkansas, home to Tyson Foods Inc. The US government's announcement is likely to lead to more export restrictions, increasing domestic supply and forcing suppliers to trim prices. The domestic supply surge will depress prices, according to an agricultural economist. This move may impact the global poultry market, with the US virus unlikely to kill enough birds to offset the drop in overseas demand.

site_title: Allen & Gledhill named Regional Law Firm of the year
summary: Allen & Gledhill was named Regional Law Firm of the Year and Singapore Law Firm of the Year at the IFLR Asia Awards 2015. This is the firm's second consecutive win for regional law firm and 14th win for national law firm award in Singapore. Chairman Lucien Wong attributed the awards to the firm's commitment to providing high-quality legal services to clients.

site_title: The really great outdoors
summary: Luxury wilderness camps offer secluded and exclusive adventure getaways. The Clayoquot Wilderness Resort in British Columbia features safari-style luxury tents and offers activities such as hiking, horseback riding, and whale watching. The Beyond Xarananna Okavango Delta Camp in Botswana is an ultra-exclusive destination with nine tented suites and numerous wildlife viewing opportunities. The Oberoi Vanyavilas Ranthambhore in India allows guests to see Royal Bengal tigers in the wild, while the Saffire Freycinet in Tasmania offers stunning views and exclusive experiences. Other luxury camps include Chinzombo Lodge in Zambia and Awasi Patagonia in Chile, each offering unique and luxurious wilderness experiences.

site_title: Opulent retreat in an ancient town
summary: Aman Resorts has opened its third property in China, Amandayan, in Lijiang's Old Town, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The ultra-luxurious resort is designed in traditional Nakhi style, featuring courtyards, stone floors, and local materials. The property boasts stunning views of Jade Dragon Snow Mountain and includes a well-preserved 1725 Wenchang Palace, a tea house, and a spa. Guests can enjoy traditional Chinese and Western cuisine, as well as explore the surrounding area, which features natural attractions like Tiger Leaping Gorge and Black Dragon Lake.

site_title: In brief
summary: United Envirotech posted a net profit of S$12.5 million for the three months ended Dec 31, 2014, with revenue surging 80.6% to S$116.07 million. Sinjia Land received approval to transfer to the Catalist Board, while Soilbuild Reit acquired a property at Loyang for S$97 million. Sinotel Tech chairman Jia Yue Ting made an offer to take the company private with an offer of 9.8 Singapore cents per share. China Dairy Group proposed a share consolidation to maintain a minimum trading price rule.

site_title: Everyone is guessing when it comes to oil prices
summary: Oil prices continue to be a guessing game due to complex factors, with predictions ranging from $20 to $200 per barrel. The weekly rig count has fallen to its lowest level in years, but drillers have become more efficient, complicating the relationship between rig counts and production. Storage space is running low, with 60% of US storage filled, and the backlog of uncompleted wells is estimated at 3,000. Oil production continues to defy gravity, but demand projections are uncertain due to economic growth and fluctuations in currency markets.

site_title: KepCorp closer to taking KepLand private; bid extended
summary: KepCorp, a Singapore conglomerate, is close to taking its property arm Kepland private after extending its takeover offer for two weeks. The company now owns 85.1% of Kepland, just shy of the 90% threshold needed for a successful privatization bid. Analysts believe the offer will likely receive high levels of shareholder acceptances due to the extended deadline. If the bid succeeds, Kepland shareholders will receive a base price of S$4.38 per share, with the option for an additional 22 cents if the threshold is reached.

site_title: Still plenty of demand for Air Supply
summary: Air Supply, an Australian soft-rock duo, performed a 90-minute set at The Star Performing Arts Centre in Singapore as part of their 40th anniversary world tour. The 64-year-old Graham Russell and 65-year-old Russell Hitchcock, despite their age, delivered a high-energy show with hits like "Lost in Love," "All Out of Love," and "Making Love Out of Nothing at All." The crowd of 5,000 responded positively to a new, dance-heavy song "Desert Sea Sky," marking the duo's first chart action in years. The show proved that there is still demand for Air Supply's music after four decades.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Tweaks to Medisave limits to simplify process
summary: Singapore's Medisave system will undergo changes starting January 2016, including the renaming of the Medisave Contribution Ceiling (MCC) to Basic Healthcare Sum, set at S$49,800. The Medisave Minimum Sum (MMS) will be scrapped, allowing members to withdraw CPF monies without topping up to the MMS. The government also plans to introduce a standardised Integrated Shield Plan (IP) and restructure Medisave Withdrawal Limits for health insurance premiums. Additionally, four chronic conditions will be added to the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS) and Medisave use, and a new Community Hospital Common System will be launched to improve patient care.

site_title: Intraco wins S$6.6m arbitration award
summary: SINGAPOREAN trading company Intraco won a S$6.6 million arbitration award against Timor Global, a Timor Leste coffee plantation and trading company, in a dispute over a 2007 joint venture agreement. Intraco claimed S$9.8 million, with S$3.2 million already received. The award does not include interest and costs, which are yet to be decided. Intraco plans to enforce the award, while Timor Global was also facing bank debt troubles, including a US$5.7 million payment order by the High Court.

site_title: GST: can Singapore and Malaysia learn from each other?
summary: Malaysia is set to introduce a goods and services tax (GST) on April 1, 20 years after Singapore's introduction. The Malaysian GST will share similarities with Singapore's but also have unique quirks. Malaysia will tax imported services, unlike Singapore, and has introduced a GST audit file to standardize audit processes. The country will also not offer concessions to exporters, unlike Singapore, which could impact its competitiveness as a financial services hub. Despite sharing some similarities, both countries can learn from each other's GST models.

site_title: Prudential sounding shareholders before naming new CEO
summary: Prudential, a British insurer, is meeting top shareholders to gauge their preferences for a new CEO, following Tidjane Thiam's unexpected departure in May. The company has identified a successor from internal and external candidates, but regulatory approval is required. The move aims to repair Prudential's relationship with investors and regulators, which soured in 2010 over the failed AIA Group takeover. Analysts expect the new CEO to address challenges such as expanding in Asia, navigating uncertain European regulations, and meeting ambitious financial targets.

site_title: The folly of Fed bashing
summary: Conservative criticism of the Federal Reserve, known as "Fed bashing," is on the rise, particularly from Republicans. This criticism stems from attitudes towards power and distrust of big government, rather than fundamental disagreements over monetary policy. Despite the Fed's role in the financial crisis and its efforts to promote a steady recovery, conservative critics argue that the Fed needs to be more accountable and tamed. However, proponents argue that such proposals, such as an audit of the Fed, could exact a large economic cost and undermine confidence in the institution.

site_title: Changi is world's best airport for third year in a row
summary: Changi Airport has retained its title of World's Best Airport for the third consecutive year at the 2015 World Airport Awards, beating Incheon International Airport and Munich Airport for the top spot. The airport also won the Best Airport for Leisure Amenities award, and its hotel, Crowne Plaza Changi Airport, was named World's Best Airport Hotel and Best Airport Hotel in Asia. Changi Airport is set to expand with new facilities, including Terminal 4 in 2017 and Jewel Changi Airport in 2018, to cater to growing passenger traffic.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee receiving the World's Best Airport award from Mr Plaisted. Overall, this marks the sixth time that Changi Airport has won the top World Airport Awards title.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Smaller Manhattan apartments lead Feb rental gains
summary: Manhattan's smallest apartments are driving up rents, with median studio apartment prices increasing 10% to $2,351 and one-bedroom apartments rising 9.4% to $3,400, both the highest in over seven years. The strengthening job market and limited housing supply are fuelling demand, with smaller spaces becoming more attractive to tenants seeking affordability.

site_title: Discourse on taxes needs to continue
summary: Singapore's government is expected to continue its discussion on broadening the tax base to address the country's rising expenditure needs. Economists and tax experts believe a widening of the income tax base is likely, with potential increases in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate and introduction of capital gains tax. The next government term will need to address this issue, which involves sharing the tax burden among more people, as the current system is considered off-kilter. The government has shown willingness to make unpopular moves, but the conversation needs to continue to ensure fiscal sustainability.

site_title: Choreographing partnerships is the way to go
summary: Maya Dance Theatre is set to present Release 4.0, a collection of dance presentations featuring guest choreographers from Singapore and internationally. The event, which includes works by award-winning choreographers and international dancers, aims to develop the local dance scene and provide new ideas and perspectives for the company's dancers. The residency program allows guest choreographers to work with the company, and the event partner, 10 Square @ Orchard Central, will host the performances on March 13 and 14.

site_title: City buzz
summary: Local art enthusiasts can explore OH! Open House in Joo Chiat, showcasing art in unexpected places, including pre-war shophouses and secret gardens. The event features performances, installations, and exhibitions by rising artists. Meanwhile, Crosby, Stills and Nash will perform in Singapore for the first time, bringing their iconic folk-pop sound. A pop-up market, D'Kranji Farm Fair, will also take place, offering fresh produce and handmade products. The U Symposium 2015 will discuss the influence of modern culture on magazines, and Forlino, an Italian restaurant, now with Japanese influences, offers a new menu.

images.alt_text: Expect art in unexpected places, such as this shophouse belonging to SS Tan and his wife (above). Here, artist Guo Yixiu has created an installation which visitors on the OH! Open House walkabout will get to see.
Mike HJ Chang and Mark Thia (above) who have created an installation in Fragrance Hotel.

The Hokkaido Scallop Tartar (S$32, above) with marinated zucchini and black truffle, a colourful Robusta Lobster "Tortelli" Pasta (S$38) made with saffron potato, lobster bisque espuma and saute lobster, and the Conchiglioni Pasta alla Bolognese (S$32) which features Challand duck ragout, foie gras espuma and green apple sauce.

site_title: Wayang comes alive with splendid Titoudao revival
summary: The revival of street opera play Titoudao, about Chinese street performer Oon Ah Chiam, has been well-received with Audrey Luo taking on the lead role. The pint-sized actress brings charisma and energy to the performance, effortlessly switching between Oon and her stage persona Titoudao. The play, which was last staged in 2007, features a talented supporting cast and impressive technical elements, including stage design and costumes. The production runs until March 14 at the Drama Centre Theatre.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Fascinating sampling of Grands Crus
summary: A wine tasting in Gevrey-Chambertin, a commune in the Cote d'Or, revealed a fascinating sampling of Grands Crus wines. The wines, including those from Domaine Armand Rousseau, were characterized by their power, weight, and dominance of Pinot Noir. However, most of the wines were found to need more aging, with some showing great potential in five years. The Gevrey-Chambertin character stood out in all the wines, with a straight, firm, and compact Pinot character, but lacking the enchanting and haunting exotic perfume of Chambolle-Musigny and the seductive lushness of Vosne-Romanee.

site_title: Further mass demos likely in HK: Legco president
summary: Hong Kong's Legislative Council president Jasper Tsang warns of "another mass demonstration" against the proposed changes in the territory's chief executive election process, which could attract crowds of up to 100,000 people. The proposed reforms, which would allow Beijing to vet candidates, have sparked widespread protests since last year's Umbrella Movement. With 27 lawmakers opposed to the reforms, Tsang suggests that businessmen and visitors should not be alarmed, but rather negotiate for further concessions to the principle of universal suffrage.

site_title: Traditional arts, heritage conservation get support
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth has announced a S$25 million investment in traditional arts over the next five years, building on the existing S$23 million National Traditional Arts Plan launched in 2010.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Asian consumer confidence levels declined quarter-over-quarter in Q4 2014, except for Malaysia. Despite short-term challenges, analysts remain optimistic on regional consumption, driven by policy reforms and government spending. OCBC Investment Research favors Sheng Siong Group and Thai Beverage, while downgrading Jardine Cycle & Carriage due to weak Astra International's performance and competitive environment. Straco Corporation's share price is upgraded to "add" following the Singapore Flyer's profit in Q4.

site_title: Personal loans' long tenure will keep M'sian indebtedness high
summary: Malaysia's household debt has reached 87.9% of GDP, with a 9.9% growth in 2014, the slowest pace since 2010. The long average tenure of loans, previously up to 45 years, means high indebtedness is likely to remain elevated for years. Stricter lending rules have resulted in one in two borrowers being turned away, and micro-prudential measures have slowed personal loan growth to 5% in 2014. Despite this, the central bank does not expect vulnerabilities in the household sector to impact the financial stability of the banking sector.

site_title: PSA International's 2014 profit dips
summary: PSA International reported a 1.7% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$1.4 billion for 2014, despite a 2.9% increase in revenue to S$3.83 billion. The company handled a record 65.44 million TEUs, with its Singapore Terminals contributing 33.55 million TEUs. Higher operating cash costs and depreciation led to a 1.1% dip in profit from operations. Challenges in the industry included mega vessel mismatches and port congestion, with group CEO Tan Chong Meng warning of potential operational challenges in 2015.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: New Orleans auctioning off vacant land online
summary: New Orleans is selling almost 1,800 vacant properties online to raise tax revenue, with bidding starting at $3,000. The city aims to put properties back into commerce, generating taxes for public services, and may set the stage for construction to accommodate the city's growing population. However, the auction poses risks for buyers and sellers, and experts warn that cheap land may attract investors who don't plan to improve it. The city has taken control of the properties after owners failed to pay property taxes, and title insurance is offered as part of the sale.

site_title: London's 'iceberg homes' plumb the city's depths
summary: London's affluent residents are building "iceberg homes" by expanding luxury homes into basements, sidestepping planning rules. Since the 2008 recession, the trend has increased, with permit applications soaring in areas like Kensington and Chelsea. The underground spaces often feature luxurious amenities like marble pools and home theaters. Local residents and politicians, such as Labour member Murad Qureshi, express concerns about the disruptions, flooding, and structural damage caused by these extensive developments. In response, Kensington & Chelsea became the first London borough to impose restrictions on basement building, limiting extensions to one extra level and 50% of the garden surface.

site_title: China's central bank comfortable with economy
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan signaled the country is comfortable with its current macroeconomic environment, sticking to "prudent" monetary policy. A deposit insurance system will be rolled out in the first half of 2015, and caps on bank deposit rates will likely be removed this year. The central bank released upbeat credit data, including 1.02 trillion yuan in new loans in February, beating expectations. Despite this, China's economy is seen at risk of missing its 7% growth target, with growth in investment, retail sales, and factory output all missing forecasts.

site_title: Banking compliance: will one-size-fits-all do?
summary: Asian banks face challenges in complying with global financial regulations due to varying economic contexts. The "one-size-fits-all" approach to compliance may not be effective, as it may not account for the unique needs of emerging markets. Regulators and banks are overworked and under-trained, leading to high compliance costs and potential breaches. To address this, experts suggest standardizing compliance frameworks and tools, similar to the IT industry, to reduce costs and improve effectiveness. This could involve pre-developed, customizable solutions that can be integrated into existing processes.

images.alt_text: All the players in Singapore's world-class financial ecosystem together have the intellectual firepower to develop risk and regulatory compliance systems that are relevant for developing Asia.

site_title: China's steel output seen shrinking this year
summary: China's steel production is expected to shrink this year, with an estimated 814 million tonnes, down from 823 million tonnes in 2014. The decline is attributed to a peak in consumption and the closure of mills due to overcapacity and environmental concerns. Industry experts warn that the country's struggling steel mills will continue to face challenges, with some predicting a worse decline in production this year. The decline in steel production may also impact iron ore prices, which have already fallen into a bear market.

site_title: Retail sales down for third month, likely chilled by weather
summary: US retail sales declined 0.6% in February, marking the third consecutive month of drop, likely due to harsh weather and supply chain disruptions. The decline was broad-based, with car sales and building material sales also falling. Economists expect a temporary slowdown in growth, but a rapidly firming labour market suggests a stronger economy in the second quarter. The decline in sales may lead to lower GDP growth estimates and a delay in interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: The phonemaker giving Xiaomi a run for its money
summary: OnePlus, a Shenzhen-based Chinese smartphone maker, is trying to match Xiaomi's success by targeting foreign markets such as the US, UK, and India. The company sold over a million units of its debut device, the One, last year, with almost two-thirds shipped abroad. OnePlus's strategy involves offering affordable, feature-packed devices with a US$299 price tag and an invite-only sales system, fostering early buzz. The company expects to triple its sales this year and has received significant attention from analysts, who praise its focus on online, direct-to-consumer sales and premium specifications.

site_title: Standard fare lifted by heart, music
summary: Boychoir, directed by Francois Girard, is a coming-of-age story about 11-year-old Stet, a gifted but troubled young boy who learns to channel his rage and singing talent into something more palpable. After being introduced to the father he never knew and sent to an East Coast academy, Stet becomes the lead treble in a touring youth choir. With the help of the choir master, Carvelle, and a young teacher, Stet overcomes his lack of musical knowledge and personal struggles to perform in a prestigious concert. The film, while formulaic and predictable, features strong singing and a pleasing sensibility.

images.alt_text: Carvelle (Dustin Hoffman) trying to coax a clean, pure sound from his talented but sulky young charge, Stet (Garrett Wareing)

site_title: On the right track to make biking cool
summary: Coast Cycles, a homegrown lifestyle bicycle brand in Singapore, has unveiled its latest creation, the Quinn cargo bicycle, designed to be an eco-friendly and comfortable mode of transport. The bike's unique feature is its ergonomically designed cargo cage that can stow a laptop or handbag, providing perfect balance for the rider. Coast Cycles' CEO-founder, Jansen Tan, aims to make biking a lifestyle and not just a leisure activity, with plans to introduce electric assist bicycle models and expand his retail space in Siglap.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

The Quinn's USP lies in the ergonomically designed cargo cage located in the centre (above); the Goliath, one of Coast Cycles' most popular models; the firm's retail space in Siglap is no ordinary showroom - it's a complete bikers' heaven and a hangout which also includes the Coast and Company Cafe

The Quinn's USP lies in the ergonomically designed cargo cage located in the centre; the Goliath, one of Coast Cycles' most popular models (above); the firm's retail space in Siglap is no ordinary showroom - it's a complete bikers' heaven and a hangout which also includes the Coast and Company Cafe

site_title: STI weakens for fourth straight day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.99 points to 3,373.60 on Thursday, extending its losing streak to a fourth consecutive session. The index briefly entered negative territory for the year, but rebounded late in the day. Weaker US stocks and rising bond prices led to the decline, with US interest rate worries persisting. Noble Group rose S$0.01 to S$0.93 on Thursday, while Darco Technologies and Nam Cheong fell.

site_title: April's theatre bonanza
summary: Singapore's theatre scene is set to experience a month-long bonanza in April, with nearly every prominent theatre company staging new works. The Esplanade's "Fifty" series celebrates 50 iconic plays from the past 50 years, featuring works by renowned playwrights such as Kuo Pao Kun, Haresh Sharma, and Ovidia Yu. The month kicks off with Emily Of Emerald Hill, a classic monologue about a Peranakan woman's rise to power, and culminates with Singapore Repertory Theatre's premiere of Shakespeare's The Tempest. Despite the excitement, many theatre practitioners remain cautious about censorship, which continues to affect the industry.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

Works by 32 playwrights will be read or staged for Esplanade's The Studios: Fifty project. They include (from left) Ng Yi-sheng, Desmond Sim, Ovidia Yu, Eleanor Wong, Huzir Sulaiman, Stella Kon, Chong Tze Chien, Verena Tay, Michael Chiang, Natalie Hennedige, Chng Suan Tze, Haresh Sharma, Russell Heng, Zizi Azah Abdul Majid, Goh Boon Teck, Robert Yeo, Irfan Kasban, Tan Tarn How, Joel Tan, Shiv Tandan, Faith Ng and Jean Tay.
Haresh Sharma's play, Off-Centre, which the authorities in 1993 said gave a skewed view of mental illness, is now an O-level text.

Emily of Emerald Hill, first staged in 1985 and played by Margaret Chan (in the photos), was the landmark English-language play that paved the way for the development of local theatre. This year's production stars Karen Tan.

site_title: India CPI rises more than estimated in February
summary: India's consumer prices rose 5.37% in February, exceeding economists' estimates, and industrial production rose 2.6% in January. The central bank governor, Raghuram Rajan, cut interest rates last week to keep inflation within the 6% target by January 2016. Despite a drop in global crude prices and contained food costs, inflation is expected to stay above 6% in the fiscal year, requiring a tight monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Mr Rajan cited slowing inflation and weakness in India's economy when he cut the benchmark repurchase rate on March 4

site_title: AirAsia still mulling IPO for Indonesian affiliate
summary: AirAsia is still considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its Indonesian affiliate, following the crash of Flight 8501 that killed 162 people in December. CEO Tony Fernandes says an IPO will increase transparency, particularly after the accident. The airline is also reviewing safety procedures and operations, with no changes yet. Fernandes stated that the families of victims have been informed and are in agreement, and the airline will continue to work towards being the best it can be.

site_title: Asian's swelling middle class good news for US economy: ambassador
summary: US Ambassador to Singapore Kirk Wagar stated that Asia's swelling middle class will create job opportunities for the US economy. By 2030, Asia is expected to be home to two-thirds of the global middle class, with the Asean economy surpassing Japan to become the fourth largest single market, and its population predicted to exceed 700 million. This growth is seen as a positive development for the US economy.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: China set to overhaul bloated, inefficient state-run firms: sources
summary: China is preparing to overhaul its state-run companies to boost the economy, which is forecast to grow at its slowest pace in over two decades. The plan includes consolidation, reduction of the government's role in state-owned enterprises, and stripping ownership stakes from regulatory agencies. The changes aim to address corruption and inefficiency, and could affect thousands of companies, including some of the world's largest. The overhaul is seen as a crucial step towards making state-enterprise reform a success and putting China on a more sustainable growth path.

site_title: Housing on the rise at fringes of London's Square Mile
summary: London's affluent neighborhoods, such as Mayfair and Knightsbridge, are experiencing a shift as ultra-rich individuals are priced out. To accommodate them, residential areas are rising at the fringes of the financial district, with over 2,000 apartments planned or under construction. Prices in these areas are significantly lower, ranging from £1,550 to £7,000 per square foot, compared to the £7,000 per square foot in Mayfair and Knightsbridge. This trend is driven by foreign investors and wealth from Asia, creating an opportunity for developers to build homes for those priced out of the city's priciest districts.

images.alt_text: Home values in London's priciest districts have climbed more than 60 per cent since 2009.

site_title: Clock ticks for forced sale of Sydney mansion
summary: The Australian government has ordered Chinese billionaire Hui Ka Yan's property company to sell the A$39 million Villa del Mare mansion in Sydney's Point Piper suburb within 90 days due to a foreign investment rule violation. The sale is considered a "fire sale" and may impact the top-end market. The mansion features handmade terracotta roof tiles and an infinity pool, and its proceeds are likely to be short of the estimated A$45 million total cost. This move is part of the government's crackdown on foreign investment in Australian real estate, which has surged 42% in recent years.

site_title: Retirement adequacy calls for prudent investing and planning
summary: Singaporeans face concerns about retirement adequacy due to low interest rates and increasing life expectancy. The 2015 Budget introduced measures to boost CPF savings, including a higher salary ceiling, extra interest for older workers, and a higher contribution cap for the Supplementary Retirement Scheme. However, lifestyle expectations, financial commitments, and investment risks remain significant challenges. With Singapore's life expectancy expected to double by 2030, the need for retirement planning and prudent investing is emphasized, particularly for older workers and those who plan to work longer.

site_title: Thailand cuts interest rates in surprise move
summary: Thailand's central bank unexpectedly cut its main interest rate to 1.75% on March 12, 2015, as a surprise move to boost economic growth amid weaker-than-expected data. The decision comes as China's slowdown looms large, and Thailand's economy has been recovering slowly. The Bank of Thailand will lower its forecast for growth this year and will act when needed to support the recovery and maintain financial stability. The move is seen as a pre-emptive move to counter the potential impact of the Federal Reserve's expected rate hike.

site_title: Canada rail network congestion eroding appeal of train travel
summary: Canada's rail network congestion is eroding the appeal of train travel, according to Via Rail Canada CEO Yves Desjardins-Siciliano. The issue can be explained by a simple math problem: two trains on the same track, one moving at 177 km/h and the other at 64 km/h. This congestion affects the speed and reliability of passenger rail services, making train travel less competitive with other modes of transportation.

site_title: US banks pass stress test, some with an asterisk
summary: US banks have passed the annual regulatory stress test, with 31 banks including Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley meeting the test's requirements. However, Bank of America received a provisional pass due to weaknesses in its internal controls and capital projections, and is required to fix these issues. Deutsche Bank and Santander of Spain failed the tests outright, while Citigroup passed with plans to buy back $7.8 billion in stock. The stress tests aim to assess banks' ability to withstand financial and economic calamities.

site_title: Euro rebounds as US dollar pauses for breath
summary: The euro rose 0.9% against the US dollar for the first time in two weeks, rebounding from a 12-year low, but traders expect further losses as the common currency is forecasted to fall to parity with the US dollar by the end of the year. The European Central Bank's bond-buying program has driven eurozone bond yields to all-time lows, while investors anticipate a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in the coming months.

site_title: US mortgage rates climb to 2015 highs on strong jobs report
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 2015 highs, with a 30-year fixed mortgage averaging 3.86% and a 15-year fixed mortgage averaging 3.1%, according to Freddie Mac. This increase followed a strong jobs report, which saw 295,000 jobs added in February and a 5.5% unemployment rate, the lowest in almost seven years. Borrowing costs tracked an increase in 10-year Treasury yields.

site_title: Obama budget would shrink deficits by US$1.2t over 10 years: CBO
summary: President Barack Obama's fiscal 2016 budget proposal would shrink US deficits by $1.232 trillion over 10 years, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The reduction is mainly due to proposals for fewer tax deductions for the wealthy and lower spending on military operations in Afghanistan. For fiscal 2016, the deficit would fall to $380 billion, down from $455 billion under current laws.

site_title: Noble episode lends clout to public challengers
summary: Singapore's NOBLE Group faces scrutiny after blogger Iceberg Research accused the commodity trader of manipulating asset values by billions of dollars. The blog post led to Noble's share price falling over $1 billion, prompting the firm to provide more information about its accounting policies. The incident highlights the growing influence of independent researchers and short-sellers, who often uncover potentially controversial governance practices in Asian corporations. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing the blog post to ensure it does not breach securities law.

site_title: Apple watch success not guaranteed, Dixons carphone CEO says
summary: Apple's new smartwatch faces uncertain success, according to Dixons Carphone CEO Sebastian James. The UK's largest consumer electronics retailer believes people may not be willing to give up their wrists to wear a smartwatch. James notes that smartwatches have a shorter lifespan due to rapid technological advancements, with consumers likely to upgrade every 2-3 years. Apple's prices range from $349 to over $10,000, but James' "suspicion" is that other retailers will have the device in stock for the holiday shopping season, potentially limiting Apple's market share.

site_title: Greater global appetite for M&As this year
summary: A KPMG report indicates a global increase in mergers and acquisitions (M&As) this year, with a 7% growth in forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio and a 14% improvement in ability to fund transactions. However, Singapore is expected to see a drop in M&A appetite, with its forward P/E ratio falling 3%, attributed to global concerns over rising interest rates and weak growth expectations. Despite this, Singapore's M&A market outperformed its Asean peers last year, with a total value of completed deals reaching US$64.7 billion.

images.alt_text: Large global corporates are expected to be on a bigger prowl for mergers and acquisitions (M&As) this year, and will likely have more capacity to fund these prospective transactions, says a KPMG report.

site_title: Senior S'pore execs are Asia's best paid in US dollar terms, says study
summary: A study by Towers Watson found that senior executives in Singapore have the highest average base salaries in Asia in US dollar terms, with an average of US$586,000. This is 32% higher than Hong Kong, which paid an average of US$445,000. However, exchange rate changes and tax rates affect take-home pay, and some companies are moving their regional headquarters to lower-cost locations to reduce staffing costs. Economists attribute Singapore's high executive wages to its advanced economy and tight labor market.

site_title: ECB said to increase Greek ELA ceiling by 600m euros
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) increased Greece's Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) ceiling by 600 million euros, matching the request from the Greek central bank. The new limit of 68.8 billion euros will be reviewed again on March 18. The move aims to prevent Greek banks from using the ELA to finance the government, which would violate European Union law, amid concerns of a cash crunch before the end of the month.

site_title: Consumer comfort little changed as US buying climate weakens
summary: Consumer confidence in the US remained unchanged last week, reaching 43.3 on the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index, its second-lowest level of the year. The buying climate gauge weakened, with a drop in stock prices and disappointing wage growth limiting spending. However, healthy job growth is expected to keep sentiment stable. The index has averaged 44.5 so far this year, up from a 36.7 average in 2014.

site_title: 1MDB saga extends to Swiss bank in S'pore
summary: Singapore's Swiss private bank BSI has been holding $1.103 billion of 1Malaysia Development Bhd's (1MDB) Cayman Islands funds, sparking concerns over the firm's dealings with the embattled state-backed company. The funds were part of a $2.32 billion investment in Cayman Islands funds, which was redeemed and repatriated last year. Documents show that BSI Singapore had issued portfolio statements for 1MDB's investments, but the bank declined to comment. This revelation adds to the 1MDB saga, which has drawn international attention over its alleged financial mismanagement and corruption.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Magical romance blossoms offstage too
summary: Lead actors of Disney's Beauty and the Beast musical, Hilary Maiberger and Darick Pead, are a real-life couple. They met during rehearsals three years ago and have been together ever since. Their romance enhances their performances, making their onstage relationship more believable. The musical, based on the 1991 animated hit, features classic showtunes and a unique blend of audience engagement and character variations. The production, running in Singapore from March 21 to April 19, showcases the challenges faced by Pead, including acting through elaborate costumes and makeup.

images.alt_text: Hilary Maiberger and Darick Pead as Belle and the Beast. "The chemistry's been there from the first day of rehearsals," says Pead.
Members of the cast depicting enchanted objects in the stage production of Disney's Beauty and the Beast

site_title: National manpower strategy pivots on mindset change
summary: Singapore's national manpower strategy is shifting towards a mindset change, requiring the government, citizens, and employers to produce industry-relevant skills and prioritize lifelong learning. To succeed, a heavy mindset shift is necessary, with the government tweaking its approach to measuring outcomes, Singaporeans taking ownership of their skills upgrading, and companies investing meaningfully in their workers. Observers stress the need for fundamental attitudinal shifts, including convincing parents of trades-based vocations' worth, and individuals being self-reliant in skills upgrading. Companies must also change their perspective on on-the-job training, and the government needs to rethink quantitative assessment tools to supplement with more qualitative measures.

site_title: Bill tabled to vary HDB lease infringement penalties
summary: A bill has been tabled in Singapore to vary the penalties for Housing and Development Board (HDB) lease infringement cases, capping the penalty at S$50,000. The proposed changes would adjust the penalty according to the severity of the offense, including factors such as disturbance and overcrowding. HDB officers would also gain more powers to investigate lease infringements, including entering premises with a warrant and taking written statements. The bill was introduced by Desmond Lee, Minister of State (National Development), on behalf of National Development Minister Khaw Boon Wan.

site_title: Sinotel Technologies chairman launches offer to take firm private
summary: Sinotel Technologies chairman Jia Yue Ting has launched a private offer to acquire his company at 9.8 Singapore cents per share, representing a 1.9% premium over the last trading price. He and his sister-in-law, Zhang Rong, will hold 39.25% of the company, with plans to acquire an additional 9.27% from other shareholders. The offer aims to provide a cash exit opportunity for shareholders, citing low trading liquidity.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: United Envirotech's Q3 net profit up 49%
summary: United Envirotech reported a 49% increase in Q3 net profit to S$12.5 million, driven by a 80.6% surge in revenue to S$116.07 million. The water treatment solutions provider attributed the growth to the Chinese water treatment sector and increasing demand for membrane products and membrane bioreactor technology. Despite a 4% decrease in earnings per share, the company remains positive about its market outlook and plans to explore joint-ventures to boost membrane sales and secure more engineering projects.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by financials as dollar pauses
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.67%, following the Federal Reserve's approval of capital plans for major banks, including Citigroup and Morgan Stanley. The dollar paused at a 12-year high, allowing the euro to gain 0.08. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also rose, with the Nasdaq up 0.28%. The stronger dollar weighed on equities recently, but the Fed's approval helped lift financial stocks, with Citigroup and Morgan Stanley gaining 3.3% and 4%, respectively.

site_title: UK watchdog wants to ease bank account switching
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is pushing for bank account number portability, allowing customers to take their account number with them when switching banks. This would boost competition in high street banking, dominated by the "Big Five" banks. The FCA found that account number portability increases consumer confidence in the switching process, and the Payment Systems Regulator will consider the FCA's evidence. The UK government supports the idea, with junior finance minister Andrea Leadsom saying it could be introduced in stages, and the FCA has given regulators powers to force banks to deliver improvements.

site_title: Neeson again the conflicted, death-defying action guy
summary: Liam Neeson stars as Jimmy Conlon, a retired hitman haunted by his past, in the action-thriller Run All Night. After his estranged son Mike (Joel Kinnaman) is framed for murder, Jimmy must confront his dark past and team up with his son to take down the gang boss Shawn Maguire (Ed Harris) and his son Danny. Directed by Jaume Collet-Serra, the film marks a darker tone and moodier suspense compared to Neeson's previous Taken series, as he plays a character driven by family loyalty and a desire for redemption.

site_title: EU will be damaged if fails to agree US trade deal: UK minister
summary: The European Union may suffer economic and diplomatic damage if it fails to agree a transatlantic free trade deal, UK Minister for Europe David Lidington warned. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) has stalled, with each side accusing the other of protecting industry interests. Lidington stated that failure to agree on the deal would send a dismaying message about Europe's waning international importance, with damaging economic and diplomatic implications.

site_title: US business inventories flat, inventory-to-sales ratio highest since 2009
summary: US business inventories remained unchanged in January, contradicting expectations of a 0.1% gain. Sales fell 2.0% in January, the largest decline since March 2009, and would take 1.35 months to clear shelves, the highest inventory-to-sales ratio since July 2009. This suggests a potential stock drawdown in the months ahead, which could lead economists to lower their first-quarter GDP growth estimates. The decline in sales and inventories may also prompt businesses to cut back on stock additions, potentially affecting future economic growth.

site_title: ECB's QE could have unintended consequences
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) policy, worth 1.1 trillion euros, may have unintended consequences. The policy has boosted European bank lending, but also led to a run on the euro, rising bond yields, and currency turmoil in Asia. The euro's purchasing power parity has decreased, making it undervalued, and investors are hedging against the euro's decline. This has led to a surge in US dollar value and a decline in European bonds, stocks, and property values. The ECB's plan to boost the Eurozone economy may be hindered by these unforeseen effects.

site_title: VW brand to phase out slow-selling car models to revive earnings
summary: Volkswagen plans to discontinue slow-selling car models and scale back equipment options to revive profitability. The company aims to generate efficiency gains of "well over" 1 billion euros, lifting earnings at the VW brand this year. To achieve its goal of 6% margins by 2018, VW will phase out cars that contribute only a small portion of sales volume, abandon optional features in models ordered in fewer than 5% of cases, and boost investment in factories and electric car technology.

site_title: Swatch adds tech features to watches, positive on 2015
summary: Swatch Group, the world's largest watchmaker, plans to introduce new watches with near-field communications chip capabilities, allowing consumers to make payments with a swipe of their wrist. The company is working with China UnionPay, a Swiss bank, and a major credit card company, likely Visa, to provide functions such as building entrance control and contactless payments. The first watch models with these chips will go on sale in the next two months, while Bluetooth-enabled watches will become available by summer. This move aims to compete with Apple's upcoming smartwatch.

site_title: Oil market advances
summary: World oil prices rose on Thursday due to a weaker dollar, with European benchmark Brent North Sea crude advancing 82 cents to $58.36 a barrel and US benchmark West Texas Intermediate adding 52 cents to $48.69 a barrel. Despite a record-high US crude reserve, prices rebounded as a softer dollar stimulates demand and prices. The US Department of Energy reported a 4.5 million barrel increase in crude inventories, but prices have been capped, with analysts predicting volatility will continue.

site_title: US retail sales fall in February, weather likely a factor
summary: US retail sales dropped 0.6% in February, the third consecutive decline, likely due to harsh weather affecting automobile and shopping mall sales. Economists had forecast a 0.3% increase, and the decline may lead to lower first-quarter GDP growth estimates. Key sectors affected include automobiles (-2.5%), clothing stores (flat), and furniture/electronic appliances (-2.3%). Online stores saw a 2.2% increase, while gasoline prices rose 1.5%, lifting receipts at service stations.

site_title: US jobless claims fall, unwind prior weeks' increases
summary: US jobless claims fell 36,000 to 289,000 for the week ended March 7, unwinding prior weeks' increases. This marks a fresh sign of a rapidly strengthening labor market. The four-week moving average of claims also fell to 302,250. The unemployment rate remained at 5.5%, with the economy adding 295,000 jobs in February, the 12th straight month of employment gains above 200,000.

site_title: India's biggest bank aims to cut bad debt with huge online property auction
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) will hold a record online auction to sell repossessed properties worth nearly $200 million, aiming to cut its $10 billion bad debt. The auction comes ahead of rule changes forcing Indian banks to take on larger provisions for distressed loans. More than 10% of Indian bank loans have soured, leaving debt-burdened banks scrambling for cash. SBI's sale is the largest nationwide online sale to date, with over 300 pieces of property from 24 cities up for sale.

site_title: Greece allows lenders back into Athens
summary: Greece's creditors, including the European Union, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund, returned to Athens for the first time since the Syriza party came to power, with Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis denying that the government was forced to allow them back. The creditors are gathering data to assist talks on a new economic plan for Greece, which has been struggling to meet its debt repayments. The visit marks a breakthrough after six weeks of difficult discussions between the EU-IMF-ECB creditors and the radical new Greek government, which has been pushing for reforms and demanding a more lenient austerity program.

site_title: Oil giants use trading prowess to profit from crude's slump
summary: Europe's largest oil companies, BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Total, are benefiting from the industry's slump due to their significant trading prowess. They handle enough crude and refined products daily to meet the consumption of several major countries. The bear market allows traders to store cheap oil to sell at higher prices later, generating higher returns. This strategy is expected to pay off in 2015, as the trio capitalizes on lower prices to make more bets with the same capital. Their trading expertise is largely unknown outside the industry, but it's set to yield significant profits.

site_title: Hollande happy with euro value against the dollar
summary: French President Francois Hollande expressed satisfaction with the euro's current value against the dollar, noting it's near parity with the US dollar as it briefly fell below US$1.05. This drop, the first in 12 years, is seen as a favorable effect on European activity. Analysts predict further easing of the euro's value against the dollar, which reached US$1.40 in May last year.

site_title: The imperative to ensure our children are safe online
summary: A nationwide survey in Malaysia found that 1 in 4 schoolchildren were bullied online, with nearly 3/4 reporting name-calling or improper messages. Data from the Boston Consulting Group shows 8% of children may have unknowingly subscribed to commercial services, 1 in 10 may have been subject to data misuse, and 1 in 5 may have been exposed to harmful content. The internet poses significant risks, particularly for children, including cyberbullying, identity theft, and exposure to pornography.

site_title: Euro pulls out of dive, stocks edge higher
summary: The euro pulled out of its recent dive, recovering to trade at nearly US$1.06 after a week of breakneck moves in the global markets. The dollar eased off its gains, giving emerging markets and commodities some respite. The European Central Bank's 1 trillion euro bond buying campaign and a surprise interest rate cut by South Korea helped drive the market's pause. MSCI's main world stocks index secured its first rise in five days, with European bourses also seeing a solid start.

site_title: Greece, creditors to kick off fiscal talks in Athens: official
summary: Greece and its international creditors began fiscal talks in Athens on March 12, 2015, with a "fact-finding mission" gathering data to assist the talks. Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis said Greece would be able to pay its debts, despite a "relatively small cashflow problem." The talks come after six weeks of difficult negotiations, with the new Greek government pushing for reforms and debt restructuring. The creditors, including the EU, IMF, and ECB, want Greece to respect the terms of its 240-billion-euro bailout, which has not been fully implemented.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore Wrap Thursday highlights several key economic news stories. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. In Malaysia, an agency plans to seize approximately RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. Asean has deemed Myanmar's election a non-priority, while the UK economy contracted for the second consecutive month. South Korea's trade chief seeks a "landing zone" in US trade talks, and Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast.

site_title: Greece, OECD, sign cooperation deal on reform
summary: Greece and the OECD signed a cooperation deal to help the crisis-hit euro zone country carry out reforms, aiming to implement reforms prioritized by the Greek government. The OECD will provide Greece with know-how on reform design and implementation, and help evaluate reform effectiveness. This deal comes after Greek representatives started talks with EU, ECB, and IMF creditors in Brussels, seeking to unblock further aid. The OECD has previously provided Greece with a "tool kit" for reforms, which this new deal aims to replace.

images.alt_text: Greece and the OECD group of industrialised nations signed on Thursday a cooperation deal aimed at helping the crisis-hit euro zone country carry out reforms, officials said on Thursday.

site_title: UK trade deficit narrows sharply in Jan on booming services, oil price fall
summary: Britain's trade deficit narrowed to its smallest since mid-2013 in January, driven by a surge in services exports and a decline in oil prices. The deficit in goods trade also decreased, reaching 8.41 billion pounds. The UK's trade in services recorded its largest ever monthly surplus of 7.80 billion pounds, with exports reaching a record high of 18 billion pounds. These figures suggest progress towards weaning the country off domestic demand and could give the government fresh hope for economic recovery.

site_title: India in pacts to develop infrastructure in Mauritius, Seychelles
summary: India has secured agreements with Mauritius and Seychelles to develop infrastructure, marking an early success in its efforts to counter China's growing influence in the Indian Ocean. India aims to build a network of friendly ports to counter China's "String of Pearls" strategy. This move follows India's increased diplomatic efforts, offering civil and military assistance to countries in the region. The agreements are seen as a significant step in India's efforts to reclaim its influence in the Indian Ocean and counter China's growing economic presence.

site_title: Investment banks balk at EU fixed-income research payment plans
summary: EU regulators propose requiring investors to pay separately for fixed-income market research from trades, citing a need for pricing mechanism. Investment banks, including Nomura, argue research is cost-free for clients and separate payment would lead to extra costs for asset managers. Regulators believe the current bid-ask spread already covers the cost of research. The plan has sparked resistance from banks, who claim it would widen spreads and increase costs for clients.

site_title: Singapore Budget debate: Tweaks to Medisave limits and funding for the arts
summary: Singapore's health minister, Gan Kim Yong, announced tweaks to Medisave limits, with the Medisave Contribution Ceiling to be renamed Basic Healthcare Sum and increased to S$49,800, a 2.7% rise from last year's ceiling. The change will take effect from January next year. The Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth also discussed funding for the arts in their Committee of Supply debate.

site_title: India CPI quickens more than estimated, clouding rate calls
summary: India's retail inflation accelerated to 5.37% in February, exceeding economists' estimates of 5.21%. Factory output rose 2.6% in January, complicating the central bank's next move after an unscheduled interest-rate cut. This faster inflation reduces the chance of another cut next month, as Governor Raghuram Rajan aims to keep price gains within 6% by January.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO says will be part of any consolidation in Europe
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr stated the airline is prepared to be part of any European airline consolidation. He cited Eurowings, Lufthansa's budget unit, as a tool for this. Many industry experts believe European airlines need to consolidate to improve profitability. Spohr also welcomed a US white paper accusing Gulf airlines of receiving subsidies, stating it aligns with previous statements from Lufthansa and Air France.

site_title: US import prices rise, but inflation pressures still muted
summary: US import prices rose 0.4% in February, reversing a 7-month decline, due to increased petroleum costs. Despite this, inflation pressures remain muted, with economists forecasting a modest increase. This marks a slight deviation from the 0.2% rise predicted by Reuters. The Labour Department reported the revision in January's import prices, which had previously been reported as a 2.8% decline.

site_title: Alibaba hiring in Amazon, Microsoft backyard as US cloud unit expands
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, the world's largest e-commerce firm, is expanding its US operations and hiring staff in Seattle, including cloud computing professionals, at companies like Amazon and Microsoft. Three positions were advertised on LinkedIn, suggesting Alibaba is targeting talent from rival companies, including Amazon and Facebook. This move indicates Alibaba's growing presence in the US cloud market, where Amazon Web Services is a dominant player.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB secures RM950m standby credit from government
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) secured a RM950 million standby loan from the government on commercial terms. The move comes as the company faces criticism over its nearly RM42 billion debt and alleged financial mismanagement. 1MDB President Arul Kanda said the facility would help the company implement previously announced plans, amid Prime Minister Najib Razak's recent instruction to the Auditor General to verify 1MDB's accounts independently.

site_title: Eurozone factory output shows turn in sentiment in 2015
summary: Eurozone factory output showed a slight decrease of 0.1% in January, but annual production increased 1.2%, the best reading since July 2014. Strong performances in France, Germany, Spain, and Ireland helped drive the growth, while Italy's output fell 2.2%. The data supports hopes that the eurozone economy is recovering, with a weaker euro, low interest rates, and cheaper oil contributing to the trend. This could lead to modest growth in 2015 and an acceleration in 2016, according to the European Commission and the ECB.

site_title: Medisave limits tweaked; standardised Integrated Shield Plan to be out next year
summary: Singapore's Medisave Contribution Ceiling, set at S$48,500, will be renamed the Basic Healthcare Sum and increased to S$49,800 from January 2016. The limit will be adjusted annually to reflect growing healthcare needs. The Medisave Minimum Sum will be removed, allowing for flexible withdrawals. A standardized Integrated Shield Plan will be introduced in the first half of 2016, and Medisave Withdrawal Limits will be restructured to cover MediShield Life premiums and additional private insurance coverage separately.

site_title: ECB's Coeure says QE is working, there is no doubt it will work
summary: European Central Bank executive board member Benoit Coeure stated that the ECB's bond-buying plan is working and will continue to have effects, despite initial market concerns. Coeure emphasized the need to trust markets and avoid disrupting them. This comes as the ECB launched its quantitative easing (QE) plan on Monday.

images.alt_text: There is no doubt that the European Central Bank's bond-buying plan will work, executive board member Benoit Coeure said on Thursday, adding that it was already working and had started having effects even before it was launched on Monday.

site_title: Thai PTT Global looks to import more feedstock after oil prices drop
