summary: Thai PTT Global Chemical PCL plans to import more oil feedstocks after global crude prices drop, citing a potential shortage of domestic natural gas supply. The company, Thailand's top petrochemical producer, aims to maintain profitability by diversifying its raw materials. PTT Global will use more naphtha from its refinery and consider importing more feedstock, including shale gas, to supplement its natural gas supply. The move is part of a $4.5 billion expansion plan for 2015-2019.

site_title: Weidmann says Greek funding decision belongs to governments, not central banks
summary: European Central Bank policymaker Jens Weidmann stated that governments, not central banks, should decide whether to cover Greece's funding needs. Weidmann emphasized the importance of governments taking responsibility for their exposure to Greece, saying it's "less than ever" a task for the eurozone's central banks. This decision is crucial for Greece's economic stability, and Weidmann urged complacency in economic policy matters. The Bundesbank's 2014 profit fell to 2.95 billion euros due to reduced interest income, and Weidmann warned of a demographic shift weighing heavily on the German economy in the medium term.

site_title: Singapore banks to be net beneficiaries of gradual rate hikes: S&P
summary: Singapore banks are expected to be net beneficiaries of gradual rate hikes due to strong household and corporate balance sheets, according to a report by S&P. Higher interest rates will provide a revenue boost, while the banks' sound credit fundamentals will support debt repayment, offsetting increased credit costs. The report predicts Singapore banks will maintain their sound credit fundamentals in 2015.

site_title: Singapore: STI slides for fourth consecutive day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore slid 4.99 points to 3,373.6, marking its fourth consecutive day of losses, with a 1.3% decline. The index is now up just 8 points for 2015. US interest rate worries, a better-than-expected jobs report, and rising US bond prices have contributed to the market's downturn. Despite this, the STI briefly entered negative territory for the year and closed 0.4% higher on Thursday.

site_title: BMW speeds ahead to another record year in 2014
summary: BMW achieved its fifth consecutive record year in 2014, driven by strong demand for its vehicles worldwide. The company reported new highs in sales volume, revenues, and group earnings. Chief executive Norbert Reithofer attributed the success to "tailwinds caused by high customer demand." This marks the fifth consecutive year BMW has achieved record sales, solidifying its position as a top-of-the-range car maker.

images.alt_text: BMW, the German top-of-the-range car maker, said on Thursday it achieved its fifth record year in succession in 2014 on the back of buoyant demand for its vehicles.

site_title: Google launches virtual tour of Nepal's Everest region
summary: Google has launched a virtual tour of Nepal's Everest region, featuring over 45,000 panoramic images captured by teams who traveled on foot to remote villages inhabited by the ethnic Sherpa community. The project, in partnership with Story Cycle and Apa Sherpa, aims to raise funds for education and healthcare in the region. Apa Sherpa, a 21-time Mount Everest climber, hopes the project will promote the region and provide a way out for future generations. The virtual tour is now available online, offering a rare glimpse into life in one of the world's most inaccessible places.

site_title: PSA International net profit for 2014 down 1.7%
summary: PSA International reported a 1.7% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$1.4 billion for 2014, despite a 2.9% increase in revenue to S$3.83 billion. The company handled a record 65.44 million TEUs, with Singapore Terminals contributing 33.55 million TEUs, a 4.1% growth. PSA's business health is dependent on global trade and shipment growth, with group-wide performance holding its ground despite a sluggish global economy.

images.alt_text: PSA International (PSA) posted a 1.7 per cent slide year on year in net profit to S$1.4 billion for 2014, even as revenue climbed 2.9 per cent to S$3.83 billion.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets began trading on a mixed note, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.35% to 6,745.30 points, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt DAX 30 indices eased 0.14% and 0.08% respectively. The mixed performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus.

site_title: China in talks to include yuan in IMF basket, PBOC official says
summary: China is in talks with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to include the yuan in the institution's basket of reserve currencies, according to People's Bank of China Deputy Governor Yi Gang. This move aims to promote the yuan's global usage and facilitate China's financial reforms. The IMF will review its Special Drawing Rights basket later this year, which currently consists of the dollar, euro, yen, and British pound. China believes the yuan meets the criteria for reserve currency status and is heading towards being "freely usable."

images.alt_text: China is in talks with the International Monetary Fund to include the yuan in the institution's basket of reserve currencies, according to a central bank official.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.34% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.34% to 23,797.96 on Thursday, driven by bargain-buying following a six-session losing streak. The Shanghai Composite Index surged 1.78% to 3,349.32, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.26%. The rally was influenced by a surge in Shanghai and investors' cautious optimism despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Traditional arts to get S$25m boost in next five years
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY) will allocate an additional S$25 million over the next five years to support traditional arts. This follows the 2010 launch of the National Traditional Arts Plan, which invested S$23 million. MCCY will also develop the Stamford Arts Centre and provide S$12m to the National Monuments Fund for heritage conservation, including a Heritage Research Grant.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Shell boss gets 24.2m euro payout
summary: Royal Dutch Shell CEO Ben van Beurden's total compensation for 2014 is 24.2 million euros, including a salary, bonus, shares, pension, and other items. This figure is "unusually high" due to extra payments related to his long service and tax payments. The compensation is significantly higher than BP's CEO Bob Dudley's 20% increase to $12.74 million in 2014.

site_title: Keppel Corp extends deadline for Keppel Land takeover offer to March 26
summary: Keppel Corp has extended the deadline for its takeover offer on Keppel Land to March 26, after not receiving enough shareholder acceptances to reach its target of 90%. The conglomerate owns 80.8% of Keppel Land and is offering a two-tier price of S$4.38 and S$4.60 per share. The higher price values Keppel Land at around S$7.1 billion. An independent financial advisor had previously recommended shareholders accept the offer, citing it as "not fair but reasonable".

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.71 points to 1,786.87. The index saw 2.95 billion lots traded, with 537 gainers and 313 losers.

site_title: France stuck in deflation in February: official
summary: France's economy remained in deflation in February, with consumer prices declining 0.3% year-over-year, according to official figures. This marks the second consecutive month of deflation, following a 0.4% decline in January. The European Central Bank launched an anti-deflation program, aiming to keep inflation "close to, but below" 2%. Economists fear deflation can lead to weaker demand, slowing the economy and pushing up unemployment, making the situation more challenging for policymakers.

site_title: Handful of supertankers holding oil as contango play fades
summary: A few supertankers, chartered for oil storage, are now empty as the "contango play" to hold cheap oil and sell it later has lost momentum. More than 30 tankers were booked at the start of the year, but only 12 are still earmarked for storage, with only 1 Ultra Large Crude Carrier and 4 Very Large Crude Carriers filled. Oil prices have recovered from six-year lows, making storing oil onboard tankers unprofitable. Traders expect a supply overhang to cause prices to drop sharply in the second quarter, but recover in the second half of the year.

site_title: Malaysia said to pick banks for sale of US$2b Islamic bonds
summary: Malaysia has selected three banks - HSBC Holdings Plc, CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, and Standard Chartered Bank Plc - to arrange the sale of up to $2 billion of sovereign Islamic bonds. The bonds have a maturity of around five years or more. This move comes as the country taps global investors for the first time since 2011, amid concerns over rising debt levels and ahead of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve this year.

site_title: China's Xiaomi to set up 100 'experience' stores in India in 2015
summary: Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone maker, plans to open 100 'experience' stores in India by the end of 2015. The stores, which will be over 500-1,000 square feet, will be launched in cities like Hyderabad, Chennai, and Bangalore, and will not sell devices but rather provide a platform for consumers to experience the company's products. Xiaomi entered the Indian market in July 2014 and primarily sells its phones through online retailer Flipkart.com.

site_title: More M&A appetite likely this year, but Singapore may buck the global trend: KPMG
summary: Global corporates are expected to show greater M&A appetite this year, with a 7% increase in forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio. However, Singapore is expected to see a dip in acquisition appetite, with its forward P/E ratio dropping 3% due to global concerns around rising interest rates and weak growth expectations. The country's ability to fund transactions is also expected to improve, but at a slower pace than the global average. This trend is attributed to Singapore's open economy, which feels the effects of global headwinds faster than other economies in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 1.43% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 1.43% higher on Thursday, surpassing the psychologically significant 19,000 level. The Nikkei 225 and Topix index rose due to a weak yen boosting exporters. The gains overshadowed another loss on Wall Street.

site_title: Thai finance minister sees small impact from interest rate cut
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Sommai Phasee, stated that a 25-basis-point interest rate cut is unlikely to boost the economy significantly. The economy has expanded less than expected due to poor exports, and growth is uncertain to reach 4% this year. Phasee expressed the need for the central bank to signal a decrease in interest rates to have a substantial impact.

site_title: China central bank chief says to maintain prudent policy as economy slows
summary: China's central bank chief, Zhou Xiaochuan, stated that the country's monetary policy stance should remain prudent despite a slowing economy. Data shows the economy may miss its 7% growth target, with investment, retail sales, and factory output falling to multi-year lows. The central bank has cut interest rates twice since November and reduced reserve requirements to boost liquidity. However, economists expect further easing measures if inflation falls below 1%. The government has ruled out a massive stimulus program, but the central bank has embarked on an aggressive easing campaign to avoid a sharper economic slowdown.

site_title: China February new yuan loans well above forecast
summary: Chinese banks extended 1.02 trillion yuan (US$162.87 billion) in new loans in February, surpassing market expectations. The broad money supply rose 12.5% from a year ago, beating forecasts of 11%. Outstanding loan growth was 14.3%, exceeding analyst expectations. This surge in lending is seen as a sign of the economy's resilience, despite a target growth rate of around 7% for this year, which is the slowest expansion in a quarter of a century.

images.alt_text: Chinese banks extended 1.02 trillion yuan (US$162.87 billion) worth of new loans in February, well above market expectations, while growth in broad money supply quickened, central bank data showed on Thursday.

site_title: PBOC's Zhou touts prudent policy in new normal of slower growth
summary: China's central bank Governor Zhou Xiaochuan stated that the country's money supply growth is still "appropriate" despite a new normal of slower economic expansion. Zhou announced plans to remove the deposit-rate ceiling and introduce a deposit-insurance system this year, aiming to ease financial repression. The PBOC has cut interest rates twice since November and is expected to make another 25 basis point cut in the second quarter. The central bank is monitoring price data closely, with consumer prices rising faster than forecast in February.

site_title: Australia: Shares stage biggest rally in a month on upbeat jobs data
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to their largest one-day gain in a month, driven by better-than-expected jobs data. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5850.2, its biggest advance since February 13. This follows a similar trend in New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index, which rose 0.4% to 5886.8. The rally was seen as a positive sign for investors, despite dwindling chances of an imminent rate cut.

site_title: German inflation bounces back in February: data
summary: Germany's inflation rate bounced back in February, rising 0.1% due to consumer price increases, despite remaining below the European Central Bank's 2.0% target. This marks a reversal from January's 0.5% decline, which was the first in five years. The data offers hope that the eurozone can avoid deflation, following the ECB's recent bond-buying program aimed at raising inflation.

images.alt_text: Inflation in Germany, Europe's biggest economy, was back in positive territory in February with consumer prices rising by 0.1 per cent, official data showed on Thursday.

site_title: VW identifies half of planned 5b euro cost cuts
summary: Volkswagen has identified cost cuts worth approximately half of its 5 billion-euro target at its core autos division, with steps including ceasing unprofitable models and reducing expensive vehicle equipment. This could improve results at the troubled passenger-car brand by over 1 billion euros this year. The company's largest division, VW, saw earnings plunge 14% last year to 2.48 billion euros, with a 2.5% operating profit margin. The goal is to reach a 6% operating profit margin, which Volkswagen is on track to achieve.

site_title: Euro slumps on ECB stimulus
summary: The euro slumped to 12-year lows against the dollar, reaching US$1.0515, as the European Central Bank launched its quantitative easing program and the US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates possibly by June. Analysts predict dollar-euro parity by next year, citing the dollar's strong performance against other currencies, including the yen and won. This comes as the ECB and Bank of Korea cut interest rates to combat deflation and weak economic growth.

site_title: Seoul: Won recoups losses after rate cut, shares fall for 4th day
summary: The South Korean won recouped losses after the Bank of Korea cut interest rates, ending onshore trade nearly flat against the dollar at 1,126.4. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.5% for a fourth consecutive day to 1,970.59 points.

site_title: Noble's concession gives clout to maverick researchers
summary: Noble Group's decision to be more transparent after a blogger's accounting allegations has given more clout to independent researchers in Asia, who have exposed corporate practices that investors and analysts previously overlooked. Independent researchers, such as short-sellers and activist researchers, use social media and securities traders to spread their findings, often highlighting governance issues and accounting anomalies. Unlike activist investors, these researchers have successfully pressured companies like Noble to provide more information, leading to a shift in how companies are held accountable in the region.

site_title: China to expand scope of employment survey nationwide this year
summary: China plans to expand its employment survey nationwide in the second half of 2015, increasing coverage from 65 cities and counties to the entire country. This move aims to improve the accuracy of the country's two official unemployment measures. The expansion will also involve publishing more comprehensive indicators on unemployment, labor market participation, and other data starting next year.

site_title: Singapore-based private equity firm in Indonesia pharma deal
summary: Quadria Capital, a Singapore-based private equity firm, has sealed a "multi-million dollar" deal with PT Soho Global Health (SGH) in Indonesia, marking the first private equity deal in the country's pharmaceutical industry. The funds will be used to expand SGH's distribution network and support the growth of the medical device sector. SGH, which produces and distributes natural medicines and prescription products, has a network covering over 80% of hospitals and 90% of pharmacies in Indonesia. The partnership is backed by German development finance institution DEG.

site_title: Scintronix agrees to settle suit against ex-directors
summary: Scintronix Corp has agreed to settle a 2009 suit against former directors Ho Kang Peng and Chow Weng Fook, alleging breach of duties. The suit was filed while Scintronix was suspended and undergoing liquidation. No terms of the settlement were disclosed.

site_title: Changi named world's best airport for third consecutive year
summary: Changi Airport was named the world's best airport for the third consecutive year at the 2015 World Airport Awards, beating out Incheon International Airport, Munich Airport, and Hong Kong International Airport. The award was announced amidst the airport's significant development projects, including a new terminal and Jewel Changi Airport. The airport's popularity among travelers and its winning of the best airport for leisure amenities were highlighted as key factors in its success.

site_title: Alibaba teams with SAIC on US$160m fund for connected car
summary: Alibaba has partnered with SAIC Motor Corp to create a one billion yuan (US$160 million) fund for developing a connected car. The joint venture aims to create a platform for development and operation of a web-enabled car, with Alibaba providing cloud computing, digital entertainment, maps, and financial data. This move follows China's encouragement of non-traditional companies to collaborate with existing automakers to spur innovation and competition. Alibaba's involvement in the project may also utilize its homegrown operating system, YunOS, to increase smartphone adoption.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. is starting a one billion yuan (S$224.77 million) fund with SAIC Motor Corp, China's largest automaker, to develop a connected car that may go on sale next year.

site_title: Oil prices higher in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing 15 cents to $48.32 and Brent crude rising 56 cents to $58.10. The US Department of Energy reported record-high crude oil inventories, but analysts attributed gains to a slowdown in US oil-drilling activities. Despite this, prices are expected to remain volatile due to ongoing talks between the US and Iran on Tehran's nuclear program, which may impact global market clarity.

site_title: Lyft raises US$530m in Rakuten-led funding round
summary: Lyft, a ride-sharing service, has raised $530 million in a funding round led by Rakuten, valuing the company at over $2.5 billion. The funds will be used to expand its presence in 65 markets and invest in Lyft Line, a car-sharing service. Rakuten is investing $300 million for an 11.9% stake in Lyft. This funding round follows Lyft's previous funding rounds, including a $250 million raise last April that valued the company at above $1 billion.

site_title: Malaysia Jan factory output up 7% y-o-y, slightly below forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in January rose 7% year-over-year, slightly below forecast, according to data from the Statistics Department. This was driven by increases in manufacturing, mining, and electricity sectors. Exports fell 0.6% due to a slowdown in China. The result contrasts with expectations of a 7.4% expansion, likely due to the earlier Lunar New Year celebration this year.

site_title: Taiwan central bank governor says Taiwan has no deflation issues
summary: Taiwan's central bank governor, Perng Fai-nan, stated that the island has no deflation issues and prices will be positive this year. Lower oil prices will keep inflation very mild, according to the central bank. The consumer price index, a main inflation gauge, fell for a second month in February but narrowed its year-on-year decline compared to January.

site_title: Australia offers to pay for Bali pair's jail time if spared
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop has offered to pay the cost of life imprisonment for two Indonesian death row inmates, Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, if they are spared execution. The offer, made in a letter, comes as Canberra explores all avenues to convince Jakarta not to execute the pair, who are among several foreigners on death row for drug-related crimes. A prisoner-swap proposal was rejected, but the Australian government remains hopeful for clemency, with the majority of Australians strongly supporting their efforts.

site_title: AirAsia considering IPO for Indonesia unit, undeterred by crash
summary: AirAsia Bhd, Asia's largest budget carrier, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its Indonesia affiliate despite the recent crash of Flight 8501, which killed 162 people. CEO Tony Fernandes said an IPO would make the airline more transparent, while keeping options open. The crash occurred on December 28 when the plane disappeared from radar screens due to a sudden climb above authorized altitude. The investigation's preliminary report has not been released due to rapidly changing findings.

site_title: Time running out for KepCorp in KepLand takeover bid
summary: Keppel Corp's takeover bid for KepLand faces a setback as it falls short of the 90% shareholding threshold required to compulsorily buy out the remaining shares. Despite owning 80.8% of KepLand, the bid closes on Thursday with KepCorp still needing to acquire the remaining 19.2% stake. The offer price for the remaining shares is S$4.38 and S$4.60 if the bid is successful, valuing KepLand at around S$7.1 billion.

site_title: London square mile rising as bankers' residential ghetto
summary: Executives and bankers priced out of London's upscale neighborhoods are moving to a new residential area at the fringes of the City of London. Over 2,000 apartments are planned or under construction from Old Street to City Road, with 842 units in the City itself. This area is emerging as a new "bankers' ghetto" to accommodate those who can no longer afford luxury housing in Mayfair and Knightsbridge.

site_title: Singapore top execs best-paid in Asia in US dollar terms: study
summary: A study by Towers Watson found that top executives in Singapore received the highest average base salaries in Asia in US dollar terms, with an average of $586,000. This is 32% higher than Hong Kong, which paid $445,000. Base salaries in Singapore and Hong Kong grew 3-4%, but top management salaries increased 6-8%.

site_title: Even fewer acquittals in China last year: court
summary: China saw a decline in acquittals last year, with 778 defendants declared innocent, compared to 1.184 million found guilty, resulting in a 99.93% conviction rate. The drop in acquittals follows a teenager's wrongful execution for murder, prompting authorities to pledge to avoid miscarriages of justice. The Supreme People's Court reported the figures in a report to the National People's Congress legislature.

site_title: Thai interest rate cut will help exports: deputy PM
summary: Thailand's central bank unexpectedly cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 1.75% to boost confidence and hold the baht down, making exports more competitive. Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula stated that lower interest rates will help cap the baht's rise, supporting a 4% economy growth forecast for this year. This move aims to revive Thailand's struggling economy.

site_title: Euro slips to new 12-year low against dollar
summary: The euro has fallen to a 12-year low against the dollar, dropping 0.3% to US$1.0515. This decline follows the European Central Bank's launch of a 1 trillion euro quantitative easing scheme, which has driven down euro zone bond yields and increased the euro's appeal. The ECB's bond-buying programme has reduced the euro's value, making it less attractive to investors. The euro's lowest value since March 2003 was reached on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas sells US$5 billion of dollar bonds
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas sold US$5 billion of dollar-denominated bonds in four tranches, including a 30-year sukuk tranche with a yield 1.9 percentage points higher than US Treasuries. The bonds were sold at a spread of 150 basis points, down from 162.5 basis points in 2009. Petronas is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service, and the sale comes amid Malaysian issuers in the currency being the worst performers in Asia for the year.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines to list shares by Nov: CEO
summary: Vietnam Airlines will list its shares on the country's stock exchange by November, according to CEO Pham Ngoc Minh. The airline has raised $51 million through its initial public offering last November, but attracted little interest from foreign investors. Minh stated that the airline is in the process of selecting a foreign strategic investor, but declined to name any firm. The listing is expected to follow the rule of listing within one year from the initial public offering date.

site_title: Ringgit gains most in Asia as central bank says it's undervalued
summary: Malaysia's ringgit currency gained 0.3% to 3.6862 a dollar, its largest gain since Feb 26, after central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz reiterated the currency is "significantly undervalued". The statement calmed concerns about a potential default by state investment fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd, which led to a plunge in the ringgit to a six-year low. The move also halted a three-day decline in government bonds.

site_title: Brokers' Take: CIMB ups Straco to 'add' on Singapore Flyer's turnaround
summary: CIMB has upgraded its rating on Straco Corp to "add" due to the Singapore Flyer's turnaround, citing a stronger-than-expected fourth quarter profit of S$1.4 million. CIMB now expects the Flyer to contribute S$7 million in net profit annually, driven by flat visitor arrival growth and potential upside from redevelopment and new indoor attractions. The broker has raised its target price for Straco stock to S$1.01 from 78 cents.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rebound, dollar hits 12-year euro high
summary: The dollar reached a 12-year high against the euro after the European Central Bank launched a stimulus program, while Asian equity markets rebounded. The dollar edged closer to parity with the euro, with the single currency fetching US$1.0542. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, but the ECB's quantitative easing scheme has created uncertainty. South Korea cut interest rates to a record low, and oil prices were mixed. Asian markets rose, with Tokyo up 0.88%, Sydney adding 0.88%, and Seoul gaining 0.22%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up on bargain hunting, weaker TWD to support exports
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.62% on Thursday, following three days of losses, due to value buying and a weaker TWD. The currency has weakened to T$31.730 to the U.S. dollar, making exports more competitive. A broader-based buying was seen in various sectors, including electronics and financials, with TSMC rising 1.4%. The rally is attributed to optimism for the trade-reliant economy and the recent interest rate cut by South Korea.

site_title: India's Feb consumer inflation likely edged up for third month
summary: India's consumer inflation likely rose 5.2% in February, the third consecutive month of increase, driven by higher food prices. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) may leave interest rates unchanged in its policy review on April 7 unless retail inflation falls sharply. The central bank has cut interest rates twice this year to spur growth, with a target inflation rate of 4% set for next year. Industrial output growth slowed to 0.65% in January, and the RBI is expected to monitor inflation and economic growth closely.

site_title: AirAsia 'not giving up' but hunt for bodies drawing to close
summary: AirAsia boss Tony Fernandes said the hunt for bodies from the crashed QZ8501 jet will close within 7-10 operational days, with around 60 bodies still unaccounted for. The airline has recovered over 100 bodies and black box recorders since the crash in December, killing all 162 people on board. Fernandes assured families that the search won't go on indefinitely, despite a reported slowdown in discoveries in recent weeks. Indonesia will release the final report on the crash by August.

images.alt_text: AirAsia boss Tony Fernandes said on Thursday he was not giving up on finding more bodies from one of the airline's jets that crashed in the Java Sea last year, but flagged the hunt will draw to a close within weeks.

site_title: Oil trades near two-week low as rising US supplies expand glut
summary: Oil prices traded near a two-week low after US crude stockpiles expanded, contributing to a global surplus of 1 million to 1.5 million barrels per day. US crude inventories rose to 448.9 million barrels, the highest level since August 1982, with the nation's output climbing despite a four-year low in active rigs. The global market is oversupplied, driving prices down by almost half in 2014, with West Texas Intermediate trading at $48.21 a barrel and Brent at $57.79 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil traded near the lowest price in two weeks after government data showed US crude stockpiles expanded further from a record high, adding to a global surplus.

site_title: Intraco wins S$6.6m claim in dispute with Timor Global
summary: INTRACO has won a S$6.6 million arbitration award against Timor Global, excluding interest and costs. The award stems from a joint-venture agreement dispute between the two companies. Intraco's initial claim was S$9.8 million, with S$3.2 already received. The company is now consulting with its legal advisers on the next step, as shares remained quiet following the announcement.

site_title: China, Japan, South Korea to discuss first summit in three years
summary: China, Japan, and South Korea are set to discuss their first leaders' summit in three years, following successful foreign ministers' talks. The meeting, possibly in Seoul, aims to address territorial disputes and Japan's war legacy ahead of the 70th anniversary of WWII. A three-way summit would be a significant step towards improving relations between the three Asian economies.

site_title: Singapore: STI follows Wall Street's modest decline to slip 0.2% after opening
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.2% to 3,371.02 on March 12, 2015, following a modest decline on Wall Street. Trading was light, with 61.7 million shares changing hands worth S$62.2 million. Gainers and losers were evenly matched, with 61 stocks up and 62 down. The decline was attributed to a slight downturn on Wall Street ahead of economic data release.

site_title: Uber, Lyft rebuffed in bids to deem drivers independent contractors
summary: Uber and Lyft failed to persuade US judges to rule that their drivers are independent contractors, with separate judges ruling that juries would determine the status of each company's drivers. The companies face class-action lawsuits seeking reimbursement for expenses, which could significantly raise their costs and affect valuations. Judges Edward Chen and Vince Chhabria noted that Uber and Lyft drivers provide key services and can be terminated, but the issue is not "unambiguous" and should be decided by juries. The rulings could impact the startups' valuations and the broader "sharing economy" industry.

site_title: Dymon Asia macro fund returns 7% since January loss, adds assets
summary: Dymon Asia Capital's US$3.5 billion global macro hedge fund has recouped some losses since a 10.5% January drop, returning 7% as of March. The fund had previously pledged to return performance fees to investors if it failed to recoup the loss within two years. New capital has been added, with US$230 million injected in February and March. The fund's sister currency fund, US$300 million Dymon Asia Currency Value Fund, returned 35.5% this year through March 6.

site_title: Australia employment rises, but not fast enough
summary: Australian employment rose 15,600 in February, matching market expectations, with the jobless rate dipping to 6.3%. Hours worked increased 0.8%, a positive sign of stronger demand for labor. Despite the moderate growth, experts warn that faster growth is needed to prevent the unemployment rate from rising further.

site_title: AirAsia CEO says plans to resume flights to Europe next year
summary: AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes announced plans to resume flights to Europe next year, with London as the likely first destination. The airline's long-haul arm, AirAsia X, previously operated flights to London and Paris before cancelling services in 2012. The search for remaining passengers from crashed flight QZ8501 will likely be called off within 7-10 days.

site_title: China: Shares higher in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose in morning trade, driven by hopes for economic stimulus following weak data. The Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.92% to 3,321.11, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.27% to 1,693.79. The moves followed a weak round of economic data, with investors optimistic about potential policy changes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Thursday, edging down 8.80 points to 23,709.17, as another loss on Wall Street offset bargain-buying following a recent sell-off.

site_title: Malaysia central bank sees slower growth in 2015, sliding oil prices a risk
summary: Malaysia's central bank expects the country's economy to grow 4.5-5.5% in 2015, driven by strong domestic demand and exports. However, declining oil prices pose a risk to the country's fiscal position, with revenue under pressure. Additionally, concerns over a sovereign downgrade, capital outflows, and the prospect of higher US interest rates also threaten the outlook. The ringgit has hit a six-year low due to these factors.

site_title: US judge rejects Uber request that drivers deemed contractors
summary: A US judge rejected Uber's request to classify its drivers as independent contractors, not employees. The decision comes in a case brought by Uber drivers who claimed they should be reimbursed for expenses such as gas and vehicle maintenance. The ruling from US District Judge Edward Chen in San Francisco upholds the drivers' status as employees, potentially affecting their benefits and working conditions.

images.alt_text: A US judge on Wednesday denied ride-hailing app Uber's request that its drivers be deemed independent contractors rather than employees.

site_title: WE Holdings to buy sand supplier for S$25m
summary: WE Holdings plans to acquire marine sand supplier Hua Kai for S$25 million, subject to balance sheet and profit targets. The acquisition is partly funded by a S$25 million three-year convertible bond issue. This deal comes as WE Holdings continues its expansion strategy.

site_title: Japan big manufacturers less optimistic in Q1: govt
summary: Japan's big manufacturers have become less optimistic about the economy, with a business survey index (BSI) of plus 2.4 in January-March, down from plus 8.1 in the prior quarter. They expect business conditions to worsen in the following quarter, indicating a fragile recovery from recession. Japanese firms plan to raise capital spending by 5.1% in the current business year, but expect a 3.9% decline in the next fiscal year.

site_title: US oil price drop on record-high stockpiles
summary: US oil prices dropped to a record high on Wednesday, with West Texas Intermediate falling 64 cents to $47.65 per barrel, reversing earlier gains. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 4.5 million barrel increase in oil reserves, the highest level since 1982, stoking supply glut concerns. European benchmark Brent North Sea crude rose 65 cents to $57.04 per barrel. Analysts attribute the drop to the strong US dollar, which makes dollar-priced oil more expensive for buyers using weaker currencies.

site_title: UK lawmakers warn Royal Mail against further price hikes
summary: UK lawmakers have warned Royal Mail against further price hikes to meet its state-mandated delivery obligations, urging the postal operator to focus on improving efficiency instead. The committee recommended closer monitoring by industry regulator Ofcom to ensure Royal Mail can deliver on its Universal Service Obligation. Despite concerns about rising financial pressure, the committee concluded that Royal Mail's ability to meet the obligation was not under threat. Royal Mail has raised prices in the past, with stamp prices set to rise again to offset declining letter volumes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.34% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.34% higher on Thursday, driven by a weak yen following a choppy US market session. The euro slipped towards parity with the dollar, making Japanese exporters more competitive overseas. The dollar traded at 121.46 yen, while the euro fell to 128.07 yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 63.58 points to 18,787.10. The gains were attributed to a weak yen, which eased selling sentiment, and expectations of a possible interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma, Noble, Darco
summary: A Yoma Strategic Holdings subsidiary received approval to redevelop the former Burma Railways Co headquarters into a luxury hotel, with Yoma holding an 80% stake. Noble Group shares closed at a 17-month low due to allegations of aggressive accounting. Darco Water Technologies' shares jumped 29% after a trading query, despite the company stating it was unaware of any undisclosed information. The Singapore Exchange issued a "trade with caution" note on Darco.

site_title: Fed rejects capital plans of US arms of Deutsche Bank, Santander
summary: The Federal Reserve rejected the capital plans of US arms of Deutsche Bank and Santander, citing "widespread and substantial weaknesses" in their planning processes. The Fed also gave Bank of America a qualified pass after finding problems with its loss and revenue modeling practices. The rejections mean neither bank can distribute profits to shareholders without Fed permission. Both banks have committed to strengthening their capital planning processes. The Fed praised the progress of the 31 largest US banks, which passed the first phase of stress tests and plan to return 60% of net profits to shareholders.

site_title: Claims Australian teen was suicide bomber 'horrific': PM
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott described claims of a 19-year-old Australian teenager, Jake Bilardi, being a suicide bomber for the Islamic State group as "absolutely horrific". The claims, which cannot be independently verified, follow a photo posted online showing Bilardi in a driver's seat before an attack in western Iraq. Bilardi, who converted to Islam after his mother's death, had been identified by friends and mosque members. Abbott highlighted the lure of the Islamic State organisation for impressionable youngsters, calling it a "death cult".

site_title: Samsung Electronics says to start won-yuan direct trade on March 16
summary: Samsung Electronics will start buying and selling the Chinese yuan for the won from the Seoul market on March 16, using the Korean yuan-won market to settle direct transactions between its headquarters and Chinese subsidiaries. This move could boost the fledgling yuan-won market, aligning with China's goal to increase the yuan's international use and South Korea's aim to become a global hub for yuan-related businesses.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 3.31 points to 1781.47. Gainers outnumbered losers 117 to 53, with volume reaching 82.25 million lots worth RM23.41 million. The rally follows a broader Asia market trend, where stocks have been driven up by investors' positivity despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: South Korea central bank cuts rates to record low in surprise move
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, cut interest rates for the first time in five months by 25 basis points to a record low of 1.75%, in a surprise move to boost sluggish growth. Only four out of 33 analysts polled by Reuters had forecast a rate cut, but 19 had predicted a cut in April or later. The decision is seen as a sign of the bank's efforts to stimulate the economy amid weak growth.

site_title: US inequality debate turns to decline of unions
summary: The US inequality debate has shifted its focus to the decline of labour unions, which are seen as a key factor in stagnant wages for middle- and lower-class Americans. President Barack Obama criticized a Wisconsin law weakening union abilities. Economists and activists argue that the lack of organized labour power contributes to income inequality. This comes as wages have not risen significantly for decades. The issue highlights the need for stronger labour unions to promote workers' rights and boost wages.

site_title: CNA plans investment in China aluminium mining
summary: CNA Group has signed a non-binding MOU to invest 5% in a bauxite-processing plant and mine in Shanxi, China. The estimated value of the investment will be determined after due diligence. The mine has S$600 million reserves and generates S$10 million annually. The investment is expected to have a material impact on 2015 results, with CNA shares trading at 2.2 Singapore cents following the announcement. The agreement includes engineering expertise and services from LiuLinxian Senzetengfei Aluminium Industry Co.

images.alt_text: CNA Group has signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding to take a 5 per cent stake in a bauxite-processing plant and mine in Shanxi, China.

site_title: Thailand surprises with rate cut to lift weak confidence
summary: Thailand unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate to 1.75% on March 11, 2015, in an effort to boost the weak economy. This is the first rate cut in a year and the lowest since mid-2010. The move comes after the Bank of Thailand warned that this year's economic growth will be below its 4% forecast, citing weak consumer and government spending. The rate cut aims to lift sentiment and confidence, but economists expect limited impact and no further cuts in the near future.

site_title: Mars Inc set to open first chocolate factory in India
summary: Mars Inc plans to open its first chocolate factory in India, valued at $160 million, in Pune, Maharashtra. The plant will manufacture popular Snickers and Galaxy bars to meet growing demand, with the Indian chocolate market expected to grow 20% annually. Mars India currently imports chocolate and manufactures pet care products. The move is seen as a significant expansion opportunity for the company in the country.

site_title: Britain's banking shake-up will take at least five years to bear fruit: regulator
summary: Britain's five biggest banks dominate 85% of current accounts, but regulators expect a more diversified market to emerge in 2020 or later. The Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) predicts 5-6 new bank licences will be granted annually for the next few years, but significant inroads into the market won't be made until then. New entrants focus on targeted markets, but business is still tiny compared to the Big Five. Further consolidation is likely, even among new banks, as competition and diversification continue to drive the sector.

site_title: IMF approves US$17.5b lifeline for Ukraine
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a $17.5 billion aid plan for crisis-wracked Ukraine, replacing an existing program that proved inadequate. The four-year financial aid program aims to stabilize Ukraine's finances, support economic growth, and improve living standards. The new program provides more time, flexibility, and financing terms, with $5 billion disbursed immediately. The IMF's managing director, Christine Lagarde, stated that the program will support immediate economic stabilization and medium-term growth, as part of a comprehensive economic reform plan.

site_title: Apple apologises after outage hits online services
summary: Apple apologized for a nearly 12-hour outage of its online services, including the App Store, iTunes, and Mac App store, affecting customers worldwide and similar outages in Britain and France. The outage, which began at 0900 GMT, was resolved around 2030 GMT. Reports indicated that more than 40 countries were affected. Apple acknowledged the disruption and expressed regret for the inconvenience caused.

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets finished higher on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.28% to 6,721.51 points. The eurozone saw gains of 2.37% and 2.66% in Paris and Frankfurt, respectively. The increases were attributed to ECB head Mario Draghi's upbeat comments.

site_title: IMF chief sees 'better news' at last for advanced economies
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde reported "better news" for advanced economies, citing cheap oil, currency shifts, and low interest rates. The US economy is rebounding, the UK is showing improvement, and the eurozone is turning the corner. This contrasts with slower growth in emerging markets, such as China and Russia. The low oil price is seen as a net positive for the global economy, while currency fluctuations and low interest rates are boosting exports and investment. However, risks remain, including geopolitical turmoil and diverging monetary policies.

site_title: New Zealand leaves interest rates at 3.5%
summary: New Zealand's central bank maintained interest rates at 3.5% as inflation remains in check. Governor Graeme Wheeler cited lower oil prices and a strong domestic economy as reasons for the decision, but noted that a sustainable external balance requires a downward correction in the real exchange rate. The decision maintains the rate unchanged since July last year to assess the impact of recent interest rate hikes.

site_title: Scheme to encourage upgrades to less-pollutive diesel vehicles to be expanded
summary: Singapore is expanding its Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) to encourage diesel vehicle owners to upgrade to cleaner models. The scheme, which began in 2013, will now include Euro II and III emissions standards, benefiting about 40% of Cat C diesel vehicles on the roads. Owners will receive a bonus COE period, discounts on the Prevailing Quota Premium, and the option to transfer unused COE validity. The expansion aims to reduce air pollution and promote cleaner transportation.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: US Fed slashes payout plans of large Wall Street banks
summary: The US Federal Reserve has rejected payout plans for the US units of two European banks, Deutsche Bank and Santander, due to weaknesses in their capital planning processes. However, four large US banks, including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and JPMorgan Chase, have passed the Fed's stress tests, but with lower dividend and share buyback plans to ensure they can withstand a hypothetical financial crisis. Bank of America has also passed the test, but was told to improve its internal controls and data models.

images.alt_text: Four of the largest US banks just scraped by in an annual Federal Reserve check-up on the industry's health, underscoring their top regulator's enduring doubts about Wall Street's resilience more than six years after the crisis.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as dollar strengthens again
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 27.55 points to 17,635.39, as the dollar hit a new 12-year high against the euro. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped, with the dollar's ascent causing worry about US exports. Notable movers included Apple, Salix Pharmaceuticals, and Mylan, while large banks rose ahead of Federal Reserve decisions on capital requirements. Bond prices rose, with the 10-year Treasury yield dropping to 2.11%.

site_title: In brief
summary: Nam Cheong secured US$58 million vessel orders, increasing its order book to RM1.7 billion. GLP signed 63,000 sqm agreements in China with e-commerce, packaged foods, and pharmaceutical companies. A-Sonic Aerospace will consolidate shares, and Junma Tyre Cord Company proposed a voluntary delisting with an exit offer price of 20 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Draghi: ECB measures will hit inflation target
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the ECB's expanded asset purchases will successfully push inflation in the euro area back towards its goal of 2%. The asset purchases, which began on March 5, are expected to stabilize inflation and support the recovery. The ECB has also lifted its growth forecasts for the euro area, predicting 1.5% growth this year, 1.9% in 2016, and 2.1% in 2017.

site_title: Vietnamese brokerages raising funds to prepare for bigger market
summary: Vietnam's top 12 brokerages, which posted an 81% average net profit jump last year, are raising funds to invest in Asia's fastest-growing stock market and prepare for borrowing from local margin traders. The brokerages aim to secure a bigger foothold in the competitive sector, with plans to raise US$340 million in the next two years. The government's efforts to upgrade the stock market and attract foreign investors are expected to boost liquidity, but the market remains vulnerable to volatility and external shocks.

site_title: Wanted: A managerial culture that embraces cultural differences
summary: Asian firms seeking "global" managers to expand overseas may benefit from hiring individuals who grew up abroad, as they are well-attuned to cross-cultural ventures. Research suggests that innovators who are educated in a globally-minded approach, such as third culture kids (TCKs) and adult third culture kids (ATCKs), can successfully transition from innovation to management. A new managerial culture that embraces cultural differences is needed to support these individuals, rather than expecting them to become managers themselves. This approach can help overcome barriers to collaboration and intellectual property theft, and can lead to more innovative and successful businesses.

site_title: Tylenol maker to pay US$25m for selling metal-contaminated medicine
summary: Johnson & Johnson's subsidiary, McNeil Consumer Healthcare, pleaded guilty to selling contaminated liquid medicine and agreed to pay US$25 million. The company sold metal-contaminated medicine, violating US regulations. This resolution resolves a federal case, with no further details provided.

site_title: Japan machinery orders fall less than expected
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 1.7% in January from the previous month, underscoring the challenges facing the government's stimulus policies. Despite this, emerging export signs have led some analysts to take a more optimistic view of the outlook for capital spending. The economy is still struggling to recover from last year's recession, with the government seeking to boost spending on wages and equipment.

images.alt_text: A construction site in the Toyosu district in Tokyo. Companies have been slow to implement robust capital spending plans.

site_title: London's housing shortage seen hurting tech industry
summary: London's growing technology industry may face challenges due to the city's housing shortage. According to a Crown Estate executive, the shortage, combined with high rents, poses a significant risk to the industry's continued success. With technology companies being the largest source of office demand in London, a shortage of homes could deter companies from expanding further. The city needs 49,000 new homes annually to accommodate its growing population, but only 22,000 are built each year.

site_title: Alibaba to invest in Snapchat at US$15b valuation
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd plans to invest $200 million in Snapchat, valuing the photo-messaging service at $15 billion. This investment is separate from a potential $500 million funding round that could value Snapchat at up to $19 billion. The deal does not involve Alibaba's existing investment in Snapchat, which was valued at $3 billion in 2013. Neither Alibaba nor Snapchat representatives have commented on the matter. The investment is seen as a strategic move by Alibaba to expand its presence in the US market and tap into Snapchat's growing user base.

images.alt_text: Chinese e-commerce company Alibaba Group Holding Ltd is planning to invest US$200 million in Snapchat, valuing the photo-messaging service at about US$15 billion, Bloomberg reported on Wednesday, citing people it said were familiar with the situation.

site_title: Bonds, US$ strength show investors expect interest rate hikes soon
summary: US investors increasingly expect interest rate hikes in 2015, driven by a strong February jobs report and rising bond yields. The 10-year yield reached its biggest move in over a year, while short-dated bond yields saw their biggest gains in a month. The US dollar index has risen 9.1% against major currencies, and some investors are positioning for multiple rate increases in the second half of the year. The Fed's decision to raise rates may be delayed if US growth weakens or a Greece debt crisis escalates.

site_title: Unions square up to Obama over Asia trade deal
summary: The AFL-CIO, a top US trade union federation, has announced it will withhold election spending to oppose President Barack Obama's pending Asia trade deal. This move aims to build a war chest to fight the deal, putting pressure on the White House and Democrats who support it. The federation spent over $9 million in the 2012 election cycle, largely funding Democrats. The decision reflects growing opposition to the trade deal among labor unions.

images.alt_text: A top US trade union federation said on Wednesday it would withhold key election spending as it builds a war chest to fight President Barack Obama's pending trade deal with Asia.

site_title: Aussie mining, oil firms take a hit from China slowdown, price falls
summary: Australian mining and oil firms are facing a tough year due to China's slowdown, with the price of iron ore falling to a six-year low of below US$60. China's cut to its 2015 economic growth target to 7% has led to a decrease in steel use, reducing iron ore demand. Smaller miners are struggling, with some sharing prices plummeting by 78-90% over the past year. Major players such as BHP and Rio Tinto are maintaining their supply to maintain market share, while smaller operators are forced to reduce production or stop operations.

site_title: Temasek, Carmignac said to be in talks for stake in ICICI's insurance unit
summary: ICICI Bank is in talks to sell about 5% of its stake in ICICI Prudential Life Insurance to Temasek Holdings and Carmignac Gestion for approximately $300 million. The sale, planned for completion by the end of March, comes after Prime Minister Narendra Modi allowed more foreign investment in the insurance industry last year. The move follows ICICI's insurance venture, which is India's biggest private-sector life insurer, and is seen as part of the bank's strategy to pursue an initial public offering after the insurance bill is passed.

site_title: Rents for condos, HDB flats slip further in Feb: SRX
summary: Residential rents in Singapore continued to decline in February, with private condos and HDB flats experiencing 0.8% and 0.3% drops, respectively. Rents have fallen 6.2% from last year and 10.5% from their peak in January 2013. Consultants expect rents to decline further by 6-8% this year due to a record number of new condo completions, tighter expat inflow, and rising interest rates.

site_title: Denmark's eye on home price as it defends krone
summary: Denmark's economy minister, Morten Oestergaard, warns that house price distortions may arise as the country defends its euro peg by cutting interest rates below zero. The central bank has already driven mortgage rates to negative yields, causing house prices to surge, with some areas in Copenhagen exceeding 2007 peaks. While the government is monitoring the situation, it's not discussing immediate intervention, but is prepared to act if necessary to prevent unsustainable house price growth. The negative interest rates are seen as a necessary stimulus package to support the economy.

site_title: Lessors see demand for Boeing 757 jet replacement
summary: Airlines and aircraft leasing companies are urging Boeing to develop a new jet to replace its discontinued 757, citing demand for a 200-250 seat aircraft. Industry leaders believe Boeing can focus on upgrading its 737 model while developing a new plane, which could also help engine makers improve fuel efficiency. The proposed timeline for a new jet leaves room for Boeing to prioritize existing orders, and some see a shift in emphasis towards a small twin-aisle jet.

site_title: Apple Watch targets Chinese aspirations
summary: Apple Watch has launched in China, targeting the country's aspirations for luxury timepieces. The smartwatch starts at 2,588 yuan, appealing to China's appetite for gold-plated items. However, the anti-graft campaign may dampen luxury watch sales, as conspicuous consumption has become a hot issue. Analysts predict the Apple Watch will be a hit in China, with sales potentially surpassing 5 million units this year. Despite this, the most expensive models may face a tough sell due to the government's anti-corruption efforts.

site_title: Spickify acquired by Rocket Internet-backed rival Helpling
summary: Spickify, a Singapore-based cleaning services platform, has been acquired by Helpling, a rival backed by Rocket Internet. The acquisition, undisclosed, marks Helpling's expansion into the Singapore market. Spickify had amassed 200 recurring customers and 150 cleaners before the acquisition, charging a flat hourly rate of S$18-20 with liability insurance of up to S$1 million. Following the acquisition, Spickify will be rebranded as Helpling, offering similar services and benefits, including a mobile app launch later this year.

site_title: China Jan-Feb property sales post biggest fall in 3 years
summary: China's property sales in the first two months of 2015 plummeted 15.8% from the same period last year, the largest decline in three years, due to a housing supply glut. This has raised concerns about the government's 7% GDP growth target and the risks faced by the property sector, which accounts for 15% of China's economic output. Despite some signs of stabilization in home prices, the real estate downturn is expected to persist through the first half of the year, affecting related economic sectors.

site_title: Noble Group shares sink to a 17-month low
summary: Noble Group's stock plummeted to a 17-month low of 92 cents on Wednesday, down 1.6% after a report revealed the commodity trader was seeking a US$3 billion refinancing. The stock had rebounded last week after refuting Iceberg Research's comments on its accounting practices, but fell 12.8% this week. The company's market cap has been wiped off by S$1.92 billion since Feb 13, 2015. Noble Holdings, a vehicle associated with the group's founder, raised its stake to 20.9561% after purchasing shares on Wednesday.

site_title: No immediate plans to hold back COEs
summary: The Singapore government has no immediate plans to hold back Certificates of Entitlement (COEs) to smooth out the future supply. Senior Minister of State for Transport Josephine Teo stated that implementing this idea would not be straightforward, considering the constrained overall vehicle population growth. The idea of reserving COEs was studied over the past year, but its implementation is not currently on the agenda.

site_title: Interest rate volatility may lead to capital flight from S-Reits: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse warns that interest rate volatility could lead to a capital outflow from Singapore's S-Reit sector, presenting a buying opportunity. Currently, valuations are expensive, but volatility could bring the market back to a risk-on mode.

site_title: Standalone shophouse block at Sultan Gate sold for S$20.8m
summary: A standalone shophouse block at Sultan Gate in Singapore's Kampong Glam area has been sold for S$20.8 million, working out to S$2,618 per square foot based on its 7,401 sq ft floor area. The buyer plans to operate its own F&B outlet on the lower level, while the upper level will be used for other purposes. The property is currently leased to a bistro operator until September.

images.alt_text: The Sultan Gate shophouses were first put up for sale in March last year at an indicative price of S$28 million

site_title: Lagerfeld & Chanel bring fantasy Paris to life at fashion week
summary: Karl Lagerfeld brought fantasy Paris to life at Chanel's fashion week by creating a pop-up, fully functioning Paris cafe dubbed "Brasserie Gabrielle" that served as a catwalk and guest refreshment. The specially-built set featured a neoclassical glass-roofed exhibition hall and was designed to showcase the brand's autumn-winter women's collection. The cafe scene was designed to amplify a positive, idealized vision of Paris, countering "French bashing" and showcasing the city's elegance and sophistication.

site_title: Bank Negara chief declares banking system resilient
summary: Malaysia's banking system has been deemed resilient, according to Bank Negara Malaysia's 2014 annual report. Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz stated that the system can withstand shocks, including loan defaults by highly leveraged entities, and maintain its capital base above the minimum requirement. The report comes amid concerns over the financial viability of state-owned 1MDB, which has seen its debt and currency value decline. Despite this, the central bank has expressed confidence in the system's resilience, with projected current account surpluses and adequate international reserves.

images.alt_text: Dr Zeti said banks' profitability might be affected, but that their capital base would stay above the minimum requirement. Asked about 1MDB, she said the law barred her from commenting on the agency allegedly having bypassed the central bank in making a loan.

site_title: Boustead wins suit over Libya contract
summary: Boustead Singapore has won a US$18.8 million dispute with Bahrain bank Arab Banking Corporation, which had sued the firm for payment over a S$300 million contract to build a township in Libya that was halted due to the 2011 civil war. The Singapore High Court dismissed the bank's claim as "unconscionable" and ordered the bank not to receive payment from Boustead.

site_title: Credit Suisse's new boss could axe 2,900 jobs: analysts
summary: Credit Suisse's new CEO, Tidjane Thiam, may cut 2,900 jobs from its investment bank, or 15% of staff, as part of a shift to private banking in Asia. Analysts estimate the bank could save 150 billion Swiss francs by reducing assets in fixed income, commodities, and currencies. The move aims to improve leverage and address capital strength concerns. Thiam's new mandate is expected to focus on growing private banking in Asia, potentially driving a 28 franc price target for the stock.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality launches third property in KL
summary: Frasers Hospitality has launched its third serviced residence in Kuala Lumpur, Fraser Residence Kuala Lumpur, with 445 units. The property is the company's largest serviced residence in the city and brings its portfolio in Kuala Lumpur to 1,000 units. Frasers Hospitality expects strong demand for its properties due to the resurgence of interest from foreign firms and the government's Economic Transformation Programme, which aims to attract US$59.4 billion in economic growth by 2020. The property features a range of amenities, including a gym, pool, and dining restaurant.

site_title: New vaccine boosts India's bid to become low-cost lab of the world
summary: India has developed the first indigenously produced vaccine against Rotavirus, a diarrhoea-causing virus responsible for 80,000 Indian child deaths annually. The vaccine, Rotavac, was developed through a 25-year US-India collaboration and will be available at $1 per dose, significantly cheaper than the global market price of $20. This breakthrough is seen as a step towards India becoming a low-cost lab for vaccine production, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi stating that Indian solutions will have global relevance.

site_title: Firm policy actions, cheaper oil to lift India's growth to 7.2%: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts India's economy will grow by 7.2% in the current fiscal year, driven by "firm policy actions" from Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government and lower global oil prices. This makes India one of the fastest-growing big emerging market economies globally. The IMF notes India's economy is a bright spot in the global landscape.

site_title: Rail service still has 'some way to go'
summary: Singapore's rail service still has room for improvement despite higher levels of commuter satisfaction, according to Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew. Recent breakdowns have eroded confidence in the network, despite intensive efforts by the Land Transport Authority and rail operators over the past few years. The issues of public transport capacity and affordability will need to be addressed to meet growing demand.

site_title: Korean Air flight attendant in 'nut rage' case sues chairman's daughter
summary: A Korean Air flight attendant who was involved in a "nut rage" incident that led to the conviction of the airline's former head of in-flight service, Heather Cho, a daughter of the chairman, has filed a civil lawsuit against her in New York. Cho was sentenced to a year in jail for violating aviation law after a December 2014 incident at New York's John F Kennedy airport. The flight attendant's lawyers claim Cho was unfairly treated and seek damages for the incident.

site_title: Seattle's tallest tower set to go on sale
summary: Seattle's Columbia Center, the city's tallest building, is set to go on sale as its owners, Beacon Capital Partners, seek to capitalize on robust demand for US real estate. The 76-storey tower, completed in 1985, was renovated after Amazon's departure in 2010 and now has new tenants. The building's value has increased since its last sale in 2012, with comparable properties selling for over $499 per square foot. The sale is expected to follow a preliminary agreement for Blackstone Group to buy Willis Tower in Chicago.

site_title: Emerging markets lose their allure for investors
summary: Investors are reassessing their investment rationale for emerging markets due to messy politics and staggering economies. The dollar's upward march and expected Federal Reserve interest rate hikes are exacerbating concerns. Emerging-market currencies, such as the Turkish lira, Brazilian real, and Russian rouble, have touched multi-year lows against the dollar. Analysts point to debt vulnerabilities, corruption scandals, and economic instability as major issues. Despite some countries' efforts to reassure investors, turmoil and scandal persist, raising concerns about the long-term outlook for emerging markets.

site_title: Govt urged to cool Norway's property market
summary: Norway's Labor Party urges the government to intervene in the rapidly rising housing market, warning of a potential bubble. House prices jumped 9% in February, with households owing twice as much as their disposable incomes. The Finance Ministry has asked the Financial Supervisory Authority to consider policy measures, including limiting interest-only loans and forcing faster mortgage payoffs. The Labor Party proposes legislation to address the issue, citing concerns over the country's high leverage and record-high house prices.

site_title: Ericsson to cut as many as 2,200 jobs in Sweden
summary: Ericsson plans to cut up to 2,200 jobs in Sweden as part of a cost-reduction plan to improve profitability amid slowing sales. The measures, affecting about 2% of the workforce, will mainly target research and development and supply functions. This move aims to improve Ericsson's profitability and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Apps to help navigate cruise lines
summary: Several cruise line apps are available to help travelers navigate their trips, including Planning Cruise Ship Mate, Cruise Finder, Cruise.com, On Board Fishes, and Star Walk. These apps offer features such as ship location tracking, excursion planning, budgeting, and learning about marine life and constellations. Some apps, like On Board Fishes and Star Walk, do not require internet access and are free to download. These digital tools can enhance the cruise experience and provide valuable information for both novice and experienced travelers.

site_title: Singapore to form research council in bid to boost social sciences
summary: Singapore plans to establish a new Social Science Research Council by mid-2015 to promote and strengthen the field, driven by growing importance of social sciences in public policy and economic development. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for fresh perspectives and approaches in public policy, citing challenges such as aging and social mobility. The council will comprise prominent local and international academics, focusing on research areas like population aging and social diversity, and will be supported by increased government funding and data release.

site_title: Physical store and personal touch in retail won't go away any time soon
summary: A CBRE survey in Singapore found that 85% of respondents visit a physical store at least once a month, with 56% using in-store purchases for non-food items. Despite online shopping being popular, two-thirds of respondents expected no change in their preference for in-store shopping over the next two years. Retailers are advised to offer a multi-channel platform, combining online and offline shopping, to provide a seamless experience for consumers. Convenience, variety, and human interaction are key reasons for shopping online, and some industries may still require physical stores for a holistic shopping experience.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE retailers should not discount the importance of the physical store, says a CBRE report, even as close to half of the respondents in a poll conducted here say they shop online at least once a month.

site_title: Q2 tender for second public bus package
summary: The Land Transport Authority of Singapore will put out a tender for the second public bus package in Q2 2015. The package will operate 400 buses from the new Loyang bus depot, serving Punggol and Pasir Ris areas. The package will consist of 25 bus services, with 22 existing services and three new ones. The new Loyang depot, set to be completed by June, will accommodate 500 buses. Woodlands Transport may bid for the contract, but will need to review the terms and conditions before making a decision.

site_title: Data confirms China economy still losing steam
summary: China's economy is losing steam, with January and February investment, retail sales, and factory output missing forecasts and falling to multi-year lows. Industrial output grew 6.8% in the first two months of the year, the weakest expansion since the 2008 global financial crisis. Retail sales rose 10.7%, the lowest pace in a decade, and fixed-asset investment rose 13.9%, the weakest expansion since 2001. Economists expect China's GDP growth to slow to a quarter-century low of around 7% this year, with policymakers likely to implement further support measures to avert a sharper slowdown.

images.alt_text: Iron ore being transported in Rizhao, Shandong province. Industrial output grew 6.8 per cent in the first two months of the year, the weakest expansion since the global financial crisis in late 2008.

site_title: Don't blame ABSD for overseas property buys
summary: A Singaporean MP, Lee Bee Wah, argues that the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) is discouraging cash-rich citizens from buying local properties, leading them to invest in riskier foreign properties. However, experts counter that the ABSD discourages speculators, not responsible investors, and that foreign properties can be less risky if evaluated carefully. The MP suggests educating cash-rich Singaporeans on various investment options, including traditional assets like stocks and bonds, to encourage a balanced portfolio.

site_title: Vibrant Gujarat shows the way for India
summary: The Vibrant Gujarat summit, held in January, marked a significant shift from a state-focused event to a national and international one, attracting 25,000 participants and 21,304 memorandums of understanding (MOUs valued at 25 trillion rupees). The event, conceived by former Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi, showcased India's business-friendly environment and attracted top leaders from India, Bhutan, and international organizations. The summit's success was attributed to Modi's leadership and the state's stellar economic performance, with Gujarat now accounting for 7.6% of India's GDP and 10% of national employment.

site_title: Smart bags for the connected traveller
summary: Smart luggage is gaining popularity, with several companies developing connected bags featuring Bluetooth-enabled locks, GPS tracking, and USB ports. Bluesmart, which raised over $2 million on Indiegogo, is set to deliver its first bags in October. Other companies, such as Samsonite, Andiamo, and Delsey, are also introducing smart suitcases with features like cellular-enabled tracking, Wi-Fi hotspots, and built-in scales. The connected luggage industry is expected to continue growing, with experts predicting it will become the new normal in the market, similar to lightweight bags and four-wheeled luggage.

images.alt_text: Luggage being organised in the Hontus booth before the start of the International Travel Goods Show in Las Vegas on Sunday.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers recommend investing in airlines during times of crisis, citing examples of Singapore Airlines and Thai Airlines' successful recoveries after facing bankruptcy. Tiger Airways is a buy with a target price of S$0.39 due to rising yields and lower fuel costs. Raffles Medical Group is held due to limited near-term catalysts, but a hospital extension in Q1 2017 could drive recovery. The market is expected to rally ahead of GDP data, with Singapore stocks rising for a 5-day streak.

site_title: Rebuilding construction
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. The country is also exploring opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Additionally, the government is providing support for businesses affected by tariffs, offering a grant of up to S$100,000. The government is also encouraging workers to future-proof their careers, citing better employment rates for graduates.

site_title: Boost trade finance for Asia's poorer countries and smaller companies
summary: Asia's poorer countries and smaller companies struggle to obtain trade finance from commercial banks due to the global financial crisis. The Asian Development Bank estimates a US$425 billion shortfall in trade finance. Trade finance is considered a low-risk investment, with average default rates of 0.02% and zero defaults in a recent ADB evaluation. Expanding access to trade finance and making it more inclusive is a business proposition, with the potential to support Asia's growing exports and imports. A well-standardized framework for trade finance is needed to recognize its safety.

site_title: More funding to enhance aviation and maritime sectors
summary: Singapore has announced two funds to enhance its aviation and maritime sectors, focusing on talent development. The Aviation Development Fund (ADF) will receive S$160 million over five years, up from its initial S$100 million. The Maritime Development Fund will also receive financial injections. These funds aim to strengthen Singapore's aviation and maritime industries, which will benefit from areas such as talent development.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US Treasury urged to scrutinise foreign real estate buyers
summary: US Treasury urged to scrutinize foreign real estate buyers for potential money-laundering risk. 17 non-profit groups requested the repeal of a 2002 exemption from the Patriot Act provisions, which exempted the real estate industry from verifying buyer identities. They asked the Treasury Department to require the industry to verify buyer identities and screen them for money-laundering risk.

site_title: Car hub project to spur Philippine manufacturing
summary: The Philippines aims to become a regional car manufacturing hub, with President Benigno Aquino set to issue an order implementing the Comprehensive Automotive Resurgence Strategy (CARS) programme. The country will offer tax breaks to up to three carmakers, including Volkswagen, to encourage investment and production. The government hopes to replicate Thailand's success and save $17 billion in import costs by 2022. With a young workforce and growing economy, the Philippines seeks to become a mass producer of cars and other automotive products, despite being outcompeted by Thailand in the past.

site_title: Arsenal, Everton and Stoke coming to Singapore in July
summary: Arsenal, Everton, and Stoke City will participate in the Barclays Asia Trophy in Singapore in July. The English Premier League teams will compete against a Singapore Select XI side for the tournament prize. This event marks the first time these teams will be in Singapore, following Arsenal's recent FA Cup victory over Manchester United. The tournament's date has not been officially confirmed, but it is expected to take place in July.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Shanghai Airport posts slower profit growth in 2014
summary: Shanghai International Airport Co Ltd reported a 12% increase in net profit to 2.1 billion yuan (S$466 million) in 2014, slower than the 18.5% rise in 2013.
