The airport cited global economic uncertainty, increasing passenger volumes, and challenging airfield operations as major challenges in 2015. Passenger throughput exceeded 50 million for the first time since Shanghai Pudong Airport started operations 15 years ago.

site_title: Net neutrality may do the opposite
summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has adopted a proposal to ensure "net neutrality" by regulating internet service providers (ISPs) to prevent them from blocking or slowing down certain websites and services. However, critics argue that this regulation could have unintended consequences, such as increasing costs and reducing investment in the internet. The FCC's plan to require ISPs to accept all comers and pay for interconnection payments may lead to cross-subsidization, where costs are shifted to households. This could ultimately harm the internet's vitality and stifle innovation, echoing the failures of deregulation in the railroad industry in the late 19th century.

site_title: Thailand resorts to rate cut on weaker growth prospects
summary: Thailand's central bank unexpectedly cut its key interest rate to 1.75% for the first time in a year, citing weaker growth prospects and risks from China's slowdown. This move joins a wave of global monetary easing as inflation fades on lower oil prices. The decision aims to stimulate growth and compensate for the lack of other drivers, with stocks rising and the baht declining.

site_title: Big US banks' buybacks and dividends may not reflect financial health
summary: US banks, including JPMorgan Chase & Co and Citigroup Inc, are set to receive Federal Reserve backing to buy back shares and increase dividends. However, the approvals may be more about financial engineering than reflecting improved financial health. Much of the funding comes from selling preferred shares, which pay high dividends and serve as a cushion against losses, never needing to be repaid. This practice has raised concerns about the true financial health of the banks.

site_title: Tharman: S'pore will continue to invest in biomedical sector
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced that Singapore will continue to invest in the biomedical sector, despite its output reaching $21.5 billion and employing 16,800 people last year. GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) is setting up a new global headquarters for Asia in Singapore, which will be one of three "control towers" alongside the UK and US. The new headquarters will be built in the "one-north" development and will have a capacity for up to 1,000 employees.

site_title: Acquisition-related expenses dampen Del Monte Pacific Q3 bottom line
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a US$2.2 million net loss for its fiscal third quarter ended Jan 31, 2015, due to acquisition-related expenses from the US-based Del Monte Foods Inc. Despite higher sales of US$637.6 million, the group's bottom line was hurt by expenses related to the acquisition. Sales from DMFI increased 21% and group sales rose 18% and 8% in the Philippines and Asia Pacific, respectively. The group expects to generate sustained recurring earnings in FY15, excluding acquisition-related expenses.

site_title: Influential German architect Frei Otto dies at 89
summary: German architect Frei Otto, known for his innovative tensile structures, died at 89 on March 10, 2015, weeks before being named the recipient of the Pritzker Prize. Otto's work, inspired by the soap bubble, led to designs such as the West German Pavilion at the World Expo in Montreal and the stadium covering at the 1972 Munich Olympics. His work influenced generations of architects and was characterized by its use of lightweight materials and natural principles.

images.alt_text: Mr Otto (above) was known for creating dazzling tensile structures that inspired generations of architects to dangle roofs from poles and cables; the Munich Olympic stadium that he designed in collaboration with Behnisch & Partner features acrylic roofs draped from steel cables.

Mr Otto was known for creating dazzling tensile structures that inspired generations of architects to dangle roofs from poles and cables; the Munich Olympic stadium (above) that he designed in collaboration with Behnisch & Partner features acrylic roofs draped from steel cables.

site_title: Qatar Air buys Sheraton hotel at Heathrow
summary: Qatar Airways has acquired the Sheraton Skyline Hotel at London Heathrow's airport, marking the carrier's first foray into lodging outside the Gulf. The four-star hotel will continue to operate under the Sheraton brand, managed by Starwood. This deal advances Qatar Airways' expansion plans into the UK and North America, complementing its existing investments in the UK, including a stake in Heathrow and IAG SA, owner of British Airways.

site_title: Yoma gets Landmark lease extension from Myanmar authority
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings has received a lease extension from the Myanmar Investment Commission for the redevelopment of the former Burma Railways Company headquarters into a five-star hotel. The site, comprising the Grand Meeyahta Hotel and the heritage site, will be developed into a mixed-use development. The company will begin necessary steps with the Ministry of Rail Transportation to finalize the lease extension. Yoma had been negotiating with authorities for a protracted period to secure the extension.

site_title: Apple Watch will threaten Swiss watch industry: Swatch co-inventor
summary: Apple Watch sales are predicted to reach 20-30 million units annually, threatening Switzerland's 4-century-old watch industry. Co-inventor of Swatch, Elmar Mock, warns that the Apple Watch will put pressure on traditional watch industry jobs and revenue, particularly in the lower- and mid-range market. Swiss brands like Tissot and TAG Heuer are already dipping into the smartwatch market, but the industry as a whole has underestimated the threat, with Mock predicting an "Ice Age" for watches priced between 500-1000 francs.

site_title: Greece gets 555m euro lifeline as reform talks begin in Brussels
summary: Greece has received a 555 million euro lifeline from the European Stability Mechanism, providing a brief respite for its radical new government. The aid comes after a week of intense pressure from creditors, and will help Greece's cash-strapped government avoid immediate financial crisis. The move is seen as a positive development for Greek leaders, offering a temporary reprieve from the economic pressures they face.

site_title: Learn how to make the most of this year's Budget at a seminar next week
summary: A seminar next week will provide insights on how to make the most of Budget 2015 for businesses and entrepreneurs in Singapore. Experts, including the Singapore Business Federation, Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, and Nanyang Technological University, will discuss the implications and possibilities of the Budget. Topics will include entrepreneurship, productivity, quality, and internationalization, as well as strategies for SMEs to optimize business landscapes and opportunities.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Spending cycles favour Exxon, Shell amid oil slump
summary: The oil price slump has sent most major oil companies into negative cash flow, with some, like Exxon and Shell, better positioned due to their lower spending cycles. Exxon and Shell can withstand lower oil prices due to their stronger balance sheets, allowing them to cover project spending, operating costs, and dividend payments. Chevron and Total, however, will have to borrow more to stay afloat, while BP faces significant outgoings related to its oil spill fine and Rosneft stake. Analysts expect Exxon and Shell to outperform their peers in the long term, while Total and Chevron may offer higher returns in the future.

site_title: UK-Asean cooperation in IP can have big payoffs
summary: The UK and Singapore have a strong economic and trade relationship, with the UK's total exports to Singapore rising by 10% to £6.5 billion in 2013. The UK and Singapore also have a close bilateral relationship, with the UK being Singapore's largest market in Asean. The UK enjoys a trade surplus of £2.4 billion with Singapore, and is home to three-quarters of Singapore's investment in Europe. The UK-Asean cooperation in intellectual property (IP) is seen as a potential area for growth, with the UK's innovative companies and creative industries being showcased during the GREAT British Week in Singapore.

site_title: India allows 7 state-run banks to raise capital from market
summary: India has allowed seven state-run banks to raise capital from the market as part of efforts to comply with global Basel III banking rules. The government allocated 79.4 billion rupees for capital infusion, lower than expected. Top lender State Bank of India and Punjab National Bank plan to raise funds through share sales. The move aims to help state-run banks meet global banking standards.

site_title: Singdollar bond market surges, S$1.1b raised in March so far
summary: The Singapore dollar bond market has seen a significant surge in funds raised in March, with over S$1.1 billion raised so far, triple the amount in the same period last year. This follows a year-to-date total of S$2.83 billion, which is 63% of the S$4.49 billion raised in the same period last year. The surge is attributed to higher yields and expectations of interest rate hikes, with investors seeking stable income streams. The equity market, however, remains quiet, with zero initial public offerings in Singapore up to March 9.

site_title: In a world awash with liquidity, a cooling property market isn't bad
summary: In a post-quantitative easing world, a cooling property market in Singapore is seen as a positive development, as it mitigates systemic risk posed by a heated market. Despite luxury home prices dropping 20% and overall private home prices decreasing 5% from their 2013 peak, the government's focus on public housing remains unchanged. Resale flat prices have dropped 8% from their 2013 peak, while household income grew 72% from 2005-2014. The government may consider further cooling measures, but private developers cannot expect the government to prioritize their interests.

site_title: euNetworks Group's last trading day to be March 13
summary: euNetworks Group's last trading day will be March 13, and trading will be suspended from March 16. The company has agreed to a voluntary delisting and a mandatory cash offer by JP Morgan (SEA) at S$1.16 per share. The offer will close on March 13 at 5:30pm, with no extension planned.

site_title: Singapore Budget Debate: COEs, rail disruptions and cleaner vehicles
summary: Singapore's COE supply remains unchanged, with no plans to hold back COEs to smooth out future supply. The government cited the risk of introducing more volatility into premiums. Rail disruptions continued to plague public transport, despite efforts to improve services. The Early Turnover Scheme, encouraging cleaner vehicle replacements, will be expanded to include more diesel vehicles. The scheme will run from August 2015 to July 2017.

site_title: Indonesian rupiah heading to 'new normal', no need to panic: central bank
summary: Indonesia's rupiah reached a 17-year low, prompting concerns, but Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo said the currency is heading to a "new normal" and there's no need to panic. The central bank will ensure dollar availability in the forex market to mitigate the impact. President Joko Widodo held talks with senior officials to address the issue, which is seen as a step towards a more stable currency.

site_title: LNG market heading for volatile times: BG Group
summary: The liquefied natural gas (LNG) market is expected to experience volatility in the coming years due to "lumpy" additions to supply and demand. Seven projects in Australia are expected to add 58 million tonnes per annum of LNG capacity by 2019, while the US Gulf of Mexico is set to start exporting its first cargo around year-end. This new supply will be absorbed by growing Asian demand, with the creation of up to six new markets. BG Group expects 122 million tonnes of new supply capacity by 2020, with LNG trade worldwide projected to exceed 400 million tonnes per year by 2025.

site_title: Singapore to establish Social Science Research Council by mid-2015
summary: Singapore plans to establish a Social Science Research Council by mid-2015 to promote social science research in the country. The council, comprising local and international academics, will provide direction and support for research areas that meet Singapore's future needs and those of other Asian societies. The move aims to foster a portfolio of social science research and enhance Singapore's global reputation in this field.

site_title: US crude stockpiles rise in line with expectations: EIA
summary: US crude oil stockpiles rose by 4.5 million barrels last week, meeting analyst expectations, according to the Energy Information Administration. Gasoline stocks fell by 187,000 barrels, while distillate inventories rose by 2.5 million barrels. Refinery crude runs increased by 187,000 barrels per day and utilization rates rose by 1.2 percentage points. US crude imports declined by 575,000 barrels per day.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher as dollar stays strong
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.15% to 17,690.23, following a decline in the prior session due to concerns over a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The euro hovered near a 12-year low against the dollar, with European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stating that the bank's stimulus program would boost growth and inflation. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also edged up, with the Nasdaq reaching a fresh record.

site_title: India's economy recovering, reforms vital: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reported that India's economy is recovering, with growth forecast to reach 7.5% in the 2015/16 fiscal year. This is lower than the government's target of 8.5% growth. The IMF attributes India's recovery to positive policy actions and lower global oil prices. However, the report emphasizes the need for India to revitalize the investment cycle and accelerate structural reforms to sustain growth.

site_title: South Korea, China, Japan seek to ease tensions, set up FM meet
summary: South Korean Deputy Foreign Minister Lee Kyung-Soo met with Chinese and Japanese counterparts to address mutual tensions and pave the way for the first meeting of foreign ministers in three years. Relations between China and South Korea are strong, but both countries have issues with Japan due to historical and territorial disputes. The meeting aimed to discuss trilateral cooperation and potentially lead to a three-way leadership summit later this year. Japan and China have been at odds over the sovereignty of East China Sea islands, while Seoul-Tokyo ties remain problematic due to Japan's colonial rule over the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Wall St's selloff brings out sellers here
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 19.67 points to 3,378.59, its third consecutive decline this week, due to Wall Street's 1.9% drop and a sudden upward surge in the US dollar. Banks, Jardine stocks, and Singtel contributed to the fall. A rebound in the late afternoon raised hopes for a recovery on Wednesday. The decline was attributed to concerns over interest rates being raised sooner rather than later.

site_title: Junma Tyre proposes voluntary delisting
summary: Junma Tyre Cord Company, a Catalist-listed firm, proposes a voluntary delisting with Ultimative making an exit offer price of 20 Singapore cents for 15,875,600 shares. The offer is made by Yang Cong's special purpose vehicle, Ultimative, which holds 78.37% of Junma Tyre's shares.

site_title: Oil market rises before US inventories data
summary: World oil prices rose on Wednesday as traders awaited the weekly US inventories data, with European benchmark Brent North Sea crude gaining 20 cents to $56.59 a barrel. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate added 18 cents to US$48.47 a barrel. However, gains were limited by the strong dollar and concerns about a global supply glut. Analysts expect the US inventories report to show a rise in oil reserves, which could further boost prices, but volatility is likely to continue due to ongoing supply and demand imbalances.

site_title: Singapore-listed Noble chairman boosts stake as stock falls
summary: Singapore-listed Noble Group chairman Richard Elman has increased his stake in the company to 20.956% after shares dropped to a one-year low. The shares fell 5.3% and 1.6% lower on Wednesday, amid concerns raised by Iceberg Research about Noble's accounting practices. This is the first significant stake boost by Elman since Noble's shares began to decline in mid-February.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's notable stories include Malaysia's plan to seize approximately RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin remains optimistic about his daughter's suspension in an ethics case. The Asean region agrees that Myanmar's election is not a priority, and the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row. Additionally, South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks, while Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May.

site_title: Google offers low-cost cloud service to chase Amazon on storage
summary: Google is launching a low-cost cloud storage feature called Nearline, offering 1-cent per gigabyte pricing and fast response times of 3 seconds, to compete with Amazon's "Glacier" storage product. The new service aims to attract customers and help Google catch up with market leader Amazon, which dominates the industry with around 30% market share. This move is part of Google's efforts to expand its cloud services and offer more competitive pricing to lure customers.

site_title: Google in talks to buy Indian startup InMobi: source
summary: Google is in talks to buy Indian mobile advertising startup InMobi, a deal that could be the US company's first in India's start-up space. InMobi has over 1 billion users across 200 countries and counts investors such as SoftBank and Sherpalo. Talks are at an early stage, with Google's terms and conditions yet to be detailed.

site_title: Swiss makers quietly gear up with smartwatches of their own
summary: Luxury Swiss watchmakers Richemont, LVMH, Swatch Group, and Guess Inc are secretly developing their own smartwatches, despite Apple's entry into the market. The Swiss industry views the Apple Watch as an opportunity to attract younger consumers, rather than a threat. Companies like Swatch, Montblanc, and Guess are incorporating smart features into their traditional timepieces, aiming to preserve their prestige appeal. Analysts predict that the Apple Watch may boost sales of luxury timepieces among tech-savvy consumers, potentially benefiting the Swiss industry.

site_title: German economy gaining steam in early 2015: ministry
summary: The German economy is gaining momentum at the start of 2015, with the government expecting a 1.5% expansion this year, following a 1.6% growth last year. Despite relatively weak industrial production in January, the economy narrowly avoided recession in mid-2014. The ministry notes that the global economy is not proving dynamic, cautioning against overly optimistic expectations.

site_title: Credit Suisse new boss could axe 2,900 investment bank jobs: analyst
summary: Credit Suisse's new CEO, Tidjane Thiam, may cut 2,900 jobs (15% of staff) in its investment bank as part of a shift to private banking in Asia, analysts say. The bank could also cut 150 billion Swiss francs (S$209 billion) from its fixed income business. This move aims to improve leverage and address capital strength concerns. Thiam's plan is expected to benefit private banking in Asia and drive growth. Credit Suisse shares rallied 9% on news of Thiam's appointment.

site_title: Malaysia monetary policy to focus on growth after inflation ebbs
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has announced its monetary policy for 2015 will focus on supporting economic growth as inflation risks decrease with the decline in global crude prices. The ringgit, Asia's worst-performing currency in six months, is significantly undervalued at current levels. The bank left its key interest rate unchanged for a fourth straight meeting, citing a stable inflation outlook and modest demand pressures. Malaysia's GDP is projected to expand 4.5-5.5% this year, driven by domestic demand and resilient exports.

site_title: Greece raises 1.3b euros at higher rate: debt agency
summary: Greece raised 1.3 billion euros in three-month treasury bills at a higher interest rate of 2.7% compared to 2.5% previously. The country needs 6.0 billion euros this month to repay maturing debt. The new government is seeking a new loan deal with creditors, but has received no money from the EU-IMF bailout due to ongoing negotiations. With tax revenue lagging, the government is exploring alternative sources of funding to meet its debt obligations.

site_title: China said to plan overhaul of US$3t industrial machine
summary: China is planning an overhaul of its state-run companies, including consolidating and reducing government ownership, to boost its economy, which is forecast to grow at its slowest pace in over two decades. The plan, potentially released this month, would bundle companies by industry and hand control to state asset-management firms. This move aims to address corruption and inefficiency issues among the country's state companies, estimated to trade at discounts totaling $2 trillion. Thousands of companies, including China National Petroleum Corp and China Mobile Communications Corp, are expected to be affected.

images.alt_text: China is preparing to overhaul its bloated and inefficient state-run companies to bolster an economy forecast to grow at the slowest pace in more than two decades, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: GLP signs new agreements with 4 customers in China
summary: GLOBAL Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed new agreements with four Chinese customers totaling 63,000 sqm, with three being multi-location customers in the e-commerce, packaged foods, and pharmaceutical industries. GLP President Kent Yang stated that the growing demand for modern logistics facilities in China is driving the need for these facilities, and the company looks forward to supporting its customers as they expand in the country.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says to keep tight stance; focus on current account balance
summary: Indonesia's central bank has reaffirmed its tight monetary stance, focusing on improving the current account deficit and controlling inflation. Governor Agus Martowardojo stated that the bank will not ease monetary conditions unless inflation and the current account deficit improve. The rupiah, Indonesia's currency, hit its lowest level since 1998 amid economic concerns. President Joko Widodo held talks with senior economic officials to address these issues. The bank's decision aims to stabilize the economy and prevent a further decline in the currency.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 11.57 points to close at 1,778.16. The index saw 2.51 billion lots traded, with 321 gains and 523 losses.

site_title: Apple's iTunes and app stores experience outages worldwide
summary: Apple's iTunes and app stores experienced global outages, preventing users from making purchases or downloading applications. The outages occurred in countries including the US, Switzerland, Spain, and the UK, with users reporting error messages and difficulty accessing accounts. However, Apple's support website stated that all services, including iCloud, were functioning normally as of 7:55 am New York time. The cause of the outage is not specified.

site_title: Singapore's aviation, maritime sectors receive financial boost
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) have announced financial boosts to their respective development funds. CAAS will replenish its Aviation Development Fund with S$160 million over five years, focusing on airport productivity and manpower development, while MPA will inject S$65 million into the Maritime Cluster Fund for manpower development. These initiatives aim to boost the local aviation and maritime industries, particularly in a tight labor market, and prepare for anticipated growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Draghi says ECB action can and will return inflation to goal
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi said the bank's expanded asset purchases will push inflation in the euro area back toward its goal of 2%. Draghi stated that the monetary policy is supporting the recovery and that the yield on government debt and the euro are falling, indicating the program's effectiveness. The ECB will continue its bond-buying program until September 2016 or until inflation stabilizes.

site_title: A-Sonic Aerospace to consolidate shares
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace plans to consolidate every four shares into one share, subject to shareholder approval, at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting. The move has been granted in-principle approval by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Twitter opens new office in Hong Kong
summary: Twitter has launched an office in Hong Kong, its first market outside of China, to help Chinese businesses reach international markets through advertising sales. The office, led by Director of emerging markets for Russia and China, Peter Greenberger, aims to tap into the growing market in Greater China. With 288 million active monthly users, mostly outside the US, Twitter's growth has slowed but its fourth-quarter revenue reached $479 million, up 97% year-on-year. The move follows US internet titans Google and Facebook, which also have offices in Hong Kong.

site_title: US banks seen boosting shareholder payouts 53% after Fed tests
summary: US banks are expected to boost shareholder payouts by an average of 53% after passing the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests. The largest payouts are projected for Citigroup, Wells Fargo, and JPMorgan Chase, with Citigroup's payouts expected to surge 60-fold. The Fed's stress tests assess banks' ability to withstand economic downturns, and passing results allow banks to increase dividends and buy back shares. The median payout ratio is expected to rise to 79%, matching pre-crisis levels, as banks return more capital to shareholders.

site_title: Greece bashes Germany again as loan talks begin
summary: Greece has renewed its criticism of Germany, threatening asset seizures over war reparations claimed by Athens. Greece's justice minister, Nikos Paraskevopoulos, has vowed to approve a 2000 Supreme Court ruling ordering Germany to pay €28 million in compensation for civilians killed by Nazi forces. The move comes as technical experts in Brussels begin talks on extending Greece's bailout, with Athens demanding relaxation of the austerity program. The Greek government is seeking €6 billion to meet its debts, and has tapped into its pension and agricultural assistance funds for emergency cash.

images.alt_text: Greece on Wednesday renewed attacks on its top paymaster Germany as technical experts began talks on the crisis-hit country's new reform proposals.

site_title: Greece gets half-billion-euro lifeline
summary: The European Stability Mechanism (ESM) has provided Greece with a half-billion-euro lifeline, giving its radical new government a brief respite from creditors. The 555 million euros will help Greece meet its debts, with the country facing an 8 billion-euro debt repayment deadline in March. Greece claims unpaid reparations from Germany for World War II, totaling 162 billion euros, while Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras pressed for negotiations with Berlin. The lifeline comes after the ESM initially hesitated to provide the funds, but ultimately agreed to release the money.

site_title: US mortgage applications fall in latest week: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications decreased 1.3% in the week ended March 6, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Refinancing applications fell 2.9% to the lowest level since January, while home purchase demand rose 1.9%. Fixed 30-year mortgage rates averaged 4.01%, the highest level since January 2. The refinance share of total mortgage activity dropped to 60% from 62% the previous week.

site_title: Alibaba in funding talks with India's Snapdeal: source
summary: Alibaba is in talks with Indian online marketplace Snapdeal over a potential cash investment, its first direct investment in India. Snapdeal, competing with Flipkart and Amazon, is seeking $1 billion in funding. Alibaba has been eyeing India for months, but this would be its first direct investment in the e-commerce space. Ant Financial, an affiliate of Alibaba, bought a 25% stake in an Indian payment services provider last month. Negotiations are ongoing, but no deal has been reached yet.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded slightly on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.32% and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.38%. This follows a 2.52% decline on Tuesday due to concerns over US interest rate hikes and weak Chinese economic data. Despite this, mining and healthcare shares supported gains.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets rebounded slightly at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index of top companies up 0.32 per cent at 6,724.35 points.

site_title: China's Jan-Feb crude oil runs up 3.5% on year
summary: China's January-February crude oil throughput increased 3.5% year-over-year to 82.64 million tonnes, or 10.22 million barrels per day. This marks a decrease from record refinery runs in December. The daily crude throughput rate for the first two months of the year was lower.

site_title: Room for improved rail reliability: Transport Minister
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew stated that despite recent rail disruptions, there is room for improvement in train reliability. A survey conducted last year showed that 91.3% of commuters are satisfied with public transport, with satisfaction levels for rail improving by 4 percentage points from 2013. The minister expressed frustration over the recent disruptions, citing their impact on commuters' routines and confidence in the transport network.

images.alt_text: A survey conducted in Singapore last year indicated that more commuters are satisfied with public transport but as the recent rail disruptions show, there is room for improvement in train reliability.

site_title: China state-owned company share gains highlight market risks
summary: Chinese state-owned companies' shares surged ahead of major announcements, sparking concerns over Beijing's restructuring plans being leaked to investors. Five state-owned firms, including trainmakers CNR Corp and CSR Corp, rose by their daily limits before filing news, raising questions about the effectiveness of China's regulatory system. Regulators have vowed to investigate potential insider trading, while analysts suggest that asymmetric information may exist, with insiders potentially trading shares before public announcements.

site_title: Singapore: Wall St's Tues blowout weighs on local stocks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 19.67 points to 3,378.59, its third consecutive drop, after the US market closed weaker on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 1.9% and the S&P 500 1.7%. A sudden surge in the US dollar and concerns over interest rate hikes contributed to the market's decline.

site_title: China's hottest phone? Here's the upstart chasing Xiaomi
summary: OnePlus, a Chinese smartphone manufacturer, is gaining traction in the global market by selling high-end devices at affordable prices. The company's debut device, the One, sold over a million units last year, mostly in overseas markets like the US, UK, and India. OnePlus expects to triple sales this year, reaching over three million units, and is focusing on word-of-mouth marketing. The company's strategy mirrors that of Xiaomi, another Chinese smartphone maker, and has gained attention from analysts, who see OnePlus as a potential challenger to the market.

site_title: Thai central bank surprisingly cuts rates in bid to lift growth
summary: Thailand's central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 1.75% in a bid to boost the sluggish economy. The move was a surprise to analysts, with only five predicting a rate cut in a Reuters poll. The cut is part of a trend in Asia, with other countries such as India and China easing policy this year. Thailand's military-led government had expressed concerns about cutting rates too early, but the central bank aims to support economic growth, which is forecast to be below 4% this year.

site_title: No plans to hold back COEs: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's government has no plans to hold back Certificate of Entitlement (COE) supply to smoothen out future COE supply, citing concerns of introducing more volatility into premiums. Senior Minister of State Josephine Teo stated that reserving too few COEs would have no impact, while reserving too many could lead to a shortage. The government prefers to promote green private transport through the Carbon Emission-based Vehicle Scheme (CEVS) instead of categorizing COEs by carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: There have been calls to smoothen out future Certificate of Entitlement (COE) supply by holding back COEs but this is not a straightforward exercise and the government has no immediate plans to implement it.

site_title: Made in China: Beijing plans new wave of state firm consolidation
summary: China is set to embark on a new wave of industrial consolidation under the "Made in China 2025" plan, aiming to reinvigorate state-owned enterprises and boost global competitiveness. The plan, led by Premier Li Keqiang, will focus on key sectors like railways, nuclear power, and high-end equipment. The government aims to strengthen control of lifeline industries while relaxing grip on non-essential sectors through stake sales and stock market listings. Experts expect mergers and acquisitions to create national champions and boost exports, but some are skeptical about the effectiveness of state-dictated mergers.

site_title: Indonesia attracts US$1.4b in investment for 11 nickel smelters
summary: Indonesia has attracted $1.4 billion in investment for 11 new nickel smelters, a significant increase from initial resistance from the industry. The smelters, set to be built over the next two years, will have a combined capacity to produce 22,000 tonnes of refined nickel annually. The investment is a result of Jakarta's export restrictions, which aim to force mining firms to develop smelting and processing facilities to refine all of Indonesia's raw ores and concentrates. This marks a shift towards domestic processing, as required by the Indonesian government.

site_title: Temasek, Carmignac said to be in talks for ICICI insurance stake
summary: ICICI Bank Ltd is in talks to sell approximately 5% of its stake in ICICI Prudential Life Insurance Co to Temasek Holdings Pte and Carmignac Gestion for about $300 million. The sale, planned to be completed by the end of March, follows Prime Minister Narendra Modi's relaxation of foreign investment rules in the insurance industry. This move aims to attract more investors to the venture ahead of planned initial public offerings, similar to Housing Development Finance Corp.

images.alt_text: ICICI Bank Ltd, India's largest private-sector lender, is in talks to sell part of its stake in an insurance unit to Temasek Holdings Pte and Carmignac Gestion for about US$300 million, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: UK industrial output unexpectedly falls in January, hit by tumble in IT work
summary: British industrial output unexpectedly fell in January, with a 0.1% decline, contrary to economists' forecasts of a 0.2% increase. The decline was attributed to a reduction in IT work and a 0.5% drop in manufacturing output from December. This marks the second consecutive month of a decline in the UK economy, posing a fresh challenge to Prime Minister Rishi Starmer's government.

site_title: Seoul: Won erases some losses after touching 20-mth low; stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.4% to 1,126.5 per dollar, its lowest since July 10, 2013, as it erased most of its intraday losses. Local shares, however, recovered and finished nearly flat, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) edging down 0.2% to 1,980.83 points. The gains were largely attributed to firm performances in heavyweights Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and Hyundai Motor Co.

site_title: Euro sinks to lowest since April 2003 as low yields hurt
summary: The euro has fallen to its lowest value since April 2003, plummeting 0.5% against the dollar to US$1.0643. This decline is attributed to the significant gap between eurozone and US government bond yields. The euro has lost 12% of its value this year and 35% since May 2024. It also dropped 0.3% against the yen, reaching its lowest since the middle of 2013.

site_title: Tender for second bus-service package in Q2
summary: The Singapore government will tender for the second bus-service package in the second quarter of 2015, serving the Punggol and Pasir Ris areas. The package includes 25 bus services, 22 of which are existing SBS Transit services and three new ones, to be implemented in the second half of 2016. The bus services will be operated from the new Loyang bus depot and deployed from various terminals.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares hit by China data, US rate talk
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.75% on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 179.01 points to 23,717.97, amid concerns of a US interest rate hike in summer. Poor Chinese economic data added to investor worries, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.15%. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Ericsson cuts 2,200 Swedish staff as part of savings program
summary: Swedish telecom equipment maker Ericsson announced it will cut 2,200 positions in Sweden, mainly within R&D and Supply, as part of its cost-cutting program aimed at reducing annual costs by 9 billion Swedish crowns. The restructuring will entail charges of around 3-4 billion crowns from 2015-2017. This move is part of Ericsson's efforts to achieve its target of reducing costs, with full effect expected in 2017. The firm employs around 115,000 people, with 17,000 in Sweden.

site_title: Noble falls to lowest in 17 months as post-Iceberg rally erased
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 5.4% to a 17-month low of S$0.925, wiping out a recent 8.2% gain, after a trading house rebutted criticism of its accounting practices. The stock has tumbled 22% since a report from Iceberg Research claimed US$3.8 billion of fair-value gains were overstated. Despite efforts to increase transparency, investors remain uneasy, with directors buying shares to stem the decline.

site_title: House for sale in Indonesia - with free wife
summary: A house in Sleman, Indonesia, is being sold with a unique offer: the owner, 40-year-old widow Wina Lia, is willing to marry the buyer for free. The house, valued at 999 million rupiah (S$104,000), has two bedrooms and a fish pond, and Lia had listed it as a "rare offer" to serious buyers. The offer has sparked interest online, but Lia said she was shocked by the reaction and had not intended for the ad to go viral.

site_title: EU court rules there is duty to publicise insider information
summary: The European Union's top court ruled that holders of privileged information have a duty to make it public to prevent insider dealing, even if the impact on prices is unclear. The judgment came in a case brought by Jean-Bernard Lafonta, former chairman of Wendel, who challenged fines imposed by the French market regulator AFM. The court's decision aims to strengthen regulations and prevent insider trading, but its implications for enforcement and penalties are yet to be determined.

site_title: Local bond market going strong; over S$1b raised from 8 deals in March
summary: The Singapore bond market is experiencing a resurgence, with eight deals worth over S$1 billion raised in March alone, more than three times the activity seen in the same period last year. Year-to-date, SGD bonds have raised S$2.83 billion, 63% of the S$4.49 billion raised in the same period last year. Investors are not deterred by rising interest rate expectations due to attractive yields, with some opting for shorter-term bonds and higher-yielding bonds. The SGD market is following the US dollar bond market's recovery, with 62 G3 currency bonds issued worth US$35.8 billion this year.

site_title: China economy remains resilient despite slowdown: stats bureau
summary: China's economy remains resilient despite a slowdown, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. The economy is expected to continue losing steam, prompting policymakers to provide further support measures. Unemployment rates remain relatively steady at 5.1%, while growth in investment, retail sales, and factory output fell to multi-year lows in January and February. This slowdown could force companies to restructure and climb up the value chain, potentially leading to long-term benefits.

site_title: Brent rebounds towards US$57 after US crude stocks fall
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose towards US$57 a barrel after US crude stocks fell for the first time in two months, according to data from the American Petroleum Institute. US crude inventories fell to 439.4 million barrels, while crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub rose by 2.2 million barrels. Analysts attributed the rebound to a knee-jerk reaction, with the sell-off seen as overdone, and a strong US dollar. The price increase is seen as a sign that oil has held its value despite geopolitical risks, including an attack on Libyan oil fields.

images.alt_text: Brent crude rose towards US$57 a barrel on Wednesday, paring some of the previous session's sharp losses, after data showed US crude stocks fell for the first time in two months.

site_title: McDonald's Japan launches complaint app
summary: McDonald's Japan is launching a new smartphone app for customer complaints amid a series of scares, including the discovery of a human tooth in some fries. The move comes as the company faces declining sales and profits in Japan. The app will allow customers to post their feelings and requests, and the company is reviewing its procedures for dealing with suspected product tampering. This comes after a series of incidents, including the discovery of unexpected objects in food, which have damaged the company's reputation in Japan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks erase early losses to end 0.31% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.31% higher on Wednesday, reversing early losses, as a weaker yen overshadowed a sharp fall on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 58.41 points to 18,723.52, while the Topix index was flat. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US. Despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: China to scrutinize NZ milk powder imports after poisoning scare
summary: China will increase scrutiny on milk powder imports from New Zealand due to a poisoning scare, where suspected environmental activists threatened to contaminate infant formula with poisonous pesticide 1080. New Zealand police found no traces of the poison in products, but China's quality watchdog will demand official certificates and test reports to ensure safety. Chinese consumers are advised to be cautious and report any damaged packaging to local regulators. This move follows a 2013 contamination scare and potential impact on New Zealand's dairy exports, which rely heavily on China as its biggest buyer.

site_title: China starts free trade feasibility study with Georgia
summary: China has initiated a feasibility study with Georgia to potentially sign a free trade agreement. The two countries' trade totaled $960 million in 2014, with China being Georgia's third-largest trading partner. This move comes after China has already signed free trade agreements with several countries, including Australia, South Korea, and several countries in Southeast Asia. The joint working group will assess the feasibility of a trade agreement between the two nations.

site_title: Korean Air flight attendant in "nut rage" case sues chairman's daughter
summary: A former Korean Air flight attendant, Heather Cho, has filed a civil lawsuit against the airline and its chairman's daughter, seeking damages for emotional distress. Cho was sentenced to a year in jail for "nut rage" after she became abusive towards a flight attendant, Kim Do Hee, over macadamia nuts. The lawsuit claims Cho screamed obscenities, hit, and shoved the flight attendant. Cho has resigned from her positions at the airline and has appealed her conviction. The lawsuit seeks compensation for Kim's career and emotional well-being.

site_title: China auto sales edge down in February
summary: China's auto sales decreased 0.2% in February to 1.59 million vehicles, affected by the Lunar New Year holiday. However, passenger car sales rose 6.4% year-on-year to 1.40 million units. The first two months of this year saw a 4.3% year-on-year increase in auto sales to 3.91 million units. Established foreign brands like General Motors and Ford continued to perform well in the Chinese market, with sales records set for February. The Chinese auto market remains a key area for foreign companies, but slower economic growth and congestion concerns are impacting sales.

images.alt_text: Sales in the world's largest auto market slipped 0.2 per cent from the same month last year, the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM) said Tuesday.

site_title: China Jan-Feb factory output grows 6.8% y-o-y, misses forecasts
summary: China's factory output grew 6.8% in January and February, missing forecasts and indicating a slowdown in the economy. This follows expectations that China's growth will slow to around 7% this year, despite potential stimulus measures. Fixed-asset investment and retail sales also rose, but at lower-than-expected rates. The data reinforces views that China's economic growth will be its slowest in a quarter of a century this year.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall as risk aversion prevails, dollar soars
summary: Asian stocks fell to a two-month low due to risk aversion and concerns over US interest rate hikes, which boosted the dollar to a 12-year high against the euro. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index declined 0.3%, with Australian, South Korean, and Malaysian shares also losing ground. The dollar's strength weighed on emerging markets, while Japan's Nikkei rose 0.5% due to better-than-expected machinery orders. The euro fell to a 12-year low, and the eurozone faces concerns over Greece's debt talks and deflationary pressures in China.

site_title: Petronas prepares US$7b bond as borrowing costs soar on oil
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil firm, is offering a $7 billion US dollar bond as borrowing costs surge to a one-year high. The five-year portion is priced at 135 basis points above Treasuries, amid a global slump in oil prices and debt concerns. This is the second-largest dollar bond from Asia, issued into the worst dollar-bond market this year, with notes losing 2.3% so far. The move is seen as a response to the high yield on existing dollar-denominated bonds, which reached 2.93% in March.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.38% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares declined 0.38% on Wednesday, following a Wall Street sell-off, amid speculation the Federal Reserve may hike interest rates as early as June. The benchmark Hang Seng Index fell to 23,807.10.

site_title: China's Silicon Valley sparking 49 technology startups a day
summary: China's Zhongguancun district, its answer to Silicon Valley, birthed 49 technology startups daily last year, according to Wan Gang, the nation's minister of science and technology. The district is home to over 1,600 technology incubators and established companies like Lenovo and Baidu, with Xiaomi, the nation's biggest smartphone vendor, reaching a US$45 billion valuation. This surge in innovation marks China's shift away from manufacturing reliance and towards technology development.

site_title: China's Jan-Feb implied oil demand up 4% on year: Reuters calculations
summary: China's implied oil demand rose 4% in January and February to approximately 10.37 million barrels per day, according to Reuters calculations based on preliminary official data. This marks a significant increase from the previous year.

images.alt_text: China's implied oil demand in the first two months of the year grew 4% over a year earlier to about 10.37 million barrels per day (bpd), according to Reuters' calculations based on preliminary official data.

site_title: China Jan-Feb property investment growth eases to 10.4% y-o-y
summary: China's property investment growth eased to 10.4% year-over-year in January-February, down from 10.5% in the full year 2014, amid a housing supply glut. Property sales dropped 15.8% from the year-earlier period, while home prices fell again in February, but at a slower pace. The slowdown poses a risk to the government's 7% economic growth target, and the real estate sector's decline may crimp demand in related industries.

site_title: Interest rate-related volatility may lead to capital flight from S-Reits: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse warns that interest rate-related volatility may lead to capital flight from the Singapore real estate investment trust (S-Reit) sector. S-Reits have underperformed property developers and seen analyst rating downgrades due to expensive valuations and subdued growth expectations. The report suggests that the sector's valuations are "not compelling" at a 5.9% average 2015E yield, and that growth is becoming more constrained due to high asset prices and restricted acquisition options. This volatility may present a buying opportunity for S-Reits.

site_title: Australian miners brace for more pain as China slows
summary: Australian miners are bracing for a tough year as China cuts its growth target to a 15-year low, further depressing commodity prices. The price of iron ore has fallen below US$60, a six-year low, due to China's slowing growth and supply glut. Smaller miners are struggling, slashing costs, and some have stopped production, while larger players like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto are maintaining their share of exports. The situation is similar in the energy sector, where a global supply glut has led to a 50% decline in oil prices, potentially sparking a wave of merger and acquisition activity.

site_title: Sony to launch PlayStation in China after delay
summary: Sony has announced that it will launch the PlayStation in China on March 20, after a two-month delay from its initial January 11 planned launch. The company will sell the PlayStation 4 and PlayStation Vita consoles, as well as software, in the country. The move comes after China authorized the domestic sale of game consoles through its first free-trade zone in Shanghai, ending a 15-year ban. The consoles will be priced at 2,899 yuan and 1,299 yuan, respectively, and will include games such as Dynasty Warriors 8 and Final Fantasy.

site_title: BCA sets aside S$20m to testbed green building technologies
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has set aside S$20 million from a S$52 million innovation scheme to test new green building technologies. The scheme supports technologies that achieve 20-40% improvement in energy efficiency, covering projects such as chilled ceilings and under-floor cooling systems. The goal is to mitigate risks and spur the commercialization of energy-efficient solutions. BCA will also run workshops to identify potential demonstration projects, starting March 13.

site_title: Australia: Shares erase some losses as rate cut hopes ease resources pain
summary: Australian shares closed 0.5% down, erasing some losses, as expectations of a second 2015 rate cut boosted the market. Despite a 1% early fall, the S&P/ASX 200 index recovered to close at 5793.2. Resources stocks trailed key commodity prices, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index fell 0.5%. The index has lost over 3% in the past seven sessions.

site_title: Gold stuck near 3-month low as dollar strength weighs
summary: Gold prices hovered near a 3-month low due to the dollar's strength and expectations of higher US interest rates, which curb appetite for the metal. Spot gold dropped 4% in the last seven sessions, reaching $1,162.85 an ounce. Stronger-than-expected US nonfarm payrolls data renewed expectations of interest rate hikes, boosting the dollar and making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. However, Asian demand, particularly in China, has attracted some bargain hunters, and sustained physical buying could provide a floor for falling gold prices.

site_title: Panasonic comeback seen in biggest sale to Japan's institutional investors since 2011
summary: Panasonic Corp has completed its largest bond sale to Japan's institutional investors since 2011, raising 400 billion yen (S$4.6 billion) with a yield of 0.934%. The company forecasts its best profit in seven years, with predicted net income of 175 billion yen, after posting significant losses in the previous two years. Moody's upgraded Panasonic's credit rating last month, citing its competitive market position and successful restructuring efforts. In contrast, Sharp Corp is considering drastic reform to reduce losses in its television operations, following a week where the fortunes of the two electronics makers have diverged.

site_title: GSK to set up new global HQ for Asia in Singapore
summary: GSK, a British drugmaker, has announced plans to set up a new global headquarters for Asia in Singapore. The new eight-storey building, spanning 15,000 square meters, will be located in the one-north development and will accommodate up to 1,000 employees. The move is expected to be completed by the end of next year and will be the company's first major expansion in the region. The new headquarters aims to increase accountability and autonomy in Asia, with a focus on regional decision-making. The move comes as GSK battles declining sales and rising cost pressures.

site_title: Spotify, a music streaming service going for broke
summary: Spotify, a music streaming service, has faced criticism for its payment to artists, with some claiming it only pays a mere "two billion dollars" despite its self-reported payout of 1.8 billion euros to the music industry over seven years. The company's vice president, Jonathan Forster, defends the model, citing its expansion to 15 million paying users and 45 million free listeners, and plans to reach 20 billion dollars in payouts. However, analysts estimate that only 17% of subscription revenues go to artists, with the rest going to streaming providers and taxes. Despite facing competition from Apple, Spotify remains committed to its goal of creating a more equitable music industry.

site_title: China: Shares higher in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose in morning trading, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.32% to 3,296.46, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 0.11% to 1,693.82. The gains were driven by buying of financial shares as investors awaited domestic economic data.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on Wall Street slides; TSMC inches up
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.4% on Wednesday following Wall Street's decline, with tech heavyweights TSMC and Hon Hai Precision trading mixed. The main TAIEX index dropped to 9,501.69, extending a 0.3% drop in the prior session. Electronics shares slipped 0.2%, while TSMC rose 0.4% and Hon Hai fell 0.1%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Del Monte, WE Holdings, Nam Cheong
summary: Singapore stocks open on Wednesday amidst a choppy Wall Street, which fell due to concerns about interest rate hikes. Del Monte Pacific reported a narrower third-quarter net loss of US$2.2 million, with an operational profit of US$23.4 million. Shares closed at 32 Singapore cents on Tuesday. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, as investors stayed positive.

site_title: Del Monte posts Q3 loss as acquisition expenses reverse operational profit
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a Q3 net loss of $2.2 million, or 0.17 cents per share, due to acquisition-related expenses. This is a narrower loss compared to the year-ago quarter's $6.4 million loss. The company's operational profit was dragged down by expenses, resulting in a net loss of $6.4 million or 0.5 cents per share in the same period last year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.34% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.34% lower on Wednesday, tracking US stock losses amid worries about higher interest rates and the soaring dollar. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 63.77 points to 18,601.34. The strong US jobs report elevated expectations of a faster interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, contributing to the dollar's multi-year highs against the euro and yen.

site_title: India's Modi to visit Sri Lanka's Tamil heartland
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will visit Sri Lanka's war-torn Tamil heartland, becoming the first Indian leader to do so, as part of a tour to strengthen ties with Indian Ocean nations. Modi's visit aims to promote reconciliation, support democracy, and reform in Sri Lanka, where around 100,000 Tamil refugees remain in India. The visit follows Sri Lanka's new president Maithripala Sirisena's vow to reduce Beijing's influence and address Tamil grievances. Modi's focus will be on trade and investments, with an emphasis on rebuilding ties strained under former president Mahinda Rajapakse.

site_title: Google chief financial officer retiring
summary: Google's chief financial officer, Patrick Pichette, is retiring after nearly seven years with the company. Pichette, who joined Google in 2008, will assist in the search for his replacement and ensure a smooth transition. He cited his desire to explore the world with his wife and enjoy a mid-life crisis as the reason for his departure. Pichette expressed gratitude for his time at Google, particularly working with co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page, and chairman Eric Schmidt. His departure is expected to occur within six months.

site_title: Hillary Clinton blasts US Republicans over Iran nuclear letter
summary: Former US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton criticized 47 Republican senators for a letter warning Iran against a nuclear deal with President Barack Obama, calling their actions either helpful or harmful to the US commander-in-chief. Vice President Joe Biden also condemned the letter, saying it was designed to undercut the president during sensitive international negotiations. The letter, signed by potential 2016 Republican presidential candidates, claimed a nuclear deal with Obama could last only while he remains in office.

site_title: BOJ's Shirai says temporary slowdown in inflation acceptable
summary: Bank of Japan policymaker Sayuri Shirai said a temporary slowdown in consumer inflation is acceptable if domestic demand recovers and underlying price developments continue. Shirai warned that achieving the central bank's 2% inflation target may take longer than expected due to households cutting spending in response to rising costs and slow wage growth. The BOJ has held its stimulus since October, and Shirai signaled no immediate need for additional support, citing heightened uncertainty over capital spending and private consumption.

site_title: Italy's top court clears Berlusconi in bunga bunga sex case
summary: Italy's top court has acquitted billionaire media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi on charges of paying for sex with an underage dancer and abusing his position as prime minister. The ruling, confirmed after nine hours of deliberations, ends a lengthy legal saga and leaves Berlusconi free to resume his role in Italian politics. He had been serving a community service order for tax fraud and remains involved in other legal cases, but the acquittal is unlikely to prevent his return to politics and opposition to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's plans.

site_title: WE Holdings plans S$25m acquisition, equal-sized convertible bond issuance
summary: WE Holdings has signed a non-binding deal to acquire marine sand supplier Hua Kai for S$25 million, with a plan to issue an equal-sized convertible bond offering. The acquisition will be financed with S$8 million in cash and new shares upfront, with the remaining S$15 million paid in three annual installments if Hua Kai meets profit targets. The deal is part of WE Holdings' plan to build a commodities arm and issue S$25 million convertible bonds to finance this and other ventures.

site_title: Nam Cheong clinches US$58m orders for two vessels
summary: Nam Cheong, a shipbuilder, secured orders for two vessels worth US$58 million, increasing its order book to RM1.7 billion. The contracts, from Marco Polo Marine and Topaz Energy and Marine, are expected to contribute to earnings in 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Rents of private non-landed homes, HDB flats fall in February: SRX
summary: Rents of private non-landed homes and HDB flats in Singapore declined in February, with private units posting a 0.8% drop and HDB flats marking a 0.3% decrease. Rents in Core Central Region and Rest of Central Region fell 1.2% and 1.5% month-on-month, respectively. Rental volumes also declined, with 2,586 private units and 1,371 HDB flats rented in February, representing a 25.8% and 25.7% decrease from January.

images.alt_text: SOFTNESS persisted in the leasing market for private non-landed homes and public HDB (Housing & Development Board) flats in February with both segments marking a decline in rents.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on Wall Street slides; TSMC inches up
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.4% on Wednesday, following a decline on Wall Street. The main TAIEX index dropped to 9,501.69, with electronics shares slipping 0.2%. Tech heavyweights TSMC and Hon Hai Precision traded mixed after posting February sales results, with TSMC rising 0.4% and Hon Hai falling 0.1%.

site_title: Fed speculation overshadows Asian markets, dollar rallies
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday, with most markets declining due to increasing expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in the summer. The dollar strengthened to 12-year highs against the euro, while Japan's Nikkei edged up. The Dow tumbled 1.85% and the S&P 500 fell 1.70% on Wall Street. The jobs report in the US fueled dollar buying, while concerns over Greece's bailout talks and the European Central Bank's bond-buying scheme also contributed to the dollar's surge.

site_title: Dropbox says Android security flaw fixed
summary: Dropbox has fixed a security flaw that could have allowed hackers to access data stored in its service on Android devices via compromised third-party apps. The vulnerability, discovered by IBM researchers, was addressed in the software provided to third-party app developers. Despite the flaw, Dropbox reported no evidence of user data being accessed. The company has warned Android developers to update the latest version of the software. The vulnerability was fixed a few months ago, and Dropbox has more than 300 million users.

images.alt_text: Dropbox, the popular online file storing system, said on Tuesday it has fixed a security flaw that could have allowed hackers to capture data stored in its service on Android devices via compromised third-party apps.

site_title: Japan machinery orders fall in sign of soft capex demand
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 1.7% in January, a smaller drop than forecast, suggesting companies remain cautious about increasing capital expenditure due to uncertain economic conditions. This data challenges Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus policies, which aim to boost spending on wages and equipment. Core orders, a key indicator of capital spending, rose 1.9% year-over-year in January, but corporate spending plans remain slow to materialize, leaving room for the Bank of Japan to expand stimulus later this year.

site_title: China Rongsheng halts trading, cites possible deal announcement
summary: China Rongsheng Heavy Industries Group Holdings halted trading on March 11, 2015, citing a possible "very substantial disposal" announcement. The company, one of China's largest private shipbuilders, has been struggling with heavy debt and a slowdown in the shipbuilding market. Government agencies have approached Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings to buy a stake in Rongsheng, but a decision has yet to be made. This move could be a test for China's government in reforming bloated industries.

site_title: Israel's Netanyahu says sees "real danger" of losing re-election bid
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned of a "real danger" of losing his re-election bid in the March 17 vote, citing a worldwide effort to ensure his defeat. Netanyahu urged supporters to cast ballots against left-of-centre Zionist Union party candidate Isaac Herzog, who has promised to revive peace talks with Palestinians and divide Jerusalem. The election is seen as a closely contested race, with Netanyahu's Likud party running neck-and-neck with the Zionist Union in opinion polls. Netanyahu's visit to a rally in northern Israel came amid international pressure and criticism of his involvement in US politics.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close down
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed lower on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 2.52%, Paris's CAC 40 down 1.12%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.71%. The decline follows a record high on Monday. In contrast, the US saw its S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: London schoolgirls 'stole jewellery' to fund Syria flight
summary: Three London schoolgirls, Kadiza Sultana, Shamima Begum, and Amira Abase, fled to Syria last month, joining Islamic State (IS) jihadists, and are believed to have stolen family jewelry to fund their travel. The girls, aged 16 and 15, paid over £1,000 for flights to Istanbul, where they joined IS fighters. Relatives claim the girls were "terrified" by police attention and were victims, not involved in terrorism. Police have no evidence to suggest involvement in terrorism and may allow the girls to return home without charges.

site_title: Euro extends fall to 12-year low as bond yields drop further
summary: The euro fell to a 12-year low against the US dollar, extending a decline after the European Central Bank's bond-buying program began. The euro slid to US$1.0666, while German 10-year yields dropped to 0.237%, and the two-year bond offer a negative yield of 0.235%. The decline is attributed to uncertainty over Greece's financial situation and expectations of a potential US interest rate hike.

site_title: New Zealand spies on China, other Asian nations: Snowden papers
summary: New Zealand's Government Communications Security Bureau (GCSB) collects data on communications from 20 nations, including China, Japan, North Korea, and Iran, and shares it with the US and other international allies. The GCSB's reach extends beyond the South Pacific, with satellite interception and covert listening posts used to target foreign countries. The intelligence is passed on to the NSA and other agencies through the "Five Eyes" surveillance network. The revelations suggest New Zealand spies on its friends on behalf of the US, contradicting claims that the operations are solely for national interests.

site_title: Qatar to double migrant worker numbers ahead of World Cup
summary: Qatar plans to double its migrant worker population to 2.5 million by 2020 ahead of the 2022 World Cup, with major projects and infrastructure developments driving the growth. The country aims to improve housing standards and living conditions for migrant workers. However, human rights campaigners have called for further reforms, including addressing the "kafala" sponsorship system and passport confiscation. The move comes amid international pressure to improve labor conditions for workers on World Cup projects, which have faced criticism for poor treatment and low wages.

site_title: No women at 90% of Japanese boards belies Abe's push for equality
summary: Japanese boardrooms remain predominantly male, with just 196 of 1,858 firms on the Topix index having female directors, representing 1.5% of all board members. This represents a slow progress since Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's 2012 plan to empower women, with half of Japanese companies having only male managers. Experts, including Kathy Matsui, warn that excluding women from decision-making roles could hurt innovation, while businesses may be worse off for the lack of female representation.

images.alt_text: Two years after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe came to power with a plan to empower women, Japanese boardrooms are still the biggest boys' clubs in the developed world.

site_title: ECB's 'QE' on track with day one purchases at 3.2b euros: official
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing (QE) programme kicked off with a successful first day, purchasing 3.2 billion euros in bonds. This marks the beginning of the ECB's goal to buy 60 billion euros in public and private sector debt each month. The programme aims to stimulate growth and prevent deflation by injecting money into the economy, similar to the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England's QE schemes. This move is seen as a key measure to revive the eurozone's flat-lining economic recovery.

site_title: Hyundai Motor to build second US plant
summary: Hyundai Motor Co plans to build its second US factory, with an annual production capacity of 300,000 vehicles, to meet growing demand for sport utility vehicles. The new plant in Alabama is expected to break ground this year and start SUV production in 2017. This move aims to counter declining sales of sedans, which are shifting to SUVs in favor of US and Japanese rivals. The decision follows Hyundai's US sales rising 4% from January to February, lagging the market's 9% growth.

site_title: Harrison Ford plane suffered engine failure: investigators
summary: Harrison Ford's plane suffered engine failure shortly after take-off from Santa Monica airport, forcing a U-turn before crashing onto a golf course. The Star Wars and Indiana Jones star was seriously injured in the accident, which also damaged the vintage aircraft's wings and fuselage. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is investigating the incident.

site_title: Uber pledges to enlist 1 million female drivers by 2020
summary: Uber pledges to recruit 1 million female drivers worldwide by 2020, aiming to increase the female driver ratio from 14% in the US to a global average. The company, facing backlash over driver assaults, emphasizes its flexible scheduling and safety features, including driver identity notifications and estimated arrival times. This move is seen as a response to incidents in cities like Boston, Chicago, and Delhi, and aims to promote a more inclusive and safer ride-hailing experience.

site_title: India's lower house passes land acquisition bill
summary: India's lower house passed a land acquisition bill that aims to simplify the process of acquiring land for infrastructure projects, potentially attracting investment and boosting the economy. The bill, which still needs approval from the upper house, makes it easier for companies to purchase land, but opponents argue it would harm farmers. The bill's passage was opposed by Congress and other lawmakers, who stormed out of parliament in protest. The bill's fate now hangs in the balance as it faces potential hurdles in the upper house, where the ruling party lacks a majority.

site_title: US: Stocks sink on dollar fears; Dow -1.85%
summary: US stocks plummeted Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average sinking 332.78 points (1.85%) to 17,662.94, as investors fretted over higher interest rates and a soaring dollar. The dollar hit multi-year highs against the euro and yen amid expectations of a faster-than-anticipated Federal Reserve rate hike. Tech stocks also fell, with Apple and Google losing 2.0% and 2.2%, respectively. Despite the decline, some stocks rose, including Urban Outfitters, which jumped 11.5% after reporting strong quarterly sales.

site_title: Dubai foreign workers stage rare strike
summary: Hundreds of foreign construction workers in Dubai staged a rare protest, blocking a road near the Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest building. The police intervened and resolved the dispute over overtime working hours, with the employer paying on time for salaries. The workers' rights were preserved, according to police, and the issue was resolved in less than an hour.

site_title: Greece gets half-billion-euro lifeline
summary: Greece has received a half-billion-euro lifeline from the European Stability Mechanism, providing a brief respite from its creditors. The 555 million euros will help the anti-austerity coalition, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, meet its debt obligations. Greece claims unpaid reparations from Germany for World War II damage, totaling 162 billion euros, and Tsipras has pressed for negotiation. The European Central Bank and Eurogroup had initially been reluctant to provide the funds, but eventually agreed, with ECM director general Klaus Regling stating that the EFSF does not have a stake in the amount.

site_title: Andorra takes over BPA bank on US money laundering concerns
summary: Andorra's financial authority has taken control of private bank Banca Privada D'Andorra (BPA) amid US concerns over money laundering. The US Department of the Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) named BPA a primary money laundering concern, citing $2 billion in laundered funds from Venezuelan state oil company PDVSA and organized crime in Russia and China. The Andorran government intervened to ensure the bank's continuity, not due to solvency issues. BPA has agreed to an internal investigation and cooperation with authorities.

images.alt_text: The financial authority of tax haven Andorra has taken control of private bank Banca Privada D'Andorra (BPA) after the United States declared the lender as under suspicion for money laundering, the Andorran government said on Tuesday.

site_title: Hundreds of staff ID cards missing, stolen at Atlanta airport
summary: Hundreds of staff ID cards have gone missing or been stolen at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, with an estimated 1,400 badges lost or stolen between 2012 and 2014. The airport downplays the issue, stating that lost or stolen badges are invalidated and deactivated, and that secured areas can only be accessed with a valid badge and PIN. However, some security analysts have expressed concern, citing that a single lost badge could pose a security threat. The US Transportation Security Administration has ordered a review of airport security nationwide to identify potential vulnerabilities.

site_title: Gold stuck near 3-month low as dollar strength weighs
summary: Gold prices hovered near a three-month low due to a strong US dollar and expectations of higher US interest rates, curbing appetite for the metal. Spot gold reached $1,163.15 an ounce, down 4% from the previous session, its lowest since December 1.

images.alt_text: Gold hovered near its lowest in over three months on Wednesday, hurt by consecutive losses in the last seven sessions as a robust dollar and expectations of higher US interest rates curbed appetite for the metal.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment dips in March: survey
summary: Australian consumer sentiment declined 1.2% in March, according to a survey of 1,200 people by the Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank. The index reading of 99.5 matched the reading from March last year, with pessimists slightly outnumbering optimists. Concerns about proposed budget measures and taxation tempered the favourable effect of lower interest rates. The Reserve Bank of Australia's rate cut in February was seen as a positive factor, but respondents were still mostly unfavourable about economic conditions and employment.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) lowered rates by a quarter point to a record low of 2.25 per cent in early February and left the door open for further easing if needed.

site_title: Burger King cuts soft drinks from kids' meals
summary: Burger King announced it will cut soft drinks from its children's meals, following McDonald's lead. The US fast-food chain will offer alternative beverages such as apple juice, fat-free milk, or low-fat chocolate milk. The move aims to reduce the amount of sweet sodas consumed by children.

site_title: Extramarital dating site draws French flak
summary: A French dating website, Gleeden, promoting extramarital affairs, has sparked a national debate and backlash after its ads were displayed on buses in several cities. Seven cities withdrew the ads, and opponents took to social media to mobilize against them, citing concerns over public morality and private sexual conduct. The Catholic Family Associations filed a complaint against the site, citing a 1804 article in the civil code that stipulates married couples must show mutual respect and fidelity. The controversy reflects a deep strain of social conservatism in France, where traditional family values and freedom of expression are often at odds.

site_title: Apple's high-fashion - and high-margin - gadgets
summary: Apple unveiled its new Watch, priced from $349 to $17,000, with a focus on fashion and style. Despite the high-end model's expensive price tag, the company's market capitalization dropped $20 billion, indicating investor disappointment. The Watch's main selling point appears to be its convenience, with potential for health apps and easy information display. Apple's emphasis on materials and design may be a strategic move to maintain margins, as luxury fashion retailers command higher valuation multiples. The company's ability to keep margins buoyant despite high prices remains a key strength.

site_title: Frasers to start selling condos in Yishun project at end-March
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Ltd will begin selling condos in its North Park Residences project in Yishun, Singapore, at the end of March. The 920-unit project, part of Northpoint City, will target both investors and owner-occupiers, with a preview starting this weekend. The project's integrated design with a transport hub and retail component is expected to command a 30% price premium, but developers say this will lead to higher yields and capital appreciation.
