Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of PSB in reflecting and shaping the country's culture and identity, despite the shift to global media content. The funding will support new-media platforms, enhancing existing platforms and commissioning diverse and innovative content across various media platforms.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping 11 cents to $49.89 and Brent easing 35 cents to $58.18. The decline was attributed to a strengthening US dollar and ongoing geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, particularly in Libya and Iraq. The US dollar's surge has made dollar-priced oil more expensive for buyers using weaker currencies, reducing demand and pushing prices lower. Analysts also noted that intensifying fighting in Libya and Iraq has reduced oil output, further contributing to the decline in prices.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank says monetary policy focused on stability, growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo emphasized the focus on macroeconomic stability and growth in the country. The central bank cut its benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 7.50% in February, and will meet again on March 17. The move aims to support growth in Southeast Asia's largest economy.

site_title: 1MDB makes payment on dollar bonds, price slumps to record low
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) made a payment of $66 million on its 2023 dollar bonds, bringing the price to a record low of 83.64 cents on the dollar, yielding 7.12%. The company's debt has raised concerns, and it announced plans to dismantle assets, set up standalone entities, and raise cash from selling its power business. This payment comes after 1MDB's ability to service its debt was questioned following a loan delay and rising borrowings of 41.9 billion ringgit.

site_title: Citi-linked China broker sets IPO price amid competition concerns
summary: Chinese brokerage Orient Securities Co Ltd has priced its IPO, raising over $2.2 billion, in the largest mainland initial public offering since 2011. The IPO comes amid concerns of competition from banks, which are expected to receive brokerage licenses, and is part of China's efforts to calm the red-hot stock market. The IPO price gave Orient Securities a 22.98 times price-to-earnings ratio, lower than the industry average. The funds will be used for working capital and business expansion.

site_title: Public service wages must be fair and realistic to ensure flow of able and committed leaders: DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of fair and realistic public service wages to attract able and committed leaders in Singapore. Despite a moderate 3% annual increase in benchmark salaries since 2011, political salaries have not been adjusted in the last three years. The current ministerial salary, at S$1.1 million, remains unchanged from the 2014 benchmark of S$1.2 million. Teo emphasized the need to strike a balance between recognizing the ethos of public service and providing fair compensation to ensure a steady supply of dedicated leaders.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Singapore must continue to keep wages in the public service fair and realistic to ensure a flow of able and committed leaders, Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean said on Tuesday.

site_title: BMW says February sales rise 7.6%
summary: BMW reported a 7.6% increase in February sales to 151,952 vehicles, setting a new record for the month. BMW-branded vehicle sales rose 5.2%, while Mini sales increased 27.1%. Key sales growth was seen in Germany (13.3%) and North America (13.8%), with the BMW X5 experiencing a 46% increase. The company attributed the success to strong demand for the Mini and X5 off-roader.

images.alt_text: BMW said deliveries of BMW, Mini and Rolls-Royce cars rose 7.6 per cent in February to a best for the month of 151,952 vehicles, thanks to good sales in Germany, North America and due to demand for the Mini and the BMW X5 offroader.

site_title: Brent steadies above US$58.50 after China data; strong dollar hurts
summary: Brent crude oil steadied above $58.50 a barrel on Tuesday, supported by China's annual consumer inflation data showing a 1.4% rise in February, beating analyst estimates. A firmer US dollar also kept a lid on prices. Despite a 4.6% decline last week, Brent is expected to trend sideways, with investors waiting for weekly US inventory reports for further direction. Geopolitical tensions remain a concern, but analysts say the dollar's impact on oil prices is more significant.

site_title: New Zealand police probe threat to poison baby formula
summary: New Zealand authorities are investigating a "criminal threat" to poison baby formula, with small packages containing poison sent to the National Farmers Federation and Fonterra. The threat, made in November, claims to contaminate products unless a poison called 1080 is banned by the end of March. Police are taking the threat seriously and are appealing for public assistance. Despite concerns, the Ministry of Primary Industries and the New Zealand Food and Grocery Council have assured that products on shelves are safe, with extra testing introduced to reassure parents.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.11% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.11% higher on Tuesday, driven by a rally on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 27.63 points to 24,150.68. The gains were attributed to investors awaiting Chinese inflation data. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, where the STI index reached a 0.4% gain.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat, NZ slips as dairy threat sours sentiment
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Tuesday, reversing early gains, while New Zealand's NZX slipped 0.2% due to threats made against baby formula from New Zealand milk producers. Environmental activists were suspected of making the threats to halt the use of an agricultural poison. Australia's ASX 200 index closed 0.04% higher at 5,824.2, while Fonterra and Synlait Milk fell 1.2% and 1.7% respectively, their lowest in over 18 months.

site_title: Quick take: China's 2015 CPI target of about 3% "wildly unrealistic": EIU
summary: China's consumer inflation rose to 1.4% in February, rebounding from a more-than-five-year low, while producer prices dropped 4.8% from a year ago, extending factory deflation. The country's 2015 CPI target of 3% is considered "wildly unrealistic" due to persistently weak price rises and deflationary pressures. Authorities are expected to shift focus to fiscal policy to boost demand, and while the economy may avoid outright deflation, disinflation is likely to persist.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Chinese banks said preparing to challenge Citic in broking
summary: Chinese banks, including Industrial Bank and Bank of Communications, are preparing to challenge Citic Securities Co and China International Capital Corp in the nation's brokerage industry. The banks plan to acquire Huafu Securities Co and Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc's stake in Hua Ying Securities Co, respectively, in a move that could lead to a shakeup in the industry. Analysts warn that allowing banks to enter the securities business could be devastating to Chinese brokers, leading to cut-throat competition and a potential loss of assets for brokerages.

site_title: MCL Land places S$630 psf ppr top bid for 99-year private housing site in Jurong West
summary: MCL Land (Vantage) has secured the top bid of S$338.12 million or S$630.13 psf ppr for a 99-year private housing site in Jurong West Street 41. The site garnered nine bids at a state tender, with HY Realty's second-highest bid at S$317.9 million or S$592 psf ppr. The successful bid is expected to generate significant revenue for MCL Land, solidifying its position in the Singapore property market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China's labour market will come under more pressure: minister
summary: China's labour market will face increased pressure this year, according to the country's social security minister, Yin Weimin. Employment fell more year-on-year in January and February compared to the same period last year. Despite tolerating slower economic growth, Chinese leaders aim to maintain healthy employment levels. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Euro slips to lowest since Sept 2003 against dollar
summary: The euro slid to a 12-year low against the dollar, reaching US$1.0808, due to expectations of a potential US interest rate hike and the European Central Bank's continued monetary easing. The ECB launched a 1 trillion euro bond buying program, driving euro zone debt yields lower and weighing on the euro. This is the euro's lowest value since September 2003.

site_title: China's deficit plans put squeeze on local government financing
summary: China's plan to run its largest fiscal deficit since the global financial crisis may help develop its bond market, but it could also squeeze out major providers of local government financing. Local government financing vehicles (LGFVs), which were used to skirt restrictions on local fundraising, are struggling to service their debts and may go under. The government is trying to address this problem by pushing a municipal bond model, but this may not help with existing debts, particularly those linked to projects without a steady income stream.

site_title: Head of Prudential's US business to become new CEO
summary: Mike Wells, head of Prudential's US business, has been elected as the new CEO of Prudential Plc, succeeding Tidjane Thiam. Wells, who has been with Prudential for 15 years, will replace Thiam, who is set to step down as CEO of Credit Suisse AG. Wells' appointment is pending regulatory approval and may take several weeks to finalize. Wells' predecessor, Thiam, has been with Prudential since 2009 and will step down as CEO of Credit Suisse AG.

site_title: China to launch Guangdong free trade zone March 18: trade body
summary: China is set to launch its Guangdong free trade zone (FTZ) on March 18, following the success of its Shanghai FTZ, which was launched two years ago. The new zones in Guangdong, Fujian, and Tianjin aim to develop a more open economy through financial reforms, including the use of a fully convertible yuan currency. The launch is seen as an important step towards this goal, with key officials attending the ceremony.

site_title: Hot stock: Ellipsiz continues rally in the wake of broker's 'buy' call
summary: Ellipsiz shares rose 6.48% to 11.5 Singapore cents, following a "buy" call from UOB Kay Hian. The broker set a target price of 17.1 Singapore cents and called Ellipsiz an "attractive target" for acquisition. The stock jumped 12.5% on Monday, prompting a trading query from the Singapore Exchange. Ellipsiz attributed the surge to the UOB Kay Hian report, but denied any undisclosed information.

site_title: Gold holds near 3-month low on US rate expectations
summary: Gold prices remained near a three-month low on Tuesday, as expectations of a US interest rate hike in mid-year weighed on demand for the metal. Spot gold was steady at $1,166.66 per ounce, with renewed concerns about a rate hike from the Federal Reserve and a strong US jobs report on Friday. Analysts predict gold will continue to be negatively impacted by the US rate hike, with technical analysts forecasting a potential support level at $1,150.

site_title: China: Shares mixed in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares experienced a mixed trading session on Tuesday, March 10, 2015, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.45% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 0.35%. The rebound in inflation, which rose to 1.4% in February, contributed to the mixed market.

site_title: China lawmakers' pollution battle adds to growth challenges
summary: China's lawmakers are focusing on pollution as the country's economic growth faces challenges. Premier Li Keqiang pledged to fight pollution with "all our might," but critics argue that efforts to clean up the environment may have worsened the situation. The government aims to cut energy intensity by 3.1% and target pollutants, but experts warn that the main economic drag will likely begin next year and continue for five years. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Asia: Tokyo lifted by weak yen but Shanghai, Hong Kong slip
summary: Tokyo's stocks rose due to a weak yen, while Shanghai and Hong Kong fell as Chinese consumer spending data showed further weakness. The euro struggled against the dollar after the European Central Bank launched stimulus measures. Greece's debt talks were also a concern. In other markets, Singapore's stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day, and the US stock market reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Condo resale prices remain flat in February, again: SRX flash estimates
summary: Condo resale prices in Singapore remained flat in February, according to SRX flash estimates. Prices in Core Central Region (CCR) and Outside Central Region (OCR) increased 1.5% and 2% respectively, while city-fringe locations saw a 0.8% decrease. The year-on-year resale price index eased 3.2% from February 2014, and the month-on-month change in January 2015 was revised to unchanged.

images.alt_text: RESALE prices of condominiums and private apartments remained flat in February this year compared to January, according to flash estimates released by SRX Property on Tuesday.
Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Baidu may introduce autonomous car this year
summary: Baidu, China's largest search engine, may introduce an autonomous car this year, according to CEO Robin Li. This move follows similar efforts by Google, Apple, and Leshi Internet Information & Technology, which aim to develop driverless vehicles. China's Information Technology and Industry Minister Miao Wei has encouraged companies outside the auto industry to partner with existing manufacturers to spur innovation and competition. Other companies, such as Tesla, are also pushing forward with autonomous vehicle development.

site_title: China forex chief says to launch China international payment system this year
summary: China plans to launch its international payment system, CIPS, this year, aiming to replace existing networks for processing yuan payments. The move is part of efforts to increase the yuan's global usage and reduce reliance on the US dollar. The CIPS system will provide a worldwide "payments superhighway" for the yuan, making it easier for businesses to process renminbi transactions. The launch is seen as a significant step towards increasing China's global economic influence and reducing its dependence on the US financial system.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 2.73 points to 1794.82. Gainers outnumbered losers 127 to 61, with a total trading volume of 35.47 million lots worth RM12.68 million.

site_title: Hot stocks: S-Reits fall; Singapore government bond yields rise after positive US jobs report
summary: Singapore's S-Reits experienced drawdowns on Monday, with yields on 10-year government bonds rising 10 basis points to 2.4%, a new high since October 2014. This increase is attributed to the positive US jobs report, which led to a surge in US Treasury yields and expectations of an earlier Federal Reserve interest-rate hike. As a result, Reits, which are sensitive to interest-rate changes, saw declines of 1.4% to 3.35% in trading. Analysts predict that Reits may struggle to match their past performances due to these headwinds.

site_title: China to raise retirement age as pressure on pension fund rises
summary: China's pension fund is under pressure to break even, prompting the government to consider raising the official retirement age. Minister of Human Resources and Social Security Yin Weimin announced that the retirement age will be gradually increased, starting at 50 for some female workers, but will be phased in over five years. No specific timeline has been provided for the retirement age increase. This move aims to alleviate the financial strain on the pension fund and ensure its sustainability.

site_title: South Korea's February department store sales rebound sharply from January
summary: South Korea's department store sales rebounded 7.1% in February, the fastest gain since August 2014, after the Lunar New Year holiday shifted from January to February this year. This contrasts with a 11.0% drop in January, the steepest contraction on record. Sales at discount stores also surged 30.5% in February, while gasoline sales rose 12.5% for the third consecutive month.

site_title: Australia: Stocks rise with Japan futures as yen extends losses
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.3% with Japan futures up 0.4%, tracking a US share rebound. The yen extended losses against the dollar, while the kiwi and euro also declined. China's consumer and producer prices data is set to be released, providing insight into the slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. European shares fell despite the European Central Bank's quantitative easing, with US shares reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Credit Suisse to replace CEO Dougan with Prudential's Thiam: FT
summary: Credit Suisse is set to replace CEO Brady Dougan with Tidjane Thiam, who heads insurance group Prudential, following pressure from politicians and the media in Switzerland. Dougan's departure comes after the bank reached a $2.5 billion settlement with US authorities over tax evasion charges. Thiam's appointment is expected to be announced by Prudential on Tuesday, as the bank reports its annual results. Dougan, who has been at Credit Suisse for 25 years, was criticized for his investment banking strategy and his handling of the tax evasion scandal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.53% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.53% higher on Tuesday, driven by the yen's three-month low against the dollar, which made Japanese exporters more competitive abroad. The dollar reached its highest level since early December at 121.51 yen. Wall Street stocks also gained, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.78% and the S&P 500 advancing 0.39%. The euro was mixed amid the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program.

site_title: Australia throws ailing auto industry lifeline
summary: The Australian government has reinstated A$500 million in funding to the country's ailing auto industry, ensuring it can continue until its manufacturers cease production by the end of 2017. Toyota, Ford, and Holden, Australia's key car manufacturers, plan to shut down by 2017 due to high costs and a small domestic market. The funding was reinstated to support component manufacturers, which would be affected by the withdrawal of government subsidies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, CNA, Yangzijiang
summary: NOBLE Group seeks US$3 billion in bank loans to refinance debt amid allegations of aggressive accounting. CNA Group secures S$9.65 million in contracts, impacting 2015 earnings. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings names Ren Letian as new CEO, replacing his father Ren Yuanlin.

site_title: Singapore: STI stages rebound ahead of China inflation data
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 3.23 points or 0.09% to 3.407.8, driven by a rebound in US markets and anticipation of China's inflation data. 47 million shares worth S$71.9 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 86 to 37. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings led the gains, while Lippo Malls Indo Retail Trust and Noble Group declined. The rebound comes ahead of China's inflation data release at 9:30am, with investors awaiting the impact on global markets.

site_title: Malaysia company dollar bonds are Asia's worst performing this year
summary: Malaysia's dollar bonds are Asia's worst performers this year, losing 1.57% due to factors such as a 13% decline in the Malaysian ringgit, a 47% slump in oil prices, and debt repayment concerns at state-backed investment firm 1MDB. Investors, including those at Invesco and One Asia Investment Partners, cite sustained weakness in the currency and structural issues as weighing on the nation's debt. Despite a diversified economy, the country's exposure to oil prices and budget deficit target cuts have negatively impacted its credit rating and sovereign debt.

site_title: Boeing to improve 777, studies options for midsized jet
summary: Boeing plans to improve the efficiency and seating capacity of its 777 jetliner by delivering a 2% fuel efficiency gain and 14 extra seats starting in the third quarter of 2016. This upgrade aims to boost sales of the existing model, which would otherwise undermine production and cash flow. The move is also designed to maintain investor confidence in 777s and address speculation about potential production cuts, similar to Airbus' 40% reduction in A330 production last month.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic sees profits taking off this year
summary: Virgin Atlantic expects a significant boost in earnings in 2015, with more customers on transatlantic routes, new planes, and lower fuel costs. The airline reported its first profit in four years in 2014 and is in the midst of a turnaround plan, focusing on long-haul routes and shutting its domestic airline, Little Red. Delta Air Lines' 2013 purchase of a stake in Virgin Atlantic has also led to an emphasis on transatlantic routes. The airline's CEO attributed the expected earnings boost to these factors.

site_title: HBO to launch streaming service with Apple TV
summary: HBO announced its standalone streaming service, HBO Now, set to launch on Apple TV next month. The service, priced at $14.99/month, will offer exclusive original content and compete with popular streaming services like Netflix. The partnership between HBO and Apple provides increased appeal for the Apple TV device, especially for consumers looking to end cable or satellite subscriptions. With this move, HBO enters the streaming-only video market, marking a natural evolution for the network. The service is set to launch on April 12.

site_title: Oil prices mixed in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices in Asia were mixed on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate gaining one cent to $50.01 and Brent easing eight cents to $58.45. The stronger US dollar weighed on prices due to dollar-priced oil becoming more expensive for buyers using weaker currencies. Geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, particularly in Libya and Iraq, also contributed to the mixed market. In other news, China's inflation rebounded to 1.4% in February, while the producer price index fell 4.8%, its worst reading since 2009.

site_title: Fed's Fisher calls for 'prompt' rate hike in final speech
summary: Dallas Fed President Richard Fisher urged the Federal Reserve to promptly raise interest rates, followed by gradual increases, in his final speech as a policymaker. Fisher dismissed stagnant wage growth as a lagging indicator, predicting inflation will rebound once energy prices stabilize. He also expressed concerns about the risks of a steep rate hike later this year, instead advocating for an early and gradual rate increase. The Fed has signaled a potential rate hike later this year, with June to September being the expected timeframe.

site_title: Oil company BPZ Resources files for bankruptcy in US court
summary: BPZ Resources Inc., a Texas-based oil producer, filed for bankruptcy protection in a US court on March 9, 2015. The company, which has operations in Peru, cited low oil prices and debt maturity as reasons for the move. Despite filing for bankruptcy, BPZ said it would continue to operate its businesses to pay off its debt. The company has a 51% stake in Peru's offshore oil block Z-1 and controls three onshore oil blocks in Peru.

site_title: Australia business confidence gets no lift from rate cut: NAB
summary: Australian business confidence fell to its lowest since late 2013 in February, according to a National Australia Bank survey, despite a rate cut to 2.25%. The index of business confidence dropped three points to zero, with declines in mining and retail confidence outweighing improvements in manufacturing and construction. Forward orders remained steady, and inflationary pressures were restrained, with firms reporting sluggish wages growth and only a small increase in retail prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates again in May, with a 30-80% chance of a rate cut in April.

images.alt_text: A measure of Australian business confidence fell to its lowest since late 2013 in February as a cut in interest rates seemingly failed to dispel uncertainty over the economy and government policy.

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by Apple, GM
summary: US stocks rose Monday, driven by gains from Apple and General Motors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 138.94 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced. Apple launched its smartwatch, and GM announced a $5 billion share buyback program. The gains offset losses from a strong US jobs report, which may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Other notable movers included Macerich, Whiting Petroleum, and Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

site_title: Euro area pushes Greece to open books as aid talks resume
summary: European finance ministers have pressured Greece to open its books and follow through on pledged reforms, as the country's cash supplies dwindle. Greece will resume talks with creditors in Brussels and technical talks in Athens to review data. Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis assured negotiations will proceed in good faith, and access to bailout funds could be restored if Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras delivers on promises. The euro area's finance ministers have set a June deadline for a broader agreement on further support, and creditors are willing to help solve Greece's financing issues once talks resume.

site_title: Barclays pay chief must step down, says UK pensions group
summary: Barclays' pay chief John Sunderland should step down immediately, according to a UK pensions group, following the bank's failure to honor a promise made last year that he would leave. Despite being criticized for allowing high pay to executives and investment bankers, Sunderland remains chair of the remuneration committee 11 months after making the initial promise. Barclays failed to comment on the matter.

site_title: Airbus's multibillion-dollar bet: Whether to overhaul A380 Jumbo
summary: Airbus is considering revamping its A380 jet, a multibillion-dollar project, amid a lack of new orders. Emirates President Tim Clark has suggested taking up to 200 more A380s, but Airbus requires more customers for the A380neo before committing. Turkish Airlines may play a role, with talks to lease two A380s as a trial run. The project's cost is estimated to be in the billions, and Airbus has said it's poised to break even on the A380 this year. Boeing's 747-8 program has also been successful, but analysts don't see it affecting the A380's sales prospects.

images.alt_text: Airbus Group NV's pursuit of new buyers for the A380 jet looms large as the planemaker approaches a crucial decision: whether to plow billions of dollars into revamping the world's largest passenger aircraft.

site_title: Apple Watch to include array of features to connect
summary: Apple unveiled its high-end smartwatch, the Apple Watch, with various features to connect users, including messaging, calls, and health apps. The watch is integrated with iPhone and Apple Pay, offering a range of apps and sensors for health and fitness. Available from April 24, the watch starts at $349 and will be available in several major markets worldwide. Analysts expect Apple to outsell competitors, with predicted sales of 20 million units in 2015, bringing valuable attention to the market.

site_title: China February inflation quickens 1.4%, beating forecasts
summary: China's consumer inflation increased to 1.4% in February, exceeding market expectations and reversing a five-year low in January. Meanwhile, factory deflation worsened, with the producer price index declining 4.8% in February. This deepens concerns about the country's economic weakness.

site_title: Singapore Transport Minister 'extremely concerned' about LRT disruption
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew expressed concern over the ongoing disruption to the Bukit Panjang Light Rail Transit (BPLRT) services due to a power trip and fire. Engineers from the Land Transport Authority and SMRT have been working to restore service, but it will take more time. To alleviate the inconvenience, LTA and SMRT have deployed buses and additional officers at affected stations. The disruption began on Monday evening and has affected the entire BPLRT line.

site_title: UK retail sales growth holds steady in February: BRC
summary: British retail spending rose 1.7% in February compared to the same period last year, according to the British Retail Consortium. This marks a slight increase from January's 1.6% rise. The growth is attributed to a plunge in inflation giving consumers a boost, contrasting with the 0.7% rise in February 2014, when bad weather affected shopping.

images.alt_text: British retail spending kept shops busy in what is normally a quiet month in February, suggesting a plunge in inflation has given consumers a boost, an industry survey showed on Tuesday.

site_title: PM calls on Thais to ensure security, rebuild confidence for foreigners
summary: Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha of Thailand urged the public to help ensure security and boost international confidence after a grenade explosion in Bangkok, the second in the capital in over a month. Three suspects have been detained, and police believe they are from the same political background as those responsible for a previous attack. The military remains in power under martial law, which has kept away some visitors and led to plans for international intervention.

site_title: Japan's economic growth revised down for final quarter
summary: Japan's economic growth has been revised down to 1.5% in the final quarter of 2014, down from an initial estimate of 2.2%, according to the Cabinet Office. This revision, combined with a decline in capital investment and a weaker Nikkei 225 stock average, has sparked concerns that the Bank of Japan may need to ease policy again. Analysts attribute the weakness to corporate Japan's preference to invest overseas rather than in domestic capacity, despite a rise in consumer spending.

site_title: Euro edges up as ECB launches QE programme
summary: The euro rose Monday as the European Central Bank launched a quantitative easing programme to combat deflation and stimulate growth in the eurozone. The ECB plans to buy 60 billion euros' worth of bonds per month over 18 months to lower long-term interest rates. The move aims to foster spending and investment, but markets remain focused on the Greek debt crisis and the risk of a default crisis or 'Grexit'. The euro edged up against the dollar and yen, but fell against the British pound.

images.alt_text: The euro inched higher Monday as the European Central Bank embarked on its long-awaited quantitative easing programme aimed at preventing the eurozone from sinking into deflation.

site_title: US shale oil growth slows as price crash idles drilling rigs
summary: US shale oil output is expected to post the slowest growth in over four years in April, following a 41% decline in drilling rigs since December. Refineries are expected to return from maintenance, bringing relief to an oil market that has seen prices decline over 50% since June. Oil production from six major US shale plays will increase by 298 barrels a day, the smallest projected increase since February 2011. Production in some regions, such as the Eagle Ford and Bakken, is expected to decline, while the Permian Basin is expected to rise.

site_title: Japan must deal with its past and make up with neighbours: Merkel
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged Japan to confront its past and reconcile with Asian neighbors, particularly China and South Korea, during a press conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Merkel noted that Japan's wartime legacy remains a contentious issue, and its relations with its neighbors have worsened since Abe's rise to power. Merkel emphasized the importance of reconciliation and finding a peaceful resolution to territorial disputes, citing Germany's own experience after World War II. Her comments come ahead of Japan's planned statement marking the 70th anniversary of the war's end.

site_title: Nigeria pleads for mercy for nationals on death row in Indonesia
summary: Nigeria has urged Indonesia to spare the lives of three citizens on death row for drug trafficking. The three Nigerians, convicted and losing their appeals, met with the Indonesian ambassador in Nigeria, Danjuma Sheni. Nigeria is seeking clemency for the three individuals.

site_title: Alibaba taps Jeff Zhang to oversee consolidated retail division
summary: Alibaba appoints Jeff Zhang to oversee its China Retail Marketplaces division, which includes Taobao, Tmall, and Juhuasuan. The move aims to streamline operations and enhance efficiency, following a period of struggling growth. Tmall is growing faster than Taobao, with a 60% increase in gross merchandise value in the last quarter. The appointment comes after the dismissal of Yilei Wang, President of Tmall, and shares in the company ended 2.2% lower on the New York stock exchange. The move is part of Alibaba's efforts to adapt to a changing retail landscape.

site_title: Crowdfunding platform for designers to kick off in April
summary: Singapore's first design-centric crowdfunding platform, Sniffr, is set to launch in April by OTTO Solutions. Unlike other crowdfunding platforms, Sniffr is rewards-based, targeting consumers instead of investors. This move is seen as a growing trend in Singapore, with observers noting the increasing attractiveness of crowdsourcing and design to local companies. Sniffr aims to connect designers with consumers, offering a unique platform for design-centric projects.

site_title: Greece to start technical talks with lenders this week
summary: Greece agreed to start urgent technical talks with its eurozone lenders this week, following a meeting of eurozone finance ministers in Brussels. The talks aim to extend Greece's current bailout until June, with the Greek government outlining reforms demanded by lenders. Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem warned that Greece would not receive payments until the reforms are implemented. The new talks come after Greece's new Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras vowed to renegotiate the country's debts and end austerity measures.

site_title: Sam Goi's GSH to start selling strata offices at GSH Plaza
summary: The consortium behind GSH Plaza is launching over 100 strata titled office units, ranging from 480 to 1,700 sqft, with an average price of S$2,850 to S$3,500 per sqft. The units are part of the 28-storey Central Business District building and will cater to various business needs.

site_title: Greenback's rally pauses at 11 1/2-year high
summary: The US dollar paused at an 11 1/2-year high against a basket of currencies, with expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in mid-year supporting the greenback. Strong US jobs data and rising Treasury yields fueled the rally, but profit-taking in Europe brought the dollar index down 0.2% to 97.45. The euro fell to a 21-year low against the dollar, while the yen traded at 120.95. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program and Greece's bailout review are expected to keep the euro under pressure.

site_title: Tourism, luxury goods companies hard hit by Russia's recession
summary: Russia's recession has significantly impacted tourism and luxury goods companies in Europe, with Russian tourists' spending in Europe dropping 20-30% in 2014. Luxury brands such as Ferragamo and Brioni have seen a decline in sales, with some retailers cutting staff or margins to cope. The rouble's depreciation has crushed Russians' spending power, forcing them to put off pricey holiday plans. Some brands, however, have kept prices unchanged or even raised them to preserve client relationships. The decline in Russian travel has also affected airlines, tour groups, and hotels, with some slashing prices to fill beds.

site_title: China seeks tightening of e-commerce rules to curb fake goods
summary: China's State Administration of Industry & Commerce (SAIC) is seeking to tighten e-commerce rules to curb the proliferation of fake goods. Minister Zhang Mao stated that greater oversight is needed to protect consumers and create a fairer business environment online. The spread of knock-off products poses a greater challenge in the online market than in traditional retail. The move aims to address concerns raised after Alibaba Group Holding Ltd was accused of peddling fake goods.

site_title: M&S to offer investors gift card instead of dividend
summary: M&S, a British retailer, will offer private investors a gift card instead of a dividend payment, starting with over 190,000 UK-registered investors. The gift card can be loaded with up to £1,000 at a 10% discount and can be used in M&S stores. This move aims to engage private investors and follows a decade of failed attempts by billionaire Philip Green to take over the company. The change is optional and participants will continue to receive shareholder discount vouchers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mostly lower
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mostly lower on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.51% and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.55%. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rose 0.27% to a new record close. Despite this, mining and healthcare stocks helped prop up shares. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets finished the day mostly lower on Monday with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index down 0.51 per cent to 6.876.47 points.

site_title: Racing for a good cause
summary: OCBC Bank is hosting a two-part donation drive for its OCBC Cycle charity programme, raising funds for underprivileged children and youth. A donation of S$2 per person will be collected through a plush toy guessing game at OCBC Centre from March 9-13, with proceeds going to the SportCares Foundation. A similar drive at Orchard Gateway from July 25-Aug 7 will support the Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The event also features a competitive OCBC Cycle Speedway Championships and various rides, with over half of The Business Times Cycle of Hope Corporate Bike Ride proceeds donated to four beneficiaries.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Market discipline - less talk, more action needed
summary: Market regulators in Singapore face a challenge in policing price rigging, manipulation, and insider trading in the local stock market. While some believe that regulators lack the resources to investigate every contravention of the rules, others argue that the problem lies in defining an acceptable minimum of transgressions. Retail investors have lost confidence in the system, with some giving up trading local stocks due to concerns about price manipulation and lack of protection. A BT reader's theory that unknowing and unsuspecting retail investors bear the brunt of market manipulation adds to the concern.

site_title: Euro's straightjacket a threat to goal of political union
summary: The eurozone's flawed design has led to its failure to achieve its goal of a unified Europe, instead exacerbating economic imbalances and fostering political tensions. The euro's lack of a fiscal shock absorber and the refusal of northern European countries to spend more on southern Europe have contributed to the crisis. Greece's negotiations with the EU showed the limits of the eurozone's design, with the country caving under pressure from the European Central Bank. The eurozone's failure threatens to abort the project of political union, highlighting the need for a more integrated and coordinated approach to economic policy.

site_title: The unknown reality of VR goggles
summary: Virtual reality (VR) technology has reached a new milestone with the launch of the Gear VR store, allowing game designers to sell their VR experiences to customers. The store, powered by Samsung and Oculus, offers a range of VR games, including "Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes," a cooperative game of bomb defusal. However, concerns remain about the long-term viability of VR, with many questioning how users will engage with virtual worlds beyond novelty and exploration. Industry experts, including Oculus and Valve, acknowledge that the true potential of VR has yet to be realized, and further innovation is needed to create immersive experiences.

site_title: Alibaba: Governance by corp politburo
summary: Alibaba's record-breaking New York IPO in 2014 marked a significant shift in global corporate governance, as the company's unique governance structure, led by the Alibaba Partnership, bypassed traditional shareholder voting rights. Investors may need to trade off benefits to comply with regulatory requirements, which are stricter in the US than in Asia. Alibaba's IPO was met with both acceptance and skepticism, with some viewing it as a new era in corporate governance, while others raised concerns about the lack of transparency and potential risks associated with the variable interest entity (VIE) structure.

site_title: China on brink of heart disease 'epidemic': study
summary: China is on the brink of a heart disease epidemic due to unhealthy eating, smoking, and obesity, according to a study published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology. Three out of four Chinese citizens have poor cardiovascular health, with only 0.2% of men and women in ideal health. The prevalence of diabetes has more than doubled in China over the past decade, and cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death. Experts urge China to adopt a nationwide strategy to improve citizens' health and reduce risk factors.

images.alt_text: Unhealthy eating, smoking and obesity are threatening a heart disease epidemic in China, where three out of four people are in poor cardiovascular shape, said a study on Monday.

site_title: Got diabetes? There's an app for that
summary: US health researchers have launched a new software tool, ResearchKit, to collect data on major diseases through iPhone apps. The open-source platform allows researchers to design apps that track users' behaviors and provide real-time health data. Apps for diabetes, heart disease, asthma, breast cancer, and Parkinson's disease are available, with data collected from built-in iPhone sensors and wearable devices. The initiative aims to simplify recruiting and improve data collection, enabling larger and more cost-effective studies.

images.alt_text: US health researchers said on Monday they are targeting millions of smartphone users with Apple Inc's new software tool, hoping to collect an unprecedented amount of data on major diseases by tracking their behaviours via iPhone.

site_title: HK non-bank lenders thrive amid bank mortgage curbs
summary: Hong Kong's non-bank lenders are thriving due to bank mortgage curbs, which have led to a surge in mortgage inquiries. Since regulators restricted bank mortgages in 2009, non-bank lenders have proliferated, offering 90% financing at higher interest rates. The number of new mortgages approved in December increased 56% to 7,606, driven by low interest rates and record rents. Non-bank lenders' market share remains small, but their impact on the property market is growing, with the amount of property-related loans by non-bank lenders reaching HK$8-9 billion.

site_title: Today's young 'will be in relatively good shape to retire' (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin says young Singaporeans are likely to have sufficient retirement funds through the Central Provident Fund (CPF) system, citing a 25-year-old polytechnic graduate who would have around S$165,000 by age 65. The government has introduced measures to encourage older workers, including a Special Employment Credit, and will offer two CPF Life plans from age 65. The government also aims to extend re-employment to 67 in two to three years and has launched a retirement-planning service to help CPF members make informed decisions.

site_title: Time to kill off zombie company Sharp
summary: Sharp, a Japanese tech giant, is facing financial struggles and may be at risk of bankruptcy. Despite being founded in 1912 and introducing the world's first transistor calculator in 1964, the company has experienced declining fortunes, with nearly $5 billion in losses in 2012. Sharp is forecasting a $251 million loss for the current quarter, as its Aquos TVs struggle to compete with Chinese and Korean rivals. The company's woes have persisted despite cosmetic changes, including a new president and efforts to raise equity.

site_title: SIA and 7 other carriers reach settlement in price-fixing lawsuit
summary: Singapore Airlines and seven other airlines have reached a settlement in a price-fixing lawsuit related to trans-Pacific flights. The eight airlines agreed to pay US$39.5 million to the settlement fund, with Singapore Airlines paying US$9.2 million. The lawsuit claims that the airlines fixed prices on tickets, potentially overcharging passengers. The settlement does not apply to five non-settling airlines, including Air New Zealand and All Nippon Airways, which continue to face the lawsuit. A hearing will be held in May to approve the settlement fund.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: It may be 'Morning Again in America'
summary: The US economy has added 295,000 jobs in February, with the unemployment rate dropping to 5.5%, the lowest in seven years. This marks the 12th straight month of job gains over 200,000. Average hourly wages rose three cents to $24.78, but the rate of wage increases remains below 4%, a post-recovery economy benchmark. Despite strong job growth, concerns about underemployment and stagnant wages persist, leading to conflicting expectations among investors and policymakers about interest rate hikes.

site_title: Twitter activity matches TV viewers' engagement: study
summary: A study by Nielsen found that Twitter activity closely correlates with TV viewers' engagement with shows, with a 79.5% correlation between the two. The research involved hooking up 300 people to brain monitors while they watched TV shows, and comparing the brain activity with the volume of tweets about the same shows. The study supports Twitter's claim that its real-time social network can accurately predict the public's changing moods and interests. The findings suggest that Twitter chatter can even predict which premieres will draw the biggest audiences.

site_title: SGX launches two iron ore contracts
summary: SGX launches two iron ore contracts, the SGX Iron Ore CFR China (58 per cent FE Fines) swap and futures contracts, to provide better hedging opportunities for lower-grade iron ore. The new contracts are based on the Metal Bulletin and The Steel Index indices, respectively, and are designed to reduce basis risk on hedges. The move comes after a widening price spread between high and low-grade iron ore, with prices differing by up to $18 per tonne in June 2014. The contracts are the sixth iron ore offerings by SGX, which has seen compound annual growth rates of 112% and 134% in volume and open interest, respectively.

site_title: iflix to launch video streaming service in South-east Asia this year
summary: IFLIX, a video-on-demand platform founded by Patrick Grove, is set to launch in South-east Asia this year, offering premium TV and film content from Hollywood and Asian studios. The service aims to compete with Netflix and Singtel's Hooq. An initial public offering (IPO) on the Nasdaq is reportedly planned within the next two years, further solidifying its presence in the region.

site_title: India's budget was no big bang event, but it is still pro-growth
summary: India's budget presented by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley on February 28, 2015, aimed to revive the country's $2 trillion economy over the next five years. The budget allocated $114 billion for infrastructure development, including roads and rail projects, and set a target of building 100,000 kilometers of all-weather roads. The government also announced plans to reduce corporate tax to 25% over four years, increase revenue sharing with states to 42%, and provide funds for micro and small businesses. The budget was deemed pro-growth, despite lacking major tax reliefs and reform-linked announcements.

site_title: How much control should you have over your firm?
summary: A family firm's ownership structure is crucial in determining its performance and behavior. Four key challenges to consider when designing an ownership structure include retaining control while growing, the pyramid effect, refusing to share and share alike, and the power of numbers. To overcome these challenges, families can use mechanisms such as pyramidal structures, dual-class shares, cross-ownership, and voting caps to concentrate control in the hands of family members. However, as the family grows, ownership is diluted, and a family board or internal market for buying and selling family shares may be necessary to manage conflicting interests.

site_title: EU capital markets plan lacks investor protection: UK official
summary: The European Union's capital markets plan aims to boost market-based financing, but a top UK regulator warns that it lacks investor protection. Martin Wheatley, chief executive of Britain's Financial Conduct Authority, says the plan's focus on growth over consumer protection risks harming investors. He advocates for a balance between growth and protecting investors, particularly in emerging sectors like crowd funding. Failing to address consumer protection could lead to damaging stories of investor loss and harm the industry's growth potential.

site_title: Modi's US$1t infrastructure plan revives tax-free rail debt
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has announced that tax-free bonds will be allowed for rail, road, and irrigation projects, starting April 1, to cut borrowing costs for a $1 trillion infrastructure development push. The move aims to support the country's economic expansion, which is forecast to reach 8-8.5% next year. The government plans to spend $187.3 billion on upgrading its antiquated rail network over the next five years, with a 700 billion rupee increase in infrastructure spending in the coming fiscal year.

site_title: FDA clears first ever 'biosimilar' drug, paves way for cheaper drugs
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved the first biosimilar drug, Zarxio, produced by Sandoz, to prevent infections in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. Zarxio is a close copy of the existing medication Neupogen, made by Amgen, and is expected to be significantly cheaper, with some estimates suggesting a 90% discount. The approval paves the way for less expensive alternatives to complex and costly biologic drugs, which could save US$5.7 billion in drug costs over the next 10 years. The decision marks a significant milestone for the US healthcare system and could lead to greater competition and lower prices for biologic drugs.

site_title: Iron ore giants to boost supply despite surplus
summary: Global iron ore supplies are expected to increase by 60-75 million tonnes in 2015, driven by expansions in Australia and Brazil, which will offset China's mine closures. Net supplies will rise to 75 million tonnes, with prices expected to fall to a five-year low of around US$30 per tonne. Major producers, including Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton, and Vale, are investing billions to boost low-cost output, despite a record surplus. The glut is projected to surge to 437 million tonnes by 2018, with prices averaging US$58-66 per tonne this year.

images.alt_text: Rio Tinto Group and BHP Billiton Ltd in Australia and Brazil's Vale SA invested billions to raise low-cost output even as prices fell to a five-year low, seeking to boost sales and force less competitive rivals to close.

site_title: Plans for new Iskandar project unveiled (Amended)
summary: Australian developer Walker Corporation and investment firm Wang & Wong Pte Ltd have unveiled plans for Senibong Hills, a 16-hectare site in Iskandar, Malaysia, with over 55 landed homes and 1,800 high-rise apartments. The project is expected to start with landed homes priced at RM1.88-2.3 million (S$700,000-860,000) and will be followed by high-rise apartments at RM550 psf. The joint venture aims to mitigate the "perception of over-supply" in Iskandar by launching landed homes first, with a strategy to cater to buyers seeking owner-occupation and offering amenities and design.

site_title: Goldman faces threat to crucial profit source after stress test
summary: Goldman Sachs faces uncertainty after performing poorly in the Federal Reserve's stress tests, which could limit its ability to buy back shares or increase dividends. Analysts warn that the bank could earn 42 US cents a share less than expected this year, and US$1.78 a share less than expected next year. The Fed's decision on Goldman's buyback plans is expected on Wednesday, with some analysts suggesting the bank could propose actions to increase shareholder distributions.

site_title: Petronas' RM7.3b quarterly loss deepens Malaysia's fiscal risk
summary: Malaysia's national oil company Petronas reported an unexpected RM7.3 billion loss in the last quarter, deepening the country's fiscal risk. This loss adds to existing concerns, with the Bank of America Merrill Lynch maintaining its deficit forecast of 3.8% of GDP. Petronas' dividend payouts are also expected to decrease. Malaysia's revised budget projection is 3.2% of GDP, and a second revision is now possible, increasing the odds of a revised budget.

images.alt_text: The odds are rising that Malaysia will need a second revision to its Budget, now that national oil company Petronas has posted an unexpected RM7.3 billion loss in the last quarter.

site_title: Too few women at the top, says Clinton-Gates report
summary: A report by Hillary Clinton, Melinda Gates, and Chelsea Clinton found that women are still far from achieving equality in leadership positions. Despite progress in health and education, women hold fewer than 30% of lawmaker positions and are underrepresented in cabinet posts, especially in defense and finance ministries. Women CEOs of top Fortune 500 companies are also underrepresented, with only 5% holding the position. The report highlights the need for continued action to achieve gender equality, particularly in politics and the economy.

site_title: Sino Construction rebound rests on transformation success
summary: Sino Construction's shares plummeted 76% in two days after a failed fund-raising plan, wiping out three-quarters of its market value. The company had been transforming from a construction business to an energy conglomerate, but was unable to secure cornerstone investors for its equity-linked bonds. The collapse came after an unexpected profit warning, a month-long delay in financial results, and the resignation of several directors. Despite this, management remains committed to its plans, and a renewable power generation business is expected to start generating profits by mid-April.

site_title: Russian probe focuses on Chechen suspect as Nemtsov killer
summary: Russian investigators are focusing on Zaur Dadaev, a Chechen suspect, as the possible organizer and triggerman in the murder of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. Dadaev, a former police officer, admitted involvement in the killing. The Kremlin-backed Chechen leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, linked the killing to the reaction to international support for Charlie Hebdo, but Nemtsov's allies dismissed this attempt to link Islamists to his death. The investigation is ongoing, with the Kremlin pledging to bring the killers to justice.

site_title: Malaysian task force formed to tackle 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysia's Inspector General of Police Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar formed a task force to investigate allegations of misconduct in 1MDB, a state-owned investment fund. The task force, comprising the police, Attorney-General's Chambers, and Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission, will investigate any reported misconduct, including allegations against Prime Minister Najib Razak. Najib had previously assured that anyone found guilty of misconduct would face consequences, with the fund struggling to pay off over $11 billion in debt. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Greek reform proposals fall far short of commitments, say EU officials
summary: Greek officials' reform proposals fell short of commitments, raising doubts about the country's access to EU aid funds. Eurozone officials stated that Greece's latest proposals, including hiring non-professional tax collectors, were "far" from complete, potentially delaying an aid disbursement this month. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis hinted at a referendum if the country's creditors raise unacceptable demands, while Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras navigates a tightrope between sticking to his election pledges and avoiding default.

site_title: Russia's investment grade status shielded by its reserves and fast reaction: Fitch
summary: Russia's investment-grade status is being shielded by its massive reserves and swift response to economic woes, according to Fitch Ratings. The country's foreign currency debt remains investment-grade despite plunging oil prices and sanctions. Fitch may review its "BBB-" rating next month, but senior director Paul Rawkins believes Russia's strong starting position and reserves will support its investment-grade status. The economy is forecast to contract 4.5% this year and 1% in 2016, but Rawkins warns of a slow-burn situation and potential negative rating triggers.

site_title: Tepid palm oil rebound expected
summary: Crude palm oil prices are expected to rebound in the medium term, offering investors a buying opportunity for plantation stocks. According to Dorab Mistry, director of Godrej International, the current low price environment provides a chance to invest in plantation stocks, which will benefit from a potential price hike in the next two years.

site_title: Osborne hoping to swing election with final budget
summary: Britain's finance minister George Osborne is set to announce his final budget on March 18, aiming to bolster Prime Minister David Cameron's re-election prospects. The budget is expected to show a record low inflation, resulting in an estimated £3 billion windfall, which could give the government room for manoeuvre. Osborne is likely to announce some rare good news on the country's budget deficit, but will avoid expensive gifts to voters, instead opting for targeted measures to help low earners.

images.alt_text: Mr Osborne is likely to look for more targeted ways of helping voters.

site_title: Fewer plane accidents in 2014 but death toll trebles: Iata report
summary: The 2014 global jet accident rate was the lowest in commercial aviation history, with one accident for every 4.4 million flights. However, the year saw a significant increase in fatalities, with 12 fatal accidents resulting in 640 deaths, more than tripling the 210 deaths in 2013, according to the International Air Transport Association (Iata) safety report.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sprawling GCB site at Ridout Road on the market
summary: A 73,277 sq ft freehold Good Class Bungalow redevelopment site at 35 Ridout Road in Singapore's District 10 is on the market for S$88 million, or around S$1,200 per square foot. The site can be subdivided into four smaller plots, making it attractive to high net worth individuals and developers. The property is located in a tranquil environment but is close to Dempsey Hill and Orchard Road shopping belt. It is zoned for residential use and is within a GCB enclave, making it a rare opportunity for buyers.

site_title: Bailout of Sharp seen paring profits at Mizuho, Mitsubishi UFJ
summary: Bailout of Sharp Corp, a Japanese electronics manufacturer, threatens to dent profits of Mizuho Financial Group Inc and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc, the largest lenders. A write-off of loans into equity could reduce Mizuho's full-year recurring income by 17% and Mitsubishi UFJ's by 5%. The move comes as Sharp faces a 30 billion yen loss and a credit downgrade to CCC+, with default risk reaching a 22-month high. The banks' profits are strong, making the write-off a manageable loss, with Mitsubishi UFJ reporting consecutive quarters of operating profits over 500 billion yen.

site_title: Sibor jumps to 0.836% on further US dollar strength
summary: The three-month Sibor rate in Singapore jumped to 0.836% on Monday, driven by continued US dollar strength, with a 115% increase from its 2014 low. The US dollar rallied after stronger jobs growth data, leading to a 4.09% increase against the Singapore dollar. Analysts predict the Sibor rate could reach 1% by the end of 2015 and the US dollar could reach S$1.40 by the third quarter. Experts anticipate further adjustments to Asian FX and interest rates as the US Federal Reserve prepares to tighten monetary policy.

site_title: When there's trouble at the family mill, call in the CEO
summary: A family-owned business can benefit from having a Chief Emotional Officer (CEO) to manage emotional dimensions and ensure a smooth transition. Family conflicts can threaten a company's commercial prospects, but a well-planned family strategy can mitigate this risk. Research shows that family-controlled businesses outperform public companies, and their owners often prioritize long-term success over short-term gains. Effective succession planning, emotional professionalism, and parallel planning for both the family and business are key to success. Companies like Wates Group and the Romav Group demonstrate that family owners can balance business and family influence, leading to long-term success and community responsibility.

site_title: TPP may yet prove to be good for health care
summary: Trade negotiators in Hawaii are finalizing the Trans Pacific Partnership, a free trade agreement involving the US, Canada, Australia, and several Latin American and Asian countries. Despite concerns that the deal will harm human health by limiting access to cheap generic drugs, many of the prescription drugs prescribed in middle-income Asia are off-patent, and the US has committed to respecting flexibilities allowing countries to ignore intellectual property rules in health emergencies. A successful conclusion to the deal is expected to promote economic growth, create new jobs, and raise living standards, ultimately benefiting health care systems in participating countries.

site_title: Weak start to week after Wall Street plunge
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 12.94 points to 3,404.57 on Monday, mirroring Wall Street's decline after a strong US jobs report raised concerns of earlier interest rate hikes. Blue chips Singtel and CapitaLand led the decline, while Noble Group's shares fell 0.055. Despite this, some analysts remained optimistic, including Maybank Kim Eng's call to "buy" Hongkong Land, citing a 32% discount to its RNAV. In the US, stocks fell after the jobs report, with the Federal Reserve potentially raising interest rates sooner rather than later, according to Bank of Singapore's chief economist.

site_title: Labour market to tighten further, but help will be available
summary: Singapore's labour market is expected to tighten further over the next decade due to slower local employment growth and strict foreign-worker caps. Despite local employment growth of 95,000 in 2014, it is expected to slow dramatically, with only 20,000 jobs created annually by 2025. The government will develop Singaporeans through the SkillsFuture initiative and introduce measures to encourage the retention of higher-skilled foreign workers. To help businesses remain competitive, the government will also raise the productivity of the foreign workforce and introduce policies to encourage the retention of skilled workers in the process sector.

site_title: Gudang Garam family member pays top notch price for Pagoda St shophouses
summary: A member of the Gudang Garam family bought two adjoining shophouses on Pagoda Street in Singapore's Chinatown for S$20 million, translating to S$3,500 per square foot based on the estimated built-up area of 5,700 sq ft. The 999-year leasehold properties currently generate a combined rental income of S$30,000 a month, reflecting a 1.8% gross yield. Industry watchers consider the price steep, with typical yields ranging from 3-4% for similar properties. The buyer plans to renovate and increase rents, citing the property's high footfall in a prime location.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: SingPost invests US$1.1m in e-commerce JV
summary: SingPost has invested US$1.1 million in a joint venture with Indonesian mobile phone retailer Trikomsel to import and supply goods to online retailers in Indonesia. The venture aims to sell customizable e-commerce solutions to international and Indonesian brands. SingPost will own 33% of the joint venture, while Trikomsel holds 67%. The move is part of SingPost's strategy to strengthen its e-commerce foothold in the region, with Indonesia expected to become the third-largest consumer base in the world.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse loses tussle over NYSE merger
summary: Deutsche Boerse AG has lost a European Union court challenge against the veto of its $9.5 billion merger with NYSE Euronext, which would have created the world's biggest exchange. The EU General Court in Luxembourg rejected the company's arguments that the merger would have led to "efficiency gains" and that the European Commission's market definition was too narrow. The commission had blocked the deal in 2012, citing concerns that it would have created a "near-monopoly" in European exchange-traded derivatives, causing significant harm to worldwide users of European financial derivatives and the European economy.

site_title: Noble seeking commitments on increased US$3b refinancing
summary: NOBLE Group is seeking a US$3 billion refinancing, increasing its initial request from US$2 billion, to refinance debt due in May. The commodities trader has asked banks to commit US$150 million each on a one- and three-year loan. The refinancing will replace a US$2 billion 364-day revolving credit and a US$2.36 billion multi-tranche loan, both signed in 2012 and 2014. Noble is expected to finalize the terms within a couple of weeks.

site_title: IRAS on alert for attempts to escape tax using shell set-ups
summary: Singapore's tax authority, IRAS, will monitor high-income earners for setting up shell companies to avoid higher personal income taxes. The government has raised income taxes for the rich, with rates up to 22% starting in 2017. IRAS will step up audit programs to detect and deter tax avoidance and evasion. Meanwhile, the government aims to create a more progressive tax system through property taxes, and has seen SMEs winning more government tenders, with 80% of contracts going to SMEs in the past two years.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister of State for Transport and Finance Josephine Teo also pointed to the use of property taxes to create a more progressive tax system.

site_title: GM strikes deal with investor, agrees to US$5b buyback
summary: General Motors (GM) has agreed to buy back $5 billion in shares by the end of 2016 after reaching an agreement with activist investor Harry J Wilson. Wilson had requested a board seat and asked for the company to use some of its cash to buy back $8 billion in shares. GM will also adopt a strategy to return free cash flow to shareholders while maintaining investment grade credit and a minimum balance of $20 billion.

site_title: Rousseff asks Brazilians to back austerity plan
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff urged citizens to support austerity measures to combat the country's economic woes, citing a global slowdown and drought. The plans, which include cutting government spending and tax breaks, aim to reduce a gaping deficit and maintain Brazil's investment grade rating. Rousseff expects the economy to recover by the end of this year, but her popularity has been hurt by the multibillion-dollar Petrobras scandal and economic slump.

site_title: S-E Asian banks edge out global rivals in regional share sales
summary: S-E Asian banks, including Maybank, DBS, and CIMB, have edged out global rivals in managing regional stock sales, capitalizing on corporate banking relationships and bigger balance sheets. They ranked among the top five arrangers for South-east Asia's US$24.1 billion of equity and equity-linked deals in 2014, with Maybank ranking second and DBS advising on a US$800 million IPO. The banks' increased assets have boosted their capacity to attract deals, with combined assets rising 96% since 2009.

site_title: Technology startups find fertile ground in Gulf states
summary: The UAE and other Gulf Arab nations are fostering entrepreneurship to diversify away from oil, with the "year of innovation" declared in 2015. Local tech startups are gaining traction, with the Gulf Cooperation Council countries providing funding and support for entrepreneurs. However, obstacles such as finance, regulatory requirements, and cultural barriers remain. The goal is to create jobs and reduce public spending, as the region faces a rapidly rising youth population and declining oil prices.

site_title: Job growth for Hispanics outpacing others in US
summary: US job growth has outpaced other groups, with Hispanics experiencing a 5% increase in employment over the past 12 months, surpassing blacks (3.8%) and whites (1.4%). This growth is largely attributed to a rebound in the construction industry, which has created 315,000 jobs for Hispanics, mostly in four states with high Latino populations. A decline in illegal immigration has also contributed to lower Hispanic unemployment, with enforcement efforts and improved economic conditions in Mexico reducing the incentive to emigrate.

images.alt_text: Of all the country's major racial and ethnic groups, only Hispanics, as of late last year, had returned to their unemployment levels before the recession.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages SMRT and Dairy Farm International have maintained "buy" ratings, with updated forecasts for SMRT due to expected expansion and training for staff, and Dairy Farm's positive growth outlook. SMRT's target price is lowered to S$1.85, while Dairy Farm's target price remains at US$11.20. Sino Grandness has been ceased from coverage by Maybank Kim Eng Research due to a substantial decline in its share price.

images.alt_text: SMRT's trains experienced five disruptions over the past two weeks across the North-South Line (NSL), East West Line (EWL), Circle Line (CCL), and Bukit Panjang LRT Line.

site_title: China lets local governments swap debt into municipal bonds
summary: China has allowed regional authorities to swap high-yielding debt into municipal bonds, potentially reducing interest payments by up to 50 billion yuan a year. The move aims to cut financing costs on liabilities estimated to be over $3 trillion, helping to boost spending while addressing concerns about local-government debt. The swap will allow borrowers to extend maturities and reduce market worries over refinancing risks, but some economists warn it may distort market order and unfairly burden investors.

site_title: Shipping magnates stand in contrast to Greece's troubles
summary: Greece's shipping industry continues to dominate the global market, with the country's fleet valued at $106 billion, accounting for 19% of the world's tankers. Billionaires John Angelicoussis, George Prokopiou, Peter Livanos, and George Economou control a combined fortune of $7.6 billion, with Angelicoussis' family stake valued at $2.4 billion. Despite the industry's success, Greece faces economic and political turmoil, with 36% of the population at risk of poverty or exclusion from social benefits. The shipping industry's privileged tax status has come under scrutiny, with the government seeking to boost revenue through increased taxation.

site_title: Sony to cut 1,000 jobs at Swedish mobile division
summary: Sony is cutting 1,000 jobs at its Swedish mobile division, reducing its workforce from 2,200 to 1,200 employees. The move is part of a restructuring plan to drag the mobile division out of the red, with a total of 2,100 jobs to be cut by March 2016, representing about 30% of its workforce. The Swedish mobile unit will focus on research and development, customer support, and software engineering in the Lund factory.

site_title: Blood gold flows illegally from Central African Republic
summary: In Central African Republic, Seleka rebel group controls territory in gold and diamond-producing regions, fueling a conflict that has killed at least 3,000 people and displaced 2.5 million. The group demands illegal taxes and fees from miners, who are forced to sell their production to middlemen buyers and smuggle it out of the country. The country's gold production has dropped to 95% of its pre-war levels, with an estimated 30% of diamonds also being secretly exported.

site_title: Apple's watch won't bring salvation for gold bugs
summary: Apple's new gold-plated watch has sparked speculation that it could drive up the price of gold, with some analysts predicting the company could consume up to 756 metric tonnes of gold per year. However, estimates by analysts Gene Munster and others suggest this is unlikely, with Munster predicting Apple will only sell 10,000 of the priciest model and that the watch will not significantly impact the gold market. The actual amount of gold used in the watch and its price will also be crucial in determining its impact on gold prices.

site_title: Kaisa offers sharp haircut but milder than expected
summary: Kaisa Group Ltd, a Chinese developer, has proposed a debt restructuring plan that offers a severe but not extreme haircut for its bondholders, with implied reductions ranging from 50% to 100%. The plan, which includes extending maturity and slashing coupons, aims to avoid default and a proposed takeover by rival Sunac China Holdings Ltd. The company has $2.5 billion of offshore debt, with two interest payments due this month, and failure to secure an agreement could scupper its main lifeline.

site_title: Seattle passengers benefit as Delta, Alaska fight it out
summary: Delta and Alaska Airlines are competing for market share at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, leading to traffic congestion. The airport's growth is driven by the airlines' expansion into Asian and European markets. Locals often pick up arriving passengers on the departure level to avoid the traffic. The competition is fueling the airport's explosive growth, making it the 15th-largest airport in the US.

site_title: Greece has enough cash to pay second IMF loan tranche: sources
summary: Greece has sufficient cash to pay the second IMF loan installment, totaling 1.5 billion euros, set to be repaid on March 13, according to government and banking sources. This follows the successful payment of the first installment on Friday. Greece's cash reserves are dwindling as it reworks a bailout deal with European partners. The country still needs to pay the final two installments on March 16 and 20.

site_title: Bill Gross's fund at Janus posts first monthly outflow in February
summary: Investors pulled $18.5 million from Bill Gross's Janus Global Unconstrained Bond Fund in February, the first monthly outflow since he took over the portfolio in October. Gross, a former Pimco executive, resigned from Pimco in September to join Janus Capital Group Inc. This marks a significant change in Gross's investment strategy, which has raised concerns among investors.

site_title: Youth singers perform with pop star Jessie J
summary: Youth singers from arts training centre 10sq, many from financially-disadvantaged backgrounds, were invited on stage by pop star Jessie J during a sold-out concert at Marina Bay Sands. The 16 teens, who had previously performed a capella at a meet-and-greet session, sang along to Jessie J's song "Masterpiece" as part of the Singapore International Jazz Festival. The surprise performance was arranged through the integrated resort's corporate social responsibility programme and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, which supports music training for less-privileged youngsters.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Above: Jessie J with the youths from 10sq singing group at a meet-and-greet session organised by Marina Bay Sands.
Above: One of the teenagers gets a selfie taken with the chart-topping singer.

site_title: The danger in making pronouncements from numbers taken out of context
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang announced the country's GDP growth rate would be "around" 7% this year, down from 7.4% last year, sparking media reports of a slowdown. However, the actual growth rate is context-dependent, with a 7% increase in a $390 billion economy requiring $27 billion in additional output, compared to $840 billion needed in a $11.8 trillion economy. This highlights the diminishing marginal returns to investment and the unrealistic expectations of maintaining annual growth rates that were achievable 25 years ago.

site_title: Gaggan's modern Indian comes out tops
summary: Thailand's Gaggan restaurant has taken the top spot in Asia's Best 50 Restaurants list, surpassing last year's winner Nahm. Singapore's Restaurant Andre and Waku Ghin secured 5th and 9th places, respectively. The list, which includes five Bangkok restaurants and eight Japanese restaurants, highlights the growing influence of Asian cuisine. This year's winner, chef Gaggan Anand, praised the recognition of modern Indian cuisine, while Singapore's Andre Chiang expressed relief at maintaining his restaurant's position.

site_title: Oil rebounds from early drop on modest Cushing stock build
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday after a modest stock build at the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery point, easing concerns about record-high US crude inventories. The front-month US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude jumped 2% to $50.61 a barrel, while Brent crude gained 20 cents to $59.93 a barrel. Genscape reported a 157,000-barrel increase in oil stockpiles, contrary to market expectations. This data helped alleviate worries about US crude inventories reaching another record peak.

site_title: Square shifts its shape and identity
summary: Square, a six-year-old payments startup, has shifted its identity from a consumer-focused company to a service provider for small businesses. The company introduced Square Capital, a money-lending program, and promoted Square Cash, a smartphone app for sending money to debit accounts. Square's focus on data collection and processing has helped it gain a competitive advantage, but critics argue that its payments business is plagued by thin margins and high customer acquisition costs.
