To reach its $6 billion valuation, Square must continue to expand its customer base and capitalize on its data-driven merchant services.

images.alt_text: Square now wishes to be known as a company that builds services for small businesses, buttressed by the huge amount of data collected from the millions of credit card swipes that it processes daily.

site_title: ECB underwhelms on first day of quantitative easing
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing programme began on Monday, with small purchases sparking concerns about its ability to meet its 60 billion euro target. The euro plummeted to an 11.5-year low against the US dollar, and European stocks slumped, with investors taking profits from last week's gains. ECB officials acknowledge the purchases have been surprisingly small, and doubts remain about meeting the target. The programme's impact on core markets has been stronger, but the ECB faces challenges in finding domestic sellers, which could distort sovereign borrowing markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 15.22 points to close at 1,791.74. The index saw 2.14 billion lots valued at RM1.87 billion traded, with 273 gains and 544 losses.

site_title: In brief
summary: Genting Hong Kong sold a 2.7% stake in Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings for US$316.9 million, reducing its stake to 22.2%. Yongnam Engineering & Construction secured a S$159 million contract for the JTC Food Hub @ Senoko project. Triyards Holdings won deals worth over US$100 million, including a turret fabrication job. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank announced Helen Wong's retirement and named Tan Teck Long as her successor.

site_title: Consumers curb earnings expectations, New York Fed survey shows
summary: US consumers have reduced their expectations for wage increases, with median earnings growth over the next year falling to 2.2% from 2.5%. Expectations for inflation over the next year also decreased, while the probability of finding a job in the next three months has risen to 54.5%. Additionally, consumers have lowered their expectations for household spending over the next year, with a median projection of a 3.8% increase, the lowest in survey history.

site_title: Goldman says US$40 oil call may be too low as demand surprises
summary: Goldman Sachs has downgraded its US$40 oil forecast, citing stronger-than-expected demand and reduced global inventories. The bank attributes the surge in oil prices to weather-related disruptions and supply chain issues in Iraq and Libya, as well as increased US production. Goldman now predicts oil prices may miss its target for the next two quarters, with West Texas Intermediate crude potentially reaching $54 a barrel. The bank also warns that US producers will boost output later this year, undermining the market's re-balancing efforts.

site_title: Eurogroup head calls on Greece to stop wasting time, start reforms
summary: Eurozone finance minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem urged Greece to stop wasting time and start implementing reforms to complete its bailout program. Greece's new left-wing government must discuss reforms with creditors, as it faces financial constraints. Dijsselbloem stated that if Greece continues on the reform path, the eurozone will support it further. The Eurogroup meeting will discuss Greece's program and reforms, with the goal of restarting talks and implementing necessary changes.

site_title: HSBC boss says he is right person to run bank
summary: HSBC Chief Executive Stuart Gulliver defended his role as the bank's CEO, stating he is the right person to lead the revamp of Europe's biggest bank. He claimed to have successfully restructured the bank by cutting its size and reducing complexity. Gulliver denied evading tax, stating his personal tax affairs were in order, following media reports about HSBC's past failures in controlling Swiss private bank accounts.

site_title: Goldman sees decline in US crude prices
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts US crude oil prices will decline to around $40 a barrel in the near-term due to rising global inventories. The bank attributes this to sequentially weakening oil activity and the end of winter demand. Goldman also expects Brent oil prices to come under renewed pressure, with a forecast of a two-thirds drop in Asian LNG prices making the fuel competitive against oil in the industrial power sector. This forecast is seen as skewed to the downside, with Goldman expecting US oil prices to reach $65 a barrel in 2016.

site_title: IRAS to watch for tax evasion through 'corporatisation'
summary: Singapore's tax authority, IRAS, will closely monitor "corporatisation" trends where high-income earners set up companies to avoid higher income taxes. This trend poses a risk to Singapore's competitive tax edge. If tax evasion is found, IRAS will disregard corporate structures and assess individuals based on their income. The move aims to prevent high-income earners from exploiting the tax regime. The corporate tax rate in Singapore is 17%, with the recent income tax hike increasing the rate to up to 22% for the 2017 year of assessment.

site_title: What to watch for as Apple details reasons to buy smartwatches
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is set to address questions about the company's first smartwatch, which is expected to launch in April. Key points include the price range, starting at $349, and potential higher-end models costing upwards of $10,000. Battery life is also a concern, with estimates ranging from a full day to five days, depending on usage. Apple has been working with developers to create a range of apps, including health and fitness tracking, maps, and music control. The watch's rollout is expected to be broader than initially stated, with possible launches in countries such as Germany and Mexico.

site_title: Govt to launch shared e-commerce and HR platforms for SMEs
summary: Singapore's government plans to launch two platforms for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs): a shared e-commerce platform and an HR solutions platform. The platforms aim to help SMEs streamline operations and cut costs by 45%. The e-commerce platform will integrate warehouse functions and order-fulfilment capabilities, while the HR solutions platform will gather HR providers for SMEs to outsource administrative functions. The platforms are expected to have 50 companies enrolled each by April 1, with the goal of catching up with other countries in e-commerce.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Hong Kong fund Friedmann to lobby Greece for Athens airport sale
summary: Hong Kong-based fund manager Friedmann Pacific Asset Management Ltd plans to lobby Greece's new government to sell its majority stake in Athens International Airport, with the company expressing interest in purchasing the stake. Friedmann Pacific, which has already invested in a French airport, aims to add three to five more airports to its portfolio in the next few years. The move underscores Chinese companies' growing appetite for assets in struggling eurozone economies, as Greece seeks to kickstart the privatisation process after cancelling key terms of its bailout programme.

site_title: Oil drops towards US$59 on dollar, stock builds
summary: Brent crude oil fell to around US$59 a barrel on Monday as the dollar strengthened and global oil inventories reached record highs. The US unemployment rate fell, making commodities priced in the dollar more expensive for other currencies. Oil producers in Opec chose not to cut output to support prices, instead defending market share. Analysts predict oil prices will continue to drop due to rising inventories, with some forecasting US crude to reach around US$40 a barrel.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat after recent decline
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday after two weeks of declines, with the Dow Jones rising 4.53 points, the S&P 500 gaining 1.66 points, and the Nasdaq Composite adding 8.46 points. This follows the S&P 500's biggest one-day loss in about two months. Despite recent declines, the benchmark S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite are still near fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Yongnam unit wins S$159m JV contract
summary: A joint venture between Yongnam Engineering & Construction and Jian Huang Construction Co has won a S$159 million contract to build a seven-storey development in Singapore's JTC Food Hub @ Senoko. The project, expected to start in March and complete by mid-2017, will feature 50 modular factory units and an integrated coldroom-warehouse facility. The development will be operated by a third-party logistics service provider, offering services to Food Hub tenants. This project marks a significant milestone for Yongnam, reinforcing its capabilities and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Indonesia central bank governor, finance minister to hold Tuesday news conference on weak rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, finance minister, and chief financial regulator will hold a news conference on Tuesday to discuss the weakening rupiah, which fell 0.7% to a near 17-year low on Monday. The rupiah's decline is attributed to a stronger-than-expected US jobs data and expectations of a possible Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The news conference will focus on recent economic conditions, including the rupiah's performance.

site_title: Malaysia's anti-corruption commission willing to look at 1MDB: Bernama
summary: The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) is willing to investigate the accounts of 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) if irregularities or wrongdoing are found, according to MACC Chief Commissioner Abu Kassim Mohamed. The investigation would be based on a report from the Auditor General, which was instructed by Prime Minister Najib Razak to verify the accounts after criticism from 1MDB.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) would investigate the accounts of 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) if any indication of irregularities or wrongdoing are found, MACC Chief Commissioner Abu Kassim Mohamed told state news agency Bernama.

site_title: Singapore Budget Debate: Workforce and enterprise matters in focus
summary: Singapore's labor market is expected to tighten further, with local workforce growth slowing significantly in the second half of the decade. The government is working to extend the age of re-employment to 67, and businesses will need to adapt to a tight labor market by raising productivity and becoming more manpower-lean. Meanwhile, the government is introducing common platforms for small- and medium-sized enterprises to share resources and streamline processes. The government is also monitoring tax evasion by high-income earners, with a focus on 'corporatisation'.

site_title: ECB underwhelms on first day of QE
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) launched its quantitative easing (QE) programme on Monday, but market participants were left disappointed by the initial pace of purchases. The ECB aims to buy 60 billion euros per month, but initial purchases have been surprisingly small, with the average ticket size around 2 million euros. This has raised questions about how the bank will achieve its target.

site_title: Greek PM to meet EU chief on Friday
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to meet with EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker on Friday to discuss Greece's financial lifeline and potential reforms. The OECD will advise Athens on reform proposals, which include streamlining bureaucracy, raising revenue from online gambling, and hiring amateur tax sleuths. Eurozone finance ministers are discussing the proposals, with Greece warning of a possible referendum if they are rejected. The meeting comes as Greece faces a cash squeeze and seeks an alternative pain-free reform plan by April to persuade international creditors.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras will meet with EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker on Friday, his office said on Monday, hours ahead of key talks on Athens' financial lifeline.

site_title: Sony sacks 1,000 employees at Swedish mobile unit
summary: Sony is laying off 1,000 employees at its Swedish mobile unit, reducing its workforce from 2,200 to 1,200 employees. The company aims to cut 2,100 jobs, about 30% of its workforce, by March 2016 to improve its financial results, which lost $1.2 billion in the fourth quarter of 2014. The layoffs will primarily affect the research and development operations in Lund, Sweden, but the city will remain an important hub for software, systems engineering, and customer support.

site_title: Euro hits new 11.5-year dollar low as ECB starts QE
summary: The euro reached a 11.5-year low against the dollar, falling to $1.0823, after the European Central Bank announced a $1.1 trillion quantitative easing program to combat deflation. The move was seen as a response to concerns over Greece's reform plans and the euro's weakening due to expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate hike. The ECB's program is expected to keep the euro weak, with analysts predicting parity with the dollar in the coming weeks.

site_title: Palm drops as Feb output estimate beats expectations
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures fell to a near two-week low on Monday after planters' estimates showed steady palm output in February, countering expectations of a 3% drop. Total February crude palm oil output was forecast at 1.16 million tonnes, unchanged from January, with robust growth in Peninsular Malaysia offsetting poor yields from Borneo regions. The benchmark May contract closed down 0.7% at RM2,269 a tonne, despite foreign buying due to a weaker ringgit.

site_title: Platts considers Malaysia's Pengerang terminal in pricing process
summary: Oil pricing agency Platts is considering a proposal to reflect deliveries from Malaysia's Pengerang Terminal in its Singapore pricing assessments, starting from July 1. This move aims to offer traders more flexibility in loading cargoes and improve market liquidity. The Pengerang Terminal, which started operations last year, has six berths and an initial storage capacity of about 1.3 million cubic meters. The change will introduce free-on-board Straits benchmarks to replace the existing FOB Singapore benchmark, allowing traders to load cargoes from approved terminals in either Singapore or south Malaysia.

site_title: Oil drops towards US$59 on dollar, stock builds
summary: Brent crude oil fell towards $59 a barrel on Monday as the dollar strengthened and global oil inventories reached record highs. The US unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since 2008, making commodities more expensive for holders of other currencies. Oil producers in OPEC chose not to curb output, defending market share rather than supporting oil prices. Goldman Sachs analysts forecast US crude to drop to around $40 a barrel, citing rising global inventories and a supply glut.

site_title: Eurozone property stocks tumble as ECB driven rally questioned
summary: Eurozone property stocks plummeted by 1.8% as investors questioned a 25% rally since December, driven by the European Central Bank's money-printing. Despite low interest rates, property values lag behind the equity market, trading at a 17% premium to net asset value. Analysts downgraded five stocks, citing better value in the UK, where real estate shares fell 1.3% amid concerns of a US rate increase. The sector's rally is seen as financially driven, posing risk to its longer-term prospects.

site_title: Malaysia Jan factory output growth seen steady at 7.4% year-on-year: poll
summary: Malaysia's January factory output is expected to have grown 7.4% year-on-year, supported by a lower base in the same month of 2014. This growth was partly driven by the manufacturing, mining, and electricity sectors. However, January's exports fell 0.6% due to weakened sales to China, while imports dropped 5.3%, resulting in a trade surplus of RM9.01 billion.

site_title: ECB, euro central banks begin buying bonds
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) and euro area central banks have started buying bonds as part of a purchase programme to kick-start inflation in the single currency area. The ECB announced the start of purchases under the Public Sector Purchase Programme via Twitter, with German Bundesbank confirming it was active in the market since 9:25 am. The programme aims to stimulate inflation and was long-awaited, but further details on the amounts and types of bonds being purchased were not immediately available.

site_title: China to allow local govts to swap 1t yuan of expensive debt
summary: China will allow local governments to convert up to 1 trillion yuan ($220.7 billion) in high-interest debt to lower-interest bonds, easing their massive debt burden without crippling the broader economy. The move aims to relieve pressure on local government finances, which have been strained due to surging debt and a crackdown on short-term financing. The conversion will lower the local government debt burden by around 400 million yuan per year, providing relief and capital for other expenditures. This move follows China's efforts to manage its massive local government debt, estimated around $3 trillion.

images.alt_text: China will let local governments convert up to 1 trillion yuan (S$220.7 billion) in debt to lower interest bonds as it seeks ways to ease their massive debt burden without crippling the broader economy.

site_title: Airlines need to improve despite 'safest' year: IATA chief
summary: IATA chief Tony Tyler stated that last year was the safest ever for commercial aviation despite high-profile incidents like the disappearance of MH370, resulting in 641 fatalities in 12 accidents. The rate of fatalities per flight dropped to its lowest point on record. The industry is working on new technologies, including improved flight tracking, to enhance safety. Despite this, flying remains the safest way to travel, with "hull losses" averaging 0.23 per million flights.

images.alt_text: Last year was the safest ever for commercial aviation despite high-profile incidents such as the disappearance of Flight MH370, but the industry is still working on new technologies to improve its record, IATA chief said Monday.

site_title: Gold gains as dimmed outlook for Greece aid boosts haven appeal
summary: Gold prices rose amid concern over the potential collapse of a Greek aid agreement, boosting demand for haven assets. Eurogroup Chairman Jeroen Dijsselbloem stated the Greek government's proposed measures were "far" from complete, increasing uncertainty. This followed a 5.2% drop in February after euro-area finance ministers approved Greece's economic package. The metal erased its 2015 gains and slid the most since December 2013 due to a low US jobless rate, which may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Gold prices rose despite a bearish outlook due to uncertainty surrounding the Greek aid agreement.

site_title: EU court upholds blocking of Deutsche Boerse/NYSE Euronext merger
summary: The European Union's General Court upheld a 2012 decision by the European Commission to block a merger between Deutsche Boerse and NYSE Euronext, citing concerns it would create a "near monopoly" in European financial derivatives. The court rejected Deutsche Boerse's arguments that the merger could have benefited customers and that concessions made by the companies were sufficient. The Commission's definition of the relevant market was deemed too narrow, with the court ruling that the merger would have maintained significant competition in the market.

site_title: Air travel "safer" in 2014 despite Malaysian disasters: IATA
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) reported that 2014 was the safest year in commercial aviation history, despite two major crashes involving Malaysia Airlines, resulting in hundreds of fatalities. There were 12 fatal accidents in 2014, a record low, with an accident rate of 0.23 per 1 million flights. IATA's director general, Tony Tyler, attributed the improvement in safety to the industry's focus on safety, despite the tragic events. The organization is also exploring new technologies to improve real-time tracking of aircraft, with a proposed system to be implemented by 2016.

site_title: All eyes on Apple's Cook as Watch launch expected
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is expected to announce details of the Apple Watch, a wearable device that wirelessly ties to an iPhone, measures heart rate, and signals new messages or appointments. The watch, priced at $349, is set to launch in April. Analysts estimate Apple could sell 10-32 million watches in 2015, a potential market game-changer. The company has not confirmed the event, but Cook is scheduled to take the stage on Monday in a presentation titled "Spring Forward."

site_title: OECD: Eurozone growth gaining pace, others stable
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) reported that the eurozone is contributing to an improvement in global economic growth prospects, with its leading indicator rising to 100.7 from 100.6. Most other major economies, including the US, Japan, China, and India, maintained stable growth momentum. However, Russia's reading fell to 99.3, and Brazil and India's readings edged higher but then fell. The eurozone countries, particularly Germany, France, and Italy, also showed positive changes in their growth momentum.

site_title: Sibor jumps to 0.836% on US$ strength
summary: The 3-month Sibor in Singapore jumped to 0.836% on Monday due to continued US dollar strength. This represents a 3% increase from last Friday and a 115% increase from its 2014 low of 0.389%. The US dollar's rally, fueled by stronger jobs growth data, has seen it rise 4.09% against the Singapore dollar year-to-date.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary:

The UK economy shrank for the second month, while South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast.

site_title: Singapore: STI ends lower, no surprises as US rate worries take their toll
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 12.94 points to 3,404.57 on Monday, March 9, 2015, amid US rate worries. The decline was driven by weak Wall Street performance after a strong February jobs report raised interest rate concerns. Blue chips like Singtel and CapitaLand contributed to the fall, while Noble Group's slide also weighed on the index. The session saw short-covering efforts, but ultimately ended with a loss of 10 points.

site_title: Taiwan Feb exports disappoint, but cheaper imports may help economy
summary: Taiwan's exports fell 6.7% in February, exceeding expectations, due to the Lunar New Year holiday and weaker commodity prices. However, electronic goods exports rose 5.3%, and imports fell 22.4%, leading to improved terms of trade. This is expected to support the domestic economy, driven by strong global demand for smartphones and a recovering US economy. The falling import bill is also expected to increase corporate earnings and household income.

site_title: Japan companies cut investment at home even as cash on hand soars
summary: Japanese companies cut investment at home by 0.1% in the nine months through December, despite a record forecast profit and cash reserves of nearly $1.9 trillion. This marks the third straight quarter of declines, contradicting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies. Economists attribute the decision to low-potential growth, with some companies shifting production back home due to the weak yen. The Bank of Japan has urged companies to invest in facilities and workers, but few appear to have taken heed, highlighting structural problems in the Japanese economy.

site_title: First round-the-world solar flight takes off from UAE
summary: The Solar Impulse 2, a solar-powered plane, took off from Abu Dhabi on March 9, 2015, beginning a five-month, 35,000 km journey around the world. The mission aims to promote sustainable energy and reduce dependence on fossil fuels. The plane, weighing as much as a family car, has a wingspan similar to a passenger airliner and will make stopovers in India, Myanmar, China, the US, and southern Europe. The journey will be completed in approximately 25 flight days at speeds of 50-100 km/h.

site_title: Traditionally frugal Germans fuel economy with spending spree
summary: Germans are splurging on high-end items like kitchens and electronics, despite their traditionally frugal nature, due to low interest rates, falling unemployment, and rising pay. Sales of new kitchens have increased by over 10% at Haecker, while Michelin-starred restaurant Fischers Fritz saw a 10% surge in turnover. Economists predict continued spending growth, driven by low interest rates, labor market stability, and rising wages, with some forecasting a 2.1% economic expansion this year.

site_title: Gold struggles near 3-month low on firm dollar, US jobs data
summary: Gold prices edged up on Monday, but remained near a three-month low due to a strong US dollar and expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The dollar hit an 11-year high after a strong US jobs report boosted expectations of a rate hike. Analysts predict gold prices could drop to $1,141, citing a stronger dollar and weaker euro as factors. Demand for physical bullion may provide some support to prices, while uncertainty over the debt crisis in Greece could boost bullion.

site_title: Noble seeking commitments on increased US$3b refinancing
summary: Noble Group Ltd is seeking an increased US$3 billion refinancing to pay off debt due in May. The commodities trader has asked banks to commit US$150 million each on a one- to three-year loan. The company is still dealing with controversy over improper accounting practices. A term sheet is expected to be released imminently, with final terms to be finalized within a couple of weeks.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields fall on QE launch but Greece jitters resurface
summary: The European Central Bank launched its sovereign debt purchase programme, causing eurozone government bond yields to fall, with German 10-year bond yields dropping 4 basis points to 0.36%. However, Greek 10-year yields rose 8 basis points to 9.58% due to concerns over the European Union's rejection of reform proposals vital to unlocking new bailout cash. Other eurozone countries, including Italy and Spain, also saw lower yields, but lower-rated debt lagged the rally. The ECB's programme is expected to have a smooth start, but domestic investors' willingness to sell remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Most eurozone government bond yields fell on the first day of the European Central Bank's sovereign debt purchase programme, with only fears about Greece's funding spoiling Monday's launch party.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close 0.17% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares closed 0.17% lower on Monday, weighed down by expectations of a potential US interest rate hike. The Hang Seng Index fell 40.95 points to 24,123.05. Asian shares were also impacted by strong US jobs figures, which may prompt the US central bank to raise rates as early as the summer.

site_title: China's international payments system ready, could launch by year-end: sources
summary: China's long-awaited international payment system, the China International Payment System (CIPS), is ready and may be launched as early as September or October, according to sources. The system will process cross-border yuan transactions, reducing transaction costs and processing times, and increase global usage of the Chinese currency. China has selected 20 banks for testing, with 13 being Chinese banks and the rest foreign bank subsidiaries. The system's launch was delayed from 2014 due to technical problems, but authorities aim to have the first phase online by the end of the year.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall early, tracking drop on Wall Street
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Monday, tracking a 1.4% drop on Wall Street following strong US jobs data and expectations of a possible interest rate hike. German exports declined by the largest amount since August, while China's imports slid. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed at 1,562.39 points.

site_title: Kaisa to cut offshore bond coupons in second restructuring
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd. is seeking to trim obligations on 17 billion yuan of offshore debt through a restructuring plan, which would cut coupon payments and defer repayment by five years. The plan, conditional on a satisfactory debt restructuring, would see offshore creditors recover just 2.4 cents on the dollar, while bondholders may be forced to accept the proposal due to the risk of a liquidation scenario. The move comes as Kaisa's liquidity continues to deteriorate, with cash collections from property sales dropping significantly, and the company's total cash balance decreasing.

site_title: Bank of France cuts French Q1 growth forecast to 0.3%
summary: The Bank of France has revised its Q1 growth forecast for the French economy to 0.3%, down from an earlier 0.4%. The central bank's business sentiment indicator showed a slight cooling in February, while sentiment in the services sector rose. President Francois Hollande's government expects 1.0% growth this year, despite concerns about a tentative recovery.

images.alt_text: The French economy is on course to grow 0.3 per cent in the first quarter, the Bank of France said in its latest business survey on Monday, revising down its forecast from an earlier 0.4 per cent.

site_title: Singapore looking at extending re-employment age to 67 in two to three years' time: Amy Khor
summary: Singapore is considering extending the re-employment age to 67 in 2-3 years, with incentives to encourage employers to re-employ beyond 65. Currently, employers must re-employ employees up to 65 after they turn 62. The government cites a 40% employment rate among citizens aged 65-69, similar to advanced economies like Japan, as encouraging. Nearly 99% of private sector employees aged 62 were offered re-employment in 2014, with 91% maintaining their basic wages. The move aims to support older workers and boost the economy.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Jurong Aromatics completes maintenance at Singapore petchem complex
summary: Jurong Aromatics Corporation has completed maintenance at its 100,000 barrels per day petrochemical complex in Singapore, adding optimization and processing flexibility to the world-class plant. The temporary turnaround works, which started in December, have been completed, with rectification works on the xylene splitter also finished. Industry sources suggest operations may resume in the first half of April, but this has not been confirmed.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says export growth slower than expected
summary: South Korea's export growth is weaker than expected, according to Finance Minister Choi Kyung-hwan, who attributed the slowdown to structural problems accumulated over time. The economy is experiencing a fledgling recovery, but the pace and strength are weak. The minister emphasized the need for structural reforms to overcome the weakness and bolster the recovery.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.95%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.95% lower on Monday, influenced by weaker-than-expected Japanese growth data and a sharp drop on Wall Street last week. The Nikkei 225 index fell 180.45 points to 18,790.55, while the Topix index lost 0.59% to 1,531.76.

site_title: Higher budget estimates for People's Association is to help community bonding: Lim Swee Say
summary: Singapore's Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Lim Swee Say stated that the 51.3% increase in the People's Association's budget to over S$1 billion reflects the government's commitment to promoting social cohesion and racial harmony. The majority of the increase, S$239.3 million, will go towards developing facilities for residents' use.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: BOJ survey shows bond dealers feel market functioning impaired
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) conducted a survey of 40 financial institutions, finding that 65% believe the bond market is not functioning well, and 62.5% report bid-ask spreads are not very tight. This suggests that the BOJ's quantitative easing efforts may be having an impact on market functioning, despite the BOJ's goal of improving market conditions. The survey results may raise concerns about the effectiveness of the BOJ's monetary policies.

site_title: SGX opens derivatives office in HK to target Greater China
summary: SGX opens derivatives office in Hong Kong to expand its presence in the Greater China region, following the launch of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect trading link. This move aims to capitalize on the increased interest in its China A50 futures contracts. The office will provide a hub for SGX to better serve its clients in the region.

site_title: EU aides play down Greek reform plan, no early progress
summary: EU officials downplayed Greece's reform plan, calling it "far from complete" and saying it would take a long time to complete. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis threatened to call a referendum or hold early elections if creditors rejected the plan. A senior German politician suggested Greece would be better off outside the euro zone, while other EU leaders have stated their desire to keep Greece in the currency area. An opinion poll showed a majority of Greeks want a compromise deal with international lenders to avoid leaving the euro.

site_title: UBS China appoints Karen Chen as president
summary: UBS China appoints Karen Chen as president, effective immediately. Chen, who joined UBS in 2014, previously held senior positions at Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Standard Chartered Bank. As president, she will also be nominated as executive director and head of wealth management.

site_title: India's central bank to hold rates on April 7, ease gradually after that : poll
summary: The Reserve Bank of India is expected to hold interest rates on April 7, easing gradually over the coming year due to subdued inflation concerns. Economists polled by Reuters give a one-in-three chance of another rate cut in April. The RBI has already cut the repo rate to 7.50% in March, following a drop in crude oil prices and fears of deflation.

site_title: Taxpayer stake in Lloyds falls below 23%
summary: British taxpayers have recovered £8.5 billion from their £20 billion emergency investment in Lloyds Banking Group through a share sale, reducing their stake to under 23%. The sale, which took place at an average price of 73.6p per share, is part of the government's plan to return the bank to private ownership and reduce the national debt. The bank's dividend payment last week also marks progress in its transformation into a low-risk, customer-focused bank.

site_title: China: Stocks rise; surge in banks offset brokerage losses
summary: China's main stock indexes rose 1.7-1.9% on Monday, their largest gains in over a week, as banking stocks surged despite losses in brokerages. The Securities Regulatory Commission is considering issuing brokerage licenses to banks, potentially creating new revenue streams and intensifying competition. The CSI300 index rose 1.7% and the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.9%, while Shenzhen's ChiNext extended gains of 2%. Total A-share trading volume was 50.6 billion shares.

site_title: Singapore labour market will tighten further: MOM
summary: Singapore's labour market is expected to tighten further, with local workforce growth slowing significantly in the second half of this decade. Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin stated that the government will maintain a tight pace on foreign workforce growth. Local employment growth of 95,000 in 2014 is expected to drop to around 20,000 per annum in the last part of this decade due to baby boomers exiting the workforce and smaller cohorts entering. Businesses must adapt to the new reality and make fundamental changes to raise productivity.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Too few women at the top, says Clinton, Gates report
summary: A report by Hillary Clinton, Melinda Gates, and Chelsea Clinton found that women remain underrepresented in leadership positions, holding less than 30% of global lawmaker seats and 24% of finance or budget cabinet posts worldwide. Women CEOs in top Fortune 500 companies now represent 5%, while women on board seats vary from 8% in Portugal to 36% in Norway. Despite progress in health and education, women still face significant barriers to equality in politics and economics. The report highlights the need for continued action to achieve gender equality.

site_title: Thai PM says security must come first to boost foreign confidence
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha urged Thais to report suspicious activity to boost international confidence after a grenade explosion in Bangkok, the second in the capital in a month. Police detained three suspects, who claimed to have been hired for a 20,000 baht fee to carry out the attack. The suspects also claimed plans for further attacks were made to prompt UN intervention. The incident comes as Thailand remains under martial law, which has kept away some visitors and hindered efforts to rebuild foreign confidence.

site_title: Japan service sector sentiment improves in February
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index rose to 50.1 in February, up for a third straight month, according to a Cabinet Office survey. This improvement suggests a moderate recovery trend, contrary to the previous view that the economy was showing weakness. The outlook index also advanced to 53.2, indicating confidence in future conditions. The Cabinet Office described the economy as being in a moderate recovery trend, despite some weakness.

site_title: German trade surplus contracts on falling exports
summary: Germany's trade surplus contracted in January due to a 2.1% decline in exports, which fell to 96.3 billion euros. Imports decreased by 0.3% to 76.6 billion euros, leading to a seasonally adjusted trade surplus of 19.7 billion euros, down from 21 billion euros in December. This marks the first time the surplus has decreased in three months.

images.alt_text: A drop in German exports caused the country's trade surplus to contract in January, official data showed on Monday.

site_title: Japan economy's return to growth weaker than thought
summary: Japan's economy grew 0.4% in the final quarter of 2014, down from an initial estimate of 0.6% growth, according to revised government data. This weaker-than-expected data may pressure the Bank of Japan to launch more stimulus to boost the world's third-largest economy, which has struggled for two decades. Corporate capital investment also shrank, further indicating a weak recovery from recession.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines says expired battery on MH370 did not hinder search
summary: Malaysia Airlines says an expired battery in the "black box" flight data recorder of missing Flight MH370 did not hinder the search. The battery expired in December 2012, but the airline claims a similar beacon would have been transmitting for 30 days upon activation. This contradicts lawyers representing MH370 families, who say the expired battery could be key in any legal action against the airline. The search for the plane, which vanished in 2014, remains ongoing, with experts believing it crashed into the ocean off Australia.

site_title: China brokerages fall as regulator mulls letting banks compete
summary: China's securities regulator is considering allowing banks to enter the brokerage industry, potentially leading to increased competition and pressure on brokerages. Citic Securities and Shenwan Hongyuan Group fell 4.7% and 3.4% respectively, while Bank of Communications and Industrial Bank are likely to be among the first banks to take advantage of the opening. Analysts warn that this move will lead to cut-throat competition, threatening the business model of brokerages. No timetable has been set for the announcement of the new policy.

site_title: Seoul: Won hits 3-mth low as US jobs data keeps Fed in play, stocks drop
summary: South Korea's won hit a 3-month low due to a strong US jobs report, which raised expectations of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates sooner. The won fell 1.2% to 1,112.1 and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped 1% to a 1-1/2 week low of 1,992.82 points. Foreigners and institutions dumped 64.6 billion won and 176.2 billion won worth of local shares, respectively, contributing to the slump.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on commodities, US rate hike fears
summary: Australian shares fell 1.3% on Monday, their largest drop in nine weeks, due to concerns over a potential US interest rate hike and a record low in iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5821.3, its lowest close since February. The drop was attributed to large resources stocks, which weighed down the benchmark index after iron ore hit a record low following reports of Chinese steel mill closures.

site_title: Japan Q4 GDP revised down to +1.5% annualised
summary: Japan's gross domestic product (GDP) rose 1.5% annually in the October-December quarter, revised down from the initial 2.2% estimate. Capital expenditure declined 0.1% from the previous quarter, below expectations. The economy grew 0.4% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. The revised data contrasts with the median forecast of 2.2% annualized growth.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall as US jobs data stirs rate hike expectation; TSMC drags
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.76% on Monday, tracking regional bourses after strong US jobs data sparked interest rate hike expectations. The TSMC electronics sub-index fell 0.5%, while banking shares also dropped 0.5%. The Taiwan dollar declined 0.3% to T$31.545 to the US dollar. The US jobs data raised expectations of a potential interest rate hike sooner than previously expected, contributing to the regional market downturn.

site_title: With BMWs common in Gangnam, Koreans splurge on Bentleys, Maseratis
summary: In South Korea, a growing acceptance of conspicuous consumption is driving the sales of luxury cars, with Bentleys and Maseratis becoming popular among young, affluent Koreans. The trend is fueled by a rise in wealth and a desire to stand out in a traditionally conformist society, with some owners preferring to flaunt their status while others prefer discretion. The number of South Koreans with assets exceeding 1 billion won has doubled to about 167,000, and sales of imported vehicles priced above 100 million won (US$91,100) grew by a third in 2014.

site_title: Rupiah drops to lowest since 1998 as US jobs data boost dollar
summary: Indonesia's rupiah plummeted to its lowest level since 1998, falling 0.7% to 13,069 a dollar, after a US jobs report boosted the dollar and increased expectations of a US interest rate hike by June. The rupiah's decline is attributed to a stronger US economy and a surge in dollar strength, with Bank Indonesia seeing an undervalued exchange rate as beneficial for exports. The central bank's decision to lower interest rates in February has been questioned, with some predicting a rate cut this year.

site_title: China must restrict, record e-commerce firms breaking counterfeit rules: regulator
summary: China's commercial regulator, Zhang Mao, says e-commerce firms must be restricted and recorded for breaking counterfeit rules on their websites. Existing rules are deemed too lenient, and stricter punishments are needed to improve the market and eliminate fake goods. The regulator emphasized the need for cooperation between firms and the government to keep up with the growing e-commerce industry.

site_title: China money-market fund assets jump to US$351b, Fitch says
summary: China's money-market funds saw assets surge six-fold to US$351.3 billion in 18 months, driven mainly by retail investments in e-commerce funds. Retail investors accounted for 70% of total assets, while institutional investors are expected to drive growth at a slower pace. The People's Bank of China lowered interest rates to counter slow economic growth, leading to lower financing costs and higher money-market fund yields. The largest asset manager, Yu'E Bao, holds 26% of total assets. Fitch analysts predict continued growth in demand for Chinese money-market funds.

site_title: China: Shares down 0.52% in morning trade
summary: China's shares dropped 0.52% on Monday morning, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 16.88 points to 3,224.31. The decline was attributed to liquidity concerns, despite positive trade data over the weekend. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.52%, or 8.60 points, to 1,643.17.

site_title: UN chief calls on world to stop destruction of Iraqi sites
summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon condemned the destruction of Iraqi cultural sites by the Islamic State group, calling it a war crime. The group has bulldozed the ancient city of Nimrud, smashed artifacts in the Mosul museum, and is reportedly targeting the 2,200-year-old city of Hatra. Ban urged the international community to stop the destruction and hold perpetrators accountable. The UN Security Council had previously adopted a resolution to choke off financing for IS from antiquities trafficking and looted assets.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as US, commodities weakness prompt selling
summary: Australian shares fell by 1% on Monday, the largest decline in nine weeks, due to weak commodity prices and upbeat US jobs data. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 64.8 points to 5834.1. Iron ore prices hit a record low after Chinese steel mill closures, and energy stocks like Santos and Origin Energy also fell. The US Federal Reserve may raise interest rates sooner rather than later, prompting investors to bet on rate hikes.

site_title: Developers to launch 100 office units at GSH Plaza
summary: GSH Plaza, a 28-storey Central Business District building, is launching over 100 strata-titled office units with sizes ranging from 480 to 1,700 square feet. The units' average price is S$2,850 to S$3,500 per square foot, with a majority stake owned by GSH Corp.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC keeps 'buy' on SMRT, cuts target price
summary: OCBC Investment Research maintains its "buy" call on SMRT Corp, cutting its fiscal 2016 profit forecast by 10.5% to S$101.4 million due to expected fines from recent train disruptions. The broker lowered its target price to S$1.85 from S$1.90. The Land Transport Authority's unacceptable train disruptions raise the possibility of fines, affecting SMRT's profits.

images.alt_text: OCBC Investment Research has maintained its "buy" call on SMRT Corp, but lowered its forecast to account for expected fines from recent train disruptions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened down 18.00 points to 1788.96 on Monday, with losers outnumbering gainers 255 to 116. The country's shares were affected by market volatility.

site_title: Ringgit slides to six-year low on prospects for US rate rise
summary: Malaysia's ringgit slid to a six-year low against the US dollar due to speculation the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates by the end of June. The unemployment rate in the US fell to its lowest since 2008, boosting US Treasury yields and causing the ringgit to depreciate 0.9% to 3.6840 a dollar. China's imports slumped 20.5% in February, further weakening the ringgit. The decline in the ringgit is attributed to expectations of a US rate hike, which depresses the currency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.52% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.52% lower on Monday following weaker-than-expected Japanese growth data and sharp drops on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 98.04 points to 18,872.96. A strong US jobs report earlier in the week also impacted the market, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 falling 1.54% and 1.42% respectively.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Monday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) dipping 20 cents to $49.41 a barrel and Brent shedding 39 cents to $59.34. A stronger US dollar and concerns about swelling US inventories contributing to a global supply glut drove the decline. The US dollar's rally after a robust US jobs report also reduced demand for oil, with analysts predicting no respite for the oil market.

site_title: Asian stocks buckle under Fed rate hike expectations
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday, with Japan's Nikkei down 0.7% and MSCI's Asia-Pacific index dropping 0.5%. The US jobs data, showing 295,000 new jobs and a 5.5% unemployment rate, fueled expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike sooner than thought. Money market futures almost fully priced in a rate hike by summer, with some analysts predicting a possible June rate hike. The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen, while gold fell to a three-month low.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Genting HK, China Fishery, SingPost
summary: The Singapore market will open on Monday after a poor Wall Street outing, with strong US jobs data raising concerns about earlier-than-expected interest rate hikes. Genting Hong Kong will resume trading after announcing a $218.2 million gain from selling shares in Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings. China Fishery Group will hold an EGM on March 25 to seek shareholder approval for a rights issue. SingPost will invest $1.1 million in a 33% stake in an Indonesian e-commerce venture.

site_title: Singapore: STI takes early hit from Wall St's pre-weekend woes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 27.65 points, or 0.8%, to 3,389.86 on March 9, 2015, due to Wall Street's pre-weekend woes caused by strong US jobs data raising concerns of interest rate hikes. Noble Group and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust were the most active losers, with Noble Group down 2.4% and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust down 0.7%. The decline was largely attributed to the US market's reaction to the jobs data, which overshadowed the local market's performance.

site_title: UK crowdfunders face six-month wait to get licence: consultancy
summary: UK crowdfunding firms face a six-month wait to receive authorisation from the Financial Conduct Authority due to high scrutiny. Only two firms have been authorised in the past nine months, with 15 still awaiting approval. The FCA introduced a new regulatory framework last April to protect consumers, but the lengthy approval process poses a challenge for new businesses. The delay affects private investors seeking higher returns from crowdfunding platforms.

site_title: DBS, CIMB elbow out global rivals in share sales: South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asian banks, including DBS, CIMB, and Maybank, have surpassed global rivals in managing regional stock sales, capitalizing on corporate banking relationships and larger balance sheets. In 2014, these banks accounted for 22% of total deal flow, while global banks like Credit Suisse and UBS ranked lower. The growth is attributed to increased assets and long-lasting relationships, with combined assets boosted by 96% since 2009. This trend is expected to continue with economic growth in the region projected to reach 5% this year.

site_title: China overtakes North Korea as Japan's top security concern
summary: Japan's top security concern has shifted from North Korea to China, with over 60% of respondents citing China's military strength and assertiveness as a concern. The survey found a growing minority, 30%, favoring a military build-up, while 71.5% expressed interest in Japan's Self-Defense Forces. The shift in concern comes amid China's modernization of its military and tensions over disputed islands in the East China Sea. Japan and China are set to hold security talks on March 19, following a meeting between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Chinese President Xi Jinping in November.

site_title: 'Britain's white jihadi' a teen from Australia: report
summary: A teenager from Australia, identified as Jake, has been dubbed "Britain's white jihadi" after a photo surfaced of him with Islamic State group fighters. However, doubts about the image's authenticity led to its identification by friends and mosque members. Jake, a former high-achieving student, converted to Islam and traveled to Istanbul before joining the group in Iraq and Syria. His case highlights the growing concern of young people joining jihadist groups, with around 140 Australians traveling to fight with IS.

site_title: SingPost, Trikomsel in e-commerce JV
summary: SingPost and Indonesian mobile phone retailer Trikomsel formed a joint venture to develop an e-commerce business in Indonesia. SingPost holds a 33% stake, valued at US$1.1 million, while Trikomsel owns the remaining 67%. The joint venture aims to import and supply goods to e-commerce and online retailers, as well as provide e-commerce platform support.

site_title: Air strike on Islamic State-run refinery in Syria kills 30
summary: A US-led coalition air strike in Syria's Tel Abyad region killed 30 people, including refinery workers and Islamic State militants, near the Turkish border. The strike targeted an oil refinery run by the Islamic State group, which has been a major source of revenue for the militant organization. However, the Pentagon assesses that oil is no longer the main source of revenue due to air strikes and plummeting global oil prices.

site_title: Delicate balancing act
summary: Singapore is grappling with how to finance its future spending needs, with experts weighing the pros and cons of increasing direct or indirect taxation. Raising taxes, particularly on the top 5% of income earners, could generate S$400 million in revenue annually. However, experts caution against raising taxes, citing concerns over competitiveness and the impact on lower-income earners. Instead, they suggest focusing on sustainable economic growth, investing in skills and innovation, and implementing progressive tax policies to balance the nation's revenue streams.

site_title: US crude dips as Opec head says group should not cut output
summary: US crude futures decreased by 14 cents to $49.47 a barrel, settling down 2.3% from the previous session, amid a strengthening dollar and Opec's Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri's statement that the group should not cut output to "subsidise" higher-cost shale. The dollar's winning streak, fueled by a 6-1/2-year low US unemployment rate, made dollar-denominated crude more expensive.

images.alt_text: US crude futures eased on Monday as the dollar strengthened and after Opec's head said the group should not cut output to "subsidise" higher-cost shale.

site_title: Obama to announce training initiative for high-tech jobs
summary: US President Barack Obama will announce a training initiative for high-tech jobs, aiming to provide Americans with the skills needed to secure positions in the tech industry. The program will collaborate with local government leaders and national employers to expand access to tech jobs. With over 500,000 job openings in tech fields, the average salary is 50% higher than the average private-sector job in the US. The initiative is part of the administration's efforts to address the skills gap in the US workforce.

site_title: Genting HK to get US$317m net proceeds from Norwegian Cruise stake sale
summary: Genting Hong Kong will receive US$316.9 million in net proceeds from selling a 2.7% stake in Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings, a move that will reduce its stake in the cruise operator to 22.2%. The sale was made through Star NCLC Holdings and investment firm TPG Global, with the shares' current carrying value of US$98.6 million. The deal will result in a US$218.2 million gain for Genting Hong Kong.

site_title: Australia job advertisements rise for ninth month in Feb
summary: Australian job advertisements rose for the ninth consecutive month in February, reaching their highest in at least two years, with a 0.9% increase to 143,484 per week on average. Despite this, employment growth still lags behind the growing working population, leading to a gradual increase in the unemployment rate. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates to a record low of 2.25% in February, with expectations of further easing to 2% in April, amid concerns about a tepid economic growth outlook.

site_title: China takes lessons from Japan, past master on slowdown, deflation
summary: Chinese regulators are studying Japan's economic history to avoid a similar path of recession and deflation, which has plagued Japan for 20 years. China is learning from Japan's liberalization of capital flows and yen, as well as its handling of asset bubbles and bank bankruptcies. China is carrying out similar financial reforms, including liberalizing interest rates, internationalizing its currency, and opening up its capital account. Chinese policymakers aim to achieve domestic economic stability, prioritizing policy over international considerations, to mitigate the risk of financial imbalances and debt.

site_title: Hong Kongers protest cross-border visits as China eyes action
summary: Protesters in Hong Kong rallied against parallel traders, who buy goods in the city to sell in mainland China, driving up prices. The protests, the fourth week in a row, come amid concerns about safety and the influx of Chinese visitors overwhelming the city. The Chinese government has considered curbs on tourist arrivals, which could further impact Hong Kong's economy, which benefits from Chinese shoppers. Governor Guo Shuqing of Shandong province called for fewer tourists to visit Hong Kong, particularly for milk powder.

site_title: Diamond miners meet to discuss fake gems threat
summary: The world's largest diamond producers, including Anglo American and Alrosa, have formed the first-ever industry association to promote their interests and combat the threat of manmade stones entering the market. The group, which will have an initial budget of $6 million, aims to address issues such as diamond marketing, research, and consumer confidence. The association will formalize an industry response to questions from consumers and investors on the rise of manmade stones, following incidents of undisclosed mixing in India and other countries.

site_title: Putin describes secret operation to seize Crimea
summary: President Vladimir Putin revealed in a documentary trailer that he gave the secret order to seize Crimea a year ago, describing a meeting with security services chiefs where he stated, "We must start working on returning Crimea to Russia." The operation began four days later, with unidentified soldiers taking over the local parliament and voting in a new government, which was formally annexed by Moscow on March 18, 2014, prompting international condemnation.

site_title: Australia challenges Nurofen painkiller
summary: Australia's consumer watchdog has launched court action against Reckitt Benckiser, alleging false or misleading claims about its painkiller Nurofen. The ACCC claims Nurofen's products claim to treat different types of pain but use the same main ingredient. Nurofen disputes the allegations, stating its products comply with Australian guidelines. The ACCC is seeking an injunction and orders for corrective notices and penalties. The matter will be heard on March 31.

site_title: Tough to sell nuke reactors made in China
summary: China's nuclear power technology is poised to enter the global market, with the country signing deals to export its Hualong 1 reactor to Argentina and aiming to increase its share of global sales. However, China faces significant challenges, including a lack of experience in building and operating its own reactors, as well as concerns over management standards and safety. Despite this, China is encouraging consolidation among its nuclear companies to pool resources and intellectual property, and plans to unveil a merger between its State Nuclear Power Technology Corp and China Power Investment.

images.alt_text: To break into a market dominated by the likes of France's Areva, Beijing is encouraging consolidation to cut internal rivalry and pool intellectual property and financial resources.

site_title: Asian Futures Drop Amid US Rout on Payrolls; Aussie Bonds Sink
summary: Asian markets are expected to follow the US lower on Monday, with stocks and bonds declining amid a stronger US dollar and expectations of higher interest rates. The US jobs data showed a rise in nonfarm payrolls and a low jobless rate, leading to a surge in the dollar and a jump in futures odds of a US rate increase by September. The yen and euro slumped, while the yuan climbed, and Australian bonds yielded 2.76%, the highest rate since January 5. The Bloomberg dollar index soared to a record, and China's exports grew 15% in the first two months of 2015, surpassing the government's goal.

site_title: Escalating air war on IS not the answer: US general
summary: US General Martin Dempsey defended the air war against Islamic State, warning that escalating bombing raids or sending in more troops would be a mistake. He urged "strategic patience" in the fight, citing concerns over civilian casualties and propaganda. Dempsey's comments came during a visit to a French aircraft carrier in the Gulf. Expanding the air war could risk escalating the conflict and play into the hands of IS, Dempsey said. He emphasized the need for a measured approach to counter the extremist group.

site_title: Third blast on US oil train stirs scrutiny
summary: A third train carrying flammable crude oil has derailed and burst into flames in northern Illinois, prompting concerns over the safety of newer tank cars and the need for stricter regulations. The accident, which occurred just weeks after similar incidents in West Virginia and Ontario, has raised questions about whether the new federal standard, set to take effect in 2017, will be enough to prevent future accidents. Lawmakers are pressing regulators to act more aggressively, with some calling for stricter tank car standards and the phasing out of older models.

site_title: In Japan, Abe's robot panel aims to give drone industry an edge
summary: Japan's government, led by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, aims to fast-track industry-friendly regulation for the drone industry, giving it an edge over the US. The Robot Revolution Realisation Committee, an advisory panel, will review existing laws and set up industry-run best practices for drones. Companies such as Yamaha Motor and Secom Co are preparing drone technology and services. The Fukushima area may become a "field test zone" for robots and drones, with minimal regulation. This move is expected to boost Japan's drone sector and position it competitively in the global market.

site_title: Chechen confesses involvement in murder of Russia's Nemtsov
summary: A Russian court charged two men with the murder of opposition activist Boris Nemtsov, a former police officer from Chechnya, Zaur Dadayev, confessed to his involvement. Nemtsov was shot four times in the back on February 27 while walking with his girlfriend along a bridge near the Kremlin. Four others, including Dadayev's brother and a private security company employee, were arrested and charged with murder, extortion, and banditry. Investigators believe the killing was a contract assassination, but officials have not yet shed light on who ordered the murder.

site_title: Greece to propose use of 'casual' tax spies to help fill coffers
summary: Greece is facing a severe financial crisis, with its coffers expected to run out of cash by the end of March. To address the shortfall, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' government is proposing the use of "casual" tax spies, including tourists and non-professional inspectors, to spy on suspected tax evaders. The proposal aims to scare tax dodgers and engender a new tax compliance culture. With tax arrears reaching 76 billion euros, Athens is scrambling for additional ways to pay its bills, including borrowing from government pension and social security funds.

site_title: Canadian oil train ablaze, blocks traffic in derailment
summary: A Canadian National Railway Co train carrying crude oil derailed and caught fire in northern Ontario, blocking rail traffic between Toronto and Winnipeg. The incident occurred around 2.45 am on Saturday near Gogama, with no reported injuries. The company has not yet determined the exact number of cars involved in the derailment or fire.

site_title: European banks' profitability gap shows big cost cuts needed
summary: European banks need to cut costs by 20% and increase revenues by 15% to match their cost of capital, a study by EY said. The study found banks' return on equity (RoE) will average less than half their cost of capital, lagging US rivals, and job cuts are inevitable. The euro zone's banking supervisor has said returning to sustainable profitability is the industry's biggest challenge, and firms may need to sell off businesses. British banks are expected to climb to 9.5% in profitability this year, the highest since 2007.

site_title: Tears for MH370 as mystery persists on anniversary
summary: On the first anniversary of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370's disappearance, emotional ceremonies were held in Kuala Lumpur and Beijing to remember the 239 passengers and crew. A new report by an international investigative team found the battery on the black box locator beacon had expired, but shed no new light on the cause of the disaster. Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak reiterated his nation's commitment to finding the plane, believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean. Relatives and friends criticized Malaysia's handling of the crisis, with some holding protests and rallies demanding answers and truth.

site_title: Is illiquidity bad?
summary: A relatively illiquid, small-sized stock in the Singapore market can be an intriguing buy due to its cheap valuation metrics. These stocks, valued at 5 times earnings or a discount to book value, tend to be manufacturers, traders, and distributors. However, investors should be aware of the risks, including liquidity, size, and key man risk. Companies with long operating histories, a track record of profits, and growing shareholder value are preferred. A sustainable dividend yield is also crucial, but investors should be cautious of the potential for unrealized losses and fluctuating yields.

site_title: China exports rise 15% in first two months amid headwinds
summary: China's exports rose 15% in the first two months of the year, driven by a recovering US economy, surpassing the government's 6% goal. Imports fell 10%, reflecting weakened domestic demand and lower commodity prices. Analysts attribute the trade surplus to the US economic recovery, with a 3% US growth estimated to boost China's exports by 8-9%. The larger trade balance adds uncertainty for the Chinese currency, which has declined 1.2% against the dollar since January.

site_title: Battle for yield leading investors to heated hotels sector
summary: Investors are expected to invest heavily in the hotel sector in 2015, with a focus on budget and "buzz" hotels, as yields are attractive compared to alternative real estate. Investors are seeking higher returns, typically around 6.5-7.5%, due to low government bond yields. Lifestyle hotels, which feature smaller rooms, local-themed design, and buzzworthy lounges, are gaining popularity, with chains like Hilton and Marriott expanding their economy-end offerings. Yield premiums can range from 100-150 basis points, driven by operating agreements allowing investors to assume different levels of risk.

site_title: Mumbai eyes rules to allow taller buildings
summary: Mumbai is seeking to amend its 24-year-old building rules to allow taller buildings, aiming to increase the supply of apartments, cut property prices, and help India's financial capital emulate wealthy peers. The plan, part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Housing for All" programme, proposes increasing the Floor Space Index (FSI) to range between two and eight, up from an earlier cap of 1.33. The move is expected to benefit developers, but critics warn that it may lead to infrastructure breakdowns and insufficient investment in public transportation.

site_title: Curbs on sugar intake hard to swallow: experts
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that added sugar comprise less than 10% of daily calorie intake, with ideally half that amount. However, experts argue that these goals are unattainable due to widespread sugar addition in various food products, making it difficult for manufacturers to reduce sugar content without increasing costs. The WHO's guidelines, which are non-binding, face skepticism from food manufacturers and industry groups, who claim that finding alternative flavor boosters will be challenging.

site_title: China's Feb trade surplus reaches new high
summary: China's trade surplus reached a record high of $60.6 billion in February, driven by a surge in exports that rose 48% year-over-year. Imports, however, declined 20% due to lower global commodity prices. The strong export growth is seen as a positive sign for China's economy, but the weak import figure points to anaemic demand at home. China's trade surplus for January and February combined reached $120.7 billion, exceeding analysts' expectations. The country's GDP growth target has been lowered to 7% for 2015, amid concerns over domestic demand and debt.

site_title: Interest rate uncertainty will keep market volatile
summary: US stocks plummeted after a stronger-than-expected January jobs report, sparking concerns the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates sooner. This led to a market correction, with traders anticipating a "market-friendly" report. The unexpected jobs data sent stocks diving, as a strong report would have signaled a more accommodative monetary policy. The market's volatility is expected to continue, with traders adjusting their expectations and awaiting further economic data.

site_title: As Draghi starts QE, Germany's DAX remains a favourite: Options
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing (QE) has sparked optimism in the German stock market, with the DAX Index reaching a five-year high. Despite the ECB's bond purchases, options traders remain bullish on the DAX, citing low implied volatility and cheap hedging costs. Experts, such as Olgerd Eichler from Mainfirst Bank AG, believe that even a 5% decline in the DAX would not deter investors, given the strong economic expansion and boost from the lower euro.

site_title: For traders on Wall Street, 'good news is bad news'
summary: US stocks plummeted after a strong jobs report, with investors fearing a rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Despite positive economic data, traders believe the Fed will raise interest rates to curb growth, causing Treasury rates to rise and stocks to fall. The jobs report's impact was amplified by a speech from Federal Reserve President Richard Fisher, who stated that the unemployment rate is near the "non-accelerating inflation" threshold, prompting a rate hike. This "good news is bad news" phenomenon is a Wall Street phenomenon where positive economic data is seen as a catalyst for rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The adjustment in the stock market is partly playing out on a sector level, as traders rotate out of some of the sectors that benefited the most from quantitative easing.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: SingPost and City Developments Ltd. organized Chinese New Year celebrations for senior residents, distributing food, hongbaos, and essential items. SingPost's Food Goodie Bag programme provides quarterly food support to needy elderly, while City Developments Ltd. treated nearly 50 elderly residents to lunch at a hotel restaurant. Meanwhile, Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first Asean country by 2025, and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is evolving its climate investing approach.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

Vital staff spent time with the elderly, served food, played Bingo and memory games, participated in karaoke, distributed oranges, goody bags and lucky draw prizes, supermarket vouchers and hampers worth over S$3,000. Since 2010, Vital, a department under the Ministry of Finance, has started a CSR programme called "VitalCare" where staff take time-off to volunteer in both local (Metta Welfare Services, President's Challenge, Lions Befrienders) and overseas causes (Singapore International Foundation).

site_title: Vital for corporate leaders to ensure data integrity with backup
summary: Corporate leaders must prioritize data integrity and ensure backups to prevent data loss, which can impact sales, bottom line, and compliance. A recent survey found that nearly 80% of companies experience downtime costs over $20,000 per hour, highlighting the need for backup and disaster recovery as a strategic element of an IT plan. Industry data shows that backup is the only way to fully protect business data, and companies must maintain an offsite backup copy to address disasters that destroy production systems and onsite backups.

site_title: US$ strength weighs on commodity prices
summary: A strong US dollar weighed on commodity prices, with the euro reaching a 10-year low against the dollar. The dollar surged amid expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike and the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program. Oil prices rose due to unrest in Libya, but US crude inventories surged, offsetting some gains. Gold and silver fell as the dollar strengthened. The European Central Bank launched its stimulus package, and China lowered its economic growth target to approximately 7% for 2015.

site_title: China takes lessons from Japan's economic woes
summary: China's regulators are studying Japan's economic history to avoid a similar recession and deflation. Beijing views Tokyo's handling of capital flows and yen liberalization in the 1990s as key factors that led to Japan's asset bubble burst. Chinese regulators are seeking to learn from Japan's experiences, despite kinks in diplomatic ties, to keep the world's second-largest economy stable.

images.alt_text: China's challenges that echo Japan's past include a cooling property market resulting from tighter policy, oversupply that coupled with economic slowdown, is raising fears of a jump in bad loans.

site_title: Making the best of bad situations
summary: International SOS, a medical and security assistance provider, celebrates its 30th anniversary amidst increasing medical and security risks faced by businesses globally. Risks include the Ebola outbreak in Africa, air pollution in China, and aviation mishaps in Taiwan and Indonesia. Companies are turning to International SOS to mitigate these risks, presenting an opportunity for the company. With the rise of globalization and mobility, businesses are facing growing uncertainty, and International SOS is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: Hundreds still at sea waiting for backlog at US West Coast ports to clear
summary: Hundreds of sailors are still stranded at sea, awaiting clearance at US West Coast ports, two weeks after a labor dispute was resolved. The backlog is expected to take about three months to clear, with 29 vessels still adrift and over 700 crew members stuck. The sailors, mostly Filipino, are drawing salaries while stranded, with some enjoying basic amenities like pools and ping-pong tables at the seafarer's center. The International Seafarers Center provides support services for the stranded sailors.

site_title: Mosey on down to a Southern smokehouse
summary: Meat Smith, a Southern-style smokehouse, has opened in Telok Ayer Street, Singapore, offering a meat-lover's paradise with barbecued and smoked meats, loud music, and a fun-loving vibe. The restaurant, founded by serial restaurateur Loh Lik Peng, features a menu designed by American chef Andrew Baldus, with dishes like pork crackling, fried green tomatoes, and grilled half chicken. Prices are friendly, with most items under S$15. While some dishes, like the whole short rib, are over-seasoned, the restaurant's unique offerings and desserts like apple cobbler make it a worthwhile visit for adventurous eaters. Rating: 7/10.

site_title: As banks go online, new challengers emerge
summary: Banks in Singapore are investing in digitalization to keep up with customer expectations, but fintech companies are also emerging as competitors in the online payments market. A report by McKinsey estimates that there are nearly 700 million digital banking consumers in Asia, with a significant portion in fast-growing markets like China and India. Fintechs are disrupting the financial services industry, and banks need to collaborate with them to remain competitive. Some banks, like DBS, are partnering with fintechs and startups to innovate and gain a competitive edge, while others are focusing on developing their own digital solutions.

site_title: Global investors at risk from low quality assets, warns IIF
summary: Global investors are at risk from low-quality assets due to a "fundamental asset-liability mismatch" caused by low interest rates and a shortage of high-quality assets, warns the Institute of International Finance (IIF). The warning echoes the IMF's October 2014 warning of a potential financial market bust. Institutional investors have boosted their holdings of corporate and foreign bonds by 65% since 2008, but may struggle to rebalance their portfolios due to deteriorating market liquidity. The IIF warns that risks could accumulate and render the financial system more fragile in the event of a severe market downturn.

site_title: For SGX, a dearth of IPOs amid volatility
summary: Singapore's IPO market has ground to a halt in the first two months of 2015, with no new listings on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) since Keppel DC Reit listed last December. Analysts attribute the slowdown to volatile market conditions, including the slump in commodity prices, and economic uncertainty affecting local firms. Overseas companies are also shying away from listing in Singapore due to lacklustre stock performance and low trading volumes. The new chief of SGX will play a crucial role in improving the IPO scene, with some analysts expecting more listings to launch in the coming months.

site_title: Higher interest rates for NTUC members for the rest of the year
summary: NTUC members in Singapore will earn higher interest rates on their NTUC-OCBC Starter Accounts from March to December 2015, with rates ranging from 0.5% to 1% per annum. This is part of a 50th birthday celebration, with Pioneer Generation members receiving a higher base interest rate of 1% per annum. Members who charge at least $400 to their NTUC Plus! Visa cards will also earn higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: To celebrate Singapore's 50th birthday, National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) members will earn higher interest rates of up to one per cent per annum (pa) on their NTUC-OCBC Starter Accounts from March to December 2015.

site_title: Yellen's dilemma: what does the latest jobs report mean?
summary: The US job market showed signs of strength in the latest jobs report, with the unemployment rate falling to 5.5% and job creation continuing at a strong pace.
