New players, such as Ethan's Gourmet Foods, Stoke, and Meat Collective, are also emerging, offering Japanese, organic, and affordable options. These businesses aim to educate consumers about the quality of meats and provide them with options for cooking at home, with some even partnering with local restaurants to offer cooking services.

site_title: Swiss govt will not alter SNB's independence
summary: Switzerland's government has stated it will not alter the Swiss National Bank's (SNB) independence, despite the shock currency move in January that sparked a backlash. The federal council has confirmed it will not touch the SNB's independence, with a spokesman saying the government knows its purpose and the SNB's independence is well-established. The government will instead seek to coordinate more closely with the SNB, potentially leading to a new currency cap.

site_title: Singapore Budget Debate: Preparing to meet evolving needs
summary: Singapore's parliament heard from the Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Education, and Ministry of Trade and Industry on Friday, discussing plans to meet the country's evolving needs. The Ministry of Home Affairs plans to increase spending on cyber crimes and emergency medical services, while the Ministry of Education will spend S$250 million on education schemes for families. The Ministry of Trade and Industry aims to encourage firms to build training capability through a partnership with the Workforce Development Agency and the Ministry of Education. The government plans to boost spending by 0.2% of GDP over the next five years.

site_title: Pay gap narrowed for EU women during financial crisis
summary: The gender pay gap in the European Union narrowed during the financial crisis, with women paid 16.4% less than men in 2013, compared to 17.3% in 2008. The gap was wider in richer economies, but overall, the trend suggests that women's jobs may be more protected than men's.

images.alt_text: The gender pay gap in the European Union narrowed during the financial crisis, possibly because the jobs of many women are more protected than those of men.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 0.87 points higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.87 points to 1,806.96, with 2 billion lots valued at RM1.9 billion traded. Gainers outpaced losers 456 to 361. The index's recent performance is not directly related to the provided articles.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady in early trading
summary: European equities steadied in early trading on Friday, holding flat at 1,569.33 points after recent sharp gains. Investors remained cautious ahead of a US jobs report that could hint at a US rate hike. The FTSEurofirst 300 index was set for a fifth straight week of gains.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore Wrap Friday: Key stories include Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident in his daughter's clearance as Thai PM in an ethics case. The ASEAN bloc agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority, and the UK economy shrinks for the second month. South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks, while Malaysia's May industrial production rises 0.3%, below forecast.

site_title: Germany adopts legal quotas for women on company boards
summary: Germany's lower house of parliament passed legislation requiring major companies to allot 30% of non-executive board seats to women, starting from 2016. The quotas will affect over 100 listed companies and 3,500 medium-sized firms. The move aims to address the under-representation of women in business, with only 7% of executive board seats and 25% of non-executive board seats currently held by women. Companies not meeting the quota will be required to fill vacancies with women or leave positions empty, as championed by the centre-left Social Democrats.

images.alt_text: Germany's lower house of parliament passed legislation on Friday requiring major companies to allot 30 per cent of seats on non-executive boards to women, as a new survey found females remain grossly under-represented in business life.

site_title: Thai govt gets bids for 780,000 tonnes of rice
summary: Thailand's Commerce Ministry received bids for 780,000 tonnes of rice out of a 1 million-tonne tender, with bids exceeding the floor price of around 8 billion baht (US$247 million). This is part of the government's efforts to sell off its bulging stockpiles of rice, which were built up under a subsidy scheme run by the ousted Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra. The sales are expected to be approved next week, following five tenders since the military seized power last May, with a total of 1,177,983 tonnes sold for around 17.21 billion baht.

images.alt_text: Top exporter Thailand received bids for around 780,000 tonnes of rice out of the 1 million tonnes offered in its latest tender, the Commerce Ministry said on Friday, as the government continues to sell grain to reduce its bulging stockpiles.

site_title: China's Fosun buys 5% stake in Thomas Cook
summary: China's Fosun International has acquired a 5% stake in Thomas Cook Group for $140.1 million, increasing its holding to 10% and aiming to double its stake. The investment is expected to enhance earnings and aid expansion in China, particularly in the fast-growing markets. Thomas Cook shares rose 15% following the news, which could help the company compete with TUI Group, the world's largest tourism company.

site_title: Thai Air says could sell assets to cover 2015 losses
summary: Thai Airways International plans to sell non-core assets worth 15.5 billion baht (US$481 million) to cover potential losses in 2015. The airline expects to take a 5 billion baht charge due to staff cuts and fleet reduction. A drop in fuel costs is expected to save around 16 billion baht. The company's president, Charumporn Jotikasthira, cited a need to compensate for restructuring costs despite a potential return to operating profit in 2015.

site_title: Myanmar police charge 14 garment workers as protests gather pace
summary: Myanmar police have charged 14 garment workers with rioting for blocking roads in Yangon during a protest over wages. The workers, 8 men and 6 women, face jail if convicted. Police broke the strike, and most employees have returned to work. The charges come amid increasing criticism of authorities' handling of protests. The garment workers were arrested on Wednesday, following a series of protests over wages and working conditions in the country.

site_title: Euro tumbles to new 11.5-year low
summary: The euro plummeted to a 11.5-year low of US$1.0963 against the dollar on Friday, amid anticipation of a strong US non-farm payrolls report that could lead to a Federal Reserve interest rate increase. The European Central Bank's massive stimulus package, worth 1.1 trillion euros, was set to launch next week, while the Fed is expected to hike rates later this year due to optimism over the American economy. Analysts predict the euro could reach parity against the dollar amid policy divergence between the ECB and Fed.

images.alt_text: The euro dived on Friday to another 11.5-year low, one day after the European Central Bank announced it would launch its massive stimulus package next week.

site_title: BP unveils US$12b investment in Egypt gas fields
summary: BP has announced a $12 billion investment in Egyptian gas fields with Russian partner DEA, citing a "vote of confidence" in the country despite rising militancy. The London-listed company holds a 65% stake in the project, with DEA owning the remaining 35%. The investment will be made in the West Nile Delta region and comes despite concerns over deadly militancy in Egypt.

site_title: German companies required to name more women to top board posts
summary: German companies with over 100 listed employees must appoint at least 30% of non-executive oversight board members as women starting next year. The legislation also requires companies to present a plan to address gender imbalance in top management positions. The measure aims to increase women's representation on boards and address historical gender disparities in the German business sector.

site_title: China reviews giving banks stock broking licences: regulator
summary: China is considering issuing banks with brokerage licences as part of reforms to boost financial institutions' performance and develop the capital market. The China Securities Regulatory Commission is studying details on implementation, with no announced timetable. This comes after profits at brokerages more than doubled last year due to a surge in retail investors and increased trading volumes. The regulator recently granted online brokerage licences to 20 firms, reflecting growing interest in the sector as internet finance expands.

site_title: Hotel boom in Manila offers hope to Philippine tourism
summary: A record number of hotel rooms (4,612) are expected to open in Manila this year, largely due to the growth of its gaming scene, boosting the underperforming Philippine tourism sector. Global brands such as Accor, Hilton, and Wyndham are contributing to the new openings. While this may help address the chronic shortage of quality accommodation, Manila still lacks sufficient airports to accommodate island-hopping travelers, and the country's tourism sector faces challenges, including infrastructure limitations and territorial disputes.

site_title: Singapore: STI rises 15 points over the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 15 points to 3,417.51 over the week, driven by expectations of a market-friendly US jobs report. The index reversed Thursday's 20-point loss and was led by SingTel, Jardine Matheson, and Hongkong Land. Despite the gain, the broad market recorded 202 rises versus 219 falls.

site_title: VLCC rates on key Asian routes to hold steady
summary: VLCC rates on key Asian routes are expected to hold steady, with owners resisting charterers' attempts to lower rates despite an overhang of available tonnage. Average VLCC earnings are around $45,000 per day, up from $27,300 last year. Chartering activity from West Africa remains quiet, while rates for other trades, such as Aframax tankers and clean tankers, have fluctuated. The market is awaiting a significant increase in demand to drive rates higher.

site_title: Ladies, have you tried leaning in somewhere else?
summary: The author, a Singaporean woman, critiques the focus on women's empowerment and International Women's Day, arguing that it overlooks the struggles of women from marginalized backgrounds. She laments the lack of attention to women who face violence, lack access to education and healthcare, and are trafficked. The author suggests that instead of celebrating individual successes, the focus should be on addressing the systemic issues that affect women who do not have a voice, and ultimately, creating a more equitable society for all women.

site_title: Swiss central bank's Feb forex reserves hit new record
summary: Switzerland's foreign exchange reserves reached a new record high of $523.17 billion in February, according to the Swiss National Bank. The reserves rose nearly 11 billion Swiss francs, sparking debate over whether the central bank was intervening in the market or if the increase was due to currency fluctuations. Analysts divided on the cause, with some attributing the rise to a depreciation of the Swiss franc in February, while others suggested the central bank may still be intervening despite removing the euro cap in mid-January.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines upgrades aircraft tracking, a year after MH370
summary: Malaysia Airlines has upgraded its aircraft tracking system to track long-haul flights every 15 minutes or less, a year after the disappearance of Flight MH370. The move follows a UN aviation agency proposal to improve tracking and coordination between military and civil aviation authorities to avoid confusion and missteps. No trace of the Boeing 777-200 has been found, which vanished on March 8, 2014, with 239 passengers and crew on board. The improved tracking system aims to enhance search efforts and prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong shares ended 0.12% lower on Friday, marking a fourth-straight loss, due to China's lower economic growth target. The Hang Seng Index fell 29.04 points to 24,164.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.22% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.55%. These losses come despite a regional advance and a rally on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Singapore will raise spendings to fight crimes: Ministry of Home Affairs
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Home Affairs plans to increase spending from 1.1% to 1.3% of GDP over the next five years to combat cyber crimes and aging population needs, including emergency medical services. The ministry will raise its budget by 11.7% for fiscal year 2015 to 1.2% of GDP. Additionally, 2,000 new officers will be added to the Home Team to reinforce crime-fighting efforts, following a 10-year growth in manpower from 19,300 to 24,700.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up, euro struggles on ECB stimulus
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, driven by gains in New York and the European Central Bank's announcement of a massive stimulus program. The euro remained at 11-year lows, while the dollar strengthened ahead of US jobs data. Tokyo rose 1.06%, Seoul 0.34%, and Hong Kong 0.18%. The ECB forecast eurozone growth at 1.5% and 2.1% in 2016 and 2017, respectively, but predicted zero inflation this year. The news pushed the euro below US$1.10 and the dollar to 120.10 yen.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at 5-mth high on offshore demand
summary: South Korean shares reached a five-month high on Friday, closing up 0.7% at 2,012.94 points, driven by offshore demand ahead of the European Central Bank's bond-buying stimulus programme. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 1.4% for the week, while the South Korean won climbed 0.2% against the dollar. This follows a seven-week streak of gains.

site_title: Japan trade official: no need to wait for TPA discussion in US
summary: Japan's Deputy Chief Trade Negotiator Hiroshi Oe stated that there's no need to wait for US fast-track trade legislation before concluding a two-way trade deal with the US. Economy Minister Akira Amari emphasized early enactment of trade promotion authority legislation as a key condition for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal.

site_title: Ng Wai Choong to helm Energy Market Authority from April
summary: Ng Wai Choong will become the new CEO of the Energy Market Authority (EMA) in Singapore from April 1, replacing Chee Hong Tat. Ng, who is currently the deputy secretary at the Ministry of Finance, has extensive experience in leadership roles and will lead EMA in developing Singapore's energy sector.

site_title: Apple to join Dow blue-chip index, replacing AT&T
summary: US tech giant Apple will join the Dow Jones Industrial Index, replacing telecom company AT&T, effective March 19. This move comes after Apple surpassed AT&T in market capitalization, now valued at over $730 billion. Apple's inclusion in the elite list of 30 top companies marks a significant milestone for the iPhone and iPad maker.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.17%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.17% on Friday, driven by a weaker yen, which boosted exporter shares. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,971.00 and the Topix index at 1,540.84. Investors await the US jobs report, while Asia's stocks rally continues despite new Trump threats.

site_title: Hot stock: Sinarmas Land share price leaps to new high
summary: Sinarmas Land shares surged 7% or 5.5 cents to a new high of S$0.84, with 17 million shares changing hands. The company is restarting talks for a US$300 million IPO of its industrial property arm, PT Puradelta Lestari, which may sell shares in Indonesia this year. The IPO had been shelved in 2013. The stock's rally was driven by the news, making it one of the top 20 most traded stocks.

site_title: Apple lets companies fine-tune apps before watch debut: Bloomberg
summary: Apple has allowed select companies, including Facebook, United Continental Holdings, and BMW, to test and fine-tune their apps for the upcoming Apple Watch before its official launch. The testing took place at Apple's headquarters, where Internet access was blocked and outside materials were prohibited. The companies spent weeks refining their apps for the watch's unique design, which will allow users to check email, pay for goods, and monitor health information. Apple will showcase the Apple Watch at a special event on March 9 and is expected to launch it in April.

site_title: Median open market value of Cat A cars remains below S$20,000 after re-categorisation
summary: The median open market value (OMV) of Category A cars in Singapore has remained below S$20,000 after re-categorisation, according to the Land Transport Authority. This is a consistent trend since February 2014. The re-categorisation has resulted in a greater proportion of cars with lower OMV in Cat A.

site_title: Broker's take: CIMB Research maintains 'neutral' rating on plantation sector
summary: CIMB Research maintains a 'neutral' rating on the plantation sector, citing that established well-managed palm oil players will offer strong cashflows and good dividend yields to long-term investors. Analysts believe listed palm oil players are shifting towards an integrated business model, similar to Wilmar. This stance suggests a neutral outlook for the sector, with potential for long-term growth.

site_title: China: Stocks slip as investors weigh lower economic growth
summary: China's stocks slipped on Friday, with the CSI300 index falling 0.5% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.2%, as investors digested comments from top officials on the country's economic growth and debt challenges. Finance Minister Lou Jiwei called for an expansionary fiscal policy to withstand downward pressures, while Premier Li Keqiang stated that 7% annual economic growth was the "new normal." Analysts saw the weak economic environment and policy stance as already priced into the market.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble shares surge on pledge of more transparency (Amended)
summary: Noble Group Ltd shares surged 3.48% to a high of S$1.04 on Friday after the company pledged to provide more disclosures and transparency following improper accounting accusations from Iceberg Research. This comes after reaching a one-year low of S$0.92 earlier in the week. The extended gains placed Noble's stock among the top 20 gainers on Singapore's Straits Times Index.

site_title: Xiaomi to support 100 startups in push to expand product line
summary: Xiaomi, the world's most valuable startup, plans to invest in 100 emerging technology companies, backing its existing 27 startups. CEO Lei Jun aims to expand into "smart home" devices and boost sales to 120 billion yuan (US$19 billion) this year. The company will focus on new markets, including Brazil and Russia, and has no immediate plans to sell phones in Europe, Japan, or the US. Lei emphasized the importance of supporting other innovators, citing Zimi as a success story, and proposed revisions to China's companies law to better support innovation.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi, the world's most valuable startup, is planning investments of its own in 100 emerging technology companies.

site_title: Pertamina plans US$2b annual investment for Mahakam block
summary: Indonesia's state-owned energy firm Pertamina plans to invest around US$2 billion annually in the Mahakam gas block if given control, aiming to produce 1.2-1.5 billion cubic feet of gas per day. The government plans to hand Pertamina control of the block in 2017, once the current operator Total SA's contract expires. Analysts have questioned Pertamina's technical and financial capacity to maintain current production levels, but Pertamina's director believes the company can keep production steady. A decision on Pertamina's future control of the block is expected by the end of March.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Pertamina would invest around US$2 billion annually into the Mahakam gas block if given control, and target output of 1.2 billion to 1.5 billion cubic feet of gas per day (bcfd), a senior official at the state-owned energy firm said.

site_title: Fed should not be too patient on US rate hikes, Williams says
summary: Federal Reserve policymaker John Williams suggests the Fed should consider raising interest rates earlier rather than waiting, citing the risk of "drastically" overshooting inflation and forcing a dramatic rate hike. Williams believes a gradual increase is safer, starting in mid-year, to avoid destabilizing the markets and damaging the economic recovery. This marks a stark contrast with dovish worries of another policymaker, Charles Evans, who calls for delaying rate hikes until 2016.

site_title: Lessons learnt as MH370 hunt marks one year
summary: The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which vanished on March 8, 2014, has reached its one-year milestone with no debris found despite an extensive air and sea search in the Indian Ocean. The search, led by Australia and Malaysia, has covered a 60,000 sq km area and has mapped the ocean floor for the first time, yielding insights into sea life and habitat. The search has provided valuable lessons for future search and rescue missions, including the use of next-generation search tools and the importance of reliable data quality.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rose in Asian trade on Friday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing by 32 US cents to US$51.08 and Brent gaining 47 US cents to US$60.95, driven by concerns over tensions in the Middle East and Ukraine. Analysts cited the potential for increased market upside.

site_title: Australia: Shares post worst weekly performance since mid-Jan
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Friday, finishing 0.09% lower, despite a late rebound in financial and real estate stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 5.26 points to 5,898.90, its worst weekly performance since January 16. Resources and energy stocks declined due to lower iron ore prices, while major banks fell, but insurance company QBE and investment bank Macquarie led gains.

site_title: Amazon opens store on Alibaba's online marketplace Tmall
summary: Amazon has opened a store on Alibaba's online marketplace Tmall.com, expanding its presence in China. The store sells imported goods such as food, shoes, and kitchenware. This move follows other Western retailers like Zara, Burberry, and ASOS, who have also joined Tmall to boost their Chinese sales. Amazon already operates its own e-commerce site in China, and its new Tmall store is the latest step in its efforts to compete in the country's booming e-commerce market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.18% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.18% to 24,235.76 in the first minutes of trade on Friday, following gains on Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index added 42.72 points. The move comes ahead of US jobs data release later in the day.

site_title: RHB to expand in Singapore, makes DMG & Partners Securities wholly-owned unit
summary: RHB Banking Group is expanding in Singapore, acquiring the remaining interest in DMG & Partners Securities from Deutsche Asia Pacific Holdings Pte Ltd. The company will rebrand DMG as RHB Securities Singapore Pte Ltd, solidifying its presence in the city-state as a hub for regional treasury and business origination. RHB aims to scale up its operations in Singapore, hiring 200 new staff across the region, with the investment bank currently employing 400 staff in Singapore.

site_title: Women earn 16.4% less than men in EU
summary: The European Union reported a 16.4% average salary gap between women and men in 2013, with the largest disparities in northern countries like Estonia (29.9%) and Germany (21.6%). The gap narrowed from 2008 to 2013 in most EU countries, with significant declines in Lithuania, Poland, and Malta. However, it increased in nine member states, primarily in Portugal. Eurostat also found that women hold just two-thirds of office jobs and two-thirds of non-executive positions, but one-third of director and executive roles.

site_title: South Korea police say probing US ambassador attacker's visits to North Korea
summary: South Korean police are investigating possible links between a knife attack on US Ambassador Mark Lippert and his frequent visits to North Korea. The attacker, Kim Ki Jong, made seven visits between 1999 and 2007. Lippert needed 80 stitches after being slashed at a forum discussing Korean reunification. The police plan to seek a formal detention warrant against Kim on Friday.

site_title: Britain seeking quick sale of RBS bank: report
summary: Britain is seeking to sell the Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) as quickly as possible, Chancellor George Osborne stated in a Financial Times report. The bank, 80% owned by the British government, was bailed out with £45.5 billion in 2008. Osborne hopes to sell the bank after the May general election, with the public wanting to see a return of their investment. However, the sale process could take years, according to Osborne.

images.alt_text: Britain is looking to sell the Royal Bank of Scotland as quickly as possible, Chancellor George Osborne told the Financial Times on Thursday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oil companies, Noble Group, Keppel Corp
summary: Global oil market concerns rise as US inventories hit record highs, weighing on oil prices. Noble Group defends its accounting practices after Iceberg Research claims of improper accounting. Keppel Corp's energy-from-waste plant in the UK begins commercial operations, marking one of Europe's largest waste-to-energy projects. Despite market volatility, stocks continue to rally, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Volkswagen to announce US$1b investment in Mexico: source
summary: Volkswagen plans to announce a US$1 billion investment in Mexico to expand its Puebla plant, producing the Tiguan compact vehicle. The investment is expected to generate around 1,900 jobs. The announcement is set to be made on Monday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.34% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.34% higher on Friday, driven by a rising dollar against the yen ahead of the US jobs report. The Nikkei 225 index rose 63.01 points to 18,814.85. Investors awaited a potential interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve, while a weaker yen boosted Japanese exporters. Shares in Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Holdings jumped 2.22% after announcing a stake in Scor.

site_title: GIC nearly doubles stake in operator of Madame Tussauds waxworks, Legoland
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has nearly doubled its stake in Merlin Entertainments, operator of Madame Tussauds waxworks and Legoland, to about 5.2%. GIC's stake rose to 52.6 million shares from 27.6 million. This comes after private equity firms CVC and Blackstone launched a sale of 156.5 million shares. As a result, Merlin's shares closed up 2.8% at 426.5 pence on the London Stock Exchange.

site_title: CEO reputation continues to be a premium currency: Weber Shandwick, KRC Research report
summary: A report by Weber Shandwick and KRC Research found that a CEO's reputation is a premium form of currency, accounting for 41% of a company's reputation and 39% of its market value in Singapore. Executives attribute CEO reputation to attracting investors, crisis protection, and talent retention. The majority believe CEOs should have a visible public profile, and nearly half think CEOs are more willing to speak to the media today than in the past. The survey of 1,700 executives from 19 countries also highlighted the importance of external relationship-building and avoiding taking public stances on policies.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.54% or 18.48 points to 3,413.75. Investors await the US payroll report and await clues on monetary policy, while European Central Bank head Mario Draghi's quantitative easing program launch boosted sentiment. Around 56.2 million shares traded, with gainers beating losers 93 to 42.

site_title: Singapore office leases among cheapest in Asia-Pacific: Cushman & Wakefield report
summary: Singapore's office lease prices remain among the cheapest in the Asia-Pacific region, with an occupancy cost of US$93 per square foot (psf) per year, according to a Cushman & Wakefield report. This is 49% cheaper than Hong Kong's CBD, where costs reached US$184 psf per year in 2014. The increase in prices in Singapore was attributed to a supply crunch, resulting in a 9.8% rise in occupancy costs last year.

site_title: OCBC Australian notes due 2019 get final rating of 'AA-': Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings assigned a final rating of 'AA-' to OCBC Australian notes due 2019, citing direct, unsubordinated, and unsecured obligations of the bank. The notes rank equally with all unsecured and unsubordinated obligations. This follows the completion of the notes issue and receipt of final documents conforming to previously received information. The rating is the same as OCBC's 'AA-' Long-Term Issuer Default Rating.

images.alt_text: Fitch Ratings has assigned Singapore-based Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp's (OCBC; AA-/Stable) A$300 million floating rate notes due 2019 a final rating of 'AA-'.

site_title: Sharp asks turnaround fund to take stake worth up to 30b yen
summary: Sharp Corp has asked a corporate turnaround fund, Japan Industrial Solutions, to invest up to 30 billion yen (S$343 million) to aid its restructuring efforts. Sharp hopes to receive the investment by March 2016. The move comes as the embattled electronics maker seeks to improve its financial situation.

site_title: Rupiah set to decline for fourth week on central bank tolerance
summary: Indonesia's rupiah is set to decline for a fourth week due to the central bank's tolerance of a weaker currency. The rupiah reached its lowest level since 1998, with a 0.5% drop to 12,988 a dollar. Bank Indonesia's Senior Deputy Governor said an undervalued exchange rate can help exports and reduce imports, which will likely contribute to a 3% to 3.1% current-account deficit this year. The government aims to boost economic growth to 5.7% in 2015.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's rupiah was set to decline for a fourth straight week as the central bank signaled that it will tolerate a weaker currency.

site_title: Japan's mega utility merger to boost LNG "buyer power"
summary: Japan's mega-utility merger between Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) and Chubu Electric Power Co will create the world's largest LNG importer, accounting for 16% of global purchases. This will give Asian buyers increased bargaining power to press producers for more flexible contracts, potentially leading to lower prices and a shift in the balance of power in the global LNG market. The merger aims to reshape LNG buying in line with Japan's push for a more flexible pricing system, which could benefit Japanese buyers and potentially displace South Korea's Kogas as the world's No.1 LNG importer.

site_title: China fiscal policy to help avoid sharp growth slowdown: Finance Minister
summary: China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei announced plans to implement an expansionary fiscal policy this year to prevent a sharp slowdown in the economy. Local governments will repay over 100 billion yuan in debt, addressing a debt pile of over US$3 trillion. The move aims to stabilize the economy amid concerns about slowing growth.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's condition 'largely unchanged': PMO
summary: Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's condition remains "largely unchanged" since his admission for severe pneumonia on Feb 5, according to the Prime Minister's Office. He, 91, is still in intensive care at the Singapore General Hospital.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Rock with Shamrocks
summary: Singapore will celebrate St Patrick's Day with a street festival featuring a street parade on March 15, marking the 10th anniversary of the event. The parade will be led by the Gaelic Lions GAA players and will feature various Irish groups and performances. The festival will also include live music, Irish food, and activities for children. Ambassador of Ireland to Singapore, Geoffrey Keating, will be the parade patron, highlighting the historical ties between Ireland and Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia's RHB picks new CEO candidate, seeks central bank approval
summary: Malaysia's RHB Capital Bhd has selected an unnamed candidate to succeed CEO Kellee Kam and will seek central bank approval to appoint the new CEO. The board will proceed to seek approval from Bank Negara to appoint the successor after calling off a proposed merger with CIMB Group Holdings Bhd due to a failure to agree terms in a worsening economic environment. RHB appointed Khairussaleh Ramli as acting group CEO.

images.alt_text: Malaysian lender RHB Capital Bhd said it will seek approval from the country's central bank to appoint an unnamed candidate it has selected to succeed Kellee Kam as its next chief executive officer. "A successor has been identified," RHB said in a statement issued late on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong freedoms 'eroded' by China: British MPs
summary: A British committee of MPs warned that Hong Kong's autonomy from China is being "eroded", potentially leading to a "crisis of governance". The report, released on Friday, expressed concern over the vetting of candidates for Hong Kong's 2017 leader election by a pro-Beijing committee. The committee urged the British government to press China to protect fundamental rights and urged the upcoming state visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping to convey that China's actions are not in its interests. The report warned that Hong Kong's political and economic freedoms are being strained, particularly over press freedoms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.17 points to 1805.92, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks. Gainers outnumbered losers 154 to 126, with volume reaching 251.25 million lots worth RM108.13 million.

site_title: Australia complains over Indonesia's treatment of death row prisoners
summary: Australia has lodged a formal complaint to Indonesia over the treatment of two death row prisoners, Myuran Sukumaran and Andrew Chan, who face execution for drug smuggling. The pair were moved from their Bali prison in a heavy-guarded convoy and photographed with a police chief, sparking outrage in Australia. The executions have raised diplomatic tension between the two countries, with the Australian government stressing that Chan and Sukumaran have been rehabilitated in prison and warning of potential political repercussions. Indonesia has rejected a prisoner swap proposal and is expected to decide on the executions' date in the coming days.

site_title: Harrison Ford badly hurt in LA plane crash: reports
summary: Harrison Ford, 72, was critically injured in a plane crash on a golf course outside Los Angeles on Thursday. The vintage two-seater plane crash-landed, causing multiple gashes to his head and significant bleeding. The pilot, whose identity was not disclosed, was also critically injured. Ford was taken to a hospital for treatment, but details about his condition are not available.

site_title: DHL Express to triple capacity with new S$140m facility
summary: DHL Express is investing S$140 million in a new logistics facility at Singapore's Changi Airfreight Centre, set to open in 2016. The 26,200 sq m facility will be the first fully automated parcel sorting and processing system in South Asia, tripling DHL's current capacity and enabling 14,000 shipments per hour. The expansion supports up to five times more flights in Singapore and capitalizes on the growing trade volumes in South-east Asia, particularly with the rise of e-commerce.

images.alt_text: The 23,600 sq m facility will process 14,000 shipments per hour, compared to the current 2,400 shipments.

site_title: US-based stock funds attract US$8.4b in latest week
summary: US-based stock funds received a record US$8.4 billion in new investments in the week ended March 4, according to data from Lipper. Non-US stock funds attracted the majority of the cash, with US-focused funds and emerging market funds also seeing significant inflows. Taxable bond funds continued their ninth straight week of inflows, while US Treasury funds experienced their largest outflows since June 2014.

images.alt_text: Investors in US-based funds poured US$8.4 billion into stock funds in the week ended March 4, marking their biggest inflows since late December, data from Lipper, a unit of Thomson Reuters, showed on Thursday.

site_title: Global supply glut weighs on oil prices
summary: Oil prices fell due to a global supply glut, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dipping 77 cents to $50.76 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude falling seven cents to $60.48 a barrel. US crude inventories reached a record high of 444.4 million barrels, sparking doubts about expected production cuts. Analysts say the market is tolerating the excess supply, but may eventually acknowledge it. The ongoing supply/demand surplus is estimated at 1.4 million barrels per day, with rising US crude oil inventories.

site_title: For the 'unbanked', mobile money still has some way to go
summary: Mobile money services aim to provide financial inclusion to the 2.5 billion unbanked globally, but its adoption remains limited. While mobile money transfers are growing, many transactions are simply topping up prepaid accounts or sending small amounts of money. Only a small percentage of users actively use mobile money for transactions, and the majority of money flows through these networks are from users to phone companies. Success stories exist, such as Kenya's M-Pesa, but critics argue that telcos prioritize revenue over financial inclusion, and that cheaper, safer options are needed to expand mobile money's potential.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed higher on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.61% to 6,961.14 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gaining 1% to 11,504.01 points, and Paris's CAC 40 rising 0.94% to 4,963.51 points. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Delta jet skids off runway during snowstorm at LaGuardia airport
summary: A Delta Air Lines jet skidded off the runway during a snowstorm at LaGuardia Airport in New York, striking a fence before coming to rest on a snow-covered embankment. The incident occurred at around 11am EST, but no passengers or crew members were seriously injured. The plane, Delta flight 1086 from Atlanta, had landed during the storm and the nose had pushed through a chain-link fence. The plane's location was just feet from the waters of Flushing Bay.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on ECB stimulus, pharma deal
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, snapping a two-day losing streak, driven by European monetary stimulus and a US$21 billion pharmaceutical merger. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 38.82 points, the S&P 500 gained 2.51, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 15.67. The European Central Bank announced a 1.1-trillion-euro bond-buying program and raised its eurozone growth forecasts. Pharmaceutical stocks, including AbbVie and Biogen, fell and rose, respectively, after the merger announcement.

site_title: ECB bond-buying scheme to start on Monday
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced it will start a government bond-buying programme on March 9, 2015, to boost the sagging eurozone economy. The ECB plans to spend 60 billion euros per month on buying sovereign bonds and private sector assets until at least September 2016. The move aims to support the emerging data and ease borrowing conditions for firms and households, with European stocks advancing for a second day following the announcement. The ECB's quantitative easing programme is expected to support higher economic growth and inflation, with inflation forecast to reach just below 2%.

images.alt_text: "We will also continue to purchase asset-backed securities and covered bonds," said Mr Draghi

site_title: Costumes are roused in SDT's Sleeping Beauty
summary: The Singapore Dance Theatre's Sleeping Beauty ballet features costumes created in Japan and Melbourne, designed by Tracy Grant Lord, a New Zealand-born and Australia-based costume designer. The costumes, which include tutus and scenic cloths, are designed to accommodate the dancers' extensive movements and partnering. This is SDT's first production of Sleeping Beauty, which was first performed in 2010 and promises to be a visual spectacle with Peter Tchaikovsky's score. The ballet will be performed from March 12-15 at the Esplanade Theatre, with tickets available from $30-$70.

site_title: Keppel FELS all set to ride out the downturn
summary: Keppel FELS, a Singapore-based rig builder, is well-positioned to weather the current downturn in the oil industry. The company boasts a strong order backlog until 2017 and has delivered its 100th jack-up rig recently. Keppel FELS differentiates itself through its focus on technology, proprietary designs, and resilience. Analysts predict a decline in new order wins for the company, but its strong foundation and ability to adapt to changing market conditions make it better equipped to navigate the challenges ahead.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Dairy Farm's full-year gain up 2% at US$509m
summary: Dairy Farm's full-year net profit rose 2% to US$509 million, driven by gains from non-trading activities and strong growth in health and beauty, home furnishings, and restaurants divisions. The company's food division reported a 6% decline in operating profit due to challenges in Singapore and Indonesia. Sales increased 6% to US$11 billion, with underlying earnings per share rising 4%. The company plans to invest in strategic areas to drive future growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Mandarin Oriental says hackers stole credit card data
summary: Hackers broke into the Mandarin Oriental luxury hotel group's database, stealing credit card information from "an isolated number" of its US and European properties. The breach was caused by undetectable malicious software and affects only credit card data, with no other guest data compromised. The group has removed the malware, alerted technology peers, and is coordinating with credit card agencies and law enforcement to protect guests and systems. None of the affected hotels are in Asia, and Mandarin Oriental operates 45 hotels in 25 countries.

site_title: US airlines attack UAE, Qatar airline subsidies
summary: US airlines, including American Airlines, Delta Airlines, and United Airlines, have accused Qatar and the United Arab Emirates of providing $42 billion in subsidies to their airlines, allowing them to gain market share at the expense of US carriers. The subsidies include interest-free loans, subsidized airport charges, and below-market labor costs. The US airlines have called on the government to raise the issue and urged changes to bilateral commercial aviation agreements with Qatar and the UAE, potentially leading to the termination of existing agreements and renegotiation of new deals based on reciprocity.

site_title: A Budget seminar for SMEs
summary: The SME Magazine will host a Budget 2015 Seminar for SMEs and entrepreneurs on March 17 at the SPH Auditorium. Speakers include business leaders, an economist, and a tax expert, discussing the impact of past and current budgets and how to optimize opportunities. The seminar is supported by StarHub and NTU's Business School, and registration is available at eventreg.asiaone.com/register/Budget2015.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: History, logic and market forces say oil prices will rise again
summary: Oil prices are expected to rise again as they have done in the past, despite recent declines. The price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil has fallen 57% since June 2014, but history shows that it has recovered in the past, with five previous drops of a similar percentage. Increased supply due to fracking technology and rising demand are contributing factors, but the supply situation is expected to balance out by the end of this year. The rise of alternative energy sources and increased oil consumption will also delay the adoption of renewables, making a gradual price increase the logical conclusion.

site_title: Brazil graft probe won't extend to Rousseff: media
summary: Brazil's graft probe into Petrobras won't extend to President Dilma Rousseff, according to reports from Brazilian media. Prosecutor general Rodrigo Janot will not investigate Rousseff or her election rival Aecio Neves, citing insufficient references. Rousseff was chairman of Petrobras' board from 2003-2010 and was implicated in the scandal, but the probe will focus on 54 people, including politicians with parliamentary immunity. The investigation, sparked by a whistleblower, alleges US$3.8 billion in kickbacks from inflated Petrobras contracts.

site_title: Jazz affair in Words & Music
summary: The National University of Singapore's 10th Arts Festival will feature a novel jazz musical production, "Words & Music: A Love Story Told in Jazz," opening on March 20. Based on American playwright AR Gurney's "Love Letters," the show combines original songs and jazz standards, performed by small ensembles and a full band. Directed by Singapore jazz veteran Jeremy Monteiro, the production showcases original words and music, with a unique blend of classic and contemporary pieces. The festival aims to promote arts appreciation among non-arts students and make the arts a part of daily life.

site_title: Major banks in US all pass first phase of stress tests
summary: The 31 largest US banks passed the first phase of stress tests, with the majority meeting the minimum 5.0% core capital ratio. Investment banks Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley were among the weakest performers due to their capital market exposure. Despite this, the banks demonstrated resilience in withstanding a severe economic crisis, with the average Tier 1 capital ratio increasing to 8.2% from 7.6% last year. The Federal Reserve praised the industry's progress in strengthening capital levels, citing the tests as a measure of the financial system's resiliency.

site_title: OW Bunker and the failure in governance
summary: OW Bunker, a global marine fuel logistics firm, collapsed due to lack of transparency and conflicts of business roles. The company's CEO and finance manager extended a $125 million credit to a supplier without board approval, leading to a $150 million loss. An aggressive risk-taking culture and inadequate remuneration policy contributed to the failure. The company's subsidiaries, including Dynamic Oil Trading, had significant autonomy, with boards composed mainly of employees within the group. The lack of transparency and governance oversight led to a governance lacuna, resulting in moral hazard and excessive risk-taking.

site_title: McDonald's to cut back on antibiotics-fed chickens in US
summary: McDonald's plans to stop serving chicken raised with antibiotics important to human health, a move in response to growing consumer demand for healthier food. The company will work with poultry farmers to only use poultry-specific antibiotics not used on people, and will phase out the practice over the next two years. This move follows similar initiatives by other companies, such as Chik-fil-A and Purdue, and aims to reduce antibiotic resistance. The change is seen as a step towards better meeting customer expectations for healthier food.

site_title: City buzz
summary: Air Supply is celebrating 40 years of love songs with a concert. The band's hit songs, such as "All Out of Love" and "Every Woman in the World," have become iconic in the music industry.

site_title: Search for MH370 may be scaled back, says Australian PM
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott suggests scaling back the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which vanished on March 8, 2014, with 239 people on board. The search, led by Australia, has been ongoing for a year, with a budget of A$120 million. Despite finding a few shipping containers, no trace of the plane has been found. Abbott expresses hope for a successful search and promises to continue efforts to solve the mystery and provide answers to the families of the victims.

site_title: Abercrombie remains adrift; sales miss analysts' estimates
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co reported a 10% decline in fourth-quarter sales at comparable stores, worse than analysts' estimated 8.2% drop. The teen retailer struggled to attract customers during the holidays, leading to the disappointing sales figures. Abercrombie is currently searching for a new CEO. The company's sales decline is attributed to its inability to lure customers, resulting in a lower-than-expected revenue.

site_title: Chicago's Willis Tower up for sale
summary: Chicago's Willis Tower, the 1,450-foot skyscraper, is up for sale with a potential asking price of $1.5 billion. The 110-story building, once the world's tallest, was last sold in 2004 for $841 million. The sale could set a record for an office building in the third-largest US city, driven by investors seeking higher yields in commercial property. The building's 1970s construction and iconic status may impact its value.

site_title: En pointe on the silver screen
summary: The Paris Opera Ballet will be broadcast on the silver screen in April, showcasing three classic works. This marks the company's first live broadcast in Singapore since 2012. Although the audience won't experience live performances, they will watch historic footage of the Paris Opera Ballet's acclaimed technique and versatility. The event aims to bring ballet enthusiasts in Singapore closer to the art form, despite the lack of live performances.

site_title: UK election risks add to EU disintegration concerns
summary: The UK is set to dissolve Parliament ahead of the May 7 general election, with a hung Parliament a likely outcome. This could have significant implications for UK foreign policy, including a potential "fast-track exit" from the European Union and a renewed commitment to Britain's independent nuclear arsenal. A second hung Parliament could lead to a coalition or minority government, potentially injecting uncertainty into the debate over EU membership and Trident renewal, with key international ramifications.

images.alt_text: The closer the Conservatives or Labour get to 326 of the total 650 seats in the House of Commons, the more likely a minority administration will come about.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental's FY14 profit, revenue edge up
summary: Mandarin Oriental International reported a net profit of US$97 million for FY14, up 1% from the previous year, with revenue rising 2% to US$1.39 billion. Earnings per share increased to 9.67 US cents. The results came despite challenging market conditions, particularly in Hong Kong, where two hotels experienced strong performance but were impacted by demonstrations in Q4.

site_title: Making do with more in the Information Age
summary: In the US, only 30% of the workforce is needed to produce goods, while the remaining 70% focuses on planning, services, and management. Despite having enough resources to cover basic needs, workers and middle-class households continue to struggle, and productivity growth has been stagnant. The shift from "rival" and "excludible" goods to Information Age goods, which are easily shared and can't be monetized, has created a paradox where people are producing and consuming more than the economy indicates. To sustain a middle-class society, the economic system must be redesigned to value the goods produced in the Information Age and provide fair compensation to creators.

site_title: Imperfect nuclear deal with Iran is better than no deal at all
summary: US and Iran in nuclear talks; a deal could lift economic sanctions and allow cooperation on fighting ISIS, but critics argue it would allow Iran to retain centrifuges and potentially develop a nuclear bomb. Iranian restrictions on uranium enrichment and nuclear facility inspections are agreed upon, but time-limited, raising concerns. An imperfect deal is seen as better than no deal, potentially reducing tensions and destabilizing the Middle East.

site_title: UK govt sells its stake in Eurostar rail for £585m
summary: The UK government has sold its 40% stake in the Eurostar rail link to a consortium of Caisse de Depot du Placement du Quebec (CDPQ) and Hermes for £585m. The sale price exceeded expectations, generating an additional £172m for the UK Treasury. The remaining 60% of Eurostar is held by French and Belgian rail operators. The deal is part of the UK's plan to raise £20 billion by selling off publicly owned assets to pay down national debts. Regulatory approval and shareholder approval are required for successful completion.

site_title: Streaming - and the new Normal
summary: A new play, "Normal," tackles the Singaporean education system's emphasis on streaming, where students are categorized into Normal, Express, or Polytechnic streams based on academic performance. The play explores the impact of this system on a child's morale and confidence, particularly for those in the Normal stream. Written by Faith Ng, who came from the Normal stream herself, the play follows two girls navigating the pressures of the school system and parental expectations. It highlights the long-lasting effects of negative reinforcement and the importance of self-acceptance.

images.alt_text: Claire Chung (left) and Audrey Teong star as two girls struggling to cope in the Normal stream in Faith Ng's play "Normal".
Helmi Yusof

site_title: OCBC suggests partial sale of KepLand shares as a hedge
summary: OCBC Investment Research recommends that Keppel Land shareholders sell part of their holdings at S$4.54 to S$4.55 to hedge out the risk of the offer not reaching the 90% acceptance level, which could lead to a lower offer price of S$4.38. Most analysts believe Keppel Corp can amass enough acceptances to cross the 90% threshold, but a portion of shares can be sold at the current price to lock in a higher value of S$4.60.

site_title: Keppel unit's UK energy project up and running
summary: Keppel Seghers, a UK energy-from-waste project, has begun commercial operations, processing up to 425,000 tonnes of refuse-derived fuel per year. The facility is one of the largest in Europe, aiming to divert over 75% of Greater Manchester's waste from landfills. When fully operational, it will process up to 850,000 tonnes annually, helping to reduce waste. Keppel Seghers is a wholly owned unit of Keppel Infrastructure, a division of Keppel Corp.

site_title: Abercrombie selling company plane; marks end of an era
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co is selling its private plane, marking the end of an era for the teen retailer. The company, struggling to regain its cachet, wrote down the value of the aircraft by $11 million and has yet to find a buyer. Following the departure of former CEO Mike Jeffries, the company is seeking a new CEO and a lower-key image, with a focus on reducing logo-emblazoned clothes. Same-store sales plummeted 10% in the last quarter, sending shares tumbling 16%. The move is part of Abercrombie's efforts to adapt to changing consumer preferences.

site_title: The role of soft power in S'pore's foreign policy
summary: Singapore's foreign policy relies heavily on its "soft power," leveraging its successful governance model, economic policies, and global connectivity to win foreign friends and shape global developments. Minister of Foreign Affairs K Shanmugam emphasized the importance of remaining exceptional and giving back to the international community to maintain relevance. Despite having little influence on major power relations, Singapore has carved a niche for itself by promoting regional platforms, such as Asean, to promote peace and prosperity.

site_title: SGX clarifies need for continuous all-day trading
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has clarified that its decision to implement continuous all-day trading (CAT) was based on a public consultation and aimed to minimize investment risks for all participants, not just algorithmic traders and high-frequency traders. The move was introduced in 2011 to reduce gap risks and volatility, and has since shown positive results. The SGX has stated that it will continue to review its operating hours to align with other Asian markets, but has no plans for 24-hour trading in the cash equity market.

site_title: 1MDB likely to be dismantled under debt repayment plan: sources
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund is likely to be dismantled under a debt repayment plan, with most of its assets to be sold. The fund, worth $14 billion, will sell 80% of its power unit Edra Energy and split its land assets and stakes in two high-profile projects. The plan aims to turn 1MDB into a "skeletal structure" that could eventually be dissolved. The government has appointed a new boss, Arul Kanda, to oversee the restructuring, which is expected to be completed in six to nine months.

site_title: Hongkong Land posts full-year profit of US$1.33b
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings reported a full-year net profit of US$1.33 billion, up from US$1.19 billion in the previous year, driven by a net gain of US$397 million from the valuation of its investment properties. Revenue rose to US$1.88 billion, with commercial properties performing well in Hong Kong, where office rent rose 3% to HK$102 per sq ft. The group's residential development business also contributed to the earnings, with sales of units in Hong Kong and Macau. A final dividend of 13.0 US cents per share is recommended.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: S'pore to see largest rise in number of ultra-rich
summary: Singapore is expected to see the largest increase in ultra-rich individuals over the next 10 years, with the city-state's ultra-high net worth (UHNW) population projected to grow by 54.3% to 4,979 by 2024, ranking 9th globally. This growth is attributed to the migration of HNWIs from China, India, and Indonesia, which will have a significant impact on the property market, particularly in high-end residential and commercial sectors. The global super-rich population is expected to increase 34% to 231,000, with Asia driving growth.

site_title: Tharman's Budget wrap
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam presented his budget, focusing on sustainable aviation and advanced chip packaging. The country is setting up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, and a new grant of up to SGD 100,000 is available for tariff-hit businesses. Graduates are advised to stay calm with better employment rates in early data. Tharman also plans to visit the US for trade talks.

site_title: 50 shades of a homegrown thriller
summary: Local erotic thriller "Lan Tong" has been deemed too raunchy for audiences, with censors cutting three minutes from the version currently playing in cinemas. The film, which features sex scenes including public fornication and sodomy, was initially shot early on to help actors lose their inhibitions. Writer-director Sam Loh defended the content, stating it made their work easier. An uncut version premiered at last year's Singapore International Film Festival, but was not suitable for general release. The film's explicit nature has left some audiences blushing.

site_title: CPF system is fair and sustainable
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) system is considered fair and sustainable, Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said in parliament. The system, which is both individual and collective, provides financial support to members through government transfers and is internationally recognized as one of the better retirement savings schemes. The government has introduced measures such as CPF Life and the Silver Support Scheme to supplement incomes and mitigate inequality. Despite calls for greater flexibility, the government has decided to retain the system's fiscal discipline and prudence, citing the risks of early payouts.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: S'pore execs link 39% of firm's market value to CEO reputation
summary: A survey by Weber Shandwick found that Singapore executives attribute 39% of a company's market value to a CEO's reputation, similar to the global average of 44%. The poll of 100 non-CEO executives from companies with annual revenues of $25 million and up suggests that public perception of a CEO is becoming increasingly important. Executives believe a visible public profile is crucial for a company to be highly regarded, with 83% saying it's essential. The findings highlight the importance of succession planning and managing public perception of a CEO.

site_title: Macquarie buys planes from AWAS for US$4b
summary: Macquarie Group is acquiring 90 passenger planes from AWAS Aviation Capital for US$4 billion, expanding its portfolio to 220 aircraft. The transaction, expected to settle over the next year, will add 5% to earnings per share in the first full year after acquisition. Macquarie will also raise at least A$500 million (S$535.5 million) to fund the acquisition, increasing its earnings potential.

site_title: STI falls ahead of expected Wall St weakness
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 20.26 points or 0.6% to 3,395.27 on Thursday, driven by declines in Jardine Matheson, Singtel, and Golden Agri-Resources. Despite this, US stocks rose to all-time highs earlier in the week, leading to speculation of potential weakness ahead of a key payrolls report on Friday. Meanwhile, shares of Innovalues rose S$0.03 to S$0.73 on volume of 6.2 million, and OCBC Investment Research highlighted a hedging opportunity in the ongoing Keppel Corp bid to take Keppel Land private.

site_title: StanChart profit falls 37% on impairments, US settlement
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 37% decline in 2014 profit due to impairments, US settlement, and cost-cutting measures. The bank cited higher bad loan charges, an accounting charge on its Korean business, and a previously announced $300 million fine related to money laundering. Despite the decline, the bank's new CEO, William Winters, plans to cut costs, sell assets, and remove riskier assets to bolster its financial strength. The bank also announced a management reshuffle and held its dividend unchanged.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip on lower volume in February: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dipped 0.6% in February, with overall prices falling 5.7% year-over-year, according to SRX Property. Resale volume fell 8.5% to 1,148 flats sold, down from 1,255 in January. Tightened credit, a three-year wait-out period for new residents, and rising Sibor rates are contributing factors. Despite this, resale volume rose 20.7% year-over-year. Experts expect HDB resale prices to fall 5-8% for 2015, with around 18,000-20,000 homes potentially changing hands.

site_title: Bank of England's role in rigging money market auctions under probe
summary: The Serious Fraud Office is investigating the Bank of England's possible role in rigging money market auctions during the 2007-2008 financial crisis. The investigation follows an independent inquiry commissioned by the Bank of England, which found that its former chief currency dealer, Martin Mallett, failed to alert his superiors about concerns he had about market problems. The Bank of England has referred the results of the inquiry to the Serious Fraud Office, which will lead to a criminal investigation casting a shadow over the central bank.

site_title: Amended: Redefining reserve returns
summary: Singapore's Official Foreign Reserves have been corrected to US$251 billion, down from the earlier stated S$251 billion. The correction was made to reflect the accurate conversion rate.

site_title: Jan factory orders fall, making it 6th straight monthly decline
summary: US factory orders fell 0.2% in January, marking the 6th straight monthly decline, according to the Commerce Department. Economists had expected a 0.2% gain. Manufacturing weakness is attributed to softening demand in Europe and Asia, a strong US dollar, and lower crude oil prices. Unfilled orders at factories fell 0.2% for a second straight month, while non-defence capital goods orders excluding aircraft rose 0.5%. The sector is expected to regain momentum in the second quarter.

site_title: Ride-sharing programme by Uber stopped in Japan
summary: Uber's ride-sharing pilot programme in Fukuoka, Japan has been ordered to stop due to violating the nation's road transportation law. The programme, which allowed users to share rides, was deemed illegal because it allowed unlicensed drivers to make money. Uber will revise its compensation model and continue to negotiate with authorities, while also revising the programme. This is a fresh blow to Uber, which faces regulatory challenges globally, particularly in cities like Tokyo and Seoul.

site_title: Apple to delay production of larger-screen iPads: sources
summary: Apple is delaying the production of a larger-screened iPad, initially planned for this quarter, due to supply chain issues with display panels. The 12.9-inch iPad is part of CEO Tim Cook's efforts to revitalize the iPad line, which has seen four consecutive quarters of declining sales. The delay is expected to push production to around September. This move aims to bolster Apple's iPad sales to businesses, which are seen as a growth opportunity, and follows the introduction of larger iPhones.

site_title: Vinous diary for CNY
summary: A wine writer reminisces about a 2000 Hermitage La Chapelle from Paul Jaboulet Aine, a wine that brought back fond memories of a late friend, Gerard Jaboulet, a renowned Rhone Valley winemaker. The wine had a rich, fruity taste with seductive savory undertones. The writer recalls Gerard's generosity and hospitality, including serving the 1961 La Chapelle at a dinner party before his passing in 1997. The writer also reviews two Chateau Rayas wines, a Chateau Angelus, and two Margaux wines, highlighting their unique characteristics and aging potential.

site_title: Military spending will still rise steadily
summary: Singapore will continue to increase military spending at a steady pace, despite regional tensions, according to Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen. In the Committee of Supply 2015 debate, Ng emphasized that Singapore will maintain its long-term approach to military spending. The country will closely monitor the situation but will not be swayed by regional developments. This stance is in line with Singapore's strategy to maintain a stable defense posture.

site_title: Sharp bets on another bailout; banks want bold overhaul at firm
summary: Japanese electronics firm Sharp Corp is seeking its second major bailout since 2012, with its main banks calling for a more drastic overhaul. The company may consider exiting the solar panels and plant closures, but banks want Sharp to follow the successful Panasonic and Sony with bolder moves. Sharp has a history of bailouts, with its banks agreeing to provide 360 billion yen in loans and credit lines in 2012. Credit rating agency Standard & Poor's Corp has downgraded Sharp's rating to "junk" territory, and banks are keen to avoid triggering a collapse.

site_title: 40% of cities see prime home prices fall or stay flat in 2014: Knight Frank
summary: Knight Frank's 2015 Wealth Report found 40% of cities saw prime home prices fall or stay flat, with US cities leading in price growth. New York saw the biggest growth, followed by Aspen, with luxury prices rising 18.8% and 16% respectively. Singapore's high-end residential segment was the hardest-hit, with prices down 10.4% due to cooling measures. The report suggests wealthy Chinese investors are driving demand for luxury properties, with many considering alternative citizenship or permanent residence abroad.

images.alt_text: AS various Asian cities find the prices of their prime residential properties pressured by macro-prudential measures, US cities topped the list of price growth for such units last year.

site_title: Time for digital financial innovation
summary: The financial industry is undergoing a revolution similar to the printing press's impact on human history, with the advent of digital financial innovation. Established banks are facing challenges from new operators, including fintech start-ups, which offer services more efficiently and introduce new ones. Countries with unbanked populations, such as Indonesia and Kenya, can leapfrog generations of technology to move to the future. Regulators must facilitate change, and those who adapt will thrive, while those who resist will be left behind. This revolution will lead to a new world of opportunity for digital innovators in financial services.

site_title: HKEx sees just US$9m revenue boost from Stock Connect
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd reported a US$9m revenue boost from its Stock Connect program with Shanghai in 2014, a disappointing figure given the program's potential. The program, launched in November, contributed HK$68 million (S$12 million) to revenue, with fourth-quarter profits reaching HK$1.52 billion. This capped profit growth, highlighting the program's underwhelming impact.

site_title: 60somethings bite back
summary: A play called Pioneer (Girls) Generation, featuring 60-something actors, explores the lives of retirees living in a Singaporean retirement village. The play tackles topics such as sex, relationships, and aging with humor and openness. The play's lead, Catherine Sng, shares her candid views on sex, stating she and her husband have more sex now than ever due to the lack of pregnancy worries. The play aims to showcase the lives of these retirees with authenticity and humor.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Euro nears 11½-year low ahead of QE plan
summary: The euro has fallen to a 11½-year low against the dollar, trading at US$1.1026, as investors await the European Central Bank's announcement of its massive bond-buying programme. The ECB decided to keep interest rates unchanged, which had little impact on the euro's value. This move comes ahead of the ECB's plan to increase quantitative easing, a measure to boost economic growth in the eurozone.

site_title: Hotel market staggers in New York City
summary: New York City's hotel market is experiencing a downturn due to a strong dollar and weak global economy, which could curb tourism and make the city less attractive to developers and investors. Rising interest rates may also make hotel construction and renovation too expensive. The sustained growth of the hotel sector has been a significant factor in the city's appeal, but a decline in tourism could have long-term consequences for the industry.

site_title: More analysts partial to L-shaped oil recovery
summary: Analysts and market watchers favor an L-shaped oil recovery, expecting a range of $50 to $60 per barrel for at least the next few years, rather than a U or V-shaped recovery. This prediction is based on shale oil growth and a reduced expectation of a near-term price surge to $100 per barrel. The International Energy Agency, BP, and even Saudi Arabia are among those supporting this view, which contradicts the market's initial optimism about a rapid price rebound.

site_title: NZ may tighten rules on property loans for investors
summary: New Zealand's central bank is considering tightening rules on property loans for investors to cool the Auckland housing market. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) is seeking views on how to define property investment loans and require banks to hold adequate capital for those loans. This move aims to address the risks associated with investment property lending without raising interest rates. The local dollar has already fallen in response to the announcement.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers provided updates on three companies: Innovalues, Keppel Land, and Swissco Holdings. Innovalues is expected to see revenue growth of 15-20% in FY15, driven by automotive and office equipment segments. Keppel Land's privatization offer is seen as having better-than-even odds of success, with a 73-77% probability of crossing the 90% compulsory acquisition threshold. Swissco Holdings is expected to secure a time-charter rate of at least US$75,000-US$80,000/day and add only two new rigs to its fleet in H2 2015.

site_title: Music and melancholy
summary: A romantic drama "Song One" follows Franny (Anne Hathaway), a PhD student in anthropology, who visits her brother Henry's hangouts after he's hit while crossing the street, to atone for her hostile response to his music career. She meets James (Johnny Flynn), a successful folk singer, and they form a connection while Henry is in a coma. The film explores music, romance, and self-discovery, showcasing the indie music scene in New York City. The original songs and actors' performances are praised, with the film mostly steering clear of melodrama.

site_title: IBM buys AlchemyAPI to bolster Watson technology
summary: IBM is acquiring AlchemyAPI, a machine-learning systems maker, to bolster its Watson technology. AlchemyAPI's software tools analyze and classify text and images, and its technology gets smarter with use. The acquisition will add services to Watson, expanding its capabilities. IBM has 160 partners developing applications on Watson's platform, with more than 3,800 pending. The deal is part of IBM's efforts to grow through newer businesses, as revenue has been falling for three straight years. The acquisition is also seen as a response to increasing competition in the data analytics and artificial intelligence fields.

site_title: Time for S'pore firms 'to venture out'
summary: Singapore companies should venture abroad to remain relevant in a shifting economic landscape, according to PwC Singapore Budget Seminar 2015. The seminar highlighted tax allowances and schemes to encourage local enterprises to expand globally. This move aims to boost economic growth and competitiveness in the region. The seminar emphasized the importance of internationalisation to stay relevant in the current economic climate.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: S&P 500 slides after US$17b ETF outflows in 2015
summary: The S&P 500 index has experienced its largest two-day decline since January, falling 0.9% after US$16.8 billion in outflows from exchange-traded funds (ETFs) tracking American equities in 2015. Investors are rethinking their loyalty to equities amid rising interest rates and a strengthening dollar, with the S&P 500 trading at a 18.7 times earnings multiple near its highest level since 2010. This has led to a shift towards bonds and other asset classes, with outflows from US equities exceeding $28.3 billion in the quarter.

site_title: Beijing pares economic growth target to around 7%, calls it new normal
summary: China has lowered its 2015 GDP growth target to approximately 7% as the country rebalances and faces slower global growth. The new target reflects the government's recognition of a "new normal" of slower growth, with trimmed targets for trade growth, fixed-asset investment, and retail sales. The inflation target is also cut to 3% this year, while money supply growth is set at 12%. The government has reaffirmed its commitment to structural reforms, including liberalizing the financial system and reducing vested interests among state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Tharman gives assurance of fiscal sustainability
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam assured Parliament on March 5, 2015, that the government has been prudent in its budgeting, even with a temporary boost in revenues. He highlighted the government's "healthy" financial position, with a deficit mainly due to funds set aside for future investments. Tharman emphasized the importance of long-term sustainability, referencing Singapore's Constitution and the net investment returns (NIR) framework, which ensures the preservation of reserves for future generations. He assured parliamentarians that the government will never cross the red line of failing to balance its budget within each term of government.

images.alt_text: In seeking to build a fair and inclusive society, Singapore has built a system that will endure through generations - and certainly beyond each election cycle.

site_title: ECB to launch one trillion euro bond buying scheme on March 9
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced it will launch a one trillion euro bond-buying scheme on March 9, aiming to boost the eurozone economy and lift inflation. The program will purchase sovereign debt until at least September 2016, with a monthly spending of 60 billion euros. This move follows accelerating growth in the eurozone, with major consumption and leading indicators beating forecasts.

site_title: US jobless claims rise; Q4 productivity revised down
summary: US jobless claims rose unexpectedly to 320,000 for the week ended Feb 28, exceeding economists' expectations. Nonfarm productivity contracted at a 2.2% annual rate in the fourth quarter, revised down from the initial 1.8% pace. The revisions indicate a weaker economy.

site_title: Covers that raise the bar
summary: Diana Krall's album "Wallflower" features easy-listening soft rock classics, including tracks by Elton John, The Eagles, and The Carpenters, with a distinctive raspy vocal style. The album, produced by David Foster, is a predictable yet pleasant listen. Jamie Cullum's "Interlude" is a swinging big band covers album with a mix of jazz and indie influences. Annie Lennox's "Nostalgia" features her powerful vocals on standards from the Great American Songbook. All three albums received ratings of B-.

site_title: Banks in US brace for second part of Fed's stress test
summary: The Federal Reserve is set to release the first part of its annual "stress tests" for US banks, evaluating their financial health against a severe economic shock. The test will determine which of the 31 banks have enough shareholder capital, with Deutsche Bank and Santander likely to fail. The results will influence the banks' ability to pay dividends, with those that fail facing reduced payouts. The Fed aims to gauge the banks' risk management and capital adequacy to prevent a repeat of the 2007-09 crisis.

site_title: Thai developer LPN sees condo market slowing
summary: Thailand's largest condominium developer, LPN Development, is cautious about buying land due to weakening domestic demand for high-rise buildings and restricted lending by banks. The company's managing director, Opas Sripayak, stated that several developers are shifting focus to single-detached houses and townhomes after condominium bookings slowed in recent months. This trend is a response to the decline in demand and the need to adapt to the changing market.

site_title: US factory orders fall again in January
