The FTSE 100 and DAX 30 indices closed at record highs, while the CAC 40 fell. The ECB's decision-making council will meet on Thursday to outline the bond purchase program.

site_title: Dating app Tinder premium plan aims at under-30 crowd
summary: Tinder, a popular smartphone dating app, has launched a premium paid subscription version called Tinder Plus. The new tiered plan charges users under 30 $9.99 a month and older subscribers $19.99. The pricing system has drawn criticism, with some labeling it "age discriminatory." However, Tinder's spokesman defended the move, citing test results that younger users are more budget-constrained. The premium plan offers features such as unlimited liking capabilities, Passport to change location, and Rewind to "take back" a swipe.

site_title: Facebook fends off telecom firms' complaints
summary: Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg defended the company against complaints from telecom firms that the social network generates significant revenue while the companies host its service on smartphones. Zuckerberg stated that Facebook wants to work with telecom companies to launch smartphone internet access in developing countries, but acknowledged the need for a profitable model. Telecom executives, such as Telenor's Jon Fredrik Baksaas, expressed concerns about the financial impact of Facebook's free messaging services, which bypass their paid services. Zuckerberg and telecom companies are working to find a balance between providing internet access and generating revenue.

site_title: Bill Gates tops Forbes rich list, Michael Jordan joins
summary: Bill Gates tops Forbes' annual list of the world's richest people for the 16th year, with a net worth of $79.2 billion. Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg joined the top 20, and basketball star Michael Jordan made the list for the first time, ranking 1,741st with a $1 billion net worth. The number of billionaires rose to a record 1,826, worth $7.05 trillion, with the US having the most billionaires, followed by China and Germany.

site_title: RMB under pressure after Beijing cuts rates; more easing expected
summary: China's central bank cut interest rates for the second time in three months to support a sluggish economy and ward off deflation risks. The move is expected to benefit the property market and state-owned enterprises, but may weaken the renminbi. Economists believe a sharp drop in the renminbi is unlikely. The rate cut cycle may also impact Asian economies, particularly those with strong ties to China.

site_title: Sweden eyes fingerprint scans to stop passport fraud
summary: Sweden is considering fingerprint scans for all nationalities entering the country from outside the Schengen Area to combat passport fraud. The proposal aims to address the issue of "lookalike abuse," where individuals use a passport belonging to someone who looks similar to themselves. Sweden, which expects 90,000 asylum seekers in 2015, has seen 950 such cases reported annually, with 77% of those coming from Turkey. The move would pre-empt the European Union's potential mandatory screenings.

site_title: OCBC reinvents miles redemption with new card
summary: OCBC has introduced a new credit card that allows users to redeem miles for travel bookings directly, breaking the traditional system of air miles redemption. The move aims to boost card spending by 30% this year, as credit card spending growth slows in Singapore. The bank's new strategy also reflects the increasing competition from non-bank lenders in the market.

site_title: 5G is the next big thing but no one knows why
summary: The wireless industry is poised for the rollout of 5G technology by 2020, but first, they must define what new features it will offer beyond the current 4G network. The GSMA estimates operators will spend $1.7 trillion on equipment upgrades, but experts say there's no need for significant upgrades unless 5G delivers radical improvements in speed and functions. 5G promises faster speeds, denser network coverage, and the "Internet of Things," but its technical standards are still unclear, and the industry must navigate the challenges of limited spectrum and competing technologies like Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.

site_title: Oil prices drop on lofty supplies
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) falling 17 cents to $49.59 a barrel and European benchmark Brent North Sea crude falling $3.04 to $59.54 a barrel. Analysts attributed the drop to excess global supplies, particularly a partial recovery in Libyan oil production, and high crude inventories. The gap between Brent and WTI had widened to over $12, prompting some analysts to expect WTI to recover lost ground.

site_title: Eurozone prices, jobs firm but deflation threat remains
summary: The eurozone's consumer price index eased slightly, with jobless figures picking up slightly, but deflationary fears persist due to falling oil prices. The European Central Bank is expected to take drastic measures to prevent economic stagnation. Analysts welcome the modest improvements, but the ECB must still act to mitigate the deflation threat.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices in the 19-nation euro zone were down 0.3 per cent in February, less than the drop of 0.6 per cent in January when tumbling energy prices slashed the cost of living.

site_title: Fund managers' love of consumer stocks is paying off in 2015
summary: Hedge funds are experiencing a resurgence in their investments in consumer discretionary companies, outperforming the broader market. The sector has gained about 6% for the year, more than double the Standard & Poor's 500 Index. This follows a weak performance in 2014, but is attributed to factors such as cheap gasoline, a strong dollar, and the strong performance of Netflix. The Consumer Discretionary Index has led the current bull market, with a 380% gain since 2009, compared to 212% for the broader S&P 500 Index.

site_title: Loh Boon Chye leaving BofA Merrill Lynch
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Singapore executive Loh Boon Chye is leaving the firm after 17 years, citing a desire to take a break before deciding on his next endeavor. A veteran banker, Loh helped build the bank's global markets franchise across the region, increasing market share and client penetration. He will be replaced by Chris Gammons, who has 20 years of experience serving Asian clients in Singapore and South-east Asia.

site_title: US warns Israel PM not to 'betray' trust on nuclear deal
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry warned Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu not to reveal details of an emerging Iran nuclear deal, citing concerns that it would "betray" America's trust. Kerry made the comments in Geneva as talks with Iranian counterpart Mohammad Javad Zarif aimed to pin down a deal by a March 31 deadline. Netanyahu planned to elaborate on the deal in his congressional address, but Kerry urged restraint, stating that releasing classified information would compromise the trust between the two countries. The US and Iran are racing against time to reach a deal.

site_title: Swensen's operator on property trail
summary: ABR Holdings, the Singapore franchisee for Swensen's ice-cream and restaurants, has evaluated 10 property development opportunities but remains undecided. The company aims to diversify into residential and commercial properties in Singapore, Malaysia, or Australia, but is cautious about rushing into a project. ABR Holdings has net cash of around S$80 million and is currently focused on maintaining stable margins and growth in its existing business, including its Malaysian operations and a confectionery business called Season's.

site_title: Outlook for projects still positive, says Yongnam
summary: Yongnam Holdings, a structural steel contractor and specialist civil engineering solutions provider, posted a net loss of S$8.5 million for FY2014 due to a 41.4% plunge in revenue and lower project margins. Despite this, the company remains positive about the outlook for infrastructural developments and commercial projects in Singapore and the region, with a S$1.1 billion worth of new projects planned. The company's order book stands at S$405 million, with 60% expected to be completed in 2015.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Sino Construction dives after profit warning
summary: Sino Construction's shares plummeted 55.8% on Monday after the company warned of an expected net loss for FY14 and a month-long delay in releasing its financial results. The stock closed at S$0.117, wiping off S$194 million from its market cap. Despite this, the company's sole executive director, Drew Madacsi, remains unfazed, attributing the selloff to a "knee-jerk reaction" and a small trading volume. Analysts warn that the company needs to communicate its strategy and outlook to the market, and the selloff may present a buying opportunity, but with caution.

site_title: Mixed fortunes for S'pore-listed commodity traders
summary: Singapore-listed commodity traders Wilmar International, Olam International, and Noble Group reported mixed quarterly results, with Wilmar bucking the trend by recording a net profit gain despite falling revenues. Olam was hit by currency devaluation, while Noble recorded its first quarterly loss in three years due to "one-off" impairments and negative goodwill. Analysts remain optimistic about Wilmar's cheap valuations and growth prospects, with Citi and UBS placing "buy" calls on the stock.

images.alt_text: PLUNGING commodity prices in 2014 had varying effects on Singapore-listed commodity traders - Wilmar International, Olam International and Noble Group - which reported mixed quarterly results last month.

site_title: Japan's Q4 business capital expenditure growth slows
summary: Japan's Q4 business capital expenditure growth slowed to 2.8% year-over-year, down from a 5.5% gain in the prior quarter. The data suggests little revision to the preliminary GDP growth rate of 2.2% for the fourth quarter, with analysts citing sluggish demand and companies taking a wait-and-see stance. This slowdown in business investment raises concerns about the strength of Japan's economy, which is seen as key to spurring growth.

site_title: Consumer spending up in January as fuel prices fall
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.3% in January, boosted by falling fuel prices, but manufacturing and construction spending declined in February. The increase in consumer spending followed a 0.1% drop in the prior month, while incomes grew 0.3% for the second month.

site_title: StanChart staff brace for big change under new chief
summary: Standard Chartered's new CEO Bill Winters faces significant challenges to reverse the bank's 2-year slump in fortunes. He must tackle issues including cleaning up bad loans, raising at least $4 billion in capital, trimming costs, and improving investment banking performance. Winters lacks experience in Asia, where the bank's problems lie, and insiders expect further major changes, including potential job cuts. Analysts differ on the bank's capital needs, but a consensus is at least $4 billion to achieve a core capital ratio of 11% by year-end.

site_title: Industrial building next to Bendemeer Station fetches S$88m
summary: A Singapore industrial building next to the upcoming Bendemeer MRT Station has been sold for S$88 million. The 79,818 square foot property, completed in 2002, has a balance lease term of 50 years and is nearly fully let. Market watchers believe the buyer, likely eyeing capital appreciation, will refurbish the building and seek permission for strata subdivision. The property's prime location and ample car parking facilities make it attractive, with a zoned Business 1 use under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan 2014.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Berkshire insurance 'superstar' could fill Buffett's shoes
summary: Warren Buffett has identified Ajit Jain and Greg Abel as potential successors to his CEO role at Berkshire Hathaway. Jain, 63, has been instrumental in growing the company's insurance businesses, while Abel, 52, leads Berkshire's energy companies. Buffett praised Jain as a "superstar" who "loves what he does" and is not looking to take his job. Buffett's second-in-command, Charlie Munger, also supports Jain and Abel as front-runners for the top job, citing their "brains" and "unmatchable" underwriting skills.

site_title: IBM's top brains working on a 'brain in a box'
summary: IBM researchers are developing a "brain in a box" by mimicking the human brain's structure and processing capabilities. The brain's efficiency in processing information, despite consuming little power, is a unique feature that sets humans apart from machines. IBM's efforts aim to replicate this efficiency in a machine, enabling faster decision-making and processing. This project focuses on creating a more intelligent and efficient computing system, potentially revolutionizing the field of artificial intelligence.

site_title: India's gamble on investment- led growth
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has announced a public investment-led growth strategy, delaying a planned reduction in the fiscal deficit to 3% of GDP by a year. The government will instead use savings from cheaper oil to boost capital expenditure, with a 26% increase in infrastructure spending. The goal is to upgrade India's rickety transport and power networks, but the move may be seen as too lax by investors, potentially leading to capital flight. Despite the risks, the government hopes to sustain a big push to public investment, which could make India the envy of the West.

site_title: Chipmaker NXP to buy Freescale in US$11.8b deal
summary: NXP Semiconductors announced a $11.8 billion deal to acquire Freescale Semiconductor, creating a major player in the chip industry. The merger will help the companies better compete with customers like car manufacturers and phone makers. NXP will pay $6.25 per share in cash and 0.3521 of one of its shares for each Freescale share, valuing Freescale at its existing market capitalization. The deal is expected to create an industry powerhouse focused on high-growth opportunities in the "smarter world."

site_title: New China property rule to aid graft fight
summary: China has implemented a new property registration regulation, allowing authorities to collect ownership data on a unified platform, aiming to strengthen protection of ownership and combat corruption. The regulation, which went into effect on Sunday, will create a nationwide database accessible during property transactions and among government agencies. Analysts expect the move to increase home supply and drive down prices, while also making it harder for corrupt officials to illicitly own multiple homes. The government hopes to use the data to design a more reliable property taxation scheme.

site_title: Sibor up again, now more than double last year's rate
summary: The three-month Sibor in Singapore has surged to 0.786%, more than double its rate last year, due to the US dollar's rally. The Singapore dollar has weakened against the US dollar, losing 7.3% in the past six months. Homebuyers are seeking fixed interest rate loans to protect against further rate hikes, with DBS Bank reporting an increase in enquiries for fixed rate packages. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to recenter the exchange rate in April, according to analysts, but its decision may be influenced by the economy's growth forecast of 2-4% in 2015.

site_title: CIMB cuts 15 jobs in Singapore a week after 50 elsewhere in Asia
summary: CIMB Group Holdings has cut 15 jobs in Singapore, primarily from its equities segment, following a similar move that resulted in 50 job losses in Asia last week. The layoffs are part of a restructuring effort aimed at reducing costs amid a waning equities backdrop and a lack of merger and acquisition deals in the region. This move comes as CIMB's new CEO, Tengku Zafrul Aziz, seeks to scale back and refocus the investment banking business.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Malaysia Airlines to trim capacity
summary: Malaysia Airlines plans to trim its European and Middle Eastern routes by reviewing network contribution and profitability, potentially leading to cancellations. The airline will instead focus on domestic and regional routes, expanding capacity by 6-8% per annum. As part of a RM6 billion recovery plan, Malaysia Airlines Bhd will review previous contracts, including catering agreements, to meet market-based requirements. The airline aims to achieve a compounded annual growth rate of over 5% from 2015-20 and project a return to profitability by end-2017.

site_title: A great start to making it easier to do business in India
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley presented a budget that sets a positive tone for the country's future, predicting a 8.1-8.5% GDP growth rate. The budget aims to ease doing business, with proposals for a comprehensive bankruptcy law, pre-regulatory compliance mechanism, and a rationalisation of corporate tax rates. The government also announced a delay in fiscal consolidation, reduced corporate tax from 30% to 25% over four years, and introduced measures to curb black money. The budget includes a National Investment and Infrastructure Fund, increased public expenditure, and a focus on the "Make in India" programme and universal social security.

site_title: The public-private formula for universal health coverage
summary: The public-private formula for universal health coverage is being re-examined to determine the optimum mix of government and private sector engagement in providing health services, financing, regulation, and information management. The UHC concept is often confused with a one-size-fits-all approach of financing through universal health insurance, but a mixed framework is needed to balance equity and efficiency. Governments should increase UHC and improve basic public health care, allowing for private sector participation in promoting healthy competition and higher quality care. Empirical evidence shows that an optimum mix of public and private care can improve accessibility, efficiency, and quality, but sustainability must also be a prime consideration.

site_title: Former Tyco chief out of jail and living modestly
summary: Former Tyco CEO Dennis Kozlowski, convicted of looting nearly $100 million from the company, has been released from prison after serving 6.5 years. He has paid his debt to society and now lives modestly with his new wife, Kimberly, in a two-bedroom rental overlooking the East River. Kozlowski acknowledges his past mistakes and maintains he was unfairly convicted, particularly in light of the lack of big-name prosecutions during the 2008 financial crisis. He has started low-level consulting work and plans to open his own M&A advisory shop, and has been granted parole after serving 6.5 years in prison.

site_title: Brazil cracks down on protesting truckers
summary: Brazilian police cracked down on striking truckers, arresting protesters and ending roadblocks in all but two states. Demonstrations turned violent, slowing food deliveries and affecting Latin America's largest economy. Authorities arrested at least eight people, sent riot police to some areas, and imposed steep fines on those blocking roads illegally. The nearly two-week-old movement over rising freight costs continues, with protesters demanding more action from the government.

site_title: EU pushing for unity to end row over Tsipras's comments on Spain, Portugal
summary: The European Union is mediating a dispute between Greece and its eurozone partners Spain and Portugal over comments made by Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, who likened pressure from Spain and Portugal to blackmail. Tsipras accused them of undermining debt talks with Brussels. Madrid and Lisbon have lodged a formal complaint with the European Commission. The EU is seeking to resolve the row and maintain unity among member states.

site_title: Prices of small private housing units holding out well - for now
summary: Singapore's small private housing units, typically up to 506 sq ft, have seen a 0.6% month-on-month decline in January, the smallest among four index categories. Year-on-year, prices of small units have fallen 4.1%, while the Central Region sub-index dropped 6.6%. Experts predict prices may ease further due to increased competition from HDB flats and rising vacancy rates in suburban condo developments, potentially leading to disposal of these units at lower prices.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: In brief
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) signed pre-lease agreements for 1 million sq ft in São Paulo, Brazil, with Sequoia Logistica and pharmaceutical firms Sanofi and Medley.

site_title: More than 80 exhibitors sign up for Natas fair
summary: The National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (Natas) fair is set to take place this weekend, featuring over 80 exhibitors from the travel industry, including ASA Holidays, Royal Caribbean Cruises, and Singapore Airlines. The fair, which was moved from its original March 27-29 dates, aims to capitalize on the start of the travel-booking season and provide a platform for exhibitors to sell their inventories. The event is seen as a response to rival fair Travel Revolution 2015, which is also being held in Singapore and has attracted over 50 participating travel brands.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China's tech industry takes on food safety
summary: China's tech industry is launching innovative solutions to tackle the country's food safety issues. Apps like Alibaba's Jutudi and Joyvio's tracking system allow consumers to monitor the origin and quality of food products, from farm to table. Smart gadgets, such as Baidu's smart chopsticks, test for contaminants like gutter oil. These initiatives aim to increase transparency and trust in the food supply chain, addressing the country's persistent food safety scandals.

images.alt_text: A employee of fruit producer Joyvio explains how to use a smartphone to trace the origin of fruit. Scanning a code will provide details of the fruit's journey from the farm. It also details soil and water tests.

site_title: UK Feb house-price growth eases
summary: UK house-price growth slowed to 5.7% in February, the lowest in 17 months, according to Nationwide Building Society. This marks a decrease from 6.8% in January and 0.1% from the previous month. Despite the slowdown, mortgage approvals rose for a second month in January, and underlying factors such as low borrowing costs, tax cuts, and rising employment suggest the market may be stabilizing.

site_title: Record Sydney home sales fuel bubble fears
summary: Sydney home sales reached an 80% success rate for the fourth consecutive week, the longest stretch on record, amid a projected interest-rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. This boost in cheap finance is fueling the city's biggest property market, with prices rising 14.7% from last year. The surge in housing prices has led to a record 139% debt-to-income ratio in the third quarter of 2014, raising concerns about a property bubble. Economists predict a 25 basis-point cash rate reduction, further increasing the market's momentum.

site_title: Zooming ahead with technology
summary: Bee Advantage, a Singapore-based technology solutions provider, aims to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) improve business processes and performance through workflow and process automation, data analytics, and customized solutions. Founded by Joseph Kalaivanar in 2014, the company offers low-cost workflow automation and data analytics solutions, partnering with a Microsoft-certified data analytics partner to deliver tailored solutions. Bee Advantage has secured two advanced-level prospects against larger companies in the US and Europe and is currently working with the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore to develop an Internet-of-Things prototype for machine-to-web interaction.

site_title: Apple car reports fuel Geneva debate about car of the future
summary: Apple's potential car project has sparked debate at the Geneva car show, with carmakers concerned about software companies' innovative capabilities and new revenue streams. Technology giant Apple may be building a car, with estimates suggesting it could surpass the combined market value of major carmakers. Industry experts believe a "brain" of next-generation vehicles will be controlled by either carmakers or tech companies, with the latter gaining an edge in the next five years. Carmakers are investing in high-tech capabilities to stay competitive, but the shift towards software-driven vehicles poses significant challenges.

site_title: UK govt fails to block deal between German, Russian energy firms
summary: The UK government failed to block a deal between German energy firm RWE and a Russian-controlled investment company, L1 Energy, to buy RWE Dea's oil and gas subsidiary for 5 billion euros. RWE Dea's holdings include a large North Sea natural gas field called Breagh. The deal, worth 7.6 billion euros, was finalized despite British concerns about potential sanctions on the gas field due to its proximity to Ukraine. The move is seen as a significant development in the energy sector, with implications for the UK's energy security.

site_title: Sale of billionaire's home uncovers dirty secrets
summary: A London mansion once owned by Kazakh billionaire Mukhtar Ablyazov is being sold to repay a £14 million debt to the BTA Bank, which accused Ablyazov of embezzling $6 billion. The sale highlights the UK's vulnerability to money laundering through real estate, with hundreds of billions of pounds laundered annually. The government plans to publish a national risk assessment of money laundering and terrorist financing, and legislation is being drawn up to require the ultimate owner of UK companies to be listed on a registry. The practice of using trust funds and offshore companies to buy properties minimizes taxes and protects privacy.

site_title: China Feb HSBC PMI at 7-month high but more rate cuts seen likely
summary: China's factory sector activity reached a seven-month high in February, but export orders shrank and deflationary pressures persisted, according to a private business survey. This added to the view that more interest rate cuts are likely to be needed to address the country's cooling property market, high debt levels, and excess factory capacity. Policymakers are embarking on their biggest easing campaign since the global crisis, aiming to boost the economy.

site_title: Japan's Reits prefer share sales to bonds as property market turns bullish
summary: Japan's real estate investment trusts (Reits) are raising funds from shares rather than bonds, amid a bullish property market driven by Abenomics. Reits offered 222 billion yen of equity this year, with note sales dropping 39% to 23 billion yen. Tokyo office prices have risen to their highest since 2008, with land values increasing at 125 out of 150 monitored sites. Reits have increased property purchases by 72% and assets have more than doubled since their listing in 2014. Experts expect real estate prices to continue rising, with Reits playing a key role in driving the market.

site_title: Late push puts STI into the black
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day with a 1.03-point gain at 3,403.89, despite a late push. The index was largely unaffected by China's interest-rate cut, which boosted the Hang Seng and China indices. The gains were driven by expectations of a strong Wall Street performance, but were also influenced by falls in DBS and OCBC shares. The market saw a 1.36 billion-unit turnover worth S$1.29 billion.

site_title: Tat Hong gains A$6.7m from Aussie property sale
summary: Tat Hong Holdings sold four Australian properties to Primewest Funds for A$23.3 million, generating a gain of A$6.7 million for the company. The properties were used for storage purposes and will be leased back for 12 years. Tat Hong is restructuring to deal with a business downturn and has previously sold non-core assets to increase working capital. The sale-and-leaseback transaction will be reported in Tat Hong's fourth-quarter results.

site_title: Boardrooms in Singapore still lagging in gender diversity: Hays survey
summary: Singapore's corporate boardrooms still lag behind in gender diversity, with only 27% of management positions held by women, according to a Hays survey. This is unchanged from last year and below the Asian average. China leads the region with 36% of management roles held by women, while Malaysia and Hong Kong follow closely. Hays emphasizes that progress is being made, but more needs to be done to support women in leadership positions and encourage flexible working practices.

site_title: Goldman S'pore investment bank team down by a third
summary: Goldman Sachs Singapore's investment banking team has shrunk by about 30% after 15 departures, including retirements, transfers, and redundancies. The team, which had around 45 people, is now down to 30. The departures include head of South-east Asia mergers and acquisitions Ruben Bhagobati and managing director Antoine Izard. Despite the reduction, Goldman Sachs remains committed to Singapore, with around 800 staff in the country, and its securities unit remains a major business in the region.

site_title: Saudi travel tycoon receives boost from pilgrimage travels
summary: Saudi travel tycoon Mohammed Al Madani's company, Al Tayyar Travel Group Holding Co, captures nearly half of Saudi Arabia's domestic market for VIP travelers. The company, which serves government workers and their families, logs at least 10 international trips per year. With millions of people moving in and out of the country annually, Al Tayyar Travel Group is Saudi Arabia's largest air travel business, catering to the needs of the kingdom's government and expat communities.

site_title: The problem with Japan's neglected graves
summary: Neglected graves are a growing problem in Japan due to low birth rates and depopulation. About 30,000 public cemeteries in Japan have abandoned graves, leading to serious issues such as unkempt graveyards and overdue payments. Local governments are removing neglected graves and transferring remains to charnel houses, often using public funds. The Tokyo metropolitan government has started surveying neglected graves, with over 1,095 graves with no surviving relatives being transferred in recent years. The problem is expected to worsen with Japan's aging population, with the number of graves estimated to reach 1.67 million by 2039.

site_title: SEC plans to level playing field for newer ETF firms
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is considering a plan to level the playing field for newer exchange-traded fund (ETF) firms by allowing them to assemble shares more flexibly. The current rule requires ETFs to use the same securities as their underlying index, but the oldest providers, such as Vanguard and BlackRock, are allowed to use similar securities. The change could benefit newer entrants into the market, such as Charles Schwab, and make ETFs more competitive in illiquid markets like bonds. The plan is still in its early stages and may not result in a formal rule change.

site_title: Indonesia's Feb inflation cools faster than expected, more rate cuts seen
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation eased to 6.29% in February, below expectations, due to lower oil prices. The central bank is expected to roll out more interest rate cuts to prop up growth. Economists predict a cumulative 75-basis-point cut in Bank Indonesia's policy interest rate corridor by year-end, taking the main rate to 6.75%. The country's economic activity is slowing, and falling oil and commodities prices are a concern.

site_title: Near Fed majority backs June liftoff that Yellen hasn't yet endorsed
summary: A near majority of the Federal Reserve's 17 members support a possible June interest rate hike, despite Chair Janet Yellen's reluctance to endorse the move. Seven members want the option of a June tightening, while four oppose it, citing an economy and labor markets still far from readiness for rate hikes. The Fed is likely to remove language on a "patient" approach to raising rates at its March 17-18 meeting, potentially paving the way for a June increase or a September liftoff.

site_title: US$ up again on positive US data, China rate cut
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen on Monday, extending its gains after better-than-expected US growth data and China's interest rate cut. The dollar reached 119.85 yen, its highest level in nearly two years, amid improved risk sentiment. China's rate cut, citing "historically low inflation," supported buying of Japanese equities, while US growth data showed the economy grew 2.2% in the last quarter of 2014. The euro also gained, with dealers awaiting Thursday's European Central Bank monetary policy meeting.

site_title: S'pore again leads Asia in real estate investment
summary: Singapore investors led Asia in real estate investments in 2014, with $11.9 billion in properties acquired worldwide, a 26.6% increase from 2013. China and Hong Kong followed, with $10.1 billion and $6.3 billion, respectively. Asia's outbound real estate investment reached a record $40 billion, driven by emerging new sources of capital, such as Chinese insurers and Taiwanese property companies. Investment strategies have evolved, with investors diversifying into hotels, industrial assets, and beyond traditional gateway markets, with notable destinations including Paris and Los Angeles.

site_title: When financial sector growth becomes a drag
summary: JPMorgan Chase executives faced criticism from investors for prioritizing scale over smaller size, with one executive stating "scale has always defined the winner in banking." The company's CFO, Marianne Lake, defended the approach, citing its success. Meanwhile, other financial institutions are addressing challenges, such as Chinese banks struggling with consumer lending and Japan's MUFG targeting the US securitization market. Policymakers are also responding to economic concerns, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and the PBOC considering a stimulus package.

site_title: India overhauls monetary policy, sets 4% inflation target for FY2017
summary: India's government and central bank have agreed to commit to inflation targeting, setting a 4% inflation target for FY2017 with a band of plus or minus 2 percentage points. This marks a radical change in monetary policy, prioritizing subduing chronically volatile prices. Reserve Bank of India governor Raghuram Rajan has championed the move, which is increasingly popular among large emerging markets. The agreement will require amendments to the Reserve Bank of India Act and is expected to lead to further interest rate cuts to achieve the target.

images.alt_text: Inflation in India has moderated sharply as oil prices slumped since last year. Under the new policy document, the RBI will first aim to have consumer inflation fall below 6 per cent by January 2016, in line with objectives already spelt out by the central bank.
Mr Rajan says inflation has to be subdued for India to achieve sustainable long-term growth

site_title: Eurozone leaders must accept that austerity for Greece won't work
summary: Eurozone leaders face a critical decision on Greece's debt crisis, with a deal agreed to provide a temporary reprieve. However, austerity measures are unlikely to work, and the issue is more about the underlying causes of the crisis, such as countries' inability to pay debts in the eurozone. European leaders should focus on redistributing surpluses from major exporters to deficit countries, rather than relying on austerity. A default or Grexit could trigger a global financial crisis, and leaders must use the next four months to find a solution that doesn't put the eurozone or global financial system at risk.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Midas Holdings' FY14 earnings exceeded expectations with a 19% year-on-year growth to 56.6 million yuan, driven by Q4 recovery. Sinarmas Land's net profit was above expectations, bolstered by a divestment gain and joint venture projects in Indonesia. Super Group's FY14 results were above expectations, but the company is unlikely to see payoff due to intense competition. China Merchants Holdings (Pacific) saw core net profit in line with expectations, but with a possible conversion of convertible bonds affecting future earnings.

site_title: Royal Mail announces China link-up through Alibaba's Tmall
summary: Royal Mail has partnered with Alibaba's Tmall Global to connect small British companies with Chinese consumers, boosting its overseas parcels business. The partnership, set to launch later this month, will provide access to British retailers and exporters through a virtual store front and payment portals, with Royal Mail handling documentation and customer services. In return, Royal Mail will receive commission on sales and shipping revenue. China is the UK's largest international consumer of online goods, accounting for 25% of overseas online shoppers.

site_title: Eurozone jobless rate falls to 11.2% in January
summary: The eurozone jobless rate decreased to 11.2% in January, its lowest level since April 2012, according to Eurostat. Unemployment dropped by 140,000 to 18.06 million, reflecting an improvement in the economy from a soft patch late last year.

site_title: India sets inflation target in monetary policy overhaul
summary: India has adopted inflation targeting, setting a 4% consumer inflation target with a 2% band, from March 2017. This marks a historic monetary policy overhaul led by Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan, championing the move to control volatile prices. The goal aims to benefit the country's poorest citizens.

site_title: What China's 'new normal' means for leaders
summary: China's economic growth has slipped to 7.4% last year, its lowest since 1990, marking the end of its period of miracle growth. President Xi Jinping has taken to calling this "the new normal," a shift from an investment-driven, export-oriented economy to one driven by consumption. The Communist Party is also reorienting its leadership mindset, emphasizing social responsibility and awareness of social context. Xi's crackdown on corruption has been more robust than previous administrations, and Beijing is prioritizing responsible leadership to maintain power and address social issues like pollution and environmental damage.

site_title: Berkshire's Buffett says sold Exxon Mobil stake for acquisition, stock buys
summary: Warren Buffett, CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, revealed that the company sold its entire 41 million-share stake in Exxon Mobil Corp in the fourth quarter, citing the need for the funds for acquisitions and stock purchases. Buffett described Exxon Mobil as a "wonderful company," but noted its diminished earning power due to the decline in oil prices. The sale was made to take advantage of the funds for future investments.

site_title: Nasdaq hits 5,000 for the first time since March 27, 2000
summary: The Nasdaq Composite index reached 5,000 for the first time since March 27, 2000, closing at 4,997.35. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6% to 18,241.68, while the S&P 500 gained 0.4% to 2,112.85. The milestone marks a significant milestone in the market, with the Nasdaq nearly reaching its all-time peak of 5,132.52.

site_title: Tat Hong gains A$6.7m from Australia property transaction
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane rental company, has gained A$6.7 million from a sale-and-leaseback transaction of four Australian properties to Primewest Funds. The properties were sold for A$23.3 million and leased back for 12 years at A$1.91 million annually. This transaction resulted in a share price increase of 0.1 cents for Tat Hong.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit new records as ECB stimulus looms
summary: European stocks hit new records as investors await the European Central Bank's quantitative easing stimulus, set to be unveiled on Thursday. The British FTSE 100 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices reached record highs, while the eurozone's consumer prices remained in deflation territory for the third month. The ECB's stimulus is seen as a boost to economic growth, but its effectiveness remains uncertain, with some analysts questioning whether it will be enough to drag the region out of a deflationary spiral.

site_title: Noble's Q4 loss consistent with rating: Moody's
summary: Moody's rates Noble Group, a Singaporean commodities firm, at the lowest investment grade rung, citing consistent earnings with its current credit rating. Despite this, Moody's expects the firm to maintain "excellent" liquidity and execute growth plans with slightly higher indebtedness.

site_title: Giuliani loves America, but Obama doesn't?
summary: Former NYC Mayor Rudy Giuliani sparked controversy after stating that President Barack Obama "doesn't love" America. Giuliani made the comments during a private dinner in New York, saying Obama's upbringing and rhetoric didn't reflect the same level of patriotism as his own. However, journalists found that Obama has repeatedly expressed his love for the country, including in speeches and public statements. Giuliani later admitted his comments were "blunt" but insisted Obama's words and actions have a negative impact on the country's morale.

site_title: US construction spending falls in January
summary: US construction spending unexpectedly fell 1.1% in January to an annual rate of $971.4 billion, down from 1.8% in the same period last year. This decline was attributed to both private and public outlays. The Commerce Department reported the data on Monday.

site_title: German central banker urges rule change for risk-free government bonds
summary: German central banker Andreas Dombret urged regulators to change rules allowing banks to consider government loans as risk-free, citing the need for greater resilience in the face of financial distress. The current "zero-risk weighting rule" has been criticized during the eurozone debt crisis and is now being reviewed. Dombret's comments come as regulators consider revising the rule, which currently allows banks to hold little or no capital against sovereign debt. The change aims to reduce the risk of a two-tier debt market emerging.

site_title: Bill Gates still world's richest man, Forbes says
summary: Bill Gates has maintained his spot as the world's richest man, according to Forbes magazine, with a fortune of $79.2 billion. This marks 16 years of holding the top spot. Carlos Slim takes second place with $77.1 billion, while Warren Buffett ranks third with $72.7 billion. The number of billionaires has broken an all-time record, reaching 1,826. The rise of the dollar and plunging oil prices have had a significant impact on this year's list.

site_title: Oil spread blow-out portends new price slump
summary: US oil prices may experience a sharp dive as Oklahoma storage tanks fill up sooner than expected, potentially reaching capacity weeks earlier than anticipated. The spread between first and second-month oil futures collapsed, with prompt prices diving by over $1 to their deepest discount in four years. Analysts predict a possible price drop to $44 or lower, with some traders concerned that space may run out before end-March. The situation is exacerbated by the shutdown of a 110,000 barrel-per-day crude unit at a BP refinery in Indiana, which may increase the demand for Cushing storage.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard buys networking firm Aruba for US$2.7b
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) has acquired networking firm Aruba Networks for $2.7 billion. The deal gives HP a broader range of offerings for corporate wireless networking as it prepares to split into two separate companies. Aruba will become part of HP Networking, which will also include HP's leading switching portfolio. The acquisition aims to provide enterprises with next-generation mobile networks and simplify their networking solutions. The split is part of HP's reorganization to focus on mobile devices and sharpen the focus of each unit.

images.alt_text: US computer giant Hewlett-Packard said on Monday it was buying mobile networking group Aruba Networks for some US$2.7 billion.

site_title: VW wins third European Car of Year Award since 2010 with Passat
summary: Volkswagen's Passat sedan won the 2015 European Car of the Year Award, securing 340 points out of 420. The Passat beat out the Citroen C4 Cactus and Mercedes-Benz C-Class sedan to take the top prize. This is Volkswagen's third European Car of the Year win since 2010, following previous victories for the Golf and Polo models. The award recognizes the Passat's range of technology, including on-board connectivity and hybrid engines, making it the third time a Volkswagen model has won the award in six years.

site_title: China rate cut seen helping property market
summary: China's central bank cut interest rates for the second time in three months, expected to boost property sales and stabilize house prices. However, a strong recovery is unlikely due to an over-supply of unsold homes, accounting for 15% of China's GDP. This move is seen as positive for the government and central bank, which aim to stabilize the sector after a 24-year low in economic growth last year.

site_title: Morgan Stanley says New York Attorney General may file lawsuit
summary: Morgan Stanley said the New York Attorney General's office plans to file a lawsuit alleging the bank misrepresented or omitted material information in 30 subprime securitizations. Morgan Stanley disputes the allegations and has presented defenses. The bank's legal expenses increased to $3.41 billion in 2014, up from $1.95 billion in 2013. The New York Attorney General's office has not commented on the matter.

site_title: The 'next America' is now
summary: A US report, "States of Change: The Demographic Evolution of the American Electorate, 1974-2060," reveals that the American electorate is becoming increasingly diverse, with a growing minority population, aging demographics, and a shift away from single-generational identities. This demographic change is hindering the creation of durable coalitions and contributing to the country's political paralysis. The report identifies 10 transforming trends that will shape the nation's future, including the waning power of whites and the rising power of Hispanics, but notes that these changes are not necessarily leading to a more unified political system.

site_title: Taiwan says agrees with China on commercial air routes
summary: Taiwan and China have agreed on new commercial air routes, resolving differences over original proposals from Beijing. China will delay implementing the main north-south route, known as M503, and suspend plans for three smaller west-east routes, moving them further west of the Taiwan Strait to reduce safety risks. The agreement aims to maintain cross-strait peace and stability, despite ongoing political and military suspicions between the two sides.

site_title: Google's Pichai unveils plans for US mobile-phone services
summary: Google's Senior Vice President Sundar Pichai unveiled plans to expand US mobile-phone services, aiming to take on US wireless carriers and increase global connectivity. The initiative, called Project Titan, involves partnering with carriers like Sprint and Vodafone to provide wireless towers in areas with limited coverage. Google is investing in mobile software and services, building on its Android operating system, which dominates the smartphone industry. The move aims to increase mobile ad revenue and address the company's growing pressure to accelerate growth in the face of increasing competition.

site_title: For casinos in Manila's gaming strip, more is better
summary: Manila's casinos are expected to attract rich punters and partygoers with luxury clubs launched by Michael Van Cleef Ault, founder of popular luxury clubs. Ault has invested in City of Dreams casino-resort, hoping to capitalize on rising wealth in the Philippines. The move is part of his strategy to expand his business globally, following the success of his ultra-luxe nightclub Pangaea in Singapore's Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Mermaid's earnings dive 67.4% on higher costs
summary: Mermaid Maritime's shares plummeted 10% after the company reported a 67.4% decline in net profit to US$4.3 million for the October to December period, due to higher business costs.

site_title: Taiwan orders Alibaba to withdraw after violating rules: official
summary: Taiwan has ordered Alibaba to withdraw from the country within six months due to violating investment rules as a Chinese company. The online retailer was fined NT$120,000 (US$3,824) and must transfer its holdings from its Taiwanese operation. Alibaba entered Taiwan in 2008 as a Singapore-registered company, and the decision follows a review by Taiwan's Investment Commission since September. Alibaba's CEO Jack Ma is scheduled to give a speech in Taipei on Tuesday.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns its H2 revenue may be lower than expected, with an operating loss similar to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will replace outgoing CEO Helen Wong. Singapore stocks have experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: US manufacturing growth increases to 4-month peak: Markit
summary: US manufacturing growth surged to a 4-month peak in February, reaching 55.1, according to Markit's report. This is the highest reading since October, indicating growth in the sector. While output growth remains below last year's peaks, production is expected to rise at an annualized rate of around 4%. Employment growth eased to its lowest since July, while new orders rose in February. The positive sign suggests the sector is recovering, despite slower growth compared to previous months.

site_title: Janus' Bill Gross warns on dangers of low interest rates
summary: Bill Gross, a prominent bond investor, warned that ultra-low interest rates could harm global growth instead of boosting it. He stated that low interest rates globally destroy financial business models, exacerbating low growth rates by raising savings and deferring consumption. Gross, who oversees the Janus Global Unconstrained Bond Fund, advised investors to stay conservative in their portfolios, focusing on high-quality bonds and low P/E stocks. The US Federal Reserve is considering raising interest rates for the first time since 2006, with potential increases starting in the second quarter.

site_title: Consumer spending in US rises 0.3% adjusted for inflation
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.3% in January, adjusted for inflation, following a 0.1% drop in the prior month, according to a Commerce Department report. Nominal spending fell 0.2% and incomes grew 0.3%. Economists' forecasts ranged from a 0.3% decrease to a 0.5% increase. This data provides a positive indication of the US economy, contradicting expectations of a decline.

site_title: Risk of US$32 oil price seen by BofA as US heating demand fades
summary: Bank of America predicts the US crude oil price may drop to $32 a barrel as winter heating demand fades, ending support from ultra-low-sulfur diesel prices. The price surge was driven by below-normal temperatures and record snowfalls in the US northeast. However, as onshore US storage approaches maximum capacity, weakness is expected to return in the second quarter, according to Bank of America strategists. The US benchmark is still 50% below its value in June due to a global crude-supply surplus.

site_title: Gold futures trade near two-week high on China interest-rate cut
summary: Gold futures rose near a two-week high after China's interest-rate cut, supporting prices. The People's Bank of China lowered benchmark lending and deposit rates by a quarter percentage point, boosting demand for physical gold. Gold imports by India, the top consumer, may jump to 100 metric tons in March, according to chairman of Rajesh Exports Ltd. The metal rose 0.1% to $1,213.60 an ounce, with silver futures also gaining 0.2% to $16.585 an ounce. The cut is expected to lift demand for physical gold, according to Kitco Metals Inc.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday, closing at 1,817.13 after a 4.08-point drop. The index saw 2.25 billion lots valued at RM2.19 billion traded, with 313 gainers and 617 losers.

site_title: US manufacturing growth slows to 13-month low: ISM
summary: US manufacturing growth slowed to a 13-month low in February, according to the Institute for Supply Management, with the index falling to 52.9 from 53.5 in January. This marks the lowest reading since January 2014. Most components of the index declined, suggesting a slowing growth in the factory sector, but the main index's 50-plus reading indicates 28 consecutive months of growth.

site_title: Apple, Google workers head to court on US$415m poaching settlement
summary: US workers who accused Apple, Google, and two other Silicon Valley companies of conspiring to limit job mobility and keep salaries low will try to win approval of a $415 million settlement. The antitrust class action lawsuit, filed in 2011, alleged that the companies agreed to avoid poaching each other's employees to keep salaries low. A judge rejected a previous $324.5 million deal, citing that the settlement was too low, and now a new deal must meet a minimum of $380 million to be approved.

site_title: China parliament to juggle reform drive and slower growth
summary: China's National People's Congress will convene to address the country's slowing economy, with a focus on state-owned enterprise reforms, price reforms, and fiscal reforms. The government is expected to lower this year's GDP growth target to around 7%, the lowest in a quarter century, to promote sustainable domestic consumption. To combat deflation, the People's Bank of China has already cut interest rates twice, but critics argue that these measures do not advance the reform process. The government faces challenges in implementing reforms, particularly in getting local governments to comply, which could impact economic growth.

site_title: India's Jan infrastructure output growth at more than a year's low of 1.8%
summary: India's infrastructure output growth slowed to 1.8% in January, the lowest in over a year, due to a sharp decline in crude oil and natural gas production. This marks a decrease from 2.4% in December. The infrastructure sector, accounting for 37.9% of India's industrial output, is a major contributor to the country's economic growth.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat after consumer spending data
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, following a strong S&P 500 performance in March, which was its best month in over three years. Consumer spending data showed soft spending in January, and the manufacturing sector report is expected. The Dow Jones fell 0.04%, the S&P 500 gained 0.03%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2%.

site_title: Singapore fund in talks with Israeli tech startups
summary: A US$200 million Singaporean government-backed fund is planning its first direct investments in Israeli tech startup companies. The move follows a shift in focus towards Asia among Israeli companies, driven by growth prospects and concerns over trade sanctions. Tech-hungry Asian countries, particularly China, are also increasing investments in Israel, a hub for innovative companies. This investment aims to capitalize on the growing interest in Asian markets among Israeli companies and support the development of the region's tech sector.

site_title: Varoufakis urges 'intelligent' debt restructuring
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis has urged for "intelligent" debt restructuring, suggesting a write-down of Greece's debt would be unacceptable for creditors. Varoufakis acknowledged that the term "haircut" is a "dirty word" and that creditors don't want to hear it. He emphasized the need for a restructuring plan that benefits both Greece and its creditors, rather than a straightforward write-down.

site_title: Malaysia seen keeping policy rate unchanged as ringgit stays
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to keep its policy rate unchanged at 3.25% due to capital outflow and economic risks, despite inflation falling to its lowest since 2009. The ringgit has weakened by over 3% this year, and reserves have fallen by almost US$21 billion in the past five months. The central bank's decision is seen as a cautious move to address economic risks, with economists unanimous in their expectation of no rate change.

site_title: India central bank revises priority sector lending norms
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), revised its guidelines for priority sector lending, making medium enterprises, sanitation, and renewable energy sectors eligible for priority lending. The target for lending to the redefined priority sector remains at 40% of adjusted net bank credit. Foreign banks have been given time to comply with the revised norms without a specified deadline.

site_title: Ringgit leads retreat in Asian currencies on China rate cut
summary: The ringgit fell 0.7% to 3.6270 a dollar against the US dollar, leading losses among Asian currencies, after China's benchmark interest rates were cut by a quarter of a percentage point. The yuan dropped to a two-year low against the dollar, amid concerns it will spur weakness in the currency and hurt Malaysia's exports, which are a significant contributor to the country's economy. This move has raised concerns about Malaysia's competitiveness and impact on its energy-exporting nation.

site_title: Goldman said to cut Singapore investment bank jobs by about 30%
summary: Goldman Sachs is reducing its investment-banking team in Singapore by about 30% due to tougher regulations and higher capital requirements. Ruben Bhagobati and Antoine Izard, among others, are departing the firm. This move follows similar staff cuts by other financial institutions in Asia, such as Standard Chartered and Nomura Holdings. Goldman Sachs remains a significant player in Southeast Asia's mergers and acquisitions market, ranking fifth last year with an 11.8% market share. The firm's decision is seen as a response to the increasing pressure on financial firms globally.

site_title: London Metal Exchange aims to further cut warehouse logjams
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) introduced new rules and proposals to cut warehouse logjams, following consumer complaints and lawsuits. The reforms aim to reduce delays in obtaining aluminium from storage. The LME also plans to launch new contracts for aluminium premiums and ferrous products on October 26. These measures come as part of a wide-ranging reform package to address supply restrictions through the warehouse network.

site_title: Loh Boon Chye leaves Bank of America Merrill Lynch
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch executive Loh Boon Chye is leaving the firm after a 3-year tenure. He was deputy president for Asia-Pacific, head of Asia-Pacific global markets, and country executive for Singapore and South-east Asia. Loh plans to take a break before deciding on his next move. Chris Gammons has been appointed as Loh's replacement, taking over additional roles as head of South-east Asia investment banking and Asia-Pacific financial sponsors.

site_title: Singapore: Index rises but broad market stays weak
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.03 points to 3,403.89, despite a weak session, as investors pushed the index higher in the final seconds. The STI was largely unaffected by China's interest rate cut, and falls in DBS and OCBC dragged the market down. Turnover was in line with daily averages, with 169 rises versus 289 falls. The overall session was weak, with the index ending in the red for most of the day.

site_title: Oil falls under US$62 on dollar, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices dropped below US$62 a barrel, with Brent crude reaching a low of US$61.70, due to a stronger dollar and increased Libyan crude output. The dollar hit an 11-year high after China's rate cut weakened the yuan and impacted emerging currencies. This marks the largest monthly rise in Brent crude since May 2009.

site_title: UK manufacturing growth at seven-month high in Feb: PMI
summary: British manufacturing growth reached a seven-month high in February, according to a survey, with the Markit/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI) rising to 54.1. This represents a full point increase from January and comfortably above the 50 mark denoting growth. The quarterly growth rate is estimated at around 0.5%. However, the survey also highlighted concerns over reliance on domestic demand, with export orders declining and business investment falling at a sharp rate.

site_title: Oil falls more than 1% on dollar, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices dropped over 1% on Monday, falling to around $62 a barrel, due to a stronger US dollar and increased Libyan crude output. The US dollar reached an 11-year high after a rate cut in China. Despite OPEC's efforts to curb supply, output from several countries may be recovering, with Libya's production reaching over 400,000 barrels per day. Oil prices are expected to fall further before potentially recovering in the second half of 2015, with forecasters predicting prices to reach $60 a barrel by 2016.

site_title: Jean-Louis Laurent Josi starts new role as AXA Asia regional CEO
summary: AXA Asia announced the appointment of Jean-Louis Laurent Josi as regional CEO, effective immediately. Josi, who joined AXA in 2006, will report directly to Henri de Castries and will be part of the management committee. The appointment follows the region's "tremendous growth" and marks a new milestone in AXA Asia's development. The insurer has expanded its presence in Asian markets through organic growth and acquisitions, and plans to accelerate growth with investments in digital tools and initiatives to improve the customer experience.

site_title: One in 10 drop bid for UKbank jobs on vetting, Reuters says
summary: More than 10% of applicants for senior UK banking jobs withdraw their applications during the vetting process, Reuters reported. Since April 2013, 22 people out of 186 applications for CEO, chairman, and other senior positions withdrew, citing a tougher review process implemented by the Prudential Regulation Authority and the Financial Conduct Authority since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Insurance sector veteran Sergei Korol joins ACR Capital
summary: ACR Capital Holdings appointed Sergei Korol as group chief financial officer, replacing Tan Chong Liong. Korol has 17 years of experience in the insurance sector, most recently as regional CFO of ACE Group in Hong Kong. His appointment is seen as a strategic move to support the company's growth in the North Asian market. ACR Capital Holdings, a reinsurance operating subsidiary, has expanded its operations to 11 territories across Asia and plans to deepen its foothold in the region. Korol's role will oversee financial matters, including forecasting and reporting.

site_title: Eurozone factory growth steady in Feb; hiring and exports pick up: PMI
summary: Eurozone manufacturing growth steadied in February at 51.0, matching January's six-month high, driven by a weaker euro and faster hiring. Export orders rose at the fastest pace since July last year, while factory gate prices declined at a slower pace than in January. Despite this, the sector's growth pace remains modest, and the eurozone's goods-producing economy still faces challenges.

site_title: German manufacturing growth gains pace on strong new orders: PMI
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector growth accelerated in February, driven by a seven-month high in new orders, according to Markit's PMI. The index rose to 51.1, above the 50 line separating growth from contraction. The improvement is attributed to rising demand from Asia and the US, low oil prices, and private consumption overtaking exports as Germany's main engine of growth. This signals a strong start to 2015 for Europe's largest economy, following a 0.7% expansion in the final quarter of 2014.

site_title: Oil drops as gain in Saudi Arabian output boosts Opec production
summary: Oil prices fell 1.4% in New York after Saudi Arabia increased its production, lifting Opec's output beyond its collective quota for a ninth month. Opec pumped 30.6 million barrels a day in February, surpassing its target of 30 million a day. This move, combined with US drillers cutting rigs, has driven a global glut, leading to a 50% decline in oil prices in 2014. Prices may trade at $64-$65 a barrel in the near-term, according to Iraq's oil minister.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Malaysia's agency plans to seize approximately RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup predicts MSCI's global equity index will reach 1,150 by mid-2026. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin is confident his daughter will be cleared of ethics charges. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has deemed Myanmar's election a low priority. The UK economy contracted for the second month, affecting Prime Minister Starmer. South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Greek factory activity contracts again in February: PMI
summary: Greek factory activity contracted in February, with a manufacturing PMI of 48.4, the eighth month below the 50 mark. This is the sharpest decline in output since October 2013. New business inflows fell at an accelerated rate, leading to a decline in factory output and producer prices. Despite this, employment in the sector rose for the first time in 16 months, with a modest net increase. The new government's bailout extension and reforms are expected to ease economic pressure, but uncertainty remains a significant challenge.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines restructuring gathers pace as new leadership moves
summary: Malaysia Airlines is undergoing a state-led restructuring program as part of its new leadership. The airline is re-negotiating contracts, reviewing its fleet and routes, and laying off nearly a third of staff. A 12-point recovery plan aims to achieve profitability by 2017 and re-listing by 2020. The new CEO-designate, Christoph Mueller, will oversee a company of 14,000 employees. The airline plans to cut capacity by 10% this year and grow by 5% annually for the next five years, focusing on Southeast Asia and the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: GSK and Novartis complete deals to reshape both drugmakers
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and Novartis have completed a series of asset swaps worth over $20 billion, reshaping both drugmakers. GSK formed a consumer health joint venture with Novartis, bought Novartis' vaccines business, and sold its cancer drugs portfolio to Novartis. GSK plans to return $6.2 billion to shareholders and provide 2015 earnings guidance on May 6. The transactions come as GSK faces challenges, including a record fine in China and disappointing lung drug sales, which led to a 51% cut in its CEO's bonus.

site_title: Europe: Stocks little changed at highest level since July 2007
summary: European stocks rose less than 0.1% to 392.27, the highest level since July 2007, after a fourth weekly rally. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index advanced 2.6% last week, driven by better-than-expected financial results and the European Central Bank's quantitative easing. The index has rallied 14% in 2015, boosted by Greece's bailout deal and the region's economic reports.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint sells 2015's first SGD perpetual bonds
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint is selling SGD perpetual bonds, the first in 2015, with an initial price guidance of low 5%. The deal, anchored by TCC Prosperity Limited, has a possible issue size of S$200-300 million and is being co-ordinated by DBS Bank and Maybank Kim Eng. The bonds will not be recalled before year 5.

site_title: Yongnam Holdings reports S$8.5 million net loss for FY2014
summary: Construction firm Yongnam Holdings reported a net loss of S$8.5 million for FY2014, down 53.9% from a net profit of S$5.5 million in the previous year. Group revenue fell 41.4% to S$212.1 million due to the completion of major projects and slow starts on new projects. The lower revenue resulted in a lower level of steelwork fabrication and erection activity, absorbing fixed production and overhead costs.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Sibor up again, at 0.786%, more than double last year's rate
summary: The 3-month Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) surged to 0.786%, more than double last year's rate, as the US dollar rallied. This is the highest level since January 2009. The Singapore dollar weakened against the US dollar, falling to S$1.364, its lowest level since August 2010. The currency has lost 7.3% against the US dollar in the past six months, the third-worst performance among major South-east Asian economies.

site_title: BlackBerry takes its device management platform to the cloud
summary: BlackBerry is launching a cloud-based version of its device management platform BES12, making it more accessible to small- and medium-sized businesses. The platform can manage and secure devices powered by Android, iOS, and Windows, as well as medical equipment and industrial machinery. BlackBerry aims to broaden its offerings and attract a wider range of customers, including smaller businesses and larger companies with divisions needing cloud-based capabilities. The new cloud-based version will be offered to customers later this month, with India's Essar Group signing up for a trial.

site_title: India factory output slides to five-month low: survey
summary: India's factory output in February fell to a five-month low, with the purchasing manager's index (PMI) dropping to 51.2 points, its lowest dip since September. The slowest pace in five months suggests the need for strong government steps to reignite growth, following the government's budget announcement that skipped big reforms but promised infrastructure spending.

site_title: ANZ launches new rebate credit card
summary: ANZ has launched a new rebate credit card, following a survey that found Singapore consumers prefer flexible rebate options over pre-determined categories. The majority of respondents (66%) preferred a concept that allows them to choose the spend category for the highest rebate (5%). This flexible approach aligns with the survey's finding that consumers value choice and flexibility over set rebate categories.

site_title: Americans say keep politics out of the Fed: Reuters-Ipsos poll
summary: Most Americans believe the Federal Reserve should be left alone from congressional oversight, with 66% opposed to detailed oversight and 24% supporting it. A Reuters-Ipsos poll found that 49% think important monetary decisions should be made without political influence. Supporters of the "Audit the Fed" campaign argue for more transparency and accountability, while opponents worry it could lead to political influence over interest rates and damage market confidence. The Senate Banking Committee is set to discuss Fed reform, including the issue of the audit.

site_title: China central bank says injected 180b yuan into interbank market in Jan via SLOs
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), injected 180 billion yuan (US$28.70 billion) into the interbank money markets in January through short-term liquidity operations (SLOs). The injections occurred ahead of China's Lunar New Year holiday, as money rates climbed. This is the first time the PBOC has disclosed the details of its SLOs. The facility is used to provide direct lines of credit to commercial banks, supplementing the central bank's monetary policy tools. The move aims to stabilize the financial system and support economic growth.

site_title: Gerard Ee to head Charity Council
summary: Gerard Ee has been appointed chairman of the Charity Council for a two-year term, starting March 1, 2015. He succeeds Fang Ai Lian, who is retiring after leading the council for over eight years. Four new members and nine re-appointed members will form a 14-member council.

site_title: French factory activity slows further in February: PMI
summary: French factory activity slowed further in February, with Markit's final purchasing managers' index falling to 47.6 from 49.2 in January. This decline was driven by a sharp decrease in new orders and sluggish demand, leading to increased job-cutting and reduced production stocks. For the 11th straight month, employment in the manufacturing sector fell, with the rate of job shedding slightly more pronounced than in January. The weak demand environment has raised concerns about deflation.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 5-mth high on China rate cut; Samsung Elec rallies
summary: South Korean shares reached a five-month high on Monday, driven by a 4.9% rally in Samsung Electronics and a 0.55% gain in the Korea Composite Stock Price Index. The move was fueled by a rate cut by China, aimed at bolstering its economy. The South Korean won fell against the dollar, but recovered in afternoon trade due to exporter demand. The KOSPI closed at 1,996.81 points, while Samsung Electronics reached a 9-month intraday high.

site_title: Noble Group's stocks hit one-year low
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted to a one-year low of 93 Singapore cents on Monday, down 4.5 cents from its close on Friday. The company's fourth-quarter loss was $240 million, largely due to a $438 million write-off, and faced criticism over accounting practices. Shares have fallen over 22% since February 13, following a similar decline of 8% last Friday.

site_title: China orders two local governments to punish polluting steel mills
summary: China's Ministry of Environmental Protection has ordered local governments in Linyi and Chengde to crack down on polluting steel mills, with 13 of 15 inspected enterprises in Linyi found to have violated environmental laws. The move aims to improve air quality and follows China's new environment law, which imposes unlimited fines and prison sentences on officials who fail to comply. Steel mills are now paying an estimated 160 yuan (US$26) per tonne of steel to comply with environmental guidelines, adding pressure on already struggling mills.

site_title: Nokia, NTT DoCoMo prepare for 5G ahead of Tokyo Olympics launch
summary: Nokia and NTT DoCoMo have partnered to develop 5G networks ahead of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The companies have achieved data transmission speeds of over 2 gigabits per second in an indoor trial using the 70 gigahertz spectrum band. This is significantly faster than current 4G network speeds. The companies plan to conduct an outdoor 70 GHz trial later this year, utilizing a spectrum range expected to be freed up by 2019 for 5G use. The collaboration aims to showcase early technical progress in 5G radio equipment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.26% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.26% on Monday, following China's central bank cutting interest rates for the second time in three months to boost the economy. The Hang Seng Index ended at 24,887.44, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.79%. The moves come amid global economic uncertainty, with the US and EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Solar plane passes new test ahead of planned world tour
summary: A solar-powered plane, Solar Impulse 2, successfully completed its third test flight in the UAE ahead of a planned round-the-world tour. The plane, powered by 17,000 solar cells, will travel 35,000 kilometers to the east, aiming to demonstrate clean technology and renewable energy. The tour, which could begin as early as Saturday, will see the plane fly from Abu Dhabi to India, Hawaii, and New York, with stops in the US and Europe, depending on weather conditions. The two Swiss pilots, Bertrand Piccard and Andre Borschberg, will alternate at the controls and are well-prepared for the challenging journey.

site_title: China rate cut will help steady ailing property market, but not spark recovery
summary: China's central bank cut interest rates for the second time in three months, aiming to boost property sales and stabilize weak house prices. The move is expected to help the 15% property sector, which accounts for a significant portion of China's GDP, but a strong recovery is unlikely due to a glut of unsold homes. The rate cut follows earlier decreases in mortgage rates and downpayment levels, and is seen as a step to support the economy and ward off deflation.

site_title: Crude's slump seen causing Indonesia to miss biofuel target
summary: Indonesia's goal to increase biodiesel use by 1.7 million kiloliters in 2015 may be threatened due to the slump in crude prices, which has reduced the appeal of producing energy from plants. The decline in fossil-fuel costs has cut the appeal of biodiesel, despite the recent increase in subsidies, which has led to a surge in palm oil prices. Experts estimate that consumption of subsidized palm biodiesel may miss the target, with demand potentially as low as 1 million kiloliters this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.15% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.15% higher on Monday, driven by a weaker yen supporting exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 28.94 points to 18,826.88, while the Topix index edged up 0.07% to 1,524.97. Investors weighed China's interest rate cut at the weekend.

site_title: Setting aside rancour over Hong Kong, China welcomes Prince William
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping welcomed Prince William on his first visit to the mainland in almost three decades, setting aside rancour over Hong Kong. The trip comes after sparring between London and Beijing over pro-democracy demonstrations in the former British colony. Prince William handed over an official invite for Xi to make a state visit to Britain, marking the first visit by a British royal family member to China since 1986.

site_title: OCBC expects 30% growth in cards business this year
summary: OCBC Bank expects a 30% growth in its cards business this year, driven by the launch of Singapore's first air miles card that allows high net worth customers to redeem flights on all airlines at any time. The new Voyage card waives administrative fees and can redeem flights within hours, unlike existing systems. This comes after the bank's cards business grew 23% last year, outpacing the industry average of 7%. The card's launch is part of the bank's efforts to enhance its lifestyle financing offerings.

site_title: New media, New China: Xinhua relaunch on barred networks
summary: China's official news agency Xinhua has re-launched its English-language presence on Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube, despite being blocked in the country. The agency unified its output into one account for each service, re-branded as "New China," and acknowledged that parallel accounts hindered its ability to keep up with global media.
