This move marks a new phase for Xinhua's global presence, but the services remain inaccessible to China's 648 million Internet users due to the country's strict censorship system.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit fresh 5-month high on China rate cut; won falls
summary: South Korean shares reached a fresh five-month high on Monday, driven by China's interest rate cut and lifting risk appetites. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.33% to 1,992.44. Samsung Electronics surged 3.2% after unveiling its latest Galaxy S smartphone model, while construction shares rallied on forecasts of a housing market recovery. The South Korean won fell 0.05% against the dollar.

site_title: Singapore leads Asia in real estate investment in 2014: CBRE report
summary: Singapore led Asia in real estate investment in 2014 with $11.9 billion, surpassing 2013's record of $10.4 billion. Asian outbound real estate investment reached a record $40 billion, with Singapore, China, and Hong Kong as top investors. The market saw a shift towards secondary gateway cities and regional centers, with Paris, Los Angeles, and the UK gaining popularity. Investment strategies also evolved, with a focus on hotels, industrial assets, and diversification across asset classes.

images.alt_text: Singapore was the top Asian investor in real estate in 2014 with US$11.9 billion worth of properties acquired across the world, said CBRE Research, adding that this was an increase from 2013.

site_title: UK election may end with no majority winner: survey
summary: A UK general election may end in a near-deadlock between the Conservative and Labour parties, with Labour predicted to win 282 seats and the Conservatives 278, according to a survey of 537 pollsters. Despite winning the most votes with 32.6%, the Conservatives may not secure a majority. The survey also suggests the Scottish National Party could win up to 29 seats and the UK Independence Party six. The election is set to take place on May 7.

site_title: Broker's take: 'Buy' call on Valuetronics
summary: DMG Research has initiated a "buy" call on Valuetronics, a Singapore-based manufacturer of consumer and industrial electronic products. The research house expects the company's industrial and commercial electronics segment to register strong growth, driving higher margins. The target price is set at S$0.64.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.70% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.70% on Monday, driven by China's central bank cutting interest rates for the second time since November. The benchmark Hang Seng Index added 173.47 points to 24,996.76.

site_title: Dollar hits 11-year high, rises broadly after China rate cut
summary: The US dollar reached an 11-year high against a basket of major currencies, rising to 95.505, following China's interest rate cut, which weakened the Chinese yuan and emerging Asian currencies. The Australian dollar initially gained but reversed, sliding 0.6% due to mixed local economic data and concerns about China's slowing economy. Analysts predict the Reserve Bank of Australia may cut interest rates, with some expecting a relief rally if the rate remains unchanged. The euro eased 0.2% to US$1.1176, while the dollar strengthened against the yen, reaching a two-week high of 119.95.

site_title: Trial to push for better flight tracking a year after MH370
summary: Australia, Indonesia, and Malaysia are launching a trial to track long-haul flights more closely, aiming to improve search efforts for the missing MH370 aircraft a year after it vanished. The trial will require aircraft to check in every 15 minutes, rather than every 30-40 minutes. The system, adapted from existing technology, could narrow down search areas in future tragedies, providing greater public confidence in aviation. The trial will cover flights in areas covering 11% of the world's surface, with the first results expected by May.

images.alt_text: Australia, Indonesia and Malaysia are launching a trial to allow air traffic controllers to more closely track aircraft traversing remote oceans such as the one believed to be the final resting place of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370.

site_title: Prices of completed condos fell 1.6% in January: SRPI
summary: Singapore's completed condos saw a 1.6% month-on-month decline in January, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) Overall Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI). Central Region prices fell 1.9%, while Non-Central Region prices dropped 1.4%. Small apartments and condo units (up to 506 sq ft) saw a 0.6% decrease. The revised December 2014 index values showed a 1.0% month-on-month decline, with Central Region prices shedding 1.6% and Non-Central Region prices easing 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: New online portal to help investors understand Specified Investment Products
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) and Securities Association of Singapore (SAS) launched an online e-learning portal to educate investors on unlisted Specified Investment Products (SIPs). The portal, available at http://sips.abs.org.sg/, offers five modules covering various SIPs, including derivatives and structured deposits. Investors can access the portal at no charge and at their own pace. Upon completion, investors receive a certificate, which can be presented to financial intermediaries to demonstrate their understanding of SIPs. The portal aims to enhance investor knowledge and make informed investment decisions.

site_title: Gold rises in longest run since October on China rates, US GDP
summary: Gold prices rose for a fourth consecutive day, reaching the highest level in almost two weeks, following China's second interest rate cut in three months and the US reporting a slower-than-estimated economic expansion. The People's Bank of China lowered benchmark lending and deposit rates, while the US grew at a 2.2% annualized rate, down from an estimated 2.6%. The slowdown in China poses a risk to global growth, supporting demand for gold, according to a strategist.

images.alt_text: Gold climbed for a fourth day, advancing to the highest level in almost two weeks, after China announced a second interest rate cut in three months and the US reported a slower pace of economic expansion than estimated.

site_title: Hot stock: Sino Grandness counter falls nearly 20% in early morning trade (Amended)
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group saw its share price fall 19.8% to S$0.345 in early morning trade after releasing its fourth-quarter results. The group reported a 64 million yuan loss, mainly due to non-cash interest and fair value charges. Full-year net profit fell 18.9% to 233.4 million yuan. Revenue for the quarter dropped 8.3% to 503.6 million yuan due to delivery timing differences.

site_title: Australia: Shares storm to fresh 7-year high as China rate cut spurs resources
summary: Australian shares rose to a fresh 7-year high on Monday, driven by a Chinese rate cut that boosted resources stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 43 points or 0.74% to 5973.1, its highest intraday level since May 2008. Iron ore majors BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rallied, while Australian banks rose on expectations of a domestic rate cut. The Australian central bank may announce a second 2015 rate cut, fueling borrowing expectations.

site_title: China: Shares up 0.67% in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose 0.67% in morning trade on Monday following the central bank's 25 basis point interest rate cut over the weekend to boost the flagging economy. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 22.05 points to 3,332.35, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.65% to 1,640.67. The rate cut aims to stimulate economic growth and stabilize the market.

site_title: China's home prices drop again in February, but more signs of stability seen
summary: China's home prices fell 0.06% in February, marking the 11th consecutive monthly drop, but at a slower pace than January. The decline slowed from 0.1% in January and 1.62% year-over-year, indicating a stabilization in the market. Analysts warn of ongoing risks, including debt and deflationary pressures, but the central bank's interest rate cut and signs of a bottoming out in the sector are seen as encouraging. The property industry accounts for 15% of China's GDP, making stabilization a welcome news for the government and central bank.

site_title: NXP Semiconductors to acquire Freescale for US$11.8b
summary: NXP Semiconductors has agreed to acquire Freescale Semiconductor for approximately US$11.8 billion in cash and stock. Freescale shareholders will receive US$6.25 in cash and 0.3521 of an NXP share for each Freescale common share. The deal includes Freescale's debt, totaling around US$16.7 billion. The acquisition is expected to combine the two companies' expertise in automotive electronics, benefiting from increased use of electronics in vehicles.

site_title: S&P sees India's sovereign rating unchanged in next year
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has stated that India's sovereign debt rating is unlikely to be upgraded in the next year, citing the need for substantial, quality reforms. S&P currently rates India at "BBB-minus" with a "Stable" outlook. Senior Director Kim Eng Tan emphasized that India must strengthen two macroeconomic metrics, but a significant improvement is unlikely in the near future.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise after China rate cut, US data
summary: Asian markets rose Monday after China cut interest rates for the second time since November, citing "historically low inflation." The move helped boost the dollar against the yen, while better-than-forecast US economic data also contributed to the gains. Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney led the gains, with Seoul also rising. The decision comes ahead of the annual meeting of China's National People's Congress, where Premier Li Keqiang is expected to deliver an address on the state of the economy.

site_title: Indonesia Feb inflation cools to 6.29% y/y as fuel costs drop
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation in February eased to 6.29% y/y, lower than expected, due to falling fuel and chilli prices. This is the second consecutive month of decline, with a 0.36% drop in the consumer price index. The drop in inflation is a welcome relief for policymakers, but the overall economic outlook remains a concern.

site_title: China's yuan falls to more than two-year low after central bank rate cut
summary: China's yuan fell to a two-year low against the dollar after the People's Bank of China cut the benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 2.5%. The spot yuan opened at 6.2730 per dollar, 34 pips weaker than the previous close and 1.98% weaker than the midpoint. The rate cut aims to boost economic growth, but a slowing GDP growth rate and US tariffs pose pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Broker's take: CIMB Research issues 'buy' call on Venture Corporation
summary: CIMB Research has issued a "buy" call on Venture Corporation, increasing its target price to S$8.96 from S$8.91, citing strong pretax margins and a stable core net profit. The research house believes the company's experience and customer diversification will help it navigate economic concerns in Europe and Asia. A final dividend per share of S$0.50 was also in line with expectations. The stock rose three Singapore cents to S$8.15 following the announcement.

site_title: Japan's February final manufacturing PMI 51.6 vs 52.2 in January
summary: Japan's manufacturing sector expanded at a slightly slower pace in February, with a final PMI of 51.6, below January's 52.2. Despite this, export demand remained strong, and the sector is expected to continue expanding. The economy is expected to grow moderately this year, driven by exports and stabilizing consumer spending. In contrast, Japanese households cut spending more than expected, and retail sales fell for the first time in seven months.

site_title: Asian stocks advance as Chinese central bank cuts interest rates
summary: Asian stocks rose 0.2% to 146.44, driven by China's central bank cutting interest rates by 25 basis points to stimulate growth. The move follows two rate cuts in three months, as global central banks ease monetary policy amid concerns over growth and inflation. Japan, South Korea, and New Zealand also saw gains, while Australia awaits its interest-rate decision. The US stock market edged to fresh records, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Samsung unveils S6 phones, mobile wallet to challenge Apple
summary: Samsung unveiled its S6 phones and mobile wallet, aiming to challenge Apple's dominance in the premium smartphone market. The devices feature a three-sided screen, metal bodies, and fingerprint readers, with the S6 Edge having a curved screen that extends onto the sides. Samsung Pay, compatible with 90% of card readers, will be available in the US and South Korea before a global rollout. The company's shares rose 3.8% after the announcement, as Samsung seeks to regain competitiveness after Apple's iPhone release.

site_title: Australia Q4 gross company profits fall 0.2% quarter on quarter
summary: Australian company gross operating profits for the fourth quarter fell 0.2% quarter-over-quarter, contrary to forecasted 0.3% growth. This represents a 9.6% decline from the previous quarter. The decline is attributed to various economic factors affecting the country's business sector.

site_title: Indonesian manufacturing activity contracts to record low in Feb
summary: Indonesia's manufacturing activity contracted for the fifth consecutive month in February, with the HSBC Markit PMI index falling to a record low of 47.5, the lowest reading since 2011. This marks the first time the index has fallen below 50, signaling a contraction in activity.

site_title: Oil prices stabilise in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices stabilized in Asia on Monday, following sharp gains in the previous session. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) fell 37 US cents to US$49.39, while Brent crude eased 28 US cents to US$62.30. Analysts predicted the end of volatile trading and a beaten-down commodity bottoming out. Oil prices had surged US$1.59 for WTI and US$2.53 for Brent on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong lawmakers hand themselves in to police over protests
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy lawmakers handed themselves in to police on March 2, 2015, amid an investigation into mass protests for free elections. Police vowed to investigate the "principal instigators" of street blockades, while protest leaders have been arrested and released without charge in a procedure criticized as harassment. The move is the latest step in a widespread investigation into the protests, which ended in December when rally camps were cleared.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble shares continue downward trend on Monday
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 4.1% to S$0.935 in early morning trade on Monday, following a 8% drop last Friday after the company reported a US$240 million loss for the fourth quarter. The loss was largely due to a US$438 million write-off. The commodities trader also faced criticism over its accounting practices.

site_title: Ascendas Reit's multicurrency medium term note programme limit raised
summary: Ascendas Reit's multicurrency medium term note programme has been increased from S$1 billion to S$5 billion, effective March 2. The funds will be used for financing and refinancing A-Reit's acquisitions, investments, and development works, as well as for on-lending and general working capital purposes. Singapore Exchange Securities Trading Limited has given in-principle approval for the increase. The programme was established in 2009 by A-Reit's trustee, HSBC Institutional Trust Services (S) Limited.

site_title: Japan business capex growth slows in Q4, points to economic headwinds
summary: Japan's corporate capital expenditures grew 2.8% year-over-year in Q4, but at a slower pace than the prior quarter, casting doubt on the strength of business investment. The data suggests little revision to a preliminary reading of 2.2% annualized economic growth in Q4. Despite rising profits and share prices, companies are taking a wait-and-see stance due to sluggish demand, with capital spending expected to remain stagnant until the economy firms up in the coming fiscal year. This slowdown in capital spending raises concerns about the success of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, property companies
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 8% after reporting a $240 million loss for the fourth quarter, largely due to a $438 million write-off. Property firms may react to a 3.2% reduction in development charge rates for non-landed residential projects. The Singapore Exchange will appoint a new chief regulatory officer, Tan Boon Gin, starting June 15.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.38% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.38% higher on Monday, boosted by a drop in the yen against the dollar, which benefits Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 71.46 points to 18,869.40. Global central banks' easy monetary policies and China's interest rate cut also contributed to the positive start. The dollar gained against the yen, while the euro remained stable.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 0.19 points to 1821.40. The index saw 183 gains and 159 losses, with a total trading volume of 73.67 million lots worth RM239.25 million.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 4.59 points or 0.13% to 3,407.45. The market was boosted by weekend rate cuts from China and an infrastructure-focused budget from India, with gainers beating losers 97 to 74. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Australia manufacturing index falls in Feb: Australian Industry Group
summary: The Australian Industry Group's performance of manufacturing index (PMI) fell 3.6 points to 45.4 in February, below the 50 threshold, indicating a contraction. Sales, output, and employment declined, but exports showed a third straight month of expansion. The survey has been weaker than official measures, suggesting the sector has been in recession for almost five years due to weak domestic demand.

site_title: Modi forgoes seizing oil's drop to engineer deep fiscal fix
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi opted for a more incremental approach in his first full-year budget, choosing to boost growth in India's economy through infrastructure spending despite a strong election mandate and sliding oil prices. The budget features a wider deficit projection and delays in implementing tax and subsidy reforms, allowing for longer-term moves to make the country more competitive. Modi's decision is seen as a cautious approach to manage the economy, prioritizing short-term growth over immediate fiscal control.

site_title: China's economic growth expected to slow to 7% in Q1: state think tank
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow to 7% in the first quarter of 2015, according to a state think tank, citing heavy downward pressure amid structural adjustments. This forecast aligns with China's central bank's recent interest rate cut, aiming to ward off deflation. The report also predicts a 1.2% year-over-year increase in the consumer price index and a 5% annual growth in exports, while imports are expected to decrease 10.7% in the quarter. This slowdown reinforces the need for policymakers to implement more stimulus measures to support the economy.

site_title: Australia's RBA swept along in global stimulus rush
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to ease monetary policy for the second time in as many months due to disappointing business investment and global central banks' interest rate cuts. China's interest rate reduction puts pressure on the RBA to keep easing to prevent a rise in the local dollar. The RBA is concerned about the impact of mining investment decline and slow wage growth, which have led to a 12-year peak unemployment rate of 6.4% and subpar economic growth.

site_title: Berkshire insurance 'superstar' could fill Buffett's shoes
summary: Warren Buffett has praised Berkshire Hathaway executive Ajit Jain as a "superstar" who could potentially fill his shoes as CEO. Buffett, who has expressed support for Jain's leadership, stated that the board of directors would likely appoint Jain as CEO if he were to step down. Jain, born in India, has been instrumental in running Berkshire's insurance businesses, and Buffett's comments have fueled speculation that Jain may be the next in line for the top spot.

site_title: Three top Citigroup executives could be ousted if bank fails 'stress test'
summary: Three top Citigroup executives, including CEO Mike Corbat, CFO John Gerspach, and head of franchise risk and strategy Brian Leach, could face pressure to step down if the bank fails another "stress test" by the US Federal Reserve. The test measures a bank's ability to withstand a crisis. The Fed previously rejected Citi's plans for dividends and stock buybacks after the bank failed a stress test last year. If Citi fails again, investors and the board would likely pressure the executives to leave.

site_title: India's top investors back Modi budget on infrastructure drive
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's first annual budget has been welcomed by top investors, who see a boost in infrastructure spending and tax cuts as key measures to bolster the country's economy. The budget allocates 700 billion rupees (US$11.3 billion) for infrastructure development, including roads, ports, and power plants, and aims to increase private investment, which has been stagnant at 8.5% of GDP. Despite a higher-than-expected budget deficit, investors are optimistic about the growth prospects, with some even seeing the budget as a positive for overseas investors.

site_title: For casinos in Manila's gaming strip, more is better
summary: Michael Van Cleef Ault, founder of luxury clubs, has launched two nightclubs in Manila's City of Dreams casino-resort, targeting wealthy punters and partygoers. Manila's casinos are expected to benefit from rising wealth in the Philippines, which is the fastest growing Asian economy after China. The move also capitalizes on China's crackdown on corruption, with VIPs already frequenting casinos in Australia. Ault aims to draw rich gamblers through his doors, leveraging the growth in the Philippines' economy.

site_title: South Korea's January current account surplus at record high
summary: South Korea's current account surplus in January reached a record high of $10.73 billion, driven by a 9.2% decline in exports and a 15.5% drop in imports. The goods account surplus was $9.83 billion, while the financial account saw a net outflow of $8.24 billion. This strong trade performance is expected to support the country's economic growth.

site_title: South Korea's January factory output sets worst fall in 6 years
summary: South Korea's January factory output plummeted 3.7% from December, the largest drop in six years, according to Statistics Korea data. This marks a reversal of a 3.4% gain in December, which was initially reported as a 3.0% rise. The decline is attributed to a shaky recovery of Asia's fourth-largest economy, with policymakers facing pressure to address the slowdown.

site_title: Australia says hunt for missing MH370 jet may be called off soon
summary: Australia's deputy prime minister says the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may be called off soon due to lack of progress. The Boeing 777 vanished a year ago, carrying 239 passengers and crew. Despite extensive searches, no trace has been found, and investigators believe it was flown thousands of miles off course before crashing into the Indian Ocean. Discussions between Australia, China, and Malaysia are underway to determine if the search should be terminated within weeks.

site_title: China draft counterterror law strikes fear in foreign tech firms
summary: China is drafting a counterterrorism law requiring technology firms to hand over encryption keys and install security "backdoors". The law, expected to be adopted in coming weeks or months, also requires companies to store servers and user data within China, supply law enforcement with communications records, and censor terrorism-related internet content. This move has sparked concerns among foreign tech firms, who view the terms as increasingly onerous and potentially threatening their business operations in the country.

site_title: China's Huawei unveils 'luxury' watch in bid to rival Apple's
summary: China's Huawei unveiled its first luxury smart watch, featuring sapphire crystal glass, ahead of Apple's expected event to unveil the Apple Watch. The 42-millimeter watch is aimed at the higher-end wearables market and will be released mid-year. Huawei's move comes as the company focuses on higher-end smartphones and aims to achieve $70 billion in revenue by 2018. The global smartwatch market is forecast to reach $30 billion by 2018, with Huawei seeking to become one of the world's most loved brands.

site_title: French tax evasion fight to yield 2b euros in 2015
summary: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin announced a tax evasion crackdown that could yield 2 billion euros (US$2.2 billion) in 2015, similar to the amount raised in 2014. The campaign aims to encourage taxpayers to declare previously undeclared assets held abroad, mainly in Switzerland. Sapin prefers to combat tax fraud over raising taxes, citing last year's system that allowed people to regularize their foreign bank accounts as a success, yielding 0.1% of France's gross domestic product.

site_title: Tupperware's sweet spot shifts to Indonesia
summary: Tupperware has shifted its focus to Indonesia, overtaking Germany as its top market. The company has tapped into Indonesia's growing middle class and expanding workforce of women, who are drawn to its durable and affordable products. Tupperware's business model is built on social networks, with saleswomen using traditional gatherings, or "arisans," to sell products and recruit new agents. The company has also provided a way out of poverty for thousands of Indonesian women, who are now part of its sales force of over 250,000.

images.alt_text: A growing middle class has more disposable income for containers of all shapes and sizes that are sturdier than those found locally.

site_title: US targeting 'Jihadi John,' senator says
summary: US forces are targeting Mohammed Emwazi, a 26-year-old London man believed to be "Jihadi John," the English-speaking executioner for the Islamic State group. Emwazi, a computer expert, was identified through media reports as responsible for the beheadings of at least five Western hostages. US Senator Dianne Feinstein confirmed that Emwazi is a target, citing his disaffected story as a major problem for Western nations, highlighting the issue of young people feeling rejected or disenfranchised.

site_title: Iraq predicts oil will rise to US$64-65 per barrel
summary: Iraqi Oil Minister Adel Abdel Mahdi predicted oil prices will rise to $64-$65 per barrel, citing a recovery from the six-year low of $45 per barrel in January. The country owes over $20 billion to oil companies operating in the south, which Abdel Mahdi plans to pay with a $12 billion budget allocation and treasury bonds. This move aims to improve the country's relationship with oil companies and secure the future of its oil industry.

site_title: Australia home prices keep rising, surge in Sydney
summary: Australia's home prices continued to rise in February, with Sydney experiencing a surge of 1.4% and 13.7% year-over-year growth. This is despite a 0.3% increase across all major cities and a 22.6% rise since the 2012 growth cycle began. The Reserve Bank of Australia is under pressure to cut interest rates to address lower export prices and global policy easing, but rising home prices pose a challenge, particularly in Sydney where speculation is a concern. Regulators may adopt macroprudential measures to cool the market.

site_title: South Korea's February manufacturing PMI steady at 20-month high
summary: South Korea's manufacturing activity remained steady at a 20-month high in February, with the HSBC/Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 51.1. New export orders also grew for the second consecutive month, while output prices shrank for the 39th month in a row. The steady growth is seen as a sign of a rebound in Asia's fourth-largest economy, which slowed sharply to 0.4% in the final quarter of 2014. This positive trend is expected to continue in the current quarter, according to the South Korean central bank.

site_title: India's ruling Hindu party to share power in Kashmir
summary: India's ruling Hindu nationalist party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), has formed a power-sharing deal with the People's Democratic Party (PDP) in the Muslim-majority state of Jammu and Kashmir. The historic agreement, following inconclusive elections, saw PDP leader Mufti Mohammad Sayeed sworn in as the state's chief minister. The coalition, which includes 16 pages of a shared agenda, aims to maintain autonomy and make laws for the region while also addressing long-standing issues, including a draconian law giving Indian forces sweeping powers.

site_title: Tintin set to go under the hammer at Paris auctions
summary: Tintin's latest adventure is taking him to Paris auctions, as Christie's and Sotheby's host major comic and graphic novel sales. Christie's previously auctioned a Tintin book for 2.6 million euros and an original 1937 Tintin book for 4 million euros. Sotheby's will sell 288 items, including 50 signed by Tintin cartoonist Herge, with one drawing valued between 430,000 and 480,000 euros. The sales are expected to attract international attention, with rising prices attracting investors and foreign buyers.

site_title: Bombardier's CS300 flies into a tough market, say analysts
summary: Bombardier launched a test flight of its CS300 jet, the larger version of its CSeries narrow-body aircraft, amid a tough market dominated by Boeing and Airbus. Despite delays, CEO Alain Bellemare remains committed to certification by end-2015, but service may start in 2016. Analysts say the opportunity to reshape the market has been lost, citing weaker oil prices and a slowing global economy as concerns. Shares were down 1.5% on the test flight announcement.

site_title: Cogent donates S$100,000 for needy children
summary: Cogent Holdings presented a cheque for S$100,000 to two Singapore charities, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, to celebrate its fifth listing anniversary and Singapore's 50th year of independence. The charities received S$50,000 each. Cogent executive chairman Tan Yeow Khoon expressed gratitude for Singapore's support and pledged to bless the community, believing that its growth will also benefit the community. This donation is part of Cogent's efforts to give back to the community it serves.

site_title: Asian firms challenge Apple with snazzy new smartphones
summary: Asian firms Samsung, LG, and HTC unveiled new high-end smartphones, including curved displays and wireless charging, ahead of the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona. The launches challenge Apple's iPhone 6, with Samsung's Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge models featuring advanced cameras and processors. LG showcased its Flex 2 phone with a curved back and HTC revealed the HTC One M9 with a metallic aluminium design. The move aims to regain market share, but analysts warn that Samsung's lack of software expertise may hinder its efforts.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest 33 after anti-mainland march
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 33 protesters and fired pepper spray during clashes with demonstrators in Yuen Long, a neighbourhood near the Chinese border. The protest was sparked by anger towards parallel traders, who take advantage of lower prices in Hong Kong while dodging tariffs on their return. The arrests and clashes disrupted traffic and local businesses. Police took "resolute actions" to stop the violent acts, with five officers injured. The incident comes after Hong Kong's leader announced plans to consider restricting the number of Chinese tourists entering the city.

site_title: India budget criticised for lacking big-bang reforms
summary: India's budget, unveiled by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, has been praised for balancing business and poverty needs, but criticized for lacking big-bang reforms. The budget includes a $11.3 billion infrastructure boost and new pension programs for the poor, but failed to slash a $35 billion annual subsidy bill or privatize state-run banks. Experts say Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has missed an opportunity to reshape economic policies after its historic mandate. The budget aims to boost growth while addressing social equity concerns.

images.alt_text: While presenting the budget, Mr Jaitley tried to deflect criticism of the pace and scale of reform

site_title: China seeks to cushion economy as leaders meet to set 2015
summary: China's central bank cut benchmark lending and deposit rates by a quarter percentage point to combat deflationary pressures, joining other countries in easing monetary policy. The move aims to support the economy, which is expected to grow around 7% in 2015, down from 7.5% last year. The People's Bank of China also increased the deposit-rate ceiling to 1.3 times, easing financial repression. However, the yuan may not depreciate significantly, and the impact of the rate reduction will be limited due to banks' risk aversion.

site_title: Hue and cry over fusion
summary: Violet Herbs, a fine-dining concept by chef-owner Edward Hoe, has opened at 81 Tras Street. The restaurant aims to offer affordable fine dining despite its unique, purple-soaked atmosphere.

site_title: Oil downgrades mean more high-yield debt ahead
summary: Oil prices have fallen by 50% since last year, putting energy companies at risk of downgrading their debt to the US junk market. Moody's recently downgraded Transocean to Ba1, and analysts predict between $17 billion to $26 billion of energy company debt could fall into junk status over the next year. Companies like Transocean and Weatherford are at risk, with refinancing costs potentially doubling. However, some analysts believe high-yield energy bonds will remain in demand, particularly for smaller companies, and investors are seeking "high-quality" bonds to absorb falling angels.

site_title: Tax changes to help Reit sector in India
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced tax code changes to help the real estate investment trust (Reit) sector, which may spur US$20 billion of property development. The changes include rationalizing the capital gains regime and offering tax incentives on rental income. The move aims to revive construction activity, with Reits playing a key role in this process.

site_title: Tens of thousands march for slain Russian opposition leader Nemtsov
summary: Tens of thousands of people in Moscow honored the memory of opposition leader Boris Nemtsov, who was gunned down near the Kremlin in February. The march, which drew an estimated 70,000-100,000 people, condemned Moscow's stance on Ukraine and called for a thorough investigation into Nemtsov's murder. US Secretary of State John Kerry urged Russia to conduct a transparent investigation, while Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko called Nemtsov a "bridge between Ukraine and Russia" whose murder has been destroyed. The incident has been described as a "political murder" by Russian opposition figures, and has raised tensions with the West.

site_title: High beef prices prompt retailers, consumers to choose goat meat
summary: High beef prices have led to a surge in demand for goat meat, with chefs and retailers incorporating it into high-end menus and promotions. Wholesale prices for goat meat are significantly lower than those for beef, making it an attractive alternative. Demand has increased, with US imports of goat meat doubling in a decade and sales boosting by 25% last year. The appeal of goat meat is driven by cultural tradition and rural economics, particularly among communities with Middle Eastern, South American, and Caribbean roots.

site_title: China home prices decline in February: survey
summary: China's housing prices declined in February, with an average price of 10,539 yuan per square meter, a 0.24% drop from January. This marks a turnaround from the previous month's 0.21% rise. On a year-by-year basis, prices fell 3.84%, with only Shanghai and Shenzhen experiencing annual price increases. The decline is attributed to the Chinese New Year holiday and the government's anticipated micro-easing measures, which are expected to stabilize the market.

site_title: The road to riches isn't just paved with keys of condos
summary: A Singaporean debate centers on whether restrictions should be placed on using Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings to buy private property. Some argue that it's financially smart to use CPF for retirement savings, while others claim that it's essential for social mobility and equality. The article examines the pros and cons of using CPF to buy private property, comparing it to investing in stocks. The data suggests that property prices have historically been volatile and have not consistently outperformed stocks. The article concludes that both asset classes have their own unique characteristics and risks, and that property investment may not be the surest bet to riches.

site_title: Phone firms look beyond the handset at top mobile fair
summary: Phone firms are set to unveil new smartwatches and Internet-connected gadgets at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, aiming to seduce new buyers and conquer users' bodies. Tech giants Samsung, LG, Huawei, and Asus will launch wearable devices, including smartwatches and fitness trackers, to boost sales and make them a mainstream gadget. Experts predict a "tipping point for wearables" this year, with low-cost smartphones and wearables expected to feature prominently at the event. The focus is shifting away from handsets to connected objects, with companies seeking to create a new "5G" generation of wireless connections.

site_title: Australia, Malaysia and Indonesia trial new plane-tracking system
summary: Australia, Malaysia, and Indonesia are trialing a new plane-tracking system that increases tracking intervals over remote oceans to 15 minutes, up from 30-40 minutes. The system, using automatic dependent surveillance contract (ADSC) technology, aims to improve real-time monitoring and response to abnormal situations, such as the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370. The trial, starting in Brisbane, will be extended to Melbourne and other countries, with the goal of making aircraft tracking more effective over oceanic areas.

site_title: JES to ask SGX for more time to report results
summary: JES International Holdings, a China-based shipbuilding company, will ask the Singapore Exchange for an additional month to report its 2014 results due to issues with its Chinese subsidiaries' fixed assets valuation. The company's auditor requested an independent valuer to assess the fixed assets, but the valuer needs 2-3 weeks more to complete the report. JES also plans to hold its annual general meeting in the same timeframe.

site_title: Fashionable or geeky: the modern watch dilemma
summary: Watchmakers and technology developers are racing to create stylish smartwatches that appeal to the female market, ahead of the Apple Watch launch. Despite initial criticisms, some companies, such as D1 Milano, are succeeding by transforming smartwatches into aesthetic accessories. The Italian startup unveiled a thermochromic watch that changes color with temperature, which has gained popularity in the Middle East. While these smartwatches may not be designed to tell time, they could potentially win over fashion-conscious consumers who want a stylish accessory.

site_title: Relying on others - where does the buck stop?
summary: Directors in companies are expected to exercise the same standard of care and diligence as a reasonable director in the same position. As businesses become more sophisticated, this standard has risen, making it increasingly unlikely that individual directors or boards have the necessary expertise to ensure decisions are in the best interest of the company. However, the law does not expect directors to have infinite knowledge, and they can rely on others for help. Seeking independent advice and having procedures in place for information dissemination and professional advice can help directors make informed decisions. Ultimately, directors have a legal duty to exercise their own independent judgment in good faith.

images.alt_text: In performing their corporate and fiduciary duties, directors are expected to exercise the same standard of care and diligence that a reasonable director, in the same position, would.

site_title: Ebola returns to Sierra Leone capital from the sea
summary: Ebola has re-emerged in Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, after a decline in new cases in late January. Sick fishermen brought the virus ashore, sparking a cluster of infections and deaths. Despite a strong response by volunteers and health officials, the outbreak has spread to the countryside, with dozens of new cases and deaths reported. Experts warn that the disease can be vanquished in West Africa, but challenges such as cultural resistance to containment measures and misunderstandings will need to be overcome.

site_title: One in 10 scraps bid for top UK bank job as vetting gets tougher
summary: More than one in 10 candidates for top UK banking jobs have withdrawn during a regulatory vetting process, which has become tougher since the financial crisis. Since 2013, the Prudential Regulation Authority and Financial Conduct Authority have interviewed 186 candidates for senior positions, with 22 withdrawing, according to freedom of information data. The vetting process, which includes 90-minute interviews, has become more challenging, focusing on culture, conduct, and strategy, and candidates are often grilled on their past experiences and potential mis-selling scandals.

site_title: Data breach exposes information about 50,000 Uber drivers
summary: Uber Technologies revealed a 2014 data breach that exposed information on 50,000 drivers, including names and driver's license numbers. The breach occurred in May 2014, but was discovered in September, prompting Uber to take legal action and change access permissions. The company is notifying affected drivers and offering a year of free identity protection services. To date, no reports of actual misuse have been received, but drivers are advised to monitor their credit reports for fraudulent transactions.

site_title: Volatile week for oil prices amid oversupply
summary: Oil prices experienced volatility last week due to concerns over oversupply, with Brent crude rising to $61.67 a barrel and WTI falling to $48.94 a barrel. The US economy's slower-than-expected growth in the fourth quarter of 2014 also impacted prices. Meanwhile, metals such as gold, silver, and platinum gained ground due to a weaker US dollar and increased demand from China. The global supply glut has led to a 50% decline in the value of oil since June.

site_title: Friday's jobs data holds key to Feb rally extending into March
summary: US stocks are expected to continue their rally into March, driven by strong February jobs data and a long streak of economic growth. The Labour Department report is expected to show 230,000 new jobs added in February, with employers competing for more choosy candidates, leading to wage inflation. This could influence the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike timing and impact stock behavior. The Nasdaq Composite is near all-time highs, with Apple set to announce its first new product category, the Apple Watch, and companies in the housing market performing well due to pent-up demand for new homes.

site_title: Director activity falls while buybacks go up
summary: Singaporean director activity fell last week, with only eight companies recording 20 purchases worth S$4.6 million and no sales. However, overall buyback activity rose for the second straight week, with 12 companies posting 44 repurchases worth S$19.5 million. Notable buys include SingTel, Challenger Technologies, Lum Chang Holdings, Roxy-Pacific, CWT Limited, and GP Batteries International. These purchases were largely driven by the companies' earnings results and share price rebounds. The buyback activity was sharply up from the previous week's seven firms, 18 trades, and S$10.1 million.

site_title: BOE to assess whether issuing digital currency will boost stability
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) will research the potential benefits of issuing a digital currency, such as Bitcoin, to enhance financial stability and regulatory goals. The BOE believes digital currencies have "considerable promise" and could be used for interbank settlements and non-financial transactions. However, a technical hurdle remains in developing a standard protocol for transferring value over the internet. The BOE's research aims to explore the feasibility of a central bank-issued digital currency, which could offer a more controlled means of settlement and exchange, while saving on production and distribution costs.

site_title: APACTix eager to impress with services at SEA Games in June
summary: APACTix, a Singaporean ticketing company, is preparing to showcase its services at the SEA Games in June. The company, which has been operating in Singapore since 2013, aims to build its reputation through exceptional customer service. APACTix will provide ticketing services for the games, marking its first major event. The company's focus on customer satisfaction is expected to contribute to its growth in the Singaporean market.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Support for AIIB grows with six more countries joining China-led bank
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is gaining support with six more countries agreeing to join, bringing the total to 26 potential members. New Zealand, India, Indonesia, and Singapore have already signed a memorandum of understanding, while Australia and South Korea are reportedly close to joining. The AIIB, led by China, has an initial capital of $50 billion and aims to dispense with bureaucracy to speed up projects. Meanwhile, China's Silk Road Fund, a parallel venture, is also moving forward with a $40 billion capital and a market-oriented approach.

site_title: Markets appear to be struggling for direction
summary: Markets appear to be struggling for direction, with stocks closing weaker despite positive news, such as Greece's bailout approval. Investors remain uncertain about how to react to market-moving news, leading to a murky picture for the week ahead. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average reached new highs in February, but bond yields are at record lows, raising concerns about a potential selloff in bond markets. The Singapore stock market is also volatile, with conditions suitable for nimble day traders, but showing signs of improvement, such as increased volume and a shift towards mid and large-cap stocks.

site_title: Seattle targets inequality - on public transit
summary: The King County Metro in Seattle has started a project pricing public transit tickets based on passengers' income, aiming to address inequality. Discounts are offered to households with incomes up to 200% of the federal poverty level, such as $47,700 for a family of four. This move is expected to help low-income commuters afford transportation to work, preventing them from being pushed out of the city due to high costs. The project is being closely watched nationwide for its innovative approach to addressing income inequality.

site_title: Why international mobile rates are stuck in the past
summary: International mobile rates remain high, with US carriers charging up to $20 per megabyte for data roaming, while a gigabyte costs about $10 domestically. Despite advances in wireless technology, carriers have not reduced rates, citing the need for profit. Some carriers, like T-Mobile, offer limited free roaming, but this often includes outdated technology. Europeans and users in other countries with competition and regulation can find more affordable roaming options, while others may opt for cheaper or free alternatives like messaging apps and Wi-Fi calling.

site_title: Australia's gold output at decade high as miners cash in on currency drop
summary: Australia recorded its highest annual gold production in a decade in 2014, with 284 tonnes produced, a 4% increase from 2013. The surge in gold output, driven by lower prices, led to high-grading practices, where producers mine richest deposits to remain profitable. Despite this, mine lives are shortened. Analysts expect the trend to continue, with the Australian dollar's decline and expectations of interest rate cuts supporting gold miners, leading to a nearly 30% increase in the S&P/ASX All Ordinaries Gold index this year.

site_title: Global award, TV drama boost Japanese whisky's golden touch
summary: Japan's whisky demand has surged, with producers struggling to keep up with increased sales. The TV drama "Massan" has contributed to the boom, with over one in five Japanese tuning in to watch the period drama about the establishment of Japan's first whisky distillery. As a result, companies such as Suntory and Nikka Whisky Distilling are limiting shipments and increasing production to meet demand. The industry's growth is attributed to the revival of highballs, a mix of whisky and soda, and the recent awarding of the world's best whisky to Suntory's Yamazaki Single Malt Sherry Cask 2013.

site_title: Where banks pay interest to borrowers and charge depositors
summary: European banks are paying interest to borrowers while charging depositors, with interest rates as low as minus 0.0172%. This phenomenon is a result of the European Central Bank's efforts to revive growth and stoke inflation by printing money and buying government bonds. The move has led to a surge in negative-yielding bonds, with nearly $1.75 trillion of bonds in the eurozone trading at negative yields. Some countries, such as Denmark and Switzerland, have reduced interest rates to minus 0.75% and below zero, respectively. The unusual financial situation has raised concerns about the stability of the economy and potential cash hoarding by large savers.

site_title: HK developer Sun Hung Kai's profit falls 20% amid lower sales
summary: Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd, Hong Kong's second-largest developer, reported a 20% decline in first-half underlying earnings to HK$8.46 billion due to lower home sales. Despite this, the company remains on track to meet its full-year sales target of HK$32 billion. Chairman Raymond Kwok attributed the decline to the residential market's slowdown, particularly for small to medium-sized units. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority introduced measures to cool home prices, but Goldman Sachs Group Inc. remains confident in the company's steady earnings growth for the full year.

site_title: Airbnb valued at US$20b in latest fund raising, say sources
summary: Airbnb is reportedly raising US$1 billion in funding, valuing the company at US$20 billion or more, according to sources. This round of funding would make Airbnb one of the most highly valued private US technology companies, joining companies like Uber and Snapchat. The company, founded in 2008, has listings in over 34,000 cities and has raised more than US$700 million in funding. This influx of capital is helping startups expand operations and staff, with Airbnb joining the ranks of highly valued private companies in the tech industry.

site_title: South Korean exports post worst decline in 2 years
summary: South Korean exports fell 3.4% in February to $41.46 billion, the largest monthly decline in two years, due to weaker sales to Europe and China, lower oil prices, and long holidays. Imports plummeted 19.6% to $33.80 billion, resulting in a record trade surplus of $7.66 billion. The decline was attributed to a Lunar New Year holiday and falling oil product prices. The government expects global demand to show signs of recovery, and the Bank of Korea is expected to hold interest rates steady.

site_title: Kremlin critic wanted to dish the dirt
summary: Thousands of Russians marched in Moscow to honor Kremlin critic Boris Nemtsov, who was shot dead on Friday, amid a deepening split in society. The opposition, led by Gennady Gudkov, called for an end to a "campaign of hate" against them, while Putin vowed to pursue those responsible. National investigators are pursuing several lines of inquiry, including the possibility of radical Islamists or the opposition killing Nemtsov to blacken Putin's name. The murder has widened a split in society, with some fearing it could threaten Russia's future, and opposition leaders warn of mass civil conflict if the authorities do not change their tactics.

site_title: Hyundai recalls almost 205,000 Elantra cars over power steering loss
summary: Hyundai is recalling nearly 205,000 Elantra cars from 2008-2010 due to a power steering issue that can cause the system to stop working, making it harder to turn the vehicle. Although the driver can still steer, it requires greater effort, particularly at low speeds. The recall comes after the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) increased scrutiny on automakers over safety issues, following criticism from Congress over a deadly ignition-switch defect in millions of General Motors vehicles.

site_title: Crackdown on Bangkok street stalls
summary: Bangkok's ruling junta is cracking down on street hawkers, aiming to "reclaim the sidewalks" and "clean up" the city's image. Authorities plan to relocate or restrict touting to night-time areas, affecting thousands of vendors who sell everything from food to sex toys. While some vendors will be allowed to sell in designated zones, many are concerned about the cost of commuting and potential loss of income. Critics argue that the crackdown will disproportionately affect the poor who rely on street vending for their livelihood, and that a broader plan is needed to address vendors' needs.

site_title: Anwar's request for Malaysian royal pardon rejected: report
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdul Halim Mu'adzam Shah has rejected a royal pardon request for opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, who is serving a five-year jail sentence for sodomy. Anwar's lawyers claim they were not informed of the rejection, contradicting a report by The Star newspaper. The decision upholds the nation's highest court's ruling from February 10, which convicted Anwar of sodomising a former aide, a charge he denies. The ruling means Anwar will officially lose his parliamentary seat.

site_title: Ploughing a diversification route
summary: Japfa Limited, a Singapore-based meat and dairy producer, has expanded into China, India, and Myanmar to diversify its business and gain stability. The company's Indonesian operations were impacted by low prices for day-old chicks, resulting in a loss of US$13.9 million in the fourth quarter. However, its animal protein business in other countries, such as Vietnam, India, and China, has contributed to the company's overall growth. Japfa CEO Tan Yong Nang attributes the company's diversification strategy to its success, saying that it has given the company more stability and growth potential.

site_title: Lend Lease to own 30% of joint venture for Paya Lebar Central site
summary: Lend Lease has secured 30% ownership of a joint venture for a 99-year leasehold mixed-use site in Paya Lebar Central, Singapore. The top bid of S$1.67 billion was submitted by entities linked to Lend Lease. The joint venture will be 70% owned by Lend Lease's investment partner. The project will leverage Lend Lease's global capabilities to develop large-scale urban regeneration projects. This deal further solidifies Lend Lease's position in the Singapore market.

site_title: Three held after anti-China protest in HK
summary: In Hong Kong, at least three people were arrested during a protest in Yuen Long against parallel traders, who buy goods to sell at a profit across the border. About 400 protesters clashed with police, blocking main streets and halting traffic. The demonstration was the latest in a series targeting mainland Chinese visitors, fueling calls for Hong Kong nationalism and independence. The protests come nearly three months after police cleared pro-democracy street protests in the city.

site_title: Germany at the centre of twin European crises, but reluctantly
summary: Germany is at the center of European crises over Ukraine and Greece, but Chancellor Angela Merkel's leadership efforts have been met with failure. Despite attempting to revive the Minsk ceasefire deal, Merkel's efforts have been unsuccessful. This comes as Germany struggles with its own role as a reluctant hegemon, uncomfortable with leadership.

site_title: Noble's shock Q4 loss: Why no warning?
summary: Noble Group, a commodities firm, reported a surprise US$240 million loss for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, largely due to an unexpected US$438 million writeoff. The company's lack of a profit warning before the release of a report by short seller Iceberg Research has raised questions about its accounting practices and the effectiveness of its internal controls. Iceberg's criticisms, including a claim that Noble's Australian-listed associate Yancoal should be written down by as much as US$600 million, appear to have some merit, as Noble did take a significant impairment charge for Yancoal. The market is now reevaluating Noble's financials and the company's response to Iceberg's allegations.

site_title: Google backflips on Blogger sexual content ban
summary: Google has reversed its decision to ban sexually explicit content on its Blogger platform after receiving public backlash. The company initially announced the ban, but later decided to step up efforts to enforce its policy barring "commercial porn" instead. The decision was made after a barrage of public comments, with Google prioritizing user feedback.

site_title: China to end two-tier pricing for natural gas from April
summary: China plans to end its two-tier pricing system for natural gas, effective April, in response to an oil market slump. The new pricing scheme aims to track oil prices and introduce more market-oriented elements. The move is part of a broader effort to encourage domestic production, increase imports, and burn cleaner fuel to reduce emissions. This change is expected to have a significant impact on China's energy market, potentially leading to lower prices for non-residential users.

site_title: Greek economy minister sees deal with EU/IMF on reforms next week
summary: Greek Economy Minister George Stathakis expects a deal with EU/IMF on reforms next week, which will unlock remaining bailout funds. Athens has presented a list of proposed reforms, including 1.5 billion euros in revenue from privatisations, to demonstrate financial discipline. The agreement is expected to be finalized before Easter week.

site_title: Lufthansa flight school knew of crash pilot's depression
summary: A German pilot who crashed a plane in the French Alps last week, killing 150 people, had previously told officials at a Lufthansa training school about his severe depression in 2009. The pilot, Andreas Lubitz, broke off his training for several months but passed medical checks, and his condition was noted in emails exchanged with the flight school. Lufthansa has faced criticism over its handling of Lubitz's mental health, with lawyers representing families of victims calling for more regular psychiatric testing of pilots.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: Entrepreneur Chang Meng Kiat hosted a 21st consecutive Chinese New Year dinner for the aged and sick at the Sree Narayana Mission Home, donating over S$1.5 million to the charity. This marks his 21st year of giving back to the community.

site_title: Best Employers show why it pays to engage workers
summary: This year's Aon Hewitt Best Employers award winners in Singapore scored 80% in employee engagement, exceeding the 59% market average, and made 29% higher profits than the market average. The winners include McDonald's Singapore, American Express International, and Microsoft Singapore, with leaders emphasizing the importance of strong leadership, accessibility, and genuine concern for employees. Aon Hewitt's study found that near leaders, who are accessible and enable their people, are key drivers of employee engagement.

site_title: Making Singapore future-ready
summary: The 2015 Singapore Budget focused on enhancing the country's economic growth and competitiveness. Key takeaways for business leaders include increased funding for the Professional Conversion Programme and initiatives to support small and medium-sized enterprises. The budget also introduced a new National Research Fund and a further 5% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate. Additionally, the government committed to investing in infrastructure and public transport, aiming to make Singapore a more attractive location for businesses and talent.

site_title: Blackstone cashes out through Motel 6 CMBS
summary: Blackstone Group has cashed out $626 million of its equity in Motel 6 through a $1.8 billion commercial mortgage-backed security (CMBS) deal. The move comes as investors are willing to finance large real estate operators at low costs. The deal was the second-largest CMBS of the year and included a revised structure with thicker classes of securities. Blackstone has invested $192.1 million in the chain's renovation and plans to roll out a new national marketing campaign this summer. The move has raised questions about Blackstone's end game and the chain's debt burden.

site_title: Business leaders weigh in on Britain's election
summary: Over 100 British business leaders have signed a letter supporting a Conservative-led government ahead of the May 7 general election, citing policies that have supported investment and job creation. The letter, published in the Daily Telegraph, includes signatures from prominent executives such as Bob Dudley of BP and George Weston of Associated British Foods. The move is seen as a boost to Prime Minister David Cameron, who is neck-and-neck with Labour leader Ed Miliband. The executives argue that a change in government would threaten jobs and deter investment, putting the recovery at risk.

site_title: New Internet rules set up industry's next battle
summary: New internet rules in the US and Europe allow telecom and cable groups to prioritize and charge for certain data services, such as driverless cars and medical data, while maintaining the openness of the internet. The rules, known as "specialised services," aim to fund network upgrades and support new industrial uses of the web. However, net neutrality activists warn that this could lead to a two-speed internet system where start-ups are squeezed out by larger companies. The rules have sparked debate and concern among regulators and industry leaders, with some predicting potential court challenges and regulatory uncertainty.

site_title: Eighth straight month of gains for the greenback
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro for the eighth consecutive month, driven by a revised economic growth estimate of 2.2% in the fourth quarter. The Federal Reserve remained "patient" on ending its near-zero interest rate policy, with inflation below its 2% target. Eurozone inflation improved, easing deflation fears, while Greece secured a four-month bailout extension. The European Central Bank is set to provide details on its large-scale asset-purchase programme, expected to ease concerns about Greece's economic stability.

images.alt_text: The US dollar edged higher against the euro last Friday, building on the prior day's sharp rally and closing February with its eighth consecutive month of gains.

site_title: ECB to unveil details of QE programme
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will unveil the details of its quantitative easing (QE) program at its meeting on Thursday in Cyprus, with analysts expecting no new policy measures. The ECB will focus on fleshing out the program, which aims to buy 60 billion euros of private and public bonds each month starting in March until at least September 2016. Greece is also likely to be discussed, with the ECB taking a tough line on the country's bailout program. The meeting will also publish updated growth and inflation forecasts for the euro zone.

site_title: Vivendi plans dividend, share buyback after selling rest of SFR
summary: Vivendi, a French media group, plans to reward shareholders with a 5.7 billion euro dividend and a 2.7 billion euro share buyback after selling its remaining 20% stake in telecoms group SFR to billionaire Patrick Drahi for 3.9 billion euros. The sale follows Vivendi's asset sales strategy to exit telecoms and deploy its war chest on acquisitions. The company aims to maintain its ordinary dividend payout of one euro per share for 2015 and 2016, and plans to use the remaining funds for acquisitions.

site_title: Republicans' audit move set to challenge Fed's independence
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is facing a push from Congress to assert control over monetary policy, with a new "Audit the Fed" bill that could allow lawmakers to examine the central bank's activities. Republicans accuse the Fed of misguided policies and political bias, while Yellen calls it a move to politicize the Fed's work. The bill, led by Senator Rand Paul, aims to audit the Fed's balance sheet, which Yellen says is already fully public and audited. The move has raised concerns about the Fed's independence and the potential for partisanship to influence monetary policy.

site_title: Chinese Wanda Group buy 20% stake in Atletico Madrid
summary: China's Wanda Group acquired a 20% stake in La Liga champions Atletico Madrid for 44.98 million euros, worth US$48.38 million. The deal is part of Wanda's expansion into the global sports business, with plans to set up a football academy in Spain for young Chinese players and tour China with the team. Atletico's recent success, including winning the La Liga title and reaching the Champions League final, has solidified the club's position as a top European team.

site_title: British Airways parent IAG posts 81% surge in 2014 profit
summary: International Airlines Group (IAG), the parent company of British Airways, reported an 81% surge in 2014 profit to €1.39 billion, driven by strong passenger demand on key routes and a turnaround at its Spanish carrier Iberia. The group's operating revenue rose to €20 billion, with Iberia posting an operating profit of €50 million after six years of losses. IAG is seeking to acquire Aer Lingus, and while the Irish government has concerns, the airline's CEO Willie Walsh sees opportunities for expansion.

images.alt_text: Operating profit at British Airways, IAG's largest brand, jumped by nearly 60 per cent to 1.2 billion euros, buoyed by the steady US economic recovery and consolidation in the trans-Atlantic market.

site_title: Future pace of gains at Berkshire won't come close to past: Buffett
summary: Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway CEO, states that future gains won't match past performance over the next 50 years, marking a significant shift in his expectations. This follows his 50-year tenure transforming the company from a failing textile firm into a successful conglomerate. Buffett's new outlook reflects changing market conditions and the increasing difficulty of replicating past successes.

site_title: Matex International to buy China coal mines in a S$475 million reverse takeover
summary: Matex International, a Singapore-listed dye maker, plans to acquire four underground thermal coal mines in Chongqing, China, in a S$475 million reverse takeover. The acquisition, which includes four mines with 100.7 million tonnes of ore reserves, will enable the company to venture into the energy sector. The deal is conditional on shareholder approval and requires a share consolidation. Matex aims to capitalize on China's growing energy demand and the company's manufacturing sector faces rising operational costs.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Inc's foray abroad could add girth to earnings this year
summary: Singaporean companies with global ambitions are expected to boost earnings this year, driven by the government's incentives for outward-oriented sectors and the benefits of global central banks' monetary easing. Outward-oriented sectors have posted productivity growth of over 5% per year on average over the past five years, compared to less than 1% for locally-focused firms. Analysts also expect the Reit sector to perform well due to the extension of tax breaks and the lifting of the CPF salary ceiling.

site_title: Gold jumps in India after govt retains import duty at 10%
summary: India's gold import duty remains unchanged at 10% after the federal budget, leading to a surge in futures prices to a seven-week high. The move was unexpected, with seven out of 10 jewellers and analysts surveyed predicting a tax cut. The government's decision may spur smuggling and increase premium costs for bullion. Despite this, gold demand is expected to rise ahead of the Akshaya Tritiya festival in April. The government plans to monetize gold stockpiles and offer sovereign gold bonds to investors.

site_title: New market barometer measures lunch queues
summary: A team of researchers created the Live Interactive Applied Benchmark Of Queues (LiaboQueue), an alternate market benchmark tracking lunch queues in Singapore's central business district. LiaboQueue aims to provide a more holistic reflection of the market, addressing the perceived bias of the Straits Times Index (STI) towards larger stocks. The benchmark uses sensors to measure queue lengths and compares them to normalized benchmarks. After three months of testing, the results have been positive, and the team is in talks with funds to create investment products linked to LiaboQueue.

site_title: Macau's fortunes dip as New Year gamblers fail to show up
summary: Macau's casino industry faced a significant decline in revenue during the Lunar New Year, with projected losses of 53.5% in February, the longest losing streak since 2005. Middle-income consumers and VIP gamblers, who tend to arrive later, are pulling back amid government crackdowns on graft and money laundering, as well as China's economic slowdown. The decline in casino revenue is also affecting the city's tourism and hospitality industries, with average occupancy and room rates declining. Analysts warn that the Macau government's decision to limit table allocation for new projects could further impact the industry.

site_title: Jadason posts third straight loss, falls into Watch List
summary: Jadason Enterprises reported a third consecutive annual loss of S$8.9 million in 2014, placing it on the Singapore Exchange's Watch List due to a market capitalization below S$40 million. The company's pre-tax loss was S$8.7 million, wider than its 2013 loss. Equipment and supplies sales fell 24% in 2014, while the manufacturing and support services segment saw a higher operational loss. Jadason expects soft demand in the first quarter of 2015. The company has two years to exit the Watch List or face delisting.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Singapore Government has quoted taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds. In the financial sector, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as her successor. MAS and the PBOC also agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close lower on Greece jitters
summary: European stock markets closed lower on Tuesday due to mixed eurozone data and ongoing Greek bailout talks, with London's FTSE 100 tumbling 1.72% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 slumping 0.99%. Eurozone core inflation eased in March, while Germany's unemployment fell to a 1990 low. However, concerns over Greece's debt crisis and potential impact on the global economy persisted. In contrast, shares in Kingfisher rose 4.33% after announcing store closures and dividend payments.

site_title: US: Wall St rebounds from recent losses
summary: US stocks rebounded 1% on Monday, driven by deal activity in healthcare and a surge in energy shares, despite a sharp decline last week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.49% to 17,976.31, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained 1.22% and 1.15% respectively. Chinese stocks surged to seven-year highs, fueled by hopes for infrastructure spending and monetary policy easing. The rebound follows uncertainty about Friday's jobs report and upcoming earnings, which could create volatility this week.

site_title: Nomura to relocate a team of analysts from NICMR Tokyo to S'pore
summary: Nomura is relocating a team of analysts from its Tokyo-based NICMR to its Singapore office, aiming to enhance research capabilities and solidify its position as an Asian-based global financial services group. The move will allow Nomura to conduct research on Asian countries' financial markets and regulatory developments, as well as India and Middle Eastern markets. This is seen as crucial to Nomura's competitive strengths, with the goal of providing in-depth research and analysis to internal and external clients.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Malaysian banks' exposure to troubled 1MDB is credit negative
summary: Malaysian banks' exposure to troubled 1MDB is credit negative, but manageable, according to a Moody's report. The banks' total exposure is around $1.36 billion, relatively small compared to their capital buffers. The government has guaranteed 5.8 billion ringgit of 1MDB's debt, and loans to the company are well collateralized, limiting potential losses. The Moody's report suggests that the exposure does not pose a significant credit risk, but a 950 million ringgit line of credit extended by the Ministry of Finance carries a risk that could undermine fiscal consolidation.

site_title: JES seeks extra month to report results
summary: JES International Holdings, a China-based shipbuilding and engineering company, is seeking an additional month to report its 2014 results and hold its annual general meeting due to issues with its Chinese subsidiaries. The company appointed an independent valuer to assess the subsidiaries' fixed assets, but the report is not yet ready. As a result, JES believes its existing balance sheet may not accurately represent the company's financials. The company is requesting an extension until March 31 to report its results and May 30 to convene its annual general meeting.

site_title: Pakistan aims to be China's newest superhighway to Europe
summary: Pakistan and China plan to announce over 24 deals when President Xi Jinping visits, including a 3,000-kilometer economic corridor from China's Xinjiang to Gwadar, a Chinese-funded port on the Arabian Sea. The corridor will provide China with a strategic economic partner, giving it access to the Indian Ocean and easing power shortages in Pakistan. The move is seen as a shift towards greater economic cooperation between the two countries, with the corridor expected to spur investment and boost trade flows.

site_title: Asian shares mixed as Yemen crisis hits sentiment
summary: Asian shares were mixed on Friday as investors reacted to the escalating crisis in Yemen, with concerns of a wider Middle East conflict. Oil prices dipped after surging the previous day, while the euro struggled to regain its strength. Tokyo, Seoul, and Hong Kong fell, but Sydney and Shanghai rose on hopes of more Chinese stimulus. The US market also declined, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq easing.

site_title: South-east Asian banks at a digital transformation crossroads
summary: South-east Asian banks are at a digital transformation crossroads, with many yet to adopt a holistic approach to embracing digital technologies. Despite enjoying relatively healthy revenue growth, banks' efforts to digitize are hindered by a lack of integration with consumers' digital information. To succeed, banks must leverage physical and digital value chains to create new business models and forge deep relationships with consumers, or risk being left behind in the face of profound changes in the industry.

site_title: Australia's military shipbuilders need overhaul
summary: Australia's military shipbuilding industry needs to cut costs and improve productivity to remain competitive. The country pays 40% more for domestic-built vessels compared to US benchmarks due to inefficiencies. Defence Minister Kevin Andrews aims to buy 40 ships and submarines over the next two decades, with a focus on frigates and submarines. The industry faces a "valley of death" scenario in the 2020s, but a new asset-management model could ensure its sustainability. The government has invited Japan, Germany, and France to bid on a $50 billion submarine construction program.

site_title: JES International's Q4 loss rises to 222.5m yuan
summary: Chinese shipbuilder JES International reported a widened loss of 222.48 million yuan in the fourth quarter of 2014, compared to a loss of 182.28 million yuan in the same period last year. Revenue fell 1.5% to 50.14 million yuan due to production slowdown and contract cancellations. For the full year 2014, the company's loss narrowed to 290.47 million yuan, with revenue plummeting 67.5% to 176.32 million yuan.

site_title: Startups in Singapore kick off new year with a bang
summary: Startups in Singapore kicked off 2015 with significant funding rounds, with at least seven homegrown startups raising millions in the first two months of the year. Property site 99.co raised S$2 million in Series A, while Tembusu Systems secured S$1.2 million in bridge funding. The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced a public consultation paper on securities-based crowdfunding, paving the way for new equity- and lending-based platforms. The government also proposed a 50% risk-sharing program for venture debt, and various startup spaces were inaugurated to drive entrepreneurship. Experts predict a "feverish" year for startups in Singapore, with more large funding rounds and exits expected.

images.alt_text: ACE's Dr Fang says many activities are being planned for the rest of the year to help startups learn and partner global players.

site_title: Microsoft buys Office collaborator app LiveLoop
summary: Microsoft has acquired LiveLoop, an office mobile app that allows real-time collaboration on PowerPoint presentations.
