The app, which is no longer accepting new users, will close on April 24. LiveLoop allows users to share presentations and PDFs online among collaborators, accessible from any mobile device. This purchase follows Microsoft's recent acquisitions of Sunrise and Acompli, as the company aims to reinvent productivity with great collaboration across Office applications.

site_title: HK's Joshua Wong among 'world's greatest leaders': Fortune
summary: Hong Kong's Joshua Wong, 18, was named one of the world's 10 greatest leaders by Fortune magazine, ranking 10th, behind Chinese President Xi Jinping, who was ranked third. Wong, a pro-democracy activist, led mass street blockades in 2014, drawing hundreds of thousands of protesters. Fortune praised Wong's "nonviolent protest message and energetic idealism," contrasting him with Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying, who lost support from 100,000 Hong Kongers over democratic election restrictions. The magazine also highlighted Xi's strong leadership, likening him to reformer Deng Xiaoping.

site_title: Brazil arrests person linked to SembMarine's consultants
summary: Brazilian authorities arrested Guilherme Esteves de Jesus, a person linked to Sembcorp Marine's consultants, on bribery-related claims. The arrest followed allegations made by former Petrobras engineering manager Pedro Jose Barusco, who claimed Esteves was involved in bribery surrounding oil giant Petrobras. Sembcorp Marine has launched an internal investigation and denied any involvement in bribery, stating it has a strict anti-bribery policy. The arrest is part of ongoing allegations of corruption surrounding Petrobras, which has also led to claims involving Keppel Corp.

site_title: US to probe if Nissan failed in air-bag fix
summary: US regulators are investigating whether Nissan's air-bag fix recall failed to resolve a flaw on nearly one million vehicles. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) received 124 complaints about the issue, with some drivers claiming the problem persisted after multiple repairs by dealers. The regulator is looking into the matter, citing concerns over public safety.

site_title: Investors would do well to connect the dot plot with the data
summary: The Federal Reserve's dot plot, which shows policymakers' expectations for short-term interest rates, sparked a rally in Asian markets after its March update. The median expectation for 2015 rates fell to 0.625% from 1.125% in December, but the adjustment is consistent with the US dollar's strengthening and global growth slowdown. Investors should not rely solely on the dot plot, as its track record for predicting interest rates is limited, and policymakers are ready to make changes based on data. The Fed's message of paying attention to data should be heeded by investors.

site_title: Honouring Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Singaporeans are left to ponder how to best honor the legacy of founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, who passed away recently. Experts suggest building on his vision, cultivating a forward-looking mindset, and protecting Singapore's strong fundamentals. Some propose creating a Founding Father's Day, investing in young Singaporeans, and naming public buildings and institutions after him. Others recommend conserving his home as a national monument and renaming streets after him. Ultimately, the best way to honor Lee's spirit is to continue his legacy by striving to be better tomorrow than today and contributing to building a society Singaporeans can be proud of.

site_title: Uber offers free rides in a Lamborghini or Maserati
summary: Uber is offering free rides in a Lamborghini or Maserati in Singapore this weekend, from 10am to 1pm, with 15-minute rides. The service, in partnership with Dream Drive, allows users to choose between a Lamborghini Gallardo Spyder and a Maserati GranTurismo Coupe. After this weekend, the service will be available daily from 10am to 9pm until May 20, with charges starting at S$200 for a 15-minute ride. This is Uber's first two-month supercar promotion globally.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap two-day slide; Novo Nordisk rallies
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Friday, halting a two-day decline, as the euro fell to US$1.0811. The FTSEurofirst 300 index regained 1,584.88 points. Novo Nordisk shares surged 13% after the pharmaceutical firm submitted interim analysis data from its new insulin drug Tresiba to US regulators. The rally follows a six-month increase in European shares as investors bet a weaker euro will boost the region's economy.

site_title: Court okays US$10m Target settlement
summary: A US federal judge approved a $10 million settlement for customers affected by Target's 2013 data breach, which exposed 40 million credit and debit card numbers and 70-110 million personal records. Shoppers may claim up to $10,000 in damages, but must prove unauthorized charges and incurred costs. The settlement also includes measures to bolster customer data protection and address online security threats.

site_title: China to reap Alibaba windfall as tightens up on tax
summary: China is expected to collect billions of dollars in taxes from Alibaba employees who sold shares after a six-month lock-up period expired. The 437 million shares, representing 18% of Alibaba's total shares, were bought prior to the company's IPO and are now being sold. The tax, which is 20% of capital gains, will be collected by the State Administration of Taxation, with the company having registered its stock incentive plan with the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. The tax windfall is a significant step towards China's more rigorous stance on tax collection, despite being a small portion of the country's total fiscal revenue.

site_title: It's the men's world at Tokyo Fashion Week
summary: Tokyo Fashion Week has shifted its focus to men's fashion, showcasing sharp futurism, wool-and-denim casuals, and individuality. The event aims to promote Japanese men's clothes design, which is gaining international attention. Despite limited success overseas, the industry is now backing homegrown brands with the Tokyo Fashion Awards, which chose six menswear-focused brands with international potential. Winners showcased their autumn/winter collections in Tokyo, with designers emphasizing practical appeal and attention to detail. International buyers praise Tokyo's pioneering styles, which are becoming increasingly important as men worldwide take greater interest in dress and grooming.

site_title: A lion among leaders
summary: Singapore sets up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. The centre aims to promote environmentally friendly aviation practices. Additionally, the country is exploring opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. DPM Gan is set to visit the US for trade talks, and a new grant of up to S$100,000 is available for businesses affected by tariffs. The government is also advising graduates to remain calm, as early data suggests better employment rates.

site_title: Nomura swings to hospitality from retail
summary: Nomura upgraded its rating for CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) to "buy" from "neutral" and downgraded CapitaMall Trust (CMT) to "neutral" due to expected stronger hotel sector performance in Singapore from a rise in tourist arrivals to Malaysia. CDLHT's target price is raised to S$1.88, implying a 15.8% potential return. The bank expects visitor arrivals from China to rebound, boosting sentiment for hospitality stocks like CDLHT.

site_title: A pilgrim who sought world order
summary: Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's founding father, was a visionary leader who brought order to a chaotic world. Despite initial doubts, he defied conventional wisdom by opting for statehood, which led to Singapore's remarkable transformation into a prosperous, international financial center. Through his pragmatic approach, he raised the country's per capita income from $500 to $55,000 and established Singapore as a hub for intellectual and medical excellence. A strong believer in responsible leadership, Lee Kuan Yew's legacy continues to inspire, and his friendship with the author serves as a testament to his enduring impact.

site_title: Google calls for more investments in smart phone, broadband networks
summary: Google executive chairman Eric Schmidt emphasizes investing in smartphone and broadband networks as a key target for the next five to ten years. He notes that smartphones rely heavily on high-speed networks, and 98% of Americans now have access to 4G wireless internet, ahead of schedule. Schmidt urges entrepreneurs to invest in broadband infrastructure, suggesting national broadband plans as a solution to create jobs.

site_title: Food renaissance
summary: Celebrity chefs Daniel Humm and Will Guidara of Eleven Madison Park and Nomad in New York share their vision for redefining fine dining. They aim to create a comfortable, luxurious atmosphere where guests can enjoy exceptional food without feeling stuffy. The duo's success is attributed to their dedication to quality, staff, and guests, and their willingness to take risks. In contrast, Peruvian chef Gaston Acurio is using his influence to promote sustainable and locally sourced food, while also championing the country's rich culinary heritage. Meanwhile, French chef Yannick Alleno is reclaiming French cuisine's historical significance and advocating for its continued relevance.

site_title: Househunt 2015
summary: A low-profile property trust, Unithrust Global, has launched a data centre, showcasing a unique investment strategy. US weekly jobless claims have fallen unexpectedly. China has urged South-east Asian countries to back openness amid looming US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, owned by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China has unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Shanghai aims to launch new board for emerging industry companies
summary: Shanghai Stock Exchange plans to launch a new board for emerging industry companies, with a higher threshold for listing candidates. The proposal, submitted to China's securities regulator, aims to attract more smaller, high-growth start-ups. Unlike Shenzhen's ChiNext, Shanghai's new board would set stricter financial conditions and market capitalization requirements. This move is expected to shift the focus from large, blue-chip companies currently listed in Shanghai.

site_title: Ruling the regulatory kitchen
summary: US Commodity Futures Trading Commission Chairman Tim Massad believes that the final product, whether food or rules, must serve its intended purpose well. He emphasizes the importance of flavor and functionality, stating that if a product doesn't meet its purpose, it's not worth it. Massad's approach to cooking and regulation is centered on achieving a desired outcome, rather than focusing solely on technique. This philosophy is reflected in his work at the CFTC, where he oversees the regulation of the financial markets.

site_title: Shareholder capitalism on trial
summary: Shareholder capitalism is under scrutiny for prioritizing executive compensation and shareholder payouts over investment in new factories, products, and research. Critics argue that companies are returning too much money to shareholders through dividends and stock repurchases, hindering economic growth. However, experts argue that this criticism is built on selective evidence, with weak investment spending largely due to a lack of profitable opportunities in a post-Great Recession economy. Companies have more cash than ever, and investment funds are being redirected to fast-growing sectors, suggesting that shareholder capitalism is not the problem, but rather the lingering effects of the financial crisis.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's determination made Singapore into dynamic city it is today: Malaysia PM
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak paid tribute to late Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, calling him responsible for developing Singapore into a dynamic city. Najib praised Lee's determination and legacy, expressing commitment to the future of the relationship between the two nations. Najib also expressed condolences to Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and family.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak said Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, who died early Monday morning, was responsible for developing Singapore into the dynamic city it is today.

site_title: BlackRock holds 2.6% of KepLand's total issued shares after Tuesday's share dealing
summary: BlackRock sold 62,100 Keppel Land shares on Tuesday at S$4.56 each, reducing its stake to 2.6% of total issued shares. Following the sale, BlackRock holds 40.8 million shares. Keppel Corp, BlackRock's associate, still owns 86.2% of KepLand, with the offer closing date extended to March 26.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble surges and leads the actives as takeover rumours swirl
summary: Noble Group's share price surged 7.06% to S$0.91 after a Reuters report hinted at potential takeover talks. The company's market value has declined by US$1.8 billion since Iceberg Research accused it of inflating asset values. Chinese and Japanese companies have held informal talks with investment banks about approaching Noble, but no active discussions are underway. Recent purchases by fund houses, including Prudential's S$4.1 million investment, have also boosted the stock.

site_title: Update: Germanwings Airbus crashes in France, 148 feared dead
summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in southern France, killing all 148 on board, according to French President Francois Hollande. The flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf took off at 0855 GMT and crashed near the town of Barcelonnette. The 24-year-old aircraft, operated by Lufthansa's budget airline, was heading into a remote and inaccessible area. French accident investigators are at the scene to assess the situation. There are no reported survivors, and officials suspect a significant number of Germans were on board.

images.alt_text: An Airbus operated by Lufthansa's Germanwings budget airline crashed in a remote area of southern France on Tuesday and all 148 on board were feared dead.

site_title: The history driven consultant
summary: AT Kearney chairman Johan Aurik is working to keep his organization's legacy alive by adopting principles from the firm's founder, Andrew Thomas Kearney, in his efforts to future-proof the company. Aurik discovered a 1961 staff memo penned by Kearney, which outlined core values that have guided the firm since its inception. He ensures every new employee receives a copy of the memo, which contains the concept of "essential rightness" - providing real value for clients beyond conventional reports. Aurik has successfully applied this philosophy to several projects, including the "Alle" grocery chain in Ethiopia, which has shown significant growth. He has set an ambitious growth program, "Vision 2020," to almost double the firm's revenues by the end of the decade, and has adopted several principles to future-proof the company, including involving the entire organization in implementing strategies and adopting a "future-in" approach.

site_title: Evergrande gets 100b yuan in credit lines
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd has obtained 100 billion yuan (S$22.6 billion) in credit lines from four Chinese banks in the past two months amid declining sales and financial strain. The developer's cash and near-cash items fell to 36.2 billion yuan as of June 30, 2014, while accounts payable rose to 75.2 billion yuan. Despite targeting contract sales of 150 billion yuan this year, Evergrande's financial health raises concern about the Chinese property industry's overall financial health.

site_title: Quick Takes: Singapore NODX disappoints in February
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 9.7% year-on-year in February, the third consecutive month of declines, due to contractions in electronic and non-electronic exports. Private-sector economists attributed the poor performance to weak demand from key markets such as China, Japan, and Taiwan. The NODX growth rate fell to -2.4% year-on-year, with average January and February levels 2.8% below Q4 2014. Despite this, economists maintained their 2015 GDP growth forecast at 2.7%, citing soft but not collapsing manufacturing activity.

site_title: Singapore: STI up 16.70 points ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 16.70 points to 3,392.74 ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, driven by gains in US stocks. Top gainers included DBS, UOB, and Singapore Exchange. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines dropped seven Singapore cents to S$11.96 after discussing a potential stake in South Korea's Jeju Air.

site_title: Constructing Singapore
summary: JPN Industrial Trading, a Singapore-based construction machinery company, has been a key player in building Singapore's iconic developments since its founding in 1988 by three brothers. The company's expertise in providing construction machinery and equipment helped it expand to Malaysia and Indonesia. Despite facing the Asian financial crisis and labor shortages, JPN thrived and diversified its business by launching its own construction machinery brand, McWel, and expanding into aerial work platforms. Today, the company operates from a 33,000 square meter facility and has a strong presence in the regional construction industry.

site_title: H&M posts another month of strong sales growth
summary: H&M reported a 15% sales rise in February, its fifth straight month of double-digit growth, exceeding analyst forecasts of a 13% increase. The Swedish budget fashion retailer's net sales in December-February rose 25% to $4.6 billion, driven by the weak Swedish crown. H&M's shares rose 2.1% following the report, outperforming the European retail sector. The company is investing in e-commerce and new concepts to protect margins as discount chains push prices down. H&M plans to open 400 new stores this fiscal year, bringing its total to 3,551 stores.

site_title: When negative yields are fine
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has started its quantitative easing (QE) program, but bond yields in the eurozone are unlikely to follow the US example and rise sharply. Two differences between the ECB's QE and the 2008 Fed QE make it less likely for yields to increase quickly, including smaller budget deficits in the eurozone and a narrower spectrum of assets for investors. Instead, yields at the shorter end of the curve are likely to remain low, while those at the longer end may rise modestly later this year. The absolute low for interest rates is estimated to be around -2%.

site_title: Oil drops on ample supply, Iran nuclear talks
summary: Brent crude oil fell to around $53 a barrel on Monday, its lowest in over a month, due to rising global inventories and a possible nuclear deal with Iran that could allow more oil exports. Western powers are hoping for concessions from Tehran to clinch an agreement in nuclear talks this week. Oil inventories are rising at a rate of 1.6 million barrels per day, with forecasts indicating a further acceleration in the second quarter. A deal with Iran would exacerbate Opec oversupply and negatively impact oil markets.

site_title: Hong Kong retailers forecast to post slowest growth in four years
summary: Hong Kong retailers forecast to post the slowest growth in four years due to a drop in mainland Chinese visitors, who have been deterred by rising hostility and anti-China sentiment. Sales in January were the lowest since 2003, and combined revenue growth is expected to be 7.5% this fiscal year, the slowest pace in four years. The decline is attributed to China's anti-corruption crackdown and the weak yen drawing tourists to other destinations.

site_title: Global, local themes explored in NUS fest
summary: The NUS Arts Festival featured performances by local and international choreographers, exploring global and Singapore-specific themes. Choreographers Ricky Hu from Hong Kong Ballet and Chen Wu-Kang from Taiwan tackled issues of smartphone addiction and a social issue inspired by a play, respectively. The festival's Overdrive II series continues the university's collaboration with foreign choreographers to foster the growth of contemporary dance in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance president awarded AustCham medal
summary: Hong Leong Finance president Ian Macdonald has been awarded the AustCham President's Medal 2015 for his contributions to Singapore-Australia business and trade relations. Macdonald, an Australian with over 10 years of experience in Singapore, has served as HLF president since 2002. His achievement highlights the strong ties between Singapore and Australia in the business and trade sectors.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: An Exakt science
summary: Ivor Tiefenbrun, founder of Scottish high-end audio firm Linn, disagrees with the notion that vinyl is making a comeback. He believes digital streaming is the future of music, citing the improved sound quality of 16-bit and 24-bit streams. Linn's Exakt system, which provides tailored signals to each speaker, is a key example of this technology. Tiefenbrun emphasizes the importance of the source in a system, and notes that his company's focus on this aspect has led to significant advancements in sound quality.

site_title: Low wages, high dollar test Fed's patience
summary: The Federal Reserve is set to meet and consider raising interest rates for the first time in nearly six years, with Chair Janet Yellen signaling that the Fed can be patient before making a decision. Analysts expect a midyear rate hike, citing strong economic growth and low unemployment, but doubts remain due to weak inflation and wage growth. The dollar's 20% rise against major currencies since last year has also raised concerns about US competitiveness. A decision to raise rates could have significant market implications and may be delayed until a clearer picture of the economy emerges.

site_title: SPH invests S$2m in data analysis firm for 20% stake
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has invested S$2 million in data analysis firm DC Frontiers, which owns the Handshakes app, in exchange for a 20% stake. Handshakes uses social network analysis to reveal associations between individuals in the capital markets, providing transparency and automating a time-consuming task. The firm, co-founded by two former SGX regulators, has grown to cover Singapore, Malaysia, and Hong Kong, with a subscription-based model and consulting services. The investment values DC Frontiers at S$10 million, with plans to expand coverage to the rest of Asia and mine data from alternative sources.

site_title: Dollar pulls back after tepid US data
summary: The US dollar weakened broadly after tepid US data, supporting the view that the Federal Reserve may delay interest rate hikes. Manufacturing data showed a 0.1% rise in industrial production, while homebuilder sentiment and regional manufacturing were weaker than expected. Market expectations are that the Fed will remove "patient" language regarding interest rate hikes, potentially pushing the decision to later than June. The dollar pulled back from a 12-year high against the euro, and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's press conference and economic forecasts will provide further insight.

site_title: India seeks edge over China as Modi visits Sri Lanka
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi visited Sri Lanka, marking the first bilateral visit by an Indian premier in 28 years. The visit aimed to counter China's growing influence in the region, particularly after a $1.4 billion Chinese real estate project was halted due to criticism from India. Modi pledged $318 million in railway credit, $1.5 billion in currency swap, and support for Sri Lanka's Tamil minority, while also emphasizing India's growing role in the Indian Ocean. The visit highlighted India's efforts to strengthen its ties with Sri Lanka and counter China's expanding presence in the region.

site_title: Singapore less travelled
summary: Multinational businesses are redefining Singapore's identity through new perspectives, rather than solely focusing on the country's success story. US ice-cream maker Ben & Jerry's is launching "Diverse-City" trails in Little India, Toa Payoh, and Jalan Besar, aiming to engage the public on a deeper level about current affairs with deliberately vague descriptions. This approach seeks to challenge the status quo and provide a fresh view of the city-state.

site_title: Light up the world
summary: Rotary International President Gary Huang emphasizes the organization's mission to "light up the world" by highlighting the impact of its global service projects. Founded in 1905, Rotary has grown to 1.2 million members across 260 countries, with 34,000 clubs worldwide. Under Huang's leadership, the organization has achieved significant successes, including the near eradication of polio, with only 419 cases reported in 2014. Rotary also supports literacy and environmental projects, often involving international collaborations. With a focus on inspiring new members, Huang encourages family involvement and has even joined his own family in Rotary.

site_title: Turkey eyes pious to boost Islamic finance
summary: Turkey is pushing ahead with plans to boost Islamic finance, with two state-run banks, Halkbank and Ziraat Bank, set to launch Islamic units this year. The move aims to capitalize on the lack of bank accounts among the pious due to Islamic prohibition on interest, with the government seeking to double Islamic finance assets to $100 billion by 2023. The expansion is part of President Erdogan's efforts to promote his Islamist agenda and attract foreign investment.

site_title: Singapore: STI down 0.46%, trips on bumpy Wall Street
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.46% to 3,382.65 points on Wednesday, impacted by a bumpy Wall Street that dropped due to renewed fears of an early interest rate hike. The trading session saw 123.4 million shares worth S$119.1 million traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 117 to 43.

site_title: Investors wary of impact of coming Fed hike on portfolios
summary: Investors are cautious about the impact of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike on their portfolios, instead seeking returns in growth stocks and Asian markets. Despite concerns, some experts believe a moderate interest rate hike could be beneficial for the US economy, with a stronger economy and low inflationary pressures. Asian markets, such as China and Japan, are seen as attractive investment opportunities, with potential for positive surprises and growth in sectors like technology, consumer goods, and healthcare. However, investors are also wary of the risks of central bank actions destabilizing markets and currency volatility.

site_title: Singapore Budget Debate: Housing, ministerial pay and sectoral boosts
summary: Singapore's budget debate focused on housing, ministerial pay, and sectoral boosts. Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan expressed a desire for a "soft landing" for the housing market, with some suggestions to adjust the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty. The government aims to balance economic growth and market stability. Key points include a boost in sectoral investments, increased ministerial pay, and a focus on the housing market's transition. The government will be cautious in its approach to address concerns and maintain economic stability.

images.alt_text: Members of Parliament debated a wide-ranging set of issues on Tuesday, as they heard from the Ministry of Communications and Information, the Prime Minister's Office, the Ministry of Law and the Ministry of National Development.

site_title: Singapore fostering commodity trade as clearing houses expand
summary: Singapore is expanding its commodity trading capabilities as clearing houses in the city-state grow. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will work with exchanges, investors, and producers to support the development of Singapore as a trading center. The expansion aims to boost liquidity and encourage product development, particularly in derivatives markets. Singapore's strategic location near major sea lanes and its existing commodity trading infrastructure make it an attractive location for clearing houses, with ICE and Deutsche Boerse planning to establish operations in the city.

site_title: Euro sinks to 12-year low as QE bites
summary: The euro has plummeted to a 12-year low against the dollar, trading at US$1.0638, amid the European Central Bank's massive asset-buying program, which has flooded the eurozone with liquidity. The euro has lost 12% of its value in 2015 and 25% since May, with yields on eurozone debt reaching record lows. Uncertainty over Greece's economic future and potential exit from the eurozone also contribute to the decline. The dollar has reached an 11.5-year high against a basket of major currencies.

site_title: Chinese commodities imports slow as Lunar New Year holiday cools trade
summary: China's commodity imports slowed in February due to the Lunar New Year holiday, with copper imports falling 32% and iron ore imports declining 9.5%. Oil imports also slowed, while exports of aluminum and steel fell for the first time in months. Despite the slowdown, total exports gained 48% from a year earlier, driven by a US economy recovery. China's trade surplus reached a record $60.6 billion, and the country's economic growth target for this year is set at 7%, the lowest in over 15 years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 5.78 points to 1783.95. The market saw a higher volume of 130.44 million lots worth RM42.05 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 265 to 55.

site_title: UK's Crufts plays down 'rumours' of five more dog poisonings
summary: The UK's Crufts dog show has played down reports of suspected dog poisonings, following the death of a prize-winning Irish setter, Thendara Satisfaction, who died after returning to Belgium. Rumors of up to five dogs being poisoned at the event have surfaced, but an event spokeswoman has stated that these are just rumors with no evidence to support them. No vets at the event raised concerns, and no official complaints have been filed. The Kennel Club has promised severe disciplinary action for anyone caught sabotaging a competitor.

site_title: China Crest advert looses its sparkle with US$1m fine
summary: China's Shanghai Administration of Industry and Commerce fined US consumer goods giant Procter & Gamble nearly US$1 million for "false advertising" over claims its Crest toothpaste can whiten teeth. The fine, 6.03 million yuan (S$1.36m), was over a television ad featuring a popular Taiwan talk show host whose teeth were digitally enhanced to appear whiter. Procter & Gamble defended its products, stating the toothpaste can effectively remove external stains and whiten teeth with proper use. This fine is China's largest ever in a false advertising case.

site_title: Malaysia's 2015 IPOs, private debt securities seen raising over RM90b
summary: Malaysia's capital markets are expected to raise over RM90 billion this year from initial public offerings (IPOs) and private debt securities. This is the third consecutive year the country's capital markets have exceeded RM90 billion. Edra Global Energy Bhd, a power unit of 1MDB, plans to raise US$3 billion from its IPO, but its parent agency faces criticism due to financial health woes and allegations of mismanagement. The Securities Commission is prioritizing cyber attack prevention and has seen significant growth in the Islamic capital market, expanding to RM1.59 trillion last year.

site_title: London financial sector jobs jump 17% in Feb: study
summary: London's financial sector jobs surged 17% in February, with 3,010 new positions created, compared to 2,580 in the same month in 2014. Strong global equity markets and improving economic sentiment drove hiring, despite British banks cutting headcount. This rebound follows subdued hiring in January, according to data from financial services recruiter Astbury Marsden.

site_title: New activist investors shake up corporate America
summary: Activist investors are shaking up corporate America, seeking billions of dollars in available capital and inspired by notable figures like William Ackman and Carl Icahn. New entrants risk being dismissed if they lack good ideas or firepower, but the surge could lead to costly battles with shareholders over leadership, spinoffs, and buybacks. According to Damien Park, head of Hedge Fund Solutions, "Everyone wants to be an activist these days. Everyone wants that capital." This shift could lead to significant changes in corporate America.

site_title: Honda mounts ad blitz to urge repair of Takata airbags
summary: Honda is launching a nationwide advertising campaign to urge US owners to repair recalled vehicles with defective Takata airbags. The company will spend millions on print, digital, and radio ads, focusing on regions at high risk due to humidity levels. The campaign aims to save lives and prevent injuries, with a goal of increasing repair completion rates. About one-third of recalled vehicles in the US are not repaired, with older model vehicles more prone to this issue. Honda has recalled 20 million vehicles for the fix.

site_title: In brief
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) will remain unchanged following its quarterly review. Companies on the reserve list, including Keppel Land and UOL Group, will replace ineligible constituents before the next review. Pteris Global plans to sell its 30% stake in Shenzhen CIMC-Tianda Airport Support Ltd for S$54.8 million. Meanwhile, OCBC has announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.75% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.75% in opening trade on Monday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to a strong US jobs report, which increased expectations of an early Federal Reserve interest rate rise. The benchmark Hang Seng Index dropped 181.50 points to 23,982.50.

site_title: 1MDB to submit IPO plan for energy unit
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), a state investment company, plans to submit an initial public offering application for its Edra Energy Bhd unit by May, seeking to raise up to $3 billion. The move is part of a strategy to dismantle its assets and wind down the company, amid criticism over rising borrowings. The company has drawn scrutiny for its borrowings totaling $15.8 billion, and its energy unit will not include a recent coal-fired power plant project due to lower potential returns.

site_title: Hit by low prices, US drillers keep oil underground
summary: US oil drillers are keeping crude oil underground, defying production, due to low prices. Over 3,000 wells remain unfracked, with drillers waiting for prices to rebound. This "contango storage play" allows traders to buy cheap oil in oversupplied markets and lock in profits at higher future prices. The move could delay a recovery by attracting more supply, and may also extend the oil slump. Drillers are expected to delay completions, which could impact US crude output and delay a rebound in prices.

site_title: Citigroup to sell stake in Turkey's Akbank before lock-up
summary: Citigroup is selling its 9.9% stake in Turkey's Akbank TAS, the country's second-largest bank by market value, for approximately $1.15 billion. The sale comes after Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat streamlines the US lender, with proceeds from the sale to be used to focus on core businesses. The sale marks the end of a three-year lockup agreement with Akbank's owner, Haci Omer Sabanci Holding AS, allowing the bank to continue serving corporate and commercial clients in Turkey with around 500 employees.

site_title: From beans to business (Amended)
summary: Andreas Jacobs, chairman of Barry Callebaut, shares his experiences of transforming from an aimless youth to a successful business leader. His time at Insead graduate business school had a profound impact, exposing him to smart and ambitious individuals from diverse backgrounds. Jacobs now advocates for graduate business education, citing its value in creating creativity and understanding of different cultures. As chairman of Insead, he plans to focus on funding and improving the school's facilities. Jacobs also oversees the transformation of Barry Callebaut, the largest chocolate processor in the world, into a global leader. He warns that the industry faces a cocoa shortage by 2020 and is working to improve farming practices and education.

site_title: Turning passion into profit
summary:
Three individuals share their passion turned into profit: 

Nicolas Foo, a 39-year-old Lego Certified Professional, creates intricate Lego structures on private and corporate commissions. 

Garry Huang, a 33-year-old drone racer and customizer, co-founded local company Drone Matters to import and customize drones for customers, generating S$1 million in annual revenue. 

Neo Say Wee, a 38-year-old homebrewer, turned his hobby into a business, selling home-brewing kits and classes, and now partners with Five & Dime's Hsu Chen Kang. 

Jessica Cheam, a 32-year-old eco-warrior, founded Eco-Business, a media company dealing with clean technology and sustainable business matters, with an average revenue growth of 85% per year.

site_title: Gold above US$1,200/oz on softer dollar, US rate outlook caps gains
summary: Gold prices steadied at US$1,206.03/oz on Tuesday, rebounding from early losses that briefly fell below US$1,200/oz due to a softer dollar. The US rate outlook capped gains, with expectations of a rate hike limiting bullion's gains in the short term. Markets will watch Friday's US non-farm payrolls numbers and the European Central Bank's money-printing announcement for further direction.

site_title: Temasek faces new normal as Singapore eyes funds
summary: Singapore's government has approved the inclusion of Temasek Holdings' capital gains in its annual budget, forcing the state-owned investment company to allocate more funds to the government. This change will require Temasek to hold more liquid assets and settle for lower returns, potentially affecting its performance. The move comes as Singapore faces budget deficits and increases in social security costs, with the government aiming to support an aging population.

site_title: South Korea finance minister voices deflation fears: report
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Choi Kyung-Hwan expressed concerns about deflation, citing a prolonged period of low inflation and the impact of falling crude oil prices. Inflation in February reached its lowest level in over 15 years, at 0.5%, due in part to record-low interest rates. The government hopes the central bank will consider a further interest rate cut to boost domestic consumption. Choi referenced Japan's "Lost Decade" and urged caution to avoid a deflationary trap, while maintaining expansionary fiscal policies to support the economy.

site_title: ECB uncomfortable with leading role in Greek funding drama
summary: European Central Bank policymakers are grappling with the possibility of holding the key to Greece's continued membership in the eurozone, as the country faces a looming funding crunch. The ECB has veto power over lifting a 15 billion euro cap on Athens' issuance of Treasury bills, but is prohibited from financing the Greek government directly. Despite efforts to avoid playing a decisive role, eurozone central bankers are growing impatient with Athens and its reliance on central bank funding, with some advocating for restricting this financing.

site_title: Draghi touch is golden for stocks as Europe gets US$11 billion
summary: European stocks are considered a bargain compared to bonds, with corporate profits picking up and yields already negative in some countries. The Euro Stoxx 50 Index has jumped 14% in 2015, its best start to a year ever, and investors have poured $11 billion into European share funds in the past two weeks. Analysts, including JPMorgan's Kerry Craig and HSBC's Fredrik Nerbrand, attribute the surge to Mario Draghi's ECB policies and improved economic growth prospects. The Fed model, a valuation metric, suggests European stocks are undervalued relative to bonds, with estimated profits as a proportion of share prices reaching 6.4%.

site_title: Large Google investor cuts stake amid shift to cheaper searches
summary: A large Google investor, Fidelity Contrafund, has cut its stake in the company by nearly 29% due to concerns over the shift to cheaper searches on mobile phones. As of January 31, Fidelity's exposure to Google decreased to 5.2% of net assets, down from 7.3% as of June 30. Fidelity portfolio manager Will Danoff stated that while Google remains innovative, it is fighting a shift away from desktop search to mobile searches.

site_title: Confusion over whether MH370 hunt may end
summary: Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Warren Truss sparked confusion over whether the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 will continue, stating that a decision to abandon the hunt may be made within weeks. However, his office later denied plans to call off the search. The search for the Boeing 777, which vanished a year ago, is nearing its end, with specialists believing the plane's most likely resting place may be found by May. Discussions are underway about the search, including the possibility of continuing or ending it, with the families of the 239 passengers and crew seeking closure.

site_title: China trading surge helped fuel 2014 global stock rally: WFE
summary: China's surge in trading volume in 2014, particularly in the fourth quarter, led to a global stock rally. The value of equity trading rose 17.4% globally to $81 trillion, with Asia-Pacific trading volumes up 18.9% and China's markets reaching a five-year high, up over 50%. Europe and the Americas also saw significant increases in trading volumes, driven by volatility and improving economic data. This led to a 24.3% increase in initial public offerings and a boost in investor demand for financing and risk transfer.

site_title: Noble versus the Iceberg
summary: US President Donald Trump announces fresh tariffs on Canada and threatens others, causing gold prices to rise. Oil prices fall due to bearish expectations of Trump's tariffs. China's solar stocks surge as Beijing intervenes to calm price wars. OPEC announces a reduction in oil demand for the next four years. Meanwhile, Indonesian tycoons are investing heavily in the country's aluminum industry, transforming it into a major player.

site_title: Apple car rumours fuel Geneva debate about car of future
summary: Apple's rumored involvement in building a car has sparked debate at the Geneva car show, with established automakers wondering if they are still in pole position to build the car of the future. Technology companies and automakers are racing to control the "brain" of next-generation vehicles, with Apple's size and innovative capabilities intimidating car executives. Many automakers are investing heavily to position themselves as high-tech companies, with some, like Daimler and BMW, touting services like MercedesMe and ConnectedDrive. The convergence between carmakers and technology companies is changing the industry landscape.

site_title: China February HSBC PMI at 7-month high but deflation risk persists
summary: China's February HSBC PMI reached a seven-month high of 50.7, indicating improved factory sector activity, but deflationary pressures persisted, with new export orders shrinking and input and output prices falling for a seventh month. The economy's momentum slows, and policymakers may need more policy support to address economic fragility. China's central bank cut interest rates last weekend, and the country's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers to address the economic challenges.

site_title: HK runners conquer boredom in city ultra
summary: Hong Kong's first innercity ultramarathon, the Rotary HK Ultramarathon, was held on Sunday with 300 runners competing in a 50-kilometre flat road course. Despite criticism of the course's monotony, participants found it challenging and mentally demanding. Young star Nestor Wong won the event in 3 hours 24 minutes and 20 seconds. The race was seen as a success, with organizers hoping to extend the distance and attract overseas competitors next year, and marking a growing trend in ultra-running in Hong Kong.

site_title: Takata to double replacement airbag output
summary: Takata, a Japanese auto supplier, plans to double its production of replacement airbags to 900,000 per month in response to a global safety recall affecting 20 million vehicles due to defective airbags linked to at least five fatalities. The company has increased its current production of 450,000 replacement kits per month. This move aims to support automotive recalls and safety campaigns.

site_title: Huawei in patent race ahead of 5G era
summary: Huawei, the world's second-largest network gear maker, is expanding its patent portfolio ahead of the 5G era, with CEO Ken Hu stating that 5G research spending will likely rise. The company, which has already spent $600 million on 5G research from 2013 to 2018, was granted 493 patents by the European Patent Office in 2014. Huawei aims to strengthen its intellectual property position, which is crucial for future patent cross-licensing negotiations. The company is urging cooperation among telecom operators and equipment makers to agree on a single set of standards for 5G technology.

images.alt_text: Mr Hu has urged cooperation among telecom operators, equipment makers and other industries to agree on a single set of standards for 5G technology to ensure a global market.

site_title: Moving left? Let's set the context right
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 has been seen as a step to the left, with efforts to mitigate inequality and redistribute wealth. However, lawmakers have expressed concerns about rapid public expenditure growth and the potential for a welfare state. Despite rising social spending, Singapore's social expenditure as a percentage of GDP remains lower than in most OECD countries. The government has funded its deficit through accumulated surpluses, not past reserves, and is subject to fiscal prudence guidelines. Critics argue that MPs have failed to put things into context, failing to compare Singapore's spending to that of other countries and considering its past reserves.

images.alt_text: You'd think everyone were a Beyoncé fan, the way lawmakers have been saying "to the left, to the left" in Parliament.

site_title: Luxury homes hardest hit but price dip could moderate this year
summary: Singapore's luxury home market saw significant price drops in 2014, with prices of luxury homes above S$2,800 per square foot falling 17% from S$2,950 psf to S$2,450 psf. However, analysts expect a moderation in price declines this year, with buying interest recovering and innovative sales schemes replacing price slashing. The resale market for luxury homes held up better, with a 6.2% fall in average price. Property consultants anticipate a better value proposition for luxury homes, driven by a faster pace in reduction of unsold inventory and a potential easing of regulations.

site_title: Thai developer LPN sees condo market slowing in 2015
summary: Thai developer LPN Development PCL warns of a slowing condo market in 2015 due to weak domestic demand and bank restrictions on lending to home buyers. The company missed its revenue target last year and expects to post revenue growth despite a high backlog of condominium projects. LPN plans to launch 11 new projects this year, maintaining its revenue target of 16 billion baht for 2015. Rising household debt and a 15% rejection rate for loans contribute to the market downturn.

site_title: McDonald's to cut back on chicken fed with antibiotics
summary: McDonald's plans to stop serving chicken raised with antibiotics crucial to human health, as the World Health Organisation identifies them as "critically important antimicrobials." The company will work with poultry farmers to halt their use and instead source chicken raised without these antibiotics. McDonald's aims to implement the changes at its 14,000 US restaurants over the next two years, following a growing trend of health-conscious consumers seeking healthier food options.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental's 2014 revenue, earnings edge up; announces US$316m rights issue
summary: Mandarin Oriental reported a 1% increase in net profit to US$97 million for 2014, with revenue rising 2% to US$1.39 billion. Despite challenging markets, the hotel group's performance was impacted by demonstrations in Hong Kong and political uncertainty in Bangkok. The company announced a US$316 million rights issue to retire debt, reduce gearing, and finance renovations. A final dividend of seven US cents per share was recommended, unchanged from 2013. The issue price represents a 28.4% discount to the closing price on March 4, 2015.

images.alt_text: MANDARIN Oriental on Thursday reported a net profit of US$97 million for 2014, up one per cent from the US$96.3 million it made a year ago. Revenue rose 2 per cent to US$1.39 billion.

site_title: Euro hits 11-year low, stocks climb after ECB
summary: The euro fell to an 11-year low against the dollar at $1.0988 after the European Central Bank announced a 1.1-trillion-euro bond buying program starting next week. The decision boosted stocks, with the FTSE 100 index rising 0.61% and other European indices also climbing. The ECB also raised its growth forecast for the eurozone to 1.5% in 2015 and 2.1% in 2017. US stocks opened higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.17%, as investors await the impact of the ECB's bond buying program.

images.alt_text: The euro slumped to an 11-year-low against the dollar and stocks finished up on Thursday after the European Central Bank said it will begin a 1.1-trillion-euro bond buying programme next week.

site_title: Loss-making Areva bets on cost cuts, EDF partnership, China
summary: French nuclear group Areva plans to cut 1 billion euros of costs, boost its partnership with EDF, and expand in China to turn around its loss-making business. Areva's 2014 net loss was 4.83 billion euros, mainly due to charges related to its Olkiluoto 3 project and Uramin uranium mine. The company aims for 1 billion euros of annual cost savings by 2017 and targets positive operating cash flow by 2017 and net cash flow by 2018.

images.alt_text: French nuclear group Areva pledged to cut 1 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of costs, boost its partnership with utility EDF and expand in China in an attempt to turn around the loss-making, state-controlled company.

summary:

Newly registered companies with issued capital between $200,000 and $5 million were listed in SME Magazine. Businesses are rebranding heritage, modernizing traditional snacks, and seeking compensation for using outdoor areas, amidst economic and business trends in Singapore.

site_title: Triyards wins deals worth over US$100m
summary: Triyards Holdings secured deals worth over US$100 million for two ice-class multi-purpose support vessels and a turret fabrication project. The contracts were signed with Ocean Energy Ventures and London Marine Consultants, respectively. This follows a US$75.4 million win for two liftboat contracts in January, adding almost US$180 million in new orders for the company. Triyards' CEO Chan Eng Yew stated the company remains committed to growing its reputation as a vessel builder and equipment provider.
